column2: Three men and two companies pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of defrauding the public in the sale of safflower oil diet pills with the book "Calories Don't Count."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 18 -- Dr. Allen Krebs an avowed Marxist-Socialist who was dismissed by Adelphi University for alleged teaching deficiencies was offered reinstatement by the university today for one semester.

Operation of Long Island Rail Road trains over city subway tracks to a terminal in downtown Manhattan would usher in a new era of mass transit in the metropolitan area. It would be the pioneer step toward ultimate integration of the city's rapid transit lines with the commuter railroads.
New York City lost its only customer yesterday for $63.9 million in bonds that were to be the first sold under its $255.8 million "borrow now, pay later" program of budget-balancing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Luci Baines Johnson cleared up a mystery today. She is not engaged.

DONORS to the annual auction for the benefit of Irvington House outdid themselves this year. One of them even parted with a 49-item collection of Bilston and South Staffordshire enamel snuff and patch boxes.

CARACAS, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Bill Wakeham of Canada, a professional only 15 months, took the first-round lead of the Caracas open today with a four-under-par 66, one stroke better than Alvie Thompson, also of Canada.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Arthur Ashe of Richmond, Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, and two Australians -- Fred Stolle and John Newcombe -- registered victories today to move into the semi-finals of the New South Wales tennis championships.
LONDON, Nov. 18 British proxy fighter Charles Clore, nearly down for the count last week, today was the all but certain victor in the battle for control of Lewis's Investment Trust, Ltd.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 18 -- India announced today that her troops had cleared Pakistani forces from an area of Rajasthan after a "sizable engagement."
Storm, a 39-foot sloop owned and sailed by A.E. (Bill) Luders Jr. of Stamford, Conn., was named winner of the Cygnet Cup last night at the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise dinner.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 -- The National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods urged today a liberalization of laws governing abortions and homosexuality.

THE women who moved comfortably through the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel Wednesday night had culture, not fashion, on their minds. They were at ease in dresses they had selected carefully, often at the Paris couture, and worn for years.
As a psychoanalyst, I was pleased and in total agreement with your Nov. 11 editorial "Ordeal of the Pacifists."

The war in Vietnam, with its mounting lists of casualties on both sides, its ever-greater destruction, its steady escalation of men and materiel, its deepening American and North Vietnamese involvement, all point to one conclusion. Vietnam is on the way to becoming another Korea in size and duration, despite obvious differences of technique and terrain.
The letter from the "Franciscan brother" to the Mother Superior seeking a contribution for the poor was warm and sincere. But it was not grammatical.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Senators investigating anonymous recorded telephone messages that attack public figures were told today of a new mechanical device that can initiate such calls, block the use of phones and even call back those who hang up before the message is completed.

ST. LOUIS, Friday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Machinists at Cape Kennedy, Fla., and the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation in St. Louis struck at midnight yesterday, threatening to delay the launching of two Gemini space shots and halting production of jet fighters used in Vietnam.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 18 -- Floyd Patterson was wearing a blue robe with orange piping and the intertwined lettering of N.Y. on the front. That's the color scheme of the New York Mets, who also have the unhappy faculty of encountering defeat. But there is a new serenity in the former heavyweight champion of the world as he prepares for his title bout with Cassius Clay here on Monday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- The United States expressed doubt today about the wisdom of a world disarmament conference in the near future that would overshadow the 18-nation disarmament conference in Geneva.

J. Raymond Jones, New York County Democratic leader, and Edward I. Koch, Greenwich Village leader, engaged in a public and angry argument about the meaning of a resolution approved by the county executive committee yesterday.
DENVER, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- About 1,000 pickets hissed Sheriff James G. Clark Jr. tonight.
WHEN the "heavies" start rolling in at Waimea Beach, the "peanut-butter surfers" start rolling in from the United States mainland.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 18 -- Few fans at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night would be surprised if Bret Hanover captured the year's richest harness race, the $151,252.05 Messenger Stakes, and the infield tote board flashed:

This television season is expected to be the last fop two medical and hospital dramas on two networks. The shows, both now in their fifth season, are "Ben Casey" on the American Broadcasting Company and "Dr. Kildare" on the National Broadcasting Company.
The short-interest position on the New York Stock Exchange in the month ended Nov. 15 rose by 1,460,445 shares to a total of 9,883,422 shares. It was 8,422,977 shares a month earlier.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- The parents of a youth who shot up a jet airliner in an apparent hijacking attempt said today that they believed he had wanted to fly the 91 persons aboard to Cuba to prove to them the evil of Communism.
The copper industry hailed yesterday the Government's plan to case the copper shortage and relieve upward price pressure through stockpile releases and other methods.

SINCE the entertainment being provided by Bramwell Fletcher in the East 74th Street Theater is Shavian, it is bound to be civilized, cultivated, stimulating, provocative, amusing and mixed with salt, pepper and a dash of vinegar.
A rush to sell copper futures contract developed yesterday as an aftermath of the Government's plan to release copper from its stockpile.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Henry Agard Wallace, Vice President of the United States in Franklin D. Roosevelt's third term and unsuccessful third party candidate for the Presidency in 1948, died today of lateral sclerosis in Danbury Hospital.
State and city officials disclosed efforts yesterday to reduce the hazard to the public from power failures such as the Nov. 9 blackout, which hit parts of eight Northeastern states and Canada.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 -- Five United States Senators met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko for more than two hours today to discuss the Vietnamese war and other East-West issues.

Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld awarded yesterday a total of $406,175 to the widows of three crewmen who lost their lives in September 1962 when the tug Russell 18 sank in Port Elizabeth channel, off Newark, N.J.

ALMOST every weekday morning, a youthful-looking man with brown hair ties his briefcase to the rear of a bicycle at his Larchmont, N.Y., home, then peddles swiftly past pedestrian commuters to the railroad station a mile and a half away.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Copper from the national stockpile will be sold to manufacturers who need it most on the basis of shortages of supply, with defense producers receiving priority, it was officially reported today.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay said yesterday that he had stepped into the tangled transit situation and would confer with Mayor Wagner as soon as possible regarding the make-up of a neutral panel to resolve the labor dispute.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 18 -- While the armed forces and religious groups have been pressing a campaign against the Communist party, a quieter struggle has been going on between President Sukarno and the army for control of the Indonesian press.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Rutgers University and the operator of the Federal Job Corps Center at Camp Kilmer disagreed sharply today on a report by eight Rutgers faculty members that charged the Kilmer operations with "flagrant deficiencies."
Financial responsibility for the City University should be transferred from the city to the state, according to a confidential recommendation to Mayor Wagner's Temporary Commission on City Finances.
West Virginia sold yesterday $20 million of road bonds, the second installment of $200 million authorized last year by an amendment to the state's constitution.

TORONTO, Nov. 18 -- Junior noteholders of the insolvent Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd., walked angrily out of a meeting today after having charged that they had been pressured to drop their fight against a settlement proposal that would pay them nothing.
AUSTIN, Tex. Nov. 19 -- President Johnson returned to his Texas ranch today with advice from his doctors to take it easy for the rest of the year.
Officers of the predominantly Negro Central Medical Society of Manhattan denied yesterday that they had discriminated racially against a white physician who applied for membership.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Dr. William C. Douglass, chairman of the organization "Let Freedom Ring," defended today anonymous recorded telephone attacks on prominent Americans.

It is frequently the case that some of tile most sweeping changes in modern life are presaged by those little articles on the back pages of newspapers which appear to have been included more on account of their brevity than their subject matter.
LONDON, Nov. 19 The Labor party showed a huge gain today in a public-opinion poll that amazed the politicians and the analysts.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Ernie Terrell, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, denied yesterday that he was under the influence of the underworld, as charged by the California Athletic Commission.
Federal Judge Walter Bruchhausen authorized yesterday William T. Cowin, bankruptcy trustee for Analogue Controls, Inc., to continue operating the Hicksville, L.I., potentiometer producer until Dec. 3
ELKTON, Md., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The raising of cigarette prices in New York to 45 cents a pack has given birth to an organized smuggling operation, a Maryland tax official said today.

A $246.000 award for the death of a geologist in a 1955 plane crash outside Rome was settled yesterday in Federal Court. The widow and her three children are expected to receive the money in 10 days from Sabena Airlines of Belgium.

When the average American male buys a suit, jacket or coat bearing the cryptic label "imported fabric," the British woolen industry is convinced that the purchaser thinks the fabric comes from Britain. In reality, it is most likely of Japanese origin, but this fact is concealed in the label's anonymity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A comprehensive program for monitoring level of pesticide residues throughout the nation was announced today by the Federal Committee oh Pest Control.

There is obvious inconsistency in a public attitude which urges a man to become involved when others' lives are endangered, yet assumes absolutely no responsibility when he loses his own life in the process. A case in point is that of the 28-year-old New Yorker who rose to the assistance last month of two women menaced by another subway passenger.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation lodged a strong protest yesterday at being denied the right to present its views on United States-Puerto Rico economic relations at public hearings, scheduled to start late this month, of the Commission on the Status of Puerto Rico.

Majority rule is a wonderful thing, particularly if the majority happens to have the same color skin as yours, and especially in Britain for the whites, who must constitute at least 90 per cent of the population. Nevertheless, to help insure this white majority, Britain has been restricting immigration from its colonies for the past few years.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Only a half-length separated Bret Hanover, the winner of tonight's $151,252.05 Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway, from Tuxedo Hanover, the runner-up. To the sure-thing bettors, however, a half-length was as good as a half-mile.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 19 -- Former Premier Moise Tshombe charged today that President Joseph Kasavubu had embarked on "a policy of repression and intimidation" to insure his own re-election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler served notice today that the Government would henceforth "blow the whistle impartially on labor and business" for actions that it regarded as inflationary.

" The Unloved Germans," by Hermann Eich, will be published by Stein Day on Nov. 30. The book surveys the German national character before, during and since the Nazi period. W.J. Taylor Whitehead, a director of Macdonald Co., which is publishing the book simultaneously in London, comments:
IJEBU-ODE, Nigeria, Nov. 16 The wave of postelection violence that has stricken parts of Nigeria's Western Region appears to have ebbed.

Hoffman-La Roche, Inc., of Nutley, N.J., a pharmaceutical concern, announced yesterday that it had recalled 19 lots of its Librax capsules after receiving reports that the tranquilizer had produced side effects in some users.
Water Commissioner Armand D'Angelo resigned from his $25,000-a-year post yesterday and took a few parting shots at critics of his water policies.
The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. John C. Hecker as president and general manager of its Distillation Products Industries division.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The head of a British steamship company, chatting recently at a London party, confided that he went by air on all his business trips because he just could not afford the time needed to go by ship.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A 6-foot, 200-pound United States Army private who staged a two-day hunger strike last month in the hope that it would get him to Vietnam faster was on his way today, his hope fulfilled.
Bernard Kessler, president of Unishops, Inc., has been elected a director of the Trans-Lux Corporation.
SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 19 -- The national police announced today the arrest of 10 persons suspected of having planned to overthrow the government of President Chung Hee Park.
THE woman who is what the French call "d'un certain age" (a Gallie way of saying she's not telling any more) has not yet been deserted by the Seventh Avenue coat-and-suiters.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz made some suggestions yesterday, and heard some, at a conference on how to shorten election lines, reduce confusion and brighten polling places.

JOHN UPDIKE is still having trouble separating preciousness from precision in his writing. His new novel, "Of the Farm," is sound, subtle storytelling. But it is needlessly embellished with touches of the hand-painted china style.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- A high-level French delegation left today for Peking to open a major industrial exhibition on Monday.
TRENTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson visited Princeton University today to inspect the Woodrow Wilson Graduate School of Public and International Affairs.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) - The New York Knicks allowed a 17-point lead to evaporate to 1 point tonight before they spurted in the last 3 1/2 minutes to defeat the Detroit Pistons, 116-109, in a National Basketball Association game.
The British pound declined in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 -- The nation's largest afternoon paper, The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, resumed publication today after it had reached agreement with the American Newspaper Guild on a new contract.
Barney Fife, the overwrought and timorous deputy on "The Andy Griffith Show," is coming back to Mayberry for a high school class reunion.

John Lindsay's effectiveness as Mayor of New York City will, in large part, depend upon the number of votes he will be able to muster in the Board of Estimate. Presently there are six Republican votes to sixteen Democratic votes in the Board.
A woman wrested herself free from an usher who tried to restrain her and plunged about 12 feet from the third to the second mezzanine of Radio City Music Hall yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Secretary General Thant called today for a meeting of the 18-nation Disarmament Committee "at the foreign ministers' level" to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

The Campbell Soup Company is building and planning numerous additional plants because its present facilities are being used nearly to capacity, William B. Murphy, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Camden, N.J.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 -- Thousands of bridge players are arriving in San Francisco today to compete in five major championships and a number of minor events in the American Contract Bridge League national championships.

Ernesto Giuriati has been named president of the Italian Line, the board of directors announced yesterday. He succeeds Giuseppe Zuccoli, who had held the post for eight years and who will continue as a member of the board.
From somewhere in Europe, an American soldier wrote a letter "just because I had nothing else to do," He asked:
HONG KONG, Nov. 19 -- Communist China took the position today that it did not want to be a member of the United Nations while the world organization retained its present form.

Copper futures trading dropped again yesterday by the daily limit of 200 points (2 cents a pound). Though the drop came as no surprise, there was a sharp divergence from the recent market pattern. Trading, almost at a standstill on Thursday after 132 lots changed hands, zoomed yesterday to 1,975.

George T. Delacorte Jr. was praised in a statement issued yesterday by License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo for offering to finance the landscaping, grading and beautification of parking lots in midtown Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Three major youth groups that have never joined forces on anything combined their resources today to sponsor a gift of food, drugs and other commodities to the people of Vietnam.
The City Controller's office estimated yesterday that the city would eventually have to pay $127,800 more in interest charges because a deal to sell bonds to a bankers' syndicate fell through.
One of New York's oldest fixtures, the Queens County Handicap, will have its 60th running at Aqueduct today.

THE New York Jets are favored over the Houston Oilers tomorrow, partly because their defensive line has been so good. The New York Giants are underdogs to the St. Louis Cardinals, partly because their defensive line has been so erratic.

Six jazz drummers last night moved from their customary position at the back of the bandstand and set up their equipment front and center on the stage of Hunter College Assembly Hall. The occasion was a "drum workshop," the first of three jazz "workshops" concerts to be conducted by Billy Taylor, the jazz pianist, at Hunter this winter under the auspices of the Newport Jazz Festival.
Buoyed by the highest short-interest on record, the stock market got off to a strong start yesterday but weakened at the close. The upshot was a slim gain for the day.

ROME, Nov. 19 -- In addressing the Fathers of the Council yesterday, Pope Paul VI placed himself -- and by implication the essential wisdom of the Roman Catholic Church -- squarely in the middle of the road, to the left of the diehard conservatives and to the right of the ultra-progressives.
Five Protestant denominations have established a "united, ecumenical and interdenominational" ministry for the town of Sterling Forest in Orange County, near Tuxedo, N.Y.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Carl B. Stokes conceded defeat today in his bid to become the first Negro mayor of a major American city as a recount gave an even-bigger margin to Mayor Ralph Locher.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 19 -- This is Never-Never Land, remember, where the next roll of the dice will buy more shoes than your baby can ever walk through, where the third chorus girl from the left is really just Sally from the Alley underneath all that glittering varnish, and where it makes a lot of sense that Sonny Liston may someday fight for the heavyweight championship of the world.
TOKYO, Nov. 19 (AP) - Avery Brundage of Chicago said today the door was open for Indonesia and North Korea to participate in the 1968 Olympic Games.
MIAMI, Nov. 19 -- Findings indicating that the amount of life in the oceans "may be many times greater than previously thought" were reported at a scientific meeting here today.

There were two power failures yesterday in Queens. The first, in the morning, lasted less than an hour and a half and affected 940 customers of the Consolidated Edison Company, mostly in Queens Village, Hollis, Bellerose and Glen Oaks.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin met today with five United States Senators who are on a round-the-world "fact-finding" tour for President Johnson.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- Results of a study of Jewish textbooks and other teaching materials disclosed today that Jews were more "introverted" than Roman Catholics and Protestants and less critical of other religions.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Fathers Image, syndicated today for about $1 million, has earned only $120,408 in his short career of five races, but he is expected to bounce away past that figure tomorrow. He is the 8-5 favorite to win the thirteenth running of the $311,945 Garden State Stakes for 2-year-olds and if he does his prize will be $187,617.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to sustain the constitutionality of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 in a suit brought directly before the Court by South Carolina.
Two local team championships, as well as the individual scoring title, can be won today on the last Saturday of the school football season.
QUINHON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Vietcong guerrillas are using bows and arrows in night attacks against United States security guards around the air base here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- You can buy, prepare and serve a complete Thanksgiving turkey dinner for four next week at a cost of $5.08, according to the Agriculture Department.

The Reader's Digest is negotiating with Funk Wagnalls Company, Inc., about purchase of the dictionary and reference book publishing concern. Funk Wagnalls is also involved in merger talks with other companies.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Members of the United States Equestrian Team won the first three places in the national doubles and trebles event in the international horse show at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair today.
The Consolidated Edison Company reached agreement yesterday on a new contract providing a 61.5-cent-an-hour wage and benefit package for its 25,000 organized workers.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 19 -- One of the anomalies of Rhodesia's quiet revolution is that, of the small band of men who engineered it, the toughest politically is the weakest physically and perhaps the most charming and approachable.

SAIGON, Saturday, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Gen. William C. Westmoreland, United States commander in Vietnam, today hailed the heavy fighting in the Central Highlands as an unprecedented victory over the Communists.

Office partners and executives of brokerage houses will receive greater power in governing the New York Stock Exchange under a plan designed to diminish the traditional influence of the floor members.
The Brooklyn Section, National Council of Jewish Women, will hold its Angel Luncheon Dec. 6 at the St. Regis Roof. Mrs. Abraham Nathan is chairman of the committee for the event.

The Times has performed a notable service in publicizing the fact that a year ago Washington rejected a North Vietnamese offer to open peace talks in Rangoon, Burma -- a point reported by Eric Sevareid in the current issue of Look Magazine.

The Amadeus Quartet will play a special John F. Kennedy memorial program at the Mineola Theater in Mineola, L.I., Monday night, commemorating the second anniversary of the President's death. The works to be performed will be Haydn's "The Seven Last Words of Christ" (Op. 51) and Beethoven's Quartet in F minor (Op. 95).
THE women who remember that time when art elegant 4-foot-10 arbiter of fashion and merchandising named Hattie Carnegie was in her heyday may well have cause for joy.

" On Madison Avenue, you can walk out of almost any gallery with a painting and no one will stop you," an art dealer said the other day. His comment was prompted by bitter experience -- his own and that of others.
The General Electric Company and Time, Inc., disclosed yesterday that they were going into the educational materials field through a new jointly owned subsidiary.
William D. Eckert, the newly-appointed commissioner of baseball, visited his new office here yesterday and said he might not be in favor of having five deputies assigned to him.

Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo took his seat at the long table, pushed the assortment of berets, cossack hats and other headgear toward 10 inspectors in his Department of Licenses and told them to do their best to "look like yokels who were ready to be taken for all they were worth."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A California scientist believes the particle accelerator for which he received a patent this week makes the enormous structures built for the purpose unnecessary.

ROME, Nov. 19 -- The Roman Catholic world hierarchy voted overwhelmingly today for the adoption of a positive concept of religious liberty as church doctrine to replace the negative one of "toleration."
Talks exploring the possibility of a merger between the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company and the Texas Pharmacal Company are in progress, it was announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 -- Argentina's agreement to sell 1.5 million tons of wheat to Communist China, disclosed last night, has left private grain dealers surprised and doubtful of the Government's ability to deliver.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 - George Balanchine's "La Sonambula," given a new production by the Washington National Ballet at the Lisner Auditorium here tonight, is one of the choreographer's few romantic ballets.
Columbia's pass defense, rated the best in the Ivy League, will face its stiffest test when it copes with the potent aerial attack of Brown today at Baker Field. The kickoff is set for 1:30 P.M.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Foreign Minister Frank Aiken of Ireland appealed today to the smaller powers to look on their contributions for future United Nations peace-keeping ventures as an "insurance premium" against instability and big-power intervention in their affairs.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 19 -- A left-wing activist group called the Sparticists handed out leaflets at the University of California today urging that picket sign poles be used for defense "in case of attack" in tomorrow's anti-Vietnam War demonstration.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Nov. 19 -- A board of Marine Corps officers, charged with protecting the reputation of the corps, as well as its recruits, today acquitted a senior drill instructor accused of abusing trainees.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -The American Communist party was found guilty tonight and fined $230,000 for failing to register with the Government as an agent of the Soviet Union, as required by the Internal Security Act of 1950.

Why must New York have such filthy streets? My husband and I have just returned from a week's visit in your city. We were appalled and depressed by the litter everywhere along the curb, on the sidewalks, in front of stores, apartment houses, hotels -- in every part of town we visited.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- An unusual case of alleged stock manipulation, aimed not so much at running up the price of the stock as at generating business for a brokerage house, resulted today in the recommendation for a 10-day suspension of a New York Stock Exchange member firm and the the outright revocation of the registration of an over-the-counter concern.

Three separate incidents troubled the Flatbush and New Lots Avenues divisions of the IRT Subway in Brooklyn in the morning rush hour yesterday. One hundred thousand riders were affected by the two-hour delay that started at 8:05.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Nov. 19 -New devices to measure gravity, earth tremors, and strains in rock have substantially increased the prospect for understanding and perhaps ultimately predicting earthquakes.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The chairman of the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario implied today that U.S. utilities were not altogether blameless in the power blackout Nov. 9 in Canada and the United States.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 19 -Physicians attending former President Dwight D. Eisenhower announced today that they had decided on next Monday as a "tentative target date" for their patient's transfer by train to Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

ATHENS, Nov. 19 -- The Greek Government declared an Orthodox Church conference void today after its organizers defied court order against transferring 17 bishops. But an angry churchman ripped the Government decree from the gates of a meeting hall, and the session went on.

OTTAWA, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press) -- The Dominion Marine Association said yesterday that larger crews were not the answer to reducing St. Lawrence Seaway ship accidents and charged the Seafarers' International Union with a "transparent" attempt to enlarge crews at the expense of efficiency.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- American tennis hopes received a big lift today when Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., and Clark Graebner of Beechwood, Ohio, combined to defeat Australia's Davis Cup stars, Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle, 6-3, 12-10, 3-6, 6-3, in the men's doubles final of the New South Wales championship.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday it would seek to borrow $50 million in Europe through an offering of convertible bonds.
A "dream" game at South Bend, Ind., and the top Ivy attraction in the league's 10 years of formal championship play, both sellouts, are on today's final full schedule of the college football season.
A change in the name of the Nassau County Clearing House Association, Inc., to the Long Island Bankers Association, Inc., was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- British Guiana, torn in recent years by strife between residents of East Indian extraction and Negroes, will become independent next year.
The ultimate tribute to cats is this: As long as human beings endure, we will be writing about them. These three books contribute to that premise.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Mayor John F. Collins acknowledged tonight mistakes and irregularities in Boston's antipoverty program. He placed the burden on a broadly based governing body, emphasizing that he was one of 44 members on it and one of 15 members on its executive committee.

A team of 100 researchers will start fanning out today in eight cities in three northeastern states to find out how people acted in the Nov. 9 blackout. Also, if possible, they will try to learn why they acted as they did, something Civil Defense officials would very much like to know.

Princess Margaret wasn't there, and neither were Lord Snowdon, Andy Warhol, Edie Sedgwick, nor even Leonard Lyons. A pride of other "beautiful" people though, did manage to make the scene at the New York Financial Writers annual executive roast last night.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, released an expensive two-color brochure a few days ago urging immediate construction of the Lower Manhattan Expressway as an elevated structure. Mr. Moses, who has been the leading champion of the expressway for many years, declared that to substitute a depressed roadway for the elevated one would increase construction costs perhaps as much as $50 million without resulting benefits.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 18 -- This capital was recently described by a visitor as "the great unfinished city."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- George W. Mitchell, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested for consideration today a series of major innovations in the techniques of monetary policy.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- David Merrick, the Broadway producer, dismissed the director of his new play, "Inadmissible Evidence," demanded that the author cut a half hour from the three-hour show and was allegedly punched by Nicol Williamson, a British actor, it was disclosed today.

While Michael J. Quill flexes his muscles for another tiresome exhibition of contempt for the public interest, the union representing 25,000 Consolidated Edison employes in the metropolitan area has demonstrated once again that fruitful collective bargaining can be conducted in a vital public utility without strike threats or other histrionics.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 19 -- A psychiatrist testifed today that Duane Pope had been suffering from acute schizophrenia at the time he killed three persons in a bank robbery last June.
A 14-year-old boy appearing in Children's Court yesterday on an assault charge was re-arrested as a rape suspect after he had been identified by two Stryvesant Town girls who were attacked Nov. 10.

" Come on along and listen to -- the lullaby of Broadway," chanted the pert brunette in the movie. Suddenly the screen became a spangled kaleidoscope of pantomine and hoofing as several hundred tap dancers clattered the glistening floor of a huge, old-time nightclub setting.
BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Labor released frozen funds today to permit the Boston Antipoverty Program to continue another two or three weeks.
The New York Stock Exchange added three more stocks yesterday to its tough new day-margin regulations, which have the effect of tightening credit requirements.

I have been reading the autobiography of Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst and find that your editorial reference to him ("The Clergy and Politics," Oct. 25) was correct, and the letter of Elizabeth Lloyd published Nov. 1 criticizing it was in error.

I regret that I am once again compelled to have recourse to your columns in view of the assertions made by the Ethiopian Ambassador in his letter published on Nov. 6. It is neither feasible nor necessary for me to reply in detail to the Ambassador's letter which contains nothing to invalidate the facts put forward in mine of Oct. 18.

CAIRO, Nov. 19 -- The United State, concerned that the Egyptian blockage of Rhodesian cargoes through the Suez Canal could set a precedent for use of the canal in political disputes, has asked for "clarification" of President Gamal Abdel Nasser's statement that a "state of war" exists between Cairo and Salisbury.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 19 -- Indian troops have seized a second Pakistani stronghold in the far western Rajasthan Desert, a Defense Ministry spokesman said tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- An embargo on petroleum products for Rhodesia was demanded in a draft resolution presented in the Security Council tonight.
A new maritime strike has idled five ships in Baltimore and may spread to 119 companies operating more than 400 ships.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS. W. Va., Nov. 19 -- Sharper competition among lenders -- and possibly lower borrowing costs for consumers -- are in prospect if mutual savings banks in New York State win the right to make unsecured personal loans. At present they are barred! by state law from doing so.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 -- The United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile), which has been engaged in some of the heaviest fighting of the Vietnamese war, is the only unit of its kind.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today the probable cause of a Nevada airliner crash that killed 29 persons a year ago was "misinterpretation of the approach chart by the captain which resulted in a premature descent below obstructing terrain."
LAKE CHARLES, La., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Bob Panasiuk of Toronto shot a four-under par 68 today to increase his lead to two strokes at 134 in the $10,000 Alvin Dark invitation golf tournament.
The London Stock Exchange ended the week yesterday on a firm note. Tobaccos, steels and chemicals were up, with support for copper issues stemming from the sharp recovery in the price of the metal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A $61 million fund to start the rebuilding of the nation's grandest ceremonial boulevard will be sought from Congress in January.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week in good form yesterday as advances outnumbered declines by a wide margin in very active trading.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Nicholas H. Noyes, an 82-year-old Indianapolis pharmaceutical company executive and long-time friend of Cornell University, has given $3 million, his largest contribution yet, to his alma mater. James A. Perkins, president of Cornell, today announced the gift to the Cornell Centennial Fund from Mr. Noyes, a member of the class of '06.
Increased business loans and projections of a strong economy throughout 1966 depressed bond prices yesterday.

CONSULT almost any reputable survey of postwar French painting published in Paris and you will find the names of Andre Lanskoy and Zao Wou-Ki inscribed with, extravagant, if imprecise, praise. Both these painters -- the one Russian by birth, the other Chinese -- became established luminaries in the Paris art scene of the nineteen-fifties and have since been treated to the full panoply of critical stardom in which the French are past masters.
In a move that caught the copper industry by surprise, the Anaconda Company rescinded yesterday its recent 2-cent increase in the metal's price.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Senator Jacob K. Javits declared today that Governor Rockefeller was "in trouble" in New York State but could still win re-election to a third term next year.
QUEBEC, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press) -- The liner Empress of England arrived in Quebec today after having turned back from a voyage to Britain.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 19 -- A new approach to the rapid development of economically retarded areas was outlined today by the European Common Market's Executive Commission.
Montgomery Ward Co., announced yesterday that its sales and earnings in the fiscal three, and nine-month periods rose from 1964 levels.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 19 -- President Makarios and Elias Tsirimokos, Greece's Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister, ended two days of talks today vowing, to fight for enosis, or union of Cyprus with Greece, but aware that it might be a long and difficult task.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Wilf Homenuik and Alvie Thompson of Canada shared the second-round lead in the Caracas open golf tournament today. Each had a 137.
Barely did J.I. Rodale's latest work, "An Impudent Wolf," open off Broadway last night than he was hot on trail of his next one, something to do with music and its effect on humans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19, -- The index of wholesale primary market prices rose two-tenths of 1 per cent to 103.4 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Nov. 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products advanced in price while processed foods and industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, raised today the prospect that he would formally label the Republican party as antilabor before the 1966 elections.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 -- Turnbull Elevator, Ltd., a Toronto-based manufacturer with annual sales of $34 million, issued a terse announcement to shareholders today that it lost $734,333 in the year ended Aug. 31.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 19 -- Intimidation of newspaper readers, the arrest of editors and crippling circulation boycotts have plunged the free press here into serious political and financial straits.
State Supreme Court Justice Nathan R. Sobel has derided as "carelessly nurtured nonsense" the usual police contention that confessions are the backbone of law enforcement.
The chairman of the city's Board of Higher Education declared his opposition yesterday to any move that would give control of the City University to the state.

SMYRNA, Del., Nov. 19 -- The 25th annual national championship stake of the National Retriever Field Trial Club ended its third day on the Bombay Hook Wildlife Preserve with 14 survivors remaining of 45 starters.

Measures to increase East-West trade have recently been recommended by a Commerce Department mission which visited Poland and Rumania. A broader report along the same lines was made last spring by the President's Special Committee on U.S. Trade Relations with East European Countries and the Soviet Union. A study by the Committee for Economic Development has also urged early moves to increase commerce with the Communist countries.
GEORGE and Charlie, fidgeting in their chairs, awaited the arrival of the six girls. The eight adventurers, all aged approximately 13, were about to begin their first cooking class.
Bert Rapp in his letter published Nov. 15 has made a valid point concerning the difficulties of automobile travel in Manhattan.
The world champion Boston Celtics make their first appearance of the National Basketball Association season at Madison Square Garden tonight when they oppose the New York Knickerbockers.

Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday the Federal Government should give the city special aid for education to help cover the extra costs imposed on it because of immigration from the South and Puerto Rico.
The city announced yesterday a housing project for families whose incomes are too high for low-income projects, but too low for middle-income apartments.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Michigan State University officials said today they would begin taking Rose Bowl ticket orders Monday.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 19 (AP) -- In the wake of a melee that contractors estimated had caused $10,000 in damages at a nonunion construction project, Lansing's Mayor declared tonight that the city would take all possible steps to prevent any repetition.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 -- United States troops pushed through tile Iadrang River valley again today in search of North Vietnamese regulars after five days of sustained fighting that has altered the character of the war in South Vietnam's central highlands.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 -Senator Robert F. Kennedy has indicated to friends that he will assume personal leadership of the Democratic party in New York State.
The Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee announced yesterday that its borough leaders had voted to authorize a strike if the National Labor Relations Board did not move quickly in two cases.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 19 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that he was "distressed' to learn that threatening letters had been sent to Sir Humphrey Gibbs, the British Governor whom Mr. Smith has put under a slow, peaceful siege for refusing to accept the removal of his titular executive authority by Rhodesia's declaration of independence.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- The State Public Service Commission, groping for clues to the cause of the massive power failure that blacked out the Northeast on Nov. 9, received scant enlightenment today from electric utility executives.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay submitted 10 names to Mayor Wagner yesterday as candidates for a three-member panel to assist in bringing about a settlement in the transit dispute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -The heads of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the National Urban League said today that many Negroes would be "disappointed" if President Johnson did not name Robert C. Weaver as Secretary of the new Department of Housing and Urban Development.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 19 -- Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Adjie, the powerful military commander of West Java, announced today that he had banned the Indonesian Communist party in that region.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Bullets ended the Philadelphia 76ers' undefeated home record at five games with a 134-124 victory tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Twenty-eight years after the death of Maurice Ravel, a legal quarrel over rights to his royalties -- about $300,000 a year -- has erupted.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 -- Eighteen makers of petroleum products and 17 individuals were fined today in United States District Court here for conspiring to fix the price of road oil sold to Missouri.

THE short, elegant program planned by Thomas Dunn for the concert given by the Festival Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall last night offered three works -- Haydn's Symphony No. 21 in A, Stravinsky's "Dumbarton Oaks" Concerto and Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 26 in D.K. 537, which is generally known as the "Coronation" Concerto.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick announced yesterday the assignment of Deputy Inspector John T. Downer as commanding officer of the Police Academy.

Britain's diminutive Princess Margaret, decked out in the brilliant jewels and diamond tiara Americans expect of visiting royalty, reigned over a ball in her honor last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Federal mediators struggled tonight to settle a strike against the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation that is threatening to disrupt the nation's defense and space efforts.
Salary increases of $2,500 a year have been given by Mayor Wagner to seven more members of his administration, it was disclosed yesterday in the City Record.

St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Newark disclosed yesterday that the Rev. Robert L. Pierson, son-in-law of Governor Rockefeller, had been named rector, effective Nov. 28.
A new Cabinet-level Department of Education with a special adult education unit was recommended yesterday by Dr. Paul A. Miller, president of West Virginia University.

Marcia Barbour has toured extensively as a cellist, in various chamber ensembles, but last night she gave her New York debut recital in Carnegie Recital Hall. Her experience showed in the confident manner of her playing, in its general technical excellence - there were some if few, problems in intonation.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- France's first campaign in 117 years to elect her chief executive by direct popular vote began officially tonight with the first appearance of several Opposition candidates on the Government-controlled radio and television network.

Princess Margaret sailed gracefully through her first full day in the city yesterday despite a boycott of a reception by African diplomats at the United Nations and a bomb scare.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Flag tied the Pimlico turf course record of 1:43 for a mile and one-sixteenth in winning the Gay Serenade Purse by 2 1/2 lengths over Lancastrian today. The mark was set by Decline and Fall on May 18, 1962.
BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP) - The Boston Celtics rallied in the second half and defeated Cincinnati, 129-103, tonight, snapping the Royals' seven-game National Basketball Association winning streak.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Tom Rhoads, a defensive end, is lost to Notre Dame for the game with Michigan State tomorrow.

A Civil Court judge rejected yesterday a theatrical agent's application to change his name from Howard Burton Zaimant to Baron de Z'Aimant on the ground that "only a king can create a baron or a duke or a count."
MEXICAN women will have a chance to inspect American spring fashions before the clothes are in the stores here.
SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 14 -- A new mood has begun to pervade South Korea and the future is starting to brighten.

The odd thought processes of the schizophrenic may be traceable to an unusual functioning of the involuntary system that regulates digestion, circulation and respiration, it was suggested here yesterday.

Vivian Rivkin brought another interesting program to Town Hall last night, this time devoted to the chamber music of Schumann. Eight musicians were on hand for the five seldom-heard pieces, each of which had Miss Rivkin as pianist, but although the items promised much the performances delivered little.

MODESTO, Calif. -- Ten miles east of this town, out in the middle of peach orchards, sits a graveyard for horse-drawn carriages. This repository occupies part of a ranch owned by the family of the late Pierce A. Miller, who started the collection in 1933.

SAN CRISTOBAL, Dominican Republic, Nov. 19 -- This pleasant provincial capital on the hillside west of Santo Domingo professes no pride now over being the birthplace of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina. Nor can it forget that late tyrant.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 20 (UPI) -- A 34-year-old construction worker signed a statement today admitting participation in the kidnapping of 13-year-old Charles Hyde 3d. Authorities said $34,360 of the $45,000 ransom money had been recovered.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 20 -- A three-judge Federal court panel has accepted as constitutional a new plan for apportioning the Indiana General Assembly. The plan's use for next year's elections appears assured.
BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- An explosion in a clothing factory here during the night damaged machinery and injured one worker. It was the city's second bomb incident in a week.

THERE was a time, at the end of World War II, when white South Africans seemed inclined to move toward the goal of a common society under Jan Hofmeyr's liberal leadership. By 1948, Hofmeyr, then Deputy Prime Minister, seemed destined to succeed the aging General Smuts; but in that year's fateful elections, the voters chose Malan's fortress of white supremacy rather than Hofmeyr's open road.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- A shortage of skilled labor is forcing some Philadelphia employers to recruit workers abroad.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 20 -- A cheerful and grinning but peaked General Eisenhower met with newsmen briefly for the first time today since his heart attack 10 days ago and said, "I feel just fine." WHEN Lobengula, the last of the great Matabele King, was being pursued northward by Rhodesia's white settlers in 1894 he was a dying man. His nation was being defeated; his kingdom was toppling; he was burning with fever. THE Nazi extermination program easily dissolves into "legend" writes Meyer Levin in THE STRONGHOLD (Simon Schuster, $5.95). "The vastness of it was too much for the human psyche to accept." Walter Holmes, a young British designer who came to the United States 12 years ago and settled in Chicago, recently showed his spring collection at the Gotham Hotel here. It consisted of 26 styles with an easy look that often included big patch pockets.
