Israel Rogosin, a textiles executive, has made a $3 million "challenge gift" to the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center's Fund for Medical Progress.

St. LOUIS, Nov. 21 -- The New York Giants, a team that has never lost in this city, beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 28-15, today before a crowd of 31,742 in Busch Stadium. The name of the game was football, but not the kind to boast about.

Mayor Wagner asked the Board of Higher Education last night to take no action on the announced resignations and retirements of four top City University officials until "mediating processes can have their impact."

Yes, Virginia, there was an age of gracious living in New York. There was the Savoy Plaza, facing the city's loveliest open square, dedicated to the more luxurious things of life. There was the Sheraton East, formerly the Ambassador, which, with the Waldorf Astoria and its neighbors, gave Park Avenue its particular stamp of elegance.
The paving of 1,600 bus stops in the city has been ordered because of complaints that they get muddy and ruin women's shoes and stockings.

The school bell is a programed electronic beep, the lunchroom line winds through a turnstile to a conveyor belt bearing prepared frozen food heated in the convection ovens. Some of the classrooms can change size and shape, others can be viewed through one-way mirrors. Closed-circuit television watches all the rooms -- and the outside walls are entirely blank.
The Advertising Federation of America has added its voice to yet another controversy.

The Victorian Gothic interior of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church will soon ring with a joyful noise of a kind it has never heard before. On Sunday evening, Dec. 26, Duke Ellington and his orchestra will present a concert of sacred music there under the sponsorship of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 22 -- While he did nothing to dispel his own image of petulant arrogance, Cassius Clay had the good grace after tonight's fight to heap obviously sincere and ungrudging praise on Floyd Patterson.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The Labor Government, which has just deferred plans to nationalize the steel industry, is facing embarrassing problems of state ownership in other fields.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 22 -- Night riders bombed the homes of four Negro civil rights leaders here early today and shattered the pride of this racially progressive city.
" End it, end it, would ya!" screamed a fan in the balcony of the Academy of Music last night.
The British pound closed unchanged yesterday at $2.8038 in a quiet foreign-exchange market that several traders described as "deadly dull."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Howard Mumford Jones, a retired Harvard professor who won a Pulitzer Prize this year for a book on American culture, has resigned a visiting professorship at the University of Texas in protest against the university's required loyalty oath.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Secretary General Thant today hailed as "a truly significant step" the General Assembly move to broaden the United Nations Development Program.
Monumental traffic jams plagued the city and suburbs yesterday. As one was unsnarled another formed, frazzling the nerves of drivers and policemen.
Negotiations will continue today between The Daily News and the Newspaper Guild of New York in an effort to reach agreement on a new contract.
DALLAS, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- A wet mist burned off today, just as it did two years ago, and a fitful sun shone on a city filled with prayer and sorrowing memories.
The city rolled out soggy red carpets for Princess Margaret yesterday as she completed her schedule of public appearances in the United States.
The Board of Higher Education declined last night to accept the resignations and retirements of four top officials of the City University and asked them to reconsider their decisions.

The prospect for a long overdue reform of New York State's archaic divorce law is brighter now than it has ever been before. A legislative committee has been holding hearings at which almost unanimous agreement has been expressed that the law should be changed, although there are many differing views of what the changes should be.

QUARTERBACK, the glamour position in pro football, has been an especially difficult one this season for a number of incumbents. Bill Munson of the Los Angeles Rams underwent knee surgery Sunday night and is lost for the season.

TOKYO -- Nami Nakabayashi smoothed the sleek broadtail suit of her own design, sat forward in the blue brocade chair, and explained why she had no intention of expanding her couture business to the United States.
ATHENS, Nov. 22 -- Fears of a schism in the Greek Orthodox Church arose today when the Cabinet approved a draft bill that would enforce drastic reforms in church administration.

While in Arizona, Princess Margaret and her husband were taken for a boat ride on Lake Powell, a man-made lake formed by Glen Canyon Dam, which backs up the waters of the Colorado River. The boat passed an island where the royal party was regaled by the following spectacle -- and we quote The Times's account by Charlotte Curtis:

By discouraging knowledge, debate and criticism of its policies in Vietnam the Administration shows that although it thinks it is conducting a limited war there it has in fact unconsciously adopted, and expects the public to adopt, attitudes appropriate to total war.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Rumania has not offered to mediate in the Vietnamese war nor has the United States asked her to do so, the State Department said today.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 22 -- The old soldier began an orderly retreat today to a previously prepared position.

FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Nov. 22 -- The White House confirmed today that American nuclear warheads had been made available to allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, with the United States retaining ultimate control over their use.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- There are a number of ways of hunting the East's very intelligent, very wary whitetail deer, and in this heavily hunted section of the Catskill mountains they're all practiced.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 22 -- Like a little boy pulling off the wings of a butterfly piecemeal, Cassius Clay mocked and humiliated and punished Floyd Patterson for almost 12 rounds tonight until the referee halted their heavyweight championship bout because the challenger was "outclassed."
Steel production rose 2.7 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission served notice today that it would not honor state laws that served as barriers rather than as protection for woman workers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The world's only wild whooping crane flock now has at least 44 members, a record, the Interior Department announced today.

ROME, Nov. 22 -- Apathy and indifference to the "menacing calamities" of the atomic arms race and to widespread starvation were vigorously attacked here today by Gunnar Myrdal, Swedish economist and social scientist.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Without officially saying so, Guinea and France have broken off diplomatic relations, French sources said tonight.

The Northern Natural Gas Company announced yesterday plans for filing by Dec. 30 an application with the Federal Power Commission for a $200-million system to deliver natural gas daily from western Canada to eastern Canada through the United States.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York confirmed yesterday it planned to sell about $100 million of debt securities at competitive bidding on Dec. 15.

A beagle hound named Bess and a pillowcase that Beatle George McCartney slept on stirred lively bidding last night at a "celebrity auction" held at the Regency Hotel to benefit the Dag Hammarskjold Memorial Fund.
Forces dissatisfied with the liquor law reforms enacted last year lined up yesterday for a fight in the 1966 Legislature.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Nov. 22 -- Vas is the nickname of Maj. Charles C. Vasiliadis, a Harvard graduate of Huntington, L.I., a pilot who has probably flown more combat missions than any other fighter-bomber pilot in South Vietnam.
DETROIT, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Auto production continued at a high rate this week as United States auto companies moved closer to their first nine-million-car year.

SAIGON, Tuesday, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- A Vietcong regiment attacked a Government outpost north of the coastal province town of Tuyhoa early today, ambushed an armored relief column sent in to help, then wheeled south and attacked the Tuyhoa airport and the town itself, military spokesmen recorded.

The city announced last night that the Haryou-Act antipoverty agency had agreed to accept new fiscal and bookkeeping procedures as a condition for getting more funds from the city and, by implication, from the Federal Government.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- An antitrust suit against J. Walter Kennedy, the president of the National Basketball Association, and all N.B.A. clubs except the Boston Celtics was filed in United States District Court today by Woodrow (Woody) Sauldsberry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- In a sudden and unusual move, the Supreme Court ventured back this afternoon into the controversial area of confessions, interrogation, and the right of criminal suspects to counsel.

Leo D. Welch, who retires a week from today as chairman and chief executive officer of the Communications Satellite Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the Electric Bond and Share Company.
Mrs. John F. Kennedy spent yesterday, the second anniversary of her husband's assassination, in the quiet seclution of her Fifth Avenue apartment.
The Defense Department has notified the city that it is sending an aide here to discuss "the movement of nuclear warheads" through New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- In a timely decision involving turkeys, the Supreme Court overturned an earlier decision today and ruled that not every case involving a Federal-state conflict may originate in a special three-man Federal court.
Thirty per cent of the city's 9,000 traffic signal lights are still not back to normal after the massive power failure of two weeks ago, Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday.
BOSTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Ray Charles, the blind Los Angeles piano player and jazz singer, won a continuance for a year today after having pleaded guilty to a Federal charge of possession of narcotics.
Karl Richter, organist, came from Munich to give an organ recital at Philharmonic Hall late yesterday afternoon on the second anniversary of President Kennedy's assassination.

UNDULATING free-form designs, obviously influenced by three-dimensional art, have recently appeared on the home scene in impressive numbers. It's sculptured furniture. As sculptors are commissioned to design furniture, art galleries include beds in their Pop exhibitions and industrial designers decide they must sculpture and mold all their three-dimensional designs, it becomes increasingly difficult to draw the line between a work of art and a product.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Diplomatic sources now expect the United States to accept a United Nations call for a worldwide disarmament conference by 1967 that would include Communist China.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay disclosed yesterday that numerous "bright men with major law firms" were busy working out legislation to consolidate the city's 99 departments and agencies.
MANILA, Nov. 21 -- Beside the tall roadside reeds, where the ambush band had waited, the constabulary found seven dead Filipinos sprawled about their bullet-punctured jeep.

MAGNA, Utah, Nov. 22 -- While Government and industry leaders were debating the release of 200,000 tons of copper from the nation's stockpile last week, work was continuing around the clock here and at nearby Bingham on a four-year, $100 million "expansion program" of the Kennecott Copper Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A majority of the Federal Power Commission appears to feel that increased direct Government control over extra-high-voltage lines is not needed to prevent future large-scale power failures.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Cassius Clay showered beaten Floyd Patterson with praise tonight, then typically demanded plenty of credit for himself from the "American public."

Something new and surprising has just happened to Jonah Jones, the trumpet player who has been a popular favorite since he introduced his light, bright, rhythmic use of a muted trumpet at the Embers in 1955. For the first time in the 10 years that his quartet has been playing some of the most danceable music to be heard anywhere, it has been hired to play for dancing.

TRENTON, Nov. 22 -- A young man who has spent half his life in prison was granted a new trial today because his appeal of a 1949 murder conviction was denied when he could not afford to produce the transcript of the trial.
The manufacturing plant of the future will not be a great expanse of machines making more machines without men to guide them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- A citizens' aviation committee today called for drastic improvements in the airways system linking North and South America.

William F.R. Ballard, chairman of the City Planning Commission, joined Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes yesterday in criticizing the $160 million plan of Robert Moses to reconstruct the aged West Side Highway and increase its capacity by nearly 50 per cent.

YALE and Army tried, but failed, to schedule football games with one another sometime during the next five years. However, there is a possibility that the two will meet once again after 1970 as both athletic departments indicate a willingness to rein stitute the rivalry that ended in 1955.
ATLANTA, Nov. 22 -- Southern Negroes are participating in Southern farm elections in record numbers this year but they have thus far failed to win any major voice in shaping local farm policy.

An independent seamen's union defeated the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America in an election to represent 740 seaman manning 19 tankers operated by the Marine Division of the Humble Oil and Refining Company.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 22 (AP) -- "I think the contest is going to be decided by the team emotionally ready and tactically prepared for it," Coach Bill Elias of Navy said today of Saturday's Army-Navy game in Philadelphia.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Edward Heath, the leader of Britain's Conservative party and an outspoken advocate of British membership in the Common Market, met for an hour today with President de Gaulle.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Federal urban renewal officials have agreed to consider allegations of a Detroit citizens group protesting the condemnation of residential property for expansion of Wayne State University.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Drenching rains deluged Southern California today, isolating the desert resort of Palm Springs, sending mudslides ozzing into homes, flooding intersections and causing evacuation of threatened residents.

A 1,037-page book bound in black cardboard and listing on its apricot and white pages the names of those who, in the opinion of social arbiters, are somebody appeared yesterday as Vol. LXXX, No. 1, of "Social Register New York 1966."

UVALDE, Tex., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Former Vice President John Nance Garner celebrated his 97th birthday today, but the excitement of the occasion proved too much for him. He sent word from inside his small white house that a headache prevented him from greeting the 200 neighbors and visitors gathered on the lawn.
PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Nov. 22 -- Seven Marine Corps privates testified today that they were beaten or struck by a 24-year-old drill sergeant during basic training here last month.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A digest of recent news events, composed after an extensive reading of book, movie and theater reviews in the nation's leading newspapers, magazines and cultural periodicals:

MIAMI, Nov. 22 -- The old wooden decks of the liner Yarmouth Castle, which burned as savagely as a pine forest, killing 89 when she sank off the Bahamas early Nov. 13, were permitted by United States maritime safety laws, a Coast Guard board of inquiry was told today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The United States complained today that there had been "thunderous silence" from the Soviet Union and France on the need to help the United Nations out of its financial difficulties.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 22 -- President Johnson pledged United States aid for the Alliance for Progress today beyond 1971, the original terminal date.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 23 -- United States Air Force jets attacked two missile installations in North Vietnam yesterday and destroyed one of them, an American military spokesman announced.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The Labor party's left wing brought renewed pressure on the Wilson Government today to take fresh steps toward a negotiated end of the Vietnam war.

Between the closing of the current season and the opening of the 1966 campaign, local harness racing fans will have barely enough time for a shave, a haircut and a visit to the bank. The 1965 schedule ends at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., on the night of Dec. 15, but the no-action pinch will be felt for less than three weeks.
The Board of Education has found that its own Bureau of Design charges 63 per cent more to design school projects than private architects would.
The Martin-Marietta Corporation announced here yesterday the election as a director of Delos W. Rentzel, a corporate vice president and president of its cement and lime division.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The threat of a delay in next month's Gemini space shots appeared ended today when union leaders agreed to send striking machinists back to work at Cape Kennedy, Fla.
Mayor Wagner is expected to appoint Jacob Lutsky, his longtime legal aide, to a full 10-year term as a Family Court judge as soon as the Mayor's screening committee gives him clearance.

Jonathan Logan, Inc., the nation's largest women's wear manufacturer, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Davis Sportswear Company, Inc., of Lawrence, Mass., a producer of women's car coats.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 -- The establishment of a multimillion-dollar center for the study of American history was announced today by Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The over-all Federal budget moved strongly into deficit in the third quarter of this year following two quarters of surplus, the Council of Economic Advisers reported today.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 22 -- A special state gambling study commission reported to Gov. John N. Dempsey tonight that organized illegal gambling in Connecticut runs into millions of dollars a year.

BONN, Nov. 22 -- A spokesman for the Defense Ministry said today that no West German Air Force pilot could take a plane carrying a nuclear weapon off the ground, or even go aboard, without authorization by the President of the United States.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 22 -- Security was doubled by Las Vegas peace authorities for tonight's Cassius Clay-Floyd Patterson heavyweight title fight at the Las Vegas Convention Center.
The Greyhound Corporation announced yesterday the election of Gerald H. Trautman, 53 years old, as president and chief executive officer effective Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- In his speech to the Executives' Club of Chicago last week Secretary of the Treasury Fowler disclosed the culminating reason why President Johnson will "henceforth . . . blow the whistle impartially" on wage as well as price increases in industry.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held yesterday that a suspect does not have a constitutional right to be informed by the police in the initial stage of an investigation of his right to remain silent or to have a lawyer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The three-month Treasury bill rate rose slightly at today's auction to another five-year high, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
MEMPHIS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Guy Rogers scored 39 points tonight to lead the San Francisco Warriors to a 112-108 victory over the injury-riddled St. Louis Hawks.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 22 -- They all laughed when Dominick DeCecco said he wanted to own the Danish Pavilion at the World's Fair. That was two and half years ago.
What a surprise it was to read in The Times of Nov. 13 that there are fewer dirty streets in New York City this year than last.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 -- Two Federal agencies were accused today in a $5.7 million damage suit of allowing the now-defunct San Francisco National Bank to do business when they knew more than a year before its closure that its operation was unsafe and illegal.

THE Standwells, the most durable repertory group in town, were the treat of Channel 13 last night in an hour-long special that saw Francis J. Peschka's puppet creations in inspired form. In a matter of moments the viewer entirely forgot that he was watching little figures and was made a party to the reality of droll amusement and poignancy.

LAS VEGAS, Nov., Nov. 22 -- Cassius Marcellus Clay used words to ridicule Floyd Patterson before the fight. Then he held him up to even worse ridicule in the ring tonight. The champion contemptuously toyed with his outclassed challenger and wore him down to a rubber-legged, helpless hulk before the referee mercifully ended the mismatch in the 12th.
The Pennzoil Company offered yesterday to buy a minimum of one million common shares of the United Gas Corporation at $41 a share. Unless extended, the offer will terminate on Dec. 14.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- B'nai B'rith adopted today a record budget of $4,887,000 for its youth programs next year.
Pan American World Airways, Inc., estimated yesterday that a sharp increase in passenger, mail and cargo traffic in October had enabled it to more than double its earnings for the month.
MIAMI, Nov. 22 -- Findings that may signal a major advance toward spiking the fury of hurricanes were reported at a scientific meeting here today.
SALISBURY, Nov. 22 -- Lord Graham, Rhodesia's Minister of Agriculture, warned tonight that Britain was placing herself dangerously in the hands of an American tobacco monopoly.

The lead editorial in your Nov. 15 issue deplores the existence of "unsafe foreign-flag vessels." Yet the editorial fails to mention that even with an occasional accident such as had occurred on board the Yarmouth Castle, ships, including foreign-flag ships, are still by far the safest mode of transportation.

GENEVA, Nov. 22 -- The Western maritime nations and the underdeveloped countries recognized today their failure to reach a compromise in the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development's Shipping Committee on the key issue of freight rates.
HONOLULU, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Five children, four of them girls, were found drowned in their suburban home today. The police charged the mother with first-degree murder.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 22 -- A grimacing, woozy Floyd Patterson praised Cassius Clay as "a tremendous fighter" tonight and refused to use his ailing back as an alibi for losing his game bid to regain the heavyweight title a second time.
The giant teamsters' union is facing the prospect of an intense power struggle within its ranks as possible successors to James R. Hoffa, now president, jockey for position.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The nation's birth rate continued to decline through September.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 22 -- A Morris County grand jury issued a presentment today denying that there was illicit sex, alcoholism and general chaos in the Greystone Park State Hospital.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Perth Amboy Evening News asked a Superior Court judge today to order the International Typographical Union to halt mass picketing at the newspaper plant.
ROME, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The fashion worlds of Rome and Florence, usually bitter rivals, are said to be negotiating an accord for the showings of spring and summer fashions in January.
SANTIAGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 22 -- Without firing a shot, troops loyal to provisional President Hector Garcia-Godoy blocked a rightist civilian attempt at a coup d'etat today.

The London Stock Exchange ended its opening session of the week lower in dull trading. Observers traced the inactivity to a lack of interest. The opening was quiet, but irregular, with changes in fractions.
ANATOMY OF BRITAIN TODAY. By Anthony Sampson. Revised from Anatomy of Britain: 1962. 720 pages. Harpers. $8.50.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Justice Abe Fortas delivered today his first opinion in which he spoke for the full Supreme Court. In it he explained why the Court had decided that the libel suit of a North Carolina concern against the United Steelworkers of America should be tried in a county court, rather than Federal court.
The Cunard liner Mauretania, one of the best-known trans-Atlantic and cruise liners in the Port of New York, logged her last mile yesterday.
BASTROP, La., Nov. 22 (AP) -- A freckle-faced 8-year-old, Nancy Keller, was released unharmed late today nearly 24 hours after having been kidnapped from the yard of her home.
TOBAY BEACH, L.I., Nov. 22 -- Bird watchers on this South Shore barrier beach have reported a remarkable influx of small owls.

RIO DE JANIERO, Nov. 22 -- A casting director would find in Vasco Leitao da Cunha, Brazil's Foreign Minister, the image of the classic Western diplomat. Elegant, urbane, witty, fluent in languages, patient and deft, Mr. Leitao da Cunha has dealt with many of the world's prominent figures, and earned their esteem, in 38 years of active diplomacy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A tiny bouquet of white lilies was placed on John Fitzgerald Kennedy's grave in the chill gray dawn today.
Once again Americans are being told by former Vice President Richard M. Nixon that all the United States has to do to win the war in Vietnam is to make it a much bigger war.
SAIGON, Nov. 22 -- South Vietnamese troops fought a two-hour pre-dawn battle with Vietcong guerrillas today on the country's largest rubber plantation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 -- Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Kaplan of New York scored a great triumph in the mixed pair national Fall championship, which ended here last night. They totaled 936 1/2; one of the biggest scores ever compiled in such an event, to win by more than two boards.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A major issue is developing here as critics of Government policy demand heavier bombings of North Vietnam.

THE two methods for roasting turkey given here are recommended by the National Turkey Federation for better flavor and appearance, minimum shrinkage and less loss of juices, but the preparation of the bird for any method is the same.
BOSTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Curt Blefary, the Baltimore Orioles' slugging outfielder who was spurned by the New York Yankees, was named today as the American League's 1965 rookie of the year.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The Goncourt Prize, the French literary award, was given today to a 39-year-old teacher of English for his first novel.
DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 22 -- A slow but steady increase in narcotics traffic in the commuter belt of southern Connecticut was described today by law-enforcement officers and social workers.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 22 -- It was a spectacularly silent ceremony at the Convention Center here today as Cassius Clay and Floyd Patterson weighed in.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 22 -- A New Zealand woman sipped a brandy last night in a neighbor's house near the line separating this city's Greek and Turkish communities and said, "I wonder if U Thant is serious about thinking of removing the United Nations force?"
Richard Robles listened impassively yesterday as his lawyers ended his defense by reading the alleged confession of George Whitmore Jr., in the slayings of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert.

AND now Cervantes and his ineffable Don Quixote have been transported to the popular musical theater. With the exception of a few vulgarities and some triteness, they have made the transition in "Man of La Mancha" with remarkable spirit and affection.

A $20 million issue of Japan Development Bank guaranteed external loan bonds, priced to yield 6.74 per cent, was sold out yesterday after it was offered publicly by a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation, Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and Smith, Barney Co., Inc.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Eight of the nation's top college football players were named today recipients of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame scholar-athlete awards for 1965.

Princess Grace of Monaco and the Duchess of Windsor have been named honorary chairmen of the ball in the Americana's Grand Ballroom that will follow the world premiere of "Doctor Zhivago" on Dec. 22. The film will be shown at the Loew's Capitol theater.
Physicians must get rid of the ingrained idea that Hodgkin's disease is always incurable and inevitably fatal, two widely known specialists said here yesterday.
Representative of more than 20 foreign-flag and United States steamship lines active in the cruise trade met formally here yesterday to explore the establishment of a West Indies cruise agreement.

THE eggplant has a way of inspiring purple prose. Volumes have been written about its purple skin and cool green flesh. But, when all is said and done, its most important properties are its bland flavor (which makes it an amicable companion for a variety of other foods) and its availability (virtually all year).
Directors of the Leeds and Northrup Company proposed yesterday in Philadelphia a two-for-one split of the common shares.

" It was a case of organized confusion." That was the statement made yesterday by Emile Francis, the New York Rangers' general manager, whose protest to a goal judge touched off a near-riot in the Blues' 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden Sunday night.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The newspaper, magazine and book publishing empire of Lord Thomson of Fleet grew bigger last weekend with the acquisition of Hamish Hamilton, Ltd., a well-known British book publisher.

John Atkins, a pianist who made his New York debut as a soloist with the Festival Orchestra last January, appeared in Town Hall last night to make his recital debut. His program consisted of Mozart's Fantasia in C minor (K. 475) and Sonata in C minor (K. 457), Barber's Sonata and Schubert's posthumous Sonata in B-flat.

" The Bit Between My Teeth: A Literary Chronicle of 1950-1965," by Edmund Wilson, will be published by Farrar, Straus Giroux next Monday. Along with "Shores of Light" and "Classics and Commercials," this book constitutes Mr. Wilson's chronicle of 45 years of English and American literary history.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Thieves seized $700,000 to $1,400,000 in jewelry this weekend from the strong room of Carrington, Ampers Co., Ltd., one of London's leading jewelers.

Flag Raiser enjoyed a brisk trip through the rain at Aqueduct yesterday. Isidor Bieber's front-runner led the field most of the way in the mile feature, and registered a five-length victory over the Saddle Rock Farm's Ornamento.
The American Smelting and Refining Company and the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company rolled back their copper price yesterday to 36 cents a pound from 38 cents.

In one column of your editorial page of Nov. 17 Dr. Nathaniel Shafer's letter commends the frontier spirit with which New Yorkers faced the blackout crisis. In another column you report the cold comfort that hot landmarks are receiving from some of the great corporations and churches of this city.

DANCE is the very devil of a big word, like paper or tree. What kind of dance are we being offered, what is its purpose, how far its development, who fathered and mothered it, and why? Sometimes it seems we are offered the raw material of dance for the dance itself.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Clayton Fritchey, Director of Public Affairs of the United States Mission to the United Nations, announced his resignation today. He will return to journalism as a news columnist in Washington.
There must be, say people who have seen Cassius Clay at both extremes, the "real" Clay somewhere between the loud, angry, berating man and the laughing, quick-witted, often shy youth.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., which operates the Gimbels and Saks Fifth Avenue stores in New York and elsewhere, reported yesterday record sales and increased earnings for the three, and nine-month periods ended Oct. 31.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court overturned today a decision by a special court that blocked merger of the Atlantic Coastline Railroad into the Seaboard Air Line Railroad.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 22 -- The police fired shots into the air tonight to disperse shouting, rock-throwing black nationalists in the most serious demonstration thus far against Rhodesia's 11-day-old rebel regime.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 22 (AP) -- John Lawson of Kansas scored an impressive victory in the annual National Collegiate cross-country championship today.
Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday, with some market averages sinking to their lowest levels in months.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 22 -- A second psychiatrist testified today that Duane Pope had no control over his actions last June 4 when he killed three persons in a bank robbery at Big Springs, Neb.

Army plans to mount a double-barreled passing threat against Navy on Saturday. Although the cadets have had what their coach, Paul Dietzel, calls a "delicate" aerial offense this season, he expects to have two accredited passers, instead of one, in his backfield.

Wheat traders who have been hoping for more export sales to Communist nations got some encouragement yesterday. The signing of a 700,000-ton wheat deal by the United States and Yugoslavia gave prices on the Chicago Board of Trade a fillip, pushing them up as high as 1 3/4 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Two Government agencies said today that a couple who were run out of McComb, Miss., in 1964 because of their racial views had been dropped from Federal jobs because they did not meet the necessary qualifications.
Dr. Frank C. Spencer has been named George David Stewart Professor and chairman of the department of surgery at New York University's School of Medicine, effective Jan. 1.

The self-imposed salary reduction to be taken by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay and his top aides will make no dent in New York's fiscal crisis. Like President Johnson's famed dim-out of the White House, its only value is symbolic. In fact, that is all that saves it from being a mere public-relations stunt.
Thomas W. Gleason, an arch foe of the Waterfront Commission, has urged that a policing and registration agency similar to the commission be set up in the congested and unorganized port of Saigon.

NATAL, Brazil, Nov. 22 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy and his wife flew to this small agricultural center in Brazil's northeast after attending mass in memory of President Kennedy at a 200-year-old church in Salvador today.

Ken Lucas, the quarterback who guided Pittsburgh to a 30-27 victory over favored Penn State last Saturday, was named to the final weekly Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference University Division all-East team.

In the Philippine election both major contenders proclaimed friendship for the United States, and foreign policy played no role in the contest. Despite traditionally violent political in-fighting, with truth often giving way to calumny, neither candidate sought to exploit a nascent anti-Americanism that threatened earlier in the year to become significant in the campaign.

FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Nov.22 -- President Johnson said today that neither the brevity of John F. Kennedy's term in office nor the passing of time would dim the memory of Mr. Kennedy's life and achievements.

HAZELTON, Iowa, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Amish children singing hymns and their parents fought off efforts by a truant officer and county officials today to remove them from their private school and take them to a public school and won a "moratorium'' on further efforts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 -- Federal Judge Lloyd H. Burke ruled today that Mach-Tronics, Inc., and four individual defendants were guilty of stealing trade secrets from the Ampex Corporation in the manufacturing of television tape recorders.
It was two years ago yesterday, Nov. 22, 1963. The terrible news came over the wires from Dallas -- President Kennedy and been fatally wounded.

Tom Gola will return to action tonight when the New York Knickerbockers meet the San Francisco Warriors in the feature game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden.

TRENTON, Nov. 22 -- Rutgers University was ordered by the State Supreme Court today to admit a student who had refused to be vaccinated on religious grounds, even though he belonged to no particular religious sect.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 22 -- The Yugoslav Government signed an agreement today to buy 700,000 tons of wheat from the United States today for nearly $46 million.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A Defense Department spokesman acknowledged tonight that fighter-bombers of nine North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies, including West Germany, were armed with American atomic warheads.

Of the 33 network television shows that started this fall, none are in the "top 10," according to the biweekly national rating report issued yesterday by the A.C. Nielsen Company. The ratings purport to reflect the programs watched by the largest number of viewers.
The Wayne Community School District in Michigan awarded last night $9.6 million of bonds to an underwriting syndicate headed by the First of Michigan Corporation.
The Rudin interests, planning a 44-story skyscraper, will pay nearly $20 million to acquire a site fronting on Park Avenue, which is needed to complete the block-square plot.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The New York Stock Exchange's decision to give its off-floor members greater representation in the governing bodies of the exchange was hailed today by Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Lou Rossini, the New York University basketball brain-truster, looked out the window in his office on the uptown camput yesterday and engaged in a coach's occupational privilege -- "iffing."
Reports of business gains came yesterday from three major retail chains as they began the pleasant task of putting up Christmas decorations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A Zenith Radio Corporation executive testified today that government embargoes on its products and patent pools cost his company rich markets in England, Australia and Canada.
The American Stock Exchange opened on an upbeat yesterday, then quickly reversed itself and turned lower in active trading.

ACCORDINC to the commentator at one of the recent showings of the American spring collections, a costume is distinguished from a simple dress by "wearability," or, as he explained in a question: "How many places can the outfit take you?"

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 23 -- One black man was shot dead in Bulawayo today as policemen struggled to break up chanting, dancing, stone-hurling mobs and bring order to the segregated black townships around Rhodesia's major cities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was "feeling fine" and in apparent good spirits as he checked in today at Walter Reed Army Medical Center to complete his recovery from a heart attack two weeks ago.
THE girl who wears glasses is a special favorite of Joyce Christopher, a blonde woman who presides over the beauty salon that bears her name at 80 East 56th Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board's Bureau of Operating Rights recommended today that three regional air carriers be selected for four new air routes between the Northwest and other areas of the country.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 23 -- Senior officers of the Dominican armed forces were involved in a rightist plot that led to an unsuccessful civilian uprising yesterday, according to a well-informed military source.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The California police were asked today to join the search for a 17-year-old girl who will be eligible to claim a $10 million inheritance five days before Christmas.

SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Linus C. Pauling said at his nearby ranch home today that he had not yet received the letter from Ho Chi Mink and "wouldn't want to comment until I do." He laid the letter apparently answered an appeal that he and other Nobel Prize winners sent in August to the heads of various governments concerned with the Vietnamese war, urging a negotiated settlement.
Investment bankers this week are earning a Thanksgiving Day rest. Yesterday they were busy working on about half a billion dollars of long-term securities.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 23 -- Attorneys for Duane Pope read aloud today a 189-page record of an interview they had with the 22-year-old Kansas farm youth shortly after he killed three persons in a Nebraska bank robbery last June.
Your Nov. 12 editorial "Heir to the City's Bankruptcy" raises a question that must soon be confronted by all New Yorkers: Where is the money to be found to support a civilized city?

An effort to achieve a three-year Soviet-United States moratorium on the production and deployment of anti- missile missile systems is being urged on President Johnson by a high-level citizens' panel on disarmament.

WITH appropriate bows, nods and yawns to other scribes, intimate recollectors and eulogists of the Kennedy era -- this is the book we have all been waiting for. Our high anticipation has been more than justified.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Organizers of a Washington peace demonstration scheduled for Saturday issued a list of "authorized sign slogans" today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23, The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today -- in the face of unanimous opposition from major organizations in the securities industry -- that the First National City Bank of New York be permitted to create and manage a mutual fund.

Trading on the London Stock Exchange closed steady yesterday after a day of generally quiet activity with most stocks irregular. Observers traced the lack of buying to uncertainties over the situation in Rhodesia.
The Apple Valley Building and Development Company of California will be merged into the Reserve Oil and Gas Company of Los Angeles, it was announced yesterday by both companies.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (UPD -- Murray (The Camel) Humphreys, reputed political fixer for Chicago's crime syndicate, died tonight of an apparent heart attack several hours after he had tried to hold off F.B.L agents with a loaded revolver.

Mike Garrett, a very fast but not very big halfback for Southern California, was voted the Heisman Trophy yesterday by 791 electors whose goal it was to determine college football's best player of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Bill Elias said today at a Touchdown Club luncheon gathering of Navy brass, headed by Admiral David McDonald, chief of Naval Operations, that he was experiencing for the first time the "phenomenal massiveness" of an Army-Navy football game.

THE Italian Liszt. The Operatic Liszt. The Faustian Liszt. The Transcendental Liszt. The Hungarian Liszt. And quite a few more Liszts, all being explored by Raymond Lewenthal. Last night in Town Hall he gave the second of three concerts devoted to the piano music of Franz Liszt.

Two critical bottlenecks in disarmament talks have been cleared away in recent months by the pressure world opinion has exerted on the nuclear superpowers through the United Nations. Yesterday the United States wisely indicated its willingness, at long last, to accept the participation of Communist China in a world disarmament conference.
The Federal Maritime Commission rejected yesterday a suggestion it said a group of European ship owners had made that the commission not publicize its enforcement of certain shipping laws.
THERE is nothing sheepish about the Macdonalds, a family of Scots who turned a single jacket into a prospering business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The feelings of the nation this Thanksgiving week are bound to be mixed. There is great prosperity and great anxiety, substantial progress in some areas and alarming problems elsewhere.
Gen. Thomas S. Power, who retired last year as commander in chief of the Strategic Air Command, was elected yesterday to the board of the Bucyrus-Erie Company, a manufacturer of excavating machinery.
The four top officials of the City University who announced that they were quitting because of a dispute with the Board of Higher Education have arranged to meet with Mayor Wagner on Saturday.

Secretary of Commerce John T. Conner urged several hundred executives of the chemical industry last night to start thinking about the need for a change in the ground rules of future tariff negotiations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Jesse Owens, winner of four gold medals in the 1936 Olympics, pleaded not guilty today in Federal court to a four-count complaint charging him with failure to file income tax returns for the years 1959 through 1962 on a total income of slightly more than $59,000.
The International Business Machines Corporation has named C.F. Vough and H.S. Beattie as vice presidents in its office products division.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 23 -- Colombia lined up today with an influential minority at this Inter-American Conference opposed to a United States plan for a Western Hemisphere peace force.
High school students in Darien, Conn., were called overprotected and likened to "flowers in a greenhouse" in a report issued yesterday on the community's schools and civil rights.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Studebaker Corporation offered today a bonus of $150 worth of Christmas gifts to buyers who purchase new Studebakers between now and I Dec 25

CHESTER, Ill., Nov. 23 (AP) -- A handful of prisoners rioted at Menard State Penitentiary tonight and killed three guards with homemade knives. They took three other guards hostage before surrendering to 300 guards and state troopers who surrounded them in the prison kitchen.
Your Nov. 18 editorial on "The Admission of China" might have been more to the point if you had followed through with your initial assertion that "None of the major protagonists emerges with credit."
On the eve of a basketball season in which a Columbia University unit finally boasts considerable height, four of the Lions' arch Ivy rivals report that they are standing pretty tall, too.
A $1 million gift to Lincoln Center by Shelby Cullom Davis, a New York City insurance broker, was announced yesterday.
Shareholders of the M.A. Hanna Company approved yesterday a management proposal to liquidate the big closed-end investment concern.
Directors of the Anaconda Company declared here yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents a common share, payable Dec. 27 to holders of record Dec. 3.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23 -- Edgar Kaplan and Victor Mitchell of New York maintained a narrow lead into the final session of the Life Master Men's Pair Championship here this afternoon.

" Presidential Government: The Crucible of Leadership," by James MacGregor Burns, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Jan. 20. That day is the fifth anniversary of the inauguration of President Kennedy and the first anniversary for President Johnson.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The Political Committee of the General Assembly, by a vote of 91 to 0, adopted a resolution today calling for a world disarmament conference that would include Communist China.

Britain's Conservative party has given the world the unfortunate impression that it has deserted Prime Minister Harold Wilson in his effort to smash the white revolt in Rhodesia. California sold $100 million of water bonds yesterday to a syndicate led by the Bank of America and the First National City Bank.

An offering of $150 million of General Motors Acceptance Corporation 4 7/8 per cent debentures due Dec. 1, 1987, was priced at 99, providing a yield of about 4.95 per cent to maturity.

Botany Industries, Inc., a leading manufacturer and retailer of men's apparel, announced plans yesterday to add 20 additional stores by the end of the fiscal year.

Ruth McAneny Loud has been elected president of the 73-year-old Municipal Art Society to fill the unexpired term of Whitney North Seymour Jr. She is the first woman to serve in that capacity.

John V. Lindsay's campaign machine has reported to the Board of Elections that it spent more than $2.5 million on his successful campaign for Mayor. Statements filed by 12 Lindsay committees showed at the same time that the campaign was in debt for about $88,000.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 23 -- The Treasury's new offering of one-year bills sold today at the highest yields ever recorded since these securities began to be sold on a regular monthly basis in September, 1963.

The Newspaper Guild broke off negotiations with The Daily News last night and announced that it was preparing to take any action necessary, including a strike, to achieve a satisfactory contract.

The Police Department has developed a new tactical tool against street crime -- a flying unit of scooter patrolmen known informally as the Scramble Patrol.

He toyed with a water glass just: as he had toyed with Floyd Patterson two hours earlier in their so-called bout for the heavyweight championship of the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Thirty-three young women, 20 of them from Washington, will be presented on Thursday at the 16th Debutante Cotillion and Thanksgiving Ball, in the Sheraton-Park Hotel.
MIAMI, Nov. 23 -- The cruise ship Yarmouth Castle made her last voyage with only one radio operator, and she lacked the three liferafts required under a 1960 international safety convention.
Acting Labor Commissioner James J. McFadden last night set Dec. 3 as the date for the largest collective-bargaining election involving municipal employes in city history.
MIAMI, Nov. 23 -- The cruise ship Yarmouth Castle made her last voyage with only one radio operator, and she lacked the three liferafts required under a 1960 international safety convention.
Acting Labor Commissioner James J. McFadden last night set Dec. 3 as the date for the largest collective-bargaining election involving municipal employes in city history.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The Soviet Union and Communist China are keeping pace with a massive increase of radio sets in underdeveloped Africa and Asia with more broadcasting, according to the British Broadcasting Corporation's annual report.
The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday important changes in its top management, effective Dec. 1, with the retirement of W.K. White-ford as chairman and chief executive officer.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Flash floods triggered by heavy rains throughout Southern California caused at least three deaths today.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Goals by Fred Stanfield and Phil Esposito within a 29-second span of the second period spurred the Chicago Black Hawks to a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- France hinted today that she would make a voluntary contribution to the United Nations if the organization moved forward with economies and budget reforms that she has proposed.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A complete agreement was announced early this morning on a proposed contract to end the strike of some 17,000 machinists against the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation of St. Louis, which manufactures Gemini spacecraft and Phantom jet fighter planes.
Perhaps reflecting the general prosperity in the country, cigar smokers are increasingly puffing away on the more expensive brands.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23 -- Almost all the 20,000 computers in use across the United States today are owned by big business, which alone has been able to afford the high price tags put on these electronic giants.
THAKHEK, Laos, Nov. 23 -- The Laotian Army took 13 North Vietnamese prisoners when resistance in a cave seven miles east of Thakhek collapsed today. They included a North Vietnamese Army captain.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 23 -- The women's field hockey team of Britain and Ireland scored its 19th victory in 20 games in a tour of the United States by defeating an All-College team 4-1, today at Swarthmore College.
PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Nov. 23 -- A 24-year-old Marine sergeant, a Negro, was acquitted tonight of charges that he had beaten seven South Carolina white youths assigned to him for basic training here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The DC-3 flying as a fighter plane in Vietnam first flew 30 years ago.
Mayor Wagner's expected appointment of Jacob Lutsky, his legal aide, as a judge of the Family Court ought not set a pattern for filling the other vacancies on that court.
The Four Seasons glowed with Thanksgiving, decor last night for one of the leading social events of the season -- a farewell dance and buffet supper for Princess Margaret and the Earl of Snowdon.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Four men who said they were bodyguards for Cassius Clay were arrested for disturbing the peace last night during the Clay-Floyd Patterson heavyweight title fight. They were freed on $25 bond each.

It was William Dooley's turn to sing the role of Mandryka in Richard Strauss's "Arabella" at the Metropolitan Opera last night -- a first time for him at the house. Always an interesting actor, the American baritone made Mandryka a notably appealing figure, slightly shy and hesitant with an occasional gaucherie to suggest the character's provincial background.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Bandits stole hand-carved Chinese jade valued at $250,000 from an art gallery today but made sure a trussed-up guard was comfortable before they left.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 23 -- The White House announced today that President Johnson and Prime Minister Wilson Would meet Dec. 17 for a broad discussion of issues affecting both the United States and Britain and their allies.

The Chicago Bears, named by Joe Walton as "the best team I've seen this year," will play the New York Giants in Yankee Stadium Sunday with eight players the Giants know little about in the line-up. These eight represent the renaissance of the Bears, who won the league championship in 1963, collapsed in 1964 and have come back a long way this season.

The Government told the copper industry yesterday it would restrict exports of copper scrap next year to less than half of this year's level. It also announced final agreement with the aluminum industry for the disposal of surplus stockpiled aluminum.
Consolidated Edison's board of directors approved plans yesterday to build a second nuclear-fueled electric generator adjoining its Indian Point plant in Westchester.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A Cabinet Minister said today that President Sukarno would dissolve the Indonesian Communist party and affiliated organizations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- -- The Johnson Administration, having joined the civil rights movement, is learning something of its complexities and ambiguities.
The American Stock Exchange has reported the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 -- Navy has been established the favorite over Army by a touchdown in their 66th football game at Philadelphia Saturday. Today a member of the coaching staff explained why he believed the odds were justified.
Princess Margaret said good-by to the United States yesterday afternoon, and called the parting "a very sad moment."
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- President de Gaulle hinted today that he might be willing to abandon his opposition to British membership in the European Common Market.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Spanish Davis Cup team shocked Australian officials today by announcing it would not play in two major tournaments here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Government, which has already moved to sell stockpiled copper and aluminum to check price increases, has now offered to sell high-quality wheat to processors to head off a possible rise in the price of bread.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Floyd Patterson took hypnosis treatments for seven or eight days before his fight with Cassius Clay, a hypnotist, Johnny Alladin, said today.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- General de Gaulle's comment on Britain and Europe was welcomed here today as warming the climate, but qualified sources foresaw no early, dramatic move by the British Government to seek entry into the Common Market.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Southern California, digging out from a storm that left five persons dead and several missing, was hit today by more rain, with still more on the way.

A grant of $3 million to New York Medical College-Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital for a five-story building as a center for the mentally retarded was announced yesterday by the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

" L'amour, toujours, l'amour, fellas, but, please, not during basketball practice."

The operators of 121 ocean-going vessels still in the Great Lakes west of the Welland Canal were warned yesterday by the Canadian St. Lawrence Seaway Authority that they were running a grave risk of being trapped by ice.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian, writes in his book "A Thousand Days" that President Kennedy never gave "his full attention" to the problem of Vietnam.

The success of this week's two biggest issues -- $150 million of General Motors Acceptance Corporation debentures and $100 million of California water resources bonds -brought a scattering of gains throughout the bond market.
DETROIT, Nov. 2, (AP) -- The nation's auto make posted their biggest Thanksgiving week production record in history this week, according to figures compiled by the trade publication Automotive News.
The three-year feud that split the Brooklyn Democratic party ended yesterday as Stanley Steingut, county leader, received expressions of loyalty from 11 officials who had sought to depose him.

This book about the American male is too humorous a size to be taken seriously, in spite of its bibliography and index. It does not in any way resemble the weighty expositions, usually written by psychiatrists, that try to help the American woman adjust to her role in modern life. And one must admit Mrs. Kendall makes it hard for the reader prepared to be alarmed at what is happening to American men.

It sometimes seems that we perpetuate a tradition of thanks that has lost its meaning. The annual feast of plenty becomes an irony in a time when American harvests so far exceed the American need that they create a problem in themselves. But such a line of thought misses the essential point, which we too often forget.

IN their coast-to-coast travels Eastern football teams lost their hopes for good records this season. The Big Five of major Eastern teams stumbled over the likes of Southern California, Notre Dame, Georgia Tech, Stanford, Tennessee, Miami of Florida and the University of California, Los Angeles.
The sign-making industry argued at City Hall yesterday for the right to put up larger and higher "artistic" signs on commercial buildings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- United States exports rose 2 per cent in October, the Commerce Department reported today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 24 -- A wave of malaria resistant to known drugs is sweeping through United States combat units in South Vietnam.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge David B. Furman issued a temporary restraining order today barring the International Typographical Union from obstructing employes from entering or leaving The Perth Amboy Evening News.

The bitterness of top banking officials in the Soviet Union over the Kremlin's inadequate allocation of trained manpower and modern electronic equipment to the Soviet banking system has finally burst into the open.

Drexel Co., an old Philadelphia name in banking, and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., a major New York underwriting concern, announced yesterday their intention to consolidate their business activities next Feb. 1.
PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A United States helicopter plucked a wounded American soldier from the Iadrang River valley today after he had hidden in the jungle there for seven days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- In a countermove to Vietnam protest demonstrations, the American Legion disclosed plans today to distribute 100,000 "Show Your Colors" lapel buttons at the Army-Navy football game in Philadelphia Saturday.
COWARD, S.C., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Private Braveboy's family, aware since Monday that he was missing in action, voiced exultation today on hearing of his rescue.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Twenty-six nations presented a draft resolution today urging the suspension of all nuclear weapons tests and universal respect for the spirit and provisions of the treaty banning all but underground tests.
An increase of 1,226,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline supplies in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
McDonnell Co., Inc, a New York Stock Exchange member firm, reported yesterday that it had acquired the manager and distributor of the Peoples Securities Corporation, a $16 million mutual fund.

While entertaining guests recently, a young executive placed a cocktail shaker on a window seat. A gust of wind twirled the curtains around the glass container, and sent it plummeting six stories to the street, where it struck and seriously injured a man, who sued.

A nationwide alarm for a 7-year-old Staten Island girl, who had been abducted from her divorced father's home by a woman police say may be her mother, was expanded yesterday to determine whether the child might have been taken out of the country.
Ill-prepared, under-rehearsed performers, so often the reason new music doesn't get a real chance, were nowhere to be seen or heard in Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

VERONA revisted -- and the Royal Danish Ballet's production of Frederick Ashton's exquisitely diagramatic drama "Romeo and Juliet" still looked sadly shabby with its aging realization of Peter Rice's dated designs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A Federal advisory committee reported today it had found no evidence that use of contraceptive pills could cause eye disorders.
The lame-duck Wagner administration and the incoming Lindsay administration clashed yesterday over the development of Willets Point Park in northern Queens.

BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Nov. 24 (AP) -- An oil tanker and a freighter, interlocked after a collision near Cape Cod, were separated today after 11,500 barrels of oil had been taken from the crippled tanker.

The Beanery, quite possibly the smallest, seediest bistro ever to hit Manhattan, opened Tuesday night and, masochists that they are, New Yorkers were standing in line to get in. The atmosphere couldn't be more authentic -- a crowd of built-in barflies, a jukebox blare of sound, and a stale beer smell you could cut with a knife.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 24 -- Provisional President Hector Garcia-Godoy today replaced a controversial leftist who had held a key position in his regime.

Capt. Lloyd G. Sealy, the first Negro to command a Harlem precinct, was promoted yesterday to deputy inspector by Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick.
The Transport Workers Union said yesterday that there would be "no extensions whatsoever" of its 5 A.M. New Year's Day strike deadline on the city's transit system.
The Lasdon Foundation of New York City yesterday announced a $200,000 grant to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and a $250,000 grant to New York Hospital.

Administration officials have been hinting that there is need for reinforcing the so-called voluntary guidelines on outflow of capital since the nation's balance of payments reported a deficit in the third quarter. WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Commerce Department announced plans today for release of 200,000 tons of copper from the national stockpile for defense purposes.
OLEAN, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller outlined today new proposals for encouraging new businesses or expanding old ones in New York State.
New Yorkers by the thousands headed for home early yesterday, for a holiday today of relaxation, family gatherings, Thanksgiving turkey and prayer.
A king kleagle of the Ku Klux Klan has been dismissed from his job as a social worker for the city Welfare Department on the grounds of "incompetence and misconduct."
The Wallace-Murray Corporation, which was formed Sept. 1 through a merger of the William Wallace Corporation and the Murray Corporation, moved yesterday to acquire the Simonds Saw and Steel Company.

WINDSOR, Ont., Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Ontario Supreme Court approved today the application by the General Acceptance Corporation's international subsidiary to take over management of receivables and acquisition of new sales finance and personal loan paper for the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation.
A Federal judge rejected yesterday a $1,291,996 against the Government by a naturalized German-American on the ground that the claimant was a wartime Nazi agent who aided the German Navy.
A suspended policeman was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn grand jury for the murder of Dr. Milton Lopyan last summer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Two top Republicans in the House of Representatives said today that growing public concern over the war in Vietnam was likely to make it a major issue in the 1966 political campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower will eat Thanksgiving dinner with his family tomorrow at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, his doctors reported today.
The British pound was steady in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Its closing quotation of $2.8041 was the same as Tuesday.

KEOKUK, Iowa, Nov. 24 -- A Thanksgiving eve explosion and fire demolished a National Guard Armory here tonight, killing at least six persons and injuring at least 45 others who had been attending a square dance.

The Little Angels a group of South Korean youngsters, entertained youthful and adult patients yesterday at the New York University Medical Center's Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, 400 East 34th Street.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 24 -- President and Mrs. Johnson appeared at the Driskill Hotel here tonight to watch a preview of the film on the capital that will be shown to a nationwide television audience tomorrow night.

Yale University Press has sold 5,000 copies of "The Vinland Map and the Tartar Relation," at $15 a copy, printed 5.000 more to meet mounting orders and sold to the Book-of-the Month Club rights to issue the volume as a book dividend in March.

EVEN if Joe Namath didn't wear white shoes in a 1 P.M. football game or dark glasses on a 9 P.M. stroll, he would stand out -- on or off the field.

Gary G. of the Harbor View Farm took to the mile distance as if he really liked it in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Adverse side effects said to be caused by impurities in a tranquilizer have caused the drug's maker to recall the affected lots from druggists and patients, the Food and Drug Administration reported today.

The Ramsey Lewis trio, riding the crest of its hit recording, "The In Crowd,," drew a capacity audience to Carnegie Hall last night. A computer engineer who promised investors a return of up to 10 per cent in a $361,000 realty promotion has been barred from the securities business in this state.

The Newspaper Guild announced yesterday that it would strike The Daily News at 6 P.M. tomorrow unless a new contract had been agreed upon at that time.

The 17th Debutante Ball of the Junior League of New York last night at the Plaza honored 46 of the season's debutantes, who are provisional members of the league, and benefited the league's welfare trust fund. TOKYO, Nov. 24 -- Major Japanese business and industrial concerns, reflecting the effects of a continuing economic recession, showed a decline of more than 20 per cent in profits during the six months ended Sept. 30, recent corporate surveys disclose.

Pete Seeger, who set off a controversy in upstate Beacon when he volunteered for a benefit performance in the high school there, will perform as scheduled Saturday night.

Phil Silvers, who will always be Sergeant Bilko to millions of viewers, will make a pilot film next month in the hope of returning to television in the fall of 1966.

Most stocks advanced in very active trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

Bowker, the institution's chancellor, and three other top officials. WASHINGTON -- "The last time we had nothing to do," the Marquesa Mercedes Ocio de Merry del Val, wife of the Spanish Ambassador, said recently, "was approximately three months ago. It was a Monday, as I recall, and we improvised a dinner for 10. It lasted until 2 A.M."

The New York Times Nov. 14 editorial "A Lesson of the Blackout" states that "engineers speak wryly... of what they call Murphy's Second Law. This holds that if a mechanism or a process can possibly break down, then it will break down some time, somewhere, somehow."

Sidney L. Solomon, chairman of Abraham Straus, and Marianne Charlier, the Miss Bergdorf merchandiser of Bergdorf Goodman, have been named winners of the 1965 Tobe Awards.
More than half a million fans -- most of them in New Jersey -- are expected at stadiums in the metropolitan area today as the school football season draws to a close.

MIAMI, Nov. 24 -- The 33-year-old master of the Yarmouth Castle swore today that he had upheld the noblest tradition of the sea by being the last to leave the cruise ship before she sank in flames off the Bahamas on Nov. 13 with a loss of 89 lives.

Common stocyholders of the General Baking Company approved yesterday at a special meeting at 11 A.M. in the New York Hilton Hotel a plan under which Eddy Bakeries Company, Inc., would be merged into General Baking.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 24 -- A rare biography of file eighth-century founder of Tibetan Buddhism, printed some 50 years ago from wooden blocks in an isolated Himalayan monastery, has been donated to the Yale University Library.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell failed again yesterday to show up in court with his financial records.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Detroit Lions, knocked out of the National Football League title race by an inept offense, will attempt to play a "spoiler" role tomorrow when they play the Baltimore Colts.

Fieldston Hill, 13-acre estate of Edward C. Delafield and one of the last grand estates in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, has been given to Columbia University for botanical teaching and research.

Poulenc's "The Dialogues of the Carmelites" will be presented by the New York City Opera Company during its first season at Lincoln Center. The opera, which concerns the martyrdom of Carmelite nuns during the French Revolution, will be receiving its first fully staged production here. It opens March 3 at the New York State Theater.

Another legal obstacle to construction of the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan was overcome yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

A stepped up campaign to attract light manufacturing industries to Barbados, the British island in the eastern Caribbean, got under way yesterday at a news conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

But not even the wildest high roller in that desert Babylon would have dared risk a pfennig on the likelihood of Lieut. Gen. William Dole Eckert, a million-to-one shot, being named as the new baseball commissioner.

Judge Leonard P. Moore received yesterday the Emory Buckner Medal for outstanding public service from the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The presentation was made at a Thanksgiving luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee threatened yesterday to call a citywide strike next Tuesday night.

A downswing in prices of wheat futures and an upswing in cocoa and pork bellies captured the interest of commodity futures traders yesterday.

The nation's electric power production rose 7.4 per cent in the week ended No. 20, from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

Users of liquid sulphur dioxide, a chemical used for such purposes as paper bleaching, oil refining and leather tanning, were told yesterday that three makers planned to raise prices for the basic product starting Jan. 1.

Milau Associates, Inc., industrial builders, have immediate plans for an industrial center on a 56-acre tract in the Congers area of Clarkstown in Rockland County.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 -- A general strike in British Columbia was averted today after Premier W.A.C. Bennett dictated terms of settlement to labor and management and won almost instant acceptance.

The chain of life on this planet is longer and more complex than had previously been realized. Democrats who control the City Council plan to meet Tuesday with the Council President-elect, Frank D. O'Connor, in a unity move that will point up the Council's probable relationship with the incoming Lindsay fusion administration.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Two leaders of a Cuban exile group were arrested today and charged with conspiring to extort money from other Cubans.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- In the largest auction of modern art here in many years, 79 paintings and one sculpture were sold tonight for $2.4 million.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 25 -- A steady stream of misinformation about the war in Vietnam is reaching the American public.
The city will give its last "walk-in" examinations of the year tomorrow in its drive to add 700 patrolmen to the 2,000-man Transit Police Force.
LONDON, Nov. 25 (Reuters) -- The death of the multimillionaire Emir of Kuwait posed a problem for London financiers and stockbrokers today.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz predicted yesterday that Governor Rockefeller would be re-elected next year "because he will succeed in putting over the message of what he has done for the people and what he expects to do."
KURGAN-TYUBE, U.S.S.R., Nov. 25 -- A loudspeaker in the public square of the Kuibyshev State Farm blares forth radio programs in Russian, Tadzhik and Uzbek languages from 9 A.M. until 10 P.M.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The University of Texas struck for three touchdowns in 12 minutes of the last half today to defeat Texas A. M., 21-17 in their season finale.

Miss Anne Curtis Browne, debutante daughter of Mrs. Gilbert Goodwin Browne of 215 East 72d Street and the late Mr. Browne, was honored at a dinner dance given by her mother last night at the Colony Club.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- "The race for the top is finished," General Mobutu declared today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 25 -- Jorge Velasquez, riding Mrs. C.F. Parke's Pollux, withstood a two-horse challenge in the stretch, to win the first half of the opening-day feature, the $10,000 added Hurricane Handicap, today at Tropical Park.
LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Prime Minister Wilson announced tonight a drive in Washington and Moscow to get Vietnam peace talks started.
TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 25 (UPI) -- With the crack of a pistol shot, a Vietcong guerrilla thought he had killed Sgt. John Eade last week.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Three persons were killed and two others were missing and feared buried by rubble in a fire that early today swept a three-story building used to house employes and overflow guests of the New Irvington Hotel here.
The major struggle for control of ship container operations over North Atlantic routes has been taken before a Federal court.
The overtaxed Humane Society of New York is seeking to expand its limited facilities sevenfold -- from 50 to 350 first class accommodations for vagrant dogs and cats.

CARACAS. Venezuela, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The mystery of the disappearance of a 17-year-old girl due to inherit a Swiss fortune of $10 million shortly before Christmas, was solved today when she turned up here -- married and the mother of a baby daughter.

A steady stream of well-wishers dropped by the 23d-floor office of James P Mahony at Broad and Wall Streets Wednesday in what was a kind of informal farewell ceremony combined with a nod in the direction of history.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Prime Minister Wilson said today that his official residence needed more repairs -- three years after about $3 million was spent in renovating it and two adjoining houses.

Efforts to avert a threatened strike at The Daily News continued behind the scenes yesterday, but critical bargaining lies ahead today before the 6 P.M. deadline set for a walkout by the Newspaper Guild.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Intercity truck tonnage for the week ended Nov. 20 was 7.2 per cent ahead of the volume for the corresponding week of 1964, the American Trucking Associations, Inc., announced today.
