" Three Faces of Fascism: Action Francaise, Italian Fascism, National Socialism," by Ernest Nolte, will be published by Holt, Rinehart Winston on Jan. 10. The author was born in 1923 in Witten-on-Ruhr, Germany, and is now professor of history at Marburg University.
Cardinal Hayes is back where it started.
MIAMI, Nov. 25 -- How and why marine animals look and act the way they do was discussed at an international meeting on tropical oceanography here yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- R.C. Kidder's Flag won the second division of the $70,600 Dixie Handicap at Pimlico today in 2:29, bettering the 1 1/2-mile turf course record of 2:30 1-5 set minutes before by Or et Argent in the first division.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., and Herb FitzGibbon of Garden City, L.I., advanced to the second round of the Victorian tennis championship today at the expense of Australian opponents.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York told a university audience today the Brazilian students would do well to complain less and worry more about their needy fellow countrymen.

Far from a convict-coddling measure, the proposal by Acting Labor Commissioner James J. McFadden that the city establish a corporation to bond persons who have served prison terms can be a double-barreled boon to the community. It would act as an ultimate deterrent to crime; it would also help hold down the relief rolls.

PARIS, Nov. 25 (Reuters) -- The United States today called on the Western industrial powers to set up a study group for speeding assistance to the developing countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani caused a minor political storm here today with an interview in which he indicated dissent from Italy's vote to bar Communist China from the United Nations.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Reg Fleming scored two goals and assisted on another tonight while leading the last-place Boston Bruins to a 6-2 victory over the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Hawks nipped a late scoring rally by Guy Rodgers tonight and defeated the San Francisco Warriors, 119-113, in a National Basketball Association game.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Pete Larson ran for three touchdowns and Bill Wilson, all-Ivy fullback, carried for 126 yards and the league rushing honors today as Cornell defeated Pennsylvania, 38-14, before a crowd of 10,543 at Franklin Field.

BONN, Nov. 25 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard, who was to have left next Wednesday for talks with President Johnson, has postponed his departure until Dec. 18 because of his "tight schedule," a spokesman for the West German Government announced tonight.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Bill Anderson, his team behind twice, threw scoring passes of 60, 61 and 63 yards in the fourth quarter today to give Tulsa a 48-20 victory over stubborn Colorado State. The victory gave Tulsa its second straight trip to the Bluebonnet Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- About 60,000 of the country's largest employers would be required to file annual reports on their minority hiring practices under a proposal announced tonight by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission

DAYLIGHT exposes the natural tawdriness of Las Vegas and heightens the boredom that the excitement-seeking night people contrive to escape. For a couple of hours last Sunday morning, however, ennui was dispersed. The Chicago Bears came stampeding across the television screen from a different time zone and gave an eye-opening demonstration of their newly regained ferocity by beating the Detroit Lions, 17-10, in a rowdy, roughneck display of high-voltage content.
DALLAS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A young man strolled into the Dallas fine arts museum munching a sandwich yesterday, and a guard, William R. Kennedy, ordered him out. No food is allowed in the building.

GENEVA, Nov. 25 -- The International Red Cross Committee is dissatisfied with the way the United States and South Vietnamese Governments observe their pledge to respect the Geneva conventions protecting war victims, a committee source said today.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The French presidential campaign has suddenly become interesting, lively and, to the surprise of nearly everyone, a contest.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Johnny Unitas threw three touchdown passes -- two of them to John Mackey in the fourth quarter -- as the Baltimore Colts rallied to gain a 24-24 tie with the Detroit Lions today in a National Football League game.

IN a world dark with ominous headlines and ugliness, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson's television program last night was an island of beguiling beauty and loveliness. It was ever so much more than a tour of Washington; it was an enchanting interlude of serenity that healed and refreshed the spirit.
WITH Leonard Bernstein back on the podium, the New York Philharmonic resumed last night its survey of 20th-century symphonic forums. Two works two widely contrasting works occupied the program.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- New Rochelle defeated Iona Prep, 6-2, today before more than 10,000 at McKenna Field in the 18th game of their intracity football series.

TORONTO, Nov. 25 -- Frequent reference is made these days to a suggested North American energy program. Such a project envisions joint planning for the development and integration of the electric power, petroleum, coal and nuclear resources of the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Retail sales in tile week ended Nov. 20 amounted to $5.77 billion, 9 per cent higher than the total in the corresponding week last year, the Commerce Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Rail carloadings for the week ended Nov. 20 were 601,953 cars, an increase of four-tenths of 1 per cent over the comparable week of 1964, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 -- A New Yorker browsing at a Toronto news stand should feel at home. The display is dominated by hundreds of familiar American publications. The half-dozen Canadian magazines seem an afterthought.

For Myra Hess, as for her fellow Londoners, the grim years when Britain stood alone against Nazi Germany and endured the Luftwaffe's daylight air raids were life's finest hour. CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Ski enthusiasts got a little early sport today as Cannon Mountain at Franconia Notch in the White Mountains opened its lower slopes.

Nowadays, as France's major trans-Atlantic port, it is the point of arrival for many ship-traveling American visitors; it is also a handy place from which to explore the oldest road between Paris and the sea.

Clearly something more than better management is needed to cope with the crisis.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Jimmy Brown scored four touchdowns today to lead the Cleveland Browns to a 42-21 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League game.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Trouble developed today in a guidance-system power supply in the Gemini 7 spacecraft. Space agency officials were hopeful it would not delay the spacecraft's launching, scheduled for Saturday.
Those who oppose American policy in Vietnam have a right to speak but those who support it have an obligation to shout, according to a statement circulated by Freedom House.
All assembly of 400 clerics called yesterday for a re-examination of American policy in Vietnam by a White House conference of scholars, religious leaders and Asian experts.
The prosecution opened its case yesterday against William Epton, the Harlem Progressive Labor Movement leader, on charges of trying to overthrow by force the government of New York State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -The Administration was urged today to raise the level of foreign aid and to place increasing emphasis on helping developing nations enlarge their food production and curb their growing populations.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary, Michael Stewart, arrived today for the third session of East-West discussions on international issues in the last month. The Soviet leaders, including both Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist Party's First Secretary, prepared to discuss a wide range of world problems with the British diplomat during four days of intensive talks.
Steel production fell 1 per cent last week, which included Thanksgiving Day, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Three 18-year-old youths, one of whom was to be married today, were arrested last night after what the police said was a two-day holdup spree to finance the wedding.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 29 (UPI) -- President Johnson was said today to be both pleased and concerned by reports about features of the national economy.

ROSWELL, N.M., Nov. 29 -It is a touch of irony that the individual considered by many to be one of the finest authorities on the cooking of New Mexico was born in Manhattan of a British father. She is Mrs. Vernon Knapp, a stately, talkative and amiable resident of this community known for its ranching, agriculture, air base, school and an impressive number of retired millionaires.
A new labor-management council has been formed to keep the production of filmed television commercials from drifting West.
The New York Knickerbockers dismissed Harry Gallatin as coach last night and replaced him with Dick McGuire, another former Knick star.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 29 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said tonight that it seemed clear that North Vietnam had elected to "raise the level of conflict" and that the inescapable conclusion was that "it will be a long war."

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer James Callaghan warned Britain today that he would have to take further deflationary measures if economic recovery is threatened by continued steeply rising costs.
The Sperry Rand Corporation announced yesterday the development of a new computing system utilizing advanced integrated circuits that will be marketed as the Univac 1108 II.

TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today that the leaders of the incoming Senate had agreed to abolish the practice of "Senatorial courtesy" -- a controversial system under which individual members can secretly block gubernatorial appointments.
BOGOTA, Colombia -- The flow of mass international aid to Colombia, which was cut off during the last year pending economic reforms, will be resumed shortly.

BEFORE the Baltimore Colts had a chance to toast the upset of the pursuing Green Bay Packers by the Los Angeles Rams, the onrushing Chicago Bears rudely jostled the upraised glass. The overpowering performance of the Monsters of the Midway against the Giants brought a sobering pause to any premature celebration because the Bears are the Colts' next opponent.
Robert Moses yesterday characterized as an "absurd gimmick" the latest proposal that funds of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority be used to help finance the city's transit system.
TOKYO, Nov. 29 -- Prospects of stiff increases in basic living costs next year have diminished Japan's joy over the impending golden shower of New Year's bonuses.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 29 -- The Federal Government took its turn today at trying to do what the state of Alabama has twice failed to do -- convict a member of the Ku Klux Klan in connection with the murder of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo.
THE New York Giants are less than enthusiastic about their selections in last weekend's draft of college players while the Jets profess to be reasonably pleased.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller felt pulses today in Onandaga County, a citadel of conservative Republicanism, that for some months have not been throbbing pleasurably for his administration.
A million-dollar-a-year program designed to attract outstanding scholars was announced yesterday by Fordham University.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- Metropolitan Nikodim, foreign affairs spokesman for the Moscow Patriarchate, has outlined new opportunities for improving relations between the Russian Orthodox Church and Roman Catholicism brought about by the Ecumenical Council.

John E. Healy 2d, building contractor of Wilmington, Del., has been appointed general contractor representative on the National Joint Board for the Settlement of Jurisdictional Disputes. The appointment was announced in Washington by Ira H. Hardin, president of the Associated General Contractors of America.
Several thousand fleet taxi drivers will meet tonight to decide whether to strike more than 80 garages in an effort to win union recognition.
Francesca Roberto, soprano, will make her debut with the Metropolitan Opera as Cio-Cio-San in "Madama Butterfly" on Jan. 5.

J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., one of the world's largest diversified textile producers, realized the highest sales and earnings in its history in the fiscal year ended Oct. 30, according to the annual figures issued yesterday.
Losses predominated in relatively dull trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
A 60-foot Norway spruce was hoisted into position at Rockefeller Center yesterday morning as one of the city's symbols of the Christmas season.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that 338 theater owners and theater personnel engaged in the sale of tickets throughout New York State had registered with his office as provided by the New York Theatrical Distribution Act, which went into effect Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Justice Department today hopped its prosecution of Alden Whitman, a member of the news staff of The New York Times, in charges of contempt of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader and the principal speaker at Saturday's peace march here, met for a half-hour with Secretary of State Dean Rusk this morning.
Federal researchers have found a treatment that, in preliminary tests, seems effective against the drug-resistant strain of malaria besetting American troops in Vietnam.
Government and foundation grants for "such nonsense as ballet" were decried last night by a philanthropist who has donated millions of dollars to advance medical research.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A five-ounce piece of mail from Luci Baines Johnson that runs around a wheel, stays up nights and can drink from a potato will be arriving tomorrow at airports from New Jersey to California.

Copper futures prices again showed some muscle yesterday, continuing to recover from their recent weakness. The decline had been brought about by the Government's plan to sell 200,000 tons from the stockpile.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The three-month Treasury bill rate edged up again at today's auction to another five-year high, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Changes in stock prices and the leading market averages were mixed yesterday in heavy trading.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 28 The Brazilian subsidiary of the West German Mannesmann Steel Company has agreed, after a federal investigation, to make good on an estimated $15 million in promissory notes in default here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -Barry Goldwater's Free Society Association denied to its 35,000 members today that John V. Lindsay's election as Mayor of New York pointed the way to a Republican resurgence.
Arnold G. Fraiman, former assistant United States attorney, was named yesterday as the city's next Investigation Commissioner by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -An Army report due Jan. 1 is expected to recommend the formation of at least one and perhaps two more "air cavalry" divisions such as the one fighting in Vietnam.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 29 -- Despite minor electric power trouble, Gemini 7 is still expected to be launched on its 14-day space journey on schedule at 2:30 P.M. Saturday.

Armand D'Angelo, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, will spend part of his last day in office today explaining why he should not rescind an order cutting off the water supply in North Tarrytown for at least 13 hours tomorrow.

Roy M. Cohn began legal action yesterday to force the Lionel Corporation to pay about $707,000 that he now owes two brothers for his failure to honor a contract involving the sale of a parachute company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -Ghana has delivered what a State Department spokesman described today as a "conciliatory" reply to a United States protest about a book written by President Kwame Nkrumah.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- America's ruling body of tennis has taken steps to disassociate itself from the Olympic movement. And it probably will urge its international federation to do the same.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 29 -- With France again absent, the Common Market Council of Ministers met today and reached agreement on parts of the European Economic Community's budget for 1966. That action could lead to a new test of intentions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- A leading scientist said today it was wrong to spend $30 billion on getting an American to the moon by 1970 when so much else to benefit the human race could be done with the money.

There are quite a few people in New York who own restaurants, others who own nightclubs or supper clubs and still others who perform in these places. Among them, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Brilliant may be unique because they do all three.

The Bar Association of the City of New York, at a hearing yesterday, called the 178-year-old state law that makes adultery the sole ground for divorce "an absurd anachronism." It suggested six additional grounds, including narcotics addiction and "cruel and inhuman treatment."
The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation announced here yesterday the election of Robert H. Cornwell as a vice president.
QUEEN VICTORIA waltzes with Jean-Paul Sartre at Walgrove Snood's annual pre-Christmas party for the leading books, authors, and characters of the year.

The most popular in-flight attractions, according to a survey of 5,000 frequent airline passengers, are the reports from the captain on the weather, the aircraft's position and conditions at the destination. Movies and recorded music ran a poor second.

The New York 65 Health Insurance Association, which provides health insurance benefits for 118,000 subscribers at least 65 years old, announced yesterday that it would go out of business at midnight next June 30.

The Temporary Commission on City Finances presented its final "integrated package" for budget reforms yesterday with a plea to the incoming Lindsay administration to "act at once" on it to "solve the current fiscal crisis."
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 29 (AP) -- About 3,500 production workers began a week-long strike today at the General Electric Company's large steam turbine-generator department here.
COTONOU, Dahomey, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- Dahomey's army leader, Gen. Christophe Soglo, today staged his second coup d'etat in 25 months, seeking to end a political crisis.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Nov. 29 -- The Nassau County police and the District Attorney's office announced today that they were investigating a complaint that a microphone had been secreted in a public phone booth in the Rockville Centre Village Hall.

The warning directed to Mayor-elect Lindsay on New York's fiscal condition -- that the city is "going to have to do something, and fast" -- does not herald a new emergency but an old, continuing one, the result of ten years of fiscal malpractice.

BEFORE man began improving things so efficiently, the salmon family, in all its diverse forms, did very well in its allotted, natural slot in the scheme of life. But commercial exploitation over the years has taken a fearful toll, not only of the stocks but also of the conditions necesary for the fish to continue their life cycle.

Motorist who do not want to go to the trouble of taking their unwanted jalopies to Sanitation Department junkyards for disposal had a new service offered to them yesterday. The sanitation agency said it would come to them.

A second stockholder of the Norfolk Western Railway, Mrs. Sylvia Martin, owner of 18,500 shares of the carrier's common stock, is challenging the legality of a special stockholders' meeting the company held on Aug. 25 in Roanoke, Va.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 -Plans to construct a 2,600-seat legitimate theater to house hit Broadway musicals concurrent with their New York runs were disclosed here today by a group of prominent show business personalities.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 29 -- A psychiatrist testified today that Duane Pope was sane and in perfect control of his actions last June when he robbed the Farmers State Bank in Big Springs, Neb., and killed three employes.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 29 (Comtelbureau) -- Unilever, N.V., fixed at 98 per cent of face value today the issue price of its previously announced 6 per cent 300-million guilder ($83.2 million) debenture issue.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Indonesia's First Deputy Premier, a main target of anti-Communist demonstrators, denounced the role of the Indonesian Communist party today in the unsuccessful Oct. 1 coup as "treasonous."

The Pennsylvania Railroad, which has a record of paying its shareholders a cash dividend in every year since 1848 -- a longer period thany any other company whose shares are traded on the New York Stock Exchange -- announced yesterday it had decided to increase quarterly distributions by 60 per cent to 40 cents a share.

Two major film companies -- the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and the Paramount Pictures Corporation -- showed sharply divergent results in their reports yesterday covering the third quarter and first nine months of this year.

Stockholders of Heublein, Inc., the food and liquor producer, approved yesterday the purchase by that company of the Theo. Hamm Brewing Company, St. Paul, Minn., for new 5 per cent preferred stock with a par value of $62,006,300.

MADRID, Nov. 29 -- Spain's offer of $1 billion for Latin America's development over the next decade was seen today as the crowning touch in her policy of restoring influence in the continent she helped to conquer almost five centuries ago.

OUT of respect for Rachmaninoff no doubt, "Anya" describes itself as "the musical musical." The rubric is not really redundant; in any event, "Anya" needs a descriptive of its own. It is not an overwhelmingly dramatic musical, and certainly not a musical comedy.
The British pound was steady in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The closing quotation was $2.8035, down 1 point from the Friday level.

Dartmouth, the undefeated football champion of the Ivy League was selected yesterday as the winner of the 1965 Lambert Trophy -- the annual award given the team considered to be the best among the major Eastern colleges.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 (AP) -The first five bills to repeal the new state sales tax were introduced in the Legislature today, and several more are expected.
If yesterday's bond market was any indication, the holiday weekend did not end on Sunday.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- This is the season when the egos and bank accounts of French writers may swiftly rise or fall, depending on whether they land some of the bigger prizes that exist among France's 1,250 literary awards.
Three writers have won the Kaufmann International Design Awards, the Institute of International Education announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- The third-biggest tournament ever held ended here last night. The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League were a triumph for California, which provided nearly all the players and nearly all the winners.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A last platoon of youthful demonstrators against United States policy in Vietnam ended a marathon four-day "soul session" today in a $60-day suite at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

In last night's performance of Verdi's "Don Carlo" by the Metropolitan Opera, Ezio Flagello took the part of King Philip and William Dooley that of the Grand Inquisitor in an otherwise familiar cast headed by Raina Kabiavanska (Elizabeth), Grace Bumbry (Princess Eboli), Bruno Prevedi (Don Carlo) and Robert Merrill (Rodrigo).

Federal Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. reserved decision yesterday on a motion by David J. Miller, 23-year-old volunteer worker for the Catholic Worker movement, to dismiss an indict ment charging him with violating Federal law by burning his draft card.

The Transit Authority said yesterday that it approved the list of 10 candidates offered by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay for a panel to mediate its contract negotiations with the Transport Workers Union.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Clete Boyer, the New York Yankee third baseman, drew a $175 fine and a 30-day suspended jail sentence today when his attorney entered a no-contest plea to charges of assault and battery.

NATIONAL EDUCATIONAL TELEVISION muffed an opportunity last night to do a constructive program on the growing problem of leisure time. The noncommercial network was so enamored of pictures showing the populace at play that is barely mentioned reassuring instances of how idle hands and minds can be put to fruitful work.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Speakers in two committees of the General Assembly today denounced apartheid and what they called the expansionist policy of South Africa as threats to international peace.
Three Westchester County building trades organizations have elected new officers.

It is after deliberate consideration that I have decided to comment on your Nov. 16 editorial "Slow-Motion Justice" wherein you assessed the efforts of the National Labor Relations Board in the taxicab situation. My reluctance to comment is predicated upon the question of the propriety of discussing through the news media matters now pending before the N.L.R.B.

HONG KONG, Nov. 29 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China vigorously attacked the Soviet Union tonight at a Peking reception in the embassy of Albania, which is China's major ideological ally in Europe.

IGOR OISTRAKH returned to Carnegie Hall last night for his first New York recital since 1963. He brought with him a big program that had two novelties: the first local performance of Boris Tchaikovsky's Sonata in A, and the presence of Mrs. Oistrakh, Natalia Zertsalova, in her debut here as a pianist.

Orin Lehman, who lost by a narrow margin in the September Democratic primary for the Controller nomination, announced yesterday his availability for the Congressional seat now held by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay.

HONG KONG, Nov. 29 -- "Who has time for sightseeing?" The plaintive words, drifting through the fitting room walls, can be heard in Texas drawls, soft Southern speech, Eastern finishing school accents and the flat tones of the Middle West. They are the voices of the many women who come to Hong Kong for shopping rather than scenery and who remember fitting rooms and shops more vividly than the grandeur of the setting.
Thomas Lewy, baritone, made his New York solo debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, and if his singing had been as graceful as his program-making, he would have been a thorough success.

The Federal Reserve is continuing to voice concern over the the build-up of interest-bearing deposits and borrowings at the nation's commercial banks -- and the effect this build-up is having on bank lending and investment practices.
PARIS, Nov. 29 -- President de Gaulle and Government officials appeared today to have begun a determined effort to regain the ground he seems to have lost recently among the electorate.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A sore toe threatens Arthur Ashe's campaign on the Australian summer tennis circuit.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 29 -- The New York Yankees traded Phil Linz to the Philadelphia Phillies today for Ruben Amaro in a straight exchange of infield "super-subs."

DETROIT, Nov. 29 (AP) -The tempo of auto production picked up today as the United States auto industry neared its goal of making November the second 900,000-car production month in automotive history.

CALVERTON, L.I., Nov. 29 -- A moving model of a vehicle for moon exploration, under development by the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, was demonstrated today on two acres of simulated moonscape.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 29 -- A committee of the Investment Bankers Association issued today a sharply critical report on the accounting practices of the electric and gas utility industry.

Britain could not ignore the appeal of President Kenneth Kaunda for British troops in Zambia to stand guard at the Kariba dam. There are dangers in sending British forces to the border of Rhodesia, but the perils of inaction are obviously greater.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Nine recommendations to improve the international exchange of goods have been made by the Committee on Transportation of the National Citizens Commission on International Cooperation.

The Avco Delta Corporation, wholly owned financial services subsidiary of the Avco Corporation, announced yesterday it had completed arrangements to place $43.37 million of 15-year notes with institutional investors.

The election of Charles F. Noyes as honorary chairman of the board of the Charles F. Noyes Company at 42 Broadway, has been announced by David M. Baldwin, the company's president. Mr. Noyes founded the realty company in 1898. Harry B. Helmsley, head of Helmsley-Spear, is among the new directors elected to the board.

Following are the texts of the summary of findings and recommendations in the second interim report of the city's Temporary Commission of City Finances, of dissents by individual commission members and of the commission's recommendations on how the city can achieve fiscal balance:
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -The American Medical Association's policy-making house of delegates considered today what to charge patients over 65 years old under Medicare and how to collect fees.

MICHEL GOMA, the 33-year-old designer for the Paris house of Jean Paton, relaxed yesterday in his suite at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel here and talked about hats and hemlines as well as carnations and lions.

Basking in Hollywood, Fla., investment bankers took a look at the transportation industry yesterday and found the view generally balmy. The occasion was a securities committee report delivered at the 54th annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Nov. 29 -- A 41-year-old Air Force pilot, Maj. Glenn A. Higginson of Ukiah, Calif., landed his Grumman Albatross amphibian amid-Communist junks seven miles off the North Vietnamese coast yesterday and saved another American flier.
Thurgood Marshall grabbed Carl Rowan's hand as he entered the room. "How are you?" boomed the Solicitor General to the newspaperman, a former director of the United States Information Agency.
Professional golf has a new name in its top rank. Robert Thomas Creasey, a 52-year-old New York attorney, will become executive director of the Professional Golfers' Association of America on Jan. 1.

WHEN Earl Bryan Schwulst said yesterday that New York City's financial crisis "won't brook further delay," his associates at the Bowery Savings Bank could have told the municipal budget-makers that he really meant it.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., will form a subsidiary to borrow $20 million from European investors to finance the retail chain's expansion program in Europe.

All three television networks now have new shows under development as summer replacements. According to program officials, the networks intend to cut down on the large number of reruns usually televised in summer months.

THE enterprising "Mondays at Nine" modern dance series continued at the 74th Street Theater last night with works by Ruth Currier and Jeff Duncan which, in their individual ways, showed the continuing potency of the modern dance tradition.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 29 -- Jackson, a big, limber, smiling porter in a department store here, arrived panting and three hours late for work today and said to his employer:

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 29 -- The Republican-controlled Nassau County Board of Supervisors announced today that it would adopt a new budget calling for a four-cent reduction in the tax rate proposed by County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- A fine 1900-year-old bronze head of the Roman Emperor Claudius was auctioned here today for $43,400.
Late profit taking weakened most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume surged forward to 3.8 million shares from 3.06 million on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -Current events have given deeper penetration to a point which Dr. Warren Weaver, the eminent researcher into the humanistic sciences, elaborated on in an interview published today. The point is that, while the United States Government is spending nearly $30 billion on the program to land the first man on the moon, acute needs of the human race run a bad second in the priorities.

MANILA, Nov. 29 (UPI) -Malaysia, Australia and Iran pledged today increases in their contributions to the proposed Asian Development Bank at the opening session of a 19-nation ministerial conference on economic cooperation.

A supper dance will be held in the ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 16 after a preview showing of the film "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold" at the DeMille Theater. The film version of the John Le Carre novel, which stars Richard Burton, Claire Bloom and Oskar Werner, will open Dec. 23 at the DeMille and Coronet Theaters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A committee of leading private citizens gave cautious endorsement today to the creation of a new international reserve asset to supplement gold and dollars in the nation's reserve.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -A United Nations "voice of peace" agency that would act as a world bank of knowledge was proposed today at the White House Conference on International Cooperation.
Thomas W. Blazey, assistant controller of the B.F. Goodrich Company, has been named controller of the B.F. Goodrich Tire Company, a division. He succeeds Wallace F. Bowman, who retires Dec. 1.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -A total of 615 traffic deaths during this year's four-day Thanksgiving weekend set a record for the fall holiday. It was 11 per cent higher than the nation's Thanksgiving weekend toll of 554 last year and capped an annual upward trend since 1960, when the lowest total of the last eight years -- 442 -- was noted.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Dr. John Nixon, president of the Alabama State Conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, appealed yesterday to news media to "stop whipping Alabama."
" I WASN'T there, but my dresses were at least 20 of them. It was my big success."

The subject of birth control has become so urgent that it is no surprise to see the Pope, the American Medical Association and a White House advisory panel all deal with the issue within the past few days. Many students of the subject are convinced that the worldwide population explosion holds as great a danger for the future of the human race as the threat of nuclear war.

Mayor Wagner asked a state committee yesterday to postpone calling the principal figures in the City University controversy to a public hearing today, declaring that the dispute has produced "high and dangerous tensions."

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 29 -President Johnson believes that relations between the United States, India and Pakistan must be thoroughly reappraised before he can agree to a resumption of aid programs to the two countries.
Michigan State's unbeaten team took top honors again yesterday in the weekly collegiate football polls conducted by United Press International and The Associated Press.

No director of the United Gas Corporation plans to sell any of his stock in the company as a result of the recent offer of the Pennzoil Company to buy a minimum of one million shares at $41 each, Ed Parkes, president of United Gas, said yesterday.

W.C. Stauble, president of Veeder-Root, Inc., characterized an offer of $38 a share made yesterday for 35 per cent of the company's outstanding as "grossly inadequate" and urged stockholders to reject it.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Secretary General Thant warned the world's governments tonight against activities that might snap the present "margin of restraint" in nuclear tests and sabotage a world disarmament conference.

The fight to make the nation's highways safer for drivers is being lost to the "traffic safety establishment," according to an adviser to the Senate subcommittee that investigated auto safety last summer.
QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Col. Guillermo Freile Posso of the air force was dismissed today as a member of the ruling junta and separated from the armed forces.
THE Indians of Ecuador's Valley of the Volcanoes are busy these days weaving some estimable rugs for W J Sloane.
The elimination of "archaic and cumbersome" laws governing wills was urged yesterday by a state commission on estates.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 29 -- In an era when the accent in basketball continues to be on height, players on Long Island campuses seem to be getting shorter. To add to the problem, their schedules keep getting rougher.
The tempo of retail activity continued to increase last week. Department store sales rose from levels attained in the corresponding 1964 week and in the preceding 1965 week.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 29 Foreign Minister Swaran Singh said in Parliament today that Communist Chinese intrusions across the northern border "have attained serious proportions."

The American Medical Center for Burma announced yesterday that it would disband because the Burmese Government had nationalized its hospital in Namkham -- the hospital built by the late Dr. Gordon S. Seagrave, who was known as the Burma Surgeon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- In a hair-raising article entitled "How Women Really Get Husbands," Cosmopolitan tells the story of a spineless fellow named Allen trapped between a cynical divorcee and a hysterical mother.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- Britain has decided in principle to send a token force of aircraft to Zambia at the request of President Kenneth D. Kaunda, to be followed later by a limited number of ground troops, a well-informed source said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A special House Commerce subcommittee announced today that it would begin an investigation of the Northeast power failure of Nov. 9 with hearings next month.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 29 -- The Cambodian radio announced today that two United States Army enlisted men who had been held prisoner by the Vietcong since November, 1963 had arrived at the border separating Cambodia from South Vietnam.

Adorable flashed a thrilling closing burst to take the feature race of six furlongs at Aqueduct yesterday. Mrs. Ethel Jacobs's steady-going 3-year-old filly, enjoying the benefit of a rail-grazing ride by Eddie Belmonte, scored by a nose over the long-priced Lady Imp, with Tamerett a nose behind Lady Imp.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The British Communist party shuffled its leadership today to pension off old party chiefs and expel pro-Chinese militants.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 29 -- In a series of command shifts, anti-Communist leaders of Indonesia's armed forces have strengthened their control over the military establishment.

Reaction to a proposed 2 per cent city income tax ranged yesterday from instant opposition to guarded enthusiasm on the part of political, industrial and labor leaders. Many said, in effect, "Let's study it."

THE HAGUE, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- The International Court of Justice announced today it had decided by an 8-to-6 vote not to accept South Africa's invitation to go to South-West Africa to see how the inhabitants live under her rule.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Here is the list of minor league players drafted today by the major league teams:
Train service at Grand Central Terminal was delayed more than two hours yesterday afternoon by a fire that destroyed a New York Central commuter coach.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 29 -- The attitude of former President Juan Bosch toward Communism and his conduct during the recent civil war are issues in a power struggle that came into the open today.
MIAMI, Nov. 29 -- The Yarmouth Castle fire began "like a liquid burning" in an unfurnished and unoccupied cabin, the ship's chief engineer testified today at a Coast Guard inquiry.

THE old-fashioned department store Santa Claus has been updated at Bloomingdale's. Last week the jolly gentleman began doing his ho-ho-hoing over a closed circuit TV set in the second-floor children's department.

The views so far expressed on the Rhodesian situation are very one-sided. A one-man one-vote election would inevitably produce a black government which would destroy the economy more effectively than any boycotts or embargoes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -The index of wholesale primary market prices rose one-tenth of 1 per cent to 103.5 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Nov. 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods moved higher in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

The Defense Department conceded yesterday that components of nuclear weapons were being shipped through New York City. Assembled weapons, however, are not passing through the city, the department said.

We have recently heard a commercial announcement frequently aired over local (and doubtless national) radio stations by the telephone company, whose trucks currently carry conspicuous placards reading "Save 76 miles with an extension phone."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 29 -- The Government ordered the restriction of a "hard-line" colonel today, about 24 hours after eight leftist intellectuals had been released from jail.
CAIRO, Nov. 29 -- The peace conference between Yemeni republicans and royalists has been deadlocked and may drag on for 10 more days, informed sources said today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 29 -- Ambassador W. Averell Harriman stamped the label of success tonight on the Second Special Inter-American Conference now drawing to a close.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 29 -- Much to the surprise of many major league managers and general managers, who expected little activity in drafting players from the minors to the majors, 23 players were chosen today by American and National League teams as organized baseball held its annual draft under "unrestricted" conditions for the first time.
DENVER, Nov. 29 -- Faced with a rebellion of employes over his newly decreed extension of a smoking ban, the chairman of the board of Samsonite Corporation rescinded the order today.

Just a month remains before the labor contract expires on the city-owned subway and bus lines; but Michael J. Quill is still exhibiting his customary wiliness in frustrating attempts to negotiate a new agreement without the traditional year-end strike fears. The president of the Transport Workers Union has vetoed all ten of the mediators Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay proposed for possible service on a transit peace board.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 29 -- Cardigan Bay, the New Zealand-bred champion pacer, who would have been the prohibitive favorite to capture the $50,000 National Pacing Derby at Roosevelt Raceway Thursday night regardless of post position, drew the No. 3 slot today for the 1 1/4-mile event.
Two Boston physicians have developed a simple home test that, they say, acts as a reliable chemical calendar for women using the rhythm method of birth control.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -The Federal Government is increasing its spending for legal aid to the poor tenfold this year in a program that will include 200 communities by June.

" These are working man's hours. People around here get paid on Saturday, and they want to go to the bank on Saturday." This remark, from Mrs. Marie Gallo of 399 Beach Road in Eltingville, Staten Island, was typical of what people were saying last Saturday as they queued up to open accounts at the Community National Bank and Trust Company of Richmond, the newest bank in Staten Island and the city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -The Federal Government is increasing its spending for legal aid to the poor tenfold this year in a program that will include 200 communities by June.

This remark, from Mrs. Marie Gallo of 399 Beach Road in Eltingville, Staten Island, was typical of what people were saying last Saturday as they queued up to open accounts at the Community National Bank and Trust Company of Richmond, the newest bank in Staten Island and the city.

Men clad in oilskins were working ankle deep in shallow water yesterday, complementing crews on car floats pouring concrete. Another crew was driving piles deep into the old Rikers Island channel, where two major East River construction projects are going full force.
ANNISTON, Ala., Nov. 29 -A young segregationist, recently accused of trying to kill a key witness against him, went on trial today for the nightrider slaying of a Negro foundry worker.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan will soon be given a new title by the United Nations -- High Commissioner for Refugees.
The Copper Range Company, which initiated the recent copper price increase to 38 cents a pound, rolled back its price yesterday to 36 cents.

Richard Robles's lawyers charged yesterday that the 22year-old defendant was being used as "a stand-in" for George Whitmore Jr. the man first indicated and later cleared of the slayings of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert.

" Anthology of Chinese Literature," compiled and edited by Cyril Birch with Donald Keene as associate editor, will be published by Grove on Friday. The book covers the period from the Chou Dynasty (1122-221 B.C.) to the Yuan Dynasty (1260-1367 A.D.) Mr. Birch is associate professor and chairman of the Department of Oriental Languages at the University of California at Berkeley. Mr. Keene is professor of Japanese at Columbia University.

DUCHAI, South Vietnam, Nov. 29 -- Duchai is on the central Vietnamese coast, north of Saigon. Last May its complex of five prosperous fishing hamlets, set among fruit groves and palm trees behind a spacious beach, was occupied by Vietcong guerrillas.

The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation's earnings this year should "exceed $3.40 a share," W.M. Elmer, president, told a meeting of public-utility analysts in Boston yesterday. This would compare with $3.02 a share reported for 1964.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30 -- The honeymoon between business and Government may be over, but the Johnson Administration expects the "working partnership" with

Relative to Prof. Hilbert Schenck's letter on Nov. 15, suggesting that the use of electronic computer simulation would have easily and surely allowed the wicked and greedy power companies to know all about and prevent the power blackout:
ONLY one thing is more certain than death and taxes: If a question is asked in a column such as this, an answer will be forthcoming from someone somewhere.
The P. Lorillard Company announced here yesterday the election of Gordon O. Fraser as vice president for international operations.

Arthur J. Goldberg, United States Ambassador to the United Nations, will be official host at a concert to be given March 17 at Carnegie Hall by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra in honor of the orchestra's world tour next summer.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 -- Public concern over the future of the new $12.2 million Los Angeles County Museum of Art was heightened today by two developments.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 30 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, ending his three-week tour of South America, urged the peoples of the continent today to act independently to assume greater leadership in the world.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 30 -- "Su Mac Lad Appreciation Day," honoring the 11-year-old gelding, who will shortly be retired officially, will be observed at Roosevelt Raceway Saturday. The public today was invited to visit the paddock area on that day from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M., when the aged trotter, who has earned more money than any horse in harness racing history, will be on display.
Earnings for American Airlines, Inc., fell last month by 21 per cent, although its traffic was 9 per cent ahead of October, 1964.

For a heady hour yesterday morning, Mrs. Carl Nadasdy, whose husband raises sheep in Golden Valley, Minn., basked in a sort of esthetic bliss, in which thoughts of adding to her wardrobe probably intruded.
Barry Goldwater, a severe critic of the Supreme Court, defends its recent decision that individual Communists may not be compelled to register under the Internal Security Act of 1950.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Government was urged by a committee of leading citizens today to try to negotiate an international agreement on anti-dumping rules and to press for a major reduction in nontariff barriers to trade.

The advertisement of Masters discount store in Monday's New York Post said "sensational bargains." It was no exaggeration. Right up there at the top of the page was a 19-inch portable UHF-VHF television set for $8.98.
NEWARK, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Newark Board of Education obtained a court injunction today against a strike threatened for Thursday by the Newark Teachers Union.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 30 -- Two North Vietnamese soldiers who surrendered in the battle of the Iadrang Valley told today how they had come down the Ho Chi Minh Trail to "liberate the people of South Vietnam."
Lindsay and Wagner aides, seeking to arrange for an orderly transfer of a $5 billion operation -- the city -- got bogged down yesterday in an impasse over office space.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Doug Jones of New York knocked out Chip Johnson tonight in the third round of a scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout at the Miami Beach Auditorium.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 30 -- The possibility of early negotiations on the Common Market crisis between the French Foreign Minister and the president of the trade bloc's Council of Ministers emerged tonight at a council meeting.

ROME, Nov. 30 -- Papal amendments to an Ecumenical Council document dealing with birth control have been "absorbed" in a way to leave open the possibility of future modification of the Roman Catholic Church's ban on artificial contraception.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- One way to rehabilitate alcoholics is to show them movies of themselves taken while they were drunk, three psychiatrists reported today.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation said yesterday that it would spend $33 million to develop a major lead mine in southeastern Missouri.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30 -- The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission announced here today plans to gather much more detailed information on the financial operation of the nation's securities dealers and investment advisers.
The kind of music one hears while shopping is nearly always recorded and quite often insipid enough to drive one out of the store.
Swamped by a selling wave in the morning, the stock market gathered strength yesterday afternoon and almost made it to dry ground before the closing gong.

" Publications for Parents" will will be published jointly by the Dell Publishing Company and the Children's Medical Center of Boston. Mrs. Harriet H. Gibney, director of the hospital's Health Education Department, will be editorial director of the series.
A 160-mile-an-hour train, using aircraft engines and design technology, was proposed yesterday by the United Aircraft Corporation for the Washington-New York-Boston corridor.
MIAMI, Nov. 30 -- The executive officer of the Yarmouth Castle testified today that when he ordered crewmen to operate a fire hose he found it had been cut.

TRENTON, Nov. 30 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today that he would seek a graduated income tax running from 1 per cent to 5 per cent of taxable income, or one-half the rate New York State imposes.

Under game conditions, how far can a pro quarterback throw a football? The answer: about 70 yards. How far can a very fast pass receiver, like Homer Jones of the Giants, go while the quarterback is setting up to pass and while the ball is in the air? The answer; more than 70 yards.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The widespread adoption of preclearance procedures for international air travelers was recommended today by a citizens committee on aviation.

Robert J. Schwartz, a member of the national board of the Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, yesterday became the second Democratic candidate to announce his availability for the congressional seat to be vacated by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay.

The state will defend itself in court today against a claim that a 6-year-old retarded boy died of malnutrition after having spent 13 days in the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island. The father seeks $500,000 in damages.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- The Port of Chicago is having the best season in its history, Robert P. Mayo, vice president for research and statistics, Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry, said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Justice Department and General Motors Corporation agreed today on an unusual settlement of the Government's antitrust suit against the company's bus division.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Pakistan charged India today with withholding Pakistan's share of the flow of three rivers. She called on Secretary General Thant to circulate her complaint to the Security Council.

The president of New York University said yesterday that in many instances it would be more economical for the state to help private colleges and universities expand than to build new public facilities.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 30 -- Stanford University physicists are developing a refinement for atom smashers that they feel could lead to the world's "most powerful, efficient and versatile" particle accelerator.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 30 -- The United States military commander in South Vietnam has ordered soldiers to treat all prisoners humanely and has warned them that "mistreatment of any captive is a criminal offense."
A third lawsuit -- the second involving brokerage commissions -- to grow out of J. Myer Schine's sale of his coast-to-coast real estate empire was announced yesterday by Helmsley-Spear, Inc.

Andrew F. Brimmer, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for economic affairs, declared yesterday the long-term solution to the country's international payments problem required more efforts by American companies to compete with imported commodities.
The Ford Foundation announced grants of $14.5 million yesterday to create an international complex here for research on human reproduction and fertility control.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Yehudi Menuhin, the New York boy who survived the ordeal of child prodigy to become one of the world's ranking violinists, has become an honorary Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- The Action for Boston Community Development was given clearance today to continue administering the neighborhood Youth Corps program here.
MOSCOW, Nov. 30 -- His tongue as sharp and laconic as ever, Mikhail Sholokhov criticized today the Russian writers -- other than himself -- who have gained renown in the West.
The apparent transfer of learning between two species of mammals by injections of so-called "memory molecules" was reported yesterday by a team of California scientists.

The 15th luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic, part of organization's campaign to raise $300,000 for the New York Philharmonic, drew about 1,100 persons yesterday to the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
A bright spot in the world sugar surplus situation was noted yesterday by Tom O. Murphy of the Department of Agriculture.

There'll be water as usual in the taps of North Tarrytown today, because the Westchester village forced the New York City Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity to put off an inspection for three days.
A "successful" bank robber, who later talked a look-alike into a repeat performance, was sentenced to 15 years in prison yesterday for the original holdup.

The Library and Museum of the Performing Arts in Lincoln Center opened officially to the public at noon yesterday. Dedication ceremonies were held earlier in the Vivian Beaumont Theater, which shares the Library-Museum building.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Kipchoge Keino of Kenya ran the 5,000 meters in 13 minutes 24.2 seconds today, shaving 1.6 seconds off the world record set earlier this year by Ron Clarke of Australia.
Michael J. Qull asked Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday to meet "at whatever time and place you designate" to help speed the negotiations for a new transit contract.
Federal agencies are considering the removal of old freighters from the national defense reserve fleet for use in Southeast Asia as floating warehouses and temporary piers.
The sale of the Great Lakes Pipe Line Company to the Williams Brothers Company of Tulsa, Okla., for $287.6 million was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Leaders of the major civil rights organizations met today with two Cabinet officers to seek increased enforcement of Federal laws against racial discrimination.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 30 (UPI) -- William D. Eckert, the new Commissioner of Baseball, said tonight he was "no man's puppet" and that he would make decisions he deemed best for the good of the game.
Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King, a new bride, has just received her wedding present from the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

The nation's railroads have built a "Chinese wall" to deny inland shippers the right of access to low-cost water transportation, J.W. Hershey, chairman of the executive committee of the Common Carrier Conference of Domenstic Water Carriers, charged yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 30 -The Texas White House announced today that Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara and President Johnson would meet at the end of this week to discuss Mr. McNamara's trip to South Vietnam. Europe and other international matters also will be discussed.

BONN, Nov. 30 -- Siemens Halske A.G., a sleeping giant in Europe's computer industry, is starting to stir fitfully. The big West German electrical and electronics pro ducts company announced yesterday that it planned to invest $125 million "within the next few years" to build up its electronic-data processing business.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Consumer Price Index rose last month to a record high, and a Government official indicated that a faster climb might be inflationary.

It is in the best interests of the United States that a group of independent, objective Southeast Asian scholars be trained. These scholars must have access to relevant information and the opportunity to devote a substantial part of their time to keeping abreast of developments in the area.

STANDING in a corner at a big party or in the lobby of one of those upper midtown hotels where the power elite sojourns or meets for breakfast, the style-watcher quickly concludes that some of the best fashion is being worn, these days, by men.
A threatened taxi strike was averted yesterday when the Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee was recognized as collective bargaining agent for 8,000 drivers in 30 of the city's 79 fleet-owned garages.
The National Rural Electric Cooperative Association and the Investment Bankers Association may seem like strange bedfellows, but it turns out they agree on at least one point.
HONG KONG, Nov. 30 -- Communist China was reported today to have made new, heavy commitments of material aid to North Vietnam for support of the war.

FORT LAUDERDALE; Fla. Nov. 30 -- A major trade between the New York Yankees and the Cincinnati Reds, which would involve two pitchers, Jim Bouton of the Yankees and Jim O'Toole of the Reds, and perhaps Frank Robinson, the Red outfielder-first baseman, has been thoroughly explored by the clubs in recent days.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, urged New Jersey today to establish an independent state agency to deal with the commuting crisis facing 77,000 railroad passengers.

TOKYO Nov. 30 -- Masahiko (Fighting) Harada, a boyish-faced but tough bantamweight boxer with a welterweight's legs, defeated a game but weaker Alan Rudkin, the British Empire champion, tonight to keep the world 118-pound title in Japan.
A chemical abnormality has been found in the brains of Parkinson's disease patients, according to a report here yesterday.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 30 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said tonight that Rhodesia would welcome a token British force in Zambia if it could be agreed upon, for it would suit everyone in the area to have law and order maintained in that country.

The visit to London of Secretary McNamara and his meeting in Paris with nine other NATO Defense Ministers opens a search for a fresh approach to the critical nuclear issue in the NATO alliance. That search will continue next month with visits of Prime Minister Wilson and Chancellor Erhard to Washington. But it is already clear that Britain, more than any other country, now holds the key.

PARIS -- The German problem shaping up inside NATO was not resolved by Saturday's meeting of ten allied defense ministers and the decision to set up working groups to discuss nuclear questions. The Germans want more than a voice in atomic matters; they want to participate directly in the operation of what is unfortunately called "hardware," meaning nuclear warheads.

G.F.K. HARHOFF, the Danish Consul General, strummed a guitar as he waited and worried whether 60 persons could get into his new nine-room apartment on Fifth Avenue. Then he raised his heavy black eyebrows and commented philosophically:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A $38,790,000 contract putting the Bath (Me.) Iron Works into merchant ship construction for the first time since 1942 was signed today at the Maritime Administration office.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Maryland Court of Appeals rolled today that a person can voluntarily give up his right to be reindicted even though members of the grand jury that indicted him were illegally required to swear to a belief in God.
State Controller Arthur Levitt announced yesterday the issuance of $75 million in New York State bond anticipation notes to finance highway construction.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- Arthur S. Lall, former Indian delegate to the United Nations, proposed tonight a treaty relationship between his country and Pakistan to help stabilize Asia.

Events today: Puccini's "La Fanciulla del West," 8 P.M., Metropolitan Opera; Seymour Wakschal, violinist, 8:30, Carnegie Hall; Bach Aria Group, 8:30, Town Hall; Isolde Traut, English lute songs, 8:30, Carnegie Recital Hall.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 30 -- In the marble-walled chamber of the Capitol where the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico once sat, a 13-member commission is making some judgments on the future of this island commonwealth.
Volume in representative New York City department stores in November showed a wide range of increases over sales levels of the 1964 month, a survey by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Informed British sources said tonight that British and Zambian negotiators were trying to reach agreement on the terms for a British force in Zambia.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- One of Britain's most versatile and most politically minded scientists, Prof. Patrick Maynard Stuart Blackett was elected today to the presidency of the influential scientific organization, the Royal Society.
A man said by the police to have been a narcotics pusher was shot dead in his East Harlem apartment in a gunfight with two patrolmen last night.
Directors of Veeder-Root, Inc., which is attempting to beat off a tender offer by the Giannini Controls Corporation, declared a 10-cent extra dividend yesterday.
The city's water supply, although greater than a year ago, is still dangerously low and calls for continued observance of strict conservation measures.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Robert Moses came here tonight and left Westchester, County leaders temporarily speechless by proposing a new plan for a bridge across Long Island Sound.
A domestic worker and her common-law husband were arrested yesterday in the thefts of about $150,000 worth of furs and jewels from the homes of the woman's employers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Communist forces attacked two South Vietnamese companies near Danang in a predawn raid today. The assault came a few hours after United States Special Forces had repulsed a surprise raid on one of their camps, killing 104 guerrillas.

The critical periods of the Vietnamese war have often been the quietest. These have been the times when some official has come back from Saigon and persuaded the President, usually in the privacy of the White House, to increase the American commitment.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Fort Slocum sounded its last retreat tonight as the military establishment formally ended a century of occupation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The national crime rate rose 5 per cent in the first nine months of this year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

John Solum offered all four Mozart flute quartets in a neatly wrapped package last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. It was the first of a series of three programs he will give there collectively entitled "The Art of the Flute."

The relationship between rent control and segregated housing in New York City has never been adequately explored, due, in large measure, to the fact that those organizations which advocate retention of rent control are also the most ardent supporters of integrated housing.

MOSCOW, Nov. 30 -- Britain told the Soviet Union today that no concessions would be made in the defense planning of the Western alliance as inducements for Soviet agreement to a treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons.

HONG KONG, Nov. 30 -- At this time of year Scotsmen the world over pay tribute to their patron saint, Andrew. Here they had their fling prematurely on Friday night at the St. Andrew's Society annual ball. It was by invitation only, and not a single nonmember Scot in the colony was invited.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company -- and its customers -- were kept in the dark for 24 hours Monday and yesterday about the status of almost $3 billion of checking deposits because of a breakdown of the bank's computerized accounting system.

THE Danes do it differently. The Russian classic version of that old French ballet "Coppelia" has many charms, not least its appropriate union with Delibes's sugar-candy music. Yet the special Danish version, given by the Royal Danish Ballet at the State Theater, Lincoln Center, last night, has a vigor and rebustness that is all its own.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday in Oakland, Calif., the election as directors of Frank M. Cashin, Stanley B. White. and Thomas K. McCarthy.
Two Roman Catholic periodicals have criticized sharply the transfer to Latin America of the Rev. Daniel Berrigan, a Jesuit priest active in recent protests against United States policy in Vietnam.
There was a modicum of activity in the Government bond market yesterday, but the snail's pace could be so de-with the quietude of the two preceding sessions.

Hyman Bress is a violinist who likes to add a touch of novelty to his recitals. On two occasions here he has used slide projections to let the audience see on a stage screen the scores of the music he was playing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Five men have been invited to arbitrate the power struggle in American amateur sports. Three have accepted the assignment land the others are expected to accept in a day or two.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 30 -- The second Special Inter-American Conference closed in harmony today after laying the groundwork for a modernized and strengthened regional community of American republics.

ANNISTON, Ala., Nov. 30 -- A witness for the prosecution testified today that segregationist Hubert Damon Strange and two companions had boasted of killing a "nigger" only minutes after the night-rider shooting of a foundry worker here last July.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 30 -- The nation's top Ku Klux Klan leader was linked here today in what the Justice Department says, was a conspiracy that led to the death of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo March 25.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that New York City's $3.9 billion budget for 1965-66 was in balance "as of today and for the duration of the present fiscal year" ending next June 30.

CHARLES O. FINLEY of the Kansas City Athletics -- "the O is for owner," he insists -- is a stubborn nonconformist who long has been the despair of his fellow owners in the American League. Because he is a total maverick, some of his moves don't always lend themselves to easy interpretation. Hence the baseball world was baffled three months ago when Charlie O. appointed Alvin Dark to the nebulous post of administrative assistant.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., Nov. 30 -Seventeen-year-old Mary Anne Murray adores tennis, fishing, swimming, cooking and winning -- especially winning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Project Head Start, probably the most popular of all the anti-poverty programs last summer, was described by some of its best friends today as seriously crippled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Government officials and private citizens at the White House Conference on International Cooperation split ranks today on how far the United States should go in pressing for disarmament.

The Vietnam peace proposals, voiced with decorum during the recent "March on Washington," and the reply from Freedom House stem from sharply divergent attitudes toward the conflict. Yet the positions advanced by the two sides on this occasion -- which presumably reflect their estimates of what the country is prepared to support -- show interesting similarities.
" We're not bearing down enough when we go for a goal," Coach Red Sullivan of the New York Rangers said yesterday. "Once we start hitting the net for goals, my job will be a lot easier."
Hearings on the application of the New Haven Railroad for discontinuance of all interstate passenger train service begin today before the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington.

A 42-year-old physician was elected yesterday as-president and chief executive officer of Hoffmann-La Roche, Inc., the large, privately owned producer of drugs, chemicals and vitamins. He is Virginius D. Mattia, whose appointment becomes effective Jan. 1. As president, he succeeds N.F. Peterson, 66.
More than $1 million worth of Rhodesian sugar, now on its way by ship to the United States, is facing an uncertain future.
The jury trying Richard Robles for murder was told by the prosecution yesterday that "two smoke screens" had been created by the defense to hide the guilt of the defendant.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The British Communist party has deferred action on two condemnatory resolutions dealing with the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- President Johnson has decided that a resumption of surplus food sales to the United Arab Republic "is essential to the national interest of the United States" and has authorized a renewal of diplomatic negotiations to that end.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The United States gained a small amount of gold in October for the second consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
For pork bellies it was a day of decision -- more new high prices. For copper, it was a day of indecision -- an erratic downward price movement. For cocoa it was the busiest day in history.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- President de Gaulle tonight placed his foreign policy at the center of his campaign for re-election.

The countryman began reading the signs in August. Rarely have they been so ominous. It looks as if we were due for one of the old-fashioned winters that old-timers claim were the rule at the turn of the century.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 39 -- India has informed the Big Four powers of her deep concern about current Chinese Communist troop movements on her northern borders.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- France modified today her proposals for United Nations budget reforms. She was promptly assured of Canadian and United States support.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 30 -- More than 150 race cars of various classes and sizes have been transported by boat from Miami to Nassau for the 12th annual speed festival. Some of these machines raced in the Volkswagen and Grand Touring races last Sunday.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 30 -- Holders of more than $16 million in subordinated notes of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation prefer reorganization to liquidation, according to Donald H. Tetzlaff, director of securities for the National Life Insurance Company here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The International Cooperation Year about to end should be expanded into an International Decade, a citizens' commission said today.

The nine square miles of Manhattan south of Central Park constitute a complex of economic and cultural activities unparalleled anywhere else in the world. The City Planning Commission argues that providing good transportation to and from it for the more than 3,000,000 people who work in it or visit it daily must be a primary goal if the city's vitality is to be maintained.

Mrs. Ann Rennick, who works in the Buildings Department office in Queens Borough Hall, came back from lunch yesterday and found the women in her office clustered around a tall tanned man in a blue, pinstriped suit.
The Campbell Soup Company continued to set records in sales and earnings, with its first-quarter results at the highest levels in its 97-year history, W.B. Murphy, president, reported yesterday.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 30 -- Two American soldiers released after two years in Vietcong captivity said today that they wanted to quit the Army to conduct a campaign to get the United States out of Vietnam.
ANOTHER book about James Joyce? It is Anthony Burgess's question, which he hastily answers "yes" -- and only a sourmouth could object.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Kuwait's new ruler, Sheik Sabah al-Salem al-Sabah, today named the leading potential contender for his throne, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Jaber, to be Premier of the Emirate on the Persian Gulf.

Lowell Thomas, who has had a steady job as a radio news commentator for 35 years, is preparing his first weekly television show about visits to faraway places. Odyssey Productions, Inc., owned by Mr. Thomas, and the British Broadcasting Corporation are jointly financing and producing a series of 39 half-hour color films titled "The World of Lowell Thomas."
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- Some 1,500 French companies were instructed today to give fuller information about themselves to their stockholders and the public, beginning with the first quarter of next year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Poland challenged today United States assurances that physical and electronic checks would prevent the unauthorized use of nuclear warheads mounted on West German weapons.

Shortly after a first-time starter named Snow Ball rolled home at $26.80 in the second race at Aqueduct yesterday, an irate loser appeared in the Lost and Found Department. He had an untypical complaint.

The New York County Lawyers Association and two State Supreme Court Justices criticized New York State's 178-year-old divorce law yesterday. One justice called it "antiquated and anarchic, unethical and unrealistic, outmoded and discredited, farcical and degrading.

Laurence Meltzer, formerly with the commercial leasing department of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., has joined the sales department of Nassoit-Sulzberger Co. He will continue to specialize in commercial leasing.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Nov. 30 -- Mayor W. Harry Lister acknowledged today that village employes had hidden a microphone in a phone booth in the Village Hall to record remarks of a village critic.

Frank J. Bradley, who has served as president of Mutual Buying Syndicate, Inc., and May Walter, executive vice president, have turned over financial ownership and administrative supervision in the resident buying office to five key executives.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- President Johnson has been asked to provide a full disclosure of the involvement of non-communist ships in supplying North Vietnam.
WARSAW, Nov. 30 -- John A. Gronouski, who came back to the land of his fathers today to take up his duties as United States Ambassador, put on an exhibition of American political gladhanding.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 30 -- "What else can I do?" the stall owner asked defensively. "I have to raise prices because if I am to bring my rice here to sell, it costs me twice as much as last week."
THE angry young man has grown older, and now he is disintegrating under the ruins of his shabby professional and disastrous private life.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes's attempt to unblock the garment center got off to a ragged start yesterday.

Sanford Gottlieb, political director of the Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, said yesterday that "it sounds like" the two servicemen freed by the Vietcong after two years of captivity had been brainwashed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Army said today that it was still searching unsuccessfully for two noncommissioned officers who disappeared in August and September.

Dick McGuire took over as coach of the New York Knickerbockers last night and the club may never recover from the shock. The Knicks ran, ran and ran some more. They shot and hit and, believe it or not, they won, beating the St. Louis Hawks, 138-119.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Department of Justice is investigating the mailing of antiwar leaflets to American troops in Vietnam to determine if Federal sedition laws were violated.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- All indications now point to a further postponement by the Administration of a decision on whether to build an antimissile missile system.
A medical society "has every right" to refuse membership to osteopaths, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in Brooklyn.

Jan Peerce says he's 61 years old, but by the time he really got going in his recital at Carnegie Hall last night, you would have had a hard time believing that the sounds he was producing could come from a man of that age.
OMAHA, Nov. 30 -- The question before officials meeting in the Union Pacific conference room here today was how to run a railroad soon to sink 100 feet beneath the surface of a river.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The State Department disclosed today that one of two Russians who entered Alaska last August had changed his mind about staying in the United States and had been turned over to the Soviet Embassy here.

THE death of Harry Harkavy of Miami Beach, one of America's finest players, cast a shadow over the end of the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League in San Francisco. He has arrived to play in the tournament, but was hospitalized with a stomach disorder.
CAIRO, Nov. 30 -- The Prosecutor General of the United Arab Republic today indicted Mustafa Amin, one of Cairo's most prominent newspaper editors, on charges of spying and demanded the death penalty.
The route to a $250,000 golf tournament in Westchester County next summer took another twist yesterday.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 30 -- The New York Mets acquired one shortstop, named three coaches and one minor league manager today, sent Joe Christopher to the Boston Red Sox and denied that they were about to trade their star shortstop Roy McMillan.
ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he would ask the Legislature to give high priority to the mounting problem of crime and narcotics addiction, especially in New York City.
