Albert Boni started his second book-publishing career 15 years ago with annual receipts of $600. This year sales are above $1 million, and Mr. Boni has become the publisher who, in all likelihood, has put out more titles than any other private publisher in history.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- An influential economic research group forecast today that the Government would run into difficulties hitting its target of balance-of-payments equilibrium by the end of 1966.

City College's quintet, well fortified with experience, opens its season on a nostalgic note tonight. The Lavender visits Adelphi in its gymnasium at Garden City, L.I., to continue a rivalry that began in 1905.
Sparked by high-flying airline issues, volume on the American Stock Exchange soared yesterday to near-record levels. But the market generally declined.
Masuko Ushioda, the young Japanese violinist who toured the United States with the Toho String Orchestra in 1963, made an impressive recital debut last night at Town Hall.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 30 -- President Humberto Castelo Branco changed some key Brazilian military commands today to strengthen his hand against political pressure from radical young officers.

J.W. Mays, Inc., a department store chain which opened its first Manhattan unit this year on 14th Street, achieved record sales of $22,182,307 in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 against $20,373,439 a year ago.
It came as no great surprise the other day when Modern Packaging, a McGraw-Hill publication, reported that American distillers would spend about $25 million on special Christmas packages this year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- The Chicago Mercantile Exchange marked two milestones today. Trading in live cattle for Western delivery opened and the first full year of trading in live cattle for Chicago-Omaha delivery was completed.
The British pound declined yesterday in very quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here. Its closing quotation was $2.8028, down 7 points from Monday.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- The Consolidated Edison Company is seeking ways to start up its electric system from a complete shutdown without using power from outside sources, a report on file here disclosed today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30 -- A three-man arbitration board established to settle last spring's 47-day strike at The Baltimore Sunpapers today awarded the American Newspaper Guild employes a $15 weekly raise over a two-year contract.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 30 -- President Johnson has approved a plan to make job opportunities in the Federal Government more easily available.

A public offering by American Music Stores, Inc., Detroit, of $2 million of 5 1/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due Dec. 1, 1985 and 250,000 shares of the company's common stock was made yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Smith, Barney Co., Inc., and First of Michigan Corporation.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The two biggest auction houses of France plan to open a joint branch in New York early next year to compete with Parke-Bernet by conducting sales on both sides of the Atlantic.
OTTAWA, Nov. 30 -- A new film on the life of Jesus Christ directed by an Italian Marxist was acclaimed here last night by Roman Catholic and Protestant clergy and laymen.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 30 -- As Samuel Pryor departed in his 1916 electric Rausch-Lang car front Victor Borge's house at 9 o'clock last night, the burglar alarm jangled through the five floors of the pianist's home in Field Point Park here.

The 17th Christmas fair of the Women's Parish Society of St. George's Episcopal Church will be held from 10 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. on Saturday in the parish house at 207 East 16th Street. Proceeds will help the society's welfare projects.
A New York City detective who infiltrated the Progressive Labor Movement testified yesterday that William Epton, chairman of the group's Harlem branch, disclosed a plan for a "bloody" revolution."

Oil issues slipped on the London Stock Exchange yesterday on word that Continental Oil had ceased drilling operations on its offshore well in the North Sea. Continental announced its earlier strike had proved noncommercial.

" Modern Capitalism: The Changing Balance of Public and Private Power," by Andrew Shonfield, director of studies at the Royal Institute of International Affairs, London, will be published by The Oxford University Press on Jan. 13.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 1 -- Nonsmokers would rather stand than switch, the New York Central Railroad has found.
The nation's electric power production rose 5.5 per cent in the week ended Nov. 27 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday it had developed a computer it hopes will be its trump in the competition for the electronic data-processing dollar.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 -- For 54 years now, the country's investment bankers have gathered for annual conventions, most of them recently at this palmy town just north of the Miami Beach-modern pastel hotels of the south Florida coast.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan sharply contradicted yesterday the recent contention of State Supreme Court Justice Nathan R. Sobel that confessions do not play a crucial role in the solution of major crimes.
Is button manufacturing more profitable than making lightbulbs?
A much more prosperous Small Business Investment Company industry at the end of 1966 was predicted yesterday by Richard E. Kelley, deputy administrator of the Small Business Administration.
HONG KONG, Dec. 1 -- The Chinese Communist Foreign Ministry said today that Peking "will certainly not take part" in the world disarmament conference proposed by the United Nations.
Tiffany Co., the 128-year-old jewelry, silverware and specialty-store chain, doubled its profits in the first nine months this year, according to the report yesterday by Walter Hoving, chairman.
It's a rare day in December when a college basketball coach unhesitatingly predicts success for his minions at the start of the season.

WAR-HORSES should be used with discretion, yet any ballet company with Erik Bruhn on its payroll might be excused from wanting to see him astride one of ballet's more bedizened steeds. Last night at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center the Royal Danish Ballet once again presented him in the "Don Quixote pas de deux," as the partner of Kirsten Simone.
Guests at a lavish Long Island wedding last month appeared yesterday before a Federal grand jury interested in whether they had found more time to discuss underworld business than the bride's gown.

Gov. Richard J. Hughes is starting out energetically to redeem his campaign pledges. Having won the assent of the Democratic leaders in the Legislature to such forward steps as abolishing the party caucus and the antiquated practice of Senatorial courtesy, the Governor is now moving to provide the Garden State with the new sources of revenue it so badly needs.
" LA FANCIULLA DEL WEST:" "The Girl of the Golden West." It came back to the Metropolitan Opera last night after a three-season absence, and there were one or two special things about the occasion.
Jackie Gleason's television show is undergoing changes in format. The comedian and the Columbia Broadcasting System are hoping to give it new appeal.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Dec. 1 -- New Jersey unveiled today Edward Durell Stone's model of a covered 4,800-seat amphitheater that will become the cultural heart of the new $2.5 million Garden State Arts Center.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Combat casualties in the South Vietnamese armed forces rose sharply to 1,505 last week, largely as a result of the Vietcong's destruction of the Seventh Infantry Regiment, a United States military spokesman announced today.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Baltimore Bullets won their third straight game by subduing the New York Knickerbockers; 139-125, tonight in the first game of a National Basketball Association double-header.
A formal announcement on the formation of a Sunday night television "network" by Sylvester L. (Pat.) Weaver was said yesterday to be about "a week or so" away.
The printers' union and newspaper publishers met yesterday on the question of how to introduce automation found that they were far apart.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 1 -- The chief bargainer for the nation's major steel-producing companies warned here tonight that unions can cause unemployment for their members "by pricing their services and jobs out of competition."

Once again the New York Rangers dissipated a two-goal first-period lead against Toronto as the Maple Leafs rallied for a 2-2 tie last night at Madison Square Garden. George Armstrong and Eddie Shack got third-period goals for the Leafs to earn the deadlock in a National Hockey League game watched by 13,123.
An increase of 1,114,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

HONG KONG, Dec. 1 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China met today with a delegation of North Vietnamese economic specialists in talks believed to have centered on plans for increased Chinese aid to Hanoi.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 1 -- The baseball trade winds stirred today as the major leagues moved their winter meetings to Miami Beach. There were two deals that interested but did not involve the Yankees and the Mets.
Farmers, apparently still sending small numbers of hogs to market and getting good prices for them, again had an influence on pork belly futures yesterday. And once again the contracts set new highs.
CARMEL, Calif., Dec. 1 -- Joan Baez, folk singer and militant pacifist, has received approval from the Monterey County Board of Supervisors to operate an institute for the study of nonviolence.

A price increase on tool-steel and drill-rod products was rescinded yesterday by the fabricated metals division of the H.K. Porter Company as a consequence of what it called competitive market conditions.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell failed to appear in the State Supreme Court yesterday for financial examination growing out of a $46,500 judgment against him for defamation of character. Supreme Court Justice Saul S. Streit made this comment from the bench:

UNDER her clear plastic coat, the girl was wearing a snug maillot that glittered like metal and matched her gold helmet and boots. She wasn't stepping into outer space or a contemporary edition of the Ziegfeld Follies -- she was modeling the successor to the Body Stocking, called Goldbody. It was just part of the spring collection of foundation garments and underwear introduced yesterday by Warner's.
United States-flag passenger service from a United States mainland port to San Juan, P.R., will be available again for the first time in more than 12 years.

The skyscraper, an American invention, is finding a new destiny in Europe. It is being used for housing, on a huge scale and in radical forms that are having a revolutionary effect on the landscape and the way people live.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Dr. Andrew C. Ivy, the scientific adviser on the drug Krebiozen, took the witness stand in Federal Court today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Manufacturers' sales, new orders and inventories all increased slightly in October, the Commerce Department reported today.

Bargain-hunting small investors swarmed into the stock market yesterday to help push the volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange to its highest level in two months. Price changes were narrowly mixed.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- A new 700-foot pier will be built here at Pier 179 North for the handling of container shipments, under a lease signed by Sea-Land Service, Inc., and the Delaware River Terminal, Inc.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks put on a second-period surge tonight to beat the Boston Bruins, 4-2, and climb back into a tie with Montreal for the National Hockey League lead.

The Board of Estimate agreed tentatively late yesterday to award three two-year contracts for experimental operation of community antenna television service carrying TV signals into the home by wire. Wire transmission vastly improves reception.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 1 -- India is facing the most serious food shortage in her 18-year history as an independent nation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 -- President Johnson pledged today that repeal of Section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Law would be given "high priority" when Congress reconvenes in January.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 1 -- Banque de la Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's biggest bank, absorbed two smaller banks today.
Dr. Harold W. Bialkowsky was elected yesterday as president of the Stora Kopparberg Corporation, New York.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Britain, moving sharply toward a tougher policy, said today that she was prepared to send troops into Rhodesia if necessary to protect the power supply from the Kariba Dam.
It was good, last night, to see Town Hall looking full and festive for a change, and better still to hear what brought this happy situation about: the Bach Aria Group, beginning its 20th season.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 30 -- "Where is Camilo?" the people of Bogota often ask one another about Camilo Torres, a former Colombian priest who urged revolution in his country. The answer invariably is: "Nobody knows."

Seymour Wakschal, a local violinist of many years' professional experience, chose for his recital debut last night at Carnegie Hall a list of big romantic pieces that worked against him by dwarfing his playing.

ANNISTON, Ala., Dec. 1 -- An all-white jury retired tonight after 3 1/2 hours of deliberation today failed to produce a verdict in the trial of a segregationist charged with the nightrider slaying of a Negro foundry worker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- With Communist China and the Soviet Union pouring supplies into North Vietnam, the pressure is mounting here to bomb Haiphong harbor. Bombing advocates say that the harbor installations can be destroyed without seriously endangering the civilian population.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy declared yesterday that the trend in Latin America was toward progressive leadership and reforms and that if the United States did not support that trend it would "face a disaster" in the area.
The Air Line Pilots Association has aligned itself with advocates of a fourth major airport for the metropolitan area.
A tremendous price rise in Syntex helped pace a moderate advance on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as volume continued to soar for the second consecutive session.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 -- An unusual gift for the new Mayor of the Israeli sector of Jerusalem, Teddy Kollek, broke the tension last night after a political flare-up had marred his inauguration.

New buildings for a high school in Suffolk County and for an automobile parts export concern in Nassau received top architectural awards at the annual dinner of the Long Island Association of Commerce and Industry last night.

Mrs. Mary E. Kelley, who was ordered in Queens Supreme Court last week to pay $740,000 because her auto frightened a man to death seven years ago, said yesterday that she would ask a reversal on the ground that she had not been represented in court.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 1 -- The Southern Association of Colleges and Schools removed today the threat of disaccreditation it had placed against the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and other tax-supported North Carolina colleges because of the state's controversial ban on Communist speakers, which was repealed last month.
The Gold Key of New York City was presented yesterday by Mayor Wagner to Chancellor Josef Klaus of Austria. The presentation took place at Gracie Mansion, the Mayor's official residence.

BOSTON COLLEGE, Boston University and Cornell are rated as the top college hockey teams in the East. Something may have to give Saturday, however, when Boston College plays Cornell before a sellout crowd of 4,200 at Lynah Hall in Ithaca, N.Y.

WITH the score tied at 4-4, Mikhail Tal, a former world champion, buckled under the pressure in the ninth game of his 12-game match with Boris Spassky. The two Soviet grand masters were playing in Tbilisi, Soviet Georgia, for the right to challenge the world champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union.
A jury inquest was ordered yesterday to fix a fine against Representative Adam Clayton Powell for having fraudulently transferred property to avoid paying a defamation judgment.

Mike Garrett, the Heisman Trophy winner from Southern California, and Donny Anderson of Texas Tech are the half-backs on the 1965 Associated Press All-America football team named yesterday. Anderson was named for the second straight year.
IT is generally more entertaining to read Shaw than to read about Shaw. That preference is happily enhanced in this massive and astounding collection of his early letters.
A fast-talking New York labor union leader with a gift for vivid illustration addressed a London conference of the printing industry yesterday on a trans-Atlantic telephone hookup.

MR. MOTO, the not-so-private eye who only yesterday excited all the juveniles by chasing clues all over his native Hawaiian heath or in palm-studded California, is now operating in foggy London in "The Return of Mr. Moto," an extremely garrulous and inane whodunit that turned up yesterday at local theaters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The new immigration law abolishing the national-origins quota system became effective today, but its full effects will not be felt for about two and a half years.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

Ambassador Goldberg in his Nov. 12 speech to the Security Council on the Rhodesian crisis said: "It is now for all of us to stand behind the United Kingdom to lend it all necessary assistance and support in making effective the measures that it has taken.

The Johnson Administration's repeated demands for greater restraint on the part of business and labor are increasingly in conflict with its own economic behavior and with its statements -- repeated yesterday -- downgrading the dangers of inflation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The White House Conference on International Cooperation ended today by submitting some 300 recommendations to the Administration on steps that could be taken to further cooperation and peace in the world.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller has informed Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay that New York City will receive $903.8 million in total state aid next year -- an increase of $101.2 million over the amount in this year's state budget.
The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission designated Brooklyn Heights yesterday as the city's first "historic district." It also named eight more Manhattan buildings as landmarks.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company completed yesterday the sale to private investors of 600,000 shares of 5 1/8 per cent cumulative preferred stock and called for the redemption of all the 713,353 shares of its outstanding cumulative preferred stock.

The United Artists Corporation attained the highest earnings in its 48-year history in the third quarter and first nine months this year, according to the report yesterday by Robert S. Benjamin, chairman, and Arthur B. Krim, president.
Consolidated earnings of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway in November climbed to $7.2 million, or 82 cents a share, from $5.1 million, or 57 cents a share, in the month last year.
BLUE POINT, L.I., Dec. 1 -- Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea Jr. of Montauk announced today that he was seeking the post of Republican minority leader in the State Assembly that convenes next month.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 1 -- President Johnson approved this afternoon a plan that could eliminate 25,000 Government jobs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- It was a great surprise today when Rollo -- the boy nuisance of American literature, whose endless demands for the "why" of everything made him the Brat of All Time -- appeared in this office, still a child despite the passage of 131 years.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay announced yesterday that Thomas P.F. Hoving would be the city's next Parks Commissioner.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor was asked today to tone down the promotional activities of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.

A spokesman for New York's Roman Catholic bishops restated yesterday the church's opposition to anything "tantamount to divorce by consent" and urged that any revised law include machinery for reconciling feuding couples.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 1 -- Rhodesia began a gradual shift of trade from Britain to South Africa today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Johnson Administration would like to move against de facto segregation where there is a marked inequality of schools within a district but has not yet found a legal basis for doing so.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 1 -- The lawyers completed their arguments late today in the Federal Conspiracy trial of three Ku Klux Klan members.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Persons 65 and older who do not enroll by March 31 for the voluntary medical insurance under the new Medicare program will have to wait two years for another chance.
Mayor Wagner, who in his three terms has addressed about 17,500 police graduates, said yesterday in a farewell talk to 414 new policemen that New York was the safest city in the United States.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Welfare administrators from across the nation met here today with an eye on the Federal Treasury for more money, mixed feelings about the antipoverty campaign and reports that birth control was becoming a generally accepted part of local welfare programs.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 1 -- A Brazilian money operator was questioned by tax investigators last week on how he could own a bank, two luxurious apartments, five automobiles and a portfolio of blue chip stocks and declare so little income tax.
WASHINGTON Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that shoplifting was the nation's fastest growing form of larceny, having increased 93 per cent in the last five years.

TUESDAY was Kenneth Lane ay at Saks Fifth Avenue. The young jewelry designer who creates masterpieces of fakery stood amid the artistic clutter of tables and showcases laden with his works for an exclusive Kenneth Lane jewelry collection now available in Saks's Park Avenue Room.
Mayor Wagner introduced himself last night as a "frustrated violinist" making his last appearance at a concert in the Council Chamber at City Hall.

International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., confirmed yesterday that they had been discussing a merger "from time to time over the past several months."

Fred J. Borch, president and chief executive officer of the General Electric Company, voiced alarm yesterday at what he termed a trend toward "resurgent nationalism" in economic affairs in many parts of the world.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- President de Gaulle has transformed the political landscape of France and has given his country a new set of basic institutions.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -The American Medical Association decided today against urging states to loosen their abortion laws.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 1 -- Those sharpies who have been "beating the house" via place and show bets on prohibitive favorites at Roosevelt Raceway will be confronted with another obstacle there tomorrow night, if they seek to cash in on Cardigan Bay in the $50,000 National Pacing Derby.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that North Vietnam had declined to answer diplomatic inquiries "every week" on the prospect that a halt in American bombing would lead to negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Johnson Administration struck back on three fronts today to counter what appeared to be growing public concern over the threat of inflation.

A Supreme Court jury last night found Richard Robles guilty of first-degree murder in the 1963 slayings of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert. After the jury deliberated almost five hours, the five women and seven men returned to the dimly lit court room at 6:50 P.M. to announce the verdict against the 22-year-old defendant.
Prices dropped again yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, still influenced by the decline in oils on Tuesday and generally hesitant investor sentiment.

ALL National Championships give rise to a crop of unusual episodes, and last week's Fall Nationals in San Francisco were no exception. The funniest was perhaps the story of the expert whose opponent looked suspiciously at his convention card and demanded to know the meaning of a cryptic entry "U.S.I. 18 points."

SIX years ago, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Miriglia of River Vale, N.J., gave their son, Mark, a 4-month-old German shepherd for Christmas. "We called the pup Maja," said Mrs. Miriglia, "the first two letters in our son's name and the first two in my hus band's."
Perched on a six-foot stepladder in the cavernous Great Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art most of these days is a 61-year-old grandmother in a bright red smock, decorating a Christmas tree.
Several hundred businessmen interested in trade with Communist nations heard yesterday that there was plenty of it, but that United States manufacturers faced numerous obstacles getting their share.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 1 -- A $50 million United States aid package for the Dominican Republic is being wrapped up, due to be delivered here well before Christmas.

SANTA FE, N.M., Dec. 1 -- Perhaps because of the altitude and the rarefied atmosphere of the region, the people of Santa Fe dine early. For Alexander Girard, the architect and designer, and his wife, evening entertaining begins about 6:30.

MIAMI, Dec. 1 -- Seventy-five Cuban refugees, who said they had been stripped of most of their belongings by Premier Fidel Castro's Government, were flown here this afternoon by the United States. It was the first flight in what may become one of history's great exoduses.

THE Connection is far from obvious, but an observer still doesn't need the deductive powers of a Sherlock Holmes to trace the faint links that tie together a strange sequence of events. The key figure in this odd story is Cookie Lavagetto, presumably as incidental a character in the plot as the butler.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Lord Caradon of Britain pleaded with the Special Political Committee today to refrain from recommending measures it could not enforce in its efforts to destroy South Africa's policy of apartheid.
FRUNZE, U.S.S.R., Nov. 28 -- The three-hour airplane trip between Dushanbe and Frunze invites comparisons between two capitals and two peoples.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1 -- Argentine Jews are seeking a more influential role in international Jewish councils. They want, above all, to gain wider recognition as the world's fourth-largest Jewish community, whose Latin-American identity must be better understood and respected.

The new tree lights shine in many forms: 1. Spiky crystal tree-top light, $5, B. Altman Co., 8th floor. 2. String of mosaic stained-glass lights, $11, Lord Taylor, 9th floor. 3. Mirror lights with tinsel inside, $5, Gimbels, 6th floor. 4. Lights of colored glass and fake stones, $6.50, Bloomingdale's, 6th floor.

Some graduate and college students, denied draft deferments by local selective service boards, will be able to continue their education. In many instances, the local boards are reversing their decisions when the students appeal.

The Second Special Inter-American Conference of Foreign Ministers at Rio de Janeiro was a partial success, which was more than the pessimists expected when it began. The controversial issues, such as United States intervention in the Dominican Republic, were avoided. The agreements reached are useful, although none is of first-rate importance.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 -- The almost total elimination this year of alien farm labor from California agriculture was declared "virtually a complete success" today by Secretary of labor W. Willard Wirtz.
A PRETTY young thing was in a midtown sporting goods store yesterday. She confessed she was a beginner at skiing and asked to see some low-priced equipment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A trustee of the New Haven railroad told an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing here today that he would expect the railroad's creditors to "move promptly to liquidate the carrier" if it isn't soon relieved of the obligation to run passenger trains and if its freight operations aren't merged with a major trunk line.
Jim Brown of the Cleveland Browns needs only one touchdown to tie the season record of 20 in the National Football League, set by Lenny Moore of Baltimore.
A dozen city high schools systematically upgrade, or conceal, student failures on transcripts sent to colleges.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The American Medical Association's policy-making House of Delegates authorized its board of trustees today to test the constitutionality of Medicare if an opportunity arose.
" As long as you work for someone, you'll never get rich."

Isolde Traut, a young, pretty musician from England, proved to be doubly talented in her local debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. She can play keyboard instruments; she can sing. She combined these abilities in an unconventional way by singing Elizabethan songs by John Dowland and English folk songs as she accompanied herself on a lute-harpsichord.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy, back from a three-week tour of South America, will barely have time to greet his family and distribute some Latin-American trinkets before he must start grappling with a host of home-grown political problems.

The city's efforts to take the countdown element out of bargaining for a new subway labor agreement have got badly off the track. Michael J. Quill, in desperate search of ways to stall until the New Year's Day strike deadline approaches, has jubilantly pounced on an offer by Mayor-elect Lindsay to be helpful as an excuse for breaking off negotiations with the Transit Authority.

Apropos your editorial of Nov. 13 on the iniquities of parking in our city, there is a precinct of privilege which centers on Park Avenue and some of the adjacent side streets in the 70's, 80's and 90's.
Lord Shawcross, who has achieved distinction and high honors as a politician, lawyer and businessman, has entered banking.
The freshly painted white lettering on the old, two-story firehouse tucked between a warehouse and the office of a window cleaner at 159 East 87th Street says "13 Hook Ladder 13."
MANILA, Dec. 1 -- The Philippines won today an uphill battle for the selection of Manila as the permanent site for the new $1 billion Asian Development Bank.

NEWARK, Dec. 1 -- Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio gathered representatives of two teachers' unions and Board of Education officials in his office here tonight for continuous bargaining in an effort to avert a teachers' strike threatened for tomorrow.
The British pound held steady on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. After a day of quiet trading, the currency closed at $2.8027, down 1 point from the Tuesday level.
The First National City Bank announced yesterday the appointment of Carl W. Desch as senior vice president and cashier and Leif H. Olsen as senior vice president and economist.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- The 19th Holiday Ball of the Junior League of Mount Kisco will be held at the Bel-Aire Country Club in Armonk on Saturday.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 1 -- The two astronauts of Gemini 7 went to see their doctor today and after a five-hour head-to-toe examination came away with medical clearance for their 14-day space ride.

Dr. Philip B. Armstrong (letter Nov. 12) evidently wants the health of elderly Americans left in the hands of charity. Although he does not call it "charity," no other meaning can logically be drawn from his use of the phrase "voluntary social cooperation," a concept which he advocates in place of Federal Medicare.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1 -- A Federal court ordered Ku Klux Klansmen today to halt "acts of terror and intimidation" aimed at preserving white supremacy in Bogalusa, La.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 -- American ready-to-wear fashions for next spring made a hit yesterday with 800 Mexican and American women who will be able to buy them only by getting to a store in the United States.

A sudden upsurge has been reported in the number of patients admitted to Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital because of bad reactions to LSD, a drug that produces powerful hallucinations and is being used experimentally in the treatment of mental illness.

TOKYO, Dec. 1 -- Stock averages have reached a two-year high here, despite a tenacious business recession, and financial circles expect the Government to act to curb speculation if the apparently unrealistic trend continues much further.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 1 -- Britain and Zambia headed for a showdown tonight on plans for sending British troops and planes to act as a buffer with Rhodesia.
There was more talk than action yesterday in the bond market, according to several operators in the Treasury, corporate and municipal securities areas.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Discrepancies noted by auditors in the accounts of a big printing company have revived demands for stricter controls over corporate affairs, possibly in the form of a British-style Securities and Exchange Commission.
The Transport Workers Union yesterday broke off contract negotiations with the Transit Authority.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo Dec. 1 -- Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu, the Congo's new President, today assumed the power to rule the country by decree.
THOMAS PEARSALL FIELD HOVING, the newly appointed Commissioner of Parks, is a dashing man of action who flits around town on a Jawa motorcycle and eats meatball hero sandwiches.

The consensus among brokers yesterday was that Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, had utterly shattered Wall Street's frail hopes for an increase in commission rates within the near future.
The Metropolitan Opera Company will visit Paris this spring for the first time since 1910.

SINCE Saturday's separate drafts of college football players by the two major professional leagues, the New York Jets have announced the signing of four men (two yesterday). They have probably signed two others.
Expansion programs were announced yesterday by three companies in the metals and mining industries.

ROME, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller promised early relief today to the overcrowded Rome State School for the Mentally Retarded and he criticized Senator Robert F. Kennedy for having "misrepresented" conditions at the institution.

Neill K. Banks has been elected manufacturing vice president of the New Jersey Zinc Company. Formerly assistant to the manufacturing vice president, Mr. Banks succeeds George F. Halfacre in the post. Mr. Halfacre is retiring.

A major interstate bookmaker who jumped from one public telephone both to another in a "foolproof" operation to protect his business estimated at $5 million to $10 million a year was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan to four years in prison and was fined $20,000.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- British television viewers learned today that when they get color television it will probably be on the German color system known as P.A.L. rather than on the French or United States systems.

MONTREAL, Dec. 1 -- The second man sought in connection with the $423,421 Brink's burglary at Syracuse in October, in which a 20-mm. antitank gun was used, was arrested at 3 A.M. today by the Montreal police.

BORDEAUX, France, Dec. 1 -- Francois Mitterrand, candidate of the left and President de Gaulle's chief challenger in Sunday's Presidential election, called tonight for abolition of France's fledgling nuclear-strike force and "top priority" for education.

The New York State Banking Board, acting on the recommendation of Frank Wille, the State Superintendent of Banks, put its imprimatur yesterday on a proposal of the Bankers Trust Company to form a bank holding company.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- A French proposal for United Nations budget reforms was approved without opposition today by the General Assembly's Budget Committee.

A group headed by the Northern Trust Company, Drexel Co., Continental Illinois National Bank Trust Co. of Chicago, the Chase Manhattan Bank, Glore Forgan, and Wm. R. Staats, Inc., apparently submitted the best bids yesterday for bond issues totaling $16.48 million of two Indianapolis, Ind., districts.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- The Political Committee voted today to bar nuclear weapons from Africa. The vote was 105 to 0.
DEER hunters who believe they can look at the rack of antlers of a buck and knowledgeably ascertain its age are just making conversation.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, defeataed Tony Roche of the Australian Davis Cup team, 3-6, 6-1, 6-3, 5-7, 6-4 today in the third round of the men's singles in the Victorian tennis championship.

A five-alarm fire destroyed the Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy at 26 West 84th Street yesterday afternoon as 240 firemen fought to prevent it from spreading to adjacent apartment houses.
Setting his own pace under the calm guidance of Braulio Baeza, the Harbor View Farm's Gary G. registered a four-length triumph in the $28,400 Remsen Mile at Aqueduct yesterday.
ST. GEORGE, S.C., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Two Congress of Racial Equality workers were arrested today after leading a singing picket line outside a Negro school.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 1 -- Three Stamford homes decorated for the holidays will be open for a tour from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. tomorrow to raise funds for civic projects sponsored by the Stamford Garden Club.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 -- An Investment Bankers Association committee expressed today its opposition to what it called "some glaring examples of unnecessary Federal aid."
PEKING, Dec. 1 -- Communist China is making it plain that it is ready for a protracted struggle in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- On guard, women of America! The perfumed male is loose among you in 200 different irresistible aromas, and if the promises of the ad boys bear up, the mayhem among the female population will be devastating.
The directors of the Aerojet-General Corporation appointed Dan A. Kimball yesterday as chairman of the company's executive committee.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- North Vietnam has shown no interest in recent indirect soundings by Secretary General Thant on the possibility of negotiations to settle the war in Vietnam, reliable sources said today.
SAN FRANCISCO. Dec. 1 -- The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra opened its 54th season tonight, but it was a close call.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, may clip the fledgling wings of a Federally aided Syracuse project intended to organize the poor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The first round in a bitter freight-rate dispute between the New York Central and the Baltimore Ohio Railroads was won today by the B. O.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- "Simon Boccanegra" arrived at Covent Garden tonight for the first time.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 -- Sally Benson, a fragile, 68-year-old writer who has long nurtured a passion for mystery stories, emerged today as the focal point of a bizarre case involving narcotics and an alleged Communist conspiracy.

Salary increases for about 5,000 employes of the Board of Higher Education and 3,000 employes of the Board of Education were announced yesterday. The increases will take effect in three stages -- the first retroactive to last July 1, the second next July 1 and the third on next Oct. 1.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- A Federal judge cleared the St. Augustine courts of civil rights cases today in a sweeping order that dismissed about 1,000 charges against demonstrators, includ ing the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

NEWARK, Dec. 1 -- The Hughes Administration has decided to seek repeal of the state's commuter benefit tax when it introduces a graduated income tax next month to the incoming Democratic-controlled Legislature.

Justino Diaz, the 26-year old Puerto Rican basso, took on his 16th role with the Metropolitan Opera last night as he breezed through his first Mephistopheles in Gounod's "Faust." He had recently sung the role with the Washington Opera Society.

MANILA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Ships in the South China Sea searched today for survivors from a 9,500-ton oil installation platform that broke in two and capsized while being towed by a Dutch tug. One report said that 14 men were missing.

IT is commonplace that the art of book design and the quality of book production have suffered a serious and continuing decline since -- well, since books became commercial products. Like so many commonplaces, it is true -- and not true. In the glorious days of yore, there weren't many books around.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 2 -- President Johnson took a personal hand today in the Administration's apparent effort to allay fears of inflation.
The Government securities market gave superficial indications of perking up yesterday morning, but closing prices were basically unchanged on the day.

CAIRO, Dec. 2 -- Yemeni republicans are reported to have rejected the terms of the Saudi-Arabian-Egyptian peace agreement on Yemen and to have warned that efforts to abolish the republican form of government will prolong the country's three-year civil war.

ATLANTA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that if the House Committee on Un-American Activities investigates the civil rights movement, it could well mean the end of the committee.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 2 -- The Baseball Hall of Fame was petitioned today to waive its rules and immediately enshrine Casey Stengel as one of the greats of the game.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- The Crocker Citizens National Bank concluded its defense today against the Government's antitrust prosecution with an emphatic contention that its $3.75 billion merger increased, rather than lessened, competition.

The chairman of the Board of Higher Education charged yesterday that the recent proposal for a theoretical tuition fee in the City University, if enacted, would have led to a state take-over of the city system.
Mike Garrett, Southern California's all-America half-back, received the Heisman Trophy as college football's outstanding performer for 1965 at the Downtown Athletic Club last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Mike Garrett of Southern California, the Heisman Trophy winner, heads a squad of 25 players from 16 schools named to the West squad today for the 41st annual East-West football game Dec. 31.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings, sparked by Norm Ullman's three goals, exploded out of the National Hockey League cellar tonight with a 10-2 victory over Boston. The Bruins dropped into last place.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 2 -- Following is the prepared text of the remarks by President Johnson today to members of the Business Council in Washington:
Items donated for the fifth annual Operation Boutique of the Kips Bay Boys' Club will go on sale Monday in the clubhouse, which is at 301 East 52d Street.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday a series of constitutional amendments designed to give members who deal directly with the public a bigger say in the way the Big Board is run.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange were mixed yesterday in active trading. Changes either way were mostly small, but a few issues experienced rather wide swings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- William H. Draper Jr., the new national chairman of the Population Crisis Committee, warned today that the developing nations faced widespread starvation in the coming decade unless a massive population control program was begun immediately.

The Baldwin-Montrose Chemical Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had entered into a contract to sell its entire holdings in General Artists Corporation, a 70-per-cent-owned talent agency subsidiary of Baldwin.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Dreamy Price was the name of the horse and that's what she paid in the third race at Pimlico today.

The United Gas Corporation disputed yesterday the contention of the Pennzoil Company that the purchase of more than 10 per cent of United Gas's common by Pennzoil would not make United subject to regulation under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 2 -- Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Foreign Minister of Pakistan, said here tonight that his Government hoped the visit of President Mohammad Ayub Khan to Washington next week would serve to "arrest deterioration in United States-Pakistan relations."
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart of Britain went before a Soviet television audience tonight and urged the convening of an immediate peace conference on Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales in the week ended Nov. 27 amounted to $5.4 billion, about 7 per cent above the corresponding week last year.
An unusual plea for truth in advertising was made yesterday by Richard K. Manoff, chairman of the agency that bears his name.

The jury in the trial of William Epton heard a tape recording yesterday that was made on July 21, 1964, in the headquarters of the Progressive Labor Movement, 336 Lenox Avenue, in which the voices of Mr. Epton and others were heard discussing the Harlem riots of the previous weekend.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A Commerce Department publica-i tion said today that a rise in] prices of goods exported by thei United States may be "of some', importance" in explaining a! much slower growth of exports! this year than last.

The 71-year-old warden of the Hudson County jail in Jersey City -- known to inmates as "Mein Host Harry" -- and a convicted prostitute were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on perjury charges.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- Delegates to the convention of the Building Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations voted full support today for President Johnson's policies and military decisions in Vietnam.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday designated J. Lee Rankin, former United States Solicitor General, to be Corporation Counsel and said Mr. Rankin would have a major role in the new administration.
NEWARK, Dec. 2 -- About a fourth of Newark's 3,200 public school teachers went on strike today in the first such walkout in the city's history, but they failed to close a single school.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Directors of the Chicago North Western Railway announced today an increase of $1 a share in its common stock dividend for next year and possible savings for stockholders in income taxes on dividends.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 2 -- If newspapers are to stay abreast of the times and other media, they must recast or amend their traditional definitions of news, Turner Catledge, executive editor of The New York Times, said here tonight.

The New York Philharmonic will give five performances of Gustav Mahler's Symphony No. 8 in the next two weeks. The Eighth is called the "Symphony of a Thousand" because of the huge forces required for its performance, and it is played infrequently.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., would like to replace nine of the 27 vice presidents on the Executive Council of the organization at the convention starting next week in San Francisco.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler, who frequently speaks -- and eats -- at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel when he is in New York City, did both again yesterday. He told a receptive National Association of Manufacturers audience that, in effect, they never had it so good.

The American Stock Exchange went the competition across Trinity Churchyard one better yesterday, and announced it planned to increase initial and maintenance margin requirements on volatile issues -- when and if the circumstances dictate.
President Johnson's bullish economic forecast yesterday did not prevent the stock market from giving a decidedly bearish performance.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 -- Senator George McGovern, one of the Senate's soft-spoken critics of United States policy on Vietnam, left South Vietnam today somewhat reassured on several questions that had disquieted him.
SUSAN NEVELSON, who designs fabrics for Ken Scott in Italy but wore a spectacular abstract print by Tzaims Luksus, another fabric designer, didn't go to the Parsons School of Design.

THEIR defensive line, spongy for the New York Giants all season, was revised again yesterday by Coach Allie Sherman out of necessity. Lou Slaby, a 240-pound combative middle linebacker who was displaced at that position by Jerry Hillebrand two months ago, will start at right tackle against Pittsburgh here on Sunday in place of Roger LaLonde, who is hurt.
Michael J. Quill threatened yesterday to call a subway and bus strike at 5 A.M. Dec. 15 instead of waiting until his union's contract expires New Year's Day.
OTTAWA, Dec. 2 -- The always difficult problem of clearing the St. Lawrence Seaway system before winter sets in was compounded today by labor trouble, high winds and a grounded freighter.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Salvatore Burruni of Italy, aging but still game, twice smashed Rocky Gattellari of Australia to the canvas tonight before knocking him out at 2 minutes 25 seconds of the 13th round in a bout billed locally as for "the world flyweight championship."

WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 2 -- The $50,000 National Pacing Derby, the oldest event on the Roosevelt Raceway calendar, wasn't much of a betting race tonight. It was, however, a keen duel between the heavily-favored Cardigan Bay and the mildly-backed second-choice Adora's Dream.

Highway officials in some states shave costs by offering less than fair market value for land needed for highway improvements. Sometimes pressure is brought on owners by starting condemnation proceedings before negotiations begin on the price.

There's one style of hostess evening slipper that Delman will sell only to the woman whose house is furnished with wall-to-wall carpeting. That's because the soles of the gold snakeskin slippers are paved with jewels (tiny, multicolored glass, of course) and would constitute a hazard on a parquet floor.

Harris, Upham Co., Inc., one of the nation's 10 largest brokerage concerns, said yesterday it would acquire Eisele King, Libaire, Stout Co., another member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, on Jan. 1.
CHULAI, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 -- In Chulai, Danang and Phubai, the war is wet feet and mud and rain.

VAN NUYS, Calif. -- The big purple sign welcoming visitors to Every Woman's Village stands incongruously atop a squat, battered-looking bungalow. Behind the bungalow sit five other drab little structures, which, at any given time of the day or night, are normally crammed with women busily partaking of "instant culture."
The Contemporary Music Society got its concert series at the Guggenheim Museum this season off to a bracing start last night.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Not a few people were surprised when Prime Minister Wilson somewhat more than a year ago picked Arthur George Bottomley, then 57 years old, as his Secretary for Commonwealth Relations.

The Advisory Council on Reapportionment will recommend to the New York State Legislature that new Senate and Assembly district lines be drawn with the aid of modern technology. Use of computers for this purpose is an innovation, but it offers the first real hope of getting away from the bad old ways that have been practiced for generations behind closed doors.

Vincent C. Ross of the Westchester Country Club was elected president of the Metropolitan Golf Association at its annual meeting held yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. Ross takes over the office held the last two years by William Y. Dear Jr. of Morristown.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 2 -- President Johnson ordered a report tonight on the causes of the Southwest blackout.
ANNISTON, Ala., Dec. 2 -- An all-white jury sentenced a segregationist today to 10 years in prison for the night-rider slaying of a Negro foundry worker.
Complete authority for directing the diversified activities of American Metal Climax, Inc., was given yesterday to Frank Coolbaugh, president and chairman of the finance committee.

IF Dick McGuire's introductory remarks lacked the emotional fervor of the ringing oration of Spartacus to the gladiators, at least they achieved an immediate response. The new coach of the New York Knickerbockers addressed his troops on Tuesday before sending them forth into their first battle under his standard.
Prices were steady at the close of trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, with volume curtailed by uncertainties growing out of the Rhodesian situation.
An increase in sales but a drop in net earnings for the fiscal year ended Oct. 30, was reported yesterday by Armour Co., the diversified foods, chemicals and industrial-equipment company.
TOKYO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- North Vietnam, in a determined attempt to push its war effort, said today that it "must build and develop its local industry" during the next two years.

State Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz has appointed an advisory panel of real estate experts to assist his office in formulating policies and fashioning legislation in relation to the development of condominiums.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 2 -- Leo Durocher and Herman Franks, who were manager and coach of the New York Giants a decade ago, made their first trade as the respective managers of the Chicago Cubs and San Francisco Giants today, with Leo betting on the future and Herman trying to undo last season's problems.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Herb FitzGibbon of Garden City, L.I., upset Arthur Ashe today in the third round of the Victorian tennis championship, 6-2, 14-12, 9-7.

Carnegie Hall was filled last night by admirers of Louis Armstrong who paid from $5 to $50 each to attend a salute to the jazz trumpeter. The affair was sponsored by the American Guild of Variety Artists for the benefit of its youth fund.
A third Democratic candidate for the Congressional seat to be vacated by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay entered the race yesterday

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 2 -- An all-white jury in the Federal conspiracy trial of three Ku Klux Klan members who are on trial in connection with the killing of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo, deliberated all day today without reaching a verdict.
The British pound was mostly steady in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2.8030, up 3 points from the level on Wednesday.

For many years I have followed the news in your columns on architecture and on the preservation of city landmarks. I read with sorrow on Nov. 7 that the official designations of the Landmarks Preservation Commission would be opposed by some of the great institutions of New York.
The United States is facing the certainty of further escalation of the Vietnamese war. Secretary McNamara has made this clear.
MIAMI, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Ninety-four Cubans arrived today on the refugee airlift that may bring more than 100,000 here.

Wayne Thomas Lonergan, who was convicted 21 years ago of murdering his heiress wife in her East Side duplex, was paroled yesterday from Clinton State Prison, Dannemora, N.Y., and immediately deported to Canada.
Lawyers for Richard Robles, who was convicted Wednesday night for the murders of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert, indicated yesterday that they would appeal the verdict.

About a week from now, unless there is an unexpected hitch, a computer will start juggling voluminous data it has stored on New York State's population and its geographical distribution. In half an hour, it will calculate new legislative districts for the state.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The nation's unemployment rate declined to 4.2 per cent last month as November employment showed more vitality than usual.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, appealed today for the help of professional social workers who have resented competition from the Federal antipoverty campaign he heads.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology suggested in a report to the Government today the possibility of tube trains running at 200 to 300 miles an hour between Boston and Washington by 1980.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 2 -- Suits totaling $175,000 have been filed against the Bridgeport Boy Scouts council in behalf of two Scouts, charging that the boys had toes amputated because of frostbite suffered during a weekend hiking trip in freezing weather last winter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is planning to mark its 10th anniversary next week with a major transfusion of new blood.

Farbwerke Hoechst, A.G., of West Germany and the Hercules Powder Company announced yesterday they planned to establish a joint subsidiary in the United States for the production of polyester staple fibers.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 2 -- A new automatic timing device designed, built and operated by Paul Shattuck of Morristown, Pa., was activated on the Oakes Field race course today as all entrants for the big weekend of racing here went through a compulsory practice session.

SUSPENSION of disbelief -- that is at least one thing the performing arts are all about Birgit Cullber's ballet, "Miss Julie," given last night by the Royal Danish Ballet, is in many respects a gimcrack ballet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Consumer instalment credit rose by $589 million in October, the smallest rise for any month this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Federal Reserve System added $747 million to its holdings of United States Government securities on an average day during the week ended last Wednesday.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Dec. 2 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today that Dr. Finn J. Larsen, a Norwegian-born scientist from Hopkins, Minn., will become principal deputy director of defense research and engineering.
The subway patrol force will be augmented starting Dec. 15 in a drive to curb teen-age vandalism and "rumbles' between 2 and 4 P.M., Acting Transit Commissioner John J. Gilhooley disclosed yesterday.

EL, PASO, Tex., Dec. 2 -- About one million persons in sections of two states and Mexico were plunged into darkness tonight by a power failure in El Paso, but most service was restored two hours later.

There will be four quintets -- three in Brooklyn and one in Queens -- challenging Pace College's bid to retain its Knickerbocker Conference title this season and all have strength in at least one department.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

A new service for television viewers that is guaranteed to improve reception, both in black and white and in color, will be introduced here within weeks under three franchises unanimously approved last night by the Board of Estimate.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, a self-styled "amateur from way back" in art, is considering legislation that may resolve one of the art world's oldest questons: who is an expert?

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Subpoenas have been served on the head of the New Jersey Ku Klux Klan and a top lieutenant ordering them to testify before a grand jury next Wednesday about their efforts to organize a Klan cell here.
Consumption of newsprint in this country by 1975 will jump to more than 11.4 million tons, an increase of 42 per cent over the more than 8 million tons consumed in 1964.
In calling for full financial disclosure by the securities industry, Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is venturing into a delicate and potentially explosive area.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- A final version of the Ecumenical Council's declaration on problems of marriage, distributed today, confirms the Roman Catholic prohibition on artificial contraception but leaves the way open to change.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The seven years of President de Gaulle's Fifth Republic have profoundly affected the way Frenchmen feel about being French and the way non-Frenchmen view this country.
A top city school official said yesterday that he was preparing a citywide directive to insure uniform practices in the compilation of high-school students' records for college admission borads.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The apparent extravagance of the recent trip to the United States of Princess Margaret and her husband, the Earl of Snowdon, was criticized today in the House of Commons.
The Allied Chemical Tower, a brand-new 60-year-old building in the center of Times Square, was dedicated yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 2 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk indicated tonight that the United States would be willing to attend a peace conference on Vietnam proposed by Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart of Britain.
The proposal of the City Planning Commission for a $1.3 billion improvement of transit facilities endangers the 15-cent fare, the Board of Estimate was told yesterday.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 2 -- Nine Federally aided groups here representing the poor declared war today, not against poverty, but against the Office of Economic Opportunity.
TOKYO, Dec 2 -- Helen Hayes declared today that "management by committee" was hampering the role of the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater in New York.

PARIS -- Although the Vietnamese war is obviously intensifying, this sad fact should not be allowed to obscure two related U.S. gains already registered. Strangely enough, the first gain occurred far away in Jakarta and the second in Washington itself.
BONN, Dec. 2 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard is restudying West Germany's demand for participation in a joint nuclear force, as a result of lack of support within the Government coalition.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 2 -- A principal Indonesian Communist has described his party's plans for taking over the Government last October, an Indonesian Army spokesman said today.

A New York Jets rookie and the Federal Bureau of Investigation combined their skills in the arrest yesterday of an Army recruiting sergeant who allegedly sought $200 from the football player to help him evade the draft.

MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- The weather is mild and slushy in Moscow these days, but the diplomatic weather is cold and frozen. The Russians are still saying "no" on Vietnam negotiations; "no" on the military reorganization of the West's nuclear defenses, and "no" on a treaty to control the spread of nuclear weapons.
MADISON, Wis., Dec. 2 -- The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Spike, director of the Commission on Religion and Race of the National Council of Churches, announced his resignation here tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Dr. Andrew C. Ivy said in Federal court here today he had made unsuccessful efforts to get the American Medical Association and the American Cancer Society to test the controversial anticancer drug Krebiozen
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Government today defined "equilibrium" in the balance of international payments as the range between $250 million in surplus or deficit.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The wife of an internationally known scientist was found strangled today in the basement of the apartment building in which she lived.
HONG KONG, Dec. 2 -- Peking discounted today reports that Mr. Aidit, chairman of the Indonesian Communist party, was dead.

A man-made disaster threatens one of the nation's unique natural treasures. The Everglades National Park in southern Florida is a subtropical paradise, alive with beautiful birds, rare game and exotic vegetation. But it has been seriously damaged by the Army Corps of Engineers; if the Administration does not take forceful action in the next few months, it may be irreparably ruined.

RICHMOND, Dec. 2 -- Leading Southern educators applauded enthusiastically today as Vice President Humphrey attacked the South's preoccupation with history and urged its schools "to make some new history for the future."
Budget Director T. Norman Hurd has told Governor Rockefeller that the state will need $400 million more income in the 1966-67 fiscal year to cover mandatory and obligatory increases in its programs.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Appellate Division of Circuit Court upheld today the conviction of Michael V. Smith, 20 years old, of Darien, for reckless driving and negligent homicide in a 1964 auto accident.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 2 -- Albert Pratt, the grandson of two Boston clipper shipowners and once a Navy commander himself, took over the presidency of the Investment Bankers Association today and swiftly moved it onto a new course.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Prime Minister Wilson disclosed today that he had received word of the acceptance by Zambia of the dispatch there of Royal Air Force planes.
A major steamship line has offered to take six big cargo ships from the national reserve fleet and convert them for charter use by the military in the Southeast Asia emergency sealift.

The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will commission leading composers, playwrights and choreographers to create major works for six television programs. The programs -- each running an hour or longer -- will be presented by the National Educational Television network, which has 102 affiliated stations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The states of New York and Connecticut were said today to have reached agreement in principle to contribute whatever financial assistance is necessary to maintain permanent passenger service between New Haven and Grand Central Terminal in New York City.
American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., advised its employes yesterday that there would be no merger with anyone unless the present "automomous management and operation" of the company were continued.
CAPE KENNEDY, Dec. 2 -- The weather loomed today as a possible threat to Saturday's launching of the 14-day Gemini 7 flight.

The American Institute of Marine Underwriters yesterday elected Archie M. Stevenson president for 1966. Mr. Stevenson, who is vice chairman of Chubb Son, Inc., and of the Federal Insurance Company, succeeds Thomas M. Torrey.
All 15 members of the Commission on Human Rights were frozen in their posts by Mayor Wagner yesterday for terms ranging from one to three years.

MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- The Soviet leadership is laying the groundwork for a substantial expansion of passenger-car production amid speculation that it is looking to consumer spending as a way of stimulating national economy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Secretary General Thant's usefulness as a mediator in arranging peace talks between the United States and North Vietnam has been reduced almost to the vanishing point, Asian diplomatic sources said today.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Backing up strong sales reports in the automobile industry were preliminary production reports for November, which showed today that the 900,000-car mark was passed for only the second time in history.
HONG KONG, Dec. 2 -- Communist China has made adjustments in its economic planning to take account of the possibility of war with the United States.
The Michigan Chemical Corporation, a producer of brine chemicals, has announced the election of Dr. Helmuth W. Schultze as president.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit refused yesterday to establish a blanket rule that would always exclude from evidence any confession obtained when a suspect was not represented by an attorney.
LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 2 -- The jury in the Duane Pope murder trial deliberated 10 hours today without reaching a verdict. Deliberations will resume tomorrow.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- A glittering audience clapped, cheered and yelled "Come on, Dolly, one more," as Mary Martin returned to London for the first time since she washed that man right out of her hair in "South Pacific" 13 years ago.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The Beecham Group, a big proprietary drug company with worldwide interests, announced today it would acquire the shares of Harveys of Bristol, Ltd., the 169-year-old maker of Bristol Cream sherry and other wines.

CHATTANOOGA, Dec. 2 -- Chief United States District Judge Robert L. Taylor today ordered a Federal grand jury to convene here next Wednesday in special session to investigate affidavits and other documents used by James R. Hoffa, president of the teamsters' union, in his third motion for a new trial in his jury-tampering case.

Assemblyman Fred W. Preller, the 63-year-old former Queens Republican leader and former chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, was charged by the Government yesterday with failure to file income tax returns from 1959 to 1963. His income during the five years was put at $178,626.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- (UPI) --Committees of the Amateur Athletic Union cleared the way today for certifying a batch of sports records, including world marks in track and swimming.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- With rare harmony, a General Assembly committee voted unanimously today to build a permanent home for the United Nations International School at 25th Street and the East River.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 2 -- Sections of six Western states are included in an "advisory" warning issued at noon today regarding air pollution.

A drive for funds to rebuild the Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy gathered momentum yesterday as Fire Department inspectors searched in the stone shell for evidence of the cause of Wednesday's fire.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- George Meany, A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, looked back on the labor federation's first decade with satisfaction today and looked ahead to a "more promising and challenging, decade.

THE idea of using pleasure boats to help solve state budget problems appears to be going out of style. In some quarters, of course, the nation's growing fleet of recreational craft is still regarded as a prime untapped source of tax revenue.

The Lane Bryant annual awards for volunteer service to the community were presented yesterday to Mrs. Mary Pulvino Cariola, who founded the Day Care Training Center for Handicapped Children in Rochester, and to Parents and Friends of Mentally Retarded Children of Bridgeport, Inc.

There is a full moon this week, the December moon, which will light the sky almost as long as the sun did on the longest day last June. Thus do we begin to square the year's accounts. PROFESSIONAL boxing, which lost its punch as a television attraction, will attempt a comeback through color. The first title bout on tinted TV is scheduled this week when Emile Griffith, welterweight champion, is challenged by Manuel Gonzalez in Madison Square Garden.

Actually, preliminary studies indicate 100 per cent accuracy only at the extreme ends of the scale in spotting the best and the worst parole risks.

AT the age of 64 Walt Disney is a man who is revered and honored almost to the point of absurdity. His outer and inner offices in Hollywood symbolically have become a veritable thicket of honorary statues, plaques, scrolls and similar memorabilia.
