NEWARK, Dec. 5 -- Six fires flared within a two-hour period in the Central Ward early this morning and an investigation was begun into possible arson.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 5 -- The two United States soldier Who were released last week by the Vietcong arrived in Bangkok tonight an dwere whisked into an Army ambulance. A few minutes later they were placed aboard a United States Air Force plane and flown to the American air base at Nakon Ratchasima, in eastern Thailand, for medical examinations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The San Francisco 49ers scored two touchdowns in the fourth quarter today and defeated the Detroit Lions, 17-14, in a National Football League game.
Eileen Farrell gave her first solo recital here in five seasons Saturday night at the Hunter College Assembly Hall, and she was in top form.

Your Nov. 24 editorial "More Power for New York" conveys an erroneous impression. You state that smoke and soot are "inevitable with coal and to some extent with oil," and that the abatement of "smoke-soot nuisance" from coal-burning plants is "imperfect at best."
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 5 -- The rank and file of Dominican workers shunned today a protest called by leftist unions against Provisional President Hector Garcia-Godoy's regime.
Following are the texts of the Federal Reserve Board's announcement yesterday of its anti-inflationary measures and President Johnson's statement on its action in raising the discount rate:
ERMERA, Portuguese Timor -- In the spacious lounge of his big white house, Antonio Alves Carvalheira rolled a cigarette with stringy local tobacco as he pressed another cup of coffee on his visitors.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 5 -- India has protested to the United States Educational Foundation here about what she termed "anti-Indian" activities by a young American woman teaching and studying in India under a Fulbright grant.

The man designated to be the city's new Park Commissioner indicated yesterday that he favored the creation of a special Parks Department force to combat littering, vandalism and defacement of park property.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 5 -- Argentina and Chile signed an agreement at sunrise today that is intended to head off a possible military confrontation over a disputed border area.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 5 -- Swift progress in the checkout of the Gemini 6 spacecraft today raised the possibility that it might meet Gemini 7 in space one day early.

MME. RECAMIER adrift in a sea of chiffon, a medieval knight whose coat of mail is really a jacket of sequins or a rider of the Western plains whose hip-slung pants are shining silver -- these are some of the disguises a woman of fashion can assume after dark.
OMAHA, Feb., Dec. 5 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks, with 40 points in the fourth quarter, posted a 113-99 victory over the San Francisco Warriors in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 5 -- Francisco Negrao de Lima was installed as governor of the State of Guanabara today with elaborate military security measures against possible disturbances by anti-Communist radicals.

TOKYO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A Vietcong communique broadcast by the Hanoi radio said today that more then 200 United States jet pilots had been killed or wounded in the predawn raid on the Metropole Hotel in Saigon yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Francois Mitterrand was supposed to drop in on a farewell party tonight to mark the disbanding of his campaign staff. He arrived at jubilant victory rally instead, and the farewell turned into the kickoff of a renewed campaign.

The French electorate delivered a stunning defeat to President de Gaulle in yesterday's election. This is true even though he won the greatest number of votes and can still be re-elected President in two weeks' time when or if he faces a runoff election against Francois Mitterrand, who came out second.

The New York Giants put together many of the elements required to win games in the National Football League yesterday as they trounced the Pittsburgh Steelers, 35-10, before 62,735 fans at Yankee Stadium.

Thomas Dunn led his Festival Chorus and Orchestra in all six of the Motets of J.S. Bach at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon. Note the "and Orchestra." Mr. Dunn wisely abjured the tradition that regards all but one of the motets as a cappella works, adding the instrumental support that was certainly practiced in Bach's day and just as certainly enhances the appeal of the music.

The fervent hope of the architects and builders of the Federal Medicare program is that it will accomplish two major objectives: to help provide adequate medical care for the aged and, indirectly, to improve the quality of medical care for persons of all ages.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Johnson Administration asked American business today to cut back the flow of dollars for investment in foreign countries by $1 billion next year.

JUDITH RASKIN is astonishing. It was only last year that she sang her first New York recital, but yesterday afternoon, at Town Hall, she sang a program of lieder as though she had been specialized in the songs of Beethoven, Schubert, Mendelssohn, Wolf and Mahler all her life.

Michael J. Quill yesterday rejected Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz as the suggested chairman of a panel to mediate the deadlocked New York transit negotiations. He also restated his defiance of a possible court order against a strike.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Two blocked field goals and the passing of Don Meredith carried the Dallas Cowboys to a 21-19 National Football League victory over the Philadelphia Eagles today at Franklin Field.
HOUSTON, Dec. 5 -- Like two distance runners settling in for a long haul the astronauts aboard Gemini 7 set a measured pace of experimentation, exercise, eating and sleeping today.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York announced over the weekend the election as senior vice presidents of Sidney Lanier and Frank P. Smeal.

Viewers who failed "The National Drivers Test" or "The National Citizenship Test" will have another chance when the Columbia 'Broadcasting System televises "the National Health Test" on Jan. 18 from 10 to 11 P.M.
Directors of the 12 Federal Reserve Banks establish the discount rate, or lending rate to member banks, subject to the "review and determination" of the Federal Reserve Board.

Your Nov. 20 editorial "Mr. Quill: Please Note" compares the New York City transit workers and their leadership unfavorably with the Utility Workers Union, which has recently concluded a contract with Consolidated Edison amicably and without discord.

Those armchair explorers who used to glide nervously through the stories about Martin and Osa Johnson will have all unexpected reprise on Jan. 19 when Morrow publishes "Last Adventure: The Martin Johnsons in Borneo."

Western Europe has had a ten-to-twenty years' start on almost every urban problem that is currently being wrestled with in the United States, and has produced an enlightening array of applicable successes and fiascos.

The National Industrial Conference Board asserted yesterday that the American economy was embarking on a dramatic course of growth that could be expected to carry output, jobs, profits and income to unprecedented levels by 1975.
Akeo Watanabe, who appeared here last season with his own orchestra, the Japan Philharmonic, led Leopold Stokowski's American Symphony Orchestra in a concert yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.
In the world of contemporary popular music, so often trite and shallow, it is a joy to know that real talent exists.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe scored two goals in 18 seconds tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to third place in the National Hockey League with a 5-1 victory over Toronto. The victory was the fourth in a row for the Red Wings.
The Chicago Black Hawks toyed with the law of averages and the New York Rangers last night as they powered their way to a 6-2 victory.
The cost of business borrowing at the nation's commercial banks is about to take a healthy jump.
The New York State Council on Drug Addiction assailed the city administration yesterday for its failure so far to accept a $450,000 State grant for the housing and after-care of narcotics addicts.

Following is a weekly listing of unaudited net asset value of closed-end investment fund shares, as reported by the companies through the Association of Closed-End Investment Companies at the close of business Friday. Also shown is the closing market price of each funds shares, with the percentage of difference (discount or premium).
Floyd Little of Syracuse and Ron Landeck of Princeton head the all-East university division football team announced yesterday by the Eastern College Athletic Conference.
TORONTO, Dec. 5 -- The Bank of Canada matched the increase in the United States discount rate tonight by raising the Canadian bank rate by one-half of 1 per cent to 4.75 per cent.
THERE are enough holes in "The Playroom" to equip a large Swiss cheese.
Dr. Howard A. Rusk, a specialist in physical medicine and rehabilitation, has won the 1965 Gallatin Medal of New York University.

ROSWELL, N.M. -- When it is a question of public dining, Americans live largely by formula whether in New York or points west. The menus of Manhattan's usual French bistros are notably the same with their pate maison, shrimp cocktails, onion soup, coq au vin and the other familiars.

It is hard enough to play Sunday after Sunday in the National Football League with two good knees. When one has a loose piece of cartilage floating about in a Knee, playing becomes painfully difficult.
" La Mort d'un Tyran," a 32-year-old cantata by Darius Milhaud, was given its first New York performance yesterday in afternoon and evening concerts in the auditorium of the New School.
CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 6 -- Victor Niederhoffer of Chicago, seeded third, won the 34th Gold Racquets singles champion-pionship today at the Rockaway Hunt Club.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund officially began its 54th annual Christmas-time appeal yesterday to relieve suffering among the city's deprived, distressed and unfortunate.

" YOU need a bare dress, a peculiar one and one that will photograph in black and white," says Clive Evans about couture collections. Mr. Evans is a lanky young man with rosy cheeks who belongs to an august British establishment but talks with the irreverence of "Beyond the Fringe."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that before the Administration made any significant increase in the military involvement of the United States in Vietnam, there should be thorough discussion in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Scientists have at last authoritatively confirmed what air passengers long have suspected -- and earlier research had indicated -- that anybody who feels abnormal after jetting across an ocean or a continent is normal.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 -- Demand for steel seems to be moving up again.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board, defying President Johnson, announced today an increase in the discount rate from 4 per cent to 4 1/2 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 -- An attack on Ronald Reagan enlivened a weekend panel discussion by seven declared and potential Republican gubernatorial candidates.

As the tragedy over Vietnam deepens, it may be useful to think back three years to the American confrontation with the Soviet Union over the missiles in Cuba. At that time it proved possible to uphold vital American interests while enabling the adversary to retreat and yet stabilize relations on the basis of long-term common interests.

Jim Lombardi, a 23-year-old star representing the Central Jersey Track Club, won the Muche Strucke Memorial 3 1/2-mile road race yesterday at Clove Lake Park, Staten Island. The event was sponsored by the James J. Tappen Post No. 125, American Legion.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 5 -- President Johnson reacted with obvious displeasure today to the Federal Reserve Board's decision to raise the discount rate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay, declared today that New York City would set the pace and example for the rest of the country in the governing of urban areas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Freedom to defy an Administration's wishes was built right into the basic structure of the Federal Reserve System when it as created 52 years ago, and Presidents over the years have been nearly helpless when the Federal Reserve chose to exercise that freedom.

Nearly 100 youths of draft age, several girls and a 72-year-old woman showed up at Columbia University yesterday afternoon for a five-hour session in how to succeed in promoting an antidraft movement.
LIBERTY, S.C., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Sheriff P.C. Bolding of Pickens County said today a New York Negro was shot to death by a policeman yesterday as he wrestled with another officer over a police rifle.

Selwart Clarke, a violist with the orchestra of the New York City Ballet, made his local solo recital debut at Town Hall last night. Mr. Clarke offered works by the baroque composers Marais and Telemann and the 20th-century Ralph Vaughan Williams, Walter Piston and William Fisher.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 5 -- An attempt to assess developments in Indonesia since the attempted coup d'etat of Oct. 1 must go beyond the statements by political, military and religious leaders.

The investigation of Saturday's airliner collision focused yesterday on establishing the altitudes the two planes were flying and determining why at least one apparently deviated from its assigned level.

President Johnson has deplored the actions of the Federal Reserve Banks of New York and Chicago, which were approved by a four to three vote of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, raising the interest rates that they charge to banks and, thus, to all borrowers.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- The general secretary of the World Council of Churches has proposed a set of "rules of spiritual traffic" under which conflicting religions and ideologies could coexist and cooperate in today's pluralistic world.

Stocks and bonds are likely to decline sharply in reaction to the rise in discount rate -- the most basic interest rate in the country. With the immediate reaction out of the way, however, the stock market, if it moves as it has in the past, will not be affected for long.
City Councilman Robert A. Low entered the race yesterday for the Congressional seat in Manhattan's 17th District that John V. Lindsay will vacate Jan. 1 when he takes office as Mayor.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Roman Gabriel threw two touchdown passes in his second start of the season today to lead the Los Angeles Rams to their second straight victory, a 27-3 rout of the St. Louis Cardinals in a National Football League game.
Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, will give a luncheon Wednesday in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton as part of a campaign to enlist life members.
No matter what else happens in the few remaining weeks of 1965, it already has been established that this year will crack almost all existing volume records on the New York Stock Exchange.
TORONTO, Dec. 5 -- Canada appears headed for its worst international payments deficit in five years, and economists here expect an equally severe deficit in 1966.

SOLE candidate of the left, sought to satisfy both pro-Western Socialists and Moscow-line Communists . . . Intense and ironic . . . Taunted Gaullists, urging return to "democratic traditions" . . . Captured by German Army in 1940, escaped, served in Resistance . . .

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Homebuilders were called upon today to address themselves to the "hard-core" problem of how to provide housing of suitable quality and diversity for the millions of low-income American families.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 5 -- The Vietcong have strengthened their ties with the Soviet bloc.
NEWARK, Dec. 5 -- Members of the Newark Teachers Union, who went on strike last Thursday, voted tonight to accept a fact-finding panel's recommendations and return to work tomorrow.
ROME, Dec. 5 -- The mutual anathema of 1054, in which the leaders of what are now the Eastern Orthodox and Roman Catholic Churches excommunicated each other, will be nullified Tuesday.

As a nurse employed by Bellevue Hospital I read with interest your Nov. 24 news article "Hospitals to Add 95 Security Aides," reporting that this will cost $500,000 in salaries. These new "agents" would serve to help reduce a total of more than $100,000 in thefts of hospital supplies and patients' personal articles.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Dec. 5 -- The usual issues of this quiet, rustic village on Long Island Sound -- whether to raze a revered red barn or tolerate garden apartments -- were swept aside today by the disclosure of alleged narcotics traffic among 15 to 20 local teen-agers.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, concerned over what he called the "hamstringing" of law enforcement, said last night he might enter the debate before the United States Supreme Court on the right of suspects to have a lawyer during police questioning.

Big, big tone was what was most impressive in Roberto Eyzaguirre's piano recital in Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night -- that and the passionate abandon with which the Peruvian dug into Schumann's Sonata in F sharp minor (Op. 11).

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 6 -- A Vietcong guerrilla force, built up to apparent regimental strength by North Vietnamese regulars, inflicted moderate casualties on a battalion of United States infantrymen yesterday in hand-to-hand fighting near the abandoned Michelin rubber plantation, north of Saigon.

CHRISTMAS without cartoons books? Unthinkable! Christmas without a New Yorker album? Never! Well, hardly ever. That's the way it seems, anyway, and memory serves not entirely incorrectly: there was a time when "The New Yorker Album" was an annual affair. Yet what a surprise to learn that the new collection is the first in a decade.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Dec. 5 -- The military situation in South Vietnam's Central Highlands is still considered critical despite recent successes of the United States' First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) near the Cambodian border.

Officials of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York prepared last night for whatever reaction might occur in the foreign exchange market as a result of the increase in the bank discount rate announced yesterday.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 5 -- For Comdr. James Arthur Lovell Jr., first-hand experience with rockets goes back 21 years to a field near his home in Milwaukee.
PARIS, Monday, Dec. 6 -- General de Gaulle, in a stunning setback, failed to win a majority of the votes in the French presidential election yesterday.
A man and his wife and their unborn daughter were killed and six persons injured in a three-car collision in the Bronx last night.

An Eastern Air Lines pilot apparently sacrificed his life to check on the safety of his passengers after making an amazing landing following a mid-air collision Saturday afternoon with a Trans World Airlines jet.
David Sarnoff, millionaire board chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, last night helped honor Meyer Machtenberg, his former singing mentor and longtime friend, and made a nickel on the deal.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 5 -- Industrialists in Rhodesia were drawing up an over-all plan today to put themselves and the country on a war footing.
The Transit Authority has commissioned the industrial design company headed by Raymond Loewy to plan a new subway car, "dramatically different in exterior and interior."
HONG KONG, Dec. 5 -- Communist China agreed today to provide North Vietnam with loans. The amounts were not made public.
BOSTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored three goals in a two-minute span of the third period tonight to gain a 4-4 National Hockey League tie with last-place Boston.

I find William V. Shannon's column of Nov. 22 "Johnson: After Two Years" puzzling, to put it mildly. To say that "the ordeal of Vietnam has cast a pall over the two years" is the understatement of the year. Furthermore, President Johnson did not "inherit" a war, unless one concedes that he inherited it from Barry Goldwater.

RUGS and carpets represent a large and sometimes life-long investment for many householders and should be bought and handled with care. Two new booklets and a new movie about rugs and carpeting may therefore be of interest to consumers.
The Justice Department was charged yesterday with not making full use of its powers to thwart "continuing violence" in the South.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dee. 5 -- Hap Sharp of Midland, Tex., drove his Chevrolet Chaparral to a commanding victory today in the 12th annual Nassau Trophy Race. Sharp covered the 252 miles on the 4.5-mile Oakes Field course at an average speed of 103.272 miles an hour, a record.

Fernando Valenti's harpsichord recital at Philharmonic Hall last night was in the nature of a birthday party, with the harpsichordist, just turned 39, scheduled to play 24 Scarlatti sonatas. Before he could get started, he was genuinely surprised -- to judge from the way he removed his dark glasses, stared out into the auditorium and then buried his head on the keyboard -- to hear members of the audience sing "Happy Birthday."

GENEVA, Dec. 5 -- The countries of the European Free Trade Association increased their over-all exports by 8.7 per cent during the first nine months of this year to a total of $20.3 billion, the trade bloc announced today.
As a citizen of New York as well as an architect, I wish to express my gratitude and support for your important editorial published Nov. 22 "Planless City."
LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 5 -- Portugal has quietly approved an emergency plan for shipping the bulk of Zambia's copper through Angola if Rhodesia cut Zambia's rail link to the Indian Ocean.
LAIKHE, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Some night clashes were reported in the area of tile First Division battalion's fight yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- African foreign ministers instructed a five-nation committee today to plan sabotage and military action against Rhodesia if Britain failed to topple quickly that country's white-minority regime.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy pictured John V. Lindsay yesterday as a potentially great Mayor and called on New York Democrats to "cooperate a hundred per cent" with him.
The Advertising Council has reported a new "peacetime" high in the value of advertising contributed by American business for the public good.

VIRTUALLY a full evening on the subject of Red China was offered last night by WNDT, the educational television station. Except for interviews with Prof. John King Fairbank of Harvard University and John Paton Davies Jr., the former diplomat, the ambitious undertaking was a marathon of pedantry.

Long before Sunday's surprise action by the Federal Reserve Board it was an open secret that Chairman William McChesney Martin Jr. and President Johnson disagreed about the threat of inflation. They had managed to reconcile their differences, however, achieving a remarkable meshing of fiscal and monetary policies that made a major contribution to the duration and balance of the expansion.
DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- A Federal judge with a police background said today that law enforcement could meet constitutional requirements without coddling the criminal.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 6 -- The Government said this evening that it was preparing to embark on a public works program to prevent the spread of unemployment as a result of British economic sanctions.

HOUSTON, Dec. 6 -- As Gemini 7 soared smoothly through its third day of flight, it looked more and more as if its attempted rendezvous with Gemini 6 may come this Sunday -- a day earlier then expected.

Bennett Cerf, book publisher, author, TV panelist, columnist and lecturer, will cease to be president of Random House on Jan. 1. He will not move out of his office. He will become board chairman of the corporation. Robert L. Bernstein will succeed him as president.

Your Nov. 5 editorial "Medical Revolution Ahead," which discussed the recent White House Conference on Health, was entirely correct when it stated: "The crux of the problem now is availability of doctors, nurses, health technicians, hospitals, laboratory facilities and the other ingredients of first class preventive and therapeutic medicine."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Federal Reserve Board's action increasing the cost of borrowing from member banks exploded today in demands for a thorough Congressional investigation and for curbing the agency's statutory independence on the Executive branch.
Prices of pork-belly futures soared yesterday in the wake of the highest hog prices in 17 years.
Red Sullivan was eased out as coach of the New York Rangers yesterday and the team's general manager, Emile Francis, replaced him.
The accompanying chart shows departmental and agency requests for capital funds and the amount allocated to them under the City Planning Commission's Draft Capital Budget for 1966-67.

Most European markets were upset yesterday by a combination of the increases in United States and Canadian discount rates, plus the French elections and the continuing uncertain situation in Rhodesia.
ROME, Dec. 6 -- Pope Paul VI announced plans today for an extraordinary jubilee period throughout the Roman Catholic Church from Jan. 1 to May 29, 1966, the Feast of Pentecost.
The blackout that darkened the Northeast Nov. 9 might never have reached New York had Consolidated Edison engineers acted more quickly, the Federal Power Commission said yesterday.
Thank you for your fine [Nov. 30] editorial "Births and Population." Nowhere have I seen the case for birth control presented so compactly and convincingly.
A NEW travel agency devoted to getting sportsmen to the sport has been announced by Abercrombie and Fitch, the sporting-goods supermarket at Madison Avenue and 45th Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- State Department officials were divided today in assessing the potential impact upon American foreign policy of General de Gaulle's political setback.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- France continued to be by far the largest taker of United States official gold in the third quarter of this year, the Treasury reported today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Sargent Shriver defended "the establishment" today as a participant in the Federal antipoverty program that he heads.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- The Roman Catholic world hierarchy gave overwhelming approval to definitions of church attitudes on modern world problems today at the 168th and final working session of the Ecumenical Council.

Taking the lead at the head of the stretch, Mrs. Edith W. Bancroft's Hedevar contributed an upset performance in the main race at Aqueduct yesterday. With Bill Mahorney riding, Hedevar registered by six lengths over Allen Case's Victorian Era, with James Moore's Peter Pumpkin third.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex, Dec. 6 -- Joseph C. Swindler, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, indicated today that the commission would make legislative recommendations to help prevenet power blackouts similar to the one that darkened the Northeast Nov. 9.

ROME, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Vatican announced tonight that Pope Paul VI had allowed publication of all documents in the Vatican archives concerning World War II in response to requests from many nations.

THE weekend's casualty list from pro football was long and full of notables: John Unitas, Bart Starr, Don Perkins, Don Meredith, Joe Morrison. Each of them is a prime offensive figure on a team driving for a conference championship or the Playoff Bowl game. Besides that, the long season is coming to an end and just about everybody who plays this game regularly has aches and ailments.

History, or at least a tiny footnote to history, was made in Brooklyn Heights last night. At the home of Oliver Smith, co-director of American Ballet Theatre with Lucia Chase, the first presentation of money was made by the National Council on the Arts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Federal Power Commission said today that the power failure in the Northeast on Nov. 9 would not have occurred if all the electric power systems involved had been following more careful operating practices.

The warden of Hudson County Jail in New Jersey, indicted for perjury in connection with charges that he furnished his inmates with special privileges and prostitutes, yesterday asked for and received a leave of absence.

BONN, Dec. 6 -- Although a spokesman for Chancellor Ludwig Erhard declined to comment, a number of Government supporters in the Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament, expressed satisfaction today at President de Gaulle's failure to win a majority in the French elections.
Albany, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The state banking superintendent said today that granting savings banks the right to make general-purpose personal loans would benefit the public as well as the banks.

" IT is impossible not to come to America," Didier Grumbach said. The 28-year-old heir to C. Mendes, the Paris ready-to-wear concern founded in 1903 by his grandfather, was at the Plaza Hotel here last week.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation has changed its Squibb division to a wholly owned subsidiary, E.R. Squibb Sons, Inc., and elected Richard M. Furlaud president and chief executive officer of the newly incorporated unit.
Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced here yesterday that John E. Beebe has been proposed for admission as a general partner.
The appointment of James W. Bergford as a senior vice president was announced here yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 -- This Inland seaport, until a few years ago completely closed during the winter because of ice, will have some unusual activity in the coming months because of four adventurous Russian freighters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The State of New York today challenged again the accounting methods the financially-distressed New Haven Railroad uses in its commuter operation, asserting that the service made a profit of $1.3 million in 1964.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a contention by the publisher of Life Magazine that a damage verdict under New York's right-of-privacy law had violated its press freedom.
Moscow, Dec 6 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union leveled a new blast against Communist China today, accusing Peking of "helping aggressors" by sowing disunity in the world Communist movement.
BEAUMONT, Tex., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Part of southeast Texas was blacked out today for 25 minutes.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin received James Reston, associate edi-of The New York Times, for an hour-and-three-quarter interview today on Soviet foreign and domestic policy.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The first French satellite to be launched from the United states was pushed into orbit today by an American rocket.
John V. Lindsay will spend his first day as Mayor touching base at tradition-breaking public receptions in all five boroughs on New Year's Day. He invited everyone in the city to attend.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal judge cannot punish a person for criminal contempt without a hearing, except when misbehavior threatened the judge or disrupted court proceedings.
Supreme Court Justice Nicholas Pette yesterday vacated a $740,000 award he made two weeks ago to the widow of a Queens toolmaker who was frightened to death by an automobile.

The Bavarian State Theater will make its first New York appearance between April 5 and April 17 at the City Center. A company of 80 will make the trip from Munich. Expenses will be shared by the West German Government and the Deutsches Theater of New York, a membership organization that supports imported German theater.

NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The University of Oklahoma football coach, Gomer Jones, resigned today, saying he was "tired of criticism" and was leaving "for the good of the university and its football program."

Loew's Theaters, Inc., yesterday paid $1.35 million for the world premiere engagement of the Italian-made production of "The Bible" at Loew's State here, beginning next fall. Last summer it was reported that the film would open here in September, 1966.
BETHEL, Conn., Dec. 6 -- A school bus carrying 62 pupils sideswiped a tree and overturned here about 8 A.M. today, injuring 37 pupils and the woman driver. No one was seriously hurt.

Net sales of Geo. A. Hormel Co. rose to a record of $441,600,314 in the fiscal year ended Oct. 30 from $411,827,498 in the preceding year. Earnings, however, declined, according to the company's annual report issued yesterday.

THE number of major colleges looking for a new head football coach was cut by one yesterday when Pittsburgh named Dave Hart to replace John Michelosen. More coaches have been dropped or have resigned in recent days than have left in recent seasons. And there will probably be a few more openings before the end of the year.
AT the start of Janet Flanner's superb journal, France is being liberated horizontally by the Allies. At the end of it, France is expanding vertically into the missile-haunted skies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- George Meany criticized today the Federal Reserve Board's action in raising the discount rate and said President Johnson should use whatever power he had to reverse the decision.
THANKSGIVING is over and Christmas not here yet, but fresh cranberries can be used to spark menus today or any day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- American maritime policy was both defended and attacked here today before the biennial meeting of the Maritime Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- In this land of cactus candy, the chili pod and the pinto bean, almost any conversation sooner or later veers to Mexican restaurants, and there is rarely a resident without a preference for one or another.

Stocks took a severe battering yesterday morning on news of the increase in the discount rate by the Federal Reserve Board, but then rebounded sharply in later trading. Volume was the fourth heaviest for any session in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

Mrs. Karen Hantze Susman was suspended yesterday from tournament tennis until next April 1 because of her withdrawal from a first-round match in the national championship at Forest Hills last September.
The men who put tigers in Humble gasoline tanks have come up with a humorous look back to the night the power failed.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 7 -- The Soviet Union failed to land an instrument packet gently on the surface of the moon early today. It was the fourth failure this year.

A Paramount Pictures Corporation executive testified yesterday that a lawyer for Frank Sinatra and representatives of three major talent agencies told him that they were "reluctant to bring ideas" to the film producer as long as Herbert J. Siegel and Ernest H. Martin were sitting on the board.

An Eastern Air Lines pilot asserts that near-collisions between flying aircraft have increased because of smoke pollution "to a point where you have had a dull trip if you don't experience at least one on every trip sequence as a scheduled airline pilot."

It may not have been worth doing, but at least it was done well. This was the view taken of Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila" when it was revived in a splendid new production by the Metropolitan Opera a season ago. Last night it was back on the boards of the old house, for the first time this season. The question again was: Why? The answer: Because the company does it well.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Further dollar defense measures by the United States and a political setback for French President de Gaulle produced temporary confusion and no end of speculation in Britain today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Supreme Court took the lollowillg actions today:

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Billy Cunningham had a good shooting night as the Philadelphia 76ers trimmed the Los Angeles Lakers, 116-107, tonight in the first National Basketball Association game here in six years.

In view of the reputation of The New York Times for objective and sophisticated reporting, I was surprised at the absence of both in the news article in your Nov. 5 issue headed "Sotheby's to Sell Newberry Books." At the end of the first paragraph your reporter makes the statement in regard to the sale, "nobody seems to know why."
The city proposed a list of 66 housing violations yesterday for which tenants would be justified in withholding rent until necessary repairs were made.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Defense attorneys demanded a mistrial today because the presiding judge would not allow the introduction of a resolution of Congress in the Krebiozen trial.

Day will publish in January "The Longest Auto Race: New York to Paris, 1908," by Tom Mahoney and George Schuster. The latter is the last surviving crew member of the winning automobile, a Thomas Flyer, made in Rochester, N.Y.
The Federal Reserve Act, establishing the Federal Reserve System, was signed Dec. 23, 1913, by President Woodrow Wilson.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Supreme Court ruled out today the use of "grade-a-year" school desegregation plans to deny Negro children in any grade the right to attend integrated schools.
The J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation and the Schroder Trust Company announced here yesterday the election of B. Alden Cushman and W. Donald Brown as senior vice presidents.

The number of genuinely perceptive dance critics to have existed over the years can almost be counted on the thumbs of one hand. Among them is an American, Edwin Denby, who brings his own distinction to a usually all too pedestrian craft. His new collection of dance pieces, "Dancers, Buildings and People in the Streets," maintains the high standard of the earlier anthology of his criticism, "Looking at the Dance."

C.L. Sulzberger's Nov. 24 column upholds the Nuremberg war crime trial as a generally accepted legal precedent condemning all crimes against humanity. He admits a fundamental flaw at the time that its legal basis was unfortunately formulated ex post facto.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles acquired Jack Baldschun, a relief pitcher, from the Philadelphia Phillies today for Jackie Brandt, an outfielder, and Darold Knowles, a left-handed pitcher.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The impact of the Defense Departments base-closing decision appeared tonight to be relatively light in the New York metropolitan area.

JACKSON, Ala., Dec. 6 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. toured Alabama's "Black Belt" today, urging Negroes to continue protesting "segregated justice" despite recent convictions in two civil rights murders.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild, which is celebrating its 30th anniversary, held its annual membership luncheon yesterday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The master of ceremonies was Anthony A. Bliss, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association.
Steel production climbed 2.7 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 6 -- President Kenneth D. Kaunda and his 12-man Cabinet began weighing today the consequences of following the recommendations of the Organization of African Unity for crushing Rhodesia's rebel regime.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex. Dec. 6 -- President Johnson and William McChesney Martin met today in what was apparently an amiable confrontation.

The 16th annual Animal Kingdom Ball at the Sheraton-East on Jan. 20 will be the first event to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Hugh E. Paine is centennial committee chairman, and Mrs. Alfred Steele (Joan Crawford) is ball cairman. James H. Jenkins is president of the society.
HONG KONG -- Louis Vaudable, a precisely tailored Parisian, arrived in Hong Kong last week with several bunches of shallots in his baggage.

Despite some recent criticism of the Administration's voluntary program to cut foreign investments, reaction yesterday to the Government's request for a $1 billion reduction next year indicated that only a few executives were willing to speak out publicly as yet.

LONDON, Dec 6 -- There was no official reaction today to the results of the French election but the unofficial British mood was perhaps best summed up in a newspaper cartoon by Vicky that showed a towering General de Gaulle, his head in the clouds, bending over to stare at a diminutive General de Gaulle.
THERE is one family in New York whose house was redecorated by a famous designer twice this year.
More than 100 Roman Catholic priests and laymen have published an advertisement in three Catholic periodicals this week deploring United States participation in the Vietnamese war.
ALBANY -- Dec. 6 -- Republicans in the State Senate today chose Senators Earl W. Brydges of Niagara Falls as their leader when they assume control of the upper house in January.

The electrical power failure in the Northeast on Nov. 9 was largely due to mistakes in human judgment. Although this finding by the Federal Power Commission will reassure those who fear that human beings have no important part to play in the modern world of automated systems, it does not speak well for the contingency planning of the Government and the power companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Federal Maritime Commission announced today a new policy under which it will require steamship lines or steamship conferences to prove that disparate rates on outbound and inbound shipments traveling on the same route are reasonable.

Immortal gods and citizenry, bear witness to the ways of gentle folk and scholars, who in these troubled times pause to extol the memory of Marcus Tullius Cicero, slain near Rome in the 63d year of his life in 43 B.C.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the second conviction of John J. Gojack for contempt of Congress. Mr. Gojack was convicted for refusing in 1955 to answer some questions asked by the House Committee on Un-American activities.
Bond prices declined sharply yesterday as the market adjusted to a new interest rate structure keyed to the increased Federal Reserve discount rate.

The International Finance Corporation, encouraged by the relative stability of the present Brazilian Government and by the character of the recipient company, has made its first committment for funds to a Brazilian concern in six years.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Dave Hart, a defensive backfield coach at Navy the last two years, was named head football coach at the University of Pittsburgh today.

DANCE played a prominent part in the Hanukkah Festival for Israel, sponsored by State of Israel Bonds at the Madison Square Garden last night. Three new dances were presented by the Sophie Maslow Dance Company for the audience of 18,000.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay is running a pocketsized City Hall in a 21-room suite of offices on the eighth floor of the Roosevelt Hotel.
THE recent marriage of Sam Fry Jr., secretary of New York's Regency Whist Club, to Camilla Grace, a member of the same club, serves to recall a lifetime of bridge expertise.
THE revival of John Webster's 350-year-old play "The White Devil," which opened last night at the Circle in the Square, is vivid and robust.

Mayor Wagner yesterday called on the Transit Authority and two transit unions to meet with him tomorrow morning at City Hall in an attempt to head off a strike threatened for Dec. 15. Both sides agreed to attend.
DETROIT, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A whirlwind finish to the year's auto production appeared likely today as auto makers set as their goal the biggest output of any December to date.
MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 6 -- Vice President Humphrey said today that the transistor radio had become an instrument of political diplomacy whose significance was understood by the enemies of freedom.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 6 -- Henry A. Wallace, a Vice President under Franklin D. Roosevelt, left a will that is largely a philosophical essay on the great values in life.
HYDE, England, Dec. 6 -- The press and the public were excluded today as a court began to hear a murder case that has filled Britain with grim rumors -- the Pennine Moor murders.

The structure of network television is in for a major remodeling job, and there is at least an outside chance that the viewer at home may benefit. The big switch under way is for networks to take cover under the protective shields of companies larger than themselves, and one effect may be to lessen broadcasting's exposure to the fluctuations of the stock market and the Nielsen popularity ratings.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The top executives of the uneasy, but profitable United States drug industry gathered here in some splendor today for a two-day consideration of internal, external and above all governmental problems and programs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara announced today that 149 additional military bases, largely in the United States, would be closed, consolidated or reduced in size.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Britain charged today that the Soviet Union was more interested in cold-war polemics than in moving the conflict in Vietnam from the battlefield to the conference table.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Treasury-bill rate rose sharply today as expected following the Federal Reserve discount-rate increase, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
WARSAW, Dec. 6 -- There is a long, green and gold embroidered dress named Odalisque in the Christian Dior haute couture collection that made nearly 18,000 Poles laugh last week.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 6 -- Eleven persons, including four clergymen, were arrested today in a civil rights demonstration at a school construction site.

A spokesman for the Board of Education said yesterday that Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan was studying the situation that led to the showing of a Vietcong film at Bayside High School in Queens on Friday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- Following is the text of the summary of the McCone Commission's report, titled "The Need for Leadership," on the Los Angeles riots this year:
TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- Japanese Government and economic circles expressed concern today the rise in the United States discount rate would slow down the recovery from the current business recession here.

Despite a stockholder's plea of "Encourage us a little," management of E.J. Korvette, Inc., reported yesterday that the giant discount chain's problems in its food and furniture operations might prevent it from matching last year's record earnings in the fiscal year ending next July 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Every year there are more and more people to whom Dec. 7 means practically nothing. Ask a 17-year-old what was the day that will live in infamy, and if he is one of those deadpans with the cool eyelids and a sharp needle he is as likely as not to say, "The day the Americans atom-bombed Hiroshima."
ROME, Dec. 6 -- Pope Paul VI ended today the right of the four-century-old Holy Office to take secret, arbitrary disciplinary action against those accused of sin or heresy.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- President de Gaulle remained closeted in his country home today, the only candidate who had no public comment to offer on the French presidential election yesterday.
Livingston L. Wingate, whose administration of the multimillion-dollar Haryou-Act program has been the subject of bitter controversy, last night was temporarily relieved of his major duties there.
The City Planning Commission, restricted by tight debt limitations, proposed yesterday a $578.2 million capital budget for 1966-67 to bridge a "unique transitional point in city history."
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday named a Washington tax lawyer as his special consultant on tax policy.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- A man whose favorite pastime is tending his garden emerged tonight as the surprisingly powerful challenger of the man who said recently that he did not become President of France to preside at the opening of flower shows.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board told savings and loan associations today that they should "await a full assessment" of yesterday's actions by the Federal Reserve Board affecting interest rates.

HANOI, North Vietnam -- When the sirens go off, one who lived through 1941 in London remembers, but is confused by the differences. The shelters here are made of earth, and they seem built for children.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- A blue-ribbon commission that was appointed to investigate last summer's riot in Watts handed down today a set of what it described as "costly and extreme" recommendations aimed at treating the causes of the violent outbreaks.
BONN, Dec. 6 -- A spokesman for victims of Nazi persecution charged today that a proposed reduction in West Germany's compensation payments would "shake all confidence" in Bonn's actions.

THE operation was a success and Johnny Unitas is recovering nicely from Sunday's surgery on a torn knee ligament. It's comforting to know that the primary patient is doing so well, but all Baltimore is horrified at the precarious condition of the secondary patient, the beloved Baltimore Colts.

Soviet diplomacy has engineered a coup in winning agreement from the leaders of India and Pakistan to discuss their differences at Tashkent next month. This meeting under Soviet auspices will be one of three important summit conferences scheduled during the next few weeks to examine the critical problems of the Indian subcontinent.

LAIKHE PLANTATION, South Vietnamn, Dec. 6 -- "The Vietcong were dug in," said the young soldier. "The Vietcong had .50-caliber machine guns and they were waiting for us. All we had was some thick-headed Americans with a desire to live."
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The British Government has in the last few days let out word of a "peace plan" for Rhodesia that Prime Minister Wilson is to present at an opportune time.

SELMA, Ala., Dec. 6 (AP) -- The state, preparing for tomorrow's opening of the trial of three white men accused of killing a Unitarian minister engaged in civil rights activities, has won the right to challenge jurors who feel civil rights workers are inferior.

The net loss of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey is expected to be about $6.3 million this year, compared with a loss of $8.29 million in 1964, P.M. Shoemaker, president, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Jersey City.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6 -- Fighting erupted in many sections of South Vietnam yesterday and early today, ending a five-day lull in ground combat.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a company injured by a competitor's use of a patent obtained by fraud may sue for triple damages under antitrust laws.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 6 -- A biology teacher at Central High School filed a lawsuit here today asking that the state's 37-year-old anti-evolution law be declared unconstitutional.

TRENTON, Dec. 6 -- The Democratic majorities in the Legislature that will convene next month elected their leaders in the Senate and Assembly today. It was a balanced ticket and one that is certain to work closely with Governor Richard J. Hughes, the Democrat who made their leadership possible.
Stock prices plunged sharply and then staged an impressive rally yesterday following the Federal Reserve Board's increase in the discount rate Sunday.

HOUSTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A contract to sell the stock of The Houston Chronicle and other major properties to a Houston oilman for $85 million was announced today by the president of Houston Endowment, Inc.
BONN, Dec. 6 -- European reactions to Washington's weekend financial announcements ranged from satisfaction to confusion.

Michael Oelbaum, a pianist who made his New York debut in the Metropolitan Museum's Young Artist Series early in 1964, gave a recital last night in the Young Concert Artists Series at Carnegie Recital Hall. His program listed Schoenberg's Three Piano Pieces, Op. 11, Chopin's Ballade No. 4 in F minor, Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 101, and Bach's 15 Three-Part Inventions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Asserting that he "doesn't want to scare the American people," Gus Hall, chief spokesman for the Communist party in America, said today that the party was experiencing the greatest upsurge in its history.

Senators Jacob K. Javits and Robert F. Kennedy spoke yesterday at a hearing in the basement of a Harlem church to underscore the gravity of New York City's narcotics problem.

More than two-thirds of the $14,796.56 recorded yesterday as donations to The New York Times Neediest Fund came from a trust fund and an anonymous contributor. A total of 115 other donors sent the balance.

THE men's wear industry is losing one of its brightest young lights to feminine fashion.
Bargain hunters besieged Singer Sewing Centers in the metropolitan area yesterday in search of a "$2.76" sewing machine advertised in The New York Sunday News.

Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey last night urged the establishment of research and experimental institutions in underdeveloped nations that would enable young scientists and technologists there to develop their own countries.

A grand jury that investigated the Women's House of Detention for seven months has reported that it is not the "snake pit and hell hole" that inmates have called it.

The three television networks, last fall virtually tied in over-all program popularity, are no longer running neck-and-neck in the rating sweepstakes.
Buoyed by the rise in the discount rate, most bank stocks made good advances yesterday to overshadow a generally weaker over-the-counter market.

Another indication of the growing international thinking of ad agencies, particularly the large ones, came yesterday with the announcement by the J. Walter Thompson Company, the largest, of a major shift of its international management.

The best way to avoid knee injuries, a retired dentist said yesterday, is to hit a man before he hits you. DOVER, Del., Dec. 6 -- Gov. Charles L. Terry Jr. appeared today before a joint session of the state's Senate and House of Representatives to plead for legislation designed to "maintain clean air, clean water and an adequate water supply."

GENEVA, Dec. 6 -- Eric Wyndham White, director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, said today that "extensive use" was being made by industrialized countries of their right to limit their imports of cotton textiles.
Interest rates were increased throughout the country yesterday following the Federal Reserve Board's weekend increase in the discount rate from 4 per cent to 4 1/2 per cent.

Dave Newmark, the 7-foot Columbia sophomore, still has room to grow as a basketball player.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, First Secretary of the Communist party, appeared today to have reduced the power of the man widely regarded as his possible successor to top authority in the iSoviet Union, Alexander Shelepin.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- Under Secretary of State George W. Ball and Secretary General Thant conferred for 70 minutes today on war and peace in Vietnam and other world issues.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 7 -Oklahoma, after failing to win in the first three bouts, rallied to score a 20-8 triumph over Lehigh tonight in wrestling before a crowd, of 3,850 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The present boom in business spending for new plant and equipment is even bigger than previously estimated and will continue at least through the first half of next year, a new Government study showed today.

The building at 327 East 22d Street, between First and Second Avenues, formerly occupied by 13th Police Precinct, will be among the 213 city-owned properties offered at auction next Tuesday at the Statler Hilton Hotel.
" Jonah," the American Place Theater's next presentation, scheduled for February, is planned as a musical experiment in the dramatic field.

The American Medical Association, through its House of Delegates, has again refused to take a stand on liberalizing abortion laws. In 45 states these cruel and unrealistic statutes prohibit abortion altogether or, as in New York, permit it only when the life of the mother-to-be is endangered.

" Adlai E. Stevenson," by Stuart Gerry Brown, will be published by Barron's Educational Series of Woodbury, L.I., next month. ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Clark Graebner was forced out of the South Australian tennis championships today by an injury, but four other Americans advanced in singles.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (UPI) -George Chuvalo, the 28-year-old Canadian heavyweight champion, pounded out a 10-round decision tonight over Joe Bygraves, 34. Bygraves, who was born in Jamaica, fights out of Liverpool.

The New York Knickerbockers, who lost all 10 of their starts against the Los Angeles Lakers last season, have made a considerable improvement on that record in this National Basketball Association campaign.

American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation agreed last evening to merge into an international corporate giant with more than $1.8 billion in assets. This would push the merged company into the nation's top 20 companies in size.

THE Whitney Museum's 1965 Annual of American painting, opening to the public today, is not likely to set you on your ear, or even to set your teeth on edge. It is a respectable assemblage of paintings that does what it can, under limitations, to survey the current scene.

A jury of five architects -Walter A. Netsch Jr. of Chicago, James Gowan of London, Romaldo Giurgola of Philadelphia, Edward A. Killingsworth of Long Beach, Calif., and Harwell Hamilton Harris of Raleigh, N.C. -- have been named to review nominations for the 1966 R.S. Reynolds Memorial Award.
The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation keeps rolling up sales records.

The Emerson Electric Company, manufacturer of motors, electronic devices and controls as well as building equipment products, had the best year in its 75-year history in the fiscal period ended Sept. 30.
BUCHAREST, Dec. 7 -- The personal style of Eastern Europe's youngest Communist leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, is making itself felt more and more in Rumania.

TOKYO -- Several hundred leading Tokyo companies have asked for police protection against a special breed of blackmailers, called "sokaiya," who threaten to disrupt stockholder meetings unless paid off.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Following, in a translation by the North American Catholic Welfare Conference, endorsed by the Bishops of the United States, is the text of the Ecumenical Council's declaration on freedom of religion, which was promulgated today:

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Leaders of the Roman Catholic and Orthodox Churches -- Pope and Patriarch -- publicly deplored today and consigned to oblivion 11th-century excommunications that began 900 years of schism in Christianity.
The Citizens Committee for an Effective Constitution called yesterday for the nonpartisan selection of a third of the delegates to the State Constitutional Convention.

SANT CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Spanish DC3 charter plane carrying Scandinavian tourists on a holiday side-trip plunged into a house and burned minutes after takeoff in a windy rainstorm late today.

Geraldine Chaplin arrived here by plane from Paris yesterday and said that she loved her father's movies but is very concerned about what he will think when he sees hers. Although he encouraged her, he has never seen her perform.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -Stockholders of the Susquehanna Corporation voted decisively today for a merger with the American Gypsum Company.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Local 10 of the Chicago musicians union, once the operating base for the musicians' "czar," James Caesar Petrillo, went to the polls today to elect new officers.

The General Time Corporation is seeking a new corporate identity, away from being merely the manufacturer of Westclox time pieces. It has, therefore, forged a new symbol to help make the impression that it produces a wide variety of timing devices -- including some for space projects.
Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest general merchandising organization, announced yesterday that it attained record sales in November and in the first ten months of its fiscal year.
Robert E. Kintner will relinquish his duties as president of the National Broadcasting Company under a realignment of the concern's top executive responsibilities.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay said yesterday that he wanted to "examine the arithmetic of the Transit Authority" before deciding whether that agency should get more financial aid to save the 15-cent fare.
Four veterans of World War II started their return to active duty yesterday as the Maritime Administration pulled out the first of 25 Victory ships from the reserve fleet for a hitch in Vietnam.
Governor Rockefeller, speaking with the hoarse earnestness of a football coach before the big game, last night gave Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay a play-by-play program for vitalizing the city economy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that he saw virtually no room for a compromise with Communists in South Vietnam.

THE hesitation was instinctive. For the better part of two decades boxing entrepreneurs always hesitated before trying to deal With Sugar Ray Robinson, an even tougher man in contract haggling than he was in the ring. So Harry Markson, director of boxing at Madison Square Garden, was a victim of past habits when he paused before making the phone call to Sugar Ray.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 7 -- President Sukarno dared Indonesia's highest legislative body yesterday, to vote him out of office.

WASHINGTON (UPI) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, said today that he had been informed that some young men who participated in the recent Vietnam demonstrations in Washington were being classified 1-A by their draft boards "as a sort of punishment."
A SERKIN recital always has its surprises, Rudolf Serkin is one of the most individual and volatile of pianists, and can always be counted upon to throw new light on the music under his fingers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Despite the Federal Reserve Board's successful "defiance" of President Johnson in raising the discount rate, the board's action may yield political and economic gains for Mr. Johnson.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company is considering selling $100 million of debentures, E.H. Schulenberg, executive vice president, confirmed yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -Traffic accidents killed 4,820 persons in October, the highest toll for any month this year, the National Safety Council said today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 7 -- The Soviet Government announced today a 5 per cent increase in its military budget for next year. The increase was made necessary, the Government said, by the "growing activity of the aggressive forces of the imperialist states."
ROME, Dec. 7 -- The Roman Catholic Church established a precedent today by defining its relationship to man in the modern world and its position on most of the major problems that confront him.

Now that Federal Reserve Chairman William McChesney Martin and President Johnson have agreed on a cease fire, it looks as if the Federal Reserve has won a battle but the Administration has won the war. But in the long run, both sides are likely to suffer as a result of their conflict.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- The long fight over a route for Interstate Highway 87 through 10 miles of big estates and wildlife sanctuaries in Bedford has been reopened by intervention from Washington.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The three-week visit to the United States made last month by Princess Margaret and her husband, the Earl of Snowdon, cost the British Treasury about 30,000 ($84,000), the Chancellor of the Exchequer, James Callaghan, announced tonight.
St. John's University breezed to its second victory of the basketball season by trouncing George Washington University, 100-62, last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 -American labor's top policy board said today that the United States needed 80,000 new job opportunities each week to reduce unemployment to a minimum and to keep it there in the face of automation and an expanding labor force.

The chairman of the Board of Higher Education testified yesterday that when the chancellor of the City University proposed a tuition charge for students he also recommended a salary increase for the college presidents.

Justice Arthur G. Klein of the New York State Supreme Court dismissed yesterday misconduct charges against three concerns in the purchase of stock of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company about the time the company discovered a rich ore lode near Timmins, Ont.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 7 -James R. Hoffa expressed a tolerant view yesterday toward the two union vice presidents who are maneuvering to succeed him if he does not seek another term as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 7 -Roosevelt Raceway's policy of shutting down the $100 and $50 place and show windows when prohibitive favorites are trotting or pacing was scored by the New York State Harness Racing Commission tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 -The Government criticized the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company today for "a somewhat cavalier attitude" and accused the big Milwaukee beer concern of "fact-twisting" in a prolonged antitrust trial here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- The General Assembly's Special Political Committee voted tonight to urge the rest of the world to isolate South Africa almost completely, in another effort to compel the South African Government to abandon its policy of apartheid, or complete separation of the races.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 7 -- One hundred and fifty-seven Rutgers University students and faculty members donated blood today to show support of American troops in Vietnam.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The Magistrates Court in Hyde, hearing testimony in the Pennine Moors murder case, decided today to hear evidence in open court.

FOR the last three years, Lyman Judson Morhouse has been almost a mystery figure in his home community of Ticonderoga, N.Y., in contrast to his former public status as Republican state chairman. Mr. Morhouse, who was indicted yesterday on charges of bribery and conspiracy in the State Liquor Authority scandals, is now seldom seen at political and social functions and in the Essex County courtrooms where he once had a thriving practice.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- The smaller nations overrode United States and British objections tonight with Soviet support to demand withdrawal of all military bases from colonies and other "non-selfgoverning territories."
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Government officials declared tonight that President de Gaulle would enter the runoff election Dec. 19 against Francois Mitterrand.

GENEVA, Dec. 7 -- The United States endorsed today proposals for the extension of the present 28-nation pact regulating international trade in cotton textiles. The pact is scheduled to expire in 1967.
Three works new to New York and a duo-pianist pair who seem to have been absent since 1950 were presented in the Clarion Concert given at Town Hall last night under the direction of Newell Jenkins.
A new law designed to curb the activities of gypsy cabs was passed, 27 to 4, by the City Council last night. Three Councilmen abstained.

Harold S. Vanderbilt, skipper of successful America's Cup defenders in 1930, 1934 and 1947, joined yesterday the syndicate formed last July to finance the design and building of a new 12-Meter yacht to meet Australia's challenge in 1957.
PLEIME, South Vietnam, Dec. 4 -- Bomb craters around the outer wire at Pleime still soar the earth, and the jungle growth nearby is littered with white patches from spent parachute flares.
THE idea that perhaps it would be better if waterfowl shooting were suspended for a year to give duck and goose populations a chance to build up has been advanced here and there.

At the Philadelphia Orchestra's concert last night in Philharmonic Hall the man on the podium was not its regular conductor, Eugene Ormandy, but a former pupil. He was Donald Johanos, who has come a long way since he first studied with Mr. Ormandy in 1955.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Federal government has ordered New York and New Jersey to clean up the Hudson River within the next four years. The cost of the project has been estimated at $400 million.

Chairman Joseph E. O'Grady of the Transit Authority reports that, even after using up all its bookkeeping balances, the municipal subway and bus system will be $43 million in the red by June 30. Greenwich Village leaders declared yesterday that a 12-story library proposed by New York University would "mutilate" Washington Square Park.

The first-round defeat administered to General de Gaulle in the Presidential election throws France into political limbo. The General Dynamics Corporation, the aircraft and submarine manufacturer, announced yesterday the appointment of Carl G. Holschuh as a vice president.

Representative Jonathan B. Bingham said yesterday that he would introduce a bill at the next session of Congress establishing a National Art Registry to protect museums, dealers and collectors against the "burgeoning fraudulent art problem."

THE hero of the Royal Danish Ballet's performance at the State Theater, Lincoln Center, last night, was undoubtedly Flemming Flindt. To start, the company gave the first New York performance of his ballet, based on the Ionesco play, "The Private Lesson."

A boyhood dream has come true for Kenneth Sherwood, 35-year-old, Harlem-born Negro. He is now the owner of a major retailing establishment on one of Harlem's major commercial thorough-fares -- 125th Street.
CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 8 -- Don't be surprised if you see a skier in the next few weeks flapping his arms and moving his legs like a ballet dancer while descending a slope.

Legal action to prevent the certification of Herman Badillo, a Democrat, as Bronx Borough President was dismissed yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Owen McGivern.
Four small stock offerings were marketed yesterday and all were reported completely sold.

WHITE PLAINS, Dee. 8 -- Sponsors of Synanon, a philanthropic foundation for the rehabilitation of narcotics addicts, will open an East Coast headquarters here Saturday to speed the development of a big new metropolitan area treatment center.

Sales of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., crossed the $500 million-mark in 1965 for the first time in its history, John J. Powers Jr., president and chief executive officer disclosed yesterday. The Public Housing Administration in Washington announced yesterday the sale of $90.19 million of tax-exempt bonds by 39 local housing authorities. Ten different underwriting groups bought the bonds.
Futures prices for pork bellies and soybeans set new life-of-contract highs yesterday.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Dec. 8 -- Two gunmen held up the home of Harry Lieberwitz at 3 Parkwood Drive today and made off with Government savings bonds, jewelry and furs valued at $143,000.

Most issues on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday for the second day in a row in very active trading.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Police Magistrate Francis X. Kennelly halted court here last night to perform a wedding, then sentenced the bridegroom to 30 days in Freehold County jail and imposed a $200 fine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Members of the American Newspaper Guild at The Washington Evening Star voted overwhelmingly today to ratify a three-year contract that gives them the first union shop agreement at any Washington newspaper in more than a decade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board reports that fiscal 1966 subsidies for the 13 local service airlines will decline $2.5 million from what was originally estimated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Soviet Union apparently failed on Nov. 23 in an attempt to launch its third Venus probe in 11 days, official sources said today.
