Once upon a time, this British author shows, some of the most knowledgeable horticulturists and botanists were witches. And understandably so if they were going to work their spells over the rest of us folk with magic made with the aid of hemlock, hemp and henbane, the horrendous mandrake, and such.
DETROIT, Dec. 8 -- The ailing American Motors Corporation took a turn for the worse today. The company announced it would cut production and lay off about 2,400 employes.

The way to play the game at Aqueduct yesterday was to get off in front and stay there. Of the nine races on the program, five were won by horses whose jockeys kept them in front from start to finish. The winners of three, other races were in front more often than not.
The increased cost of borrowing now rippling through the economy apparently will be felt also by investors and traders with margin accounts at brokerage houses.

IT is high time that someone used a meat ax to slash through the red tape that is preventing Charles Dillon Stengel, the retired millionaire, from gaining swift passage to his rightful place in baseball's Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y. The delay is unconscionable. If ridiculous rules block the way, they can and should be changed.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The man considered most likely to head the Government's new antipollution forces told the interstate conference on water pollution meeting in Dayton today that the recent Lake Erie hearings were beginning to get action.

After roughly 2,000 days of loyal and effective service to two Chief Executives, McGeorge Bundy will retire early next year as Special Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs to become head of the Ford Foundation.
The London stock market perked up somewhat in trading yesterday as gains outnumbered declines among leading industrial issues.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8 -- The two largest American commercial banks have filed applications with the South Vietnamese Government asking for licenses to open branches in Saigon.
The state is getting a $6.3 million windfall in the current fiscal year under its new system of staggering the expiration dates of car license plates.

SELMA, Ala., Dec. 8 -- A cafe busboy-waiter who said he had seen the fatal beating of the Rev. James J. Reeb after a voting rights demonstration here last March will not be allowed to testify in the trial of three men accused of murdering Mr. Reeb.

AFTER John Browning played the Prokofiev Second Piano Concerto with the Boston Symphony, last night in Philharmonic Hall, there was a general exodus. The "Dawn and Rhine Journey" from Wagner's "Gotterdammerung" was to follow the Prokofiev, but after the blazing fireworks of the concerto it would have been anticlimactic.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Dr. Andrew C. Ivy, chief scientific sponsor of Krebiozen, the controversial anticancer drug, today confirmed under cross-examination in Federal Court that his deposits in a personal savings account in a Chicago bank had grown from $16,982 in 1954 to $222,153 in 1962.

The period from now until Feb. 1 will be a period of critical transition for Haryou-Act, the embattled antipoverty program in Harlem. Livingston L. Wingate, its executive director, has delegated operating responsibilities during that period to a deputy while he concentrates on unsnarling the agency's fiscal records.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- The United States was accused today of placing itself above international law by waging "a classic war of intervention" in Vietnam.

Howard Taubman, drama critic of The New York Times for the last five years, has been appointed critic at large, effective Jan. 1. In his new post Mr. Taubman will report and comment on cultural activities in a wide variety of fields, in New York City, throughout the nation and abroad.

William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, described yesterday as "nonsense" charges that the increase in the discount rate might hamper Administration efforts to introduce a "tough" budget next month.

ENTRIES for the "international world's championship all-breed dog show" to be held in Nassau, the Bahamas, Jan. 10 to 20, will close next Wednesday. There will be $.5,000 for the world champion. One of the judges who will decide the grand winner is Stanley Daingerfield of Surrey, England.
The Propeller Club of the United States adopted a seven- point program yesterday as part of its efforts to strengthen the American merchant marine.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission began a drive today to make company financial reports more understandable to the average investor in securities.

THE reviewer strode into his symmetrically cluttered cloister. He passed towering shelves rich with new books about the world's present state, and, given luck, its possible future. He was in search of the historical American past.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- Two Soviet writers who were arrested three months ago on suspicion of having sent anti-Soviet novels to the West are still under investigation, a Government spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Government's two top career antitrust lawyers resigned from the Justice Department today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations recommended today that the salary of George Meany, president of the federation, be increased from $45,000 to $70,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- As Chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, Representative Wright Patman of Texas will control the machinery of the committee's "investigation" of the Federal Reserve Board he has now initiated for the second time.
An early work by Georges Braque, "Barques de Peche," brought $67,500, the high price, at an auction of impressionist and modern paintings, drawings and sculpture last night.
A Brooklyn grand jury report implicating a Federal narcotics agent and a city policeman in a shakedown conspiracy was made public yesterday by District Attorney Aaron E. Koota.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 8 -- India has asked the United States for emergency food shipments to help meet her impending famine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Representatives of a semiofficial poverty project in Syracuse confronted Sargent Shriver today and demanded that any money they receive in the future continue to come from Washington and not from the official Syracuse antipoverty program.
ROME, Dec. 8 -- Pope Paul VI closed the historic Ecumenical Council in open-air ceremonies before St. Peter's Basilica today amid Roman pomp and with messages to the world.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Don Marshall's third-period goal gave the New York Rangers a 2-2 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight. As a result, the Hawks dropped into a deadlock for first place with the Montreal Canadiens in the National Hockey League race.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- W.A. Patterson, chairman of the board of United Air Lines, said today his company had refrained from signing up for a supersonic transport because the waiting list was meaningless.

Murray Hill civic groups, pushing to forestall the impending opening of the heliport atop the 59-story Pan Am Building, yesterday demanded that the Police Department release its "helicopter disaster plan."

NEW YORK CITY has 7.8 million people, 7.5 million books in its public libraries and $30 billion in assessed property. It also has only 123,000 seats for professional football and, for its thousands of pro-football addicts, an awful void from one Sunday to the next.

" Anya," the musical starring Constance Towers, Michael Kermoyan, Lillian Gish and Irra Petina, will close after its 16th performance on Saturday night at the Ziegfeld. The two-week run was preceded by 16 previews.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The Hanoi radio has described as a fabricated "legend" reports that the North Vietnamese Government sought talks with the United States in 1964 on ending the Vietnamese war.
ALONG with their wedding bells, brides of 1966 may hear the clear ring of Lenox's new hand-blown crystal stemware.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A hearing officer for the Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to throw out New Haven Railroad testimony that the company could operate passenger trains in the New York metropolitan area only with a deficit.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 8 -- The procedure of closing all $100 and $50 place and show windows whenever a prohibitive favorite goes postward at Roosevelt Raceway will be eliminated -- but not at once. This was made plain today by Alvin L. Weil, the president of Roosevelt Raceway, where tomorrow night Cardigan Bay will be the heavy choice in the $50,000 Nassau Pace.

A 33-year-old city Buildings Department inspector was sent to jail for 30 days yesterday for refusing to answer questions before a grand jury investigating what may be widespread bribery among officials in that department.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- Jenmin Jib Pao, the Peking official daily poured scorn today on the fighting ability of United States troops in South Vietnam and said they became "jelly tigers" when attacked by Vietcong guerrillas.
The Battle of Haryou-Act probably won't go down in history books as a classic example of Federal-local cooperation in removing an executive director.

IN the last days before the elves, reindeer and that fat, bearded man from the Arctic descend on us with good wishes and such, perhaps a few suggestions as to what the outdoors type of man might like to see under his tree are in order.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Frank W. Rotella, King Kleagle of the New Jersey Ku Klux Klan, charged today that a Passaic County grand jury investigating his activities was "another example of harassment which is denying our civil rights."
The directors of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation voted yesterday to increase the regular quarterly dividend by 3 3/4 cents a share, effective with the payment on Jan. 15.

The all-male Helsinki University Chorus, which had made previous visits here in 1938 and 1953, sang at Carnegie Hall last night. The concert was in memory of the 100th anniversary of the birth of a patron and friend of the chorus, the composer Jean Sibelius.

Terms of the withdrawal of Robert E. Kintner as president of the National Broadcasting Company were being negotiated yesterday by lawyers for the network and the executive. The departure of Mr. Kinter from the chief executive post of N.B.C. was made known on Tuesday.
The United Federation of College Teachers has severely criticized plans of City College students to rate the competence of their professors.

Eighteen of the major football colleges in the East were directed yesterday to employ a fifth official on the field at all their home games starting next season. This fifth official will be the back judge, a man who is used now by many colleges in the nation.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. -- -- Slowly the gnarled brown hand guided tiny fingers clenching a paint brush and the jagged line turned into a smooth curve as the white paint outlined the neck of a dog.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Jack Ruby's lawyers said today that they were dropping their effort to transfer Ruby's sanity hearing from state to Federal courts.

The Reader's Digest Association has agreed to buy the 88-year-old Funk Wagnalls Company for an undisclosed sum. The reference book publishing company will operate in the future as a Digest division. Its president, William Roulet, will continue to act in that capacity.

TRENTON, Dec. 8 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes is planning to propose the repeal of New Jersey's most controversial revenue measure -- the local personal property tax on business inventory, equipment and machinery.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The first steps have been taken toward the formation of a political movement that would link civil rights, various student protests and opposition to the war in Vietnam, a policy statement disclosed today.
The Ecumenical Council of Vatican II, which ended ceremoniously yesterday, was beyond question the most important held by the Roman Catholic Church since the Council of Trent four centuries ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara announced today details of Administration plans for a massive reduction in military bases and a "realignment" of the strategic air forces.
When the freighter Export Champion sails for Europe tonight, her mixed cargo will include 100 used cars and one used, but vitally wanted, 12-Meter yacht.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 8 -- President Johnson will hold extensive discussions Friday on next year's Federal budget.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 8 -- A 72-year-old man who went to the aid of a woman who had been stripped and molested by five men behind his apartment house early on Nov. 13 was free today, but still stood convicted of manslaughter.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea Jr. of Montauk, L.I., said today that he had enough votes to unseat George L. Ingalls of Binghamton as the Republican minority leader in the 1966 Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The White House Conference on Civil Rights today released a compendium of proposals made at a recent two-day planning session. The ideas ranged all the way from those of Booker T. Washington to Malcolm X.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- British officials suggested today that Premier Kosygin's harsh words toward the West reflected mainly Soviet embarrassment over the Vietnam war.
JAMES SHERWIN, a New York master, achieved a signal triumph when he captured the first prize, scoring 5 1/2-1/2, in the recent Empire City Open tournament at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

The statement by Secretary Rusk on Nov. 26 in regard to negotiations on Vietnam again distorts the position of the National Liberation Front and of North Vietnam, and ignores a vital amplification of that position that was made by the N.L.F. on Aug. 3, in a statement that was headline news in Europe but unnoticed in the United States.
HYDE, England, Dec. 8 -- A tale of alleged torture, perversion and murder was told in a magistrate's court here today in the case of the two children's bodies found on the bleak Pennine moors.
Gustave G. Rosenberg has now exposed, in public testimony, a serious misinterpretation of his proper role as chairman of the Board of Higher Education.
ROME, Dec. 8 -- The major doctrinal work of the Vatican Ecumenical Council was the four constitution among the 16 drafts approved.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday it would build a major steel-making plant near Baytown, Tex.

The increasing awareness of the economic importance of retirement benefits has caused some employes to question the adequacy of their pension plans and wonder how they compare with those in other companies and industries.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The United States deprived the Rhodesian Government today of control over foreign exchange accounts held in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) proposed to the world's governments today a new plan for meeting one of the most perplexing problems faced by the less-developed countries.

Plans for an interstate Compact on Education, which involves the active cooperation of politicians and educators, received new impetus yesterday with the declaration that the movement would not attempt to control education policy.
ROME, Dec. 8 -- After 168 frequently argumentative meetings, Ecumenical Council Vatican II was brought to a peaceful conclusion today. The real work of the Council is about to begin.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- The East German Communists sought today to reject reports linking the suicide last week of Dr. Erich Apel, the Communist planning chief, with disputes over a new trade pact between the Soviet Union and East Germany.
The camp fund of the Yorkville Community Association will benefit from the annual Yorkville Dinner Dance, to be held at the Plaza on Jan. 21.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 8 -- Carlos Alfredo Bernardes of Brazil, Secretary General Thant's representative in Cyprus, has obtained an agreement from Greek and Turkish Cypriote leaders to demilitarize suburban areas of Famagusta, it was made known today.
HANOI, North Vietnam -- Life begins very early in all Asia, but Vietnam gives the impression that the whole population is trying to beat the sun to work.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 8 -- Dave Newmark set a Grace Hall scoring record tonight as Columbia trounced Lehigh, 102-59, for its third victory in three games.

The computer is beginning to make its weight felt in the field of stock market analysis, more than 500 market professionals were told yesterday at an electronic data processing workshop at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Office of Economic Opportunity announced tonight that parents no longer would be allowed to choose where their preschool children would attend Head Start classes.
The Metropolitan Opera Company and the Newport music festivals signed contracts yesterday to exchange performers for a week next July.

THE small round bomb that Brigette Bardot swings by its apple-like stem in the film "Viva Maria" has become a handbag. The Victorian shirtwaists and skirts she and her co-star, Jeanne Moreau, wear have been adapted into tucked-front dresses, minus the leg-o'mutton sleeves.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- American industry rallied its forces today to cope with the recent spate of public demands that it rectify its part in pollution of the nation's waterways.

A 39-year-old former customers' man, William M. Lendman, was named president and chief executive officer yesterday of Blair Co., Granbery, Marache, Inc This is a long-established investment banking concern and member of the New York Stock Exchange.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Arthur Ashe of the United States met unexpectedly strong resistance today before defeating Patricio Rodriguez of Chile, 7-5, 5-7, 6-2, in a third-round match in the South Australian tennis championship.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 8 -- A Government spokesman insisted today that Premier Levi Eshkol's condition was improving amid growing concern that the 70-year-old Israeli leader was suffering from more than "fatigue."

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Bailey Howell's two free throws with four seconds remaining gave the Baltimore Bullets a 129-127 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight in a National Basketball Association contest.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Women here may seem to dress and act pretty much like their sisters in such places as Fairfield County, Upper Westchester, Philadelphia's Main Line, California's Piedmont and the Maryland hunt country, but they are actually in a class by themselves.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The State Department expressed disappointment today over the "extreme distortions" of world events presented by Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin in his harsh attack on American foreign policy.
ROME, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- Following, in a translation supplied by the Vatican, is the text of the speech by Pope Paul at the Ecumenical Council's closing ceremony today:
BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Bill Bridges and Zelmo Beaty provided the scoring and rebounding punch that sparked the St. Louis Hawks to a 104-93 victory over the New York Knicks tonight.

Barbra Streisand's next television show will be presented by the Columbia Broadcasting System on March 30 from 9 to 10 P.M. It will be her second appearance under a three-show contract with the network.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- Under Secretary of Commerce Alan S. Boyd proposed today a compromise approach in determining merchant marine policy.
WHEN Ida Rosenthal went into the business 42 years ago, she didn't dream she'd be celebrating her 80th birthday in her Maidenform bra.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The State Department left the door open today to acceptance of a Vietcong offer of a 12-hour Christmas Eve truce but suggested that a "real Christmas present" would be Communist acceptance of peace negotiations.

Emile Griffith of New York has been made a 14-to-5 favorite to retain his world welterweight championship against a comparative unknown, Manuel Gonzalez of Houston, when the two clash in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Dec. 8 -- Some unexpected low scoring marked the opening round of the $125,000 Professional Golfers' Association four-ball championship today.
OTTAWA, Dec. 8 -- The average Indian in Canada is condemned to a short life of slums and few opportunities.

The increase in dividends paid by savings banks on individual accounts to 4 1/3 per cent from 4 1/4 per cent, which was kicked off on Monday by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, started to spread yesterday to other Brooklyn savings banks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Public school authorities here said today that the controversial "track" system used to group pupils in classes according to their ability to learn had resulted in the misplacement of hundreds of students in "basic" classes that failed to tax their full potential.
A skyscraper "city of the future" overlooking Manhattan may rise on 84 gray and grimy acres on the Hudson River in Weehawken, N.J., if a proposal of a New York City architect and a New Jersey

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 8 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith clamped stringent restrictions today on Rhodesia's trade with two of her neighbors, Zambia and Malawi. He said the action had been forced by British economic sanctions.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler asserted last night that the "rising tide of nationalism" in both the developed and less-developed nations was generating attitudes that could be detrimental to the expansion of companies abroad.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 8 -- A plan calling for a statewide system of 12 two-year community colleges that would be in operation by 1971 has been presented to the newly created State Board for Regional Community Colleges.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey said today "rivalry within and between Government agencies" was a greater danger to good government than corruption was.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Members of the Supreme Court speculated today about a possible trend toward making them a body of supercensors of the nation's reading matter.

An increase of 1,070,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 184,147,000 barrels, compared with 183,077,000 in the preceding week and 193,731,000 a year earlier.

Two officials of the City University testified yesterday that the Board of Higher Education had failed to face up to an impending enrollment crisis and had "muzzled" administrators who tried to point up the system's financial needs.
A three-judge Federal court upheld yesterday the new United States law permitting Puerto Ricans to vote on the basis of literacy in Spanish.
Greenwich Villagers have lined up for a strenuous battle before the City Landmarks Preservation Commission over whether the Village should be preserved as a historical area.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay announced yesterday that he would retain Henry A. Barnes as Traffic Commissioner and appoint Joel J. Tyler, a Bronx Republican, as License Commissioner. Mr. Barnes, the 59-year-old creator of the "Barnes Dance" and other traffic innovations, is the first of Mayor Wagner's commissioners to be held over by the Mayor-elect.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- A Cincinnati civil rights leader called upon the merged labor federation today to send representatives to that city to force building trades unions to stop what he said were discriminatory practices.

THE Soldier Shop Inc., 1013 Madison Avenue (between 78th and 79th Streets) is for red-blooded American boys aged 6 to 60. The shop specializes in military miniatures -- that's toy soldiers to people who can't tell a Continental Dragoon from a Napoleonic Chasseur or a British Royal Fusileer.

Programs in city high schools at which controversial subjects are presented are to be followed immediately by a discussion period, Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

Apparently the urge to be a "herring maven" is too much to resist for many people because more than 1,000 have sent for their official herring-maven kits. "Maven" is a Yiddish word that means "expert" or "connoisseur."

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector,), Dec. 8 -- An investigation into the background of Dr. Alexander Torok, counselor at the West German Embassy in Tel Aviv, has become a puzzle and an annoyance to Israeli officials.
Four substantial issues of tax-exempt bonds besides the housing authority issue were marketed yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec, 8 -- South Vietnam's ruling generals have decided to set up a civilian commission to draft a constitution that might lead to national elections by late next year or early in 1967.

The stock market which has made a robust recovery Tuesday from Monday's decline, weakened again yesterday. Almost all the averages were down for the day, with the blue-chip group showing significant losses.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 9 -- Renewed violent fighting between several Government battalions, led by elite Ranger units, and an estimated regiment of about 2,000 Vietcong broke out in the predawn hours today in the foothills of Quangtin province near the central coast, 355 miles north of Saigon.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

Robert S. McNamara's order to close, consolidate or reduce in size another group of military bases is another courageous exercise in good management on the part of the Secretary of Defense. With the cost of the Vietnam war rising sharply, there is less justification than ever for wasting military dollars on installations that are not clearly necessary.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday the election as directors of Million C. Mumford, chairman of the Lever Brothers Company, and Robert G. Cowan, chairman of the National Newark and Essex Bank of Newark. They will serve three-year terms, starting Jan. 1.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- President de Gaulle's candidacy for the run-off Presidential election Dec. 19 was announced officially today.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The invasion of the United States by European art auction houses was taken a step further today with the announcement by Christie's expansion plans.
The Bowery Savings Bank announced here yesterday the election of Cortland O. Burckhardt and Herbert F. Reilly as vice presidents.
The Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., increased its sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31, Samuel Bronfman, president of the international distiller, reported yesterday.

The state rested its case yesterday in Supreme Court against William Epton, a leader of the Progressive Labor Movement, on charges of anarchy and rioting in the racial disturbances in Harlem in July, 1964.
The British pound rose slightly in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday, closing at $2.8019, up 4 points from Tuesday. Traders attributed the gain chiefly to commercial buying.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- "McGeorge Bundy is not a duplicatable man," a former colleague observed today when he heard that President Johnson's Special Assistant for National Security Affairs had resigned. Since a job usually reflects the quality of a man who fills it, Mr. Bundy's, White House assignment may not be "duplicatable" either.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 8 -- An institute at the University of Virginia, established to examine the economic, industrial and social future of the state, has received gifts totaling $225,000 from a bank and five businessmen.

" The Promise of America," by John Morton Blum, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Jan. 13. The author is chairman of the Department of History at Yale University. His book is a series of essays on such subjects as what it is to be an American and what should it be.
Councilman Robert A. Low urged Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday to resign his Congressional seat immediately.

The long voyage home ends tomorrow for the liner President Monroe. When the American President Lines' ship ties up at Pier 9, Jersey City, regularly scheduled round-the-world trips orginiating in the Port of New York for United State-flag vessels will be history.

Eastern Air Lines will offer selective reduced fares on its no-reservation air shuttle between New York and Boston and Washington, effective Jan. 21, pending approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board, according to Floyd D. Hall, president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- With "Fanny Hill" in the bookshops and "Up at Lil's Place" on the screen, it is surely prudish to go on suppressing the truth about why men hate Christmas shopping. The trouble lies in the lingerie department.

Huntington Hartford has offered to modify drastically his plan for a sidewalk cafe in Central Park to make it acceptable to Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay, who has opposed it. Mr. Hartford has given the city $862,500 toward the cost of the cafe.
Record business in 1965 and encouraging forecasts for 1966 were key features of the statements made yesterday here and in other cities by four major industrial companies.

THE red blooded American man who claims to have no more interest in clothes than that he have a clean shirt may find that his ranks are thinning. The peacock instinct is beginning to show more and more through the cracks.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Harry Britt Brown Wichita newspaper official, and two former employes of the Wichita newspapers were indicted today by a Federal grand Jury on charges of violating income tax laws.
The city's budget for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 will be "substantially above $4 billion," Mayor Wagner forecast yesterday.
DINO ORLANDO, a 29-year-old Italian designer, says he's a snob.

About 750 persons, many of them United Nations ambassadors, attended the WAIF Cinderella Ball in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom last night. Proceeds went to WAIF the World Adoption International Fund), which, since its founding in 1953 by Mrs. Robert Waterfield (Jane Russell), has been responsible for the adoption of more than 14,000 children.
BONN, Dec. 9 -- The Bundestag passed today a bill reducing compensation payments to victims of the Nazis from $575 million to $475 million in each of the next two years.
The British pound gained 11 points over Wednesday in trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday to close at $2.8030.

When Anastas I. Mikoyan announced his resignation as Soviet chief of state in the Kremlin yesterday, his audience -- the members of the Supreme Soviet -- remained silent, apparently afraid to applaud on the theory that still another Old Bolshevik might be on the receiving end of a purge.

BONN, Dec. 9 -- A United States disarmament expert arrived today with a message that the Soviet Union has offered to sign "tomorrow" a treaty prohibiting the spread of nuclear weapons if the West drops the proposal for a joint nuclear force.

A Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice pointed out yesterday, in sentencing two youths in a triple slaying, that if the victims had lived their slayers might have received sentences that would have resulted in a longer time in prison for them.
Arnold G. Fraiman, who has been designated Investigation Commissioner in the Lindsay administration, is planning a wholesale replacement of the professional staff in the present department.
Three chemical companies, led by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday price reductions of more than 6 per cent for trichlorethylene, effected Jan. 1.

BONDVILLE, Vt., Dec. 9 -This season will be remembered in skiing circles as the one in which operators in Vermont gained a big jump over their fellow promoters in the White Adirondack and Catskill Mountains.
DETROIT, Dec. 9. (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings extended their winning streak to five games with a 7-3 victory tonight over the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game.
The next time you pull into that Sinclair service station near the armory in Bergenfield, N.J., take a good look at the guy manning the gas pump -- he may be an advertising account executive.
BRICKTOWN, N.J., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A tenderfoot Boy Scout today extinguished flames in the clothing of an elderly woman, and then ran into her home and put out a fire there.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Arthur Ashe of Richmond defeated Herb FitzGibbon of Garden City, L.I., today and moved into the semi-finals of the South Australia tennis championship.

TEHERAN, Dec. 9 -- The mainline Soviet Aeroflot plane for Iran takes off from a new airport outside Moscow. Everything there is a little newer, a little faster, a little more efficient than a year ago. It is like the rest of Moscow. The change is not startling, but the progress is visible, and when compared with the rate of progress in the borderlands to the south it is impressive.
HOISTING cables dipped, the wooden cradle groaned and the world's fastest 12-Meter yacht finally settled into place on the deck of the freighter that would carry her to Europe.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- Black-garbed pirates have taken over the copra-laden Greek freighter Aeakos, aground for two months on a reef in the South China Sea, and driven off a salvage ship.

A painting of a seated nude by Pablo Picasso was sold for $52,500 to a Swiss dealer last night as a two-day auction of impressionist and modern works ended at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- The Soviet Union warned today that the Atlantic alliance must abandon any notion of sharing nuclear weapons with West Germany if there was to be any East-West agreement leading to disarmament.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay has begun grappling with one of the more delicate issues he will face in City Hall -- what his relationship will be with Robert Moses.

The Nov. 28 editorial "The Animal Laboratories" admits the lack of pertinent data, yet considers it as "fact" that "many, if not most, laboratories" provide their animals with inadequate space, food, water, records or freedom from pain.
DETROIT -- At the J.L. Hudson Company here, a department store city within a city, Christmas is everywhere in the air.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange fell slightly in dull trading yesterday. Losses were small and were attributed to profit taking, although there was some investment buying in banks, steel and insurance issues.
MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (AP) -- About 500 deck officers of the Canadian Merchant Service Guild struck today, tying up about 170 ships of 18 Great Lakes shipping companies.

The disclosure that some city high schools have systematically upgraded students' records or concealed failure in some courses underscores the unhappy consequences of the competition for college admission. Schools want to ease the way for their students. In the process some school officials undoubtedly also hope to add synthetic brightness to the image of their institutions.

Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick announced yesterday morning a new program to better police-community relations. And the sun had barely set when uniformed policemen were serving tiny cookies and coffee to citizens in East Harlem.
HOUSTON, Dec. 9 -- Gemini 7 swung into a wide, almost perfect circular orbit today for its date to rendezvous with Gemini 6 on Sunday.
The roller-coaster action in the stock market continued yesterday as most popular averages rose moderately.

The Futterman Corporation, real estate investment and insurance company, announced yesterday the acquisition of the Titan Industrial Corporation, a privately owned trading company that buys and sells steel and operates on four continents.
A 78-foot tugboat sank in the Hudson River yesterday in a pre-dawn collision with a 490-foot British freighter off downtown Franklin Street.

MADNESS once again reigned supreme in the State Theater at Lincoln Center last night when it was the turn of Flemming Flindt to take for the first time in New York the leading role in his own ballet, "The Private Lesson."

The New York Central Railroad raised its quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday to 52 cents a share from 32 1/2 cents. It also voted a year-end extra of $1.10 1/2 a share. Both are payable Dec. 31 to holders of record Dec. 21.

Consular officials of the five Scandinavian countries will be the guests of honor at the Christmas ball of the New York Chapter of the American-Scandinavian Foundation. It will be held on Thursday in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell attacked the Federal antipoverty program sharply today but said its size should be trebled.
Michael J. Quill called off last night the Christmas season transit strike he had threatened for 5 A.M. on Dec. 15.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Al Attles tossed in two free throws with 34 seconds left and Guy Rodgers added another with five seconds to go to give the San Francisco Warriors a 110-109 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
A German-American team of physicists has produced antiprotons with a beam of extremely high-energy rays.
The national indoor track and field championships will return to Madision Square Garden in 1967 if the Garden wants them, it was learned yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 9, (UPI) -- Frank Robinson, one of the National League's best outfielders, was traded to the Baltimore Orioles today in a four-player deal that sent Milt Pappas and Jack Baldschun, pitchers, to the Cincinnati Reds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Donald F. Turner, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust Division, intends to attack some long-standing pattent licensing practices of American industry as antitrust violations.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 9 -- United States pilots subjected North Vietnam yesterday and early today to the most intensive bombardment of the war.
Most commodities, especially those that advanced sharply during the week, took a breather yesterday in futures trading.

In an apparent attempt to salvage their investments, major creditors caught in the crash of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation in Canada have taken control of the Great Northern Capital Corporation, a holding company that owned a majority of the shares in the not insolvent operation.

The Feb. 1 deadline imposed by a State Supreme Court justice on the Legislature for establishing new voting districts throughout New York was affirmed yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

Ron Landeck of Princeton and Tom Mitchell of Bucknell were honored last night as the outstanding football players in the East. They received their awards at the 11th annual Eastern College Athletic Conference awards dinner at the Manhattan Hotel.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- A $12 million bond issue for the Ramapo Central School District 2 was approved here last night by more than 60 per cent of 6,666 votes cast. The proposal had been defeated twice before.

Five more Brooklyn savings banks -- the East New York Savings Bank, the Greater New York Savings Bank, the South Brooklyn Savings Bank, the Roosevelt Savings Bank and the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburgh -- joined yesterday the list of institutions saying that they intend, assuming continued favorable earnings, to increase the dividend rate on their savings accounts to 4 1/2 per cent from 4 1/4 per cent.
A 32-year-old activist in civil rights was named yesterday director of the Commission on Religion and Race of the National Council of Churches.
Armand D'Angelo, who resigned Dec. 1 as the city's Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, has been elected chairman of the Joint Industry Board of the electrical industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Uncertain whether to shake or bite the Federal hand that feeds them, some 700 university and college officials gathered here today for a cram course in the ABCs of Government aid.

State tax officials began an investigation yesterday in the disappearance of Max Donovan, a dog, who was last seen leaving for California in a sports car more than a year ago, accompanied by a model for brassieres.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Halim Budo of Albania tonight called for the application of sanctions against the United States to halt its "acts of armed aggression" in Vietnam.

MASJID-I-SULAIMAN, Iran -- Early in 1964 a passage to Hell was opened in this ancient place sacred to Solomon, son of David, the Semitic hero-king who imprisoned the powers of evil under his great seal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association reduced its buying price for mortgages today by one point.

BUFFALO, Dec. 9 -- The City Controller and two other men here were indicted by grand jury today on conspiracy charges growing out of the sale of a former Post Office annex building for use as a city garage.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- George Meany, reporting on his 10-year stewardship as president of the merged labor federation, said today that the organization had never been stronger and was on the threshold of a new period of expansion.
Vowing "I shall not kilt anyone for any reason whatsoever," a 22-year-o1d pacifist yesterday refused induction into the Army. He was not arrested.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley, the boss of the Chicago Democratic machine, said today that Senator Douglas would be a candidate for a fourth term.
HYDE, England, Dec. 9 -- A 17-year-old boy told a magistrate's court here today that he had seen one of the three victims in the Pennine moors murder case slain with a hatchet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Dec. 4 was considerably ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1964. Rail carloadings for the same period also registered an increase.

LONDON, Dec. 9 --Britain asked the Soviet Union in a note today to join her in a joint appeal to the North Vietnamese Government to negotiate the ending of the war in Vietnam "as soon as possible and without prior conditions."
THOUSANDS of easels have been moving out of stores into homes this year as props for a host of decorations -- some good, some bad -- that have come to be known as "table top art."
Senator Robert F. Kennedy suggested yesterday that the United States take "whatever initiative" it could to get an extension of the 12-hour Christmas Eve truce suggested by the Vietcong.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Administration responded today to mounting demands for programs to permit the cultivation of more acres to meet the world food crisis.
One hundred and ninety professors representing Harvard, Yale and 15 other New England colleges and universities announced yesterday full support of the Administration's Vietnam policy.
The Committee of Religious Leaders of New York City has commended Variety, the entertainment trade weekly, for its condemnation of the film "Fanny Hill."

American Jewish leaders were told last night that the loss of $17 million in annual German reparation payments had created a "major gap in the global budget" to meet Jewish needs throughout the world, with special emphasis on Israel.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 9 -- Mikhail Sholokhov, the 1965 Nobel laureate for literature, ignored today efforts to present an appeal from an international group of writers and intellectuals to intervene on behalf of two imprisoned Soviet writers.

THE last time a complete performance of Mahler's Eighth Symphony was given in New York was in 1950. There are many reasons why performances come only at scattered intervals. A conductor has to learn the gargantuan work.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy yesterday urged all those interested in the Democratic nomination for Governor to declare themselves now.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 9 -- If the $50,000 Nassau Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight had been a prizefight instead of the 1 1/2-mile harness race it was, the referee would have stopped it at the top of the stretch and declared Cardigan Bay the winner.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 9 -- Following are remarks on Vietnam made by President Johnson today during an address to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention:
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- President Johnson appealed today for organized labor's cooperation in preventing inflation.
The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., announced yesterday that it had revoked the registration of three sales representatives and expelled a brokerage firm from membership.
SELMA, Ala., Dec. 9 -- The state today was unable to persuade a reported eyewitness to come to Alabama to testify against three Selma businessmen accused of a civil rights murder.
William Howard Adams has been named associate director of the Arts Councils of America, a national association of state and community groups.

IN compiling the first part of this Christmas list (Dec. 8 column), I counted fewer than 20 recent novels worth recommending. For today's list -- general non-fiction -- there are over 50 titles I should like to include.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Pentagon's announcement yesterday of plans to shut down many military bases and to reduce the number of bombers in the Strategic Air Command was followed today by an unusual calm after the initial protests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Federal Maritime Commission announced today another move in its continuing campaign against rate disparities on ocean shipments moving in opposite directions over a common trade route.
Low-priced issues attracted most of the attention on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the market continued to climb on very strong volume.
Corporations that recruit talent from the nation's campuses believe that the business outlook for 1966 indicates improvement over the present year -- land the salaries for new graduates are going up.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 9 -- Fifty Communist leaders have been arrested in Iraq in the last four days with the uncovering of a secret organization of the banned Iraqi Communist party. The official Iraqi news agency said the arrests had been made in Hilla, Diwaniya, Kut and Najaf.

SAIGON, South Vietnam,Dec. 9 -- North Vietnam's economy and military establishment have substantially withstood the shock of 10 months of United States air attacks, according to information available here from the North.
MOSCOW, Dec. 9 --President Ho Chi Minh has described President Johnson's offer of unconditional peace talks as an attempt "to force the Vietnamese people to accept the terms of the United States."
PERHAPS the best title ever selected for a bridge book was "Why You Lose at Bridge," the classic by S.J. Simon which commands a steady sale 20 years after first publication.

How does one write about a recital by Mirella Freni? This most endearing of young Italian sopranos, about whom one would hate to write a harsh word, turned up on the stage of Hunter College Assembly Hall last night to give her first United States recital.
The National Association of Purchasing Agents checked in yesterday with one of the most cheerful 1966 business forecasts to date.
Congress will be asked by the Port of New York Authority to appropriate more than $23.5 million next year for five basic channel and waterway improvements in the New York-New Jersey port area.

The National Woman's League of the United Synagogues of America will hold a luncheon Thursday at the Plaza at which its National Community Leadership Awards in the field of Judaism will be distributed.
DETROIT, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Fines totaling $204,500 were levied in United States District Court today against six major rubber companies and three individuals on price fixing charges.

THE drama of the executive suite tends to repetition: the spectacular departure of the big name and the sudden elevation of subordinates. The script of the shuffle at the National Broadcasting Company, however, contains an added ingredient, the story of a man who does not want to be a broadcasting company president.

BART STARR was throwing the football and throwing it well in practice yesterday and Wednesday far the Green Bay Packers. This means that Starr, very likely, will be his team's starting quarterback at Baltimore on Sunday in the big game against the Colts. It.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to stop the General Motors corporation from blocking the sales of Chevrolets through discount houses.
THOSE wardrobe stretchers called separates are now being offered for bridesmaids.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 9 -- Two American students who led last Saturday's demonstration here against United States policy in Vietnam have been placed on probation by their program director and have been warned that they might be dismissed if they demonstrated again.
SAIGON, Friday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The United States Marines were thrown into action yesterday to help the South Vietnamese force battling a Vietcong regiment in Quangtin Province, south of Danang.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 9 -- President Johnson authorized immediate steps today to help alleviate the threat of famine in India.

" The Klansman," a novel by William Bradford Huie, will be published by Delacorte next fall. The novel is based on the idea that an American patriot, winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor, becomes a member of the Ku Klux Klan in 1965 and is led to commit a murder to protect his way of life. Mr. Huie wrote his publisher: "Thomas Dixon's novel.
Old and young, rich and not so rich added their gifts yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Two robbers broke into tile Duke of Wellington's town house today, beat a guard in a section used as t museum and made off with three priceless jeweled treasures of Britain's military history.

LIKE a fighter who anticipates that his opponent will throw an instant haymaker in his direction, the Army emerged from the corner with its guard high and its defenses alerted. Careful were the preparations for the bout with public opinion in the case of Joe Namath of the New York Jets, classified 4-F in the draft and thereby deferred from military service.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Dec. 9 -- The second round of the Professional Golfers' Association's national four-ball championship developed into a scoring spree today. Weather conditions were excellent, but par was battered as if it were caught in a storm.
It was indicated yesterday that a settlement was near in the City University dispute that led to the announced resignation and retirement of four top university officials.
ESSEN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- Economic trends in Western Europe are seesawing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Vice President Humphrey indicated disagreement today with the balance between military-space and civilian spending in the Federal budget.
Smoothly working thieves invaded two fashionable hotel suites on the East Side and made off with $115,000 in jewels, the police reported yesterday.

Favorites persisted in avoiding the winner's circle yesterday in the antepenultimate program of the local thoroughbred racing season at Aqueduct. On the nine-race program, only one favorite -- Gay Boullee in the ninth race -- of the 24,691 customers was able to score.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley and other interested parties including the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced today a new and immediate program to increase the number of Negro building and construction industry apprenticeships.
NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Gomer Jones was permitted today to resign as football coach at Oklahoma but continue as athletic director, thus clearing the way for selection of a new coach.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 9 -- A Republican primary fight in the Third Congressional District in Nassau County appeared certain today after Archibald L. Gillies of Glen Head announced he would seek his party's nomination for the seat.

Bob Blackman, the coach of the undefeated Dartmouth football team, turned down an offer to coach at the University of Iowa yesterday and, in an announcement that had Dartmouth alumni cheering and dancing on chairs in the Essex House here, he said he would remain as the Indians' mentor.

IN the first weeks of confusion after the abrupt removal of Nikita S. Khrushchev from power in Moscow 14 months ago, evidence began to point to a fast-rising official, Nikolai Viktorovich Podgorny, as a contender for the dominant role in the Soviet leadership.

MIAMI, Dec. 9 -- Owners of the cruise ship Yarmouth Castle petitioned the United States District Court here today to limit their liability in the ships sinking to the amount of the passengers' fares and what is left of the vessel -- six lifeboats valued at $7,750.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -Plans to extend, strengthen and coordinate antiwar strategy among Vietnam Day Committee chapters all over the country were announced here today by three leaders of the Berkeley group.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- A Republican policy group was urged today to denounce extremist groups of the political left and right as a challenge to the Democrats to do the same.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk had high praise today for McGeorge Bundy, who is retiring as the President's Special Assistant for National Security Affairs.
HANOI, North Vietnam -- Through the daylight hours nothing moves on the roads of North Vietnam, not a car nor a truck; it must look from the air as though the country had no wheeled transport at all.

THE thankless, unpaid but prestigious task of presiding over 4,000 women who are ambitious, aggressive and talented enough to have reached executive status in the fashion industry fell yesterday upon the slender shoulders of Helen Van Slyke. She was elected president of Fashion Group, an organization founded 34 years ago to help women get along in the fashion business.
IN many places across the land at Christmas time, parents consider giving a youngster a gun; a real firearm that can make holes in animate things as well as perforations in paper targets.
" The Deputy" will go on the road, after all, but not as it was staged on Broadway last year for 318 performances.

Democratic members of the City Council agreed unanimously at a caucus yesterday to continue David Ross as majority leader, thereby assuring his re-election on Jan. 5, when the Council formally organizes.

A high official at the city's Bureau of Child Health charged yesterday that the Housing Authority condemned unwed mothers to a "vicious cycle" of squalor and depravity by barring them from public housing.

PARIS -- The runoff campaign for France's Presidency may remind Americans of Senator Goldwater's original 1964 slogan -- "A choice, not an echo." Goldwater appealed to U.S. conservatives to discard previous bipartisan policy.
MIAMI, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Cuban refugee airlift, off to a slow start, has flown in fewer than 600 exiles since its start on Dec. 1. The goal was more than 800 weekly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The number of telephone calls in New York City the night of the Nov. 8 blackout broke all records -- 30 million between 5:30 P.M., just after the lights went out, and midnight.
SAIGON, Dec. 9 -- Antiwar demonstrations in the United States have had a three-way effect here in Vietnam, according to many United States and Vietnamese officers.
A witness testified yesterday that Christopher Lynch, a tall, powerfully built 17-year-old, murdered Andrew A. Mormile in an IND subway train last March.

President Johnson's authorization of a $50 million loan for fertilizers as well as swifter shipments of United States wheat will help to alleviate India's latest food crisis. But these moves will not eradicate hunger and starvation in India. They are stopgap measures that, like previous emergency efforts and India's new rationing plans, will keep famine within what has become tolerable bounds.
It was double-O night for New York University last night as Madison Square Garden kicked off its 32d season of intercollegiate basketball.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 9 -- One substantial group of filmmakers, whose work has long been ignored here, basked in newfound recognition this week.
FOR its second production of the season the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center has revived a witty, bawdy, scornful 17th-century play, "The Country Wife." But, alas, the company is not up to it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The concept of Federal Government leadership in cleaning up the nation's polluted waterways was roundly denounced today by one of industry's major trade associations.

Harry B. Anderson, a senior vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith and former head of the firm's commodities department, said yesterday the New York Produce Exchange "locked the barn door" when it put limits on the number of cottonseed oil futures contracts a trader could hold.

Paintings and sculpture from the collection of the late G. David Thompson, one of the most dynamic and acute international art collectors and traders of 20th century, will be auctioned next March at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that Communist China would have to decide whether to wage war against the United States, because the Johnson Administration would do everything necessary to prevent a Communist take-over in South Vietnam.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 9 -- President Johnson said today that the United States was determined that every prospect for peace in Vietnam be exhausted "before other hard steps are taken."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- A flash of orange fire or a "fireball" was sighted in the sky today by airplane pilots and residents in six states and Canada.
HOUSTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- Tommy Nobis, an all-America linebacker, became the first professional football prospect to get a message from outer space today.

Religious leaders of the non-Roman Catholic world yesterday hailed the three-year work of the Second Vatican Council for bringing all faiths closer together in a spirit of unity rather than divisiveness.
HAVANA, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A complaint that the Soviet Union overcharges Cuba for manufactured goods has had results. The Russians have promised correction.
Three Ohio utilities announced yesterday plans for building jointly what could become one of the world's largest steam-generating plants.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 9 Business and banking circles here expressed cautious hope today that the bulk of Rhodesia's trade with Zambia and Malawi would survive the restrictions imposed yesterday by Prime Minister Smith's Government.

More than half the seats in Town Hall were vacant last night, and so much the worse for those who failed to fill them. For, if William Doppman's piano recital was poorly attended, it was richly played. It was, in fact, an extraordinary evening.

Legislation to force the city's hospitals, schools, subways, water works and privately owned multi-storied buildings to install auxiliary power and lighting equipment will be introduced to the next session of the Legislature, a Queens Assemblyman said yesterday.
Livingston L. Wingate declared yesterday that he would return to his duties as administrative head of Haryou-Act on Feb. 1, despite reports to the contrary from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission cost analyst testified today that the New Haven Railroad's New York suburban passenger services operated at a profit but later conceded under cross-examination that accepting certain assumptions, these would show a deficit.
The World Council of Churches has announced that it will hold its next assembly in Uppsala, Sweden, on a theme with clear overtones of Ecumenical Council Vatican II.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of Secretary of State Dean Rusk's news conference today:
The Landmarks Preservation Commission's proposal to designate a 65-block area in Greenwich Village as a historic district was strongly opposed by Village real estate and business groups yesterday.

Emile Griffith was a 3-1 favorite to retain his world welterweight championship tonight at Madison Square Garden against Manny Gonzalez in a scheduled 15-round fight to be telecast in color over a regional network outside the New York area.

Connecticut will hold a referendum next Tuesday on adoption of a new State Constitution. A much-improved basic law for the state has been unanimously agreed upon by a constitutional convention of 84 delegates, equally divided between Republicans and Democrats. It has been approved by both major parties and by the nonpartisan League of Women Voters. The prospects for its acceptance at the polls seem good despite bitter right-wing opposition.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, who is among the last of the Old Bolsheviks, stepped down today as the Soviet chief of state. His resignation led to the most significant Kremlin shuffle since the downfall of Nikita S. Khrushchev 14 months ago.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 9 -- President Kenneth D. Kaunda has issued a new and urgent appeal to Prime Minister Wilson for British troops to protect the Kariba Dam, which straddles the Rhodesian frontier. The plea was described as final.
Teddy Goodman was remembered by his former students yesterday without tears.

William Shryock Renchard, native of Trenton and Princetonian, Class of 1928, was elected yesterday chairman of New York's fourth-largest bank, the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company. Mr. Renchard, now president, will take over the post from Harold H. Helm on Jan. 1, his 58th birthday.

More than 1,000 students and several hundred faculty members at Yale University called yesterday for a "nationwide reappraisal" of American policy in the Far East. The first step, they said, should be the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
COLUMBIA, Mo. Dec. 9 -- Branch Rickey, a dominant figure in baseball for half a century, died tonight in Boone County Memorial Hospital at the age of 83.

The death of John J. O'Rourke, New York regional vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is likely to provide the impetus for a new attempt by underworld elements to obtain control over 168,000 truck drivers and warehousemen in this area.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Schoolchildren in the United States are not softies.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Mike MeKeever, a former University of Southern California football star, battled for his life today after undergoing brain surgery to remove a small blood clot.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 9 -- The United States has revoked the visa of Djanira Motta e Silva, the Brazilian artist, who was planning major exhibits oil her paintings next year in Washington and New York.
PARIS Dec. 9 -- French policy toward the Common Market and European unification today became the first major issue in the campaign for the runoff Presidential election of Dec. 19.

A trans-Atlantic debate between students of Oxford and Harvard on whether the United States should carry out its commitment in Vietnam will be televised on Tuesday, Dec. 21, from 10 to 11 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board refused today to order an investigation of air freight rates.

Conditions in the money market eased in the week ended Wednesday, as the Federal Reserve moved aggressively to smooth the transition to higher interest rates following its increase in discount and time deposit rates last weekend.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Despite opposition from many Western powers, the African and Asian members of the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee pushed through today a resolution denouncing South Africa's administration of the trust territory of South-West Africa.
Municipal bonds, buoyed by the highest yields in nearly five and a half years, sold swiftly yesterday.

ATHENS, Dec. 9 -- The ultraconservative Greek Orthodox Church, which resists all current efforts for reunion between Orthodox and Roman Catholic Churches, criticized ecumenical Patriarch Athenagoras today for having voided the excommunication cast on the Church of Rome in 1054.

ATLANTA, Dec. 9 -- In the offices of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee today, civil rights workers were preparing a 10-page brochure that will announce the birth of one of the nation's smallest political parties.

The Alleghany Corporation, the holding company through which Allan P. Kirby, its chairman, and the late Robert R. Young acquired control of the New York Central Railroad, disclosed yesterday it was studying the feasibility of tendering its 984,100 shares of the Central in exchange for Alleghany common stock.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Charles H. Percy, the Republican businessman defeated last year in a bid for Governor of Illinois, is ready to make a new political bid in next year's Senate race.

The Philharmonia Woodwind Quintet made its debut as a group at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Its members are Paul Dunkel, flutist; Louise Scribner, oboist; Michael Sussman, clarinetist; William Scribner, bassoonist, and Vincent Schneider, French horn player.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- The country's home builders went on record today as being opposed to the Federal Reserve Board's rise in permissible interest rates for commercial banks.
ATLANTA, Dec. 9 -- Atlanta prostitutes, aided by the American Civil Liberties Union, won today their battle for the right to walk and ride on the city's streets.

Sol Berger, president and chief executive officer of the Colonial Corporation of America, announced yesterday his resignation and the granting of powers of attorney to three others to sell his family's 900,000 Colonial shares.

The architectural community of this city is alarmed by the ravage being wrought in our last frontier borough of Staten Island. Undisciplined and unrestrained speculation is transforming this magnificent island into another sad example of suburban sprawl.
ONE of the first things Enid Morris did on her arrival in New York was to whip up some cashmere sweaters with embroidered borders. Elizabeth Arden bought them all.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall asked today for constructive recommendations and proposals to expand research on disposal of scrap automobiles, mining refuse, slag dumps and other solid mineral wastes.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Assembly Minority Leader George L. Ingalls of Binghamton said today he felt sure he could hold his Republican leadership post in the 1966 session despite a challenge by Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea Jr. of Montauk.
A challenge to the constitutionality of the state's Condon-Wadlin law, which prohibits strikes by city or state employes, was rejected by State Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 10 -- More than 30 years ago Riza Shah, father of the present ruler, decreed that his country should be known by its ancient name, Iran (from Arya or Aryan) and that the Greco-Roman "Persia" was an impropriety.
ATHENS, Dec. 10 -- Greek emigrants traveling to the United States by sea will be offered an "intensive orientation course" during their 12-day journey from Piraeus to New York.

Edward Auer, a 24-year-old pianist who made his New York debut last January and won fifth place in Poland's Chopin Piano Competition in Warsaw in March, gave his second recital here last night in Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

" An Evening with Benjamin Britten" was the way the Atlanta Boy Choir's program at Town Hall last night was listed. It was a good idea, and -- considering Britten's output -- surprising that it came as such a novelty.

I have read with interest your Nov. 22 editorial dealing with the decision of the British Cabinet to grant independence to British Guiana next May, and stating that "in the United States there may be even more concern over this decision than over the problems stemming from the seizure of independence by Rhodesia's white minority Government."
CINCINNATI, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Willie Mays's outstanding contribution to the San Francisco Giants in 1965 is reflected in the official National League slugging averages issued today.
However much I approve Medicare in principle, I protest its use as a political football to soak the rich and punish their doctors for having opposed it.
From the ashes of a fire in September, the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx has brought forth a Christmas show that it says is better than ever.

DUBLIN, Dec. 10 -- The Irish Government has rejected a request by United States authorities for permission to allow American airlines on the North Atlantic to operate into Dublin, with stops at Shannon airport in each direction.
The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday it would cut its prices on formaldehyde effective Jan. 1. Other major producers said immediately they were studying similar moves.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Dec. 10 -- Two men were arrested today in connection with the theft over an eight-year period of an estimated $1.26 million in gold and platinum from the American Smelting and Refining Company's plant here.
GENEVA, Dec. 10 -- United States sources described today as "quite good" the outlook for the renewal of the 28-nation pact for regulating international trade in cotton textiles.
WARSAW, Dec. 10 -- An important Government-owned newspaper issued a violent attack on Polish Roman Catholic bishops today for a conciliatory note they sent earlier in the week to German prelates.
The legality of Mayor Wagner's controversial "borrow now, repay later" financing program was upheld yesterday by a state appeals court.

It is immoral to send our soldiers to Vietnam and at the same time refrain from bombing Hanoi and Haiphong although we know that instruments are manufactured and stored there to kill our men in the field.

Four days after the 60th anniversary of his New York debut, Artur Rubinstein will begin a three-concert series of piano concertos in Carnegie Hall With an orchestra conducted by Alfred Wallenstein, he will play Mozart concertos Jan. 12; the Beethoven Concertos Nos. 3, 4 and 5 on Jan. 19, and the two Brahms concertos Jan. 22.
Bob Friend yesterday became the first assistant to a bank president to be listed as an active pitcher by the New York Yankees.

Pete Bostwick Jr., the national amateur court tennis champion, and his brother Jimmy, the former champion, won the opening match in the annual Payne Whitney Memorial intersectional doubles tourney yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 10 -- State Department officials here were cautious tonight in forming any judgment about reports from Montevideo that the governing National Council was about to break relations with the Soviet Union.

OXFORD, England, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Oxford University Press announced that it is planning a complete revision of Britain's Dictionary of National Biography It is estimated that the project will cost 350,000 ($980,000).
Cardinal Spellman was the host yesterday at the 20th annual Christmas party for the children of the New York Foundling Hospital. The party was held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
THE big art book year crests appropriately with two volumes on Michelangelo. One magnificently covers his work's astounding range. The other brilliantly uncovers mysteries in his poetry.
Emile Francis had been the coach of the New York Rangers for only two games, but yesterday he was already speechless.
The H.J. Heinz Company reported yesterday the highest sales and earnings figures in its 96-year-history for the six months ended Oct. 27.
Expenditures by Haryou-Act of perhaps $300,000 this year for security guards have apparently become a focus of Federal and city investigations of the Harlem antipoverty project.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Stockholders of the American Gypsum Company voted 92.5 per cent in favor today of a merger with the Susquehanna Corporation of Chicago.

Once again The New York Times is raising the cry for the establishment of tighter controls over private capital movements from the United States. This is a shortsighted view for a newspaper whose policies are supposed to be "liberal."

" The Defense of Freedom," by Arthur J. Goldberg, will be published by Harper Row in May. The book presents the public papers of the Chief United States Representative to the United Nations. The book is being edited by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the former Assistant Secretary of Labor, who was defeated as a Democratic candidate for President of the New York City Council in September.
The British pound was fairly steady in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Spot sterling for Monday was quoted at $2.8027, down 3 points from Thursday.

THE New York Giants, fighting to keep second place in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League, are one-touchdown underdogs tomorrow. So are the New York Jets, fighting to keep second place in the Eastern Division of the American Football League.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Retail sales in November leveled out at about the October rate, despite a good rise in sales of automobile dealers, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- President Johnson signed today a proclamation continuing the oil-import program in 1966 basically unchanged front its present form.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Soviet Union has given diplomatic assurances to the United States that it has no intention of placing nuclear weapons into orbit, the State Department disclosed today.

The ability of the World's Fair Corporation to meet it commitments to restore Flushing Meadow Park and still settle its private financial obligations became a major concern of the city government yesterday.
Allan Nevins, historian and biographer, was elected president of the American Academy of Arts and Letters yesterday, succeeding Lewis Mumford, who had served for three years.
Some 75 uptown people went downtown yesterday to give Louis J. Lefkowitz a cram course in art.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 10 -- The 1965 Nobel Peace Prize was presented here today to the United Nations Children's Fund on the eve of the 19th anniversary of the fund's founding. King Olav V attended the ceremony, at which Henry R. Labouisse, an American, the executive director of the fund, received a gold medal, a scroll and a check for about $56,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 -- An abandoned home workshop project has developed into one of the fastest growing sound-equipment enterprises in the industry. While the concern, the KLH Research and Development Corporation, retains some of the informality of an amateur operation, its sales figures since 1958 indicate a strong professional hand must be at the helm.

When a caller asked yesterday to talk to Jerome S. Neuman, president of the Chock Full O' Nuts Corporation, the switchboard operator said, "He is no longer with the company." Subsequently reached by telephone at his home, Mr. Neuman confirmed that statement. "I'm out," he said, "but I'm still a board member."
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Tom Nugent was dismissed today as football coach at the University of Maryland.
The United Jewish Appeal's major beneficiaries yesterday projected a $116,685,000 budget for next year to care for more than 800,000 Jews in 30 countries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The State Department said today that a special exemption to the immigration laws had been ordered to permit Djanira da Motta de Silva, a prominent Brazilian artist, to visit the United States.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 10 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri announced today that he would meet with President Johnson in the United States next Feb. 1.

The stock market finished a surprising week yesterday on a surprisingly affirmative note.

PHUQUOC ISLAND, South Vietnam -- Nine more Coast Guard patrol boats and at least 84 high-speed Navy launches will soon join the fleet of small craft combating Vietcong supply infiltration in Vietnam's coastal waters.
MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- Senior Western diplomats assess yesterday's shuffle in the Communist party and Government as a strengthening of genuine collective leadership in the Kremlin.

HOUSTON, Dec. 10 -- The final checkout for Gemini 6 ticked away today with not a trace of trouble that might delay the spacecraft's launching from Cape Kennedy on Sunday for its scheduled rendezvous in space with Gemini 7.

Ray Robinson showed up last night, which, to a lot of fight fans, was a switch. Better than that, the famed Sugar Ray was on hand early, capping an anxiety that he had felt all day while awaiting his big retirement ceremony in the ring at Madison Square Garden.

Mayor Wagner made it clear yesterday that he intended to remain active in Democratic politics after leaving office Jan. 1 and was not conceding leadership of the state party to Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
TORONTO, Dec. 10 -- Canadian interest rates moved up briskly this week, following increases in central bank rates in the United States and Canada.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10 -- The United States Marines landed a third battalion today in a Vietcong stronghold in the Quangtin foothills. The battalion quickly joined in a drive to encircle the Vietcong guerrillas and drive them from the area.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Dec. 10 -- The Hebert brothers, Jay and Lionel, took the lead in the $125,000 Professional Golfers' Association's four-ball championship today. With a third round of 66, they brought their, 54-hole best-ball score to 196, which is 20 under par at the P.G.A. National Golf Club.
The London Stock Exchange showed a mild recovery in quiet trading yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 10 (AP) -- President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz introduced legislation today that would put the Mexican banking in the hands of Mexican investors.

Pennies and dimes from children wanting to help other children flowed into the The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

IT is as a Beethoven specialist that Wilhelm Kempff has made his greatest reputation, and last night the 70-year-old German pianist returned to Carnegie Hall with a program of three of Beethoven sonatas and his Bagatelles.
WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 10 -- -- Standardbreds from Down Under continued to fare well at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

DURHAM, N.C. Dec. 10 (AP) -- Duke's Blue Devils broke through the full-court press of first-ranked University of California. Los Angeles in the first half tonight and coasted to an 82-66 basketball victory.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference strengthened its hand in regulating the practices of its 144 members yesterday, particularly in the area of awarding and taking away scholarship help for athletes. By a vote of 79-14, with five colleges abstaining, the conference athletic directors voted to provide, where necessary, legislation to end practices contrary to the ideals of the E.C.A.C.

THE exhibition of 17 Polish painters at the D'Arcy Galleries, 1091 Madison Avenue at 82d Street, is described by the gallery as "comprehensive." Just how it can be comprehensive when it omits the two best contemporary Polish painters is a first question, even if we forget the second rank of first-raters who are also absent.
STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10 -- In a ceremony of pomp and splendor, three Americans, three Frenchmen, a Japanese and a Russian received Nobel Prizes for 1965 today.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 -- Japan's economic growth rate in fiscal 1964 ended March 31, 1965, was 11.2 per cent in real terms, which was below the previous year's figure of 11.9 per cent, a white paper on national income released by the Cabinet reported today.
