At approximately 4:30 P.M. today, loud-speakers at Aqueduct will announce, "the result of the ninth race is official." New York's 233-day thoroughbred racing season will be a past performance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Capt. Kurt Carlsen, who won fame by staying alone aboard his ship, the Flying Enterprise, after she split in two, has invented a reversible marine-propulsion system. Patent No. 3,225,732 will be granted to Captain Carlsen Dec. 28, 14 years after his ordeal in the Atlantic.
ESSEN, Germany -- Fried Krupp, thought to be the largest company anywhere owned by just one man, took a step toward public ownership today.

Britain's Prime Minister has turned a fateful corner in his war of nerves and economics against the illegal white minority regime in Rhodesia. Harold Wilson now says Britain will not negotiate with Prime Minister Ian Douglas Smith and his colleagues nor permit them to lead Rhodesia "after the return to constitutional rule." Hitherto, Mr. Wilson had been careful not to exclude the possibility of negotiations with Mr. Smith.

" Afrika Korps," "The Battle of the Bulge," "Blitzkrieg," "Midway" and "Waterloo," an authentic re-creation of Napoleon's "Most historical campaign," these are some of the games advertised as Christmas gifts in The New York Times.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Dick Barnett's 36 points and final-quarter heroics by Dave Stallworth, a rookie, guided the New York Knicks to a 109-106 triumph over the St. Louis Hawks tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- President de Gaulle will fire the first shot tomorrow in the campaign for the Presidential election runoff Dec. 19.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- The Air Force and astronomers said today that a fireball that streaked across the sky over the United States and Canada last night was a large meteor, or meteors, which probably burned up in the earth's atmosphere.

McGeorge Bundy was formally elected yesterday as president of the Ford Foundation.

NEWARK, Dec. 10 -A 42-year-old unemployed laborer returned home to his wife and three children in Joffre, Pa., today, cleared of a charge that had held him in Essex County jail for 29 days because his name was John Langston.

MADRID -- The long, black. shiny and soft hair of Spanish damsels -- celebrated in all these adjectives by poets from the conquering Moors to Federico Garcia Lorca -- is this nation's latest romantic contribution to the world.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 9 -- The immensity of the build-up in men and materials in Vietnam seems to have left many South Vietnamese wondering about their place in this new kind of war. South Vietnamese officials, unable to cope with the complexity of the new military, economic and social problems thrust upon them, are turning increasingly to the Americans for decisions.
A schoolgirl who witnessed a murder in the subway trembled in court yesterday as she hesitantly laid a finger on the shoulder of Christopher Lynch and identified him as the slayer.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The new job of Mrs. Herve Alphand, wife of the former French Ambassador to the United States, as directrice of Pierre Cardin's haute couture salon has caused much comment and some criticism.
The first suit resulting from the collision of two airliners over Westchester a week ago was filed yesterday in Federal Court here. It seeks $250,000 damages for one of the survivors.

Operations of the meat packing companies are being adversely affected by increased operating costs and a steady rise in pork price, according to the results of two of the three companies that issued annual reports yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Prime Minister Wilson declared today that his Government would not negotiate with the breakaway Rhodesian leaders and could not again trust them.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 10 -- President Johnson pressed officials of his Administration today to hold down their next years budgets because of higher defense expenditures expected for the war in Vietnam.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- The Actor's Workshop found itself in another crisis today and appealed for $50,000 "within the next few days." Otherwise, its leaders announced, the professional repertory company would have to abandon plans for its next production, Moliere's "Don Juan," and close its doors.
MADRID, Dec. 10 -- Policemen violently ejected hundreds of students from a Madrid University building today during a major demonstration against the regime.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- The United Nations celebrated the 17th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights today although many of the principles enshrined in the document still are non-existent in vast areas of the world.
FAIRFIELD, Ill., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Charles (Blackie) Harris, a Prohibition era gangster, was sentenced today to 60 to 75 years in prison for a double murder of which he was convicted Nov. 3.
BEDFORD, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- More than 300 persons crowded into a high school cafeteria last night to hear one of the John Birch Society's first public presentations in the metropolitan area.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Henry Richardson Labouisse, after six months as head of the United Nations Children's Fund, confesses that he continues to be amazed at the universal appeal of the agency devoted to helping needy youngsters.
A scholarly defense of Christopher Columbus as the true discover of the New World was offered last night by Italy's Foreign Minister, Amintore Fanfani.
Tribute came yesterday from all over the baseball world for Branch Rickey.
HONG KONG, Dec. 10 -- A 17-year-old United States sailor who had been reported missing from his ship returned to Hong Kong today after spending nine days in Communist China.

The Curtis Publishing Company said yesterday that it had formally contracted to sell 251,000 acres of mineral and timberland in Ontario and Pennsylvania to the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company for $24 million in cash.
Four Boston University undergraduates have decided to spend their junior year in rock 'n' roll.

The move to higher rates on individual savings accounts, which was touched off last Monday by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, reached New York's giant commercial banks yesterday -- though in limited fashion.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- A General Assembly committee voted 88 to 1 today to send back the controversy over peace-keeping operations to a special 33-member committee.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Seven states were elected today to nonpermanent seats on the newly expanded Security Council. After Jan. 1 the Council will have 15 members.

The New York Court of Claims is the forum in which lawsuits against the state are decided -- lawsuits frequently involving sums of such magnitude that, in legislation earlier this year, judges were made coequal in terms of pay and allowances with justices of the State Supreme Court.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 11-- Japan ratified today a treaty with South Korea establishing normal relations. The action ends 14 years of intermittent negotiation and controversy. The treaty and accompanying domestic legislation were passed by the upper house of the Diet, completing parliamentary action, by 136 to 0.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A detailed Congressional inquiry into the massive electric power failure in the Northeast Nov. 9 was promised today by the Senate Commerce Committee.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of fraud in labeling terrorism, guerrilla activity and subversion as wars of national liberation.

BONN, Dec. 10 -- The West German Government asserted today that Dr. Erich Apel, the East German economic planning chief who shot himself last Friday, had chosen suicide rather than bow to a Soviet ultimatum.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- An exceptionally high tide, whipped by gale-force winds, surged up the Thames today and threatened to flood the Houses of Parliament. Water seeped through the parapet on the terrace and basement rooms were cleared by the House of Commons staff.

Art Carney, Audrey Meadows and Jackie Gleason will be reunited on Jan. 8 in a one-hour musical version of "The Honeymooners" on the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network. They will recreate their roles in the domestic comedy series on "The Jackie Gleason Show" from 7:30 to 8:30 P.M.
Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the New Jersey Supreme Court called yesterday for a citizens' investigation to determine whether confessions are vital to law enforcement.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- New York City would lose four Senate and seven Assembly seats but would still retain its relative voting strength under a preliminary reapportionment plan being drafted by the Republicans.

THE sales desks of museums are a good source for a variety of items at Christmas time, including cards, calendars and engagement books. One of three unusual sets of greeting cards (for those dawdlers who have not yet bought any is the box of eight water-colors by American Indian artists that is sold by the Museum of the American Indian, Broadway and 155th Street.
Dr. Lawrence B. Hobson has been named director of the medical research department of the Schering Corporation.
Combat marines in Vietnam are playing Santa Claus to more than 700,000 refugees thanks to a fund-raising campaign by the Marine Corps Reserve.

Among many exceptional qualities possessed by Branch Rickey the most important was vision. He had the ability, rare in any field and all but nonexistent in baseball, of seeing clearly the shape of the future. To the world at large his most memorable achievement was breaking the color line by bringing Jackie Robinson into organized baseball in 1946 and up to the major leagues the next year. The dates are significant.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- A 24-inch water main burst in the Highland Park section here at 5:24 A.M., today, cutting off the water supply to about 90,000 persons, forcing the city's schools to close and undermining parts of two streets.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay was reported last night to have offered the post of Commissioner of Water, Gas and Electricity to Samuel S. Baxter, who now heads the Philadelphia water department.
The Baltimore Bullets will faca the New York Knickerbockers at the Garden tonight in a National Basketball Association game. It will be the fifth meeting between the rivals this season.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Uruguay's Government resolved tonight to break relations with the Soviet Union and take new steps to put an end to Communist subversion in this troubled country, a top Government official reported.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- A demonstration over United States policy in Vietnam broke out today at a major labor convention after Secretary of State Dean Rusk had ended a speech in which he reiterated the Government's determination to meet its commitments there.
The Delaware Memorial Bridge reported yesterday a traffic increase of 63,914 motor vehicles, or 6.1 per cent, last month over the November, 1964, volume of 1,019,472 units.
ATHENS, Dec 10 -- An army colonel was arrested today and charged with conspiracy as investigators pressed proceedings against Aspida, a secret political organization in the Greek Army.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Arthur Ashe of Richmond easily defeated young Ray Ruffels of Australia in straight sets today and qualified to meet the Wimbledon champion, Roy Emerson, for the South Australian singles tennis title.
The Pennzoil Company has received tenders for almost 5 million shares of the United Gas Corporation's common stock under its recent offer.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Archbishop William E. Cousins said today he would not punish a priest who participated in a Milwaukee public school boycott over racial segregation.
SELMA, Ala., Dec. 10 -- Three Selma businessmen were acquitted today of the murder of the Rev. James J. Reeb of Boston after voting rights demonstrations here last March.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced two-tenths of 1 per cent to 103.7 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Dec. 7, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices of farm products and processed foods increased, while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A trainload of gifts for the people of South Vietnam will be officially started on its journey to the West Coast Sunday in a ceremony that will include brief talks by Vice President Humphrey and Representative Gerald R. Ford Jr., Republican leader of the House.
Stockholders of the Jim Walter Corporation voted yesterday to approve a previously announced plan to acquire the Brentwood Financial Corporation for about $15 million in stock.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Atlanta Braves held their annual stockholders meeting today and it was a 17-minute session accompanied by a comedy of errors and the threat of a $2 million suit for alleged mismanagement.

During rehearsals he was instructed at one point in the first act to move over into the corner, and stand there with his back to the audience. On protesting, he was told it was traditional -- Caruso had always done it.

NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Dick Roth, a 17-year-old Stanford University freshman, was named world swimmer of the year today by Swimming World magazine.

Cargo traffic on the international section of the St. Lawrence Seaway has established a new seasonal record of 42.5 million tons. The record was announced last week by Joseph H. McCann, administrator of the St. Lawrence Seaway Corporation.
OTTAWA, Dec. 11 -- Poverty in Canada is a many-headed dragon. To destroy it may require many St. Georges.

BOTH of the major operatic components of this city are about to enter new phases of their existence, and their admirers wish them well. The Metropolitan Opera is currently playing its last season in the house it has inhabited since 1883, while the New York City Opera has already closed out its last season at the City Center.

MISSOULA, Mont. -- In President Johnson's view, life in the Great Society should include the wilderness as well as easy chairs. There are now more than 100,000 miles of hiking and riding trails in the national forests and parks. Mr. Johnson wants more.

Army's swimming team set two University Pool records and won nine of 11 events as it defeated Columbia, 62-33, yesterday afternoon in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet.
The National Trust for Historic Preservation has announced that 12 fellowships will be awarded for a seminar for historical administrators next summer.

I WAS appalled by the superficial, unauthentic, offensive review by John Tebbel of "The World of Swope" (Oct. 31). Even in the reviewer's own field of journalism, he fails to discern the greatness of Herbert Bayard Swope, who for 15 years was an editor who made The World a vital, esteemed, widely read paper -- a pattern for great journalism, and so acknowledged by all his professional colleagues.

JAMES BALDWIN'S collection of short stories invites little new comment because it contains little new work. Of the eight stories, five were published between 1948 and 1960, and none of the others was, I hope, written subsequently. The first two stories, "The Rockpile" and "The Outing," seem to be sketches for his first novel, "Go Tell It on the Mountain," published in 1953.
DALLAS, Dec. 11 -- A memorial to President Kennedy will be dedicated here early next year a few blocks from the spot where he was assassinated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A private committee of church, antipoverty and civil rights groups announced this week an ambitious plan to rehabilitate, with the backing of wealthy Washingtonians, hundreds of dilapidated apartment units in one of this city's worst slum areas.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -Every winter, this city attracts football fans, symphony and circus fans and people who are simply fans of Jacksonville. Now it is preparing to welcome even more.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Johnson's well-publicized shyness of foreigners is being shattered with a vengeance in the next ten days by the visits of three heads of Government bearing the burdens of three continents.

THE Douglas Aircraft Company brought its new baby airplane into La Guardia Airport last week to show off the latest in its long line of distinguished passenger craft, and the DC-9 obligingly added more luster to the family's reputation.
HARTFORD, Dec. 11 -- John M. Bailey, the Democratic National Chairman, returned home this week to try to put out a political fire in his own home town.

AMERICAN collectors "invading" the foreign coin field do not seem to be adopting the European method of collecting by type (one coin of each different kind). They show a strong preference for their own system of assembling a complete set of every date and mint-mark in a series.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 -- This capital's millions are muddling through, as best they can, a period of austerity decreed by their stabilization-minded Government.

BAHRAIN, a British-protected Arabian Gulf state which has had its postal affairs handled by India and then Britain, will take over its own postal operations on Jan. 1. The independent sultanate will note the occasion by issuing a 12-stamp definitive series.
During the next week or two some 400 companies will get letters from the Department of Commerce urging them to help the Government solve its international payments problem.

JOHN BROOK turns back the calendar to 19th-and early-20th-century softness and sentimentality in his show at Gallery 216, 216 East 75th Street. Style and attitude, rather than period affectation, characterize his work.

A Jesuit priest who was sent from New York to Latin America three weeks ago on a "routine assignment" said yesterday that the shift was actually a disciplinary measure for his involvement in the peace movement.
One of the oldest medical nursing orders in the world, the Sisters of the Third Order of St. Francis, will soon be using one of the most modern medical tools, the computer.

A Republican City Councilman accused the top Democratic Council command yesterday of seeking to "replenish the political pork barrel." The pork barrel, he said, now has a "void" resulting from the election as Mayor of Republican-Liberal John V. Lindsay.
Whoever is alive and drinking will get a look at himself in "High Sobriety," the musical to be presented by the Princeton University Triangle Club on Friday evening at the Ambassador Theater.
HOUSTON, Dec. 11 -- There was considerable speculation here this week about the future of The Houston Chronicle, which is to be taken over soon by John W. Mecom, Texas oilman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The White House is going to seem more like a giant revolving door next week than the place the President calls home. People will be spun in and out by the gross.

It is unfortunate that so eminent a scholar as C. Eric Lincoln ("The Absent Father Haunts the Negro Family," Nov. 28) has fallen into the trap that Dr. William Ryan describes in The Nation as "savage discovery."

IN the title of Elliott Nugent's autobiography, the word "comedy" is used ironically. For the "comedy" to which the preceding "events" lead up is an agonizing nervous disorder that put the author in a mental institution in 1951 when he was at the peak of his professional success.
I realize that when one is dealing with an expert so learned as John Leo, it is presumptuous to ask for proof of any sort ("The American Catholic Is Changing," Nov. 14).
NEW DELHI, Dec. 6 -- There had been no new ideas about the 18-year-old Kashmir issue for so long that when one finally came along it stirred a storm of controversy.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -A nonprofit corporation has been formed here to prepare needy Philadelphia youth for college and to help pay their tuition and college living costs.
The first St Christopher's Ball on Dec 21 at Delmonico's a white-tie supper dance, will benefit St. Christopher's School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

MAY I suggest that you invite Leon Edel to write a 3,000-word article enlarging on his extraordinary statement (Nov. 14) while reviewing Richard D. Altick's "Lives and Letters," that Philip Guedalla's "Bonnet and Shawl" is "a spoof and parody."

A civil engineer who became a salesman almost 40 years ago because he wanted a new challenge happily watched the company he now heads reach a corporate milestone last week by listing its shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 11 -- A new quarterly magazine, Cry California, has made its appearance as part of an expanded campaign of conservationists to fight destruction and pollution of the state's natural resources.

Since 1930, the proportion of Negroes living in cities has almost doubled. Negroes make up about one-tenth of the civilian labor force but they account for one-fifth of the unemployed and for one-quarter of those who are jobless for six months or longer. At the beginning of this year, nearly one Negro teen-ager in every three was out of school and out of work.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11 -- The 24-hour Daytona Continental, to be run over Daytona International Speedway's 3.81-mile course on Saturday and Sunday, Feb. 5 and 6, has many interesting facets.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho -- The mountains are the same, but the atmosphere of the West's first major ski resort is different. That is the initial reaction the returning vacationist has at this pleasant snow-country spa just up the highway from once rough, tough Ketchum and the Union Pacific branch line.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- A new concept of poverty in the sixcounty Chicago metropolitan area (total population 6,173,920) emerged this week from use of a sliding-scale method of counting the poor.

ABILENE, Tex., Dec. 11 (UPI) -- North Dakota State, the nation's No. 1 small-college football team, wrapped up the National Collegiate Athletic Association's midwest championship with a 20-7 victory over Grambling College today in the Pecan Bowl.

Stunning upsets marked the opening of the indoor schoolboy track season yesterday as DeWitt Clinton's star high jumper, Bill McClellon, wound up without the gold medal in the 12th annual Bishop Loughlin Games at the 168th Street Armory.
The Soviet Union has recently agreed to let Communist nations friendly to Russia enter the age of space research with the use of sputniks in orbit.

Mr. Hacker's article should be called "The Pill and Immorality" for it is a serious undermining of the JudeoChristian civilization in which we live. The immorality that he speaks of is contrary to the natural law, which comes to us from God.

TESTING, testing, testing -- this is the unsettling trend on television this season. There are nights when the responsible viewer cannot just sit there in the twilight zone of detachment -- half bemused, half asleep and totally relaxed.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The Government of Cyprus rejected today any attempt to return to the 1960 Constitution.

New concern with the cost of educating disadvantaged children has come as a shock to even the education-minded. School budgets are impersonal documents. It is only when the bill for the education of one child is examined that the real cost sinks in.

PARIS -- An American in Paris can do here what he would have trouble doing in New York -wander around the floor of the Stock Exchange. Here at the Bourse, as the French call their stock exchange, the visitor can experience free the sights and sounds, and the pushing and jabbing, of a heated, Gallic-style trading session.
A filmed look at 1,000 years of Jewish life in Poland -from start to finish, as its makers put it -- will open at the Cameo Theater on Jan. 31.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 11 -- The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club team defeated neighboring Port Washington Yacht Club, 342 3/4 to 332 1/2, today in a frostbite team race.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- The Port of Belgrade, counting on tonnage of 2.3 million this year, is attempting to become the largest and busiest harbor on Europe's longest waterway, the Danube.

Just to add the final note of madness and confusion to the Christmas rush at the bookstores, harried clerks now must deal with two books about the Kennedy Administration which have similar titles. One is Arthur M. Schlesinger's "A Thousand Days," which has just been published by Houghton Mifflin. The other is "The Thousand Days," a picture book assembled by John Raymond which Citadel brought out in the spring.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 11 -- Two Israeli scientists report that they have grown the leprosy bacillus in the laboratory. They said this was the first time it had been done.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 11 -- Not one of the 14 diplomatic missions here has shut down in the four weeks since Rhodesia's Government declared independence from Britain.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 11 -- North Carolina is moving, although with some reluctance, to reapportion both houses of the General Assembly and the state's 11 Congressional Districts ahead of a deadline of Jan. 31 set by a Federal Court.

Montage -- the arrangement of documentary materials drawn from diverse sources into an integrated whole to make a new, original statement -- is a time-honored form in photography and the fine arts and is being used increasingly in theatrical presentations.
ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- More than four months after the 2 per cent statewide sales tax went into effect, an uncertainty still remains about how much money the levy will produce.

The San Diego Chargers can wrap up their third consecutive Western Division championship of the American Football League at Houston today, but there's the strong possibility that another title would leave Coach Sid Gillman in his accustomed spot -- as a king without a crown.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11 -- The blue-water ocean racing season began today with sister 28-foot sloops finishing first and second in the annual Miami-Palm Beach competition.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Dec. 11 -- A group of 60 army officers, dissatisfied with the course of the Government's campaign to squash the rebellion among southern Sudanese who demand independence for their region, is reliably reported to have staged a serious mutiny recently.

THE tourist in the colorful Pennsylvania Dutch country with a hankering to mingle and even horse-trade with the natives need simply head a few miles east of Lancaster to New Holland, Pa. There, at the New Holland Sales Stables, livestock auctions are held every Monday, starting at 11 A.M. Miscellaneous items ranging from saddles to used typewriters are auctioned at the end of each sale.

IN the dim, dark past, when stereo records were new -- in 1958 -- sound effects were all the rage. Bowling balls were especially popular, if memory serves, but no self-respecting stereophile would be caught without a roaring thunderstorm in his living room, a ping-pong game, and maybe a steam engine or two.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 -- Joseph Byrd is a soft-spoken, scholarly young graduate student and teaching assistant at the University of California at Los Angeles who discusses most subjects with wry detachment. When he talks about the plight of the university student, however, his face registers passionate indignation.
Today's projected attempt by one manned spacecraft to take off from the ground and rendezvous with another marks the debut of maneuvers completely unfamiliar to man.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 12 -Richard Cardinal Cushing, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, told 700 persons in a Congregational church here today: "We've got to get all this Ecumenical spirit out of the hands of the scholars and get it down to the grass roots."

Erich Leinsdorf and the Boston Symphony Orchestra made their first Carnegie Hall appearance Saturday night, beginning the four-part survey of the symphonies and concertos of Brahms, which is to continue on three more Saturday nights, spaced six weeks apart, during the "Festival of Visiting Orchestras."
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (UPI) -Gale Sayers, who set all kinds of records in the Chicago Bears' 61-20 rout of the San Francisco 49ers today, broke another in the dressing room after the game.

By retaining Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes in his Cabinet, Mayor-elect Lindsay gives earnest of sticking to his promise that he will appoint the best man he can find, regardless of politics or past service with the Wagner Administration.

Damper than the breezes of Ballaghaderreen, the wind on 42d Street seeped into Canon James Hunt's old-fashioned suit and tugged at his thin, gray hair. The air -- or perhaps a touch of happiness -- brought a flush to the fine Irish landscape of his face.

MADRID, Dec. 12 -- Discussions aimed at the possible direct integration of Spain into the Western defense system are expected to be initiated here Thursday during a six-hour visit by Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler.

James L. Murnane, a Plattsburgh contractor, has been elected president of the General Building Contractors of New York State. The election was held at the association's annual meeting in Rochester.

WASHINGTON -- A roll-top desk dating back to 1887 sits in the office of Andrew Parker, president and chief executive officer of Woodward Lothrop, Inc. It was first used by Mr. Parker's grandfather, Samuel Walter Woodward a co-founder of the department store that has become an institution in the nation's capital.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Apparently it is easy to get people here to pay $50 each to support a worthy cause, but it is next to impossible to keep them quiet once they've done so.
HOUSTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Houston Astros dismissed Paul Richards as general manager today and named Grady Hatton manager in place of Luman Harris.
With all the flair of a salad chef tossing together a new dish, Emile Francis created the greatest shakeup of the National Hockey League season at Madison Square Garden last night.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Dec 12 -- Crop experts warned today that there is a danger that the Sudan will have to destroy nearly $2 million worth of sugar cane at a new development project in Khasm el Girba because of administrative delays in obtaining field equipment necessary for harvesting the crop.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Soviet Union is causing concern among Western defense organizations by using more and more of its merchant ships in a naval role, Jane's Fighting Ships said today.
Walter N. Thayer, president of The New York Herald Tribune, has been asked by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay to fill a major new city post, but he has declined.

THE lady is not a tramp. That, with unkind brevity, is the trouble with the Danish dancer Mette Honningen, who played the title role in the Royal Danish Ballet's production of Roland Petit's "Carmen" at the State Theater, Lincoln Center, yesterday afternoon. Miss Honningen was too ladylike.

THE Norsemen of the Viking Age, pirates, conquerors, explorers and settlers, were so remarkable a people that interest in them never flags. The recent furor over a 15th-century map purporting to show the location of Vinland is nothing out of the ordinary. Scholars, cranks and just interested bystanders have been writing and debating about the Vikings and Vinland for generations.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay discussed the contract demands of the Transit Workers Union yesterday with the three-man panel that he and Mayor Wagner have selected to mediate the stalled transit negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Republican Coordinating Committee meets tomorrow for an expected showdown on an anti-extremist resolution specifically mentioning the John Birch Society.
Fog, rain and wind disrupted traffic at La Guardia Airport yesterday and made driving hazardous in the suburbs.

The appointment of Jean Ordner as executive vice president and general manager of Renault, Inc., United States affiliate for the French-based automobile company, was announced over the weekend.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 -- Steel mills have doubts about 1966 but they now know that every important record will be broken in the present year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Council of Republican Organizations, supporting the Federal Reserve Board's increase in the discount rate, said today that the "accelerating pace of inflation" resulted from the "unsound spending policies of the Johnson Administration."
The Internal Revenue Service, aiming to make things as easy as possible for United States taxpayers, is now mailing out the first of its newly redesigned 1965 income tax forms.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP) -The Soviet Union charged today that Communist China's leaders had refused to cooperate with the world Communist movement to defeat the United Sates in Vietnam.

Stuart Cloete's letter in your Nov. 30 issue supporting the white Rhodesian regime prompts a comment.
A graduated city income tax, with the rich paying a higher percentage than the poor, might drive rich people out of the city, an expert in municipal fiscal affairs contends.

Bill Lanigan won the senior men's trophy in the Middle Atlantic speed skating championships at the Riverdale Rink last night. He took all four events -- the half-mile, three-quarter mile, mile and two-mile.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -Earl Morrall and Homer Jones proved the Giants knew how to pass against the Washington Redskins today as they combined for touchdown pass plays of 74 and 72 yards.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 12 -- Gary Cuozzo, young and impetuous, tried to fool the Green Bay defense, mature and disciplined, but failed today when Dave Robinson intercepted the Baltimore quarterback's little flip pass and ran 88 yards.

Henry T. Heald, president of the Ford Foundation, said yesterday that he would become a partner in a new organization designed to advise educational and research institutions on their special managerial and policy problems.
OTTAWA -- The attitude of the Canadian Government toward its reserves of foreign exchange has taken a more liberal turn in recent weeks, with benefits for the United States balance of payments.

" As retailers, we can't do business on the basis of American chauvinism, David L. Yunich, president of Macy's New York, said the other day. "I am planning to see Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor soon to make him aware that retailers are, apparently paying no attention to the Government's increased emphasis on voluntary restraints in foreign investments," David Zelinka, president of Zelinka-Matlich, Inc., declared recently.

Air cargo shipments in the New York area, most of which move through Newark and John F. Kennedy International Airports, have increased more than 32 per cent over last year, the Port of New York Authority announced last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -New York Congressional Democrats of the class of '64 are suffering a severe case of freshman jitters.

A $63 million, seven-block-long pollution-control plant to be built in the Hudson River is nearing design completion and has set off a controversy among the city's planners and administrators. The plant, a major element in the billion-dollar clean-up of the river, will cover 2.5 acres.

" Jane's Fighting Ships," edited by Raymond V.B. Blackman, will be published today by McGraw-Hill. It will be issued simultaneously in England by Sampson Low, Marton Co. The book contains 461 pages of pictures and description of the warships of the world and a 16-page index.
David Ogilvy, the founder and chairman of Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., has decided, in his words, "to go to work in the kitchen."

The United Jewish Appeal set a goal of $73,420,000 yesterday to meet Jewish needs throughout the world, with special emphasis on aid for 200,000 people who have migrated to Israel from North Africa and Asia.

Two more leading toy manufacturers have signed leases for showroom and sales space in the 29-story office building to be erected at Two Pennsylvania Plaza, adjoining the new Madison Square Garden Sports and Entertainment Center.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -New York retained the Lockett Cup by defeating Philadelphia, 5-2, today in the Class A round-robin squash racquets matches at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 12 -- Pete Bostwick, the national amateur court tennis champion and his brother, Jimmy, the 1964 titleholder, helped to score two victories for New York today, but Philadelphia won the Payne Whitney Memorial doubles tournament for the second year in a row.
State Senator Jerome L. Wilson predicted yesterday that proposals to change the state's 178-year-old divorce law would be in "deep trouble" if opposed by the Roman Catholic Church.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- A Greyhound bus on the way to New Orleans went out of control on a rain-slick high-way near here in pre-dawn darkness today, killing the driver and three passengers.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 12 -The New York Jets bounced back from a 14-point deficit against Oakland in a muddy American Football League game today. But the Raiders kept the pressure on young Joe Namath and rallied in the fourth quarter for a 24-14 triumph.

HOUSTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -The San Diego Chargers put on two long fourth-quarter scoring drives to whip the Houston Oilers, 37-26, today and clinch the American Football League's Western Division championship.

Governor Rockefeller, voicing alarm at the number of first offenders who return to crime, assigned a committee of experts yesterday to develop "imaginative new approaches" to the problem in time for consideration by the next Legislature.
BENCAT, South Vietnam, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Hatchets used like tomahawks replaced bayonets in the hands of some G.I.'s today in a hand-to-hand jungle fight.
WARSAW, Dec. 12 -- Poland will move with considerable caution in the next two years into major revisions of her centralized Communist economy, a highly influential economist said here today.

Anna Magnani, winner of the 1955 Academy Award for her performance in "The Rose Tattoo," will make her American stage debut in the Italian-language production of "La Lupa" ("The She-Wolf") under Franco Zeffirelli's direction.

Disappearing in mist-shrouded Memorial Stadium was the first-place lead the Baltimore Colts had brought into this eerie setting. It wasn't the fog that made it vanish, though. It was the hard-striking, green-shirted legion from the Wisconsin wilds.
The Regional Plan Association urged New Jersey yesterday to ask the voters to approve a $150 million bond issue next year to help revitalize the state's commuter railroads.

Container shipping holds great promise for the Port of New York, according to the Port of New York Authority, which described the operation as the most significant development in trans-Atlantic transporation by sea in a century.

The line is now forming for the position of No. 1 college basketball team. MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 12 -- Uruguay's dominant Blanco party, unable to settle growing labor unrest, warned union leaders today that it might impose tough measures that could involve military action.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 12 -- Despite an appeal by Zambia to reconsider her stand, Tanzania is determined to break relations with Britain on Wednesday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia. Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Three renegade army officers and three fugitive Communists were killed by army commandos Thursday in an ambush in central Java. Antara, the official press agency, reported today.

BUFFALO, Dec. 12 (UPI) -Jackie Kemp threw two touchdown passes to Bo Roberson and one to Ed Rutkowski today as the Buffalo Bills scored a 34-25 American Football League victory over the Kansas City Chiefs. The pass to Rutkowski in the final 3 1/2 minutes put the game out of reach of the rallying Chiefs.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- A United Nations "good neighbor" committee is being organized to try to smooth relations with New York City and the United States.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 12 -- The United States Air Force resumed bombing of North Vietnam today after a two-day pause that official spokesmen attributed solely to bad weather.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -The Hatch Act prohibition on political activity by Federal civil service employes is under the most concerted legal attack in its 26-year history.
GRANITE QUARRY, N.C., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Grady B. Mars, No. 2 man in the North Carolina realm of the United Klans of America, was fatally shot at his home here last night.

WHAT can be served as an appetizer, hors d'oeuvre or main course at luncheon and supper? The answer many hostesses give is quiche Lorraine, the cream-rich hot custard pie flavored with cheese and bacon or ham.

Original documents signed by President John Adams and Secretary of State Timothy Pickering are among 25 Customs clearance papers, ration letters for meat during the French Revolution, and three log books of King William IV of England on display at the Seamen's Church Institute Marine museum, 25 South Street.

Benjamin Franklin told how a kingdom was lost for want of a nail. Yesterday morning, the failure of a small electrical plug to remain in its socket forced a last-second abortion of the scheduled Gemini 6 flight intended to achieve a rendezvous with Gemini 7.

As stated in your Dec. 4 editorial "Back to Sixth Avenue" Councilman Paul O'Dwyer is going to propose the eradication of the name Avenue of the Americas. This name, which for 20 years has been a tribute to the nations south of the Rio Grande, has no meaning for Mr. O'Dwyer.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- A bid for the British Diners' Club by the Westminster Bank reflects a growing involvement by banks on both sides of the Atlantic in the credit-card business.
Whatever else is new about the Great Society, obviously its politics are financed in the same old way.
The city will expand its use of Methadone for the treatment of narcotics addicts when it opens today the first of a series of clinics in municipal hospitals.

Claramae Turner, a contralto whose appearance in concert and opera and on radio and television over the last 20 years have made her familiar to a large segment of the American musical public, appeared in Town Hall yesterday afternoon to make her New York recital debut.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Moves to curb the sale of imported novelty drink coolers have spread to five states after tests showed that some of the products contained contaminated water.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- For the second time in six months, integrationists have asked the United States Office of Education to withhold $32 million in Federal funds from Chicago public schools.
The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken called on churchgoers yesterday to think twice before denouncing the "God is dead" school of theology.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- President de Gaulle took a day off today from active election campaigning, but his opponent, Francois Mitterrand, stayed on the warpath with a fierce assault on the President's domestic and foreign policies.

One does not need to look at the calendar or into the faces of children to know that the gift-giving season is approaching fast. There is sufficient evidence in the deluge of requests for charitable contributions.

The bond market is entering its last crucial week of 1965. Two $100 million bond issues -- one corporate and one tax-exempt -- will give the market a good chance to settle on a going rate schedule until after the holidays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -President Johnson is plunging into world diplomacy Tuesday with a most unusual and delicate conference -- one that could restore or destroy a once promising relationship with Pakistan.
THE Tapemeasure has stretched out from Lexington Avenue to Fifth and expects to reach the Philadelphia environs soon.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A gang of burglars got away with antique silver worth $140,000 today in the latest of a series of such crimes.

BANICA, Dominican Republic, Dec. 12 -- A young New Yorker who started his Peace Corps assignment in the Dominican Republic undeterred by the civil war is busy today persuading this remote village that it needs a larger and better schoolhouse.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 12 -President Johnson expressed disappointment today that the Gemini 6 launching did not go off on schedule.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler said today that the recent increase in interest rates in the United States would probably not help to stem the flow of dollars abroad.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The International Coffee Council voted today to avoid a showdown on basic quota revisions and production goals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Ambassador to South Vietnam, declared today that the Communist world had "lost hope of a military victory." He predicted harder United States air strikes against North Vietnam.

President Johnson's alma mater, Southwest Texas State College, appeared on "College Bowl" for the first time yesterday and was defeated by Earlham College (Richmond, Ind.) by a score of 380 to 30. It was the third win in a row for Earlham.
It appears that some confusion has arisen over the news account which appeared in The Times of Nov. 29 regarding the clergy conference.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Lakers routed the St. Louis Hawks for the second straight time tonight, 123-101, and extended their Western Division lead to 3 1/2 games in the National Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Manufacturers' sales increased 10 per cent and their profits rose 16 per cent in the July-September period, compared with results for the third quarter of 1964, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported over the weekend.

PARIS -- One of France's largest nationalized banks is now backing Andre Courreges, the designer, in his ready-to-wear operation. A spokesman for Mr. Courreges confirmed a report today that a subsidiary of the B.N.C.I. (Banque Nationale pour le Commerce et Industrie) owns 45 per cent of the company set up by the designer.

DILI, Portuguese Timor, Dec. 13 -- Neglected for centuries, this remote, impoverished Portuguese territory on the eastern part of the eastermost island of the main Indonesian archipelago is getting special attention from Lisbon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -Organized medicine and the Johnson Administration are quietly working toward possible compromises on sensitive issues involving doctor-patient relationships under the new Medicare law.

This advertisement in the help-wanted columns of The New York Times three months ago began the operations here of the Revitalization Corps, a privately sponsored operation that tries to help the under-privileged by "involving the man in the street in good works."

The recent collision of two aircraft north of the city will probably result in speeding up the installation of safety equipment here, Oscar Bakke, eastern regional director of the Federal Aviation Agency, said yesterday.
Sam Graham, small and dapper in a pale blue, pleated shirt with a roll collar and a black-bordered indigo tie, stood amid chaos yesterday in the jammed back room of his restaurant.

Private owners of beautiful wild land in the metropolitan area are being urged to follow the "initiative, altruism and enlightened self-interest" of others who have helped to preserve open land for posterity.
THROUGH the glass portals at Charles of the Ritz-Vidal Sassoon where all those little-boy hairdos take shape, a silvery head over a silvery mink coat slipped in quietly one day last week.

The Federal Communications Commission will give formal consideration this week to requests from radio broadcasters seeking exemption from a proposed rule that their FM stations must cease duplicating AM programs by 50 per cent. There is now no restriction.
High-ranking Democrats expect Anthony J. Travia, Moses M. Weinstein and Joseph Zaretzki to be retained in top leadership posts in the Legislature.

David Oistrakh has appeared in New York so frequently during the past two months that he is fast becoming one of the most familiar figures on our concert stages. It is clear, however, that the popularity of the Russian violinist is not waning. For the recital he gave at Hunter College on Saturday night chairs had to be placed on the stage to accommodate the overflow audience.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Home construction, which has been declining for two years, will turn modestly upward in 1966, the Commerce Department forecast today.
HOUSTON, Dec. 12 -- Astronauts on Gemini spaceships have escape devices designed to protect them even if their rockets should blow up during launching. Only they can work the devices.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Dec. 12 Prof. Paul A.M. Dirac. British physicist and Nobel laureate, has been appointed Visiting Distinguished Professor of Theoretical Physics at the State University center here.

The great money mystery -- subtitled "Why Are People Carrying So Much More Cash Around in Their Pockets These Days?" -- is continuing to intrigue Federal Reserve officials, who are frank to admit that they don't have the answer.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. INDEPENDENCE, at Sea, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- A jet fighter's fuel tank ruptured as it roared off this huge aircraft carrier today, spewing flames over the deck and injuring 15 sailors returning from duty off Vietnam.

Representative Richard L. Ottinger denounced yesterday Mayor Wagner's plan to obtain water for the city from the pumped-storage reservoir that the Consolidated Edison Company proposed to build atop Storm King Mountain.

If past performance is a guide, the Joint Economic Committee's new investigation of Federal Reserve-Administration relations will get bogged down debating the pros and cons of the latest policy decision of the money managers, neglecting the far more important issue of whether the latter should be making their decisions independently.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- Two Soviet astronauts who had trained only three months for their orbital flight experienced an eerie "space sickness" during the mission, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.
Mayor Wagner will sign an executive order today directing that at least 1/200th of the construction costs of new city buildings be allocated to the fine arts.

PENNSAUKEN, N.J., Dec. 11 -- Ch. Merry Rover of Valley Run, a 4 1/2-year-old English setter owned by Mrs. George Abbott of Worcester, Mass., and Mrs. Charles Vanburen of New Canaan, Conn., proved to be one in a thousand dogs today as he took the best-in-show honors at the 33d annual Camden County Kennel Club fixture.
Two patrolmen were injured yesterday subduing a longshoreman accused of breaking into a medical supply store at Broadway and 92d Street. The police said the man had gone berserk.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 12 -- Yale University announced today that it had acquired two large collections of primitive art from New Guinea, where cannibals and headhunters still roam in Stone Age isolation.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- A priest talked a young pacifist into ending a fast today.

The national board of the American Veterans Committee called upon Congress yesterday to amend the Selective Service Act "to make it mandatory for local draft boards to be representative of their entire communities."
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -Gale Sayers scored six touchdowns today, raising his season total to 21 -- a National Football League record -- as the Chicago Bears routed the San Francisco 49ers, 61-20.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 --- The United States, which has been trying for a year to get other nations to contribute to the Vietnam war effort, is disappointed at what officials describe as a relatively cold response.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 12 -- President Kenyatta vigorously denounced Prime Minister Smith of Rhodesia today for having seized independence from Britain to prevent the political advancement of Rhodesia's black majority.
QUESON, South Vietnam, Dec. 12 -- United States marines moved into the foothills of Quangtin Province today in pursuit of a Vietcong force of several thousand men.
Argentina is smoldering. In any Latin-American country, when the military leaders are at odds with the civilians, there is the threat of a coup d'etat.

LAWRENCE ROSLER of Murray Hill, N.J., national men's pair champion, who is a research physicist, is one of the younger generation of American bridge experts. He is married to the former Rochelle Auritt, whom he met as an opponent in this year's Eastern regional tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -When the power blackout hit the Northeast Nov. 9, officials in several upstate New York school districts put in hurried telephone calls to Washington.
BOSTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The 15th three-goal performance of Gordie Howe's career tonight paced the streaking Detroit Red Wings to a 5-3 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins.

DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP) -Fran Tarkenton threw two touchdown passes in the first half and Ed Sharockman ran 40 yards with an interception for the only score of the second half today as the Minnesota Vikings posted a 29-7 National Football League victory over the Detroit Lions.
COCHITI, N.M., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The $50 million, five-year Cochiti Dam project received the blessing today of the Indians of Cochiti Pueblo.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- North Vietnamese military leaders called on their troops today to stiffen their fight against the United States in Vietnam. The Vietcong guerrillas of the South pledged anew a fight to the end to drive the American forces out.
MANZANO, N.M., Dec. 12 (AP) -- A search was started tonight for eight Peace Corps trainees who were overdue on a three-day hike through the rugged Manzano Mountains.

Dr. Karl Burger of Brooklyn was the only winner in the first session of the first round of the United States chess championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel last night. He defeated Duncan Suttles of Vancouver, B.C., who overlooked a pawn on the black side of a trappy variation of a Grunfeld Defense.

The Duke Ellington Chamber Ensemble made its debut yesterday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall, and introduced a new Ellington work composed for the occasion. The concert was the second in a series, "Great Performers at Philharmonic Hall," and the first in which jazz musicians were heard.

Donations from college students -- one in honor of the Vietnamese war dead, a second in memory of a friend who died in an accident and a third to help a deserving child go to college -- were received yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The United States Navy has completed tests on a revolutionary new airport concept employing a completely circular runway.

Bruno Hoffman, by his own admission the leading virtuoso on the glass harmonica (or glass harp, as he calls it) since the blind Marianne Kirchgessner died in 1808, gave a concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

The Walgreen Company, which operates 479 drug stores, eight Globe self service department stores and six Danburg junior department stores, achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 64-year history in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the report disclosed yesterday.
If the informal luncheon at which Theodore L. Bates played host to the trade press yesterday could be called a news conference, it was his first since founding Ted Bates Co., Inc., 25 years ago.
The purchase of a giant advanced computer system that can run every facet of the airline business is expected to be announced today by United Air Lines, Inc., the nation's largest air carrier.

The New York Knickerbockers, with a four-game home-court winning streak, will match fast-breaking styles with the San Francisco Warriors in the feature game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight.

DEARBORN, Mich., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The Ford Motor Company, which started from scratch in racing three years, ago and captured the Indianapolis 500-mile race this year, announced tonight that it intended to go into the stock-car racing field.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- "You treat them exactly as if they were guests in your home," said Mrs. Mary Farr Wilroy, the manager of Blair House, as she went about preparation for the arrival here of President Mohammed Ayub Khan of Pakistan and his party of 10 Cabinet min isters and dignitaries.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Charlie Baltazar, who had four doubles last week, rode four winners today at the Pimlico race track.
THE New York Giants lost one pass receiver to the injured list yesterday, but gained two others from the same source for this Sunday's game here against the Dallas Cowboys.
ROME, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Vatican experts today pried open the tomb of Queen Christine of Sweden, the only woman buried in the grottoes under St. Peter's Cathedral, to permit a death mask to be taken.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Britain proposed today the immediate establishment of a small committee of delegates of "the highest reputation and eminence" to seek ways to settle disputes before they erupt into violence.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 13 -- A Norwegian explorer said today that the only reason Leif Ericson's Viking band had failed to capitalize on its discovery of the New World was that, unlike Columbus's crew, it had had only bows and arrows instead of muskets.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Ali the leading prizes of the third Paris international dance festival, presented on stage at the Champs-Elysees theater last night, went to the Kirov Ballet from Leningrad.
In James Reston's Dec. 7 report on his interview with Soviet Premier Kosygin, the latter was quoted as saying:
Volume on the American Stock Exchange boomed yesterday to a new yearly record of 490,214,088 shares, thereby toppling the record turnover of 488,831,037 shares in 1961.

The 15-story Park Avenue apartment house in which the late Helena Rubenstein had a sumptuous 27-room triplex apartment has been sold by her estate to a group of investors for cash over mortgages of $2.45 million.

THERE is a little shop on Third Avenue and 29th Street that could put up a sign reading "For Men Only" and accurately spell out its customers, except that on occasion -- usually on Saturday -- women do enter the door. They also buy, but mostly for their husbands or friends.

QUESON, South Vietnam, Dec. 13 -- United States marines, moving doggedly ahead today under a searing sun, pushed into a valley where they had expected to find at least three battalions of Communist guerillas.
Trading on the London Stock Exchange was restrained yesterday as the market awaited today's announcement of British foreign-trade returns for November.

" The Cheerful Prospect: A Statement on the Future of American Education," by Charles S. Benson, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Jan. 6. The author is associate professor of education at the University of California, Berkeley.
TRENTON, Dec. 13 -- A half century of Republican domination of the Legislature ended this evening when the party's lame-duck majority in the Senate and Assembly adjourned for the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The president of the American Bankers Association said today that the dual banking system was in danger because state regulation is too weak, two of the three Federal regulatory agencies too slow and the third too unrestrained.

The National Basketball Association's president, Walter Kennedy, approved the contract of Woody Sauldsberry with the Boston Celtics yesterday after receiving assurance from the Celtics that they would meet "certain conditions."
ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Republican Assemblymen ousted George L. Ingalls of Binghamton as their minority leader today and replaced him with Perry B. Duryea Jr. of Montauk.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind. Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Nick Pino, a 7-foot-1-inch 270-pounder, poured in 27 points and grabbed 23 rebounds to lead Kansas State to a 103-76 victory over Indiana tonight.

WHEN Paul Hornung left the shadows of the Golden Dome at Notre Dame to become a member of the Green Bay Packers, he didn't always act with a wisdom compatible with his intelligence. Cynical old-timers on the Packers refused to accept his nickname of Golden Boy. They preferred the more derisive one of "The Golden Dome."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule whether the New England Electric System, a holding company, must divest itself of gas utility companies in Massachusetts as ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A corporate executive who is said to be a long-time friend of President Johnson suggested yesterday that the Government form a businessmen's committee to pass on capital exports, should the voluntary restraint program on overseas investments fail.
A group of 30 Negro Democratic politicians have banded together to serve notice on their party that they are expecting more power for Negroes in the Democratic organization in the left and the state.
A public hearing on the bootleg recording business will be held Thursday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Dr. W. Randolph Lovelace 2d, director of space medicine for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, was reported missing today on a private plane flight from Aspen, Colo., to Albuquerque.

The public showed only desultory interest yesterday as the City Planning Commission opened three days of public hearings on its proposed $578.2 million capital budget for 1966-67. Fewer than 50 persons were on hand at City Hall as the hearings began.
THERE probably is a right way and a wrong way to coach a college basketball team. But John Bach, Ford-ham's coach, yesterday painted a picture that makes it hard to determine which is which.
Bronx Borough President Joseph Periconi yesterday asked his successor, Herman Badillo, to join him at an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate next week.
BONN, Dec. 13 -- Heinz Nordhoff, director of the Volkswagen company, met with Economics Minister Kurte Schmucker here today amid rumors that V.W. was considering a price rise of up to $60 per model.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Supreme Court left standing today a New York ruling that banned voluntary recitation of a nursery prayer in public schools.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Army basketball team almost dissipated a 15-point lead today but held on to withstand a late surge by Corenl land post a 76-74 victory.

DECORATING BOOKS published this year are being given prominent display in the bookshops these days as the holidays focus attention on the house -- and they are as bright and cheerful as Christmas tinsel.

Cadets and midshipmen from the Air Force, Army and Navy academies will escort the young women who will be presented Dec. 29 at the International Debutante Ball. The event at the Astor will benefit the Kidney Foundation of New York Inc. which supports medical-center research.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- The president of the American Farm Bureau Federation said in effect today that American farm technology should be supplied to other countries only as a means of sowing capitalism and weeding out socialism.

MANZANO, N.M., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Eight Peace Corps trainees were found safe at an unoccupied ranch house today after their disappearance on a four-day hike had led to a search of the rugged Manzano Mountains of central New Mexico.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) The Air Transport Association said today the airline industry had adopted a "family" of four basic standard containers for air freight.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Attorneys for Duane Pope, convicted bank robbery killer, filed dual motions in Federal District Court today, asking for both a new trial and reduction of Pope's sentence from death to life imprisonment.
The reassignment of Rear Adm. John H. McQuilkin, commander of the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn, as commanding officer of the San Francisco Naval Shipyard was announced here yesterday.
Arnold Palmer plans to step up his tournament schedule next year in an effort to regain his former position as the No. 1 man in professional golf.

WERE there such a thing as a "Catholic novel," I would feel among the blessed to avoid it. For the descriptive tag implies that some central portion of the author's concern lies inert in his book; I must be trusted to reach and vivify it with my own shared belief or interest. Similarly, were Zola's "Germinal" merely a proletarian novel, it would be thin stuff.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The conflicting opinions of two Federal courts over the validity of New York State's language voting requirement have the rare virtue of presenting the Supreme Court with a clear-cut legal issue.
Steel production rose 2.5 per cent last week -- the fourth advance in five weeks -- the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

With reference to your Dec. 1 editorial "Portents" this "north countryman" begs to inquire -- what general store -- what stove -- and who was (is) sitting around where? Those your writer evidently refers to have long since become ladies' gift-fashion emporiums or serf-service cart alleys in which a cat would find trouble finding a corner in which to nap.

John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has cautioned that the nation's public and private institutions are in danger of falling under the leadership of men who lack the confidence to lead.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The wave of jewel and precious-metals robberies in London continued today with a daring daylight raid on the Government Assay Office in the capital's financial center.

ELIZABETH, N.J. Dec. 13 -- A touching note to Santa Claus from a 5-year-old Canadian boy was found today tied to a Christmas tree, one of several score bundles purchased by Edward Ward of 310 Rahway Avenue for retail sale here.

HONOLULU -- When the average mainlander arrives for an initial stay in Hawaii, he may have preconceived notions that most restaurants will offer such romantic fare as one-finger poi, two-finger poi, imu pig, lomi salmon and laulaus.
MIAMI, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Bright View Farm's Glassell B., the favorite, moved to the lead on the stretch turn and drew away to score an easy victory today in the feature race at Tropical Park.

Adlai E. Stevenson still supported United States foreign policy shortly before his death and was not on the point of resigning as Ambassador to the United Nations, according to Clayton Fritchey, who was his special assistant at the United Nations.

The Metropolitan Opera introduced a splendid new Lucia last night in Donizetti's "Lucia de Lammermoor." She is Renata Scotto, the Italian soprano who made a successful Metropolitan debut less than two months ago in an entirely different kind of role, that of Cio-Cio San in "Madama Butterfly."
At the outbreak of the Korean conflict in June, 1950, General Bliss, who became surgeon general in 1947, had to build up the Army Medical Corps, which had dwindled to about 2,700 doctors.

A new effort opens this week to come to terms with the nuclear deadlock that is sapping the foundations of NATO at a time when General de Gaulle is preparing additional blows against its superstructure. Today's ministerial meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Paris will be followed by Prime Minister Wilson's arrival in Washington Thursday and talks between Chancellor Erhard and President Johnson immediately afterward.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Supreme Court extended its broad consideration of confessions problems today by agreeing to rule on the constitutional rights of convicts who are being questioned by the police.

President Ayub Khan of Pakistan made an eloquent plea for self-determination, for negotiation or arbitration of the Kashmir dispute when he spoke before the United Nations General Assembly yesterday. Since the U.N. has tried over the years to induce India to agree to a plebiscite on Kashmir -- thus far a vain effort -- Marshal Ayub doubtless counted on a sympathetic hearing.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Britain's difficulties in trying to mount an overseas sales offensive were dramatically emphasized during a barrage of questions in the House of Commons today.

A record billion-dollar expense budget was requested yesterday by Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the city's Superintendent of Schools, to help move the system closer to its goal of "excellence in education."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court authorized Louisiana and the United States today to divide some $200 million of royalties accumulated in the 17-year-old litigation over offshore oil.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 13 -- The fuss over Rhodesian independence has not got in the way of Santa Claus.
The incoming Lindsay administration is establishing a panel of physicians to advise the Department of Hospitals and to improve hospital care.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Mexico's nationalized electric-power industry is borrowing $20 million through an issue of unit-of-account bonds -- the first issue of unit bonds since May, 1964, and the largest to date.

SAIGON, Dec. 13 -- South Vietnamese infantrymen killed 154 Vietcong guerrillas yesterday in a battle among the rice paddies and canals of Vinhbinh Province in the Mekong Delta 75 miles south of Saigon, a military spokesman said today.
Directors of the Fluor Corporation proposed a two-for-one split yesterday of the company's 976,471 common shares.
MONTREAL, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway Authority informed shipping companies today that the system between Montreal and Lake Ontario would remain open until Wednesday.

Old age, a broken home, crippling disease, death of the family breadwinner -- some such unfortunate circumstance underlies each of the Hundred Neediest Cases for which The Times traditionally seeks help at this holiday time of the year. In most instances something can be done to relieve the socially enervating situation or to cope reasonably well with its inevitable continued existence.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay held an impromptu but wide-ranging news conference yesterday in which he said that he "probably" would consolidate some city departments by executive order shortly after he takes office.
AT Craig Craeley, the Seventh Avenue casual-dress house where Patricia Ashley has worked for five years, a "good" dress is reproduced 1,000 times, a "great" one 10,000 times.

JUST in time for holiday entertaining comes a new country-style, coarse textured pate of rabbit made from fresh rabbit meat, pork and pork fat well seasoned with parsley, garlic, bay leaf and thyme. The pate slices easily and would make an appetizing first course for company dinners and sup pers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today set April 20 as the new date for opening hearings on petitions by three railroad companies for inclusion in the already approved merger of the Norfolk Western Railway and the Nickel Plate Railroad.
A new force of 300 Transit Authority policemen began a campaign yesterday to curb rowdyism among students on their way home from school.

As a Southerner who has worked for more than thirty years in the civil rights arena I wish I could feel optimistic regarding the movement now under way to reform the jury system and thus to provide a more just administration of justice in racial cases in the Deep South.

A circuit of three large former movie theaters has been established by Harry Brandt, head of an extensive chain of film houses, to present stage attractions at prices ranging from $1.25 to $1.75 on a first come, first served basis.
United States shipyards can reactivate 300 merchant vessels within the next four and a half months for use on the Vietnam Supply routes, according to the Shipbuilders Council of America.

James J. Saxon, the Controller of the Currency, who regulates the nation's 4.800 national banks, approved yesterday the conversion of the $35 million Euclid (Ohio) Savings Association into a national bank. Informed bankers said the move could prove to be a harbinger of more such conversions.

A 5-week-old boy who stopped breathing as he lay in his mother's arms on a crosstown bus was saved last night by the bus driver, a Fire Department captain, two firemen, a battalion chief and doctors at Vanderbilt Clinic in Presbyterian Medical Center.
WHO says animals and birds aren't like people? The more this wildlife catcher observes, the more I tend to suspect that maybe they're really people in different shapes. Who knows ?

Urban America, Inc., and the Action Council for Better Cities, private city planning groups operating on a national scale, have merged under the name of Urban America. Action is relinquishing its name because it has found that it is too often confused with community "action" groups engaged in antipoverty programs.
In commodity futures trading yesterday, grain contracts harvested a crop of record seasonal prices. All wheat and corn deliveries set new highs, as did most soybean contracts.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- President de Gaulle and Francois Mitterrand resumed their duel before television cameras tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Merger fever has gripped the City of London.
DETROIT, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The late Dr. Albert Schweitzer was criticized by Under Secretary for African Affairs G. Mennen Williams and his wife, Nancy, today for the way he operated his African clinic.
Howard M. Lang, managing director of South Pacific operations for the Diners' Club, has been named a corporate vice president.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Four Air Force officers completed a two-month simulated space flight helium atmosphere rest today, emerging from a large space chamber at the School of Aerospace Medicine.
Sales of new cars by the General Motors Corporation fell almost 6 per cent in the first 10 days of December, according to figures released yesterday by the company's auto divisions.
BOSTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Don Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, scored a surprise 12-round split-decision victory over Joey Archer tonight at the Boston Garden.

Representatives of 30 taxi fleet owners and spokesmen for the Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee agreed yesterday to meet today with Mayor Wagner to discuss their dispute on whether to begin contract negotiations.

This senseless, hopeless Vietnam war tarnishes our good name. We escalate endlessly to avoid admitting past and present errors. The end is nowhere in sight and soon we may find ourselves at war with China.
William E. Quigley, vice president and controller of the Anaconda Company since 1961, has been elected to the new post of vice president for finance, the company announced yesterday.
The stock market opened firm yesterday, but weakened later in the session. At the close of trading, results were mixed.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The Rhodesia and Vietnam questions, but not the Western alliance's integral problems, are on the agenda for the meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's ministers tomorrow.
Controller-elect Mario A. Procaccino suggested yesterday that Charles A. Buckley, the crusty long-time Democratic leader in the Bronx, retire for the sake of party harmony.

ROSIORII-DE-VEDE, Rumania, Dec. 12 -- From this muddy town in the Walachian plain the prospects for Rumanian farming do not appear very bright, despite the declaration of the Communist leadership last month that improvements are coming.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- The Soviet Government opened a fence-mending offensive today in welcoming to Moscow the President of Algeria, Houari Boumediene, the man who overthrew Russia's great friend in the Arab world, Ahmed Ben Bella.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Bob Lloyd of Rutgers, a junior, scored 30 points and dribbled away the final minutes as the Knights beat Princeton, 68-66, tonight for the first time in their last 18 meetings.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The White House has decked its halls with holly, mistletoe, garlands and evergreen trees, including an 18-foot fir in the Blue Room to mark the Christmas season.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 13 -- Diminutive Del Insko, who had, a near-miss, finishing second in the third race with Smoke Rings, got a direct hit with Lusty Mike, who captured the sixth at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
DIAN, South Vietnam, Dec. 13 -- The soldier, lying on a cot in the 93d Evacuation Hospital near here, said in a low voice, "I thought they were going to kill me."
A real estate speculator under Federal indictment for fraud denied yesterday that he had ever had a dog named Max Donovan on the payroll of his Wall Street concern.

WARREN, Pa., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The multi-million-dollar Kinzua Dam, a controversial flood control project on the Allegheny River that forced the relocation of the Seneca Indian tribe, was completed today after more than five years of construction work.
A crowd of 450 Negroes heard speakers at a Brooklyn rally last night charge that the City Council's bill to ban gypsy cabs would end taxi service in Negro areas.
The Bank of Montreal, the oldest and third largest bank in Canada, announced yesterday the appointment of R.D. Mulholland as executive vice president.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Britain has beaten out American competitors and landed a $300-million arms deal with Saudi Arabia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Republican party leaders warned today of a "growing danger that the United States is becoming involved in an endless, Korean-type jungle war" in Vietnam. In a unanimous declaration, the party's Congressional leaders and five Governors called for an immediate naval quarantine of North Vietnam and "maximum use" of American air power against all "significant military targets" in that country.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Prime Minister Wilson may appear in the United Nations Security Council this week to argue the British position on Rhodesia.
WARSAW, Dec. 13 -- About 50 years ago Lydia Jedrzejowska of Cracow and Michael Pucinski of Warsaw, uncertain and uneasy about the future, left Poland for the United States.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 13 -- Space agency officials disclosed today that a 2-cent plastic dust cover had inadvertently been left in one of the rocket engines of Gemini 6 before it left the manufacturer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- Twenty-eight candidates were nominated today for 27 vice presidential seats on the 29-member executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Paul A. Volcker, who resigned recently as Deputy Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, returned yesterday to the Chase Manhattan Bank as vice president for forward planning.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay said yesterday that he had directed Roswell B. Perkins, a former Assistant Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, to set up a permanent Mayor's Council on Transportation.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 13 -- Doubts were raised here today about India's capacity to handle the massive food imports needed to meet the impending famine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The first investment guarantee contract with a United States company doing business in Brazil will be signed tomorrow by the Agency for International Development with the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.
CAIRO, Dec. 13 -- The United Arab Republic called today for a new meeting of African foreign ministers to reconsider their stand on Rhodesia.

SEVERAL high-ranking bridge personalities have been better known to the general public in a political context. Among these are Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Iain Macleod, British Conservative party leader, and the late President Venizelos of Greece.

State governments, not Federal tax authorities, should take the main responsibility for "correcting the major abuses of foundations that have developed in recent years," says a report published by the Russell Sage Foundation.

Two convertible debenture issues totaling $35 million were sold yesterday in Europe for leading United States corporations to raise money without worsening the United States balance-of-payments problem.
DARIEN, Conn., Dee. 13 -- Burglars cut into a walk-in vault in the Darien Post Office with an acetylene torch early yesterday and stole $67,200 in stamps and cash.
The toy industry struck back yesterday at groups critical of what they term to be an undue emphasis on war toys.
