VENICE, Italy, Dec. 13 -- The Venetian police tonight disclosed the recovery of 85 art works valued at $1 million. Most of the pieces had been stolen from churches in central and north Italy from 1957 to 1962.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 13 -- Uruguay's Communist-influenced labor unions agreed today to call off a general strike scheduled for tomorrow. They tentatively offered also to abandon further agitation against Government wage restraints.

WHEN Daniel Abrams last appeared here he performed Mozart's piano sonatas in a special recital series. Last night he came back to play a totally different kind of program in Carnegie Hall, one devoted to 19th-century Romantics.
Standard Poor's Corporation polished up the crystal ball of its annual forecast issue yesterday and predicted an increase of 7 per cent or so in dividends next year.

The name of the Rev. James J. Reeb can now be added to a sad, strange honor roll. Other names on that roll read: Andrew Goodman, Michael Schwerner, James Chaney, Mrs. Viola Liuzzo, Medgar Evers, Jimmy Lee Jackson and Jonathan Daniels. Negro and white, cleric and layman, man and woman, they share the common fate that they died in the South for their civil rights convictions -- and that their murders go unpunished.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Denis Healey, the British Defense Minister, announced today that he had won American agreement for an extension of two months, until March 1, on an option to acquire American F-111A swing-wing supersonic fighter planes.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 13 (AP) -- About 50 University of Notre Dame students gathered in Farley Hall dormitory this afternoon to encourage a dozen others who said they would fast at least until Thursday to promote political freedom of speech for the Catholic clergy.
Low-priced speculative issues again held the center of the stage on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the market continued to advance in heavy trading.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- For more than three decades, the name of Wright Patman has been synonymous in Washington with advocacy of low interest rates, distrust of banks and bankers, concern with the problem of small business, and denunciation of the Federal Reserve System.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board disclosed to a Congressional committee today that he had sought unsuccessfully since early October to win the "concurrence" of the Johnson Administration for an increase in the Federal Reserve discount rate.

In a courtship involving leading companies making nationally branded and private-label apparel, Kayser-Roth Corporation and Colonial Corporation of America yesterday announced that they were holding merger talks.
An assistant cashier of the Merchants Bank of New York was charged yesterday with embezzling $120,000 from the bank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Representative Charles L. Weltner of Georgia said today that he would not use a magazine offered to him and other Congressional candidates by the Democratic National Committee as a fund-raising device.
A terrified little man reluctantly identified Christopher Lynch yesterday as the youth he had seen kill another boy in a subway train.
Cardinal Spellman presented the traditional crozier, ring and miter to two new bishops yesterday amid the splendor of papal white, episcopal purple and the scarlet and gold of his own office.
Nearly 100 key figures in the city government over the last, 12 years gave a warm, spirited party for Mayor Wagner yesterday as he prepared to leave City Hall.
The Austintown Local School District in Ohio, immediately west of Youngstown, awarded $4.6 million of bonds yesterday to a syndicate headed by McDonald Co., Cleveland, and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The White House said today that President Johnson had raised the salaries of his 10 top aides from $28,500 to $30,000 a year.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Harold Winstone, the British and Empire featherweight champion, knocked out Brian Cartwright tonight. The referee stopped the fight halfway through the ninth round of a 10-round nontitle contest.
Nearly 100 key figures in the city government over the last, 12 years gave a warm, spirited party for Mayor Wagner yesterday as he prepared to leave City Hall.
The Austintown Local School District in Ohio, immediately west of Youngstown, awarded $4.6 million of bonds yesterday to a syndicate headed by McDonald Co., Cleveland, and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The White House said today that President Johnson had raised the salaries of his 10 top aides from $28,500 to $30,000 a year.

City Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman last night was assured the Republican nomination for the Congressional seat in Manhattan's 17th Congressional District to be vacated by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay.
Two-year-old Kuniko was sitting near the river that morning, yawning, playing with the pebbles, watching her two big brothers swim when suddenly the flash came.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Treasury bill rate rose slightly further at today's auction after the big jump last week in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's discount-rate increase to 4 1/2 per cent on Dec. 5, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Harold Winstone, the British and Empire featherweight champion, knocked out Brian Cartwright tonight. The referee stopped the fight halfway through the ninth round of a 10-round nontitle contest.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday that he would extend the new garment area parking restrictions this month to include Fifth Avenue.
William Epton, vice chairman of the Progressive Labor Movement, took the witness stand at his trial yesterday on anarchy charges and denied having ever advocated violence.
A group of 25 fifth graders from Port Washington, L.I., have raised $12 for the Neediest Cases fund in the conviction "that we should help the others be as fortunate as we are."

The New York Giants and the San Diego Chargers -- plus "the system" -- are the objects of a college football coach's wrath because of the indirect loss of the coach's best player for a bowl game last Saturday.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- A warm and admiring but not uncritical portrait of Albert Einstein was drawn tonight by J. Robert Oppenheimer.
Bruno Sammartino and Johnny Valentine defeated the Miller brothers, Dr. Bill and Dan, in the feature wrestling bout last night at Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 10,090 paid $35,609.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- "So you want to be a member of the New Left?"

Robert E. Kintner will leave the active presidency of the National Broadcasting Company on Jan. 1 and assume the post of chairman without fixed duties. The settlement of the executive's contract with the radio and television company was understood to call for Mr. Kintner's complete withdrawal on March 31.
Nobody, but nobody, had a sports party like the one thrown for Barney Gimbel last night at the New York Hilton Hotel.
WASHINGTON Dec. 13 -- The computer used in a large Southern manufacturing plant to screen job applicants seemed to sparkle with objectivity.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Vietcong offer of a 12-hour truce in Vietnam over Christmas Eve was officially welcomed here today.
" A terrible ruling." That was the reaction yesterday of Francis R. Buono, chairman of the Queens parents group formed to fight the state law on school prayers.
WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 13 -- A member of the Waterbury Tax Review Board was shot and critically wounded in the doorway of his home tonight.
Paul Dunkel, flutist, chose a beautifully contrasting program and an excellent group of helpers for his chamber music concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The result: pure pleasure.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- The United States promised new financial help today for the United Nations peace-keeping force for Cyprus.

JAMES WARING is the darkling child of dance comedy. Last night at the "Mondays at Nine" subscription series at the East 74th Street Theater, Mr. Waring offered the lion's share of a program that in general had considerable interest.
Rain, drizzle and overcast slowed air traffic yesterday and forced New York Airways to suspend flights of its helicopters between the three major airports and Manhattan.
The recovery in bond prices that rippled through most parts of the market late last week evaporated yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- King { Faisal of Saudi Arabia has ordered the wives of Saudi diplomats abroad to shun parties, official or otherwise.
A deputy inspector in the Police Department was demoted to captain last night "for general inefficiency" by Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick.

NEWARK, Dec. 13 -- The four major electric utility companies of New Jersey cautiously reported today that the possibility of a crippling power failure "should not constitute a major worry to the public."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan today offered India a pledge of peace in return for self-determination in the state of Kashmir.

WARSAW -- This is a city with many shades of gray. A few colors leap out: from a small mound of lemons in a dim store, a green poster announcing a new play, the bright covers of Polish paperbacks, and the blue wool legs of girls.
" A terrible ruling." That was the reaction yesterday of Francis R. Buono, chairman of the Queens parents group formed to fight the state law on school prayers.

ALL last week the International Speedway at Daytona Beach, Fla., was closed to visitors while a Ford racing team, in cooperation with a group of Goodyear Tire Company engineers, carried on round-the-clock high-speed tests.
Negro parent groups from the South Jamaica section of Queens asked the City Planning Commission yesterday for more schools -- "segregated or not."
Nearly 1,000 members of Temple Emanu-E1 gathered in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night to celebrate its 120th anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey presented the Harmon Trophies for the world's outstanding aviators today with words of praise for the courageous, the venturesome and the effective.

PALISADES, N.Y. -- The New York Mycological Society consists of 45 mushroom hunters who scout wood, field and occasionally even cemeteries for the delectable fungus -- and manage to survive for a banquet once a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The United States could supply famine-threatened India with 15 million tons of wheat a year -- far in excess of its present port facilities to absorb -- and still have a "comfortable reserve" of 10 to 13 million tons on hand, a high Administration official said today.

THE exhibition of 81 works by the Belgian artist Rene Magritte, opening today at the Museum of Modern Art, covers 40 years, in galleries arranged chronologically. The best paintings are in the last galleries.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- President de Gaulle tonight rejected charges that he was "anti-American" and "anti-European."

LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 14 -- President Kenneth D. Kaunda has decided to seek United States and Soviet support against Rhodesia if Britain does not meet Zambia's demonds for quick action to topple the rebel regime in Rhodesia.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Eddie Stanky signed a three-year contract to manage the Chicago White Sox today.
Compton Advertising, Inc., announced yesterday the election of John A. Hise as president, effective Jan. 1. The board also elected C. Stuart Mitcheil as executive vice president.

RED CLIFF, Wis., Dec. 14 (AP) -- A Federal official today ordered two college girls who have been trying to set up a Domestic Peace Corps program to leave the Red Cliff Reservation of Chippewa Indians.
Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company approved yesterday plans to offer about $37.5 million of convertible preferred stock early in 1966.

The New York Knickerbockers withstood the best one-man scoring effort in the National Basketball Association season last night and managed to pull out an exciting 141-137 victory over the San Francisco Warriors.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 14 -- The United States announced today that it would aid the Yugoslav Communist economic reform with credits and debt postponements amounting to $57 million.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- A plan to make The Mall here into a tree-shaded recreational park without automobiles was announced today.
A handful of University of Notre Dame students carried into a third day yesterday a fast protesting the censuring of Roman Catholic priests by church superiors, United Press International reported.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Federal Maritime Commission ordered a formal investigation today to determine whether, truck loading and unloading tariffs in the Port of New York are unreasonably high.
Counsel for William Epton, on trial in Criminal Court on anarchy charges, asked for a mistrial yesterday. Justice Arthur Markewich denied the motion but said he would study the question overnight.
A man was put to sleep with electricity here yesterday.

ADD TO your list of unknown operas the latest arrival by Donizetti. It is "Roberto Devereux," and it received a concert performance last night in Carnegie Hall by the American Opera Society, which through the years has enthusiastically been searching out long-forgotten works by Bellini and Donizetti.
JAKARTA, Dec. 14 -- Feeling against Communists and Chinese appears to be mounting throughout Indonesia.

Angela Lansbury will be started as the exuberant Auntie Mame in the musical version of the hit comedy, to be called "Mame." Appearing with her will be Beatrice Arthur in the role of Vera, the raffish actress.
MOSCOW, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union announced today that it would start a six-month test in the Pacific on Thursday "of a variant of a system of landing space vehicles."
A utility bond issue was offered yesterday yielding more than 5 per cent for the first time since June, 1961, and underwriters estimated it was 40 per cent sold by late afternoon.

A SMALL boy with grubby hands has driven his mother into designing some of the cleverest aprons in town. Nathaneal Brodney is the exuberant 3-year-old whose father is a painter and whose mother is a designer.
On March 6, 1960, Representative Adam Clayton Powell called Mrs. Esther James "a bag woman for the Police Department," in an interview on the WNTA-TV "Between the Lines" program.

Liszt, Bartok and Gyorgy Sandor -- Hungarians all -- shared honors last night in the piano recital Mr. Sandor gave at Philharmonic Hall. His program was made up entirely of works by the two composers. By Liszt there were the Sonata in B minor, the Polonaise in E major and "Funerailles."
WHITE PLALN'S, Dec. 14 -Leaders in the arts, commerce and politics of Westchester County announced today the formation of the Council for the Arts in Westchester.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- The most interesting development in the otherwise routine convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organiza tions closing here tomorrow was the election today of eight new vice presidents to the organization's 29-member executive council.
After a bold advance to new contract highs on Monday and to further new highs early yesterday, grain futures prices retreated under profit taking.

Mayor Wagner and Council President-elect Frank D. O'Connor led a parade of witnesses yesterday who urged that the Legislature repass major legislation that the Governor vetoed in 1965. This would present Mr. Rockefeller with the problem of acting on the legislation in a state election year.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 14 -- A compromise that could lead to a meeting of the six foreign ministers of the European Common Market was outlined today by diplomatic sources.
YONKERS, Dec. 14 -- A thief who poses as a man interested in religion has been preying on churches and rectories in this area since 1962, according to the Yonkers police.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Government will attempt to establish a register of job qualifications and needs of the nation's industries, a meeting of industry representatives was told today.

TORONTO, Dec. 14 -- Japanese interests are taking control of Canadian ,Motor Industries, Ltd., a new company that has encountered financial difficulty in consummating plans to assemble Japanese cars in Canada.

WARSAW, Dec. 14 -- Ambassador Gronouski returned today after a special meeting with Secretary of State Rusk in Paris. Some sources here think that the Americans are seeking a special meeting with the Chinese, not in Warsaw, and at a higher level.
WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The shooting of George J. Macary, a member of Waterbury's Board of Tax Review, apparently had nothing to do with his official duties, the police said today.

New-car sales in early December ran only 3 per cent ahead of the pace a year ago, although still holding to a record pace. Dealers retailed 245,419 cars in the Dec. 1-10 period, compared with 239,298 a year ago.

THE New York Mets lost half the team yesterday -- the team of Bing Devine and Eddie Stanky, which arrived in New York from St. Louis 14 months ago with the job of making the Mets as successful on the field as they were at the box office.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Britain and Ireland agreed today to establish a free-trade area, in effect returning the two nations to the economic position without barriers to commerce that prevailed before Irish independence nearly half a century ago.

A little-known state commission with a preposterously long title has been engaged for four years in work, to culminate this winter, that will substantially benefit practically every person who lives or owns property in New York State. The Temporary State Commission on the Modernization, Revision and Simplification of the Laws of Estates has been trying to unsnarl the outmoded codes that govern transmission of property from one person to another on death.

A major reorganization proposal by a city fiscal commission appears likely to be by-passed by the new administration of John V. Lindsay. This is the proposal to put the budget director under the City Administrator.
The top air pollution control official of Los Angeles County has been appointed by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay as his air pollution control consultant here.

Following a courtship of 18 days in which prestige, pay and pension were chief subjects, Tommy Nobis capitulated yesterday. College football's most sought-after player of the year signed with the Atlanta Falcons, the new team beginning play next season in the National Football League.
New York University announced today a rise in tuition fees, effective Sept. 1, 1966.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Theodore W. Kheel of New York, who has earned more distinction as an arbitrator and mediator than as a breast-stroke swimmer at Cornell, was commissioned today to bring peace to amateur sports in the United States.

Both of us have lived and worked in Pakistan as U.N. advisers to the Government there. We have had the opportunity of viewing United States policy toward Pakistan through the eyes of our Pakistani friends and associates.

Hearings on the city's 1966-67 expense budget are lagging because commissioners and department heads are looking for guidance from representatives of Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay in preparing their estimates.

There is general agreement that the developing countries need technical as well as financial help. The Johnson Administration has stressed that it has been increasing the amount of technical assistance in its foreign-aid program in order to fill gaps in the skills of developing countries and help them speed their growth.

HOUSTON, Dec. 14 -- Gemini 7 astronauts tracked the fiery path of a Minuteman 2 dummy warhead today as it streaked through the darkness over the western Pacific and plunged into a lagoon at the Eniwetok test range.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Leaders of the American Farm Bureau Federation said today they expected influential Democratic support for a sweeping new farm program based on "markets not subsidies."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Department of Defense proposes to build a multi-million dollar office building, more than a third the size of the Pentagon, at the site of the old Bolling-Anacostia Air Force Base.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Dec. 14 -- United States officers think that two more American divisions are needed in the Vietnamese III Corps area to break the increasing strength of the Vietcong to the north, east and west of Saigon.
The election of Robert A. Beck and Graham G. Macmillan as vice presidents was announced yesterday by the Prudential Insurance Company.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell was ordered yesterday to pay $575,000 to a Harlem widow for having evaded payment of $33,000 he owed her on a defamation award.
Christopher Lynch, on trial for the murder of another youth in the subway, yesterday denied all knowledge of the crime.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Subways may be for sleeping -- but not for automobiles.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is continuing its commendable efforts to improve standards in the securities market. It has asked the securities industry to observe the same principle of full disclosure required of American corporations, a reform that is clearly in the public interest. And it has called for more uniform accounting procedures so that the public will be better able both to understand corporate balance sheets and to make more meaningful comparisons.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Wednesday, Dec. 15 -- Ground crews were "urgently trying" early today to prepare the Gemini 6 for a launching and space rendezvous.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company recorded another record year of sales and earnings, Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman, and Earl B. Hathaway, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement for the year to Oct. 31.

Potomac Books, a new publishing concern, will issue from Washington in the spring its first list of books. The company is headed by Cary T. Grayson Jr., president and Craig Colgate Jr., vice president and treasurer.

The stock market opened on a strong note yesterday as blue-chip issues led the Big Board list to substantial gains by noon. However, weakness that developed during the last hour cut the rise in the popular averages to modest proportions for the day.
DALLAS, Dec. 14 -- Dr. Louis Spencer Smith, sitting in his library reading at 1:30 o'clock this morning, sensed that all was not right.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 14 -- "Goldfinger," one of the most popular films shown in Israel in years, was banned today because of the Nazi past of Gert Frobe, who plays the title role.
The Futterman Corporation, a real estate investment and insurance company, announced yesterday the election of R. Ross Craig as a director.
William A. "Pat" Patterson, chairman and executive head of United Air Lines, Inc., since its organization in 1934, is going to sever all ties with the system effective next spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, has recommended to President Johnson a "negative income tax" as part of a comprehensive, five-year attack on poverty, informed sources at his agency reported today.
HARTFORD, Dec. 14 -- Connecticut voters overwhelmingly approved today the state's first new Constitution since 1818.

WHEN the Houston baseball team was first admitted to the National League, the capabilities of the shrewd and wily Paul Richards, the general manager, were favorably known to everyone in diamond circles. But Judge Roy Hofheinz, the club president, was something of a stranger.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- The Justice Department was reported today to be ready to bring more Chicago crime syndicate figures before grand juries with a "talk-or-jail" threat.
MOSCOW, Dec. 14 (AP) -The Soviet Union dismissed today as an "unlawful document" an international report on North Vietnamese troop movements in Laos.

ON many occasions a player may find it convenient to bid a three-card suit. Both the opening bidder and the responder may try such a maneuver, especially if the suit is a minor, on a "least-evil" basis.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 14 (AP) -- More than 80 planes scanned 30,000 square miles of New Mexico and Colorado mountains today searching for a plane carrying the head of America's space medicine program and two other persons.
HOUSTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -The first pictures of America's two Gemini ships flying in orbital formation may come from a pair of earth-based cameras normally used in top-secret space surveillance work.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Britain is planning to announce an oil embargo against the rebellious Government of Rhodesia later this week.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 -- The Martin Company said today it was investigating why a tiny plastic dust cover was "carelessly" left inside a Gemini 6 rocket fuel line earlier this year at its plant here.
Mayor Wagner called upon the state yesterday to give financial help to the city's hard-pressed transit system to preserve the 15-cent fare. He got a quick turndown from the Governor.

The Grand Union Company, which operates 526 supermarkets, announced yesterday in East Paterson, N.J., the election of Charles G. Rodman and Joseph L. Eckhouse as executive vice presidents. The posts are newly formed.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Sales Company is negotiating for the sale of its 48 per cent stock interest in Alsco, Inc., it was reported yesterday.

MILAN, Italy, Dec. 14 -- The Italian Government will guarantee only a part of a more than $112 million trade pact recently signed between Montecatini and the Soviet Union, it was disclosed here today.
Trading was dull and most prices fell yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. British Government bonds were also off.

American Telephone and Telegraph closed at 60 1/2 yesterday, its lowest point since 1963, The stock was trading at around 66 before the Federal Communications Commission on Oct. 27 announced it had opened a full-scale investigation of A.T. T.'s rate structure, with particular emphasis on interstate tools and the prices at which Bell System subsidiaries buy equipment from Western Electric, the parent company's manufacturing arm.
New York City approved and sent to Washington yesterday a request for $5,327,420 so 33,372 children might participate in Project Head Start next Spring.

Only 20 per cent of American public opinion believes the United States should have pulled out of Vietnam before its own fighting units became involved, according to a national poll released last night by C.B.S. News.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board sharply denied today that there was an "economic policy civil war" within the Government.

While the Johnson Administration has made a mountain out of the Federal Reserve's rise in interest rates, most economic forecasters seem to view it as pretty much a mole hill. They are sticking to their previous predictions that 1966 will be another good year for business.

THE hope that educational television would afford an opportunity for the professionals of commercial television to try their wings was winningly realized last night in the opening of the series entitled "U.S.A.: Dance" over Channel 13.

ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- Eight Greek officers of the 20,238-ton Greek luxury liner Lakonia, which sank ablaze with loss of 125 lives off Madeira Island on Dec. 22, 1963, were charged today with negligence in the disaster.
The office-copying industry, one of the most volatile and competitive in the nation, gave a good demonstration yesterday of its catalytic influence on Wall Street.

Representative Charles L. Weltner of Georgia is planning a fund-raising theater benefit this weekend as part of his campaign for re-election to Congress in 1966, but he has refused to participate in the Democratic National Committee's dubious scheme for exploiting these theater parties. He will not distribute the national committee's theater program which contains 66 full-page "advertisements" paid for by leading corporations.

The United States section of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom announced yesterday that it would ask the leaders of other women's groups in this country to support a program for peace in Vietnam hased on the following:
Profit taking put an end to five days of advances on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the market closed mixed in heavy trading.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Britain's trading position continued to improve last month, but authorities warned that there was still a "good way to go" yet for full economic recovery.
NICE, France, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Somerset Maugham's condition improved late today but the writer remained in a coma four days after suffering a stroke.
CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 14 -- A California sea lion that escaped from an aquarium in Maryland found a temporary home away from home in a small creek here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Sheldon S. Cohen, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today that "overzealousness" by Internal Revenue personnel -- including the use of wiretaps and other invasions of privacy -- had been "completely corrected as far as I know."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 14 -- United States marines and B-52 strategic bombers pursued and harassed the Vietcong in the forested hills 355 miles northeast of Saigon today.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A Federal judge ruled today that a Maryland court decision striking down every pending criminal indictment in the state could not be made retroactive.

COLOGNE, Germany, Dec. 14 (AP) -- West German sales to the United States are expected to soar to a record in 1965, cutting the German deficit in the trade between the two countries to an estimated $800 million.

PARIS -- It might be well for NATO and its principal ministers, who are holding their annual Paris Council, to contemplate the lessons of NATO's only comparable precursor, the Athenian alliance against Persia in the fifth century B.C.
Harold Wilson must have reflected both on the ironies of politics and on the heavy responsibilities of high office as he prepared his visits this week to New York and Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay said today that Congress was short-changing the cities in the distribution of Federal aid.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- The merged labor federation, in the most sweeping leadership change in its 10-year history, elected today eight new members to its 29-man executive council.
Gale Herrick, who used to work for Jules Irving and Herbert Blau on the West Coast for $1 a year, has followed them East at twice the pay.
Several benefactors of the Neediest Cases fund wrote plaintively yesterday of their own thin wallets and undernourished bank accounts.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union extended debate on Cyprus today from the dispute between the island's ethnic Greek and Turkish communities to a demand for British withdrawal from bases in Cyprus that are still legally British territory.
The City Council voted last night to give itself unrestricted power over its own budget funds.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 14- Nations talk about what they lack; America is talking about peace, Germany about unity, France about glory, Russia about freedom and India about food.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Mack Lee Hill, the Kansas City Chiefs fullback, died today after an operation at Menorah Medical Center. He was 25 years old.

HELAS, messieurs! You've got it all wrong at Customs at Orly where you take forever to let the huge trunk in "La Grosse Valise" into France. You should have made sure that "La Grosse Valise" never got out.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 12 -- Asian Communists have accelerated their infiltration of Thailand, apparently in a diversionary action to support their war effort in Vietnam.
HONG KONG -- The Royal Hong Kong Jockey Club stands for more than horse racing. It's a way of life.
American Airlines proposed yesterday a 50 per cent reduction in jet coach fares for persons 12 through 21 years of age when seats are not filled by full-fare passengers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Free Society Association founded by former Senator Barry Goldwater asserted today that an "ideological and political link" existed between the programs of the Johnson Administration and the "radical leftist movement" on college campuses.

Directors of the Bank of New York raised the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of $1.40 a share, payable Jan. 3 to holders of record Dec. 24. In previous quarters, shareholders received $1.35 a share. Yesterday's board action brings 1965 declarations to $5.45 a share, against $5.40 a share in 1964.
The city was told yesterday that its slums were spreading and that it must take "immediate actions to improve living conditions" in its "Harlems and "Bedford-Stuyvesants."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 14 -- King Hussein of Jordan is trying to placate the large Palestinian community in his country, which believes the Government is not making adequate war preparations against Israel, according to reports from Amman today.
The British pound fell slightly in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.8024, down 3 points from the price on Monday.

Your Dec. 7 editorial rightly deplores the failure of policy coordination exhibited by the unilateral decision of the Federal Reserve to raise its discount rate to 4.5 per cent. To blame the rest of the Federal Government rather than the Federal Reserve, however, is through-the-looking-glass logic roughly equivalent to holding everyone except de Gaulle responsible for lack of coordination in NATO or the Common Market.
A BLONDE with a shaggy hairdo looked around at the mob at Tiger Morse's fashion show Monday night. "It's a cross section of decadence, isn't It?" she giggled.
American manufacturers were chided yesterday for failing to prepare coherent export plans and for sacrificing promising markets for the sake of quick profits.

The new frequency modulation (FM) master antenna atop the Empire State Building begins operating officially today with broadcasts by WQXR-FM, the first station to use the facility. The antenna, reported to be the first of its kind in this country, eventually will be able to provide simultaneous broadcasts by 17 FM stations.
Bank records of The Worker, twice-weekly New York Communist newspaper, have been obtained under subpoena by the House Committee on Un-American Activities for 1963, 1961 and 1965.

Secretary of State Rusk yesterday was in the position of trying to sell the Vietnamese war to the other fourteen member nations of NATO in Paris. He pleaded for greater understanding and support of the American commitment and he warned his listeners that the fate of NAT0 might be decided in Vietnam.
Arnold Picker, executive vice president of United Artists, distributors of "Goldfinger," expressed surprise last night at the action of the Israeli censorship board.
Lee C. Deighton, chairman of the Macmillan Company, was elected yesterday as a director of Crowell Collier Macmillan, Inc., which has operated the Macmillan Company as a subsidiary since 1960.
Stockholders of Foote, Cone Belding, Inc., were given the makings yesterday of a happy Christmas.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk told fellow ministers of the Western alliance today that the United States war effort in Vietnam was no less vital to them than the commitment to Europe's defense.
BONN, Dec. 14 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said today that he would not present any "exaggerated demands" to President Johnson next week and he had no specific nuclear defense proposal to make.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Sam McDowell, a southpaw for the Cleveland Indians and Jim (Mudcat) Grant, a right-hander for the pennant-winning Minnesota Twins, shared American League pitching honors in 1965, the official averages confirmed today.

CAIRO, Dec. 14 -- With unusual vigor and detail the normally acquiescent National Assembly of the United Arab Republic has called on the Government to hold the line on prices, put a lid on its spending, and make an immediate start on a birth control program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -Kalvin Kytle resigned today as acting director of the Community Relations Service in what appeared to be a response to criticism of the civil rights agency and its pending absorption by the Department of Justice.
On Park Avenue last night, Democrats gathered amid caviar and champagne.

Two of the four administrators in the City University who announced last month that they were leaving their posts because of a dispute with the Board of Higher Education withdrew their resignations last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Double-time pay for overtime work as a partial solution to unemployment was recommended tonight by Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz.
In one of the last letters he wrote, Adlai E. Stevenson argues that Chinese expansionism must be checked in Vietnam and in the rest of Southeast Asia.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The General Assembly's Social and Humanitarian Committee approved today a proposed international pact aimed at banning racial discrimination.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 14 -- The extended harness racing season will end tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway, and the final two nights of action will not significantly change the 1965 figures, that will disclose that wagering was up at the Nassau County course, but attendance was down.

The Brunswick Corporation took a new sighting yesterday on the market for bowling equipment and found it was bad. Then directors tallied the millions of dollars in bowling equipment the company has in inventory and decided it was worth $76 million less than it had been valued at the day before.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- At a gala performance tonight in the presence of Princess Margaret, Rudolf Nureyev's production of the evening-long ballet "Raymonda" at last reached London, following its premiere in Spoleto last year and subsequent showings elsewhere.
About that 10 per cent excise tax on theater tickets, which is going to end a long, profitable but hardly popular run on Dec. 31.

There is a woman with binoculars who sits every day in the balcony above the trading floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, watching the action intently. She is the kind of avid speculator brokers like.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- The United States called today for the establishment of a United Nations peace service that would seek to prevent international disputes from becoming wars.
The Commercial Solvents Corporation and Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., with combined assets of about $203,161,000, are planning to merge to form a broadly diversified worldwide chemical company.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- An ornately lettered passport issued to the late Sir Winston Churchill in 1895 was bought here today for $2,380 at a Churchilliana auction.

The New York boxing writers, who had virtually exhausted their supply of phrases to describe Cassius Clay, put together an all-encompassing one yesterday and named the heavyweight champion fighter of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan, whose visit in 1961 generated a Kennedy summertime extravaganza involving a flotilla of yachts on the Potomac River and dinner in a canopied pavilion at Mount Vernon, was entertained tonight at a more familiar kind of state dinner.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Dec. 14 -- The president of the school board here resigned last night at the height of a controversy resulting from her complaint to !a teacher that her son had received a poor grade in mathematics in Great Neck High School.
PARIS, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Mr. Frobe said tonight he was upset that Israeli censors had banned "Goldfinger."

STANLEY P. SPISIAK, a Buffalo resident who has been active in a private capacity in water pollution control, has been named national water conservationist of the year by the National Wildlife Federation.
A National Catholic Office for Radio and Television has been established here by the American hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church.
The manager of a city housing project on the Upper West Side has been identified as the owner of eight apartment buildings with 88 violations, including faulty plastering and inadequate hot water.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Johnson is expected to send to Congress next month a defense spending budget totaling about $60 billion for the fiscal year 1967, beginning next July 1.

Leader of the Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee gave Mayor Wagner assurances yesterday that they would not take any strike action in their dispute with the fleet owners until after next Tuesday representation elections.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 14 -- The Defense Minister, Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, was appointed today to a triumvirate that will rule as an executive body directly under President Sukarno.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- Communist China was accused in the General Assembly today of ruthless repression of the people of Tibet.

Part rehabilitation projects that the City Planning Commission has deleted from the capital budget "emphatically are essential" to proper port development and the prosperity Of the city, Commissioner Leo Brown declared yesterday.
GENEVA, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union called today for an increase in the price of gold as a means of stimulating world trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Johnson and Pakistan's President, Mohammad Ayub Khan, expressed their determination today to search for peace and then began intensive discussions that will continue tomorrow.
The Detroit School District sold $15 million of bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an annual net interest cost of 3.646 per cent.

The principal property sold yesterday at an auction of city-owned properties was a vacant tract of several acres in the Oakwood area of Staten Island. An unidientified client of Morris Ritt, Brooklyn real estate broker, bid $1,641,000 for the property, which had an upset or minimum price, of $960,000.
The trend to higher rates on time and savings deposits at commercial banks, mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations continued to gather steam yesterday.
Charlie Brown of the "Peanuts" comic strip, who made his television debut last week in an animated cartoon will make at least one appearance in 1966 and probably three.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Cassius Clay, the world heavyweight champion, was arrested and charged with disorderly conduct today when he shouted "I'm the champ" and "go ahead and hit me" at police officers who stopped a car in which he was riding.

The B.V.D. Company, Inc., a diversified apparel manufacturer, is seeking to continue its growth in 1966 through new acquisitions and a revamping of its operational organ ization. It was learned that B.V.D., which bought one company in 1965 and six others in 1964, is negotiating to acquire three men's wear companies with total annual sales of $30 million.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 14 -- The Indian Government reported today that its troops killed 30 Chinese soldiers in a clash Sunday on the Sikkim-Tibet border. It said that two Indians had been killed and that seven were missing.

Australis, a 5-year-old bay mare owned by Danny Lopez of Old Brookville, L.I., won the horse-of-the-year award in the open jumper division, officials of the American Horse Shows Association announced yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- In the view of experienced diplomats here, conditions are ripe for the Western alliance to dispose of the nuclear sharing issue which has divided it over the last several years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- C.D. DeLoach, associate director for crime records in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, today assailed "arrogant nonconformists" and characterized campus and street demonstrations as a disgrace.

Five and a half years ago, bowling stocks were all the rage and a brokerage firm, in a paean to the industry's growth prospects that was by no means unusual at the time, told its customers, "The expansion potentials of bowling are not generally understood."

" The Proud Tower: A Portrait of the World before the War: 1890-1914," by Barbara W. Tuchman, will be published by Macmillan in January. Mrs. Tuchman, winner of a Pulitzer Prize in 1963 for "The Guns of August," has concentrated on society rather than on states in presenting the condition of the West in the 25 years before World War I.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Americans for Constitutional Action declared tonight that its analysis of Congressional voting in 1965 proved that conservatives were not "a dying breed."
Advances just barely out-numbered declines yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in heavy trading.

OTTAWA, Dec. 15 (Canadian Press) -- A new Canadian-United States air agreement giving Canadian airlines longer and mere profitable routes into the United States South and West is likely to be signed next month, informants said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Senator Clifford P. Case protested to the Internal Revenue Service today the proposed auction if mementos seized from the American Nazi party headquarters in nearby Arlington. Va.

The Vatican Council schema absolving the Jewish people of collective responsibility for the death of Jesus "is only a beginning for us to go further and to take out of Christian literature all that reflects upon the Jewish people," according to Richard Cardinal Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that the bombing of the North Vietnamese power plant near Haiphong "is representa tive of the type of attack we have carried out and will continue to carry out."

Manhattan College streaked to a 21-point lead and staved off a second-half rally to defeat Long Island University, 78-73, in a Metropolitan Basketball Conference game on the losers' floor in Brooklyn last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Federal Government is expected to step up sharply its efforts to determine if lead pollution poses a public health hazard.
The city will ask for Federal aid to accelerate its Building Code enforcement in slum areas.
The British pound was steady in fairly active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.8025, tip 1 point from the level on Tuesday.

Captain Jim Baldassari scored three goals and Charles Toczylowski two for the Choate School hockey team from Wallingford, Conn., yesterday as it beat St. Paul's School of Concord, N.H., 6-3, at Madison Square Garden.
Hiram Walker, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph G. Smith as a vice president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced tonight the appointment of F. Peter Libassi as special assistant for civil rights.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Industrial production rose more than a point on the Federal Reserve Board index in November to surpass the record set in August, the board reported today.

An increase of 436,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 184,583,000 barrels, compared with 184,147,000 a week earlier and 193,638,000 a year ago.
DELANO, Calif., Dec. 15 (AP) -- A group of clergymen and church laymen urged collective bargaining today to end a strike by grape pickers here.

Frank McGuire, the former St. John's coach, brings his undefeated South Carolina quintet to Madison Square Garden tonight to face New York University in the second game of a college double-header. Iona meets De Paul in the opener at 7 P.M.

The complaint about slow special delivery service made in your column by an Irate Citizen is old hat to many business users. Three or four years ago many market research agencies in New York and some other large cities instructed their correspondent employes to stop sending work back by special delivery, because it was often slower than ordinary first-class or airmail.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Howard Biddulph, retired vice president of the Howard Savings Institution, Newark, died today at Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, of a heart ailment. He was 87 years old and lived in Madison.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara urged the United States' Western European allies today to start worrying now about the threat posed by Communist China's growing nuclear strength.

Such diverse influences as snow in the Midwest, some nervous cocoa traders and too many frozen french-fried potatoes had their effect on futures trading yesterday. The result was lower prices at the close for wheat, cocoa and potatoes.
LONDON, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- European scientists acclaimed tonight America's Gemini space rendezvous as a major advance in space exploration.

Data from the flight recorder of the Trans World Airlines jet that collided with an Eastern Air Lines Constellation over Westchester Dec. 4 shows "conclusively" that the jet was at its assigned level of 11,000 feet at the time, T.W.A. said yesterday.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation expects to improve its earnings in the last six months of its current fiscal year ending June 30, Leo Jaffe, executive vice president, informed shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull had the third-four goal game of his National Hockey League career tonight to help the Chicago Black Hawks break a two-game losing streak with an 8-4 victory over the Boston Bruins.

Steel stocks suddenly awakened yesterday afternoon and paced the stock market to its biggest gain in more than a week.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15 -- Gov. John N. Dempsey said today he expected the New Haven Railroad's passenger service to be retained by the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads if their proposed merger was approved.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Johnson hailed the Gemini satellite rendezvous today as a step toward the moon.
The New York Mets talked shop yesterday on a Christmas visit to the children's ward of Bellevue Hospital, where they were unrecognized by most patients but besieged by autograph-seeking adults.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -- The head of a leading maritime union made a blistering attack today on the Johnson Administration and organized labor's close relationship with it.

Firemen, police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation answered a fire call to 136 East 67th Street, yesterday morning, but were politely turned back by attaches of the Soviet mission to the United Nations -- who live and work there.
The Health Department called on retail distributors yesterday to halt the sale of imported novelty drink coolers after preliminary laboratory tests had shown a high bacterial count in the products.
The Columbia basketball team sank 64 per cent of its field-goal attempts and 12 of 18 free throws as it beat Rutgers, 108-76, last night at University Gymnasium.

BOSTON, Dec. 15, (AP) -- Rocky Colavito of the Cleveland Indians tied a major league record for outfielders last season by turning in flawless fielding performances in 162 games, according to the official American League averages issued today.

The Norfolk Western and the Chesapeake Ohio railways asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to consolidate their merger application with those of three northeastern roads that seek to be included in the existing N. W. system.

The rendezvous yesterday between Gemini 7 and Gemini 6 provided the most exacting and important test to date for computer and radar equipment aboard the spacecraft.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, announced today the formation of the academic council for a new ecumenical institute in the Jordanian sector of Jerusalem.
HOUSTON, Dec. 15 -- Officials of the Manned Spacecraft Center celebrated the rendezvous of two spaceships by breaking out small American flags and pinning them to their workbenches and consoles.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Kohler Company was reported today to have agreed to pay $4.5 million in back wages and pension obligations to 1,400 former striking employes in a settlement of its 11-year-old dispute with the United Auto Workers Union.

Despite renewed efforts by the Government to reduce the outflow of dollars, a. corporate executive yesterday strongly defended American companies that have made or are planning direct investments in Europe and Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- In the same week national Republican leaders were trying to free the party from a psychological burden the Democrats have effectively assisted it in incurring, a Republican candidate in a local Virginia election showed them a better path to a comeback trail.
The nation's electric power production rose 5.9 per cent in the week ended Dec. 11 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
Some of the largest leases for new office buildings in the city in recent real estate history were negotiated during the last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Senator John Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, protested today that "Small Business alone among Government agencies has taken a complete axing."

The chronic morning and evening subway crushes can be eliminated by staggering working hours, according to a plan made public by Mayor Wagner yesterday. ATHENS, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Orthodox Church hierarchy of Greece refused in a special session tonight to accept changes in the church proposed by the Government.

The Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research has announced a grant of $180,000 to New York University for a five-year program to enlist and train research scholars in the fight against cancer.

With an eye to learning more about New York's economy, Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay announced yesterday the formation of an Urban Research Institute.

A syndicate led by four large banks was awarded two issues yesterday totaling $12,125,000 sold by two Georgia state agencies.

(Mrs. Jellyby was my first fictional encounter with a type all too prevalent in the real world; I was relieved that someone else had been bothered).
HONG KONG, Dec. 15 -- Peking announced today the merger of two Communist-supported organizations dedicated to the overthrow of the Thai Government and eviction of all American forces from Thailand.

SAMARKAND, U.S.S.R. -- The train to Samarkand leaves the steel-and-glass depot of Tashkent at 7:10 every evening. It is a long trip, seven hours to travel only 170 miles. The stops are frequent at villages of ancient name, now transformed into the collective farms of the Communist state.

AS THEY used to say in Indian territory, the young'uns will be out of school soon for spell and, trusting everythin's normal, they should be a-hankerin' fer somethin' to do. In which case, it would be downright smart for the folks -- both the old and not so old -- to take them up the road a-piece to West 55th Street, where "Oklahoma!" will be playing for the next three weeks.

A WIFE or offspring understandably might be shy about rummaging through a sporting goods store for an outdoors-style Christmas gift for the family stalwart. They have an easy and effective out. Buy him a book. Here's a selection that should fit most tastes.

Braniff International Airways, in a surprise announcement yesterday, disclosed it had signed an agreement with W.R. Grace Co., to buy its 50 per cent interest in Pan American-Grace Airways, Inc, (Panagra) for $15 million.
Representatives of four professions were honored yesterday in a ceremony at City Hall marking the 174th anniversary of the ratification of the Bill of Rights.
With little more than two weeks left for execution of year-end tax plans, investors wishing to take full income-tax advantage of stock gains or losses must move swiftly.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- General Assembly approved today a three-year extension of the United Nations aid program for Palestinian Arab refugees.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Charles B. Shuman was re-elected president of the American Farm Bureau Federation today.
Fuller Smith Ross, Inc., has realigned its corporate structure at the top, and for the first time now has both a chairman and a president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, asked Congress today to give the commission the legal authority to set and enforce minimum safe-operating standards for the electric power industry.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations pledged today its "unstinting support" of "all measures the Administration might deem necessary to halt Communist aggression and secure a just and lasting peace" in Vietnam.
There's a houswife in Queens who until earlier this year was something of a Japanese movie star.
The appointment of David F. Cardoza as assistant collector of customs here was announced yesterday by Lester D. Johnson, Commissioner of Customs.

WARSAW, Dec. 15 (AP) --John A. Gronouski, the new United States Ambassador to Poland, met Ambassador Wang Kuo-chuang of Communist China today for the first time in a three-hour session of the Warsaw talks.

A young man serving with the Air Force in Texas, who is looking forward to going back to college, sent $5 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, in particular for Michael, the 11-year-old boy in Case 8 who is bright but defiant in school, burdened by a difficult home background.

YAKIMA, Wash., (UPI) -- Mrs. Joan M. Douglas filed suit for divorce today in Yakima County Superior Court against Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas. They were married in Buffalo, on Aug. 5, 1963.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that if it granted the contract demands of its unions it would have to raise the 15-cent fare to 47 cents.

TORONTO, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Bob Pulford scored two power-play goals and assisted on another goal tonight to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings and end Detroit's six-game winning streak.

Only four of the 36 members of the Organization of African Unity -- Guinea, Niger, Senegal and Tanzania -- broke relations with Great Britain over Rhodesia yesterday. Thirty-four had supported a resolution at Addis Ababa on Dec. 3 to take this move if Britain had not crushed the Rhodesian rebellion by Dec. 15.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, caught in a tight budgetary squeeze, cancelled today one of its most ambitious scientific projects.
NICE, France, Thursday, Dec. 16 -- W. Somerset Maugham died early today at his Riviera villa, La Mauresque. The world-famous novelist, playwright and short-story writer was 91 years old.
LEWISBURG, Ky. (UPI) -- Relatives posted a $1,000 reward today for information on the whereabouts of an 81-year-old banker and his daughter believed to have been kidnaped.
One of the "Fearsome Foursome" got cold feet yesterday, but the three others did magnificently well in underwriting Consolidated Edison Company's $100 million bond issue.
RIVER ROUGE, Mich., Dec. 15 (AP) -- A woman was carried aloft 150 feet above the Rouge River on the lift section of a railroad bridge today but escaped injury by clinging to the ties.

ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The bodies of the nation's director of space medicine. Dr. W. Randolph Lovelace 2d, 57 years old, his wife and pilot were found today near the wreckage of their two-engine plane in a high mountain canyon.
Robert Moses accused the City Planning Commission yesterday of trying to usurp his authority as Mayor Wagner's representative on the Federal-state-city arterial program.

The California Toll Bridge Authority sold $100 million of revenue bonds yesterday to help finance construction of a subway under San Francisco Bay.

The New York Jets, who, like the Giants, will be fighting to hold second place, expect to have their best running back, Matt Snell, in the line-up against the Buffalo Bills here Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A group of about 100 mothers marched to the gates of the White House today to deliver stacks of Christmas cards for President Johnson with this message: "Give us peace in Vietnam this Christmas.''
Edgard Varese, the composer, who died Nov. 6, was honored by Columbia University late yesterday afternoon in a ceremony at McMillin Academic Theater.

The 1965 edition of the booklet, "Children's Books Suggested as Holiday Gifts," published by the New York Public Library is available free at the library and branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island.
Mrs. Evelyn Harris Asinof, a life trustee of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital.

Council President-elect Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday that every person he names to major public office will have to be certified first by the City Board of Ethics as free of possible conflict of interest.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Enoch Powell, the Conservative party's spokesman on defense, took a long look at Britain's past and a long look at her future today and endorsed the suggestion that there ought to be a League for Protection Against American Mothers.

The flood-gates of emotion burst at the Polo Grounds.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Goldie the eagle, escape artist of the London Zoo. swooped and glided with abandon among the trees of Regents Park today after his second freedom break this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The White House said today that it was "premature" to talk about a possible tax increase next year and that "the subject has not been seriously discussed in the Adminitration.'

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Reclamation Bureau is accelerating its weather modification research to discover ways of increasing the water supply in the West, Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall announced today.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation announced yesterday that its board of directors had approved the distribution of its previously announced tender offer to buy a million of its common shares at $32 a share. The maker of aerospace and other equipment has about 7.5 million shares outstanding.

BUFFALO, Dec. 15 -- Governor Rockefeller toured the Niagara Frontier today and heard himself praised for initiating the state sales tax.
FAIR HAVEN, N.J., Dec. 15 (AP) -- About 60 pleasure boats and yachts were destroyed today when an explosive fire swept through a yacht works and storage building.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Roy Emerson, Fred Stolle, John Newcombe and Tony Roche were named today as Australia's tennis team for the Davis Cup challenge round against Spain in Sydney Dec. 27 through 29.

Dennis Ralston, who hopes to sell a lot of insurance soon, gave California a sweep of the top rankings when he was named No. 1 for the second straight year by the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- Soviet suspicions of Britain's motives in proposing a committee to try to remove the causes of international conflict led the Special Political Committee today to shelve action on it until next year.

Joe Namath's ability as a football player, rather than as a high-salary man, was recognized yesterday when the New York Jets' quarterback won rookie-of-the-year honors in the American Football League.

A letter from a 10-year-old Long Island boy, questioning the title of a Beatles record album, impelled Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to investigate deceptive practices in the recording industry, it was disclosed yesterday.

Harold R. All, the Internal Revenue Service's Commissioner in the North Atlantic Region, appealed to corporate officials yesterday for cooperation in his department's effort to speed up the processing of tax audits, some of which have been pending as long as 15 years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Senator Edward V. Long of Missouri said today that he was considering turning his wiretapping investigation against the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller is convinced that he is erasing a widely held belief that he is an arrogant millionaire who neither understands nor cares about the common man's discontent.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Union gave unstinted praise today to the United States for the Gemini rendezvous, but included a reminder that Russia still holds the lead in some aspects of space technology.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Kennedy's concept of a decade of development will go down in history as a "decade" of disappointment" unless substantially more financing on easier terms is provided by advanced nations to underdeveloped countries, the head of the World Bank warned today.

On Dec. 6, 1964, Greg Larson went down in a football game being lost at the time by his team, the New York Giants, to the Minnesota Vikings. They picked Larson off the turf at Yankee Stadium and hauled him to the locker room.

The Ithaca (N.Y.) Festival has received gifts amounting to $100,000, bringing total contributions to the cultural and recreational center to $250,000. The long-range goal is $4.5 million for the construction of a concert hall, exhibition hall, sculpture court, jazz pavilion and recreational facilities.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 16 -- Texas moved today to encourage oil exploration in the Gulf of Mexico on both state and Federal leases by adopting a special yardstick giving offshore wells bonus production quotas.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

The United States champion, 22-year-old Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn defeated Grand Master Larry Evans of Las Vegas, Nev., a former titleholder, in the third round of the United States chess championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel Wednesday night.

Box holders have been announced for "La Perichole" at the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow night. The season's first performance of the Offenbach opera will benefit the Bagby Music Lovers' Foundation, marking its 40th anniversary.
Cuba today joined other nations yesterday in congratulating the United States on the Gemini space rendezvous.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16 -- A $1.2 billion program for public higher education in New Jersey over the next 10 years was proposed here today by a group of the state's most prominent citizens.

HOUSTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Space agency officials preferred to remain in the dark today about how Capt. Walter M. Schirra Jr. and Maj. Thomas P. Stafford got a harmonica and some tinkling bells aboard Gemini 6.

New York University, employing the scoring punch of Stall McKenzie and the floor generalship of Mal Graham, routed the Gamecocks of South Carolina, 83-66, at Madison Square Garden last night.

" Hooray! It's a Glorious Day and All That" is reported to have the highest capitalization, $60,000, for an Off Broadway musical. The money was raised from 72 backers, many of them from Cleveland, home of the composer, Art Gordon, and one of the lyricists, Ethel Beiber.

MIAMI, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Bugler, once John W. Galbreath's hope for a Kentucky Derby victory this year but now owned by the Circle M. Farm, finally won for his new owner when he scored a neck victory today in the $4,000 feature race at Tropical Park.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Kenya's great distance runner, Kipehoge Keino, will try for the 1.500-meter world record here Sunday and local officials said today he had a great chance of beating Herb Elliote's time of 3 minutes 35.6 seconds.
NEW HYDE PARK, L.I. Dec. 16 -- Seventeen-year-old Martin Custen looked meaningfully at his partner, Nancy, and said pointedly: "By the way, do you have a quarter? I fed the juke box last."
MOSCOW, Dec. 16. -- Nikolai V. Podgorny, the new Soviet chief of state, has given up his high administrative functions in the secretariat of the Soviet Communist party, qualified sources said today.

If the eminence that Somerset Maugham reached in the twenties was not fully sustained in the later decades of his life that is due partly to the fact that he had outlived the era that had made him, partly to his waspish personality, partly to a change in the scale of literary values.
Jeanette Scovotti waltzed away with a triumph last night as Adina in Donizetti's "L'Elisir d'Amore' at the Metropolitan Opera. And the miracle was that she took the role on two days' notice.
ATHENS, Dec. 16 -- A Greek shipowner disclosed today that he had commissioned the Soviet Union to build a $105 million merchant fleet for his company.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 16 -- "Today I cried and I had tears in my eyes and a lot of other people had the same," H.L. (Chuck) Willey said.
DETROIT, Dec. 16 -- Roy Abernethy, president of the American Motors Corporation, predicted today that the market for his "sensible-sized" cars would improve in 1966.
A 17-year-old Negro who was said by relatives and the police to hate whites, was convicted last night of the murder of a white youth in a subway car eight months ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- About 2 million persons are being required to disclaim membership in Communist organizations to qualify for hospital and nursing care benefits under the new Medicare law.

LEBANON, N.H., Dec. 16 -- The approaching weekend is the one on which almost all of the East's ski operators had planned gala openings. Many, however, will keep their doors closed and hope for better luck over the Christmas weekend.

St. John's University dismissed at least 13 faculty members yesterday and notified another that his contract would not be renewed, in a flare-up of the two-year-old controversy over academic freedom at the largest Roman Catholic university in the United States. One of those dismissed was Msgr. John J. Clancy, associate professor of theology and canon law and a former member of the Vatican Secretariat.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Labor Government was urged today to take a majority financial interest in Britain's two biggest aircraft manufacturers.

Southern Illinois University Press will begin in 1967 publication of John Dewey's early works. The University has amassed a collection of the philosopher's writings. A textual edition in five volumes is being prepared which will cover the period 1882-1898, extending from the first article he published when 22, through important works written when he was chairman of the Department of Philosophy at the University of Chicago.

HONG KONG -- The fashion-conscious women of Hong Kong, who get through the months called winter in finely made suits inspired by Chanel and Givenchy and face the summer heat waves in sleeveless versions of Courreges, Saint Laurent and British Mod designers, are often ready to give up the whole thing for a rack of ready-to-wear dresses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Johnson followed the final stages of the flight of Gemini 6 by television today and received a reassuring report on Gemini 7, which is still in orbit.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 16 -- Three men and a woman who allegedly used the name of a dying impoverished cancer victim on installment contracts to defraud 22 banks, car dealers and insurance companies surrendered here today to Federal authorities.
Mstislav Rostropovich will give a cello recital at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:30.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's foreign and defense ministers wound up their year-end meeting today with an agreement on further "consultations" on the threat posed by growing Chinese Communist nuclear strength.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Representative Hale Boggs, assistant Democratic leader of the House, predicted today that the chief emphasis of the next session of Congress would be on the war in Vietnam rather than on domestic programs.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Jean Lecanuet, the middle-of-the-roader who ran third in the first round of the Presidential election Dec. 5, urged his supporters today not to vote for President de Gaulle in Sunday's runoff.

It is unfortunate that the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System chose to increase the rediscount rate from 4 per cent to 4 1/2 per cent. It is doubtful that this action will help the domestic economy; rather it may bring undue maladjustment.
The smallest of the nation's 13 subsidized steamship operators, the Bloomfield Steamship Company, will abandon its Government-supported status at the end of the year.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay went into a poor neighborhood of Brooklyn yesterday to see how the residents felt about their antipoverty program. He found some of them cynical, some of them pleased, and most of them involved in a bitter neighborhood dispute over religion, color and national origin.

OTTAWA, Dec. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Two Cabinet ministers who have long been criticized for furniture purchases on credit from a Montreal concern that later went bankrupt announced their resignations tonight.

The New York Yacht Club cruise, one of the most plush racing fixtures of the Eastern Seaboard, will put into familiar ports in Rhode Island and Massachusetts next summer, according to the itinerary that emerged at the club's annual meeting last night.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 16 -- Malaysia, the world's largest producer of tin, decided today not to sign the third International Tin Agreement, now being negotiated in London.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Labor Government narrowly missed defeat in the House of Commons tonight over plans to reorganize army reserves, which Tories said would "sound the death knell of a citizen volunteer army in Britain."
Jimmy Brown, the Cleveland fullback, heads the 1965 National Football League All-Star team named yesterday by 42 sports writers, three from each league city. He was a unanimous selection.

Jewelry valued at $75,000 was stolen Wednesday from a guest of the Sherry Netherland Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, the police reported yesterday. This makes a total of $246,000 worth of jewelry taken from five East Side hotels in the last seven days.

The most distant gift to the Neediest Cases Fund received yesterday was from Margaret Joy Tibbetts, who sent $50 from Oslo, Norway. WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Seventeen parents have charged that their children have been subjected to anti-Semitic insults and in at least one case attacked by fellow students while traveling by bus to Woodbridge High School.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales totaled $6.64 billion in the week ended Dec. 11, 5 per cent higher than the total in the preceding week and 7 per cent above figures for the comparable 1964 week.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 16 -- Groups of youths went on a rampage through this city's major middle-class shopping area this afternoon, spilling garbage into the streets and tearing down makeshift sidewalk stalls that line the streets during the Christmas season.

One of the most exciting and dramatic moments in television's history came yesterday morning in the live coverage of the recovery in the Atlantic Ocean of the two Gemini 6 astronauts, Capt. Walter M. Schirra Jr. and Maj. Thomas P. Stafford.

Despite a number of large advances by selected issues, the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday. Trading was heavy.
