LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The trans-Atlantic battle for control of Diners' Club, Ltd., reached a climax today with the British raising their offer for shares and the Americans maintaining victory was already in their grasp.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- Prime Minister Wilson demanded today that the United Nations support "to the hilt" for Britain's economic and financial sanctions against Rhodesia. The use of British military forces against Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's regime, urged by many African nations, was again rejected by Mr. Wilson.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 16 -- Between 10,000 and 15,000 persons are believed to have lost their lives in a cyclone and tidal wave that smashed into densely populated East Pakistan early yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Charles H. Percy announced today his candidacy for the Senate seat held by Paul H. Douglas, a liberal Democrat. Mr. Percy, regarded as a moderate Republican, was defeated by Otto Kerner last year when he ran for Governor.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy said yesterday that the financial demands of the war in Vietnam should not be permitted to delay or diminish domestic programs such as the campaign against poverty.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay announced last night that he would reappoint Dr. Alonzo S. Yerby as Commissioner of the Department of Hospitals.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 16 -- As the first space rendezvous moved into history, work on the next big step toward the moon -- docking two ships in obit -- went ahead here today.

" Peace on Earth," a Christmas window exhibition at the I.B.M. Product Display Center at Madison Avenue and 57th Street, has brought not peace but a sword to I.B.M. officials, and they have ordered it closed for modifications.

OTTAWA, Dec. 16 -- Just before leaving for Paris to preside over this week's meeting of the North Atlantic Council, the Secretary of State for External Affairs said his policy for handling the chair would be this: "I shall keep the boat from rocking any more than is nec essary."

HOUSTON, Dec. 16 -- The Gemini 6 astronauts returned from man's first space rendezvous today as they peeled off from Gemini 7 and made a pinpoint splashdown in the Atlantic 700 miles south of Bermuda.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, the City of Philadelphia and the mothers of seven Negro boys asked the Federal District Court here today to end segregation at Girard College.
Five Buildings Department inspectors and five representatives of building owners were indicted here yesterday on charges of bribery and taking unlawful fees.
DELANO, Calif., Dec. 16 -- Walter Reuther promised striking vineyard workers in the southern San Joaquin Valley today a contribution of $5,000 a month for "as long as it takes to win this strike."

Dave Schellhase of Purdue, picked by many experts to win the 1965-66 college basketball scoring race, is headed in the right direction, according to the first week's major college statistics issued yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

I would like to bring to your attention the hazardous condition that is created by automobiles that are parked on the streets within the areas designated as bus stops, especially after 4 P.M. and on weekends.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Johnson and Prime Minister Wilson began today a wide-ranging discussion of important and sensitive problems of concern to the United States and Britain.

MIAMI, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested a Cuban identified with a militant anti-Castro group in connection with the bombing of a Spanish ship in Puerto Rico.
FROM the feathery look of things in stores, there will be lots of marabou feathers around this season. Marabou is being used to trim everything from sleepwear to evening dresses.

Mrs. Esther James, who has been awarded $621,500 in defamation and punitive judgments against Representative Adam Clayton Powell, went back to court yesterday in an attempt to force him to start paying $500 a week installments.
The Seagram Distillers Company will again run a New Year's Eve moderation message in daily newspapers. This year's message is: "Tonight's the night that separates the men from the boys."

While astronauts Borman and Lovell continued their epochal two-week flight around the earth, astronauts Schirra and Stafford yesterday returned safely from their historic rendezvous and formation flying mission. In splashing down so closely to the rescue vessel, the crew of Gemini 6 showed the same high precision that amazed the world when they located Gemini 7 in space and then flew for hours only a few feet away.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Johnson is about to appoint Roger Wilkins, nephew of the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, as director of the Community Relations Service.
A $1 million six-story new home for one of the world's great scientific libraries was dedicated yesterday at the New York Botanical Garden, the Bronx.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Charlie (Chuck) Baltazar, the leading rider at the meeting, scored a triple at Pimlico today. His third winner was Steve Leo Jr., in the featured $7,500 J.S. Skinner purse.
The Minerals Chemicals Philipp Corporation and the Georgia Marble Company have reached an understanding principle looking toward a consolidation of their businesses.

HOUSTON, Dec. 16 -- Physicians reported today that no serious physical or psychological problem had arisen so far in the scheduled two-week flight designed to find out if men are as ready as machines to go to the moon.
The legislative committee that has been trying all week to serve a subpoena on Robert Moses expects to succeed this morning.
The University of Kentucky sold yesterday $26.9 million of revenue bonds yesterday to finance construction of 10 new dormitories, including one 23 stories tall.

The acquisition of the United States Vitamin and Pharmaceutical Company by Revlon, Inc., was approved by shareholders of both companies yesterday. The approval authorized the creation of a new class of Revlon stock, a preferred issue bearing a $1 annual dividend.

The Grand Ballroom of the Plaza was decked with holly branches and evergreen boughs for last evening's Christmas Pearl Gala, benefitting the New York Chapter of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children.
Charlotte McDonnell Ford, older daughter of Henry Ford 2d, was married yesterday in Mexico to Stavros Spiros Niarchos, the Greek shipping magnate, who is 32 years her senior.
There appears to be no end to the use of art these days in corporate promotions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Pacifica Foundation -- whose radio stations figured in a landmark defense of freedom of speech in broadcasting by the Federal Communications Commission -- got its wrists slapped by the same commission today.

DECATUR, Ga., Dec. 16 (UPI) -- A jury found Walter O. Brooks, a state parole board member, innocent of murder today, accepting his testimony that he was gnawed by fear the night he killed a man who had accused him of fathering his former wife's unborn child.

MILAN, Dec. 16 -- The merger of Montecatini and Edison of Italy, two chemical giants, has received the informal approval of the Government and will be shortly proposed to the stockholders of both companies.
DETROIT, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers signed Al Kaline, Willie Horton and five other players to 1966 contracts today.
Norman Blankman, founder of the Long Island Arts Center and a controversial figure on the Nassau County arts scene, resigned yesterday as the center's president. He will remain on its board.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 16 -- South Vietnamese Government militiamen supported by giant bombers and naval gunfire repulsed an attack yesterday on their small outpost in Quangngai Province, 315 miles north of Saigon, killing 39 attackers and capturing 9.

Evidence from several European capitals, including Moscow, suggests that favorable conditions may be emerging for significant progress on the related problems of nuclear sharing in the Western alliance and an antiproliferation agreement with the Soviet Union.

Eggs flew through the air, a "cherry bomb" exploded and several fist fights broke out yesterday during a 90-minute picket demonstration in Times Square protesting United States involvement in the Vietnam war.
Who's gonna start this old town a' humming?
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers placed their most seasoned quarterback, Ed Brown, on waivers today. He was immediately claimed by the Baltimore Colts.
A new code of installation standards for electric furnaces and heat pumps has been adopted by the Long Island Climate Control Council.
The Carrier Corporation gave shareholders a pre-Christmas package yesterday.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Nick Scalera, a reporter for The Newark Evening News, fought a $2 overtime parking ticket here last night, and now motorists may find they have been feeding the town's parking meters for the last 24 years in vain.
The stock market climbed above November's historic peak toward 1 o'clock yesterday, but a late selling wave pushed prices down to a closing level only slightly higher than Wednesday's.
New measures to improve instruction and promote racial integration in the city school system were proposed yesterday by three top-level staff committees appointed by the Superintendent of Schools:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Five men from Meridian, Miss., filed suit today in United States District Court, asking $5 million from Time, Inc., for an article about the murders of three civil rights workers last year.
YONKERS, Dec. 16 -- A man suspected of stealing thousands of dollars from churches in the metropolitan area was arrested today after an alert salesman spotted him in a White Plains automobile agency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Federal Food and Drug Administration said today that analyses of the water in novelty ice-ball coolers imported from Hong Kong had shown no significant amounts of disease-causing organisms.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- Newcomb Mott, a 27-year-old tourist from Sheffield, Mass., lost today his appeal against an 18-month prison sentence imposed on charges that he had entered the Soviet Union illegally.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Johnson and President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan have parted with a delicate and tentative understanding -- to try to trust one another in their respective dealings with India and Communist China.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 16 -- The Laotian Government has privately voiced opposition to the use of American troops to seal off the Communist corridor in southeastern Laos through which North Vietnam sends reinforcements to the Vietcong.
CAIRO, Dec. 16 -- Peace talks between Yemen's republicans and royalists, deadlocked since they began nearly a month ago, are being adjourned until late in January, reports from Yemen indicated today.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The French have an old and proud French institute in London stocked with 60,000 volumes. The Italians have a handsome Italian institute with 26,000. The Germans have a busy German institute with 12,000. The Russians make a big thing of selling books cheap.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The inventor of the telephone, America's top World War I ace and six other pioneers in aviation were named tonight to the Aviation Hall of Fame.

ATLANTA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Georgia Association of Independent Insurance Agents, Inc., filed a suit in United States District Court today seeking to void a ruling by Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon, which permits national banks in cities of more than 5,000 residents to sell and write insurance.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A drum-shaped interplanetary explorer named Pioneer 6 rocketed into orbit about the sun today and radioed back good quality information that might help unlock mysteries of the solar system.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16 -- The Ford Foundation has made a grant of $2 million to Harvard University toward the projected John F. Kennedy Institute of Politics.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 16 -- Haggard and bone-tired, David Lean this week wound up a two-month long round-the-clock ordeal that has awed much of the movie colony here.

A magazine wanted to give him the cover-boy treatment and the big rookie fullback of the New York Giants of the National Football League showed no inclination to cooperate when Don Smith, the chairman of the arrangements committee, tried to set up the operation.

LAST summer, when there was a bit of turmoil about the future of the Hudson River fishery and the ways it might be affected by the Consolidated Edison high-water pumping impoundment proposal at Cornwall, N.Y., a research project was initiated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A Federal Power Commission examiner supported today an application by the Gulf Pacific Pipeline Company of Houston to build a $314-million pipeline to carry natural gas from Texas to Southern California for use by two electric utilities.

DARTMOUTH has its Winter Carnival and Barnard its Greek Games, but the equivalent at the Fashion Institute of Technology, a two-year community college that prepares students for jobs in the textile and apparel industry, is a fashion show.
A major attraction at the World's Fair will be retained as a permanent feature of Flushing Meadow Park in Queens. But another will not be kept because of high operating and maintenance costs.
The New Leadership Division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York will give a ball called the Winterendezvous at the Sheraton-East on Dec. 29.
The Board of Estimate rebuffed Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday in his efforts to have two major projects deferred until he has a chance to study them.
THE hot pursuit of nautical cowboys in New York would become hotter under a bill being prepared for pre-filing with the State Legislature.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A 79-year-old school dropout, Robert A. Wright is about to receive his university degree after 56 years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Negro physicians and the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., asked the Government today to use Medicare funds as a weapon to combat racial discrimination in health facilities.
Dr. Benjamin Spock, the pediatrician, yesterday lost his fight to prevent the inclusion of advertising in his book, "Baby and Child Care."
BRUSSELS, Dec. 16 -- The Chase Manhattan Bank has signed an agreement that will give it almost a half interest in a strategically situated Belgian bank.

Paul Hardeman, Inc., the construction and auto equipment company, which for the last year has been undergoing a financial reorganization, has obtained a new $6 million, one year loan from the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- United States combat deaths in the Vietnamese war, totaling 1,496 as of last Monday, are below the official estimates given to President Johnson last July.
Bond prices rose a little yesterday for the second consecutive day, but the market was slowing down perceptibly toward a year-end holiday lull.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today its intention to ease somewhat its restrictions on the interest that savings and loan associations may pay.
Rene Verdon, the famed chef engaged for the White House in the Kennedy Administration, has submitted his resignation to the present occupants, effective at the end of the year.

Tipton, president of the Air Transportation Association.

The Gulf Oil Corporation has notified the Libyan Government that it required further time to consider whether it would accept the new oil law. So far, Gulf is the only major international company that has not agreed to the new law which is designed to increase the Government's revenue from oil operations.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17 -- A Federal court ended hearings into the racial composition of Southern juries today with two judges warning that more Negroes must be called for jury duty.

DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Gov. Abdul Monem Khan of East Pakistan said today that 750 persons were missing or dead after Wednesday's cyclone along the east coast. Unconfirmed reports put the figure far higher.

HOUSTON, Dec. 17 -- Pictures taken during the 185-mile-high rendezvous of Gemini 6 and Gemini 7 over the Pacific Ocean on Wednesday were released here today by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 17 -- The best estimates available here make it appear doubtful that oil sanctions can force an economic slowdown in Rhodesia in less than six months.
An 81-year-old retired garment maker died in the hallway of his Brooklyn apartment house yesterday while trying to ward off two muggers.
DELANO, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Pickets went to their posts at vineyards in this sprawling southern San Joaquin Valley district today with new hope.

PECANS for use in holiday baked goods are expected to be less expensive that at any time in the last year because the crop is estimated at 263.8 million pounds, compared with 173.6 million pounds in 1964, according to the United State Department of Agriculture.
Two young Brooklyn convicts dramatically changed their plea in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday and admitted that they had offered a $1,000 bribe to a Housing Authority patrolman who arrested them.

The $60 that members of the Port of New York Authority's Organization and Procedures Department calculated they would spend on Christmad cards for each other was received by the Neediest Cases fund yesterday.

The huskily built, middle-aged Chief Clerk of the Federal Court of the Southern District of New York, sat in his chair in the oak-paneled courtroom of the United States Court House yesterday and then rose with 200 others as the 16 Federal judges, in judicial black robes, filed into the courtroom.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 17 -- Rhodesia's fiscal position was made shakier today by the freezing of the country's hard-currency assets in Swiss banks.
The General Theological Seminary announced yesterday the retirement of the Rev. Dr. Lawrence Rose, dean of the Episcopal divinity school since 1947.

ROME, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Undefeated Nino Benvenuti of Italy retained the world junior middleweight boxing championship tonight by outpointing the countryman he had dethroned, Sandro Mazzinghi, in a 15-rounder in the Sports Palace.

IN AN age when mental health is so eagerly pursued that there are not enough psychoanalytic hours to go around, the pressure for more efficient techniques of therapy has risen. Department of Defense requirements for privately owned merchant ships in the Vietnam war are mounting steadily, and the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service announced last night that it had signed 12 more ship charters in the last two days.

During World War II the Army had a category for men suited to accomplish a day's work under certain circumstances, yet physically incapable of meeting the rigors of full military duty. Thousands of G.I.'s performed honorably and well as desk men, drivers and the like in the Limited Service Classification, though examining physicians had found them medically unfit for overseas combat or even for field duty on home ground.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Yarmouth Castle's telephone operator says linen and cans of fuel were stored in Room 610, a room that other crewmen said was empty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -The index of wholesale primary market prices rose two-tenths of 1 per cent to 104.0 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Dec. 14, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods moved higher in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

The appointment of Eugene E. Black as general manager for the European division of Sea-Land Service, Inc., was announced yesterday by Michael R. McEvoy, president of the subsidiary of McLean Industries, Inc.
R.H. Macy Co., Inc., will build a 250,000-square-foot department store at a regional shopping center owned by Sears, Roebuck Co., in Nanuet, N.Y., Wheelock H. Bingham, president, announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Defense attorneys formally petitioned today for a mistrial in the eight-month-old Krebiozen fraud trial but were overruled by Federal District Judge Julius J. Hoffman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- An advanced party of American scientists and Navy men landed by airplane early today on a desolate icecap 630 miles from the South Pole. They plan to establish the nation's most remote scientific outpost.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that net debit balances -- the amount of cash that customers have borrowed from brokers to finace stock purchases -- jumped to $5.23 billion at the end of November from $4.88 billion at the end of October.

SOONER or later the vogue of pop art was bound to ricochet back to the practice of commercial mural painting. If not the first to effect this marriage between highbrow pop and lowbrow mural art, Willard Cummings is certainly one of the more ambitious contenders.

Consolidated net earnings of the Standard Prudential Corporation for the year ended Oct. 31, totaled $1 million, equal to 80 cents a share, on the 1,261,522 class A shares outstanding. No comparison with the previous fiscal year was available.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -A Washington orthopedic surgeon was granted a patent this week for a method of mending broken bones and damaged skin with plastic glue. WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Walt Disney Productions has been awarded a preliminary permit for a $35 million development of the Mineral King area in the Sequoia National Forest in California as a year-round recreation facility.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -The United States announced today a reduction in tariffs on 23 items imported mainly from Canada. The concessions to Canada were made in compensation for some tariff increases that were an incidental result of recent changes in United States tariff schedules.

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Dec. 17 -- With Emile Francis complaining, ridiculing and praising, the New York Rangers skated through their toughest workout of the National Hockey League season today.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 17 -- The four-day-old strike by Government sugar workers was settled today.

A contemplated merger of two Italian chemical giants, Montecatini and Edison, sent prices down on the Milan stock market yesterday. Prices were down most of the day but recovered somewhat near the close.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- The Security Council voted unanimously tonight to continue the peacekeeping force in Cyprus for another six months.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The announcement by Sir Frank Soskice, Britain's Home Secretary, that he intends to retire at the end of the present parliament has increased chances for a reshuffling of the Cabinet in the next few weeks.
ALBANY Dec. 17 -- Two doctors who experimentally injected cancer cells into elderly patients have been placed on probation for a year by the State Board of Regents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -Prime Minister Wilson assured President Johnson today that Britain would make a renewed effort to obtain peace in Southeast Asia.

FROM a fashion point of view, Brigitte Bardot won't do.

Two thousand acres of open space fall to the bulldozers on an average week in the New York metropolitan area. So much attention has been accorded to television by satellite that radio by satellite has been almost ignored. Yet the idea of bouncing voices through space could have formidable repercussions in international communications, and recently there has been a major development on the audio front.

KAUAI, Maui, Molokai, Oahu and Hawaii are names with an insidiously inviting sound to New Yorkers enveloped in cold, damp weather at this time of the year. Who wouldn't prefer to be on any one of these islands, which make up our 50th state?

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18 -- The lack of a standout stakes race did not deter 16,855 fans from visiting the Pimlico race track today. All he got that year, however, was a 25-cent Fordson, a cast-iron toy tractor.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 18 -- The modernization of the heart of this 300-year-old city at a cost of more than $39 million has been proposed to check its economic decline.
A 28-year-old father of five children went to the aid of a Brooklyn holdup victim early yesterday and was shot to death by a robber.

NOW the holly wreath hangs on the door; and the candle shines in the window. The city glitters with the Christmas light, for this is the season when the home and the heart take over as loved ones gather for the holiday.
DETROIT, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Andy Bathgate scored two goals and assisted on a third tonight in pacing the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.
Students and their professors joined ranks yesterday to march with picket signs in front of St John's University in rehearsal for a teachers' strike called for Jan. 3.
About 15 dissident church-goers yesterday picketed the headquarters of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America at 10 East 79th Street.

NEWARK, Dec. 18 -- A police sergeant who was wounded while trying to prevent a robbery at a savings and loan association was promoted to lieutenant today while he lay paralyzed from the waist down in a hospital bed.

MADRID, Dec. 18 -- Like the little match girl in Hans Christian Andersen's tale, Spain seems at first sight to be pressing her face against the window pane of Western Europe, still out in the cold, still hoping to be asked to come in.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- The Baltimore Colts, successfully utilizing two makeshift quarterbacks, Tom Matte and Ed Brown, defeated the Los Angeles Rams, 20-17, today to keep their hopes alive in the Western Conference race of the National Football League.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A major Congressional debate on Vietnam is expected to take place almost as soon as the House and Senate reconvene next month.
In the city of New York the dedication of a building is so commonplace that it usually holds significance and interest only for those intimately identified with the building's use.

MIAMI BEACH -- The American Hotel and Motel Association closed its 54th annual convention here by endorsing the "Discover America" program created by private travel organizations for the specific purpose of promoting tourism within the United States.
Air conditioning, a fireplace and three tons of batteries are part of the equipment of a luxurious 75-foot steel motor sailer launched recently at Tarpon Springs, Fla.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 -- The United States military command tonight ordered all American servicemen to keep off the streets of Saigon between 7 P.M. and 6 A.M. daily as a precaution against intensified Vietcong terrorism.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Johnson appointed Harold Howe 2d as United States Commissioner of Education today.

Governor Rockefeller made public a telegram to Senator Robert F. Kennedy yesterday accusing him of acting like a "political broker" on the subject of Federal involvement in New York's programs for the mentally retarded.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- An upside-down income tax approach to the problem of poverty that is attracting growing attention in Government circles as a possible long-range technique was explained this week by its author.

The most widely accepted definition of academic freedom is the "Statement of Principles" adopted in 1940 by the American Association of University Professors jointly with the Association of American Colleges.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- The intensified United States air offensive against North Vietnam and public discussion of troop reinforcements for South Vietnam are believed by some diplomats here to be behind Hanoi's denial today that it made a peace approach last month.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Nichols School upset first-seeded Belmont Hill School, the defending champion, 2-1, today to win the 18th annual Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament.
Australis, only a year out of the green division, piled up 1,122 points to win horse-of-the-year honors in the open jumper division in the American Horse Shows Association annual listing.

LOAVES of French bread floating past a window. A nude partitioned into five parts. A wall-to-wall apple in a room. In the 40-odd years that the Belgian surrealist Rene Magritte has been painting these disquieting riddles, he has rarely left his quiet home in a residential section of Brussels.

ATHENS, Dec. 18 -- Had it not been for World War II, Achilles Nicholas Franghistas would probably still be a successful gynecologist in Athens. Yesterday it was disclosed that he had placed orders worth $105 million with Soviet shipyards for a 600,000-ton merchant fleet.

HONOLULU, Dec. 18 -- Adm. U.S. Grant Sharp, Pacific commander in chief, now has an airborne communications post to direct America's forces in the Pacific and Asia in the event ground communications in Hawaii are disrupted by enemy attack or a natural disaster.
JENSEN BEACH, Fla. -- Two major highway improvements have greatly enhanced this area's convenience and attractiveness as a vacation spot.

WHATEVER else Richard Stern intends to do, he is apparently not going to repeat himself. His novels and stories display a wide variety of subjects and an almost equal number of different techniques in which to express them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower jauntily walked out of the hospital today, predicting he will be playing golf within a month.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- Gov. William W. Scranton signed legislation this week that upgraded Indiana State College in western Pennsylvania to Indiana University of Pennsylvania.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 18 -- Gov. Philip H. Hoff wants to keep Vermont unspoiled. He plans to ask the reapportioned Legislature, called into special session next month, to approve legislation establishing "scenic corridors" along the Federal Interstate Highway System in Vermont and 11 intermediate-traffic highways.

Charles Ufford of the Harvard Club, the defending champion, and Steven Vehslage of the Racquet and Tennis Club, the national titleholder, advanced to the semi-finals yesterday in the New York State squash racquets championship at the New York Athletic Club.

TWO Queens schools, one an old old hand at winning track events, the other new to the winner's circle, set meet records last night in the 16th annual Catholic High Schools Relay Carnival at the 102d Engineers Armory.

NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Vince Dooley, Georgia's football coach, turned down the head football coaching job today at Oklahoma.

BONN, Dec. 18 -- West Germany's five outside financial advisers warned today that the West Germans were beginning to lose faith in the stability of the Deutsche mark and urged both federal and local governments to cut down spending.

Sidewalks were almost obliterated yesterday along midtown Fifth Avenue and in Herald Square as huge crowds of shoppers, augmented by thousands of tourists, milled in and around stores on the last Saturday before Christmas.

The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers is offering again in 1966 four graduate scholarships to men in the maritime industry primarily for advanced studies in naval architecture and marine engineering.
RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 18 (AP) -- State Senator Walter Jones overwhelmed four opponents today and won the Democratic nomination for Congress in North Carolina's First District.

THERE'LL be less panic in the television business this week: A.C. Nielsen is taking a holiday from compiling ratings. Television show people don't have to be concerned whether anyone is watching for the next seven days or even if this week's program is a bomb. It will never show up in the national Nielsen report.
A dinner dance will be held New Year's Eve in the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver.

HOUSTON, Dec. 18 -- "Better than expected" was the first medical report from the aircraft carrier Wasp shortly after Comdr. James A. Lovell Jr. and Lieut. Col. Frank Borman went aboard today after almost two weeks in space.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the defender, took the lead in the United States Chess Championship tournament last night with a score of 4 1/2-1/2.
TORONTO, Dec. 19 -- The annual statements of Canada's eight banks are as predictably cheery as Christmas. But this year, visions of higher earnings draw mostly yawns from investors.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Eddie Shack scored two goals tonight and led the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-1 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.

Robert Price, the inexhaustible young lawyer who managed John V. Lindsay's mayoral campaign, is finding the problems of arranging a transition in city government a lot rougher than running a campaign.
Pressure mounted sharply yesterday to strip the profitable Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority of its autonomy and make it part of a unified transportation system.
The best two appointments Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay has made so for -- in the considered opinion of his predecessor are the two men he has decided to hold over from the Wagner administration.

" Big Brother" has been watching customers of banks and department stores for a number of years. He watches, by means of television cameras, to make sure that nothing is picked up and carried out of the store or bank.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 19 (AP) -- State Senator Walter Jones scored a smashing victory in North Carolina's First District Democratic Congressional primary last night, but a Negro woman who was runner-up said today she believed "this is the starting point for Negroes."

LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 19 -President Kenneth D. Kaunda dispatched a special mission to London, Washington and Moscow today to press for a United Nations resolution calling for mandatory sanctions plus force to topple Rhodesia's rebel regime.
Fifteen Sunday painters brightened up part of Lincoln Hospital yesterday in what the incoming Lindsay administration hopes will be the beginning of a series of volunteer projects for city betterment.
NEWARK, Dec. 19 -- Charles A. Matthews, a. 48-year-old Negro, has been chosen director of the Essex County Board of Freeholders by the Democratic majority on the board.

The call issued yesterday by Pope Paul VI for a cease-fire, followed by negotiations to end the fighting in Vietnam, ought to provide the impetus for a fresh attempt to restore peace in Southeast Asia. The Pope's plea focuses on a Christmas lull, but -- welcome as any suspension of the death toll would be -- so short a halt would obviously be little more than symbolic.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Len Dawson's passing and Curtis McClinton's receiving carried the Kansas City Chiefs to a 45-35 victory over Denver today in the final American Football League game for both clubs.

ABOARD U.S.S. WASP, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Gemini 7 command pilot, Lieut. Col. Frank Borman, said today it appeared to him that his spaceship got to within three feet of Gemini 6 as the two vehicles flew nose-to-nose through space.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 19 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan asked the Pakistani press today to halt its "irresponsible criticism" of the United States.

Doug Stay scored five goals, including two of the quickest consecutive scores in Eastern collegiate hockey history, to lead Colgate to an 8-4 triumph yesterday over Yale in the first round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Hockey Festival at Madison Square Garden.

The Board of Deacons of Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church has called for the removal of a judge who said of Representative Adam Clayton Powell: "He's like a mackerel; he shines but he smells to high heaven."

A weekend announcement gave further indication of the beginning of a trend toward wider availability of the variable annuity, a relatively new weapon against inflationary erosion of retirement income.
TULSA, Okla., Dec. 19 (UPI) -- The story of how a 17-year-old boy with the I.Q. of a genius spent 12 years in a school for mentally retarded unfolded here today.

A Sicilian judge who has been investigating connections between the Mafia and the American underworld arrived here last night from Rome to confer with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Narcotics Bureau and Joseph Valachi, a key figure in the crime syndicate known as Cosa Nostra.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Don Breaux, a reserve quarterback, hit Lance Alworth on a 66-yard pass-run play in the last quarter to give the San Diego Chargers a 24-14 triumph over the Oakland Raiders.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Goldie, the golden eagle on the run from the London Zoo since Wednesday, was recaptured in Regent's Park today. He could not resist a dead white rat put out for him by his keeper, Derek Wood. Goldie swooped and Mr. Wood managed to grab the wings and finally the claws.

HONG KONG, Dec. 19 -- Communist China hailed the fifth anniversary of the South Vietnam National Front for Liberation, the political arm of the Vietcong, with an outpouring of congratulatory comments today and a rally in Peking that pledged resolute Chinese support for the Communist insurgents.
MOSCOW, Dec. 19 Algeria and the Soviet Union have concluded a week of official talks with signs that the warm relations of former President Ahmed Bell Bella's time have not been fully restored.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Navy is getting swift delivery of a small fleet of plastic boats that were designed for pleasure but will be used in the war in Vietnam.

Unpleasant as the prospect may be, both merchants and consumers must face up to it -- December and the holiday season generally attract the year's largest number of customer complaints and adjustments. The figure is likely to be about 14 per cent of the year's total. In addition, the pace will not cease with New Year's Day, for January is the second largest month in terms of customer complaints.

COLOMBEY-LES-DEUX-EGLISES, France, Dec. 19 -- At 8:10 o'clock this morning, when most of the 191 voters in this village were still having cafe au lait and croissants, Charles and Yvonne de Gaulle were the first voters to arrive at the tiny lage Hall here.
Need for reform within the ranks of labor is clear after reading David Jones's disturbing news survey of the A.F.L.C.I.O. on Dec. 3 and his follow-up in your Dec. 16 issue.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Frank Ryan threw a 24-yard touchdown pass to Tom Hutchinson as the Cleveland Browns, who had to play the last half without Jim Brown, rallied today and beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 27-24, in a National Football League game.

Bronx District Attorney Isidore Dollinger was criticized yesterday by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for the way he has handled the case of Gareth Mar tinis. The association charged Mr. Dollinger with failing to follow usual procedures and allowing a double-jeopardy issue to arise; failure to provide help requested by his trial assistant; haste in bringing the case to trial, and inadequate presentation of prosecution witnesses.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Tom Nowatzke, a rookie who had carried the ball 12 times in 13 games, and Bob Felts, a defensive back pressed into service on offense, led the Detroit Lions to a 35-28 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles today in the closing National Football League game for both teams.
ROME, Dec. 19 -- Pope Paul VI called today for the acceptance of a Christmas truce in Vietnam. He said he hoped it would be followed by reflection, negotiation and finally peace.
Stan Getz, the jazz saxophonist, played from a wheel chair last night at Carnegie Hall.
A surge in demand for products and services next year from both the public and private sectors of the economy was forecast yesterday by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A reporter who broke the story last week of a reported Hanoi peace feeler declined today to be drawn into a discussion over whether its publication might have torpedoed possible negotiations.
NuTone, Inc., announced over the weekend that negotiations had begun for the acquisition of the Lightcraft-General Company, a California manufacturer of lighting fixtures and lamps.
A Harlem clergyman who has helped rehabilitate narcotics addicts urged Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday to retain Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick.
DAYALPUR, India, Dec. 19 -- Diwaker Dutt Tiwari bought 90 pounds of gram seeds last month to plant on his tiny plot here, but he and his family have eaten 60 pounds of them.

WALTER BROWNE of Erasmas High, a rated United States master, won the senior high school individual championship, scoring 5 1/2-1/2 in a six-round Swiss system. His nearest rival in the 32- man field was Sal Matera of Brooklyn Prep, who finished a half-point behind for second place with 5-1.
The student council of St. John's University yesterday expressed its "extreme displeasure" at the dismissal of 23 faculty members.

In a Dec. 7 editorial ("Allocating Science Funds") The New York Times calls for "better public information about the nation's total program for support of science, the nature of the choices that are being made and the reasons for those choices."

There was no surprise this time, unless it was the handsome margin by which General de Gaulle was re-elected. But neither he nor France will ever be quite the same again. The indecisive election of two weeks ago, in which the President failed to get a majority, was a landmark in contemporary French history.
James S. Schoff will retire as chief executive officer of Bloomingdale's on Feb. 1 and will be succeeded by Lawrence Lachman, president, who will also continue in that post.
" Will our resources of land, water, air, timber, rangeland, wildlife, recreation, and scenery sustain us in the year 2000?"
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $96,180,113,987. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
ESSEN, Germany -- The chronic distress of the Ruhr coal industry has become acute. The crisis is political as well as commercial.

The Lincoln Center Fund has received $212,500 for its student awards program, which enables 1,000 metropolitan area high school seniors to attend performances and participate in discussions with artists.
LOS ANGELES (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Lakers pulled away in the last period to defeat the San Francisco Warriors, 132-120, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

A suit to enjoin the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority from building a 950-car addition to the Battery Parking Garage has been started by parking lot owners in the area. Ground for the project was broken Saturday.

ALAN RICH of New York and Mark Berger of Great Neck won the Master Pairs Flight A event in the Greater New York Bridge Association's winter tournament that ended at the New York Hilton Hotel last night. Second were the New York partnership of Fred Dossenbach and Jay Wendt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Republican party leadership suggested today that "urban political machines" might be responsible for some of the increase in crime, because "citizens feel no sense of loyalty to governments dominated by such machines."

NANUET, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The argot of the heroin addict, studded with words like "spike" and "connection," echoed through a tranquil Roman Catholic retreat house here this weekend, as more than a dozen young New York women met to talk about the habit they are fighting.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 19 -- Dominican Government troops attacked a hotel in Santiago de los Caballeros this morning where leaders of last summer's rebel movement were attending a breakfast reception.

TEHERAN, Iran -- In 11 years, the international consortium that in 1954 took over the development of the newly nationalized oil fields of southwestern Iran has increased production more than five fold.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The premature disclosure of an indirect exchange of messages between North Vietnam and the United States over possible peace negotiations will not prejudice further contacts with the Hanoi Government, Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative at the United Nations, said today.

NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The University of Oklahoma, spurned by two head coaches in its search for a man to take over the chore of rebuilding its football fortunes, is turning to the assistant coaching ranks.
Britain has been locked in a struggle to bring down the Rhodesian Government since Prime Minister Smith declared the country independent on Nov. 11 in what London called an act of rebellion.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19 -- United States Army and Marine units fought major engagements with Vietcong guerrillas late yesterday on battlefields in three sections of South Vietnam.

CYRIL RITCHARD brought his old magic back to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night as he put the Viceroy of Peru through his paces in Offenbach's "La Perichole." Though his reedy baritone could not be called singing by Met standards, it was music to these ears.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 19 -- The 32 winners of Rhodes Scholarships for 1966, including 10 from Harvard and two from Yale, were announced here today.

In defense of their actions in Vietnam members of the Administration often cite opinion polls which indicate that a majority of Americans support Government foreign policy, and they emphasize the small size of their opposition.
Three $1 bills sent by four suburban children were recorded along with a $26,994.98 trust fund payment yesterday as contributions to the Neediest Cases fund.
PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Dec. 19 -- An ill-coordinated revolt by dissident mountain tribesmen against the South Vietnamese authorities in the Central Highlands apparently collapsed today.
The visit of the Royal Danish Ballet, which ended its month's session at the New York State Theater. Lincoln Center, last night has been wonderfully successful.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Rutgers University announced tonight that it had rejected the appointment of a novelist as a writer-in-residence because he refused to sign a loyalty oath required of all employes.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 19 -- Slapping one another and offering mutual congratulations, the four Gemini astronauts were reunited here today and spent 45 minutes reliving their historic rendezvous.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Australia's Davis Cup hopes took an upward run today when it completed a 3-1 victory over the United States in a two-day international tennis match.

Sherman J. Maisel's testimony before the Joint Economic Committee that the Federal Reserve Board's decision to raise the discount-rate was an "irresponsible use of independence" and that he was "shocked" by the board's lack of coordination (The Times, Dec. 14) raises the issue of how far the right of dissent may be carried and still be consonant with a United States official's responsibility to uphold our governmental institutions.

WHO would ever have expected to see Brigitte Bardot and Jeanne Moreau, the two most formi-DA-ble female figures now disporting in French films, caught up in the sort of wild adventures that used to engage Bing Crosby and Bob Hope in one of the boys' outrageous old "Road" films.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 -- New Yorkers who have been inconvenienced by the water shortage have the consolation of being in the limelight at a historic juncture in the development of the nation's vital resources.

CHATEAU-CHINON, France, Dec. 19 -- The Mayor of this little farming town in the heart of France cast his vote shortly after noon today and then, because the sun had broken through a gray sky, decided on a walking visit to his town's problem sites and beauty spots.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19 -- The seven silvery C-123 transport planes that fly low-level defoliation missions in South Vietnam have been shot at and patched with bits of red metal so often that they look as though they have measles.
One of the world's leading churchmen said yesterday that despite all efforts to keep God out of the world. He is here to stay.

A shipment of 9,500 tons of raw Rhodesian sugar that originally was to have been discharged here this week is being unloaded at Hamburg, West Germany, from the Panamanian-flag Liberty ship Pericles G.C.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Rip Hawkins intercepted a desperation pass by Rudy Bukich today and dashed 35 yards for a touchdown with barely a minute to play to carry the Minnesota Vikings to a 24-17 upset of the Chicago Bears.
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 19 -- A city patrolman with a record of outstanding police work will have a smaller paycheck this month because he pawned his service revolver for $30 to make a mortgage payment.
Big round-faced men in 10-gallon hats and even bigger men wearing football uniforms were whooping in the Dallas Cowboys' dressing room at the Stadium yesterday after their victory over the Giants.
The father of a 19-year-old soldier now in basic training has been rebuffed in his attempts to get his son and the boy's 40 barracks mates home for Christmas.

IN his new job as United States Commissioner of Education, Harold Howe 2d will have a broad stage on which to display his many roles -- the hardbitten woodsman, the ad libbing television performer, the modern administrator, the crafty cabinet-maker, the educational reformer, the patient fisherman.

Following a 200-pound Hanukkah Menorah carried aloft by alternating teams of four husky youths, 1,000 persons marched in protest yesterday against the Soviet Union's suppression of Jewish religious and cultural rights.

Vivien Leigh, who last appeared here in the musical version of "Tovarich" in 1963, will be co-starred with John Gielgud in "Ivanov." The Chekhov drama will begin a limited Broadway engagement the week of April 11.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A major political dilemma for President Johnson may be shaping up on the question of a tax increase in 1966.

TOKYO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the lower house of Japan's Diet, or Parliament, resigned today in a move to end the paralysis of parliamentary activity brought about by the forced passage of the Japan-South Korea diplomatic treaty.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Willie Mays was at the home of the San Francisco Giants' manager, Herman Franks, today for what Franks termed an "indefinite rest" after the 34-year-old Giant star collapsed in a faint yesterday in a downtown theater while promoting the Job Corps.

Eighteen prominent New Yorkers, including Mayor Wagner, Judge Francis Bergan of the Court of Appeals and former Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore have been selected to map plans for the 1967 Constitutional Convention.
Leopold Stokowski pulled out all the stops yesterday, afternoon, giving his American Symphony Orchestra audience, in Carnegie Hall a lavish musical Christmas party.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- The Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department will submit legislation next month for reforming the jury system in the South.

MANILA -- The Grand Prix for Philippine designers is on and the couturiers who dress Manila society are all entered, some with a creditable track record and others who would need a miracle to make the finish line.

MIAMI, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Southeast Florida officials said today that they would seek to extradite from Maryland a nephew of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower. He is charged with writing more than $11,000 in worthless checks in this state.
The city has six traveling salesmen roving the world to drum up trade for its hotels, which are suffering from a decline in business.

Don Meredith, a big Texas quarterback who has had a lot of growing pains in his six seasons in the National Football League, seemed 9 feet tall in Yankee Stadium yesterday as he led his team, tile Dallas Cowboys, to a 38-20 victory over the New York Giants.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United States will insist as part of any world grains agreement that other major nations, including importing nations, share in the cost of providing food for poor countries.

United States-flag passenger liners will have to add inflatable liferafts and additional qualified lifeboatmen under new sea safety regulations now in force, according to Coast Guard safety officials.
ATHENS, Dec. 19 -- The General Assembly resolution on Cyprus was hailed in Greece today.

When John W. Gardner became Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, there was widespread speculation whether even so talented an administrator could reform the sprawling colossus without subdividing it into two or more departments.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19 -- The streets of Saigon were almost deserted tonight as a dusk-to-dawn curfew for United States military personnel went into effect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany arrived today for what are expected to be two days of useful though not decisive conversations with President Johnson and other United States officials.
The city school system has received a $135,000 Federal grant to retrain about 500 Negro teachers displaced by school desegregation in the South so they can qualify to teach here.

HOUSTON, Dec. 19 -- Encouraged by the successes of Gemini 6 and Gemini 7, space agency officials turned with glowing confidence today to their plans for the first Apollo mooncraft test flights early next year.
Galina Vishnevskaya, the Soviet soprano, gave a gem of a recital yesterday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall, her only local one of the current season.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 19 -- M.J. Frankovich, vice president for world production of Columbia Pictures, announced over the weekend that Barbra Streisand would make her screen debut in "Funny Girl." The film will be produced by Ray Stark.

THE Dallas Cowboys looped a neat lasso on the New York Giants at Yankee Stadium yesterday, expertly hog-tied the Baby Bulls and left them to bellow unhappily in the frozen North while the Texans headed for Miami. The Cowboys whomped the Giants, 38-20, tied them for second place in the East and gained the right to advance to the postseason game between the divisional runners-up a few weeks hence.

Miss Elizabeth Stuyvesant Hicks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Livingston Hicks 3d of Greenwich, Conn., was one of several debutantes honored at private parties last night. Hers was a dinner dance given in the Versailles Suite of the St. Regis by her grandparents, Robert Winthrop Kean, former Representative from New Jersey, and Mrs. Kean of Livingston, N.J., and Washington.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 -- While water supply systems are generally designed with a safety margin against periods of drought, there is no infallible way of determining how large this margin should be -- as New York City has painfully discovered.

The IBM World Trade Corporation has leased 15,500 square feet of additional office space in adjoining buildings on 42d Street east of Third Avenue, bringing the concern's total tenancy in the two structures to 103,650 square feet.

Waterfront employment last month was 8 per cent over the November, 1964, total, the Waterfront Commission reported yesterday. Last month's total of 393,656 hirings was also a 2 per cent increase over the 384,921 in October, 1965.

Robert B. McKay, associate dean and professor of law at New York University, urged yesterday that legislative reapportionment under the Supreme Court's one-man, one-vote decision "be substantially insulated from the seriously distorting effects of partisan politics."

A new arrival at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was welcomed in style Saturday night. After Frederic Waldman conducted his Musica Aeterna Orchestra in Beethoven's "Coriolanus" Overture, the panels along the left stage wall were opened and, to enthusiastic applause, out slid an organ -- some 1,540 shiny new pipes in three compact sections moving on an upper level and the console itself on the floor.

THE United States Army in Vietnam may not be sure what is waiting for the soldiers in the jungles but it has a reasonable idea of what will be waiting for the G.I.'s when they get back to the mess hails.
The Duke and St. Joseph's college basketball teams will be on the road tomorrow night, risking their top national rankings.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Bonnie Stearns of Tarrytown, N.Y., dominated the hunter division today when she rode Cedar Lodge Farm's Easterly Wave to two championships in the Holiday Farms indoor horse show.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Despite the strong and widespread criticism of the war in Vietnam, United States foreign policy seems to be better understood and to be receiving more tacit support in this year's General Assembly than might have been expected in September.
The Rev. Eugene S. Callender, chairman of the board of Haryou-Act, has criticized Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay for not appointing anybody from Harlem to his task force on antipoverty.

Your editorial of Dec. 11 entitled "Those Troublesome Confessions" refers to "the proposed Model Code of the American Law Institute on pre-arraignment procedures." To date, the American Law Institute has not approved any such code.

The decade-old feud between the Waterfront Commission and the International Longshoremen's Association, quiescent lately, was renewed last week after an official of the dockworkers' union demanded to know just how long the commission planned to stay in business.
THERE are, thank God, times when we can forget about Germany. Then, because of an event or anniversary or the morning's news, Germany thumps its way back into our consciousness.
PARIS, Monday, Dec. 20 -- General de Gaulle won the runoff election yesterday for the French presidency.
Five groups, working independently, have identified what they take to be remains of a primordial flash that occurred when the present universe was born.
MELVILLE, L.I., Dec. 19 -Two women were fatally injured here last night when they were struck by an automobile as they changed a flat tire.

" The Vital Few," by Jonathan Hughes, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Jan, 27. The book presents the human element in American economic development, as exemplified by eight men. William Penn and Brigham Young represent individual liberty; Eli Whitney and Thomas A. Edison, Yankee ingenuity; Andrew Carnegie and Henry Ford, mastery of production, and Edward H. Harriman and J.P. Morgan, passion for organization. A last chapter explores the future of the American economy.
ROME, Dec. 19 Prof. Giorgio La Pira insisted today that he had brought back a valid basis for a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war from recent talks with Communist leaders in Hanoi.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Kipchoge Keino of Kenya ran two miles at Sydney Sports Ground in 8 minutes 25.2 seconds today, 2.6 seconds slower than the world record held by Michel Jazy of France. Jazy turned in his time of 8:22.6 last June in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Washington's defensive unit supplied most of the offense today, scoring three times in leading the Redskins to a 35-14 drubbing of the Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The United Nations is making sure that it won't be left in the dark in the event of another power failure.

The New York Jets ended the American Football League season yesterday by upsetting the Buffalo Bills, 14-12. Long after most of the 55,427 spectators at Shea Stadium have forgotten the score, they are sure to remember such details as these:

Wayne Hillman's goal at 9:12 of the third period enabled the New York Rangers to end their slump last night as they beat the first-place Montreal Canadiens, 3-2, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Pat Stapleton, a defenseman, scored with only 10 seconds left tonight and lifted the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5-4 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

The holiday season takes over this week and sales of new securities come almost to a halt. Only one large corporate issue is scheduled -- the $50 million offering of International Minerals and Chemical Corporation convertible debentures.
Jack Schwadron, merchandising consultant for the McCrory Corporation, said yesterday that he had no comment on reports that he would become president of S. Klein Department Stores, effective Jan. 1.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- United States auto makers moved closer this week to their final goal of 1965, the building of the 11 millionth car or truck of the calendar year.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange climbed in the month ended Dec. 15 by 1,885,187 shares to reach 11,768,609 shares.
Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, has reached down to the second rank of the company's vice presidents for a right-hand man.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20 -- The Vietcong marked their fifth anniversary with an attack on the outskirts of Saiton today and with another terrorist grenade attack, the ninth in a week. The grenade wounded five American servicemen and seven Vietnamese civilians.
TRW Inc., is planning to expand its interest in the automotive field in Britain through the proposed purchase yesterday of Clifford Motors Components, Ltd., for about $28 million in cash.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20 -- United States field commanders have been authorized to pursue enemy troops into Cambodia in some circumstances, authoritative sources said today.

CINTRA, Portugal, Dec. 20 -- At least 22 persons were killed tonight when a Lisbon commuter train smashed into a freight train at Algoeirao, three miles east of this fashionable resort town 14 miles from Lisbon.
Ghana snapped its books shut on cocoa sales, and futures prices here staged a brisk advance in vigorous trading yesterday.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its poorest performance in two weeks yesterday as profit taking depressed most issues in moderate trading.

Governor Rockefeller heard about some of the problems of Queens yesterday on the 15th and last of his special visits to hear the citizens' opinion before he writes his annual message to the Legislature.
The City and State Universities have requested Federal funds to help set up a jointly operated experimental community college in upstate Plattsburgh, N.Y.

Pro football games televised nationally on Monday nights in color is the prime objective of the National Football League as it goes into the final two weeks of negotiating its new television contract, according to Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner.

DENVER, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Cookie Gilchrist, a fullback for the Denver Broncos of the American Football League, was fined $100 yesterday for missing a workout Saturday prior to the Broncos' 45-35 loss to the Chiefs at Kansas City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A Senate subcommittee today took a pessimistic view of prospects for the Great Society programs the Johnson Administration unless "serious conflicts and hostilities" between Federal, state and local administrators can be reduced.

City College student leaders are considering the publication of a handbook analyzing their instructors' strong and weak points. It will be based on a schoolwide project that began yesterday to evaluate faculty competence.
Nearly a score of business executives, many of them representing billion-dollar-plus enterprises, joined in predicting yesterday that 1966 would be a banner year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Even with defense claiming a greater share of the tax dollar, a key Administration official foresees a continued increase in expenditures for Great Society programs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board is about to propose major steps to improve the chances of surviving an air crash and the techniques of finding the causes of accidents.

ONE of the more intriguing activities of the dance avantgarde is an attempt to use dancers against a film background. During the recent Cinematheque Film Festival in Lafayette Street many of these experiments got an airing. One of them has popped up for a little more air in the current "Dance at the Bridge" program at the Bridge Theater in St. Mark's Place.
An unusual tribute to the creativity of Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., appears in this newspaper today, in the form of a full-page ad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- One of the biggest organized movements of civilians in American history began today as the first of 14,000 young Job Corps trainees left camps all over the nation and headed home for two weeks of annual leave.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- An article in the current issue of Christian Century says that churches should recognize the "new breed" of conscientious objectors who oppose the war in Vietnam because they think it is not a "just war."

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Paul Whitcomb Williams of New York, former United States attorney for the Southern District of New York and former State Supreme Court justice, has been elected chairman of the trustees of Bard College.
Groups of Federal and state employes were among the donors whose contributions were recorded yesterday by the Neediest Cases fund.

" Black Man's Burden," by John Oliver Killens, will be published by Trident on Jan. 1. The writer, author-in-residence at Fisk University, reports on the black man's evolution in America. He analyzes the belief of white men that the Negro will be content with a second-class status, warns that violence may become widespread and predicts a better day for all only if white America completely implements democracy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Johnson has asked Vice President Humphrey to go a short diplomatic mission to Saigon after his scheduled visit to Manila for the inauguration of Senator Ferdinand Marcos on Dec. 31 as President of the Philippines.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Jim Grabowski, all-America fullback at the University of Illinois, signed a three-year contract today with the Green Bay Packers of the National Football League.

The nation's list of share owners may grow by 1975 to 30 million from the current 20 million, while the number of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange could expand to 20 billion from the current 10 billion.

It has been more than 30 years since the outbreak of tile Spanish Civil War, 27 years since Generalissimo Francisco Franco became Spain's undisputed dictator in the only Fascist regime to survive World War II. In this compassionate and understanding book, Benjamin Welles, who served as The New York Times correspondent in Spain for six years, examines that country, in light of the Civil War a generation ago and the memories of it today.

It seems to me that your editorial of Dec. 6 "Defiance at Federal Reserve" on the action of the Federal Reserve Board in raising the interest rate should have condemned that action forthrightly at least for the present.
MIAMI Dec. 20 (AP) -- Buz On, a disqualified winner in his last start, won again at Tropical Park today and this time it was official -- but not until Buz On withstood another foul claim.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Refreshed by their first good night's sleep in more than two weeks, the Gemini 7 astronauts underwent extensive physical examinations today and told experts the story of their marathon space trip.

Biserka Cvejic, who sand Dalila in Saint-Saens "Samson et Dalila" at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time last night, was apologetic between acts because she hadn't had a stage rehearsal. She needn't have been.

National and international uncertainties dominated trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The result was a declining market, with sizable losses in defense and airline issues and in other groups that have been strong recently.

Campus clothes were exchanged for white ball gowns and long white gloves last night by 98 young women, mostly college freshmen home for the holidays and for the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 20 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors adopted today a $77,213,684 county budget for next year. The vote was 30 to 10.

NEWARK, Dec. 20 -- Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio appeared to have ended the struggle over control of the city's antipoverty program today with a plan for top-level coordinating commission for all social and economic planning.
The teachers' union that plans to strike at St. John's University Jan. 3 said yesterday that it would set up a "university in exile" where striking faculty members would tutor students.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- There was agreement today among many Gaullist and anti-Gaullist commentators that yesterday's election would lead to changes in the style and composition of President de Gaulle's Government.
Gino Cappelletti, the Boston Patriots' three-way scoring threat, officially retained his American Football League scoring crown yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Leaders of B'nai B'rith met with Chancellor Ludwig Erhard today to tell him of their fears that the West German policy of recompensing Jewish victims of Nazism was being eroded.

THE Life Master Team Championship which concluded the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday night was won by Warren Colbert of Yonkers, N.Y., and Mrs. Agnes Gordon, Nat Gerstman and Bob Lipsitz, all of Buffalo.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Eighteen persons were arrested today when they refused to leave the gates of Treasure Island Navy Base following the conviction of a sailor for refusing to remove a peace symbol on his uniform.
Commercial helicopter service will be officially started tonight from the heliport atop the 59-story Pan Am Building in midtown Manhattan.

Zim Lines is withdrawing two of its combination passenger-cargo ships from North Atlantic service and putting greater emphasis on cruise sailing from the United States, Gottlieb Hammer, president of American-Israeli Shipping Company.

The Maritime Administration issued invitations yesterday for bids covering the construction of five combination passenger cargo ships for States Steamship Company, one of the nation's 15 subsidized operators.
Evan William Mandel was elected yesterday as executive vice president and a director of Revlon, Inc., the large cosmetics producer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard discussed with President Johnson today ways of giving West Germany a greater voice in allied nuclear defense. One plan reported to have been advanced by the German leader suggested joint allied ownership of a small fleet of Polaris atomic submarines.
A Federal Appeals Court here yesterday declined to prevent the Pennzoil Company from acquiring more than 10 per cent of the outstanding stock of the United Gas Corporation.
The nation's banks continued yesterday to announce the selection of new officers and directors.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Yemeni royalists said tonight that talks to end the three-year Yemen civil war had failed and that royalist forces would resume fighting within a month.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 20 -- The five active members of the European Economic Community attempted today to put pressure on France to take the next step toward ending the community crisis.
CHICAGO -- At Marshall Field Co., the department store here that dominates the Loop area, there is never a storewide sale.
If a Wall Street secretary who delightedly banked a $1,000 year-end bonus check yesterday is any criterion, tourism will be kicking quite a hole in the United States' balance of payments next summer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Rick Barry, playing in his first season, scored 37 points and pulled down 25 rebounds tonight in pacing the San Francisco Warriors to a 124-118 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.
Steel production climbed 2.3 per cent last week, for the third consecutive rise, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
An unfrocked missionary brother was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to three years in prison for a mail fraud scheme that victimized church groups of thousands of dollars.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- More than 500 residents of the Rye Neck School District attended a noisy meeting of the school board tonight to argue about a sixth-grade teacher who opposes the war in Vietnam.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America and the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company are providing initial morgage financing of $50 million for development of Columbia, a new city in Maryland.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Prime Minister Wilson said in the House of Commons today that Britain had decided on an oil embargo against Rhodesia to head off "almost irresistible" pressures for military intervention.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara announced today an indefinite postponement of $620 million worth of military construction, including housing for military families.
Changes affecting two repertory companies will take place next month.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A modern guide to Christmas cards:

THE spoil-sports in the National Football League continue to bedevil the American Football League in the still uneven struggle for public attention. Just as the Americans were ready to advance in solitary splendor to center stage for their championship playoff between the San Diego Chargers and the Buffalo Bills in San Diego on Sunday, the musclemen from the Nationals boisterously shouldered their way into a share of the spotlight.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Government charged today that landowners in West Feliciana Parish (County) had evicted from their lifelong homes Negro sharecroppers and tenant farmers who registered to vote.

TWO young Greek designers, one of clothes, the other of fabrics, decided recently to collaborate and bring the results to New York. The 30-piece collection, all of silk woven in Greece, was shown to buyers yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel, Fifty-fifth Street, just east of Fifth Avenue, under the sponsorship of the Greek National Tourist Organization.

The often-postponed construction of a $24 million interchange to relieve congestion on the Long Island Expressway at its intersection with the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is now scheduled to start this spring.
FAYETTE, Miss., Dec. 20 (UPI) -- City and county officials voted today to stop the sale of beer in this small town faced with a "black Christmas" boycott by civil rights forces.
MADRID, Dec. 20 -- The Spanish Cortes (Parliament), meeting in one of its rare plenary sessions approved today a law that at least in theory legalizes economically inspired labor strikes.
A second rebuff in four days was dealt to Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday by the outgoing Wagner administration.
Soviet scientific and technical books in English are being pushed in university communities of Latin America and Asia at "an incredibly low retail price," according to a State Department survey.

SEATTLE, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Seven Washington State organizations urged the Civil Aeronautics Board Monday to permit three airlines to provide competitive service over proposed routes in the Pacific Norhwest-Southwest case.
Jimmy Brown, Cleveland's star fullback, was named yesterday as the National Football League player of the year by the New York chapter of the Pro Football Writers Association.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- A General Assembly committee voted today to spend $33 million for the United Nations peace-keeping force in the Middle East in 1965 and 1966.

If a new move by the Citizens Union succeeds, the Proportional Representation method of electing the City Council will be up for referendum vote next November. Essential to the effort are 50,000 signatures on petitions now being circulated.
The Vietnamese war and how to achieve peace have become major items of campaign discussion in the four-way Democratic race for Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay's seat in Congress.
The bond market showed yesterday it isn't at all ready to call it quits for 1965.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Two young Britons were committed for trial today at the end of two weeks of preliminary hearings in the case of the Pennine Moors murders.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Joseph H. Louchheim, who has been New York City's Welfare Commissioner since Oct. 5, will take a state welfare post effective Jan. 15.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 -- Howard W. Johnson, dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was elected president of the institute today. He will succeed Dr. Julius A. Stratton, who retires on July 1.
The Department of Labor called a conference in Washington today on what to do about manning merchant ships in an emergency sealift to Vietnam.

Your Dec. 3 editorial "Escalation Goes On" presents certain questions. Some reconciliations between reality and idealism appear necessary while today's international politics continue to create tomorrow's history.
The first American Legion baseball player to be drafted by the major leagues was signed yesterday by the New York Mets.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The General Assembly ruled today that a simple majority was enough to adopt a resolution calling for the removal of foreign bases, as a threat to international peace, from countries that do not have self-government.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 20 -- The Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra announced today it had hired Craig Hutchinson, former manager of the Cincinnati and San Antonio symphonies, as its first full-time general manager.
Next summer may bring new television opportunities for young singers and other musical variety performers.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDS0N, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Engineers for the Consolidated Edison Company disputed today assertions by conservationists that water pumped from the Hudson River here into the New York City water system would be heavily saline.
Sears, Roebuck Co. announced yesterday it would begin national marketing of radial tires for passenger cars next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- President Johnson today authorized the elected Ryukyuan Legislature to choose the island's chief executive, who was formerly appointed by the United States High Commissioner.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 20 -- A Nassau County grand jury returned a non-true bill today an investigation of charges of wrongdoing in connection with the acquisition of park lands in Baldwin and Bellmore by the Town of Hempstead.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y. -- A memorial to a dead age pierces the sky above the Hudson River here. It is Lyndhurst, a Gothic fantasy built in 1838 and standing now as a showcase of Victorian design ideas. The elaborate turreted mansion, designed by Alexander J. Davis, was willed to the National Trust when the last of its five owners, the Duchess of Talleyrand-Perigord, died in 1961.
The New York City Housing Authority proposed state legislation yesterday to give it the power to establish on its own the income limits for tenants in low-rent public housing projects.

The move toward a 4 1/2 per cent dividend rate on savings accounts at New York City savings banks, which started on Dec. 6 at the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, last night seemed well on the way to becoming general throughout the city.

The difficulty about economic sanctions against Rhodesia has always been the certainty that they would first hurt neighboring Zambia. This grim fact may now sink in on African leaders impatient with Britain for not taking more drastic action to bring down the white rebel regime in Salisbury.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont said today that "up to now Communist China is winning this war in Vietnam."
