WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, in a new thrust at Governor Rockefeller in their dispute over aid to the mentally retarded, accused the Governor today of misrepresenting New York State's record.
The appointment of several senior officers was announced here yesterday by the New York Hanseatic Corporation and by Smith, Barney Co.

Federal health officials estimated yesterday that as many as half the 250,000 persons in state institutions for the mentally retarded had not been examined closely enough to be sure they belong there.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20 -- If anyone got any sleep last night in the waterfront district where the Riachuelo empties into the Rio de la Plata, he was either deaf or so unfeeling as to be unworthy of being called a "citizen of the Republic of the Boca."

Public-spirited people have long worried about the conservation of trees, topsoil and wildlife on this crowded and often plundered planet. The threat to such resources is still a cause for the deepest concern; but as more and more people live in cities and their suburbs, the quality of the entire environment has become a major worry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- On the guest list for the White House dinner tonight for Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was represented by John J. Sparkman of Alabama, the second-ranking Democrat. Conspicuously absent was Senator J.W. Fulbright of Arkansas, the committee chairman.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani of Italy, President of the General Assembly, said today that his Vietnam negotiating role was so secret that his own Government might have been surprised by recent disclosures.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee adopted by a vote of 100 to 0 today a resolution condemning all forms of intervention in other states, including subversion and terrorism.
The New York Civil Liberties Union charged yesterday that a witness's constitutional right of free speech had been violated at a hearing of the Federal grand jury investigating draft card burnings.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, the Defense Minister, accused Britain and the United States today of having encircled Indonesia with naval forces and new and hostile nations.
HONG KONG, Dec. 20 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China declared tonight that it was possible that the United States would extend the war in Vietnam to the whole of Indochina and to China.
MILAN, Dec. 20 -- A Milan audience warmly received the musical spectacle, "Gershwiniana," at its premiere tonight in La Scala Opera House.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20 -- United States Air Force planes, spraying chemicals, have undertaken a drive to destroy rice crops in some areas under Vietcong control. The program uses the same chemicals as the "defoliation" program, which aims at destroying jungle canopy and undergrowth capable of sheltering guerrillas.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 20 -- Business came to a virtual halt here today as bands of angry youths continued to roam the capital's streets a day after the fierce battle between Government troops and former rebels in Santiago, the nation's second largest city.
Brooklyn Borough President Abe Stark submitted an expense budget yesterday for 1966-67 that was $7,911 less than was appropriated for the current fiscal year.
The British pound weakened in quiet trading of foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Its closing level of $2.8016 was 8 points down from the Friday level.

A $115 million operating budget for the City University was approved last night by the Board of Higher Education. Gustave G. Rosenberg, chairman of the board, said the figures would be submitted to the City Budget Director at a hearing next Monday.

DIAN, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 21 (AP) -- United States troops ambushed a Vietcong unit early today and rescued three of four employes the guerrillas had kidnapped from an American construction concern.
An off-the-mainstream Concerto for Clarinet and Chamber Ensemble, by Alvin Etler, was given its first performance by the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

The long-expected trade between the New York Jets and the Boston Patriots involving John Huarte was consummated yesterday. The Jets received for Huarte, the forgotten quarterback who won the Heisman Trophy as college football's best player of 1964, a seasoned pass catcher in Jimmy Colclough and a fourth draft choice.

AMONG the rash of "Messiah" performances that break out annually in the New York concert halls at Christmas time, the one led by Herman Scherchen in Philharmonic Hall last night may well have been the most provocative to be heard this season.

A meeting to be held today in Philadelphia by a committee of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States may give the industry some answers to the questions arising out of the military services' increased demand for apparel.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 20, (UPI) -- Collie Leroy Wilkins, one of three Ku Klux Klansmen linked to the civil rights slaying of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo of Detroit, was sentenced to a year and a day in Federal prison today for parole violation in another case.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- George B. Young, president of Field Enterprises, Inc., announced today that Roy M. Fisher, vice president of the Field Enterprises Educational Corporation and executive editor of the World Book Year Book, would become editor of The Chicago Daily News on Jan. 3. The World Book is an encyclopedia.
When the week began Glenn Edward Seaman lived in Inwood, L.I., in a white stucco house with his parents, his model railroad equipment, several sports trophies and 20 years of memories.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 17 -- The Government of Iraq is prepared to amend the Constitution to recognize the rebellious Kurds as a "nation" -- that is, as an ethnic entity with its own language distinct from Arabic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A total of 8,368,587 persons over 65 years old have enrolled for the voluntary medical care coverage under the Government's Medicare program as of Dec. 11, the Social Security Administration reported today.

IN many homes during the holiday season the meals and refreshments served are as traditional as the decorations and suggestions for change are unwelcome. But there are always some who want to experiment with new twists to old favorites.

We wish to protest as vigorously as possible the sudden dismissal of more than twenty professors by the administration of St. John's University because of their activities in defense of academic freedom. Despite the administration's specious adherence to American Association of University Professors regulations concerning the discharge of non-tenured faculty members, the firings can only be regarded as an attempt to coerce the remaining professors into a docile submission to the whims of the administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Gov. George C. Wallace and Attorney General Richmond M. Flowers of Alabama competed today in attacking the constitutionality of the Federal Voting Act in the Supreme Court.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay and his family will not be able to move into Gracie Mansion on Jan. 1.

THERE is a suburban garage still uncleaned. And a particular den not straightened up, with gun oil cans and old snowshoes still to be put away. A vast number of other chores also were left undone over the weekend, because something intervened.

In a recent issue of a real estate newspaper I read that H.B. Evans, Chairman of the Housing and Redevelopment Board of New York City, is formulating a plan which includes a low-rent housing development on 64th Street between Amsterdam and West End Avenues.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Johnson received a thorough briefing today on India's food situation from Chidambara Subramaniam, the Indian Food Minister.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay is planning to create a city department of human resources as part of his reorganization of the municipal government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- United States officials fear that yesterday's battle between rival military groups in the Dominican Republic has wrecked a vital step toward pacification that was to have taken place this week.

A 24-year-old artist, who believes that he is being discriminated against by museums because he is not internationally famous, reached the fifth day of a hunger strike yesterday as a means of arguing his case.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Farmers produced a record volume of crops this year.
MANILA -- Imelda Marcos, a statuesque beauty who wears her skirts above the knee "to make me look shorter," is having her problems: She can no longer push her own grocery cart.

A registered secondary offering of 270,000 shares of common stock of the Kliklok Corporation was sold out yesterday by a syndicate headed by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and Johnson, Lemon Co. The stock was priced at $11 a share.

Four men, including a New York lawyer awaiting trial in California in a counterfeit money case, were arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of conspiracy to transport $50,000 in bogus International Telephone and Telegraph bonds across state lines.
TRENTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today knocked out a State Labor Department rule barring its industrial accident records to a company that sold them to prospective employers.

New York City must have an effective transportation system if it is to maintain its position as the nation's business and cultural capital. Crammed into the nine square miles of Manhattan Island below Central Park is a complex of activities unmatched anywhere else in the world. Every day 3,000,000 people travel in and out of this small area.

William Epton, the leader of the Harlem Progressive Labor Movement, was found guilty yesterday in Criminal Court of conspiring to riot, of advocating the overthrow of the New York State government and of conspiring to overthrow it.
The General Electric Company announced major organizational changes yesterday.

The Federal Reserve has been "leaning over backward" to cushion the impact of its recent increase in the discount rate to 4 1/2 per cent, according to a leading New York banker with close knowledge of central bank policy.
The General Federation of Women's Clubs will open a national drive for better bicycling safety today.
The Police Department swore in 414 probationary policemen yesterday, raising the department's total force to 27,023 men -- the largest force in the city's history.

Federal narcotics agents arrested an Army warrant officer and five alleged members of a Corsican smuggling ring yesterday in what they described as the largest single seizure of heroin ever made in the United States.

The teachers' faith in the ability of children from slum neighborhoods may be the most important factor in any efforts to improve such youngsters' behavior and study habits. This is the conclusion of a two-year. Government-financed study of the effectiveness of the All-Day Neighborhood School program in the city schools.

The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled unanimously yesterday that a 16-year-old boy charged with murder was entitled to a lawyer at a Juvenile Court hearing that determined he was to be tried as an adult.
U.S. Industries, Inc., a diversified manufacturing company, announced here yesterday the election of Fred M. Kirby as a director, raising the size of the board to 12 members.
TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Auburn beat Columbia University, 76-75, tonight in overtime as the first Tampa holiday basketball tournament opened.

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Flight corridors across the North Atlantic will be reduced in width to 90 miles from 120 miles as of Jan. 13, a source in the International Civil Aviation Organization reported today.
YONKERS, Dec. 20 -- Nine children and three adults attending a music class died tonight in a fire that swept through the Jewish Community Center here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The State and Defense Departments declined to comment today on reports from Saigon that United States field commanders had been authorized to pursue enemy troops into Cambodia.

DIAN, South Vietnam, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Illustrated leaflets playing up anti-war demonstrations by students in the United States are being distributed around American Army installations here. They urge United States troops to stop fighting.
MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 20 -- The Munich City Council decided today to submit to the International Olympic Committee Munich's application for selection as the site of the 1972 games.

THE exhibitions at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 33 East 36th Street, always demand superlatives. Each major show seems to be the finest yet. "Durer and His Time." a selection of 150 drawings on loan from the Berlin State Museums, is the latest of these.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 -- Early next year a team of experts from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare will descend on one of the nation's large cities to begin a Federal water pollution abatement action.

THE possibility of military draft for such young players as Tucker Frederickson, Ernie Koy and Steve Thurlow, plus the necessity of selling three players to the new Atlanta franchise in February, will in effect freeze the New York Giants' playing roster for several weeks, according to Coach Al Sherman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach ordered Federal examiners into four more Mississippi counties today to register Negroes under the Voting Rights Act.
Genesee County in Michigan awarded $13 million of bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by the Northern Trust Company in the only large tax-exempt bond sale scheduled this week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- On the tests of judgment and responsible procedure in dealing with what may or may not have been a "peace-feeler" by the North Vietnamese chiefs of state in Hanoi, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch comes off better than the Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Individuals added $10.7 billion to their liquid savings during the July-September quarter -- a record for the postwar period.

YONKERS, Dec. 20 -- From the hospital room they shared, two girls, classmates in the music program at the Jewish Community Center of Yonkers, told how they had escaped from the burning building where 12 others lost their lives tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 -- Shortly after Federated Department Stores, Inc., announced the hiring of a new executive vice president last August, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology discovered its best bet for a new president was the same man.
The pre-Christmas lull hit the London stock market yesterday as trading slowed to a walk and price changes were small. The uncertain Rhodesian situation was also thought to have curtailed activity.

Although immigrants from Flushing, in the Netherlands, discovered it and named it more than 320 years ago, Flushing, Queens, a residential and commercial community is being rediscovered by several of New York's largest retailers.
An economist for the Transport Workers Union said yesterday that the cost estimate of $680 million placed by the Transit Authority on the union's contract demands was "preposterous."

ST. LAWRENCE was, for years, one of the strongest college hockey powers in the East and reached the National Collegiate tourney a number of times. But since the growth of the sport in Eastern intercollegiate circles caused the talent to be spread more evenly, St. Lawrence, and other former strong teams, found it was a struggle to get along without some losses here and there.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Discussing the case of the 17-year-old deaf-mute. Dr. William Craig, a state pediatrician, said today that the youth evidently had suffered brain damage that caused him to have "a spotty IQ," high in some areas, low in others.
The Koehring Company, producers of earth moving and construction equipment, registered an increase of 36 per cent in earnings for the fiscal year ended Nov. 30 on a sales gain of 28 per cent.
Two hundred and twenty draftees at Fort Dix, N.J., who thought they had lost their fight to go home for Christmas learned late last night that they had won.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 21 -- The formation of a joint Brazil-United States iron ore company, incorporating properties here controlled by the Hanna Mining Company, was announced today.

Traders in commodity futures interpreted some recent Government crop reports bullishly yesterday, and their buying raised futures prices of two staples -- soybeans and potatoes -- in quite active trading.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The upper stage of a Titan 3 rocket hurtled into orbit as a space launching platform today but misfired after a flawless six-hour flight and sprayed a bundle of satellites into the wrong orbits.
The First National City Bank of New York, the city's largest bank, announced yesterday a reorganization of its top management.

A final fiscal report on the 1964 operations at the World's Fair issued yesterday charged that "controls necessary for good management were lacking" and that there were fiscal deficiencies on a broad scale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department forecast the 1966 winter wheat crop today at 1,059,116,000 bushels, based on conditions of the crop as of Dec. 1 and other factors. This would be 3 per cent larger than the estimate for the 1965 crop.
Mal Graham and Stan McKenzie combined for 54 points to pace New York University to a 110-74 triumph over St. Peter's of New Jersey last night. The victory was the Violets' sixth in seven games.
The stock market reversed itself yesterday and recovered its loss of Monday, The rebound was led by steel, drug and selected investment-grade issues.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 21 -- President Arturo U. Illia of Argentina has nothing to worry about this Christmas but strikes, economic recession, restive soldiers and a huge overdue foreign debt.
Mickey Mantle of the New York Yankees was named yesterday the winner of the first "Hutch Award." The award honors the memory of the late Fred Hutchinson, who died of cancer last year.
Oil shares spurted yesterday on the London Stock Exchange on news that British Petroleum had found natural gas under the North Sea in commercial quantities.
MILLBROOK, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Sometimes a professional hunting dog finds himself in a situation almost beyond his control. It can wind up in a hilarious sequence of events.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Brink's, Inc., filed today a $6,50,000 damage suit based on the cannon-blasting of a Brink's vault in Syracuse, N.Y., on Oct. 25. Robbers looted the vault of $400,000 in cash, checks and securities.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Sporadic shooting broke out in Santo Domingo tonight and at least one person was killed in what appeared to be clashes between police patrols and armed snipers.
Speculators in folk hero futures can rest assured: the James Bond market is holding firm.

SINCE it was first performed here in 1958, the New York Pro Musica's superb re-creation of "The Play of Daniel" has become almost as much a part of Christmas in New York as all those renditions of "The Messiah."
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 22 -- Britain's fragile political unity on Rhodesia was shattered last night.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Dec. 21 -- A worried father, tense and drawn, sat in the back of his haberdashery shop here today and said: "It's 21 days today, 21 days. Who knows where he is in this country?"
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay announced yesterday the formation of a Science and Technology Advisory Council composed of representatives of universities, foundations and corporations.

THE newest coach in the National Basketball Association, Dick McGuire of the New York Knickerbockers, faces the sternest test of his new regime during the two weeks starting tonight, and the results should provide an accurate long-range forecast of interest to the ent ire league.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Jim Brown and seven of his Cleveland teammates were selected today for the East team that will meet the National Football League's West squad in the annual Pro Bowl Game here Jan. 16.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Governor Rockefeller named Nat H. Hentel tonight to be district attorney of Queens, succeeding Frank D. O'Connor, President-elect of the City Council in New York.

THIS is the time of year when almost everyone connected with automobile sports sends cards with a merry automotive motif. Santa Claus in an Austin-Healey, in a Triumph or Jaguar, in a Ford, Chevvy or Chrysler or something even finer like a Rolls-Royce or a Mini-Minor.
Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia 76ers is moving up in the National Basketball Association statistics -- in assists.

Cornell and St. Lawrence, upstate rivals in intercollegiate hockey, reached the final of the annual Eastern College Athletic Conference holiday festival with one-sided victories at Madison Square Garden last night.
Stockholders of McGraw-Hill, Inc., and the Standard and Poor's Corporation approved yesterday at separate meetings here a previously proposed merger between the two concerns.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 -- With many families, there comes a time of grim realization that hit-or-miss financing out of the sugar bowl is leading toward insolvency and that there has to be systematic coordination of income and outgo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -The White House emphatically denied today that Vice President Humphrey would go to South Vietnam, but announced that he would extend a planned Philippine visit to include Taiwan, Korea and Japan.

Wall Street is full of good cheer and fat bonuses as it celebrates its busiest year ever, but it may be in for some sobering changes as a result of a study on its future sponsored by the New York Stock Exchange.
ROME, Dec. 21 -- The Vatican began today a long process that might end in canonization of the Blessed Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton.
The Sinclair Oil Corporation announced here yesterday the election as a director of Kendrick R. Wilson Jr., chairman of the Avco Corporation.

The election of David Horowitz as president for 1966 of the Foreign Press Association was announced yesterday. He is the New York correspondent of the World-Union Press, a news agency with headquarters in Tel Aviv, and the Heruth Daily, a Tel Aviv newspaper.

We can well understand why Mayor Wagner thought it would be appropriate to change the name of the new Gouverneur Hospital now under construction on the Lower East Side to Helen Hall Community Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The United States declared itself free today to undertake military actions in Cambodia that it considered essential for the American troops' self-defense in the Vietnam war.

MONTREAL, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Senior officers of the Canadian Labor Congress and the independent Seafarers International Union of Canada held today the first of a series of the meetings to consider the union's possible reentry into the congress.

Puccini's "Tosca" re-entered the Metropolitan Opera's repertory for the first time this season last night. The cast was mostly familiar, with Renata Tebaldi in the title role, Gabriel Bacquier as Scarpia and Sandor Konya as Cavaradossi.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The Defense Department issued today a list of military construction postponements intended to save $460 million for the fight in Vietnam.

The management of the Reading Company has not yet taken a formal position on the proposal of the Norfolk Western and the Chesapeake Ohio railways that Reading become part of a merged system the two big roads now plan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A special study group reported today that 452 Negro teachers in Southern and Border states had lost their jobs or had been demoted because of accelerated school integration this year.
Four young pacifists were indicted yesterday on charges of burning their draft cards at a rally protesting United States military involvement in Vietnam.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Despite an apparent acceleration in the law of diminishing returns, New York State took in a record sum of $139.6 million in tax revenue from pari-mutuel racing this year.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The State of Louisiana denounced the 1965 Voting Rights Act today as unconstitutional.
Julius C.C. Edelstein, Mayor Wagner's chief assistant, has been offered a job with the Research Foundation of the City University to help develop a program on urban problems.

A majority report issued by President Johnson's Maritime Advisory Committee that calls for $800 million in Federal expenditures annually for a program to rejuvenate the nation's merchant marine was challenged yesterday by the leading ship-owner member of the committee as "improper and costly."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, the draft director, stood firm today on plans to induct registrants who burn their cards or conduct sit-ins at local boards. But he said eligible persons would not lose deferments merely for demonstrating or stating their views.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 17 -- Active Chinese intervention in the Vietnamese war is regarded as unlikely by experts here.
DETROIT, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The clutch play of Bob Verga helped top-ranked Duke gain a 100-93 comeback victory over fifth-ranked Michigan in overtime tonight.
The Central School District No. 7 of Amherst and Tonawanda, N.Y., near Buffalo, sold $2,005,000 of bonds yesterday to the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Federation Bank and Trust Company.
Howard and Jean Lipman yesterday acted to share their love of contemporary sculpture with the rest of the country.
WHAT does a clever milliner do after he's pulled the scarf trick? If it's a good ploy and the hatter has the inner security that comes from a sure grip on the audience, he does it again.
Union terms for calling off a threatened Jan. 3 faculty strike at St. John's University were outlined yesterday in a letter to the Very Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, university president.
The Long Island Real Estate Board and the Jamaica-Queens County Real Estate Board will merge on Jan. 1.
Westchester and Long Island committees planned a campaign to fight a proposed Long Island Sound bridge yesterday as Robert Moses personally presented his plan for it at another meeting.
The Pennzoil Company reported yesterday that it had purchased all of the 5,159,033 shares of United Gas Corporation stock tendered under an offer of $41 a share made on Nov. 22.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 -- Six United States aircraft were lost over Vietnam yesterday and today in a series of attacks that included a second raid on the Uongbi power plant near Haiphong.
Two Peace Corps members who will spend the holidays in Ethiopia have sent a gift to the distressed and unfortunate of New York City.
TOKYO, Dec. 21 -- There now seem to be only three options open to the United States in Asia, all of them highly disagreeable.

The United States apparently does not expect any change in either the content or form of de Gaulle's foreign policy now that he has been re-elected President. Washington seems convinced the General will continue to press for changes in the NATO alliance although, so far, he has not specified what changes he desires.
The Pavilion Hotel, a landmark adjacent to the Vermont State Capitol at Montpelier, is expected to become a state office building.

For most problems of city government facing Mayor Lindsay when he takes office there is no magic wand for instant solution. But, strange to say, traffic congestion -- one of the city's worst problems -- could be almost miraculously relieved by a single command from City Hall: Enforce the law. This is one area in which the new broom, a new spirit in government, could sweep clean.

ROME, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Roman Catholics may gain plenary indulgences during the coming jubilee without traveling to Rome or even to the cathedrals of their dioceses if their Bishops see fit, Pope Paul VI decreed today.
A supper dance was given at the Union Club last night for four young women who were classmates at the Kent (Conn.) School for Girls.
Mayor Wagner made a personal effort yesterday to speed the lagging transit-contract talks and avert a strike on New Year's morning.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- Lynn A. Townsend, president of the Chrysler Corporation, predicted today that in 1966 the automomobile industry "will have another year at least as good as 1965, and probably somewhat better."
IN the beginning, the holiday season in the city is no bigger than the gleam in a child's eye.
The New York Bank for Savings announced yesterday an across-the-board increase in the dividend rates it pays on the three types of savings accounts it presently offers.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 21 -- The Des Moines school board rejected today a demand by the Iowa Civil Liberties Union that it promptly reinstate five students who were suspended for wearing antiwar armbands to school.

Original plays by two writers better known as novelists, Romain Gary and John Hawkes, are headed for the stage. Mr. Gary's script, which is untitled, will be done on Broadway next season by Saint Subber, producer of "The Odd Couple" and "Barefoot in the Park." Robert Lantz, Mr. Gary's agent declined to outline the plot.

License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCario has summoned the operators of the Gayety Theater at Second Avenue and 12th Street and the Mayfair Theater at 235 West 46th Street to a hearing next week to determine whether their licenses should be revoked.

NEWARK, Dec. 21 -- Jersey City and Patrolman Charles Free have been named in a civil suit filed in United States District Court here charging the policeman with "maliciously, willfully and brutally" beating Aurelio Rodriquez, the plaintiff, with a nightstick last Aug. 18.
The corporate bond new-issue market continued to bubble with a surprising amount of activity yesterday for a day so close to the year-end holidays.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 21 -- The Syrian Government of Premier Yussef Zayen resigned today, leaving Lieut. Gen. Amin el-Hafez in apparently undisputed control of the country.

Deere Co. had worldwide sales of $887 million in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, setting a record for the third consecutive year, the annual report disclosed yesterday. Net income, however, declined because of heavy tooling and start-up expenses for equipment and expansion of domestic overseas manufacturing facilities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Federal agencies took under advisement today a proposal to accelerate the graduation of engineer cadets in maritime academies to meet a growing shortage of licensed ship engineers.
Acquisition of the City Finance Company of Memphis by James Talcott, Inc. was approved yesterday by shareholders of both companies.

Since Congress has been disgracefully delinquent in ignoring the misconduct of its own members such as Representative Adam Clayton Powell, it is all the more unfortunate when the executive branch shows leniency in respect to Congressional standards. That is the effect of President Johnson's action yesterday in granting a pardon to former Representative Frank Boykin of Alabama, who had been convicted of conspiracy to defraud the United States.

A fireman's widow who contended her husband's death by smoke inhalation had been caused by an inadequate gas mask will receive $200,000 from the city under a ruling by the Appellate Division yesterday.

Federal authorities implicated a retired Army major and a Miami Mafia figure yesterday in their widening investigation of 209 pounds of heroin that was confiscated in George after being smuggled here from France in a soldier's home freezer.

Trustees of the New Haven Railroad asked the United States District Court in New Haven yesterday for permission to draw about $7 million from the court registry to pay off several Government-guaranteed loans over the next two years.

I should like to reply to Hermon D. Smith's letter of Dec. 7 deploring the absence of your usual "objective and sophisticated'' reporting in the matter of the sale by the Newberry Library of duplicates and "surplusage" created by the purchase of the Louis H. Silver collection.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The British Petroleum Company has found natural gas in the North Sea in commercial quantities, Fred Lee, Minister of Power, announced today in the House of Commons.

IN the early days of bridge a bid in the opponent's suit was reserved for the rare occasions on which a player held a giant hand with no losers in the opponent's suit. The expert of today uses the cue-bid in a wide variety of situations.
Museum directors and art dealers will meet next month to consider modes of looking gift horses in the mouth.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, has ordered the Board of Education of the City of Mount Vernon to correct racial imbalance in its schools by next fall.
The Lockheed Electronics Company, a division of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, has announced the appointment of Alan J. Grant to the new post of executive vice president.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Wednesday, Dec. 22 -- The General Assembly adjourned its 20th session early today after a flurry of final-day decisions that included approval of a treaty to eliminate racial discrimination.

THE Colts and Packers, who will engage in the National Football League's first division playoff game since 1958 at Green Bay on Sunday, have few of the league's statistical leaders for the season just completed.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Francois Mitterrand, who lost to President de Gaulle in the presidential runoff election last Sunday, charged today that he had been a victim of fraud in the country's overseas territories.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Lionel Bart's new musical, "Twang," a jazz spoof on the Robin Hood legend, was cut down by London's theater critics today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -President Johnson and Chancellor Ludwig Erhard agreed today to continue talking in the future about West Germany's desire for a more "appropriate" part in the West's nuclear defense.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Kipchoge Keino of Kenya, who already has bettered Ron Clarke's 5,000-meter world record, beat the Australian ace today at that distance with a tremendous last lap kick that carried him to victory by 40 yards.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 -- A North Vietnamese Army deserter declared today that his country's officers and commanders feared, above all, raids by the United States' B-52 bombers.
Philip S. Harris has resigned as president and director of S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., effective Jan. 1, 1966, Samuel Neaman, chairman, announced yesterday.
The military revolution in Indonesia is moving into a new phase now that the army has de-fused the country's political time-bomb, the powerful Indonesian Communist party (P.K.I.).

A fireman's widow who contended her husband's death by smoke inhalation had been caused by an inadequate gas mask will receive $200,000 from the city under a ruling by the Appellate Division yesterday.
Genesco, Inc., a manufacturer and retailer of apparel and footwear, announced yesterday the election of W.S. Flanagan as a director.
A City College student, Herman Berliner, denied yesterday that the publication of a student handbook on teachers was being considered.

Three of the season's debutantes, the Misses Julia Gilbert Bastedo, Janet Whitman and Janine Watson Wiedel, were honored last night at the small dinner dance given at the Colony Club by their parents. Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Bastedo of New Canaan, Conn., Civil Court Judge and Mrs. Charles S. Whitman Jr. of 70 East 96th Street and Dr. and Mrs. Philip D. Wiedel of 1030 Fifth Avenue.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Wednesday, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- Premier Souvanna Phouma denied today that United States B-52 bombers had been given permission to raid Communist positions in Laos from their bases on Guam.

The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday this would be the last season for the weekly "Dick Van Dyke Show." It was the star's own decision. Mr. Van Dyke, whose situation comedy is among the "top 10" shows in the latest Nielsen ratings, is one of the few performers to quit television while he's ahead.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The British Government plans random roadside tests to catch drinking drivers. Those whose breath betrays drinking will be taken to police stations for more accurate blood or urine analysis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- President Johnson has granted a pardon to Frank W. Boykin, 80 years old, the former Alabama Representative convicted of conspiracy to defraud the United States in violating conflict of interest laws.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The agency in charge of running community action anti-poverty programs gave up today in its struggle with dissenters who said the poor had too little voice in projects affecting them.

The dramatic announcement by Robert J. Schwartz of his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Congress in the Seventeenth Congressional District on a platform critical of the Johnson Administration's Vietnam policies is a most significant one.
PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Ten years ago, Sweden's central bank raised its discount rate without notifying its Socialist Government in advance.

THERE are economic and social indications that the American family is becoming either a rock 'n' roll band or a hotbed of hillbillies. And the guitar is doing it. The teen-age sons of doctors, lawyers, restaurateurs, politicians, manufacturers, teachers, millionaires and taxi-drivers lift their voices in common, if unlikely, chorus united by this single instrument in all its musical and mechanical variations.

LAHAINA, Maui, Hawaii -- The islands of Hawaii probably have more clubs dedicated to the serious pursuit of dining well for pleasure than any state in the Union if not any country in the world. There are luau clubs, and poi clubs, and here in this corner of paradise there was recently held the bi-monthly meeting of the Island Maui Pupu Club.

ONE of the early pioneers of modern dance, Charles Weidman, last night presented, as a holiday season attraction, his own choreographic version of Bach's Easter Oratorio at the Expression of Two Arts Theater, 102 West 29th Street.
A new wing for American art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a new look for the museum's four-block-long facade are being planned for the not-too-distant future.
New York's first skyscraper heliport, the subject of more than two years of controversy, was formally opened last night.

AT Lukas Foss's "Evenings for New Music" series, something is always bound to came up to alarm, irritate or stimulate, depending on one's musical outlook. Last night's Carnegie Recital Hall program was no exception, and there was a humdinger of a piece called "Book for Three" by Michael von Biel.

Opposition to the war in Vietnam appeared yesterday to be shaping up as a major issue in the Democratic party here among declared or potential candidates in next June's primary against Representative Leonard Farbstein of the 19th Congressional District.
The names of five potential candidates for appointment to judgeships in the Family Court will be placed before the State Bar Association's committee on the judiciary today by Mayor Wagner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Following is the text of the State Department's statement today by Marshall Wright, a press officer, in response to questions on reports that United States field commanders have been authorized to pursue enemy troops into Cambodia in some circumstances:
The Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee won 28 of 40 representation elections among drivers at fleet garages here yesterday.
Syracuse University has decided not to renew its contract with Saul Alinsky, the activist radical, under which he provided advice on organizing the pore.

" I'VE never treated anyone with reverence," says Saul David Alinsky. "That goes for religious leaders, mayors and millionaires. I think irreverence is basic to a free society." He is not surprised, therefore that Syracuse University has decided it does not need his advice any more.
From office boy to head of the company is an oft-told tale but one that seldom happens in real life.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -The Administration is considering formal acceptance of the Vietcong offer of a 12-hour Christmas Eve truce, State Department officials said this evening.
This year will be the best in the General Electric Company's history. Fred J. Borch, president and chief executive officer, predicted yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Prime Minister Wilson announced tonight that he would visit Moscow from Feb. 21 to 24.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday, recovering some of Monday's losses.
A traditional harbor welcome, usually reserved for a debutante ocean liner, was accorded yesterday to the world's most powerful floating "A" frame derrick.

BONN, Dec. 21 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, who stepped down as Chancellor of West Germany in 1963, when he was 87 years old, will give up the chairmanship of the governing party, the Christian Democratic Union, next spring.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Bill Veeck, a former owner in the American League, testified today that baseball could expand by 1966, but that the quality of play "might be diluted by expansion."
BERLIN, Dec. 21, United States officials disclosed today that an American woman was arrested by the East Germans Nov. 24. She is now in jail in East Berlin, they said.
ATLANTA, Dec. 21 -- Atlanta lit its Christmas tree on Thanksgiving night. There is no doubt that is what happened. Even the competitors of Rich's Inc., wound have to admit it.

HOUSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Manned Spacecraft Center released today several terrain photographs taken by Comdr. James A. Lovell Jr. during his 14-day Gemini 7 spaceflight with Lieut. Col. Frank Borman.

A proposed 22-point attack on the city's narcotics problem, made public by Mayor Wagner yesterday, recommends committing addicts for treatment for as long as three years, even if they have not broken the law.
Oxford debated Harvard on the United States commitment in Vietnam via Early Bird satellite yesterday. There was no winner.
YONKERS, Dec. 21 -- Delay in turning in a fire alarm was blamed today for the death of nine children and three adults in a fire at the Jewish Community Center here Monday night.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Miss Roberta Whitfield is teaching this year at the Romine Elementary School, where 454 of the 470 pupils are white. She is a Negro.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Republicans in Congress are preparing a State of the Union Message of their own to get across to the public their view of where they think the country stands and where it ought to be heading.

Directors of the American Can Company announced yesterday an increased quarterly dividend of 55 cents a share on the company's common stock, payable Feb. 25 to stockholders of record Jan. 21. In previous quarters, shareholders received 50 cents a share.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 21 -- The South African Reserve Bank, yielding to pressure from the Bank of England, has frozen Rhodesian foreign assets estimated at $16.8 million, a qualified source said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Following is the text of the joint communique by President Johnson and Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany, made public today:

THEY did something right with "The Nutcracker," seen in color on the Columbia, Broadcasting System last night. They all but threw the story of Tchaikovsky's much-loved, if overexposed, ballet right out the window into the Christmas snow.

The National Football League said yesterday that championship rulings would prevail Sunday in the Baltimore Colts-Green-Bay Packers Western Conference playoff game. If the game is tied at the end of regulation time, the teams will play sudden-death overtime.

The city government cannot be "paralyzed" just because Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay wants some decisions deferred until he assumes office Jan. 1, Mayor Wagner declared last night. "If it were intended that the Mayor-elect should assume responsibility for government immediately upon his election or shortly thereafter, the Constitution would so provide," Mr. Wagner said.
All five major Mozart operas will be presented in English by the New York City Opera this fail, probably for the first time in a single season by a major American company.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the defending titleholder won his fifth straight game by defeating Bernard Zuckerman of New York in the sixth round of the United States chess championship tournament last night.
MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Union agreed today to give North Vietnam more technical and economic aid. The agreement could also involve increased military assistance.
Thee British pound was firm in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday, closing at $2.8016, unchanged from Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The United States announced today that it would begin soon to fly oil and gasoline into Zambia, which has been deprived of her normal supplies as a result of the British oil embargo on Rhodesia.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- The Boston School Committee voted 3 to 2 last night to ask for funds to provide free transportation to elementary and junior high school pupils as a means of relieving racial imbalance.
MIAMI, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Tibet II, who started the year racing in his native Argentina, survived a bitter stretch battle at Tropical Park today to win the $4,000 featured race by a head.

ATLANTA, Dec. 21 -- A lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union charged today that 11 Negro sharecroppers were being forced from their homes in Wilcox County, Ala., for attempting to register under the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
NEWARK, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The police raided an 18-room mansion at 850 Lake Street last night that they said was a "house of torture" serving a nationwide clientele seeking "unusual thrills."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A bureaucratic conflict is crushing a $41-million program, announced by President Johnson four months ago, to aid the elderly poor.

YONKERS, Dec. 21 -- Sadness swept this holiday-festooned city today, yet that sadness pulled it together in the aftermath of last night's fire in the Jewish Community Center, in which nine children and three adults died.

The Pennsylvania Railroad expects "good business" for the first quarter of 1966 and is "hopeful" that a high level of traffic will continue throughout the year. Stuart T. Saunders, chairman, said in a year-end statement issued yesterday.

JOHN HUARTE left New York the other day. He never really arrived. Frustration shadowed him almost from the moment he signed a Jet contract nearly a year ago. Although his skills had enabled him to leap-frog over other frustrations in the past, the clever quarterback from Notre Dame had seemed anchored firmly on a dead-end street with the Jets.

The appointment of C. Raymond Hulsart as general director of a new department of personnel and industrial relations at The New York Times was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher.

The New York Metropolitan District Chapter No. 4 of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers has installed Warren L. Cruikshank as its new president. Mr. Cruikshank is president of the Cruikshank Company, 48 Wall Street.

News of Sargent Shriver's recommendation (Times, Dec. 15) of a "negative income tax" as part of the comprehensive war on poverty is most welcome. It is only this kind of creative thinking from public officials, long overdue, which will make the attack on poverty truly a war rather than the holding action it now is.
The city's current budget deficit will climb to $412 million by the end of the fiscal year, according to the estimates of Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay's budget study group.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it hoped to recover from its members in January or February the last of $9.5 million advanced to bail out Ira Haupt Co.'s securities customers.

" The Last Battle," by Cornelius Ryan, which Simon and Schuster will publish in March, will be issued simultaneously in England, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Norway, Denmark, Sweden, the Netherlands, Finland and Portugal. The first printing in the United States will be of 100,000 copies.

The people who are the objects of what are probably the most expensive Christmas greetings in town are being denied the pleasure of even opening the envelopes. Indeed, it's likely that hundreds of other people are seeing the cards before the addressees.

The American Express Company said yesterday that it had acquired Uni-Serv Corporation, a Great Neck, L.I., credit-card company, for 201,351 common shares. American Express was trading at around 70 3/8 in the over-the-counter market yesterday, thus putting, an indicated price tag of about $14.9 million on Uni-Serv.

The third "Messiah" of the week turned up at Carnegie Hall last night as T. Charles Lee led his Oratorio Society of New York in its 144th presentation of the Handel score. Running concurrently in Philharmonic Hall was Herman Scherchen's performance, which will be repeated again there tonight.

DENVER, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A Federal appeals court reversed today the conviction of George J. Gessner, a 29-year-old Army deserter who was sentenced to life in prison for turning over nuclear secrets to Russian officials in Mexico City.

IT WAS in the summer of 1924, Stephen Potter recalls, that he suffered the initial trauma that was eventually to lead to the establishment of his now-famous Lifemanship Correspondence College of One-Up-ness and Gameslifemastery. As he tells it, with typical Lifemanese economy:

BRUSSELS, Dec. 21 -- President de Gaulle's comfortable margin of victory Sunday has reinforced the belief in European Community circles that his first-round setback will not make much difference in the Common Market crisis.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 -- Henry M. Hudson of Menlo Park, Calif., is a brawny 52-year-old construction man who has spent the last 25 years building airfields and dams in Afghanistan, Venezuela, Morocco and South Vietnam.

Directors of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday to 37 1/2 cents a share on the common stock from 35 cents paid previously. The new rate will be $1.50 a share compared with $1.40 a share.

Screen rights to "The Saint of Bleecker Street," Gian Carlo Menotti's opera, have been purchased by Roy Newbert, a friend of the composer. Mr. Newbert's short movie, "Forget Me Not," was shown last year at the Spolto Festival, which Mr. Menotti founded.

EL PASO, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- A young Army officer was convicted by a five-man court-martial today of disrespect and conduct unbecoming an officer for demonstrating against the United States' policy in South Vietnam.

The Martin Beck Theater, at 302 West 45th Street off Eighth Avenue, is about to change hands. William L. McKnight, board chairman of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Corporation, confirmed reports yesterday that he was purchasing the 1,280-seat house for $1.5 million as a personal investment.
Hospital staffs should take more responsibility for dealing) with incompetent physicians, accm'ding to a doctor who has made a study of this problem.

A graphic picture of violence was painted yesterday in Federal Court in a suit by the National Labor Relations Board to enjoin a large manufacturer of women's apparel and six of its subsidiaries in the South from interfering with the union organization of its Southern employes.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- Stan Mikita drove in a slap shot with less than seven minutes to play to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 4-3 victory over the New York Rangers tonight.
" VIVA SOPHIA" the crowd screamed -- and broke through the police barricades.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- A group of professors, bishops, writers and actors took a full-page advertisement in The Times of London today to appeal to the United States to strive to end the war in Vietnam by peaceful means.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The British Government, refusing to take any chances of jeopardizing the recovery of sterling, announced today deferment of payments to the United States and Canada on loans made at the end of World War II.

LAST night at the Metropolitano Opera, Gounod's "Faust" was 12 performances old, as far this season is concerned. Given a brand new production for the opening of the season in September, the company has been presenting the work with a vengeance, but at least it has had the benefit of many changes in cast in the leading roles.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- Australia was established as a 4-1 favorite tonight to retain the Davis Cup in the challenge round against Spain beginning Monday.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday the promotions of high executives.

A number of politicians, statesmen and others who are publicly concerned with the national economy have voiced uneasiness over the increases in consumer prices and credit costs they say will be by-products of the recent rise in the Federal discount rate.

American President Lines has appealed to the Departments of State and Commerce for help in maintaining an "around the world" cruise schedule that calls for a stop at the Israeli port of Haifi after a trip through the Suez Canal.

TORONTO, Dec. 22 -- The Globe and Mail of Toronto, one of Canada's most respected newspapers, has joined with FP Publications, Ltd., an eight-paper Canadian chain headed by G. Max Bell, an Alberta financier and racing figure.

YONKERS, Dec. 22 -- The fire in the Jewish Community Center here Monday night, in which nine children and three adults died, may have been partly fed by sheets of inflammable plastic that were recently installed in the auditorium as part of a $500,000 improvement project.

Several score residents of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn pleaded with Mayor Wagner for three and a half hours at a public hearing yesterday to veto a bill to curb so-called "gypsy" taxicabs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A staff shake-up in the Justice Department's Antitrust Division was announced today by Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach.
NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 22 (UPI) -- The University of Oklahoma selected the Arkansas defensive mentor, Jim Mackenzie, to take over the Sooners' head football coaching job today.
Gale Sayers, the Chicago Bears' halfback, was voted rookie of the year in the National Football League in two polls yesterday.
The Raytheon Company had a rash of news developments yesterday.

GRAND Master Nicholas Rossolimo of New York took the measure of a former United States champion, Arthur Bisguier of Westchester, in the second round of the current United States championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

The Federal District Court in Chicago was asked yesterday to deny a notion made in October by the New York Stock Exchange and four member firms for dismissal of a suit charging them with violation of the antitrust laws.
Capital funds of $255,375 toward construction of the Dag Hammarskjold Memorial Bridge, a pedestrian overpass near the United Nations, were approved by the City Planning Commission yesterday.
Tens of thousands of children in community center music classes and art workshops in the city depend for their lives in a fire emergency on the calmness and quick thinking of their teachers.
VIENNA, Dec. 22 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist party, in a highly unusual 19,000-word document, denounced itself today for having made disastrous economic mistakes.
FAYETTE, Miss., Dec. 22 -- The newly registered Negro voters of this town have found a way to use their ballot power a year and a half before the next local primary election.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A liberal Republican organization, rebutting Barry Goldwater's Free Society Association, said today "a glorious political opportunity" beckoned to Republicans in big cities.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 23 -- The United States and its allies have ordered a 30-hour Christmas truce in the Vietnamese war, an official spokesman announced this morning.
For four commodities -- cocoa, copper, pork bellies and Maine potatoes -- yesterday was a day or rising prices in busy future markets.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission of the City of New York has decided not to designate the present Metropolitan Opera House an official landmark.

NEWARK, Dec. 22 -- A man and woman arrested yesterday in a raid on a 20-room "house of torture" were ordered held today for grand jury action on charges involving sadism, masochism and sex perversion.

The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority has acquired for $1 million a key piece of property for the long-proposed Mid-Manhattan Expressway. The projected $135 million elevated highway has never been approved by a city agency, and there is serious doubt that it will ever be built.

Eight Soviet athletes will compete in American indoor track meets this winter, the Amateur Athletic Union said yesterday. One of their four meets will be the New York Athletic Club Games Feb. 18 at Madison Square Garden.
The terminal manager of a Brooklyn trucking company who allegedly attempted to arrange sweetheart contracts for a number of concerns was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on perjury charges.
The New York Couture Group and the American Fashion Business Council will meet today to discuss the possibility of merging the two organizations.
Three American companies were reported yesterday to have reached an understanding with India to form a huge petrochemical complex in Koyali in the state of Gujarat.
An agreeable young tenor, William Elliott, who accompanied himself on guitar and banjo, gave a program of international folk and folkish songs last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
ROME, Dec. 22 -- Pope Paul VI was reported today to be directing a program of active Vatican diplomacy to encourage negotiations toward ending the war in Vietnam.
MONTREAL, Dec. 22 (Canadian Press -- Substantial reductions in a wide range of north Atlantic air-cargo rates will take effect Jan. 1 the International Air Transport Association announced today.
The appointing of new officers and supervisory board members was announced yesterday by several banks.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Bob Hope fell five feet from a stage in Korat Air Base today and tore at least two ligaments in his left ankle.
Twenty-five young women were presented at the ninth Mistletoe Debutante Ball at the Pierre last night.
Two of the original contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund maintained yesterday a tradition of giving that goes back to 1912.
PHOENIX, Ariz. Dec. 22 (AP) -- Contempt of court proceedings were ordered today against Phoenix Newspapers, Inc., in connection with published reports of a recent murder case.
British operators of general cargo ships in the North Atlantic have been urged to face up to the threat about to be posed by foreign competition in container-shipping.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A group of prominent law professors sent a strong letter to President Johnson today opposing any use of the draft to stifle criticism of Administration policy.

HARADH, Yemen, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- Royalist and republican delegates attending the Yemeni peace conference here denied today that the talks had failed, and said their forces would resume fighting only in self-defense.
WASHINGTON Dec. 22 -- The space agency began trying today to offset the tight squeeze on its budget for next year by announcing a stopgap planetary exploration program.

License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo confirmed yesterday that he had issued a cabaret license to the Playboy Club after it had "made every effort" to alter publicity showing waitresses, or "bunnies," mingling with patrons. Such mingling is unlawful here.
PARIS, Dec. 22 -- France is notifying her Common Market partners that she is willing to discuss the issues that divide them at a meeting in Luxembourg in the latter half of January.
One week from now, the Atlanta Falcons, who have no coach, no schedule, no training camp and no plays, will have no more season tickets.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A man was shot to death and another critically wounded today in the office of the East Liberty Presbyterian Church.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Harold A.R. Philby, the American-born wife of the wartime British intelligence agent and newsman who defected to the Soviet Union, has left Moscow to live in Ireland, informed sources reported today.

Four hundred Italian immigrants admitted to the United States under the provisions of the new immigration law abolishing the national origins quota arrived yesterday aboard the Italian liner Michelangelo.
The Greenwich Village Independent Democratic Club has voted support for Robert J. Schwartz for the Democratic nomination in the special election for Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay's seat in Congress.
DETROIT, Dec. 22 (AP) -- United States auto output this week was estimated at 150,288 units, the highest ever for a Christmas week, according to the trade publication Automotive News.
Professional football attendance climbed again this year and has only one way to go in the future -- further up.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- Social Security taxes will go up with the first paycheck of the new year.
Three bandits stole $23,122 in cash, wigs and wiglets from a Madison Avenue wig jobber and a couple who were delivering wigs to him yesterday afternoon.

The warning given to Mayor-elect Lindsay by his financial task force that revenues in the city's current fiscal year will fall $412 million short of expenditures, instead of $300 million as recently estimated by the Schwulst commission, adds to the seriousness of an already grave situation.
A delivery boy battled a knife-wielding payroll-robbery suspect yesterday until the police arrived.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Butler hit on 31 of 53 shots from the floor tonight and defeated Michigan, the nations No. 3 college basketball team, 79-64.
An increase of 1,827,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks for the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

The administration of St. John's University has, judging by the stories in The Times, acted with nice attention to legal requirements in dismissing wholesale those faculty members who sought a stronger voice for teachers in the conduct of the university.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Jim Barnes stole the ball from Jerry Lucas and passed to Bailey Howell for the game-winning basket with 12 seconds remaining as the Baltimore Bullets defeated the Cincinnati Royals in overtime tonight, 129-127.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- In an Administration where major policy appears often to be based on, or greatly influenced by, sample public opinion polls and the battery of machines which keep President Johnson constantly informed of how the news is being handled on television and in the press, Washington is absorbed to a higher degree than usual in its favorite game of guessing.

Robert Moses, whose contract as president of the World's Fair runs to over $1 million in salary and deferred compensation, never tired of repeating that his enterprise was not run for profit. He was so right.
BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- Two Americans have been convicted by an East German court on charges of having helped East Germans flee to the West and have been sentenced to eight years at hard labor.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday the election of John B. McKitterick as a vice president and a member of the executive office, G.E.'s policy-making group. He has been manager of the company's corporate planning operation since it was established two years ago.
The appointment of Gordon Patterson to the new post of vice chairman of Eaton, Yale Towne, Inc., was announced here yesterday.
HOUSTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- Lieut. Col. Frank Borman and Comdr. James A. Lovell Jr., the Gemini 7 astronauts, came home for the Christmas holidays today "to see if everything looks the same."

OXFORD, Md., Dec. 22 -Every outdoors stalwart has heard certain horrible words on a day when the sport is nonexistent. The phrase goes, "You should have been here yesterday." It's always yesterday or last week when the hunting or fishing was great.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 22 -- Calm edged with anxiety characterized this capital late today after a long night of sporadic firing, troop movements of the Dominican forces and the destruction of a radio station specializing in news.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay announced yesterday that two career members of the Fire Department would become the chief deputies to Robert O. Lowery, whom he has designated as the next Fire Commissioner.

Is E.J. Korvette, Inc., seeking a new president?

The following is an illustrative analysis of one-year credit charges imposed by four types of lenders for each $100 they lend. Smith of the University of Pennsylvania and published last year by the Princeton University Press.

" The Grand Design: A European Solution to German Reunification" by Franz Josef Strauss, will be published next month by Praeger. The former Defense Minster of West Germany contends that "Only a Germany contained within a Federated Europe can be prevented from taking dangerous national initiatives."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Treasury announced today that it would borrow about $5 billion in the first half of next year and disclosed plans for raising $3.8 billion of that sum.
The Misses Wendy Sherman, Anne Hayes Devereux, Gwendolyn Ford Dunaway and Helene Gertrude Brent, former classmates at the Chapin School, were honored by parties last night.

Stan McKenzie, New York University's high-scoring senior forward who was injured Tuesday night, is expected to be in the Violets' basketball lineup against Providence College Monday night in the Holiday Festival tournament at Madison Square Garden.

Tenants who deposit money with landlords and homeowners who put money in escrow accounts with mortgagees would receive interest under new legislation prepared by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

MIAMI, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Red Redeemer, a 40-1 shot, won the sixth race at Tropical Park today and another 40-1 shot, Hill Chance, just missed in the featured seventh race as his bid to catch the favored Ocala Bandit failed.
A State Supreme Court justice said at a hearing yesterday that the police were unsuited to tell suspected criminals of their rights. He proposed that magistrates do the job instead.

WHATEVER the opposite of foolproof is, that's what Michelangelo is these days. The most respectful efforts to make popular interpretations of his life and art seem doomed from the moment of conception.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 22 -- A second gift of $150,000 has been presented to Pinceton University by Miss Doris Duke, the Somerville, N.J., heiress, in support of the university's Program in Russian Studies, the university's president, Robert F. Goheen, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced tonight that a maximum of 1,039,550 barrels a day of crude oil, unfinished oils and finished petroleum products might be imported into the United States under license during the year beginning Jan 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Exports rose 3 per cent in November to a seasonally adjusted total of $2,405,900,000, the Commerce Department reported today. This compared with October's exports of $2,348,600,000.
School officials from New York City and four nearby suburban counties joined together yesterday for the first time to ask Governor Rockefeller to support increased state aid to education.
The United States Lines has established a trade development department to help exporters and importers to expand their foreign trade activities and to assist newcomers into the field.

The stock market gave a dramatic, but erratic, performance yesterday.
Wes Westrum made his first appearance at Shea Stadium yesterday since he was formally named as the manager of the New York Mets, and he unlimbered one resolution and several hints for the new year.
The three-man mediation panel in the transit dispute reported to Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday that negotiations were proceeding satisfactorily, despite the nearness of the Jan. 1 deadline.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) An aide to Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that he expected Mr. Harris to resign and become a Federal judge "in a very short time."

A 16-month-old antihijacking rule requiring locked cockpit doors during flight has been eased in the case of airliners having an extra emergency exit forward of the cockpit door. The purpose is to make available to passengers an additional exit should an emergency occur.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 22 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson celebrated her 53d birthday today in a way used by many women who want to forget they are getting older -- she kept busy.
VIENNA, Dec. 22. (Reuters) -- Rumania s Grand National Assembly or Parliament voted unanimously today in favor of a measure giving it new functions.
St. John's University broke its silence last night to suggest that some of the 31 faculty members it had summarily dismissed were discharged for "unprofessional conduct."

THE new edition of Ben Bagley's montage of Cole Porter songs, which opened last night at the Square East, has undergone a change in title from "The Decline and Fall of the Entire World as Seen Through the Eyes of Cole Porter Revisited" to "Ben Bagley's New Cole Porter Revue."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Labor costs for each unit of output in manufacturing remained essentially stable in November, the Census Bureau reported today.
IN the 3 hours and 17 minutes (not counting intermission time) it takes to move Robert Bolt's dramatization of Boris Pasternak's "Doctor Zhivago" across the screen, a few rather major things happen.

THE editors of Ski Magazine have just prepared an explanation of the new standard snow-reporting system adopted by the New England members of the Eastern Ski Area Operators for official press wire-service reports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A Presidential commission on automation has found that technological change presents no basic threat to employment that cannot be overcome by vigorous fiscal policies to spur economic growth.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- There's more than one way to be an attractive Frenchwoman, and Mrs. Charles Lucet, the wife of the new French Ambassador who arrived here last month, demonstrated this at her first party, a luncheon today for 14 members of the women's press corps.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The new United States Commissioner of Education patted the South on the back today for its desegregation efforts, but pledged "vigorous enforcement" of Federal laws to speed up the process.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association gave early Christmas presents yesterday to three of the nation's outstanding tennis prospects. They are ob Lutz of Los Angeles, Zan Guerry of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., and Jane (Peaches) Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Prime Minister Wilson announced tonight his first Cabinet shuffle since taking office 14 months ago.

Six charities have benefited to the extent of $250 each as an indirect outcome of the 1960 conflict-of-interest trial that led to the downfall of Hulan Jack, the first Negro to hold the Manhattan Borough Presidency.

COLOGNE, Germany -- More than one-quarter of the workers at the big German Ford plant here are Turks. There now are 6,200 of them at the plant, more than 1,000 miles from the Bosporous.

ROME, Dec. 22 -- Rome will experimentally ban all private and commercial vehicles from a downtown triangle roughly comparable in extent to the area between Broadway and Seventh Avenue from Times Square to Central Park.

The nationwide debate over confessions is approaching a critical point. In the last few weeks the United States Supreme Court has agreed to consider six cases raising many questions of a suspect's rights at the questioning stage of a case.

The Erhard-Johnson talks have made it clear that the project for a NATO nuclear force will continue in orbit around the alliance. The project is five years old this month, but so far no one has devised a way either to shoot it down or to bring it back safely to earth for implementation.
Monday's advance in Government bond prices from increased hopes for Vietnam peace talks has been wiped out.

St. John's University, currently embroiled in a faculty dispute, is operated by a religious order that began serving the poor in rural France 340 years ago and soon discovered that the education of priests was basic to its task.

The British pound continued firm in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday, closing at $2.8018, 2 points higher than Tuesday.

The London Stock Exchange closed yesterday with modest gains. Aircraft and aircraft-equipment issues led the industrials because of news of a big defense order from Saudi Arabia. Steels and tobaccos also showed strong support.

WASHINGTON Dec. 22 -- The multilateral nuclear force (MLF), a daring diplomatic idea of remarkable resilience and worldwide fame, died quietly last night at the age of 5.

Cornell, which has achieved a high rank in college hockey in only seven years, won the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival last night by beating St. Lawrence, 5-2, at Madison Square Garden.

A NICE perky little animated cartoon for the children's holiday season opened yesterday in neighborhood theaters -- "Pinocchio in Outer Space." It's a new, streamlined roundup of the famous characters by Collodi, adapted to the space age, against some pretty, imaginatively colored backgrounds, moving along with an easy sense of fun for the space-minded young.

GREENPORT, L.I., Dec. 22 -- A few members of the domestic Peace Corps exchanged Christmas good-bys here this week on the rural north fork of Long Island, before separating for the holidays. Two of them headed home, somewhat reluctantly, as three others stayed in the slums and migrant farm camps where they have lived for the last six months.

Dr. John V. Connorton, Deputy Mayor-City Administrator since last Feb. 1, will return on Jan. 1 to his post as the paid head of the Greater New York Hospital Association, its president, Msgr. Patrick J. Frawley, announced yesterday. Dr. Connorton will have a new title, executive vice president.

SEATTLE, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A painting Manfred Selig bought for $100 to brighten an office wall was painted on top of a second work that might fetch a quarter of a million dollars, Louis R. Guzzo, assistant managing editor of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, said in a copyrighted article this week.
Michael Myerson, under indictment in a $15 million stock fraud case, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to four years in prison following his conviction on income tax evasion for 1956.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- Arthur J. Goldberg criticized the Asian-African group today for changing the rules on what is and what is not a question of importance in the General Assembly.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 22 -- President Johnson continued work on his forthcoming budget today after what the White House called "probably the busiest week he has had as President."

ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP) -- A truck-trailer driver was killed and 15 persons injured today when a Santa Fe passenger train smashed into the truck at an intersection.

Alexander Schneider began last night's Carnegie Hall Hall chamber music concert as a violinist, and ended it as a Doctor of Fine Arts, honoris causa. GEN. ALFRED M. GRUENTHER, the wartme figure and former head of NATO, now honorary president of the World Bridge Federation, is expected to leave Harkness Pavilion today following a successful hip-joint operation designed to cure an arthritic condition.

FORGET the gander. What's good for the goose is a savory stuffing made with the likes of chestnuts and chicken stock, spiced sausage and apples and such seasonings as bay leaf, rosemary and thyme. As an added fillip for those who desire, there's a dash or two of applejack. A recipe for such a stuffing is given here as well as a menu for the Christmas feast.

GENEVA, Dec. 22 -- A bewhiskered Dutch-born United States citizen whose nonconformism caused Swiss authorities to expel him last October was back in Switzerland today for the holidays with his family. He has permission to stay until Jan. 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- "Hi, out there, space fans. This is your old pal, Bill Bellclapper, bringing you the post-orbit wrap-up direct from oceanside. The Belock Instrument Corporation announced yesterday the appointments of senior officers to replace three executives who were discharged last fall.

A John F. Kennedy Memorial, completed in Brooklyn's Grand Army Plaza less than seven months ago, has been disassembled and covered up because its white Vermont marble has turned brown. Visitors to the monument were confronted yesterday by a white shack constructed Tuesday over the site.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The state department deplored today the arrest of an American woman in East Germany and the sentencing of two American men to hard labor.

A Pennsylvania Representative charged last night that two Alabama men forced their way into the home of a 19-year-old Pennsylvania Negro last Sunday night, handcuffed him and took him back to Alabama, where he was wanted for jumping bail while facing assault charges.

Tiffany Co., which proudly claims to be the only retailer that offers customers not what they want but rather what it wants them to have, unfolded a tale of Christmas prosperity yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Military Sea Transportation Service asked today for more offers of American-flag and foreign-flag cargo ships to transport military cargoes to the Far East, including Vietnam.
