WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- James Edward Kennedy, 28 years old, one of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 most wanted fugitives, was arrested tonight in Worcester, Mass., after a gun battle with Federal agents and the Worcester police.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the week ended Dec. 18 were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1964.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- For the first time Gen. Mustafa al-Barzani's Kurdish guerrillas are continuing their fighting against the Iraqi Army into the winter, according to letters received here from Kurdish headquarters.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 23 -- Swaran Singh, India's Foreign Minister, left today on a mission to Moscow.

The recent discussions of the independence of the Federal Reserve System by Eileen Shanahan (Dec. 6) and M.J. Rossant's editorial page column (Dec. 13) have been constructive contributions to a subject of great importance to the American people.

The Chase Manhattan Bank disclosed yesterday that the Controller of the Currency had advised it on Dec. 15 that its bid to acquire the outstanding common stock of a Buffalo bank was subject to the Federal Bank Merger Act of 1960.

NUKUALOFA, Tonga, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Fifty thousand Tongans donned mourning black today and sat for nearly three hours in the rain to say fare well to their beloved Queen Salote. It had not rained for months, and the Tongans said the skies were weeping for their ruler.

Where, oh where but at the Plaza could this season's flock of debutantes be found last night? The white-gowned young women swooped back to the hotel, where many had been presented at previous parties, for the second and last of this year's Junior Assemblies.
Associate Transport, Inc., a large freight forwarder, announced the appointment here yesterday of John J. Lane as senior vice president.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The Government placed "direct orders" today with 10 clothing manufacturers for 1.06 million pairs of cotton olive-green trousers for the armed forces.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 23 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot summary market prices for the dates shown:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Federal scientists have made a major breakthrough in the universal search for a solution to the world food crisis.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The Green Bay Packers today sharpened their short passing game for anticipated "blitzing" by the Baltimore Colts in their playoff for the Western Conference championship of the National Football League Sunday.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The United States marines rolled out their "Jingle Bell Special" -- an amphibian tractor -- and brought Christmas cheer today to the South Vietnamese.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- The Chicago Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America announced today a scholarship program for members' children regardless of their grades in school. Even dropouts will be covered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that its use of an informer to report on the jury-tampering activities of James R. Hoffa had not violated his constitutional rights.
PARIS, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Esso France has ordered two of the world's largest oil tankers, each of 170,800 tons, from the French Chantiers de l'Atlantique shipyard at St. Nazaire.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Seventeen years to the day since its Covent Garden premiere, Frederick Ashton's "Cinderella" was given by the Royal Ballet tonight in a revised and completely redecorated production.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Gemini 6 and Gemini 7 apparently came within a foot of each other during their historic rendezvous flight, a space agency official said tonight.

Peter G. Tuttle, 36-year-old son of Day Tuttle, theater producer, has been missing since Nov. 28 when he left his parents' home here to return to the Connecticut Valley Hospital at Middletown, Conn., where he was a mental patient.
United States consumption of newsprint -- a key indicator of how business is faring -- set new highs in November and the first 11 months of 1965.
PARIS, Dec. 23 -- President de Gaulle declared an amnesty today for 203 person convicted of subversive activities in the drive against Algerian independence.
A FAST amphibian (70 miles an hour on land, 30 knots on water) and a finish-it-yourself sailboat are among the more noteworthy offbeat items being tuned up for next month's boat shows.

KNOWLEDGE of the book procedure for handling common suit combinations helps one to play bridge competently, but rather more is needed to play expertly. Circumstances alter combinations, and if there are reasons to think that the normal play will not succeed an abnormal play may be given preference.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23 -- Argentina is laboring under a surplus of sugar and a scarcity of money, and these dry economic facts made spectacular news today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Scientists of the United States Public Health Service reported today that radioactive caribou and reindeer might pose a health threat to nearly all residents of Alaska and not just, as previously reported, to Eskimos living near the Arctic Circle.

THE personage in whose name millions of benefactions, mostly for the pleasure of children, will be strewn tomorrow morning under decorated trees, stuffed into stockings or piled on mantelpieces throughout most of the Western world is sometimes regarded as mythic.
Small changes and limited trading were the order of the day yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
The city announced yesterday a $12 million program -- the Federal government contributing $8 million -- to save eight old neighborhoods that are fast becoming slums.
A $20,000 cello that was stolen from a parked car last week was recovered from a pawnshop yesterday. The ecstatic owner paid $25 to redeem it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Imports fell 5 per cent in November to $1,903,300,000, seasonally adjusted, the Commerce Department reported today.
The British pound was firm on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. After a fairly active morning, trading was near a standstill. The currency closed at $2.8021, up 3 points from Wednesday.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 21 -- When Prime Minister Ian D. Smith declared Rhodesia independent from Britain less than two months ago, most observers were inclined to predict one or the other of two results of the crisis.

ROME, Dec. 23 -- Pope Paul VI delivered a Christmas appeal for world peace tonight, praising "just and sincere negotiation" and condemning wars fomented by "underhanded schemes and contrived disorder."

YONKERS, Dec. 23 -- City officials defended the Yonkers Fire Department today against charges that it was slow to respond, and was inept and cowardly during Monday night's fire at the Jewish Community Center, where 12 persons died.
The Korean Orphan Choir, now on tour in the United States, sang at Carnegie Hall last night.
LARAMIE, Wyo., Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Leon Clark, hitting on 67 per cent of his shots, scored 30 points tonight and led the Wyoming Cowboys to a 99-92 victory over St. Joseph's of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse said on his return today from a five-week tour of Asia that "there is a disturbing lack of enthusiastic support for our present course of policy in Vietnam."
The $2.5 billion Bowery Savings Bank finally got around yesterday to dropping the other shoe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- An impoverished Indian tribe on a remote peninsula in Northern Wisconsin seems eager to welcome back two young volunteers of the domestic peace corps who were expelled from the reservation two weeks ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Senator Elisha T. Barrett, Republican of Suffolk County, who was passed over for the chairmanship of the Senate Finance Committee, was named today to the newly created post of vice chairman of the committee.
CARTIER'S Christmas tree is 30 inches high and worth $662,670, give or take a few strings of popcorn and cranberries.
Larry N. Field, formerly a broker here, has been named executive vice president of the Los Angeles office of the Benjamin Shore Company, national mortgage financing concern.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- An article in The Journal of the American Medical Association today questioned the use of artificial heart valves. It acknowledged their value in extreme cases but suggested they had been overused.
William M. Cameron, president of the Rath Packing Company, has been elected a director of the Chicago Great Western Railway Company.
An annual gift to the Neediest Cases Fund arrived once again from an upstate address -- $1 "in loving memory of Billy Boy."
A drug that may improve learning and memory is being tested in humans following laboratory experiments suggesting that it has this effect on rats.

Whispers have the impact of cheers these nights in the small ballroom where the nation's top chess players are sweating quietly over their boards for the United States championship and a $2,000 prize.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The Buffalo Bills alternated three men at split end today as Coach Lou Saban became more convinced that his club would have to go to the air frequently to defeat the San Diego Chargers in Sunday's American Football League title game.

The Citizens Tax Council has voted a $400,000 budget for its legislative committee's attempt to block the second passage of a proposed state constitutional amendment that would increase New York City's real estate taxing authority.

' TWAS the night before Christmas and all through the house not a creature was stirring. . . . Oh, well, you know how the rest of it goes. Santa Claus is on his way with a bag full of goodies. Let's take a peek and see what he may be bringing to those shiny-eyed little rascals in the world of sports.
PLAINVIEW, L.I., Dec. 23 -- A branch of the Sunrise Federal Savings and Loan Association was robbed by three armed men here today. The masked thieves escaped with about $10,000.
Hyman Dechter, a 37-year-old lawyer, announced yesterday that he was seeking support in next June's primary against Representative Leonard Farbstein in the 19th Congressional District.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Johnson administration has again moved to check a threatened price increase.
ATHENS, Dec. 23 -- Greece reaffirmed today her willingness to work with Turkey for a solution on Cyprus.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 -- The series of terrorist incidents in the heart of Saigon and small guerrilla military attacks within the city limits this month illustrate that even in areas of Government "control" the Vietcong can still operate on a limited scale.
DETROIT, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Paul Henderson scored two goals within 45 seconds of the last period tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 4-2 victory over the New York Rangers.
All major New York terminals did "standing room only" business yesterday as travelers began the annual rush into and out of the city for the three-day Christmas holiday.

In a letter published Dec. 16 raising unspecified objections to the National Council of Churches' recent policy statement on Vietnam, Dr. Daniel A. Poling erred in saying that the statement was drafted by the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, Stated Clerk (chief administrative officer) of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

STONEWALL, Tex. Dec. 23 (AP) -- Four Syracuse antipoverty workers who wanted to take their dispute over Federal funds to President Johnson were admitted to the Johnson ranch today after being arrested.

Former President Truman put himself into an old and jingoistic line of American political philosophy in his tart remark about the criticism of President Johnson's Vietnam policy by Senators Robert and Edward Kennedy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 -- The possibility that the Vietcong guerrillas may resume military operations before the end of the 30-hour Christmas truce ordered by the United States and its allies was raised tonight in a broadcast by the guerrilla's clandestine Liberation Radio.
BONN, Dec. 23 -- Shares of the Vereinigte Elektrizitaets Bergwerke Aktiengesellschaft (Veba), West Germany's newest "people's stock," has been battered by a wave of heavy selling this week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Capt. Herbert Fox Rommel pulled down today his sign threatening passersby at Anacostia Naval air station. The sign read:
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Del Lewis, the smallest man in the Kansas line-up, led a second-half rally tonight that carried the Jayhawks to an 81-68 basketball victory over Ohio State.

The Village Theater at Second Avenue and Sixth Street, formerly known as the Commodore Theater, has been sold by Loew's Theaters, Inc., to Roger Euster, an investor, for cash above a first mortgage of $400,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The granddaughter of former Secretary of State Dean Acheson, the daughter of the Secretary of the Navy, Paul Nitze, and the daughter of the Commissioner of Education, Francis Keppel, were among the 23 young women who made their bows at midnight last night at the annual Washington Debutante Ball at the Mayflower Hotel.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- The Defense Ministry announced today that France's reduced 6,600-man force in black Africa would be concentrated next year in three main bases: Dakar, Senegal; Fort Lamy, Chad, and Diego Suarez in Madagascar.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Is the play "A Cat Called Jesus" immoral and sacrilegious?
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Rams dismissed Harland Svare today as head coach of the National Football League team.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The State of Wisconsin contended today it was trying to protect baseball, not "bury the game" with its antitrust suit against the Braves and other National League clubs.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 23 -- State subsidies for goods and services, a cardinal aspect of Communist practice, are being sharply reduced in several East European countries as a result of economic reforms.
Burton B. Roberts, an assistant district attorney for 17 years in Manhattan, was named chief assistant district attorney for Bronx County in an unusual move yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Tariff Commission began an investigation today that could lead to the end of the controversial 40-year-old system of "American selling price" customs valuation for coal-tar chemicals and a few other products.
Purdue is experiencing only a fair basketball season, but not through any fault of Dave Schellhase, who continues to lead the nation in scoring.
With more than 5,300 commercial radio stations operating in this country, how is it possible for one to be completely different from all others?
ERNIE LADD, a defensive tackle for the San Diego Chargers, is the largest man in pro football. His height is 6 feet 9 inches, his weight 300 pounds plus, and how much plus is Ernie's secret.

The heads of eight leading book-publishing houses, the president of the American Book Publishers Council and a Westchester Congressman appealed to the Government yesterday to keep open its library in London.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 23 -- The New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry announced tonight that on Jan. 1 it would end its affiliation with the Jersey City Medical Center.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 23 (UPI) Tom Matte and Bob Boyd, two ersatz quarterbacks, worked hard today at learning to "stay in the pocket" while passing as the Baltimore Colts practiced for Sunday's title game with the Green Bay Packers.
Was it an operetta? A Japanese Noh drama? Amateur night? Or, as one member of the audience asked, the Jewish Museum's version of a Hanukkah party?
For one of the last times in the rapidly expiring Wagner administration, City Hall echoed yesterday to the applause of an auditorium-full of friends of persons named or renamed to public office.

MIAMI, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Ogden Phipp's Buckpasser and John W. Galbreath's Graustark headed a list of 92 horses nominated today for Hialeah Park's $100,000 added Flamingo Stakes to be run on closing day, March 3.
Earnings and operations of Texaco, Inc., for 1965 will reach new highs, J. Howard Rambin Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said yesterday in a year-end statement.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 23 -- Recent psychiatric studies at the University of Michigan indicate that more than half the drivers responsible for a series of fatal automobile accidents suffered some form of mental illness.
Four youths staged an audacious robbery of a jewelry store on West 57th Street at about 7 o'clock last night by smashing a show window with a rock and scooping out an estimated $40,000 worth of gems.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 23 -- Alfred Hitchcock and James Stewart have filed an unusual suit against Paramount Pictures charging improper distribution of the 10-year-old motion picture "The Man Who Knew Too Much."
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick said yesterday that his department's modernization program should eliminate the need for increases in police manpower.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 -Ten tiny orphans from India arrived by plane today and were swept into the arms of 10 eager mothers.

SAUL ALINSKY, whose organization of people in slum areas has projected him into the forefront of national controversy, was seen last night in an hour-long conversation produced by Station WTTW in Chicago for the National Educational Television network.
More shipping was lost in 1964 than in any of the preceding 12 years.

Senator Aiken of Vermont doubtless had no intention of being ironical when he said: "Up to now Communist China is winning the war in Vietnam." This is true -- but there certainly is irony in the situation.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Dec. 23 -- President Johnson and his family came to his boyhood home to hear some Christmas carols tonight, joined in the singing themselves, and then served hot chocolate, candy and cookies to the singers.

One of the last treasures to be snatched from the rising waters behind Egypt's new High Dam at Aswan is an ancient Christian prayer book, recovered from the ruins of a monastery about 10 miles south of the temple of Abu Simbel.
The City Council refused yesterday to extend beyond Jan. 1 a permit allowing the open burning of waste timber from construction sites.
The Board of Education has cleared the way for the design of tile city's first-building project that will combine a full-size public school with a high-rise apartment house.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday rejected Robert Moses' plan for a Mid-Manhattan Expressway. He appeared angered by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority's acquistion of property on the route of the projected highway.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 23 (UPI) -- A Federal Court judge issued a temporary restraining order today against white landlords, barring them from evicting Negro tenants who have registered to vote. The case is the first test of the intimidation section of the 1965 Voting Rights Act.

NASHVILLE, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Buford Ellington, director of the United States Office of Emergency Planning, said today he expected to return to Tennessee soon -- "whether it be to go back to private industry or for politics."
The American Stock Exchange had a king-sized power blackout yesterday.
THE beauty gift is the easiest to buy at the last minute. There is no problem of size, it comes attractively wrapped and at virtually any price.
It must be expected that the Dominican Republic will act like a volcano. It has erupted again, starting with an obscure bloody battle in Santiago and rioting in Santo Domingo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Johnson Administration officials were highly doubtful today that the Christmastime truce agreed to by the United States and South Vietnam would provide an opening wedge for a prolonged cease-fire or negotiations in the Vietnamese war.

The United States Court of Appeals yesterday reversed the conviction of George B. Robbins, 51-year-old colonel in the Air Force Reserve, for collecting $835 in unemployment compensation while he was employed as a company executive and drew pay from the Air Force.

MEXICO CITY, Dee. 23 -- It has been a good year, and Mexicans are acting in this Christmas season as if it had never been better. The lights have never been brighter, the stores never more crowded, the police never busier.

The first complete publication of the 16 documents of Ecumenical Council Vatican II, with commentary by more than 30 Roman Catholic, Protestant and Eastern Orthodox theologians, will come off the presses on March 7.

A city labor official offered yesterday to mediate the 10 month-old dispute between St. John's University and the United Federation of College Teachers, but a St. John's spokesman indicated the university would reject the offer.
NEWARK Dec. 23 -- This city's independent antipoverty agency issued a long and stinging rebuttal today to charges of lax fiscal control, extravagance, autocratic rule and political pressure tactics.
A Federal grant of $661,151 has been made for the creation of a model health program at Gouverneur Hospital, which will be a major element in a campaign against poverty on the Lower East Side.
Charles G. Mackenzie was named yesterday as a senior vice president of the Atlantic Companies, comprising the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company and the Centennial Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading today in three stocks that have had speculative run-ups following reports of their planned entry into the production and marketing of color-television sets.
Famine conditions in India were very much in wheat traders minds yesterday in Chicago.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 -- Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York and the Roman Catholic Church's military vicar to the armed forces of the United States, arrived in South Vietnam today for a five-day Christmas visit.
NEWARK, Dec. 23 -- The Newark Teachers Union and 10 officers were fined a total of $3,700 today by Superior Court Judge Ward J. Herbert. They had been found guilty last Friday of contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Senator J.W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that he saw no reason for controversy because he and his wife had not been invited to recent state dinners at the White House.
The Life Insurance Association of America announced the promotion yesterday of George H. Davis from associate actuary to actuary.

PARIS -- The political shadow cast by nuclear weapons must increasingly color U.S. relations with both its allies and adversaries in Europe. Discussion of the excruciating problems involved had been held in abeyance until after the German and French elections.

A singing group made up of eight 11-year-old schoolboys was the focal point of a Christmas party held yesterday aboard a Brooklyn school bus as it left Public School 225, at 1075 Ocean View Avenue in Brighton Beach, for Brownsville 12 miles away.
BALBOA, C.Z., Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Authorities here prepared a report today on the strange case of a Dutch seaman who "jumped ship" at sea Saturday and apparently gave a false name to rescuers.
HARTFORD -- On a cold, windy day early this week, hundreds of women shuffled impatiently outside the doors of G. Fox Co., department store here, waiting for it to open.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 23 -- Florida's banking commissioner, State Controller Fred O. Dickinson Jr., has declared a one-year moratorium on the issuance of state bank charters to give Florida's 441 banks a chance "to consolidate their positions."

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 23 -- Col. Francisco Caamano Deno, who led last summer's rebel movement, said today that the Dominican people were "very, very close" to the end of their patience and would no longer tolerate aggression by Government troops.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Traditional British reserve was left at home today by many of the 600 stockholders who filed into the large hall of a West End hotel for the annual meeting of the British Printing Corporation.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Eight Brighton commuters staged a modern version today of the race between the tortoise and the hare and proved that commuting was faster by train than by helicopter -- at least in England.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller, in a poetic mood, accepted today California Gov. Edmund Brown's invitation to wager on the outcome of the American Football League title game between the Buffalo Bills and the San Diego Chargers on Sunday.
Dr. Nathan P. Feinsinger, chairman of the transit mediation panel, ate some humble pie yesterday, but then did some tough talking to both sides in the bus and subway dispute.
A monumental radio survey of the sky has produced evidence of a proliferation of gigantic, brilliant objects during the "adolescence" of the universe.
The strange case of six stolen emeralds valued at more than $150,000 took another strange turn yesterday.
ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Two men whose prison sentences were commuted today by Governor Rockefeller in a traditional, Christmas-time exercise of clemency, have been accepted as students at colleges.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Metropolitan Nikodim, a leader of the Russian Orthodox Church, asserted today that the Roman Catholic Ecumenical Council had not lived up to all the expectations aroused by Pope John XXIII when he called it.
No matter who does the picking or what they call it, the conclusion is the same: The best player in the National Football League is Jim Brown.
Former President Harry S. Truman urged the public yesterday to ignore the criticism of President Johnson's Vietnam policy by Senators Robert F. and Edward M. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Retail sales for the week ended Dec. 18 amounted to about $7 billion, the Commerce Department said today. The amount surpassed the peak Christmas shopping week of last year by 4 per cent.
The labor negotiations between the Metropolitan Opera and its orchestra are causing concern in the music world.

A shortage of skilled non-officer merchant marine personnel may soon make it impossible for the National Maritime Union to provide ships' crews under existing labor agreements, Joseph Curran, union president, said here yesterday.

A master-plan study aimed at developing the full potential of New Jersey's outdoor recreational facilities for the public is being undertaken, according to Robert A. Roe, commissioner of the state Department of Conservation and Economic Development.

The Federal Reserve continued its policy of "leaning over backwards" last week to minimize the impact of its Dec. 5 rise in the discount rate. It allowed a massive, $823 million increase in "float" -- credit granted on checks in process of collection -- to increase total reserves of its member banks by some $350 million.
The major leagues' winter free-agent draft will be held in New York on Saturday, Jan. 29, William Eckert, the baseball commissioner said yesterday.
AS any New York child knows, Santa Claus comes down the fire escape and through the terrace door.

LAREDO, Tex., Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Dr. Timothy Leary, a lecturer who was dismissed by Harvard University in a controversy over research into hallucinatory drugs, was jailed with his two children and two other persons today on charges of possessing marijuana.
A game of dominoes in a Brooklyn bar grew into a violent argument early yesterday that ended with five men shot.
The father of six children obtained a court order yesterday to compel his ailing wife to take necessary blood transfusions, which she has turned down because of her religious beliefs.

The report now nearing completion by President Johnson's advisory commission on automation promises to be the most thoughtful document yet prepared in this country on the social and economic implications of technological change.

Jean Muir, the actress whose abrupt dismissal from a television program 15 years ago first exposed the existence of widespread blacklisting in broadcasting, was told yesterday that a recollection of her experiences could not be televised without censorship.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 24 -- President and Mrs. Johnson announced the engagement tonight of their 18-year-old daughter, Luci, to Airman Patrick John Nugent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Directors of the nine National Institutes of Health have been told to prepare for substantial cuts in spending for medical research and training, both in the President's next budget and in the current fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy proposed today that the United States and South Vietnam extend their cease-fire if the Vietcong "substantially honor" the Christmas Day truce.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 24 -- The reorganized leadership of the Baath party has asked Salahel-Bitar, a former Premier and Baathist moderate, to form a new government in Syria.

TENAFLY, N.J., Dec. 24 -- A contribution of two of a blind cleaning man's $75-a-month pay checks and a reduction of $125 a month in rent are two of the gestures that have been made recently to keep the Art Center of Northern New Jersey in business.

NEWARK, Dec. 24 -- Eleven persons were killed in two major fires today, eight of them in a tenement early this morning and three more this afternoon when a Christmas tree in a downtown hotel lobby burst into flames. All were asphyxiated.

The concept that all Americans should receive an income from the government sufficient to live on in dignity whether they hold jobs or not is the subject of a symposium, edited by Robert Theobald, called "The Guaranteed Income."

The anti-Vietnam war protesters are screaming at the Administration: "Stop the bombing!" These people forget we are not the only party that is bombing. The Vietcong terrorists are doing the same. Recently they bombed our billet in downtown Saigon and caused 180 casualties.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Gov. William W. Scranton, charging a "flagrant invasion of Pennsylvania sovereignty," appealed to Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama today for the release of an 18-year-old Negro returned to the South by two bail bondsmen to face an assault charge.

Astronauts of the next Gemini flight may have one less worry. Modifications are being made in the craft's electricity generating fuel-cell system, it was learned this week, that will include a simplified method of removing water and sensing instruments that should pinpoint the source of any malfunctions.

In a letter printed on this page today, Alfred B. Fitt, general counsel of the Army Department, takes issue with an editorial which asserted that the flood-control projects constructed in central Florida by the Army Corps of Engineers are largely responsible for the deteriorating condition of the Everglades National Park.

The withdrawal of the 12,574-ton West German liner Seven Seas from trans-Atlantic service and her replacement by the 15,015-ton passenger ship Ryndam next fall has been announced by the Holland-America Line.

CHRISTMAS is the one day of the year on which even the most devoted enthusiast abandons bridge, if only because he cannot find three other players. Bridge-players therefore give their presents well ahead of the big day.

COTONOU, Dahomey, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- The military regime promised today that it would adopt a new deal at home and a nonaligned stance abroad.

VANCOUVER, Dec. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Laurentide Financial Corporation, Ltd., one of Canada's largest finance companies, announced today a series of major changes to improve the company's ability to borrow money in the United States.

WARSAW, Dec. 24 -- The ideological journal of the Polish Communist party is carrying on a debate over the ideas expressed in a new book, "Marxism and the Individual," by Adam Schaff, a Polish Marxist philosopher.

The great Foxhall Keene, a fine horseman, was the first man to win a 10-goal rating from the United States Polo Association. Keene gained that distinction in 1891. In 1966 there will not be a 10-goal man in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation intends to dramatize on television next year the assassination of Rasputin, the "mad monk" who wielded great influence in the dying days of imperial Russia.

DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Association acquired Charlie Vaughn, a guard, and John Tresvant, a forward, from the St. Louis Hawks today in exchange for Rod Thorn, a guard.

More than 180 million Christmas greetings -- letters, cards and gift parcels -- were exchanged through the international postal channels of the Port of New York this year. The total is the highest seasonal figure within memory of postal officials here.
A 13-year-old boy was stabbed to death in front of his home at 219 East 97th Street last night my two youths to whom he had given a nickel when they asked for all of his money.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 24 -- When Sir Robert Menzies, the Australian Prime Minister, fires the starting gun at 11 A.M. on Boxing Day, a record fleet of 53 yachts will start in the 640-mile race from Sydney to Hobart, Tasmania.
The Paramount Pictures Corporation, which has its hands full with efforts to remove two dissident directors from its board, is now confronted with a battle with a minority stockholder group.
The Canadian National Railways System and the Seaboard Air Line Railroad both announced new equipment orders yesterday.
DENTON, Tex., Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Three trainmen were killed today and a fourth was near death from burns suffered in a freakish flaming collision of two freight trains before dawn.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Glassell B., the favorite, closed fast from last place today and won the featured seventh race at Tropical Park. It was his third successive victory at the meeting and his seventh of the year.

NOT the least casualty of the Second World War was the sense of youth -- free and feisty and not yet "responsible" -- among its veterans. The bewildering omission of youth is in fact an unstated theme of much of the writing by Americans of Louis Simpson's age who reached their majority in one of the services.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Judith Anne Corley, 24, of St. Louis, a Peace Corps volunteer, drowned today while swimming near Lagos, Nigeria, the corps headquarters here reported.
MIAMI, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Five All-America players and college football's best passing combination head the teams in the 20th annual Shrine All-Star, game tomorrow.
The next head of the City Youth Board called yesterday for job training as a more "pragmatic" approach to the prevention of juvenile delinquency.
Two men were arraigned yesterday before Criminal Court Judge Hyman Solniker on charges of burglary and possession of burglars' tools as a result of Thursday's $40,000 gem robbery in West 57th Street.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26 -- The Soviet Government has sharply reduced prices of passenger automobiles sold to collective farms. One model is selling for slightly more than a third of what it did before.

YONKERS, Dec. 27 -- There is "no proof whatsoever" to support charges of cowardice and ineptness against firemen in the Jewish Community Center fire here a week ago, Public Safety Commissioner Daniel F. McMahon said today after a full investigation.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board was investigating today the cause of an explosion in an engine of a Japan Air Lines DC-8 jet that burst into flames Saturday, a few minutes after the plane had departed from the San Francisco International Airport with 41 persons aboard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach issued regulations today requiring proof of discrimination and proof of efforts by Federal officials to obtain voluntary compliance before funds can be withheld under the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 27 -- A newer "new mathematics," one putting greater emphasis on scientific experiments and computers, is coming into being, it was disclosed here today.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 27 -- It was proposed here today, on the basis of a study at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, that grid systems of tunnels built under all major American cities could save millions of lives in a nuclear war, and serve civil needs in peacetime.

The desire to "have the stars revolve around us" as Miss Quin puts it, exists even in those not meant for fame. Alistair Berg, perverted, mentally inept, travels to an English seaside town to murder his father. He becomes Greb -- Berg reversed -- and moves into a rooming house next door to his father (who has not seen him since Alistair was a child) and his father's mistress.

The Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center has received a $2-million grant from the Commonwealth Fund for its Institute of Ophthalmology. The money will be used to expand the institute's out-patient clinic and provide additional research space.
A drive by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association to organize deck and engineer officers aboard the city-owned Staten Island ferries ran into a roadblock yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The solar wind is blowing at the "relatively slow speeds" of 670,000 miles an hour, the space agency said today.
RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A major cigarette brand went on sale today in Raleigh carrying this warning label:
GREENSBORO, N.C., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A second-half surge, led by Tom Gauntlett, carried North Carolina to a 75-61 basketball victory over Princeton tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices showed no change during the week ended Dec. 21, at 103.9 of its 1957-59 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Six young women were honored last evening in the great hall of the Metropolitan Club Fifth Avenue and 60th Street, at the club's Debutante Bail. They descended the twin staircases, which were decorated in pine branches hung with gold and silver ornaments and white pompons and were introduced to the ball committee by Spruille Braden, former Ambassador to Argentina.

A Broadway revival of "Native Son," in a revised version, will be put on in the fall by Sidney Bernstein. The alterations are being made by Paul Green, 71-year-old playwright who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1926 for "In Abraham's Bosom."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The National Planning Association projected today a gross national product of $716-billion for next year, up $44-billion from the probable total for this fear.

In the midst of discussions as to the responsibility of the Federal Government in sponsoring the arts, it is clear that, inadvertently, in terms of money, the Federal Government has for some time been the most lavish patron of the arts since the Renaissance.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Scientists must start thinking now about the possibilities of mind control that their research may soon make possible, the chairman of a symposium on the brain said today.
COMMACK, L.I., Dec. 27 -- Six young men and women were arraigned in District Court here today on charges of assault and vandalism in bars in eastern Suffolk County last night.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 27 -- It is understood here -- although American officials deny it -- that Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has privately made it clear to Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge that if negotiations with North Vietnam took place in present circumstances, his Government would not participate in them.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 27 -- Brazil has resolved every important controversy involving United States private investors that served in the recent past to discourage new foreign capital ventures here.

The appointments of Charles Leedham as deputy commissioner of the City Department of Marine and Aviation and of Murray Koenig as its director of administrative services were announced last night by Commissioner Leo Brown.
About 250 high school students picketed on Broadway outside City Hall yesterday to protest what they said was a proposed abolition of specialized high schools in the city.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 27, -- The case for Bart Starr, the Green Bay Packers' regular and invaluable quarterback, dimmed today. Although X-rays indicate no fracture of Starr's rib cage, this well-mannered Southern gentleman has a very sore back anti it is unlikely that he will be able to face the Cleveland Browns in the National Football League's championship game here on Sunday.

The Hooker Chemical Corporation achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 61-year history in the fiscal period ended Nov. 30, according to the annual report issued yesterday by F. Leonard Bryant, chairman.

Lear Siegler, Inc., Santa Monica, Calif., has agreed to acquire all assets of the Cimron Corporation, San Diego manufacturer of digital instruments and systems for commercial and aerospace applications, it was announced yesterday by John G. Brooks, chairman and president of Lear Siegler.

THE publish-or-perish syndrome is going great guns these days. It may soon achieve an odd victory. That triumph would emerge if someone proved that more is being written about the p.-or-p.s. than anything else on the campus. And I wouldn't put it beyond Richard Armour or Russell Kirk to do just that.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A police investigation of brutality charges brought last October by an African student has exonerated the officers involved, Police Chief Hubert O. Kemp said today.

A fast Illinois basketball team won a 40-minute speed test with Georgetown, beating the Hoyas at the wire, 96-94, to give the 14th annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival a quick start at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The Aerojet-General Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Tire and Rubber Company, announced yesterday it had been awarded a $64,965.121 contract by the Navy to build Mark 46 anti-submarine torpedos. Work will be done at Aerojet's Von Karman center in Azusa, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today it had decided not to build a new type of breeder nuclear power reactor that had been considered as a source of electricity for the pumps of California's vast water project.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 27 -- United States and Canadian assistance to the Zambian oil airlift is expected to begin this week with flights of Lockheed C-130's and Boeing 707's from Congolese airports.

NINE teams contested the Far East Championships in Hong Kong recently, and the winner was Thailand, which thus earned the right to play in the 1966 World Championship matches in St. Vincent, Italy, along with North America. Venezuela, Holland and the defending Italian champions.
ALIQUIPPA, Pa., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that all $331,000 in stolen bonds, representing the life savings of a physician, apparently had been recovered.
DETROIT, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The United States auto industry will write a long-awaited page in its record book tomorrow when the 11-millionth car or truck of calendar 1965 rolls off an assembly line.

Despite a magnificent rally by New York University, Providence College scored a 79-76 76 basketball victory before a capacity crowd of 18,499 at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The United States is using the current pause in air raids against North Vietnam to watch for any signs that Hanoi is willing to negotiate a peace settlement, it was authoritatively learned today. There have been no raids for four days.

SAMARKAND, U.S.S.R. -- From From the capital of Tamerlane's Mongol empire to a center of manufacture of widescreen cinema equipment -- that is how the ancient Central Asian city of Samarkand has spanned the centuries.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Emlen Roosevelt of New York and Bernardsville, N.J., were hosts to a supper dance at the St. Regis Roof last night in honor of their debutante daughter, Miss Nancy Arlene Roosevelt. Mrs. Eduardo Andrade gave a dinner for Miss Roosevelt in the Colony Club before the supper dance.

Lieut. Billy Mills of the Marine Corps and Harold Connolly of Culver City, Calif., were the only double-event athletes named to the 1965 all-America track and field team, released today by Col. Don Hull, the executive director of the Amateur Athletic Union.
Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., resigned about $3.5-million in billings yesterday. The agency appeared to be taking the whole thing extremely well -- almost suspiciously well.

Mr. Lindsay takes over a city in which housing shortages for families at lower income levels are more acute than ever, urban renewal has failed to touch the hardcore slums, and planning remains a polite charade. More than one-third of the population of a metropolis frequently billed as the greatest in the world lives in an unsound environment.

A Hollywood feature film to be televised next week by the Columbia Broadcasting System will be about 10 minutes longer than the version released to theaters in 1962. The extra footage, inserted at the request of C.B.S., was obtained from film left on the cutting-room floor when the picture was produced.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay met with both sides in the transit contract dispute yesterday and told them that there must be no strike and that he expected them to negotiate a "fair, reasonable and equitable settlement."

BONN, Dec. 27 -- Thanks to his recent trip to Washington, Chancellor Ludwig Erhard is enjoying a Christmas holiday somewhat merrier than anticipated. With opinion starting to settle following Dr. Erhard's return from talks with President Johnson last week, it is becoming evident that the Chancellor s political prestige has been substantially enhanced.
St. John's University declined yesterday an offer of mediation by the city in the school's dispute with the United Federation of College Teachers.
TOKYO, Dec. 27 -- Four officers of a Cuban freighter now in Osaka for repairs walked into the office of the United States Consul General there today and sought political asylum in the United States.

Yesterday was Boxing Day in Britain and in Canada, and banks in those countries were closed. This led to a dull and quiet foreign exchange market with trading, as one bank officer put it, "that you could put under your thumbnail."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A Senate fiscal expert who has handled Federal Government appropriations totaling more than $2,000-billion, will retire Thursday after 53 years' of service at the Capitol.

The odd-lot figures -- transactions involving less than 100 shares and generally regarded as an index to what the "little man" is doing -- show that small investors have been on the selling side of the market for most of this year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Office of Economic Opportunity announced today it was ready to finance Medicare alert projects in cities and towns that have community action programs in operation.

THE fact that much of the excitement in fashion has been generated in the adventurous little shops, commonly called boutiques, of London, Paris and New York has not been lost on Seventh Avenue's giant manufacturers.

BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- Maj. Gen. Helmut Poppe, the East German military commandant of East Berlin, warned today that he might take additional security steps at the border with West Berlin in the wake of a shooting yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- St. Joseph's snapped a two-game losing streak tonight by routing Niagara, 95-72, and joined Minnesota, La Salle and Temple in the semi-final round of the Quaker City basketball tournament at the Palestra.

The admission of a substantial flow of Cuban refugees into this country has been discussed until recently in terms of how the United States economy could best adjust to this "burden." While such an attitude could have been justified at a time when the unemployment rate was still fairly high, it now appears that a stepped-up inflow of Cubans could become a potent anti-inflationary force during 1966.
A one-year suspension of a driver's license for drag-racing on unauthorized places received bipartisan support yesterday as the 1966 legislative sessions at Albany approached.
PARIS, Dec. 27 -- "It looks like a junior prom in here," said a New Yorker named Nathan Weiss during his first visit to Castel's, one of the most popular discotheques in Paris.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Joseph M. Valachi, the convicted murderer who told Senate investigators a lurid story of Cosa Nostra activities, has been given Government permission to publish his memoirs.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- A nonpartisan reapportionment plan drafted by an advisory council appointed by the Democratic leaders was greeted with bipartisan caution today.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Royals, led by Oscar Robertson's 36 points, continued their home-court mastery over New York, beating the Knicks, 138-116, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
Treasury bills, notes and bonds all rose in price yesterday, and some recently marketed corporate bond issues also registered gains.

The promotion of Robert T. Shinkle to senior vice president and chief administrative officer for the trust department of the Bank of America was announced yesterday by Rudolph A. Peterson, president.

JAKARTA, Dec. 27 -- Negotiations between the Indonesian Government and private oil companies are threatening to create new problems in Indonesian-American relations just when officials on both sides were hoping for a rapprochement.

A 16-year old former patient at a mental hospital and his 12-year-old brother, on Christmas leave from an upstate training school, were charged yesterday with the Christmas eve slaying of a 13-year-old boy from whom the brothers allegedly took a nickel.
Housewives soon will be able to purchase frozen orange juice in many stores at a lower price than they have been paying.

The beginner's ski slope at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx was officially opened for the season yesterday under 5 to 7 inches of man-made snow. Concession authorities expect to open the intermediate slope today.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Lynda Bird Johnson kept her date waiting for two and a half hours but finally arrived today aboard a chartered plane to start a holiday visit in Wyoming and Utah.

SALT LAKE CITY -- If George Romney runs for the Presidency of the United States his candidacy will produce button-popping pride among his coreligionists in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saint -- the Mormons.
Seven more buildings in downtown Manhattan have been designated as official landmarks by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

IN the kitchen of his eight-room colonial house on Astor Avenue in the Pelham Gardens section of the Bronx, Joseph Francis Periconi set down his empty coffee cup. He reached for his overcoat while his wife prepared Laura, their adopted 6-year-old daughter, for kindergarten at Holy Rosary School.

THE outside world seems to accord to the United States supremacy in two arts: painting and dance. Sometimes one wonders why these two arts so rarely get together. The latest bout of wondering is prompted by looking at the magnificent Serge Lifar collection of ballet designs on view at the Harkness House for Ballet Arts, 4 East 75th Street.
For the first time in 179 years the Legislature will have a chance, this winter, to accept or reject comprehensive reform in the state's 18th-century divorce laws.

Overriding Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay's wishes, the Site Selection Board voted 3 to 2 yesterday in favor of the proposed Civic Center flanking City Hall as the site for Manhattan's new Social and Family Court.

After a weak opening, wheat futures staged an interesting rally yesterday. Two contracts -- July and September -- set new life-of-contract highs as a result, taking their impetus from recently increasing exports.

THERE may be a lake around the state that is already frozen solid enough for ice fishing, but don't wager on it. In a short time the ice will be thick enough to fish on safely.

ROME, Dec. 27 -- Merchants in central Rome voted tonight to "brown out" their stores and eventually close them if the city persisted in an experimental curb on movement of private vehicles in a 35-block shopping and residential area.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- A 10-legged drilling rig standing on the bed of the North Sea 40 miles off the Yorkshire coast sank today with 32 men aboard. Late tonight only 19 men were known to have survived.

Several Jewish lay and rabbinic leaders yesterday sharply criticized as "intemperate" and "divisive" a paid advertisement condemning the methods in the slaughter of animals for kosher and nonkosher food.
The admission to the firm of a general partner and the election of a director and vice president, were announced yesterday by two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange.

Christmas weekend was the worst in the country's history so far as road deaths are concerned. The Associated Press reported 719 traffic deaths for the 78 hours that began 6 P.M. last Thursday and ended midnight Sunday.

VISITORS to Hawaii who limit themselves to the pleasures of Honolulu do both themselves and the other islands a vast disservice. For a very few dollars and a short hop by air, visitors can be transported to lands whose sweep and grandeur can rank or rival Rio, the Riviera or even the isles of Greece. And the accommodations, including the food, can be excellent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Vice President Humphrey left here today on a week-long trip to the Far East, his first major diplomatic mission for President Johnson.
Brooklyn music lovers stayed away in droves last night from the Brooklyn Academy where the Metropolitan Opera National Company opened a week of repertory with Puccini's "Madama Butterfly."

A key question about the effectiveness of sanctions against rebel Rhodesia has always been whether South Africa and Portugal would seek to sabotage them. Both Governments so far have behaved cautiously; they have continued normal relations with Rhodesia, but certainly have not gone all out to nullify the sanctions and shore up the white regime which neither has formally recognized.

TOKYO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- North Vietnam charged today that United States planes and warships "intruded" into its territorial air and water space Christmas Day during the 30-hour turce.

SYDNEY Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Australia retained the Davis Cup today when the second-line combination of John Newcombe and Tony Roche whipped Manuel Santana and Luis Arilla in the doubles match, 6-3, 4-6, 7-5, 6-2.

The stock market sold off rather sharply in the late trading yesterday after showing no decisive trend earlier. Losses outnumbered gains in a ratio of two-to-one and the leading averages were down.

The movement toward political integration of the Common Market remains stalled. Despite his ending of the boycott, President de Gaulle is still opposed to yielding political sovereignty to the supranational commission, which has been deliberately excluded from the reconciliation discussions that will take place next month. On this issue, the deadlock continues, so that the commission's powers will probably be neither diminished nor enlarged.
James Farmer said yesterday that his departure from the leadership of the Congress of Racial Equality reflected the broadening and increased sophistication of the civil rights movement.

Can poverty be erased? Should it be? At what speed? These questions are discussed in "The Economics of Poverty: An American Paradox," which Prentice-Hall will issue Jan. 17 as a Spectrum Book. Edited by Burton A. Weisbrod, the volume contains a wide variety of views on the best way to combat poverty.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- No respectable ballet capital, it seems, can be without Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker" at Christmas. In London, Paris or New York the fairy tale proves irresistible holiday entertainment for children.

Lucia, who has headed the 15,000-man department since his appointment by Mayor Wagner in 1961.

Outside of Tokyo, where the market surged ahead to another new high in active trading, Continental exchanges yesterday were almost as quiet as the London, Sydney and Johannesburg markets. They were closed altogether in observance of Boxing Day.

" Darling" became the darling of the New York Film Critics yesterday by winning three of the awards voted by the organization in its 31st annual balloting. The British-made study of a young uninhibited model was named the year's best movie.

The City University asked yesterday for a 28.4 per cent increase in operating expenses for 1966-67 -- and the city's Budget Director, James D. Carroll, turned a budget hearing on the request into a cordial welcome to the boom in municipal higher education.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 27 -- Television broadcasts are expected to begin in South Vietnam on Jan. 21, the country's principal holiday, under the direction of United States military technicians.

CHATTANOOGA, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- An employe of the Tennessee Valley Authority said today that a Secret Service agent recently interrogated him because of a report that he had made "strong statements" concerning President Johnson.

The Savings Banks Association of New York State "strongly urged" the Federal Reserve Board yesterday to issue "guidelines" to the system's members "regarding the importance of restricting the issuance of certificates of deposit by member banks to minimum amounts of at least $25,000."

Despite bitter opposition by neighborhood groups, contracts for creation of the Levy Memorial Playground and Community Center in Riverside Park on the Upper West Side will be signed tomorrow by Mayor Wagner.

Ralph Lazarus, president of the Federated Department Stores, Inc., announced the appointment yesterday of Miss Rose Wells as a vice president of the department-store chain. She is the first woman to hold the title at Federated.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development urged today new tax cuts or increased Federal spending to keep the United States business boom from slackening late next year.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 27 -- President Johnson announced today his intention to appoint Prof. James S. Duesenberry of Harvard University as a member of his Council of Economic Advisers.
Uncertainty over the war in Vietnam depressed most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume tumbled to its lowest level in almost two months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The United States prohibited the export of gasoline, kerosene and other petroleum products to Rhodesia today.
The Rockwell-Standard Corporation has announced the appointment of Paul E. Allen as vice president of the Aero Commander-Albany division, a subsidiary.
Thirteen young women made their formal bows to society at the 47th annual Yuletide Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn last night.
BIRMINGHAM, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Some 250 Negro demonstrators protesting "outmoded" voter registration procedures in Jefferson County staged a five-block march to the county courthouse today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Dave Bing of Syracuse outshot 6-foot-9-inch Clyde Lee of Vanderbilt tonight, but the No. 2-ranked unbeaten Commodores outclassed the Orangemen in winning their first-round game in the Los Angeles Basketball Classic 113-98. It was Syracuse's first loss in eight games. Vandy has won nine.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 28 -- India will cut almost $300-million from anticipated spending in the first year of her new five-year plan because of dislocations caused by the recent war with Pakistan.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 29 -- Vice President Humphrey asked Premier Eisaku Sato today for the help of Japan "or any other government", in bringing about peace in Vietnam.

PARIS, Dec. 28 (Comtelburo) -- Prospects for the Japanese economy are for continued slack and perhaps continued recession, short of vigorous and speedy Government action, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Paul Warfield, Frank Ryan's favorite target in Cleveland's drive for the National Football League championship last year, is healthy again and looking forward to Sunday's title contest at Green Bay.

Karl A. Wasstrom pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to stealing the $40,000 rare stamp collection of Wolfgang Heinrich, a restaurateur. Most of the internationally famous collection has been recovered.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain scored 31 points and grabbed 40 rebounds in a spectacular offensive-defensive show tonight that carried Philadelphia to a 102-93 triumph over Boston.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall will hold a press conference in Boston tomorrow morning to announce whether he will seek another term in 1966, his office said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Exports from the United States to affiliates of American companies abroad rose again in 1964, the Commerce Department reported today.

MADRID, Dec. 28 -- A national referendum to approve a constitution for Spain -- and thus to provide the final legal instrument for the succession to Generalissimo Francisco France -- is to be held next year, high official quarters said today.

The New York City Central Labor Council sent appeals yesterday to Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Wagner and Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay, asking their intervention in the labor dispute at St. John's University.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Fifteen divers worked in 85 feet of water 42 miles off the Yorkshire coast today to try to save the British Petroleum Company's drilling rig, Sea Gem, which collapsed yesterday.

The proposed divorce law revision submitted by a Joint Legislative Committee under the chairmanship of Senator Jerome L. Wilson offers the first real prospect in many years of reform to end a scandalous and cruel New York situation, debasing courts, the bar and the public.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 28 -- The Columbia basketball team survived a late scoring spurt by Pittsburgh tonight and defeated the Panthers, 65-59, in the first game of the third annual Kodak Classic tournament.
Christmas shoppers went into reverse yesterday as department stores and boutiques dealt with the problem of exchanging oversize pajamas, cerise neckties, fur-lined tropical headwear and other gifts.
Local and national religious leaders have called upon Jews not to celebrate New Year's Eve this year but to devote themselves to observing the Sabbath.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Mike Nixon, who had vowed he never would resign, was dismissed today as head coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers after only one season during which his team compiled a 2-12 won-lost record, the worst in the National Football League club's history.

Howard Coonley, tile top-seeded entrant from the University of Pennsylvania, won both of his matches in straight games to gain the semi-final round in the annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament yesterday at the University Club.
Despite a few sharp gains, the American Stock Exchange retreated along a broad front yesterday for the second consecutive day.
Color television has made 1965 the brightest year in the history of the Radio Corporation of America, according to a year-end statement issued yesterday by the company's chairman, David Sarnoff.
The stock market gave ground yesterday in erratic but brisk trading. Losses outnumbered advances by roughly seven five, and most leading to industrial averages showed modest losses.

The World's Fair Corporation said yesterday that City Controller Abraham D. Beame had approved trips abroad by fair representatives and then criticized them in an audit made public Dec. 21. Mr. Beame was called a self-styled "fiscal white knight" who tries to avoid the blame for his actions.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- Ilya Ehrenburg, the Soviet writer, was criticized today for having said in his memoirs that the daring experimentation of the nineteen-twenties was the "golden age" of Soviet literature as compared with the Stalinist thirties, when "poets penned verse for the occasion."

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Geologic discoveries of the last 10 years have demonstrated "beyond a doubt" that until comparatively recently the Antarctic continent was not isolated from the rest of the world, it was reported here today.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Native Diver scored his 24th stakes victory today when he captured the $22,800 Palos Verdes Handicap by a neck on the opening program of the Santa Anita winter meeting.

The Saratoga Performing Arts Center, being built on state land at the Saratoga Spa in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has received new gifts amounting to $60,000. The center has now raised $3.2-million toward total cost of $3.61-million.

" The Gates of Hell" an oratorio by Issachar Miron with text by Avraham Soltes, will be given its first performance at the "Songs of Faith" Brotherhood Festival at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I., at 8 P.M. on Feb. 6.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 28 -- The Vietcong tonight proposed to South Vietnam a four-day cease-fire during the Vietnamese lunar new year celebrations from Jan. 20 to 23.

FOR the third consecutive year, a special postseason deer hunt will be conducted in the Lordville, N.Y., deer wintering yard in southern Delaware County. The hunt is permitted to cull from the herd deer that would most certainly perish of starvation during the winter.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Princeton gained a 69-67 victory over Mississippi State tonight in the first round of the Charlotte invitation basketball tournament. Navy defeated Davidson, 65-60, in the second game.

The Comedie Francaise will visit the City Center from Feb. 8 through Feb 27. Sol Hurok will present the troupe by arrangement with the French Government, which is paying transportation expenses. The group was previously brought here by Mr. Hurok in 1955 and 1961.

IT is a rare, rare "Nutcracker" that improves with further acquaintance. And yet seeing New York City's Ballet's production at the State Theater, Lincoln Center, yesterday afternoon, there seemed even more to admire than on the first night.

THE name on the ballet appeared in black type just as did the names of the other candidates. But this one should have been written in gold or outlined in neon lights. As soon as it was spotted there was no need for further study. The obvious choice -- nay, the perfect choice -- for the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy had to be Bill Bradley of Princeton.
The British pound advanced yesterday on foreign exchange markets here in moderate trading.
Changes among supervisory personnel were announced yesterday by several banks here, and in New Jersey.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 28 (UPI) -- A disclosure that college boys are being used as bait to trap homosexuals brought protests today from officials of Florida State University and Gov. Haydon Burns.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The establishment of a 10-member advisory committee on United States Public Health Service quarantine activities was announced today by the Surgeon General, William H. Stewart.
TCHAIKOVSKY'S "Queen of Spades" was given its eighth performance in its new production last night at the Metropolitan Opera with three new voices in its fine cast.

THIS first novel by a 20-year-old English author illustrates one of the problems, increasingly prevalent, in modern fiction. This is -- If you start at the bottom, how far down can you go? Or, Once you've shown that life is hypocritical, scabrous, hideously arbitrary, pointless and cruel, how can you keep the reader's attention?
The appointment of two executives to high posts was announced yesterday by two of the nation's leading distillers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission challenged today the proposed merger of the Dean Foods Company and the Bowman Dairy Company, which it called the nation's 11th and 12th largest milk processors.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- A 35-year-old college undergraduate, using forged credentials, posed as a physician and taught anatomy at the University of California Medical Center here for 15 months, officials disclosed today.
The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation said yesterday it was rounding out the greatest year in its history.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- The state Superintendent of Insurance recommended today that more trustees with investment experience be added to the board of the $1.3-billion State Teachers Retirement System.
The nation's scheduled airlines set records in all categories of traffic this year, the Air Transport Association said yesterday in a year-end review.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- With a smile as mysterious as the circumstances of his decision, Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, announced today that he would exercise his four-month-old option on a Federal judgeship next Feb. 3.

Sherman J. Maisel, the newest member of the Federal Reserve Board, lined up yesterday against criticism that the Reserve should not have raised the maximum allowable interest rate on commercial bank time deposits to 5 1/2 per cent.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 29 -- The United States Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Harold K. Johnson, said today he believed that a military victory was possible in South Vietnam provided the South Vietnamese were given the "requisite help."
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The "new English," which can bring Robert Frost's poetry to first-graders, is on the way.

It was a bittersweet day at City Hall yesterday as Mayor Wagner, in one of his last official acts, swore in Jacob Lutsky, who for 20 years has been legal aide to the city's Democratic Mayors, as a judge of the Family Court.

Nat H. Hentel, District Attorney-designate of Queens County, held an informal news conference yesterday at which he outlined some of his plans for the office, named a chief assistant and promised to have more to say soon.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay plans to let his 38 commissioners "be free to talk to the press," according to a spokesman, but with the understanding that they will let him know in advance what they are going to say "on major matters."

In his official farewell address yesterday, Mayor Wagner listed more than two dozen achievements of his 12 years at City Hall, but cautioned that much remained to do to make New York "the great city in the great society."
FERRIS MEGARITY, the merchandise promotion director of Altman's, went to Mexico last winter to assemble Mexican fashions for the store here and the fruits of his labor went on display yesterday.

A citizens' committee composed mainly of men who have had uncomfortable brushes with the state's archaic divorce laws, yesterday criticized a state legislative committee yesterday for a "less than liberal and comprehensive" reform plan.

The Union Pacific Railroad, which is seeking authority to merge with the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad over the vigorous opposition of several other carriers, decided yesterday to add two more business and financial leaders to its own board.
Robert Moses announced yesterday that the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority would start as soon as possible to construct a third tube of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.
BERLIN, Dec. 28 -- United States officials said today that an East German couple successfully fled to West Berlin Dec. 19 in an automobile that bore stolen United States Army license plates.

FOR a professional football team about to lose four players, the New York Jets seem almost unconcerned. They think the intraleague draft to stock the new Miami Dolphins won't wound them as much as it will other clubs, though it may cost them such regulars as Bake Turner, Wahoo McDaniel, Willie West and Clyde Washington.

In reply to Richard Stiller's criticism (Nov. 24) of my letter published Nov. 17, I Should like to point out that it is a well-known psycho-sociological theory (Durkheim, Hendin, Meerloo, just to name three distinguished proponents) that recognizes the correlation between suicide rate and national characteristics such as those found in welfare states.
Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., said yesterday that Murray D. Safanie will retire as chairman and chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1.

GENEVA, Dec. 28 -- Switzerland will take the lead on Friday in tariff-dismantling within the European Free Trade Association, or Outer Seven, by abolishing all duties on imports of prefabricated housing.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Youngsters planning to become economists, political scientists, anthropologists or other types of social scientists would be well advised to study mathematics well beyond calculus if they hope to achieve eminence in these fields.

P.D.Q. Bach's music may be here to stay. It will surely be around, at any rate, so long as Prof. Peter Schickele continues to create it and present it as enthusiastically as he did in Philharmonic Hall last night.
AUSTIN, Dec. 28 -- The appointment of Donald F. Simpson as assistant secretary for administration of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare was approved today by President Johnson.

The association of the Philadelphia Orchestra with the Finnish composer Sibelius and his music has been a long and honorable one. In its second season, 1901-02, the orchestra was already programing his works, and eventually it gave the American premieres of his last three symphonies -- the Fifth, Sixth and Seventh.
THE wine rack, once a rarity in the private home, has become so commonplace that its future as a status symbol appears in doubt.

The expansion is changing its character. Economists attending the annual meetings of the American Economic Association suggest that the longest peacetime expansion in history has turned into a war-propelled boom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The United States has let Hanoi know that the pause in air raids over North Vietnam is intended to provide an opportunity for the North Vietnamese Government to show its interest in peace negotiations, Administration sources revealed today.
Staughton Lynd, the assistant professor at Yale University who is reported to be in Hanoi, North Vietnam, will return to the United States no later than Jan. 8 or 9, his friends said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- A 30-minute film about demonstrations against the war in Vietnam, intended to "alert America to the danger within," is being completed here by three producers.

CAIRO, Dec. 28 -- Mustafa Amin, a dominant figure in the Cairo press until his arrest five months ago, pleaded not guilty in a military court today to charges of having spied for the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay has appointed Richard D. Heffner, a communications consultant to survey and evaluate, the work of the Municipal Broadcasting System and its stations -- WNYC, radio, and WNYC-TV, Channel 31.
Oil shares were in the spotlight yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. They sagged in early trading but recovered somewhat before the close.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Queen Elizabeth II, amid the resplendent banners and bejeweled miters of ecclesiastical pageantry, came to Westminster Abbey today on its 900th anniversary and laid a bouquet of red roses at the shrine of its founder, Edward the Confessor.
Robert, Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and tunnel Authority, issued, a formal defense yesterday of the many elaborate brochures; he publishes on highway projects in the New York City area.
Emerson Foote, who quit the advertising business more than a year ago because of his opposition to handling cigarette accounts, is moving back to Madison Avenue.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 -- A historian discounted today as fantasy most of the talk among Black Muslims and other Negroes about use of violence against whites to combat racial discrimination.
BONN, Dec. 28 -- The West German Government said today that it desired the fixing of a new date in January for a French-proposed meeting to heal the split in the European Economic Community.

At least nine of Mayor Wagner's commissioners have been asked to stay on for the start of Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay's administration. The Traffic and Hospitals Commissioners had already been appointed for new terms.

TOKYO, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- Japan Airlines said today that it planned to start an around-the-world air service in the latter half of 1966 now that it has won a route across the United States to complete the circle.
Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Beatrice Foods Company in the three months and nine months ended Nov. 30.
The Board of Education adopted its first billion-dollar budget last night. It includes $500,000 to feed poor children who arrive in school without having had breakfast.

A few years ago the idea of a successful season of 12th Century musical drama would have seemed outlandish. No more, thanks to Noah Grneenberg and the New York Pro Musica, which he directs. The Pro Musica's current season began with two performances of "The Play of Herod" yesterday at St. George's Church in Stuyvesant Square.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Mayor elect John V. Lindsay of New York City received his first invitation today to come here and discuss his proposals for the 1966 Legislature.
The Sands Hotel at San Juan, P.R., has been leased by Swiss Chalet, Inc., in a $10-million transaction. The ocean-front facility will he operated as a part of the adjoining DaVinci Hotel.
TRENTON, Dec. 28 -- A state highway construction program totaling nearly $152 million for fiscal 1965-1966, most of it federally financed, was approved today by Gov. Richard J. Hughes.
In yesterday's stock market, one of the hardest hit groups was the airlines, where losses ranged from 8 1/2 points for Northwest Airlines, to 1 3/4 points for Pan American Airways.

A public-opinion poll taken for Orin Lehman indicated yesterday that he would easily defeat Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman in a race for the seat in the 17th Congressional District to be vacated by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay.

A plant-improvement program involving the expenditure of almost $1 million is under way at Yonkers Raceway, preparatory to the opening of its 1966 season on March 4. Martin Tananbaum, the president of Yonkers, disclosed yesterday a four-point building program that will benefit horsemen stationed at the track.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Paul Henderson's ninth goal of the season enabled two Detroit Red Wing goalies, Roger Crozier and Hank Bassen, to register a 1-0 shutout against the Boston Brains tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Three Americans who have injected themselves into the Vietnam controversy by going to Hanoi may find themselves in stormy legal controversy when they return home.
City and state health officials have placed an embargo on disposable hypodermic needles imported from Japan because of possible contamination.
Mayor Wagner yesterday approved the proposed downtown site for Manhattan's new Social and Family Court and directed that legal steps be taken to condemn the buildings now there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Johnson Administration is considering asking Congress to abandon or drastically reduce an education aid program that would have provided $9-million a year for New York City.

Oversupply and undersupply dominated the thoughts of commodity traders yesterday in two staples -- sugar and cocoa. In sugar, the possibility is a matter of too much; in cocoa, it has apparently become a matter of too little in relation to current demand.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 28 -- The first day of gasoline rationing today suggested a lack of planning by the Government.

One can understand the desire of Americans who oppose their Government's Vietnam policy to "stand up and be counted." But one can be more than skeptical of the notion advanced by Hans Koningsberger in his Dec. 8 letter to The Times (International edition Dec. 10) suggesting that we should perhaps multiply rather than add when doing the counting.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- Uruguay moved toward Presidential rule today after 13 years of Government by a nine-man National Council.
