Pete Michell, a 175-pound substitute guard from New Orleans, went into the game in the closing minutes to lead Georgetown University to an 88-87 victory over New York University at Madison Square Garden yesterday. He scored with all 18-foot jump shot with five seconds remaining.

Courtney C. Brown, dean of the Graduate School of Business of Columbia University, was elected yesterday as a director of the Borden Company. Dr. Brown, who is 61 years old and a native of St. Louis, is also professor of business policy at Columbia.

Balked by what one Commissioner considers "a matter of honor," the city has failed to take advantage of a new law that provides for a 50 per cent state reimbursement for all money it spends on Housing Code enforcement.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The Polish liner Batory arrived [here today with the largest group of Communist bloc immigrants to steam into a United States port since World War II days.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- The way the Republicans see it, the Democrats would win control of both houses of the Legislature under a nonpartisan reapportionment plan proposed Sunday.

ROME, Dec. 28 -- Amintore Fanfani resigned today as Foreign Minister after publication of "unjust and unfounded" comments on Italian and foreign leaders by his close friend, Prof. Giorgio La Pira, the recent bearer of supposed peace feelers from North Vietnam.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Two British sociologists have concluded, contrary to the popular view, that poverty in Britain's "welfare state" is not only widespread but increasing.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 -- A procession of young and old Negro men, some still bruised and complaining of pains in the head, told a Federal judge today of a night of terror at the hands of the white police at Bogalusa on Oct. 20.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 28 -- Brazil's businessmen and the Government are significantly at odds over prices and profits.
ROME, Dec. 28 -- Rome's city government ignored a protest blackout of shop windows and signs throughout central Rome today and continued an experimental curb on private vehicular traffic in the area.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Scientists are learning to look at our planet with new eyes that see in many kinds of light, according to reports presented here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- A high-level Soviet delegation is about to leave for Hanoi on an unspecified mission, the official press agency Tass announced today.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Collections of the recently imposed state sales tax indicate that revenues are almost up to estimates, the State Tax Department said today.

Bill Blair tipped in a rebound with three seconds remaining to give Providence an 81-79 triumph over Illinois last night and send the Friars into tomorrow night's final of the Holiday Festival basketball tournament against Boston College.

ALLEGRA KENT danced the Sugar Plum Fairy at yesterday's matinee of "The Nutcracker" in the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. And there were dozens of small but equally delectable confections in the audience.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 28 -- Was Daedalus, the fabled designer of the fabulous Labyrinth of Crete, more than a myth?
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Three Cornell University scientists cautioned today that food preserved by nuclear radiation might be lethal.
Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the defending United States chess champion, resigned his ninth-round adjourned game last night against Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., a former titleholder.
MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union announced today the successful launching of two more unmanned satellites in the mysterious Cosmos series.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked the Government today to make newspapers take more responsibility for investigating the employment policies of advertisers.
BELGRADE Yugoslavia, Dec. 28 -- Evidence is accumulating that the Communist countries of Eastern Europe are preparing radical long-term changes in their trade relations.
The Transit Authority is prepared to seek an injunction to bar a subway and bus strike threatened for 5 A.M. Saturday.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- An emergency radio network utilizing Muzak -- a service that pipes music to restaurants and supermarkets -- will begin operations in the state Jan. 15, the State Civil Defense Commission announced today.
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Daily Express reported from Washington today that the United States had sent Communist China and North Vietnam a detailed outline of its Vietnam policies.
Louis J. Lefkowitz arrived with the idea of learning how the public might be protected from art frauds and forgeries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Ray C. Bliss, the Republican national chairman, announced plans today for a stepped-up organizational drive in the nation's big cities, where Democrats normally win their crucial majorities.
The Government securities market continued to advance yesterday, but the rest of the bond market was practically at a standstill waiting for the new year.

Serious errors of fact and highly questionable assumptions in the letter of Lawrence Mohr (Dec. 21) prompt me to write concerning the proposed low-rent housing development on West 64th Street. Most inaccurate is the statement that the creation of low-rent housing will discourage other building and will lower property Values in adjoining blocks.

WASHINGTON, Conn., Dec. 28 -- A controversial proposal to establish a school for emotionally disturbed children in this small residential community was unanimously approved today by tile town's five-man zoning board.

PARIS -- One implicit purpose of the current and second halt in United States bombing of North Vietnam could be to test Moscow's diplomatic intentions. For many months both Soviet and Soviet bloc leaders have been suggesting that peace might be arranged in Southeast Asia if only we would interrupt the aerial offensive once again.
NEITHER resignations nor political fights are a novelty for Amintore Fanfani, the Italian Foreign Minister who resigned yesterday because of a double embarrassment.

During the last year there has been much speculation but little confirmation that Communist China has added, or will add, combat troops to the technical personnel and the materiel it has contributed to the North Vietnamese cause.

The New York Rangers were dealt a serious blow yesterday when it was learned that Phil Goyette, their top center, would be lost to the club for a month with internal injuries as a result of being speared by Ted Green of the Boston Bruins in Sunday night's game.

A Queens youth whose bar mitzvah took place the day Hanukkah began wrote to the Neediest Cases fund that the purpose of religion is "to help others, to make people more the way the Lord wanted them to be."

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Britain's upper classes watch the popular television programs favored by ordinary folk -- but they feel guilty about it, according to a survey just completed by the Independent Television Authority.

SALT LAKE CITY -- Tile speaker was an intellectual product of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, although he no longer went to church and said he was "out of step" with his former religious colleagues.

Speakers at the current American Association for the Advancement of Science meeting have sounded urgent warnings that society must prepare now for the biological and psychological reshaping of human beings that promises to emerge from current research. President George W. Beadle of the University of Chicago cautioned against tampering with man's biological evolution, as is already done routinely with plants and animals.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Navy announced today a $1.9-billion ship repair and conversion program for the fiscal year 1966, which ends next June 30.

MAYOR-ELECT John V. Lindsay may decide to skip his inauguration if he happened to watch Channel 13 last night. The educational station presented an imaginative, if agonizingly uneven, study of the office of Mayor; it succeeded in leaving little doubt as to why the post is often characterized as a graveyard for higher ambitions.

E.J. Korvette, Inc., plans to take possession of the former Saks-34th Street site on Herald Square, in March or April, 1966 and erect its proposed department store there by August 1967, a top Korvette executive said yesterday.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 28 -- President Johnson may ask Congress to extend the Jan. 25 deadline for submitting his new budget.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced here yesterday the election of J. Henry Smith as a director, Mr. Smith, who is 55 years old, is vice president and actuary of the society.

TOKYO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Hanoi radio said today that "several hundred thousand Chinese youths, including a large number of army men, have enlisted as volunteers to fight by the side of the Vietnamese people against the United States aggressors."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The value of the nation's mineral output soared to $21.3 billion in 1965, Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said tonight.

" What's Right With Our Young People," a new book by Grace Nies Fletcher, presents the views of young Americans on a variety of subjects. The book, which Morrow will issue Jan. 14, is based on the author's interviews with 400 persons, from seventh-graders to college students, she encountered on two cross-country trips.

IF his and hers coats in white mink start to supplant matching black leather jackets in Greenwich Village, it will mean that the newly opened Mr. A. Furs, 150 Bleecker Street, is selling its most expensive items.

Representative Paul A. Fino, Republican of the Bronx, yesterday called on Sargent Shrivet, director of the Federal antipoverty program, "to state specifically' whether he had supported or authorized a grant of $40,000 to LeRoi Jones' Black Arts Repertory School.
The election of Capt. J.W. Clark, president, Delta Steamship Lines, as chairman of the Committee of American Steamship Lines was one of three maritime industry executive changes announced yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 28 -- Scoring 10 straight points early in the first period, Otterbein College rolled to a 92-66 victory tonight over Hofstra University in a holiday doubleheader at the losers gymnasium.
A former Government official now in teaching and a former teacher now in Government voiced sharply contrasting views yesterday on the campaign to stem the nation's dollar outflow.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- A Pittsburgh steelworker was seized by Alabama bail bondsmen Dec. 16 shortly after they arrested a Norristown, Pa., Negro, it was reported today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Driving rains and winds moving at speeds up to 100 miles an hour slashed into the West Coast today from the Pacific.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 -- The row $33.5-million Los Angeles Music Center marked its first year of operation today by announcing some large gifts and changing the names of its two major theaters.

MARIO Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., the United States Auto Club's national champion, has been asked to join Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico to drive the No. 1 Ferrari entry in the Daytona 24-hour Continental on Feb. 5 and 6. Andretti was born in Italy and drove his first

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 28 -- Alleged drag racing by youths here that led to the death of an adult motorist on Christmas Eve resulted today in the arrest of a 20-year-old girl on a homicide charge, even though she had not been driving any of the cars.
General Telephone and Electronics International, Inc., has acquired the assets of three affiliated Spanish companies, which manufacture, television and radio sets and market-lighting products.

Expulsion of the Warsaw correspondent of The New York Times is only the latest in a series of repressive acts by the Communist regime that mark retreat from the days after 1956, when Poland enjoyed greater freedom than any other Soviet bloc country. It is discouraging that the Communists have indulged for the second time in six years in the self-defeating gesture of expelling a Times correspondent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Administration is now engaged in another private debate on the best strategy for the war in Vietnam. It is trying to find the right degree of military pressure -- strong enough to keep the enemy off balance, but not so strong as to corner him into an all-out struggle and close all channels to a negotiated settlement.

PLAYERS who object to post-mortems and insist on proceeding immediately with the next deal miss much of the fun in bridge. It is true that the post-mortem is better avoided if it is likely to be heated and acrimonious, but some friendly discussion can be both entertaining and instructive.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 28 -- Alarmed at the growing number of personal bankruptcies on Long Island amid general prosperity, a cross-section of the community has joined to provide a financial counseling service.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz made a personal effort tonight to end a strike that is threatening to cause an ammunition shortage in Vietnam.
TOKYO, Dec. 28 -- Vice President Humphrey arrived tonight to begin a week-long goodwill trip to four Asian capitals.

The City College basketball team kept its head and its wooden shoe last night, downing Queens, 63-54, in the championship game of the first City University tournament at Fitz-Gerald Gymnasium, Queens College.

Dick McGuire's New York Knickerbockers will be seeking their first victory of the season over the Boston Celtics today when they meet the world champions in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden.
SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 29 -- Harry Hopman, Australia's Davis Cup team captain, believes his Australian team will be playing the United States in the challenge round next year.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Stephen S. Chandler was stripped today of all his duties and authority on the ground that he "is presently unable or unwilling to discharge it [his job] efficiently."

THE best buy in the bridge business is surely membership in the American Contract Bridge League. For $2 -- scheduled to increase to $3 in 1967 -- a player receives not only the right to register master-points and full information about events in his area but also a substantial monthly magazine.
The nation's electric power production rose 10.6 per cent in the week ended Dec. 25 from the level of the corresponding 1964 week, the Edison Electric-Institute reported yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The supply of crude oil for Rhodesia at the Mozambique port of Belra will run out tomorrow, informed sources said here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States, in an exploratory move toward closer scientific cooperation with the Communist bloc, relaxed travel restrictions today to permit physicians and medical scientists to visit Communist China and four other countries.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange staged a mild rally yesterday, but most price increases were small.
The Furness Bermuda Line, operator of the Queen of Bermuda and Ocean Monarch, will make Pier 88, at West 48th Street, the local terminal for the two cruise ships.
Ralph Blumberg, the Bogalusa, La., broadcaster who was forced to sell his radio station under pressure from the Ku Klux Klan, will join WCBS-TV News here on Monday as a reporter.
The admission of new partners was announced here yesterday by three member firms of the New York Stock Exchange. The admissions become effective Jan. 1.

Liberian Iron Ore, Ltd., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a statement for an offering to its shareholders of rights to subscribe for 659,171 additional shares of capital stock. The offering is planned for late February.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The Coast Guard said today it would press charges of negligence against the Illinois owner of a sea-going houseboat that was smashed and sunk by Atlantic waves today.

A teach-in at Columbia University was told yesterday that the failure of superior American firepower and technology to overcome a poorly armed foe in Vietnam raised serious questions about the efficiency of the United States military.
HASTINGS, England, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- The 41st International Chess Congress opened here tonight, with five grand masters among 221 competitors from 20 countries.
City medical examiners regularly arrive late or not at all at the scenes of suspicious or unusual deaths, according to a report handed to Mayor Wagner yesterday.

MIAMI, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Robert Lehman's Rehabilitate, an outsider in the field of 12 juveniles, returned a payoff of $194.80 for $2 today in winning the $15,000 Miami Beach Handicap over one mile and 70 yards at Tropical Park.

YONKERS, Dec. 29 -- The city government issued a detailed rebuttal today of charges made against Yonkers firemen after the Dec. 20 fire at the Jewish Community Center, in which nine children and three adults were killed.
Council President-elect Frank D. O'Connor, in his first appointments, yesterday named three well-known young lawyers -- one of them a woman -- to top posts in his office.
Harvey Haddix, one of the leading left-handers of modern baseball, joined the New York Mets of the National League yesterday as a pitching coach, thereby completing Manager Wes Westrum's staff.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 29 -- The strange radio emissions from space that have been attributed to a phenomenon named "mysterium" seem more perplexing than ever.
Kastor, Hilton, Chesley, Clifford Atherton, Inc., made it official yesterday. It announced that as of Saturday the agency would be known as Kastor, Foote, Hilton Atherton, Inc.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Vasco T. Leitao da Cunha, former Minister of Foreign Affairs and newly appointed Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, told United States businessmen yesterday that Brazil wants to step up trade with the United States. He spoke at a farewell luncheon in his honor given by the Brazil-United States Chamber of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec, 30 -- Signs of a possible break appeared yesterday in a strike that the Government says is threatening the supply of ammunition to Vietnam.

Gardner Ackley, the chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers. reminded an audience of sophisticated fellow professionals yesterday that coping with an economy expanding toward nearly full employment is no bed of roses.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 -- A Federal District judge accused Bogalusa law enforcement officers today of having perpetrated "a deliberate scheme" to harass and beat people in the a Negro community on the night of Oct. 20.
In the next four weeks the Interstate Commerce Commission is expected to issue its approval of the merger plans of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads.
Frank S. Hogan was sworn yesterday for his seventh four-year term as District Attorney of New York County. The oath was administered by an old friend, Supreme Court Justice John A. Mullen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The disciplining yesterday of an Oklahoma City Federal district judge by his fellow judges may create a new policy for the removal of judges without impeachment, legal observers said today.

Gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday increased 2,638,000 barrels, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 189,048,000 barrels, compared with 186,410,000, a week earlier and 193,989,000 a year ago.
JEWELRY with extravagant price tags has joined television sets and automobiles as items that can be purchased on the installment plan.

Governor Rockefeller and two of the state's top Democrats -- Controller Arthur Levitt and Senator Robert F. Kennedy -- made public separate plans yesterday for getting more Federal funds to New York. Their timing was said to be coincidental.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, financing arm of G.M., announced here yesterday the election of Clyde E. Shepherd as a vice president. Mr. Shepherd, who has served as regional manager in Boston, also was named head of branch operations in the Eastern United States.
Two British spies and a Siamese cat are proving the biggest attractions at local motion picture theaters this Christmas week, traditionally the best week of the year for all show business.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 29 -- President Johnson underwent a "head to toe" physical examination today and was pronounced in "fine condition."

The Columbia Broadcasting System will pay $18.8-million a year for television rights to preseason and regular season games in the National Football League under the terms of a new two-year contract. For the last two years C.B.S. has paid $14.1-million a year.
CASSEROLES do not have to be a conglomeration of leftovers. Planned combinations of specifically purchased foods can be good enough to serve to family and friends.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A special study group recommended sweeping changes today in the United States Employment Service.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 29 -- Kristine Ffister, a 15-year-old sophomore at Valhalla High School, rode her big brown gelding, Highclere, to both the horsemanship and working hunter championships today at the Secor Farms junior horse show.
SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Australia may have to defend the Davis Cup next year without Roy Emerson.

NEW VERNON, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Sons of two prominent families of Harding Township, a wealthy community set in a rolling spacious landscape, were arrested last night when the police searched one of their homes and confiscated a quantity of marijuana.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed today the conviction of Lawrence W. Medlin, a Nashville sandwich shop operator, in a case linked with the jury-tampering charge against James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
The bond market kept drifting yesterday toward the end of the year with only a small amount of activity to disturb the calm.
Henry Root Stern Jr., State Superintendent of Insurance said yesterday mandatory coverage in passenger automobile liability insurance should be more than doubled.

JERUSALEM (Israel Sector), Dec. 29 -- Mrs. Golda Meier, Israel's Foreign Minister, warned today that the impending British and American agreements to supply Jordan and Saudi Arabia with modern planes and missiles would upset the balance of power in the Middle East.

THE Metropolitan Opera prides itself on its internationality. Nothing could have pointed this up more than the backgrounds of the three artists who made their debuts with the company last night in the season's first performance of "Aida."

The Federal Power Commission's order licensing the Consolidated Edison Company to construct a $162-million hydroelectric power plant on the west bank of the Hudson River at Cornwall, N.Y., was set aside yesterday in a unanimous decision by the United States Court of Appeals.
A model of the "store control center of the future" was displayed yesterday by the Pepsi-Cola Company and the Super Market Institute at a news conference at the Regency Hotel here.
" WOMEN are losing the knack, but men are beginning to find it."

John Austin of Boston College and Jim Walker of Providence are the two fancy-Dan guards everyone will have eyes on when the Eagles and Friars meet in the final of the 14th annual Holiday Festival basketball tourney at Madison Square Garden tonight.

MADRID, Dec. 29 -- Two planeloads of leftist Asian, African and Latin-American delegates to next week's anti-imperialist" conference in Havana departed from Madrid last night. Their use of Madrid as a transfer point emphasized Spain's increasing help to Cuba.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Ron Holmberg of New York, a former Tulane University star, easily defeated Ham Richardson of Dallas today in the final of the Sugar Bowl invitation tennis tournament. The scores were 6-1, 6-2, 6-4.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The State Department confirmed today that the United States had been supplying Patton medium tanks to Jordan to help modernize her army.

CAIRO, Dec. 29 -- Western analysts here think the Soviet Union has apparently agreed to write off a sizable part of the United Arab Republic's heavy debt to Moscow for massive shipments of military equipment over the last decade.
Lehigh Valley Industries Inc., once in the coal business, and now a widely diversified industrial company, is acquiring two consumer concerns, in a transaction involving $4.3 million.
It was almost impossible to tell, from the way he walked and talked and worked, exactly when John Vliet Lindsay stopped running for Mayor and became the Mayor-elect.

Pinkerton's, Inc., the "eye that never sleeps," focused on shrinkage in business inventories yesterday and came up with the view that auditors will uncover more than $2- billion worth of losses by the end of this year.
WARSAW, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman met Foreign Minister Adam Rapacki today as part of a United States search for ways to end the war in Vietnam.

A group of 32 prominent clergymen, civil rights leaders and university professors urged yesterday an increase of $41.6-billion a year in national expenditures for job training, housing and health in the nation's large cities.

Associated Community Teams, the Harlem antipoverty agency known as Act, charged yesterday that "someone" in the city government has been holding back funds from the agency in an attempt to "sabotage" its program.

MIAMI, Dec. 29 -- Cuba' Presidential Palace will become museum and Premier Fidel Castro will acquire his own offices for the first time since 1959 under a reshuffle of governmental facilities announced today by the Havana radio.
The head of one of the country's largest lithographers' unions pleaded with Michael J. Quill yesterday not to go through with the threatened city transit strike.
Plans for another large office building in the Lincoln Square area are being developed by the architectural firm of S.J. Kessler Sons for Harry Horwitz, real estate investor.
ROME, Dec. 29 -- Arthur J. Goldberg, here as a special envoy of President Johnson, called on Pope Paul VI tonight for an hour-long discussion of the search for peace in Vietnam.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Nate Branch and Grant Simmons combined for 52 points to spark once-beaten Nebraska to a 92-79 semi-final victory over Oklahoma tonight in the big eight basketball tournament.

WHAT might serve as a collective noun for Sugar-Plum Fairies? A "confectionary" of Sugar-Plum Fairies, a "candor" or even a "suite"? Whatever the collective noun might be, the uncollective fairies themselves are fluttering happily around the State Theater, Lincoln Center, where the New York City Ballet's production of "The Nutcracker" proceeds apace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A Republican leader told Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien today that she believed overzealous Democrats somewhere in the Post Office Department were holding up Republican mail.

GENEVA, Dec. 29 -- An accord between Switzerland's poultry farmers and importers is expected to keep Swiss feathers from flying, although this country is a major battlefield in the so-called chicken war involving the United States.

Thomas J. Murphy, executive vice president of the Newspaper Guild of New York, said last night that his union had received reports of a possible three-newspaper merger here to take place on Sunday or early next week.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Dec. 29 -- Jim Lee, a 177-pounder from Norfolk (Va.) State, was named the outstanding wrestler in the metropolitan intercollegiate invitation tournament as it ended last night at C.W. Post College. Lee, who lives in Mount Vernon, N.Y., defeated six straight opponents and in the final round, Lee defeated Art Rudolph of Hofstra, 7-2.
MILFORD, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Connecticut, which was once one of the most prolific sources of oysters in the country, will be without a native oyster crop in 1968.
ROME, Dec. 29 -- City officials, heeding the protests of worried shopowners and irate motorists, reduced today by about one-half the 35-block experimental pedestrian "island" in the heart of Rome.

The board of trustees of St. John's University disclosed a new program last night that it said would give the faculty a greater voice in educational affairs and offer the protec tion of tenure. These were among the demands made by the United Federation of College Teachers, which has called a strike against the university for next Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (UP) -- An all-Philadelphia final was set for the Quaker City tournament when unbeaten Temple defeated La Salle, 66-59, in overtime for its 10th victory and St. Joseph's routed Minnesota, 91-66, in semi-final games tonight.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 29 -- The Governmental crisis in Syria appeared tonight to be nearing a solution. Salah el-Bitar, the moderate leader who has been asked by the leadership of the Baath party to form a new cabinet, was expected to present his ministerial team and program to the legislative Revolutionary Council for investiture presently.

A large pastry model of the hospital and medical training ship Hope was on display last night with the Christmas decorations at the fourth Hope Ball and Cotillion. Proceeds of the debutante event, held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, will aid Project Hope, which supports the ship.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 28 -- A jailer at the Nassau County Jail has been asked to resign. He was accused of having accepted $15 from an inmate to buy a pipe and tobacco for the inmate in violation of prison rules, and of having failed to live up to the agreement.

The New York Philharmonic will celebrate the 30th anniversary of Rudolf Serkin's public debut in the United States and of his first Philharmonic appearance with a pension fund benefit concert on Jan. 25, 8:30 P.M., at Philharmonic Hall.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 29 -- The astronauts who made the 14-day flight of Gemini 7 felt as though they were standing on their heads for the first two days. But initial analysis of the results of their trip indicates there are no medical obstacles to missions lasting weeks or even months.
WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 29 -- A bright future for harness-racing bettors at Roosevelt Raceway in 1966 was painted today by Alvin Weill, the president of the Westbury track.
The rate war in the savings market continued to escalate yesterday, despite admonitions from Federal Reserve officials that rate increases at this time might be "dangerous."

REDSTONE, Colo., Dec. 29 -- (AP) -- A coal mine explosion deep in the mountain wilderness of western Colorado last night killed nine miners, all working overtime to get some extra time off for New Year's Eve.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 29 -- The Indian Government is concerned about growing evidence that Communist China is helping to arm Pakistan.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- The Soviet Union's Communist youth leader has warned that "harmful and alien" tendencies in art and literature are promoting disaffection among young people.
A mortgage banker recently elected to the board of managers of the West Side Young Men's Christian Association gave $1,000 yesterday to the Neediest Cases in honor of the association.

The Lindsay administration took steps yesterday to soothe ecclesiastical feelings that it had ruffled by not consulting the Protestant Council of the City of New York in selecting the invocation clergymen for Saturday's City Hall inauguration.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 29 -- A disturbed nation is waiting tensely this week to see whether President Hector Garcia-Godoy will lock horns with a militant group in the armed forces that has been a law unto itself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Social Security benefits in 1965 totaled $18.3-billion, Robert M. Ball, Social Security Commissioner, reported tonight. The figure, a record, represented a $2.1-billion rise over 1964.

" THE most wonderful thing that ever happened to me was getting a guide dog," said Cy Lederman of Brooklyn, who has been totally blind for the last six of his 37 years. The greatest problem of a blind person is mobility -- getting from place to place.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 29 -- Government sources said after a meeting of the ruling junta today that the South Vietnamese were planning a cease-fire for the lunar New Year before the Communists broadcast their proposal yesterday for a halt in the fighting during the four-day celebration.

Once again the New York Rangers had to face the brawn and keen defense of the Chicago Black Hawks last night at Madison Square Garden. The fifth-place Blues also had to face Glenn Hall, the best goalie in the National Hockey League.
The stock market reversed yesterday the downtrend that had prevailed in the first two days of the week and advanced moderately in a busy session.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 -- Historians were told today that the Johnson Administration, even if it developed more fruitful policies on Vietnam, could not put them into effect without more enlightened public understanding of Southeast Asia's long history.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 29 -- If you are good at visualizing shapes and using words, you can probably thank heredity. If you are poor at mental "brainstorming," blame your upbringing.
TOKYO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of a message from President Ho Chi Minh to Pope Paul VI, as broadcast today from Hanoi:

DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Output of 155,006 passenger cars in the final week of 1965 will bring United States auto production for the year to a record of 9,335,560 units, Automotive News predicted today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Treasury announced tonight that its new issue of 168-day June tax-anticipation bills had been sold at an average yield of 4.281 per cent.

Burlington Industries, Inc., has announced the appointment of Thomas C. Harlocker as vice president and managing director of Burlington Carpet Mills, Canada, Ltd., a subsidiary. Mr. Harlocker formerly served as vice president of Loomtex Mills, Inc.

BRIDGEWATER, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Some of the leading figures in American arts, letters and sciences have formed a sponsoring committee to help build "a small town cultural center" in memory of Van Wyck Brooks, the author-critic who died here on May 2, 1963.
Computers apparently have become as essential to modern airline operations as stewardesses.
In the face of a threatened transit strike on Saturday morning, New Yorkers have begun in earnest to prepare for any disruptions a walkout might cause.
A general decline in the number of syphilis cases here this year, in contrast with a nationwide rise, was reported yesterday by the city's Department of Health.

A spokesman for the nation's merchant fleet yesterday urged the Federal Government to institute "some sort of crash program" to meet the increasing shortage of engineers and skilled unlicensed personnel.

A plan to add 200 acres of new land around the tip of Manhattan was announced yesterday by William F.R. Ballard, chairman of the City Planning Commission. The commission said garages and parks could be built on it, and express highways relocated under it.

Robert J. Schwartz, one of the four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Congress in Manhattan's 17th District, said yesterday he would not be bound by a Democratic meeting next Wednesday, at which a choice is to be made, unless the suggested procedure in changed.

The pause in the bombing of North Vietnam repeats an experiment that failed last May. It is vital to understand what went wrong then, if the new effort is not again to be condemned to failure in advance.

TELEVISION and the motion picture industry are entering a new relationship. The home screen has used up so many feature-length films and promises to need so many more that the TV networks are starting to underwrite the cost of motion-picture production.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller will propose a six-point traffic safety program to the 1966 Legislature, including driver-safety courses for motorists convicted of moving violations.
Plans for the Interchemical Corporation to acquire the Rinshed-Mason Company for more than $42.5 million in stock were approved yesterday by Interchemical shareowners at a special meeting here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Johnson has undertaken a major diplomatic offensive in the hope of turning the continuing pause in the American bombing of North Vietnam into a movement toward peace negotiations.

MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 30 -- Ferdinand E. Marcos was inaugurated today as the sixth President of the Republic of the Philippines before a cheering, sunbaked crowd of 80,000 people gathered in Luneta Park on the shore of Manila Bay.

HONG KONG, Dec. 29 -- President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam has told Pope Paul VI that "United States leaders want war, not peace." In a message sent to the Pope yesterday, the North Vietnamese leader reiterated Hanoi's conditions for a peaceful settlement, which include a demand that the United States withdraw its forces from South Vietnam.
Trading was light yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, but the market maintained a steady tone.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The conviction of Abraham W. Bolden, 30 years old, the first Negro Secret Service agent ever to guard a President of the United States, was upheld today by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Students assembled by the United Nations Association of Britain at a conference to promote international understanding listened politely today as a South African advanced arguments in favor of racial segregation in his country.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Prime Minister Sir Robert Menzies, 71 years old Dec. 20, is expected to announce his retirement about the third week of January. The Melbourne Herald reported today.

PARIS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Prices and the general cost of living in West Germany should experience a slower increase in the coming year, according to a survey by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

Senator George D. Aiken's remarks, calling Vietnam "an ancient enemy of China's," and saying that "for a thousand years the Vietnamese fought against China to prevent her overrunning Southeast Asia" (as you cite them in your editorial of Dec. 24 "The Irony of Vietnam"), seem to have as little immediate relevance to the present situation as the Norman Conquest has to the relations between de Gaulle and Wilson.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 29 -- A special ministerial meeting of the six European Economic Community members in Luxembourg on Jan. 17 moved a step closer to realization today I with an announcement byi West Germany that it wottld{l be represented. !

NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio announced today that he had offered the facilities and staff of the Newark City Hospital to the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry in Jersey City for use free of charge.

HONG KONG, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A weekly magazine quotes an unidentified senior member of the International Control Commission as having said that the North Vietnamese Government was split on the question of opening cease-fire negotiations with Saigon and Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the historian who was a special assistant to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, will take up residence next week at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J.
Mayor Wagner signed into law yesterday a "Good Samaritan" bill that provides payments by the city for persons injured or killed while trying to prevent crimes.
A proposal for flexible ticket prices, based on supply and demand, drew a wide range of opinion -- pro and con -- from Broadway yesterday.
The Transit Authority has no plans to run the city's subway trains in the event of a strike on Saturday, a spokesman said yesterday. However, the question of running the buses was left open.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 29 -- The Department of Justice has asked a panel of three Federal judges to declare unconstitutional a state law banning women from Alabama juries.
Royal S. Radin, Liberal party leader of Staten Island, was appointed Commissioner of Relocation yesterday by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay.

The Communications Satellite Corporation asked major aerospace concerns yesterday to submit designs for a multipurpose satellite with at least 20 times the capacity of Early Bird, the world's first commerical communications satellite.

The deadline for a disastrous transit strike is now less than 48 hours away. Two months have slipped by without serious negotiations, and Michael J. Quill is back in his favorite posture as the man with stop-or-go power over the subways and buses on which six million daily riders rely.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The secrecy in which the Administration has enveloped its current search for a suspension of the war in Vietnam is essential to the purpose. It is an ideal example of how diplomacy must be conducted in such delicate circumstances if it is to make any progress at all toward its objective.

START looking now: Here come the Edwardians. A looming trend for 1966 in the book world will become a lavishly revived interest in the time-gilded age of portly King Edward VII and lovely Lillie Langtry.
THOSE who enjoy using the outdoors in one way or another are vaguely aware of the phenomenon of water movement in lakes and ponds at certain times of the year.

The Toomey Mortgage Company of Hackensack, N.J., has been appointed leasing and financing agent for the Park Ridge Industrial Park on Hawthorne Avenue in Park Ridge, N.J. The industrial area, consisting of 200,500 square feet of improved land, is being developed by John Collins of Teaneck, N.J.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt today suggested to Legislature some alternatives to the 2 per cent state sales tax.

CAIRO, Dec. 29 -- The Yemeni republican leader accused Saudi Arabia today of having sabotaged agreements between republicans and royalists at the abortive peace conference, which ended in a deadlock last Sunday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 29 -- The next decade will be crucial for archaeology, scholars agreed today, in a modern world that is using up more and more open space for dams, roads and housing and in the process is destroying the ancient world.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- To his academic peers, Dr. Roy Franklin Nichols, who took office today as president of the American Historical Association, typifies what they look for in a graduate dean -- an active teacher, author and administrator.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- A four-foot pulpwood log, jammed in the rails at a switch early this morning derailed the New York Central Railroad's Cleveland Limited passenger train near Corfu, a Genesee County village four miles west of here.
Negotiators in the transit dispute discussed economic issues and working conditions in detail yesterday, but progress was stymied by uncertainty as to how the costs of any settlement would be met.
As an admirer of the New York Public Library's central research division I nevertheless find my sympathy for its current financial plight somewhat limited.

The election of J. Fred Weston as president of the American Finance Association was announced here yesterday at the group's annual meeting in the New York Hilton Hotel. The meeting is part of the joint program of the Allied Social Science Associations.

The Gemini 6 and 7 astronauts will hold a new conference at 11 A.M. today. Live television coverage will be provided by the American Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System. The National Broadcasting Company will present taped highlights at 1 P.M.

Most commodities drifted down in price yesterday in active futures trading. In some cases, brokers talked of evening-up operations as the year draws to an end, which means owners of contracts selling out their positions and those who have sold short buying to settle their accounts.

Rosalyn Tureck's piano recital of music by Bach drew a near-capacity audience to Carnegie Hall, and for good reason. In the past decade Miss Tureck has established herself as one of the world's foremost students and interpreters of Bach's keyboard works, and each time she performs in New York she seems to show increased authority over the literature to which she has devoted herself so single-mindedly.
The bright spot in last night's concert by the New York Philharmonic in its hall was the playing of Mozart's Piano Concerto in A (K. 488) by the diminutive Spanish pianist, Alicia de Larrocha.

ONE of the oddest institutions in cookdom is the feast Hawaiians call luau. And on a recent trip to the island of Oahu, there seemed to be one woman who was the doyenne of luau-makers, Irene Robinson.

GRAND master Nicholas Rossolimo of New York scored a stunning victory over the former titleholder, grand master Larry Evans of Las Vegas, in the first round of the current United States chess championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The libel suit of a Chicago police captain against Time-Life, Inc., for $350,000 damages was sent back to United States District Court for further action by the Federal appellate bench yesterday.
OTTAWA, Dec. 29 -- Canada will give India an additional $15-million worth of food to meet the emergency there, Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson announced today.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Bart Starr tuned up his throwing arm today and reported he planned to play for Green Bay Sunday in the National Football League title game with the Cleveland Browns.
The nation's banks yesterday continued to add to their rosters of supervisory personnel, a process that began several weeks ago and traditionally reaches a crescendo by the end of the year.
The Thomas J. Deegan Company, Inc., announced yesterday that Maj. Gen. Chester V. Clifton had been elected president and a member of the board. He has been executive vice president.

" I KNOW I should be minding my own business," said Buzzie Bavasi, refusing to mind his own business, "but I can't understand why the Cubs fired Bob Scheffing. thought he did the best managerial job in the league last season."
An expanded program of helpful hints to cultural centers on avoiding pitfalls in their costly projects is being developed by Art Councils of America.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- One of the surprising developments in America's burgeoning recreational skiing picture is the frenetic attention suddenly being paid the sport by resort owners in the thriving southern Catskill Mountains.

Directors of the Aurora Plastics Corporation declared yesterday a 50 per cent stock distribution on its common shares to effect a three-for-two split. The distribution will be made Feb. 3 to stockholders of record Jan. 11.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Many more errors occur in giving drugs in hospitals than is commonly assumed, a research team declared today.

Seven Jewish youths, including a 20-year-old rabbinical student, were arrested in Brooklyn late last night for allegedly looting at least 10 synagogues in the borough in the last year and a half, the police reported.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 29 -- Hofstra University defeated Iona, 82-67, in a Metropolitan Conference basketball game tonight after Otterbein overwhelmed New Hampshire, 75-67, in the first game.

A blue-ribbon panel of commercial bankers, and a college professor proposed yesterday an 11-point program "to lift from New York-chartered banks the restrictions which unreasonably hamper them in serving the banking and credit needs of industry, commerce and the general public."

When things go bad for the New York Knickerbockers, they don't go halfway. In losing to the Boston Celtics, 99-96, at Madison Square Garden yesterday, the Knicks extended two losing streaks, strengthened one jinx, reversed a pattern to no avail, suffered a painful goal-tending call and lost one of their starters in traffic.

The City's Acting Commissioner of Labor wrote the final chapter yesterday in attempts by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association to organize deck and engine-room officers aboard the Staten Island ferryboats.
The appointment of Edward Gudeman, a general partner of the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers, as a trustee of the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, N.Y., was announced yesterday.
Earnings of the Hewlett- Packard Company rose by 38 per cent for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 while sales gained by 22 per cent David Packard, chairman, said yesterday.

While City Hall is properly barred from interference with the process of education itself, the Mayor-elect holds the key to school reforms now blocked by obstacles that only political leadership can remove.

Newspaper reportage, pre-judgment and possible miscarriages of justice are discussed by Howard Felsher and Michael Rosen in "Press in the Jury Box," which Macmillan will issue on Feb. 21. Mr. Felsher is a writer-producer for television and Mr. Rosen is an attorney who did the research.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- English teachers ought to go to the copy desk of a good newspaper and learn more about the language, Dr. Don Cameron Allen, a professor at Johns Hopkins University, said today.
ROME, Dec. 29 -- Premier Aldo Moro accepted tonight "with much regret" the resignation of Foreign Minister Admintore Fanfani.

Sixty young women were presented at the International Debutante Ball, one of the last of the season's big coming-out parties, at the Astor last night. They represented 11 countries, some of the 50 states, the District of Columbia, nearby counties and an upstate town.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29 -- The stench of rotting garbage in the streets of Buenos Aires has thwarted President Arturo Illia's plan to halt Argentina's runaway inflation.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Ambassador Foy D. Kohler of the United States met for an hour today with the Soviet Chief of State, Nikolai V. Podgorny.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Oscar Robertson and Jerry Lucas again accounted for most of the scoring as the Cincinnati Royals downed the Los Angeles Lakers, 111-109, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
" Don Giovanni,' as given by the Salzburg Marionette Theater last night at Town Hall, was an astounding tribute to human skill at manipulating nonhuman figures to suggest reality.
The Millinery Workers Union ratified yesterday a three-year contract that provides a 10 per cent increase in wages and fringe benefits.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Led by Dave Newmark and Stan Felsinger, Columbia rallied from a sluggish first half and pinned an 83-63 loss on Ivy League rival Brown to win the third annual Kodak Classic tonight.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- "The best that can be found" in American high school English teaching is simply "not good enough," Prof. James R. Squire of the University of Illinois said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., Dec. 29 -- A stevedoring company and union at the port of Cambridge have been ordered to cease and desist from making race or union membership a condition of job referral.
We wish to call attention to the fact that separate articles in The New York Times by your correspondents John Cogley and George Dugan tend to mislead regarding a crucial point.
The city signed contracts yesterday for the construction of a $1.1-million sculptured playground and community center in Riverside Park near 103d Street.

Teen-agers home from private schools and colleges for the holidays gave their parents a night off yesterday by going to the Gold and Silver Ball at the Plaza. No more than a score of adults were on hand to chaperone the 800 youngsters.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in tile shareholdings of officers, directors and contrailing stockholders.

The British pound was steady in busy trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday, closing at $2.8024, up 2 points from Tuesday. Traders attributed the rise in volume to year-end commercial transactions.
A number of investors owning stocks that have grown considerably in value are hesitant to sell them because of the Federal capital gains tax they would have to pay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A spokesman for the United States Information Agency said today that plans were being discussed to keep approximately a tenth of its library in the London Embassy as a reference library.
BAY SHORE, L.I. Dec. 29 -- Nine welfare recipients were arrested here this morning and accused of selling prescription drugs to local high school students.

Your engagement to the Nugent boy is the most heart-warming news we've had out of the White House since the last tax cut, and we all hope you're just as happy as you look in the pictures the papers have been carrying.
BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, announced today the end of his Senate career and thereby set in motion the kind of political brouhaha Boston likes best.

Jimmy Walker scored a record-tying 50 points, quarterbacked his basketball team with skillful ball control and playmaking and set a field-goal record in leading Providence to a 91-86 victory over Boston College last night in the final of the 14th annual Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.

The true football fan faces a major endurance test this weekend. Two games will be televised today, four tomorrow and one on Sunday. Only those fans in good condition will be able to withstand a gruelling 15 or more hours of pigskin programing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- The Chicago Symphony Orchestra celebrated its 75th anniversary tonight with a special concert in Orchestra Hall at which a symphony composed by its director, Jean Martinon was presented for the first time.

EL PASO, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Two Cinderella football teams meet tomorrow in the 31st annual Sun Bowl, with the Southwest, Conference team, Texas Christian University, favored over the host city's Texas Western.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Federal Government announced today that it was sending its own analysts to Chicago to investigate complaints of racial discrimination in the public schools there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that workers can stop paying dues to a union that has lost its union shop status even though they previously signed pledges to pay dues for a specified period.
The Newspaper Guild of New York warned last night that it would call a strike "without notice" at three of the city's newspapers if they merged or consolidated their operations before Jan. 10.
WHITTIER, Calif., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The story of a young Air Force lieutenant who dangled from a jet tanker traveling 600 miles an hour 35,000 feet over Greenland was disclosed today by his father.

Mario A. Procaccino was sworn in as Controller yesterday in ceremonies that began with a laugh and ended with lasagna. More than 1,200 friends, relatives, Democratic and Republican politicians and judges showed up at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx for swearing-in ceremony in the grand ballroom -- a vinyl-walled room used mainly for weddings and bar mitzvahs.

ONE of the most entertaining bridge books of all time was recently published in England and is likely to appear in an American edition. It is "Bridge in the Menagerie" by Victor Mollo, and it is obtainable from the publishers, Faber and Faber, Ltd., 24 Russell Square, London W.C.1., England, for $2.30 including postage.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay urged New Yorkers yesterday not to drive their cars into the city if the transit workers strike tomorrow morning.
Commissioner of Parks-designate Thomas P.F. Hoving yesterday asked for the resignations of the two active staff members of the city's Office of Cultural Affairs.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics outlasted the San Francisco Warriors to take a National Basketball Association game tonight, 116-113.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The high-powered offensive units of Georgia Tech and Texas Tech were expected to race up and down the field tomorrow in an all-out scoring duel at the 21st annual Gator Bowl football game.
JAKARTA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Royal Dutch-Shell Oil Company sold out its entire Indonesian operation to the Government today for $110-million.
Expansion plans were announced by a number of concerns in a variety of industries yesterday.
PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 30 (AP) -- A $554,379 suit was filed yesterday against Merrill Lynch, Pierce. Fenner Smith, Inc., the nation's largest brokerage firm.
Bobby Fischer adjourned his game with Dr. Karl Burger of Brooklyn in the final round of the United States Chess Championship last night.
" Never been anything like it before," William F. Tobin, the 26-year-old chief planner of the inauguration of Mayor John V. Lindsay, was saying yesterday.
A state law requiring a written prescription for drugs containing stimulants and depressants will go into effect at midnight tonight.

TORONTO, Dec. 30 -- The possibility of tough Federal securities laws in Canada has been raised by Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson's call for a conference of Federal and provincial officials on securities legislation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Defense Department asked news media in the United states today to "refrain voluntarily" from publishing or broadcasting advance information on troop movements to Vietnam.
City Hall was engulfed in a flurry of last-minute business yesterday as the Wagner administration, after virtually 12 years, observed its penultimate day in office.
The Sunshine Mining Company announced yesterday it had taken control of the Bismarck Mining Company with the election of three of the company's five directors.

Two men were found shot to death yesterday in an automobile on a quiet back street in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx in what the police said could have been a classical "gangland rub out." One of the victims also had his throat cut and had been stabbed repeatedly.
The Dana Corporation, auto-equipment maker, showed record sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30, its report disclosed yesterday.
The Cornell University Glee Club will tour the Far East for three months this winter and early spring. The tour is sponsored by the State Department's Office of Cultural Presentations.
The Gillette Safety Razor Company announced yesterday the appointment of Thomas W. Casey as vice president for marketing. He had been vice president in charge of sales.
WASHINGTON Dec. 30 (AP) -- Retail sales apparently set a record for the second straight week in the final week before Christmas.

One of the two vice chairmen of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority yesterday accused the chairman, Robert Moses, of having published many expensive booklets and brochures "just to advertise Bob Moses."
NEW ORLEANS Dec. 30 (AP) -- Jim Ryun and John Lawson shattered two Sugar Bowl track marks today during a nine-event meet in which the record book was almost entirely rewritten.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- With a bad scare behind them, the Cleveland Browns plan a final intensive workout tomorrow and then will pack up and move to Green Bay for Sunday's National Football League championship game with the Packers.

" CHESS," wrote the experts I.A. Horowitz* and P.L. Rothenberg in their delightful rumination "The Personality of Chess" (1963), "has been variously considered a pastime, game, way of life, obsession, religion, waste of time, supreme intellectual challenge, curse, blessing, integrating force and destroyer of family life."

Leontyne Price, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, will receive the 50th Spingarn Medal of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, it was announced yesterday by Roy Wilkins, executive director of the organization.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 -- The Justice Department has charged three police officers in Bogalusa, La., with depriving Negroes of their civil rights in violation of a Federal law of 1870.

Business paid considerably more for bank credit in the first 15 days of December than it did as recently as last September, according to a report released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Norfolk Western Railway in a year-end statement issued yesterday, said its 1965 earnings would total "more than $9.50 a common share, highest in history." In 1964 its net income, restated to reflect charges in the final quarter, totaled $8.53 a share.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The American auto industry closed its calendar year in high gear today as the last cars and trucks of a record-breaking 1965 rolled off assembly lines. Some 630,00 auto workers will now enjoy the long New Year's holiday weekend.
NEWARK, Dec. 30 -- A Federal Court refused today to dismiss a price-fixing indictment against eight oil companies on a motion claiming that women had been discriminated against as prospective jurors.
In the spirit of the Christmas season, peace was made yesterday between the Pennzoil Company and the United Gas Corporation.

A legislative committee proposed yesterday a five-year outlay of $250-million through a narcotics control commission that would have broad powers to coordinate and supervise all public and private treatment programs for addicts.
Godfrey Cambridge, a standup comic now at Basin Street East, uses a large part of his comedy to stand up for better understanding between the races.
Holiday trimmings notwithstanding, the New York Hilton Hotel took on the appearance this week of two other institutions:
The British pound was firmer in active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Its closing quotation of $2.8031 showed a gain of 7 points over Wednesday.
MANILA, Dec. 30 -- Steve Mabry had visitors this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Republican Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York will make a trip to South Vietnam next week.

BERKELEY, Calf., Dec. 30 -- The council of the American Association for the Advancement of Science said today that it was "deeply disturbed" by the impending cuts in Federal funds for medical and scientific research arising from the cost of the war in Vietnam.
IN a back room at 888 Madison Avenue, Alan Miller and his colleagues are doing their bit to prow that the rise of paperbacks has not meant the descent of handsomely bound books.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Government standards to limit the amount of pollution fed into the atmosphere from automobile exhausts will be promulgated tomorrow by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare through publication in The Federal Register.

Walter Kidde Co., Inc has expanded its consumer-products business through the acquisition of S.W. Farber, Inc. The cash purchase price was not disclosed, but trade sources estimated the transaction at about $10-million.
READING, Pa., Dec . 30 -- Long Island University romped to a 90-55 victory over Dartmouth College tonight and won the Albright invitation basketball tournament.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 30 -- A Hollywood press agent was spilling out his troubles the other day at a local pub: I got a call this morning from one of my clients, a director who hasn't made a good picture for five years.

The Houston Astrodome, once derided as a sty in the eye of Texas, ended this year "tremendous in every category," according to Roy M. Hofheinz, the president of its leasing corporation. A boat show, a polo match and a bloodless bullfight starring El Cordobes already have been booked for early next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Mediators announced tonight a tentative settlement of a strike that the Government said was threatening the supply of ammunition to Vietnam.
BONN, Dec. 30 (Comtelburo) -- Siemens and Halske AG will soon acquire a share in a new company arising from the merger of two leading shipyards in Hamburg.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The United States announced today that it had contracted for a jet cargo plane to begin its share of the airlift of petroleum products to Zambia.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A stubborn fire that burned for four days in the hold of a ship carrying 127 tons of small arms ammunition, was put out today.

Wagering on horse racing in the United States scared to nearly $4.5-billion in 1965 as 59-million fans kept the turnstiles clicking merrily at thoroughbred tracks in 24 states and at plants catering to trotters and pacers in 16 states.

The business machines industry is growing so rapidly that its members are finding it necessary to make "courageous" leases, according to a study of the office-space market in four cities. And the impact of the industry's growth is being felt sharply here.

MADRID, Dec 30 (Comtelburo) -- Spain is facing a payments deficit this year that will reduce her gold and foreign currency reserves for the first time in seven years, government figures indicated today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 30 -- Three United States Marines and eight South Vietnamese soldiers were executed and mutilated by enemy troops, apparently North Vietnamese regulars, while on patrol earlier this month, an American military spokesman said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 -- Stockholders of the Atlantic Refining Company, meeting here, and of the Richfield Oil Company, meeting in Wilmington. Del., approved today a proposal to merge Richfield into Atlantic.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 -- A cloak-and-dagger story involving Pope Pius XII in "one of the most astounding events in the modern annals of the papacy" was related to the American Historical Association today.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- A new constitutional status for six islands and groups of islands in the east Caribbean as "states in association with Britain" is proposed in a white paper published by the Colonial Office today.
The New York Rangers, approaching the panic stage, dropped Doug Robinson yesterday and assigned the leftwing to the Clippers, their Baltimore farm.
An investment group has accumulated more than 20 per cent of the common stock of Bond Stores, Inc., the apparel chain.

OBERSTDORF, Germany, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- John Balfanz of Minneapolis recorded jumps of 229 and 234 feet today for fifth place in the first event of the German-Austrian ski-jumping tournament. The winner was Veikko Kankkonen of Finland.

Michael Quill and other transit union leaders could face jail, and transit workers could lose their jobs -- or at least go through three years with no more wage increases and five years without job security -- if all legal processes are invoked to punish transit strikers.
IN 1965, fashion was a ploy, a tool, an excuse.
The United Federation of College Teachers filed with the National Labor Relations Board yesterday a charge of unfair labor practices against St. John's University.
Members of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America, A.F.L.-C.I.O., have reversed themselves and accepted a contract with Consolidated Edison that they voted to reject four weeks ago.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- Senior Western diplomats believe the Soviet Union is preparing to intensify its support for North Vietnam's war effort rather than to assist in Western attempts to open peace talks.
Five cities in the United States have rapid (subway type) transit systems with basic fares ranging from 15 cents in New York to 30 cents in Cleveland for travel within the city.
DUFFY DAUGHERTY, the Jolly Green Giant, from Michigan State, is such an incurable optimist that he once felt it imperative to warn the alumni.
American Airlines, Inc., conducted an unusual and successful recruiting experiment this week in which the results more than paid for the entire cost of the project.

The State Department's decision to permit physicians and medical scientists to visit China, North Vietnam, North Korea, Albania and Cuba returns to an old tradition that has been almost forgotten. It used to be generally recognized that scientists merited special freedom of movement, which was sometimes extended to them even in periods of war.

ATLANTA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell said today that a record $60 billion would be needed for national defense next year and that some of President Johnson's Great Society programs may have to be cut back to avoid a tax increase.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Ken Gardner came off the bench tonight and led Clemson to a 77-67 victory over Manhattan in the championship game of the seventh annual Poinsettia basketball classic.
Scientists who have been studying communications between dolphins have reported recording what in effect appear to be telephone conversations between those aquatic mammals.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The once gracious living room of Gracie Mansion was bleak as Mayor Wagner, who leaves office at midnight tonight, talked of the successes and disappointments he had encountered in 12 years at City Hall.
Copper made news in futures trading yesterday -- a day marked by heavy volume and generally rising prices in many commodities.
Rootlessness marked the lives of nearly all of the seven Jewish youths arrested Wednesday night on charges of burglarizing more than 10 synagogues in Brooklyn and numerous homes.

Charles Evans, a producer of women's sportswear who looks as if he ought to be a leading man in the movies, plans to inject some of the nervous and dynamic energy of Seventh Avenue into a new business.

Orin Lehman announced the formation of a citizens committee yesterday to support his campaign for the Democratic nomination for the Congressional seat to be vacated by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay, a Republican.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Mr. Whiston said at a news conference today that Mr. Gardner's criticism was "unfair."

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 30 -- The White House, breaking its silence on current efforts to bring about a peaceful settlement of the war in Vietnam, said today that the United States wanted only to be reasonable and to resolve the conflict around the conference table rather than on the battlefield.

HONG KONG, Dec. 30 -- North Vietnam's Communist leadership has forecast "still greater victories" against the United States in 1966 and has asserted that economic progress can be achieved even under conditions of war.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The Rhodesian crisis has produced chinks in the reputation of Lloyd's of London, the great insurance institution, whose name has come to symbolize British financial integrity.
The United States Treasury gold stock declined $75-million last week.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- "I am sure today's announcement won't be as much of a surprise as yesterday's," the president of the Boston Opera Company said today as he smiled into the television lights and proclaimed himself a candidate to succeed Leverett Saltonstall as a Republi can Senator from Massachusetts.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 30 -- The New Jersey College of Medicine, which planned to leave its quarters in the Jersey City Medical Center at the end of this month, today postponed its move until Jan. 31.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 30 -- A program to compensate the victims of violent crimes might actually contribute to the growth of crime, a speaker said here yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 30 -- President Johnson's special envoy, W. Averell Harriman, flew here today for talks with President Tito on the Vietnam crisis.

It is incredible that Amintore Fanfani should have quit as Foreign Minister and risked plunging Italy into political crisis merely because of some indiscreet remarks of his friend, the unpredictable Giorgio La Pira.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The St. Joseph's Hawks crushed previously unbeaten Temple, 97-65, tonight to win the Quaker City basketball tournament for the third time in the tourney's five-year history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The United States Consumer Price Index rose to a new high last month, and Government officials forecast a further increase for December.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury indicted 25 men today in connection with a multimillion-dollar theft ring at the Charleston Naval shipyard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Justice Department announced today that it had moved in Federal District Court in New York to block the acquisition of the Carte Blanche credit card business by the First National City Bank, New York.
The Defense Supply Agency in Philadelphia announced yesterday that it has raised sharply its estimates for textile requirements for the first quarter of 1966.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- There are growing signs that a major clash in the growing Soviet-Chinese conflict may break out at the international conference that is to begin Monday in Havana.

In your Dec. 24 edition you quote Cardinal Spellman as saying that he fully supports everything the United States is doing in Vietnam. That is his privilege. But when he adds, as you report that he did. "My country, may it always be right. Right or wrong, my country," then we must ask if this is what our religious leaders are teaching.
The stock market moved into higher ground yesterday in moderately active trading.

ROME, Dee. 30 -- The Rome City Council voted today to end the experimental pedestrian "island" a day and a half early. The experiment, which closed a major area downtowm to passenger-car traffic during rush-hour periods, had been scheduled to end Jan. 5.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Lynda Bird Johnson ended a three-day holiday stay in Wyoming and Utah today after nearly being stranded in a snowstorm.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that persons charged with traffic violations in New York City do not have to be advised of their right to counsel.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 30 -- The Right Rev. James Pike, Episcopal Bishop of California, predicted today, after being deported from Rhodesia, that a "bloodless coup" would soon be staged in that country.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 -- An area-wide drive to reduce losses from cargo pilferage in Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif., began this week wire a two-year appropriation of $40,500 by maritime interests representing local port governments and industry.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 30 -- Announcement of plans for a Congressional hearing on United States policy on South Africa has provoked strong resentment here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Administration's current Vietnam peace efforts have raised the question whether a new role is being contemplated for the International Control Commission.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday set up a study group that will complete a master plan for reorganizing the city government and named three more of the key aides who will help him at City Hall.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The top-seeded teams advanced with clean sweeps today in the second round of the annual Sunshine Cup tennis matches.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 30 -- The United States is continuing reconnaissance flights over North Vietnam to determine whether the Communists are taking advantage of the bombing lull to regroup forces or to further infiltrate South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The enduring mystery of the war in Vietnam is why the Communists have not accepted the American offers of unconditional peace talks.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Dec. 30 -- Three United States Navy icebreakers today shoved a massive iceberg totaling almost 2.5 million cubic yards half a mile to get it out of the McMurdo Sound shipping channel, which it threatened to block.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 ( UPI) -- Stanley R. Resor, Secretary of the Army, and Harold Brown, Air Force Secretary, announced jointly today that they were leaving immediately on a trip to Vietnam.

Mayor-elect Lindsay faces all the old budgetary, staff and utilization problems of the world's largest municipal hospital system, plus the additional challenge imposed on it by such innovations as Medicare and the Folsom Act for the reorganization of state health services.
The London stock market was firm yesterday in light trading. Reports of current efforts to bring about peace in Vietnam seemed to have little effect on the session.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Judge John P. Gaultieri has stepped down as presiding judge of the Court of Claims, Governor Rockefeller's office announced tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Lord Sempill, a pioneer in aviation, died in Edinburgh today, leaving behind the question whether his brother, who was registered as a female at birth, can inherit a 300-year-old baronetcy.
CALCUTTA, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Carole Prosen of Orlando, Fla., reached the women's singles final in the Asian lawn tennis championship today by defeating Rita Suraiya of India, 6-2, 6-4.
OTTAWA, Dec. 30 -- Prime Minister Pearson said in a statement today that McGeorge Bundy had been sent here by President Johnson to discuss "the latest developments in the Vietnam situation."
MANILA, Dec. 30 -- Ferdinand E. Marcos warned today that corruption and lawlessness must be smashed or this young republic could not survive the crisis he said it now faced.
ROME, Dec. 30 -- Pope Paul VI may play "a role of active exploration" for peace in Vietnam through quiet Vatican diplomacy, according to qualified sources here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations cautioned the Johnson administration today against cutting back on domestic programs because of the cost of the Vietnam war.
FOR the last two years, ocean powerboat racing has had to be content with a "world" champion. Next season, it will have one without the quotation marks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Johnson's "peace offensive" to bring the war in Vietnam to the negotiating table yielded what appeared to be the first small dividends today.
Leaders of the Committee for the Six Million Jews rejected last night a design for a monument to the Jews who died under Nazi rule that was approved earlier this month by the city's Art Commission.
PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative at the United Nations, will meet President de Gaulle at noon tomorrow to discuss the Vietnam crisis.

The city's two major transit unions walked out of negotiations with the Transit Authority yesterday and said they would not return until Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay joined the talks on a continuing basis.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- A Soviet astronaut has hinted that the Russians may be planning to develop a new class of space vehicles, designed to glide to a controlled landing after reentering the earth's atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Selective Service officials are considering helping meet the manpower needs of the Vietnam fighting by bringing back the Korean wartime rules that made it difficut to get and hold a college deferment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the United States would accept a "nonaligned" South Vietnam provided it could be kept safe from Communist aggression.
The American Stock Exchange made it two in a row yesterday. Prices advanced somewhat for the second consecutive day in moderate trading to help reverse the losses of earlier in the week.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 30 -- The pockmarked man, reclining in his underwear in a barracks room crowded with the cots of his followers, rolled to his feet with agility. Grinning, he pushed aside his pistol and cartridge belt and extended a hand to an unexpected visitor.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, asked for and received equal time yesterday from Radio Station WQXR to respond to an editorial broadcast over The New York Times's station Wednesday night. He will broadcast his reply to the editorial this evening at 6:35.
