UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 30 -- Eugene Holmes, the general chairman of the Ford Dealers Thunderbird Classic committee, announced today the signing of a contract to hold the $100,000 Thunderbird Golf Classic at the Upper Montclair Country Club in 1966.
An estimated total of 4.65-million travelers flew or sailed across the North Atlantic last year, making 1965 the best year along the world's busiest international travel route.
HOUSTON, Dec. 30 -- "A large orange flame" swirled around the Gemini 6 while it was headed toward orbit and rendezvous with Gemini 7 on Dec. 15, Capt. Walter M. Schirra Jr. said today.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The British balance-of-payments deficit worsened in the third quarter but showed substantial improvement for the first nine months of 1965, Treasury figures showed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Federal Government is ending the year with the biggest wave of voluntary retirements -- and, accordingly, of job openings for promotions and recruitment -- of any employer in history.

Henry T. Heald, has asked private philanthropy in his last report as president of the Ford Foundation to become bolder as the Federal Government takes over more of the functions previously left to foundations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Only the weather figures to be a factor tomorrow in the 41st annual Shrine East-West football game.

Arthur A. Goldberg has been elected a vice president of E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., and Harold W. Reilly has been admitted to Chas. E. Quincey Co. as a general partner, it was announced yesterday. Both appointments are effective Jan 1.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- President Johnson today promoted 10 Army National Guard and Army Reserve officers to major general and 25 to brigadier general.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The United States and Mexico signed today a $75-million currency-exchange stabilization agreement that for the first time provides potential help both ways.

Two brothers -- both career civil servants -- stepped down from top-level city jobs last night rather than continue under the incoming administration of Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay on a day-to-day basis.

AS recreation area operators in the Northeast were wondering about the effect a warming trend might have on their slopes and trails this weekend, members of the Rosendale Nordic Ski Club were hoping to stage the first major jump on their 70-meter hill on Sunday.

Hundreds of school children and teen-agers added over $400 to the Neediest Cases fund yesterday donating money saved from allowances, from piggy banks originally filled to buy Christmas presents, from caroling, or earned by baby-sitting and from paper routes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The 60 million income tax forms that are reaching taxpayers in the mail this week and next will be somewhat easier to fill out than last year's -- or so the Internal Revenue Service hopes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Rail freight volume in 1965 reached the highest level since 1944, rising 5.6 per cent above the 1964 total.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- With his Italian-born wife at his side, Attorney General Edward W. Brooke opened his campaign today to become the first Negro elected to the United States Senate since Reconstruction days.

The New Jersey Turnpike received authorization yesterday to widen its most heavily traveled segment -- the 30-mile stretch from Woodbridge to the northern terminus at Route 46, near the George Washington Bridge.

On Christmas Day The Times published two illuminating letters. Raymond B. Fosdick asked if a nation which destroys rice crops when people are hungry can be termed civilized. T.T. Shih remarked that this country destroys "only roads and bridges," and urged the bombing of Hanoi to bring our adversary to the conference table.
A graduated system of withholding taxes should be looked at in two over-all ways -- namely, compelled and voluntary.

Everyone likes to make merry on New Year's Eve. Society here, no exception, will usher in 1966 at parties at homes, hotels and nightclubs. Many persons will be celebrating in the south where they have already gone to escape the wintry blasts.

" Birth Day," instead of "Family Things, etc.," will identify William Inge's new comedy. Lined up for the six-character cast are Betty Field, Hiram Sherman, Beau Bridges, Katharine Houghton, Robert Hooks and Barbara Ann Teer.

Ever since Adam awoke from his celebrated sleep, in which he lost a rib and gained Eve, man has been puzzling about the stuff of dreams -- their psychic meaning and physiological mechanism. Yet until recently so little was known scientifically of dreams that the field was a charlatan's paradise.

Your Dec. 26 editorial "New York Program: Planning" claims that among the city's "interdepartmental jumbles" is the fact that "Real Estate defies planning as the sell-off of city-owned land in Staten Island continues unchecked. . . . "
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The British Embassy announced today that Queen Elizabeth had honored 12 Americans for promoting friendship and understanding between Britain and the United States.
Thousands of New York churchgoers will watch the old year out tonight in prayer, meditation and at festive social hours.

PARIS -- While nothing has yet been done on an official level, it is beginning to look as if President Johnson and General de Gaulle will probably meet in Paris some time during 1966. The French Foreign Ministry has answered American inquiries by saying that, should the President take a European tour next year, he would be welcomed here.

BONN, Dec. 30 -- The United States and West Germany will hold talks early next year to discuss possible shifts in Bonn's program of arms purchases from the United States, American sources here revealed today.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 30 -- A milestone in the urbanization of Long Island was passed here today when the Justice of the Peace Court held its last session and went out of existence.
TOKYO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- American women and East German men accounted for a major share of the 21 world records officially recognized today by the International Swimming Federation.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 30 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority is paying $21,936,542 to the United States Treasury today as its semiannual return or dividend on the Government's appropriations investment in the power system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Prices that farmers received for products rose 4 per cent during the month ended Dec. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today. This put farm prices 11 per cent above the level a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Congressional auditors investigating how well the military utilizes its manpower reported some of their findings today.
BONN Dec. 30 -- A 70-year-old former Nazi police captain hid his face as a long list of crimes he is accused of having committed in wartime Poland was read to him in court today.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The state's highest court ruled 5-to-2 today in favor of snowball throwing.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The Westminster Bank, earlier bested in a proxy fight for control of the Diners' Club of Britain, said today it had recently acquired a 40 per cent minority interest in the company.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Jim Taylor, the Green Bay Packers' star fullback, was suffering from a pulled groin muscle and Bart Start, the quarterback, still was below par in his passing today as the Packers prepared for Sunday's National Football League title game with the Cleveland Browns.
BONN, Dec. 30 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard warned the West German people today that their hard-won postwar material gains may be endangered by current economic conditions.

IN the near future New York State will get a new Conservation Commissioner. His area of responsibility will range from the care and cultivation of oil wells to preventing kids with BB guns from practicing marksmanship on chickadees.

The Board of Higher Education and the chancellor of the City University last night took additional steps to transform their truce into permanent peace. In a special meeting, the board accepted several key demands made by Dr. Albert H. Bowker, the chancellor, when he withdrew his resignation earlier this month.

ROME, Dec. 30 -- Premier Aldo Moro cut short a holiday today to take over temporary direction of Italy's foreign affairs and to face a delicate political situation produced by the resignation of Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 30 -- The 38-foot sloop, Freya, owned by Magnus and Trygve Halvorsen, was the likely winner on a handicap basis today for a record third consecutive year in the Sydney-to-Hobart yacht race.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had extended for another 10 days a trading suspension on the common stocks of Fotochrome, Inc, and Noramco, Inc, traded on the American Stock Exchange, and Bristol Dynamics, Inc., which is traded over the counter.
Government bond prices declined, and corporate bond prices rose in a market governed more by the fact that the year was drawing to a close than by the economic outlook.

Truman Capote invested six years' work in a new kind of book that he calls "the nonfiction novel" and now is receiving in return $2-million in magazine, book and film payments. The book. "In Cold Blood." will be published by Random House Jan. 17.

The principals and the mediators in the stalemated transit negotiations believe that a shutdown of the city's subways and buses by strike is more likely than in any previous transit crisis. There have been settlement cliff-hangers in the past, but never a general transit strike that left New Yorkers without transporportation.
MADRID, Dec. 30 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco warned tonight against weakening the West through attempts to impose on Europe what he called an illusory and "rootless" concept of political unity.
WASHINGTON Dec. 30 -- With the tacit approval of the State Department, a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee will hold hearings early next year on American policy on South Africa.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- A Polish member of the International Control Commission ran into a police station here this morning and requested political asylum, a South Vietnamese Government spokesman reported.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- University of California, Los Angeles, dazzling Southern California with one of its finest performances of the season, swept to its fourth consecutive Los Angeles Basketball Classic championship tonight with a 94-76 victory.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller will make an intensified attack on air pollution with the help of Dr. Edward Teller, the "father of the hydrogen bomb."

It may be of little importance if President Johnson chooses not to invite Senator J. William Fulbright to White House dinners for visiting foreign statesmen. It is a more serious matter if the White House has decided to ignore or bypass the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on legislative and other problems affecting American foreign policy, as a recent Washington story in The Times suggests.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 31 The weather was the chief topic among the Browns today as the Cleveland team completed its preparations for the National Football League championship game at Green Bay, Wis., on Sunday. If the weather forecast for Sunday proves correct, it could present severe problems for the Cleveland offense.

Introducing a new product the better mousetrap, the television machine that strains out snow, the electric carving knife is being managed better nowaday's. The result is that the perils of marketing something new but only possibly better are diminishing.
"Bagels and Yox," the American-Yiddish musical that ran or Broadway for 208 performances during the 1951-52 season, will be revived at 2:45 P.M. today at Brandt's Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Theater.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 31 William H. McKnight of 959 Knollwood Court, a group leader and research chemist with the plastics division of the Union Carbide Corporation. Bound Brook, died today at the age of 47.
NORTH BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 31 Leroy Danziger, a lawyer specializing in transportation law, died Wednesday night at Middlesex General Hospital in New Brunswick at the age of 62.
For the first time in this county, Roman Catholics, Protestants and members of the Eastern Orthodox churches will offer common prayers this month for Christian unity.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 Miss Martha Sanborn Pruyn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sewall Pruyn, of Loudonville, was married today to Alan David Judson, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Havelock Judson of Valatie. The ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church was performed by the Rev. Robert Lamar and the Rev. Kirk Arthur Hudson, brother-in-law of the bride.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad's profits in November climbed to $805,000 from $145,000 in the 1964 month, Jervis Langdon Jr., chairman, announced yesterday. In October of this year, the road cleared $820,000.

YORK, Pa., Dec. 31 Miss Virginia Thornton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Thornton, was married this evening to James Mitchell Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Chidester of Chicago Heights, Ill. The Rev. Dr. Richard J. Oman performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

HUDSON, N.Y., (AP) Dec. 31 A disabled veteran of World War II charged today that his son, an Army trainee at Fort Dix, N.J., had been beaten by a sergeant when he was unable to march because of illness. Army officials at Fort Dix said they would investigate next week.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 31 George H. Beaudry, manager here of Wallachs, Inc., a branch of the New York clothing chain died Wednesday in White Plains Hospital at the age of 63. He lived on Old Well Road in Harrison.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 31 Mr. and Mrs. F. David Lapham have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Penelope Dearborn Lapham, to John Dexter Anderson. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Dexter Anderson of Rockford, Ill.
DUXBURY, Mass., Dec. 31 Walter C. Beckjord, retired chairman of the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company, died at his home today. He was 77 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 31 Polish officials here asked the South Vietnamese today for the return of a Polish member of the International Control Commission who defectedearlier today. They said he was mentally ill.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 31 The 47-year-old Albee Theater, once a vaudeville house has become Providence's new performing arts center, bringing top-flight entertainment to a city in the cultural doldrums.
The smell of the greasepaint and the roar of the crowd has replaced the odor of coal-burning and the cry of the train caller at an old railroad depot in Kentucky.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 31 President Johnson warned against possible inflationary actions tonight in a statement aimed at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's price increase.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel producer, raised the prices of its structural steel products $5 a ton yesterday.

As a countermeasure, perhaps, to the city's exces- sive ingestion of holiday visitors, both pedestrian and automotive, and to the debilitating mob scenes that inevitably result on sidewalk and street, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has mounted a small exhibition entitled "Early American Cities."

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 Robert S. Kilborne 3d, a collector of antique automobiles and a racer of power boats, was killed today in an automobile crash. His age was 37. He maintained homes at 1 Gracie Avenue in New York and at 435 Sea Spray Avenue in Palm Beach.
A rabbi prominently identified with Conservative Judaism has charged that the rabbinate, no longer exercises any religious and cultural influence over its congregations.

United State Circuit Judge Robert P. Anderson yesterday authorized the bankrupt New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to begin liquidating a number of old debts by paying more than $7 million to the Federal Government.
What were the best investments of 1965? Not the stock market generally, although the Dow-Jones industrial averages set a historic high at the end of the year, up about 11 per cent from a year ago.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 31 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Edward McMurray Jr. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Yardley McMurray, to John Archibald Murray 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray of Summit, N.J., and Cotuit, Mass.

Delta Air Lines, Inc., a large carrier operating mainly in the South, announced yesterday that its profits and revenues in November and the first five months of its present fiscal year rose sharply from 1964 levels.
The year, at least, was consistent. Bond prices declined yesterday just as they had done most of the time during 1965.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 Social Security taxes will be higher and Federal excise taxes lower in the new year.
The public inauguration of John V. Lindsay as Mayor of New York at City Hall today will be carried live on radio and television.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 31 Mrs. Ruth Blanchard Walker, widow of Frederick Burrell Walker, was married today to James Herbert Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Kane Johnson of Haddon Heights, N.J. The bride's parents are Mrs. Fessenden Seaver Blanchard and the late Mr. Blanchard. The Rev. James Seth Stewart performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 The Soviet Union announced today that its space technicians had made a successful midcourse correction for Venus 3, one of its two Venus probes speeding toward a rendezvous about March 1 with the mysterious cloud-shrouded planet.

Tillman Kermet Breiseth, playwright, who taught literature at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y., since 1948, died Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 40 East 10th Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The United States National Academy of Sciences has entered into a scientific exchange program with Yugoslavia as the first step toward closer scientific cooperation with Eastern European countries.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (UPI) In a move that caught foreign metal traders by surprise, the price of Congo copper was raised today well above the level agreed among other copperproducing countries.

When a singer is as strikingly beautiful as Barbara McNair, minor vocal failings may be easily overlooked. But Miss McNair, who has taken 10 years to come uptown from the Village Vanguard, where she made her professional debut, to the Persian Room of the Plaza, does not have to depend on looks alone.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks built their league lead to three points by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 4-1, in a National Hockey League game here tonight.

DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP) Arkansas will seek its 23d straight victory, its second bowl triumph in a row and a possible national football championship tomorroy when it sends its high-geared offense against Louisiana State University in the Cotton Bowl.
A police lieutenant became a hero for the second time in six weeks yesterday morning when he led a family of eight to safety from their blazing apartment house.
"Judith" and "Inside Daisy Clover" have been scheduled as the first two screen offerings of the new year at the Raido City Music Hall, following the current Christmas show featuring "That Darn Cat."
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's price increase is a significant push toward inflation and is a disservice to the national interest at this time.

John V. Lindsay takes office today. Since last May, when he made the momentous decision to run for Mayor of New York, he has been in politics. Now he is in government. As a non-Democrat who succeeded in getting elected, he accomplished the difficult. Now he tackles the almost-impossible; the task of governing New York with vigor and effectiveness.
A dungeon-like space beneath the stage floor of the Anta Washington Square Theater, where "Man of La Mancha" is playing, serves as a sort of communal dressing room for the show's entire cast.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 President Ho Chi Minh insisted on stressing North Vietnam's own peace terms today and pub- licly thanked "the American people" for opposing the military actions of their Government.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 31 (AP) William du Pont Jr., banker and sportsman, died tonight at the Memorial Division of the Wilmington Medical Center, where he had undergone surgery Dec. 9. He was 69 years old.
New Yorkers welcomed in the New Year under a cloud as bid as a glint in the eyes of Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union.

THE most frequent question a declarer must ask him- self is: "Should I draw trumps?" There is no simple answer to this, but a generalization can be ventured. Always draw trumps unless ruffing tricks are needed in the shorter trump hand, or trump control is shaky, or some other play is urgently required by the situation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 Gardner Ackley, chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers, denounced today as "inflationary and not in the public interest" the price increase for structural steel announced by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 31 (Reuters) Top batting following fine bowling by Barry Knight today earned England the lead over Australia on the second day of the second cricket test match.

The Boston Maine Corporation said yesterday it had sold the North Station Railroad terminal property, including the Boston Garden sports facility in the terminal building, to Linnell Cox, a Boston real estate development firm. The price was not disclosed.

Heyman Zimel of 7 Manon Road in Paterson, N.J., a lawyer and editor of The Passaio County Bar Reporter, a monthly journal, died of cancer yesterday at the New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. He was 57 years old.
The expected upward trend of consumer income coupled with leather companies' success in promoting their wares in non-shoe items adds up to a "basically good" outlook for the industry in 1966.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 31 The engagement of Miss Susan Dale Lasdon to Alan V. Abrams has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley S. Lasdon, parents of the future bride. Mr. Abrams is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Abrams of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

Bobby Fischer retained the United States chess championship yesterday, defeating Dr. Karl Burger in their final-round adjourned garhe at the Henry Hudson Hotel. The 22-year-old titleholder has now won the championship seven times, a new record.
MIAMI, Dec. 31 (UPI) Freddie R. rallied in the stretch at Tropical Park today to give Jorge Velasquez his fourth of five winners on the 10-race program.

PARIS, Dec. 31 Arthur J. Goldberg, the permanent United States representative at the United Nations, told President de Gaulle today of President Johnson's desire for "an early and honorable settlement" of the Vietnam conflict.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP)--A pair of flashy sophomores, Kim King and Lenny Snow, matched the glitter of Texas Tech's star halfback, Donny Anderson, and paced Georgia, Tech to a 31-2l upset victory over the Red Raiders today in the 21st Gator Bowl football game.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 31 The Norwalk Hospital announced today a drastic change in the operation and staffing of its emergency clinic, in an effort to upgrade the treatment given there and to deal with what many hospital authorities refer to as the growing emergency room crisis.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) There is bitterness and rebellion today because the Vatican Council failed to give Roman Catholics guidance on family planning, a British priest reports in the monthly Catholic Gazette.
The formation of the KerrMcGee Chemical Corporation as a wholly owned subsidiary to handle retail marketing of plant foods and farm chemicals was announced yesterday by the Kerr-McGee Corporation.

In line with executive changes announced earlier this month when a new general manager was named, the Holland-America Line reported yesterday the appointment of Henrick P. Rahusen as freight traffic manager in New York. He succeeds Otto I.M. Porton, who has been promoted to assistant general manager for the company in North America.
PARIS, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Russian Orthodox Church of Western Europe today declared itself independent of the Russian and Greek Orthodox churches.
THE man Robert F. Wagner appointed yesterday as a new member of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is his friend, frequent adviser and new landlord. In fact, he is a lot of people's landlord.

DENVILLE, N.J., Dec. 31 "We have a butcher, baker and candlestick maker," Egil Quam said of his gaily decorated store, which contains what may be the largest selection of Scandinavian foods in the country. He turned a beaming smile toward his daughter Linda, who was dressed in Norwegian costume only a little brighter than the store.

The stock market closed a year of record-breaking trading with a bang. Leading market averages climbed to historic high ground, and stocks advancing outnumbered those declining by a ratio of more than seven to five. Volume again was moderately heavy.
Jimmy Walker and his Providence teammates were invited back yesterday to compete in next season's Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 31 (UPI) Munich, Montreal and Madrid were named today as proposed sites for the 1972 Olympics.

KIMBERLEY, South Africa, Dec. 31 A young Angilgan bishop here, with a record in the civil right movement in the United States, is being accused of trying to embarrass the Government by distributing food to 1,000 hungry, disposessed black South Africans.
Winners of the second annual Millennium Prizes, awarded to Polish artists and scientists, will be announced at a dinner Jan. 12 at the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and 44th Street.

ORADELL, N.J., Dec. 31 Charles S. Strickler of 327 Country Club Drive, who retired in 1959 as a vice president of the Borden Foods Company division of the Borden Company, died yesterday at Holy Name Hospital, Teaneck, following a lung operation. His age was 68.
A man threatened to jump front a 60-foot crane early yesterday, but was talked down by the same policeman who had persuaded him to get off the Brooklyn Bridge seven years ago.
The First Army said farewell to Governors Island yesterday in a ceremony tinged with sadness.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (UPI) Tod Hullin of the University of Washington threw three touchdown passes today and the West made them stand up for a 22-7 victory over the favored East in the 41st annual Shrine football game.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 31 A poison obtained in minute quantities from the skin of 2,400 South American frogs has been found to be 10 times more toxic than any other known venom.
The Timken Roller Bearing Company has announced the election of Norman H. Peterson as vice president for corporate services. Mr. Peterson formerly served as assistant to the president.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 31 Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Henry Charles Crossfield of Llewellyn Park of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Crossfield, to Thomas Pearson August, son of Thomas Tappan August of New York and the late Mrs. August.
BOCA GRANDE, Fla., Dec. 31 (UPI) An explosion shot fire through the engine room of a British phosphate ship today, sending seven crewmen to the hospital. Six others suffered minor injuries.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 Top-ranked Michigan State and the University of California, Los Angeles, tangle tomorrow in the 52d Rose Bowl game a contest most of the experts view as strictly no contest.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 31 An unexpected visit to Saudi Arabia today by Premier Abdel Rahman al-Bazzaz of Iraq suggested to Arab political observers that he would seek the good offices of King Faisal in easing Iraq's current dispute with Iran.
LOWNDESBORO, Ala., Dec. 31 Civil rights workers began erecting tents in a cornfield today for Negroes who said they had been ordered from their farm homes during a voter registration campaign.

Mayor Wagner, changing his plans to attend the swearing in of John V. Lindsay as Mayor, took a surprise flight to Mexico yesterday morning, 20 hours before the deadline for a threatened citywide transit strike.
LONDON, Dec. 31 William Golding and Graham Greene were among those named today on the Queen's Honors List, which looked notably to writers.
GENEVA, Dec. 31 The International Press Institute said today that the newspapers of the world more than held their ground last year in the struggle to maintain freedom.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 31 The White House today announced agreement in principle on new United States-Candadian air routes that will allow much deeper cross-border penetration by airlines of the two countries than has been permitted before.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 There appear to be two big questions in the minds of United States officials now scanning the world for a clue that the conflict in Vietnam might be moved to the conference table.

Mr. and Mrs. Curt Muser of 415 East 52d Street and Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Muser, to Arthur Augustus Klipfel 3d, son of Mrs. Klipfel Jr. of Wapakoneta, Ohio, and the late Mr. Klipfel. The couple plan to be married on Jan. 29.
The Del E. Webb Corporation announced yesterday in Phoenix, Ariz., the appointment of L.C. Jacobson as chairman of the Sahara-Nevada Corporation, a subsidiary.
A single envelope arrived yesterday with $3 for the Neediest Cases fund from two young people who are apparent strangers.
"It's been a hell of a year," one commission broker declared yesterday on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.
Libya may have decided to call the cards of the six American oil companies that have refused to agree to that country's new oil-tax laws.
Tests are under way in more than a dozen United States communities to find out whether phosphates can help prevent tooth decay the way fluorides do.
Amtel, Inc., a Providence, R.I., manufacturer of air engine parts, announced yesterday the election of George H. Mettler as president.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 31 Senator Stuart Symington suggested today that the three Americans who were visiting Hanoi were "probably guilty of a criminal offense."
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 31 (AP) Water stored up from record snowstorms and rainstorms surged down into the Phoenix area today in a manmade flood that chased several thousand people from their homes.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 The Moscow city authorities, in an unusually drastic move, have barred unescorted schoolchildren from public places after 10 P.M. during vacation time.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 Dr. and Mrs. William U. McClenahan of Chestnut Hill have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Stewart McClenahan, to Michael Samuel Kendall. He is the son of Mrs. Harry C. Kendall of Cincinnati and the late Dr. Kendall.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 31 T.T. Krishnamachari, India's Finance Minister, resigned tonight when Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri did not clear him of corruption charges before the new year.

New capital issues in Britain rose to a record total of the equivalent of $2.2-billion in 1965, up from $1.4-billion in 1964, the Midland Bank, Ltd., reported yesterday. The previous record was $1.7-billion in 1961.

WASSENAR, The Netherlands Reinder Zwolsman put down the soup spoon, picked up his pipe and explained how he would install a ground-floor shopping arcade in the Hotel Continental in Paris, one of his properties.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 31 The engagement of Miss Regina M. Riley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Riley, to Lawrence J. Chase, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hotward Winfield Chase of Philadelphia, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 31 The Vietcong have overrun three more small Government outposts in the northern part of South Vietnam in an offensive that began soon after the Christmas truce had ended.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP) The cat-like agility and pin-point passing of Steve Sloan, Alabama's quarterback, make the Crimson Tide, a slight favorite over massive, hard-running Nebraska tomorrow night in the 32d annual Orange Bowl football game.

An official of the Soviet Embassy in Washington and a member of the Soviet State Commission on Radio and Television have registered "specific objections" to parts of the C.B.S. News documentary "The Volga" and have asked the Columbia Broadcasting System to cancel the network show, scheduled to be televised Tuesday at 10 P.M.
The American Stock Exchange ended the year yesterday in a very bullish manner. Most of the issues advanced on strong volume and its turnover for the year set a record.

CLEARFIELD, Utah, Dec. 31 (AP) Tons of gifts for South Vietnam that didn't make a Christmas deadline may reach their destination in time for another holiday, the Oriental Lunar New Year Jan. 20 to 23.

The English novelist Ford Madox Ford is having the sort of revival that would make most authors turn with pleasure in their graves. In the quartercentury since his death, he has had a little fame, but only now is he getting the literary recognition which he knew he deserved. Great artists know they are great, even if they are too aware to say so, and Ford's neglect baffled him.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Dec. 31 (AP) Ralph C. Ruggles, a newspaper publishers' representative, died of a heart attack today at the Nassau Community Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 55 Grand Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Business groups in a United States Chamber of Commerce poll are reported to be voting overwhelmingly for a sweeping change in the method of electing American Presidents.

Oscar Robertson, who has been averaging 35 points a game against the Knickerbockers, and his supporting cast, the Cincinnati Royals, meet the New Yorkers tonight in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden.

In a 2 A.M. radio and television broadcast to New Yorkers today, a weary Mayor John V. Lindsay outlined a series of emergency plans aimed at alleviating the hard- ships of a transit strike. The new Mayor, speaking at City Hall, urged severe restrictions on all travel into Manhattan.
The Universal Marion Corporation agreed yesterday to sell the assets and business of its division, the Marion Power Shovel Company, to the Pittsburgh Coke and Chemical Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 Electronic equipment in- vented by a Long Island engineer can tell a motorist the local speed limit and warn him-and perhaps the police.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 31 Indian and Pakistani military leaders will meet in Pakistan Monday for their first joint discussion of troop withdrawals along the cease-fire line, it was announed here today.

For the United States, this will be the year of Vietnam. No prediction is safer than that nor more burdened with anxiety as 1966 begins. By long tradition everybody says "Happy New Year!" but this time we keep our fingers crossed. Perhaps it will be happy, and peaceful, too; these last few days have raised some tenuous hopes that an end to the long and frustrating war may be within reach.

The Mehl Manufacturing Company may have to order a custom-built, extra-large desk for Robert A. Kurland, its new president, a director and executive committee chairman. Mr. Kurland is a 7-foot-tall former all-America basketball player.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP) Soviet newspapers announced today that retail prices on sugar, cotton fabrics and other goods would be reduced in rural areas starting tomorrow to bring them in line with city prices.
Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, declared in a year-end statement yesterday that the 1965 steel labor contract left the industry with "unresolved cost aggregations."

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz reported last night that his office had received a "virtual avalanche of complaints" about unordered merchandise received during the Christmas season by residents of the Metropolitan area.
Dr. Manfred George, editor of Aufbau, a German weekly here, died Thursday night in the University Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 785 West End Avenue.
In an atmosphere of crisis, caused by the threat of a transit strike, John Vliet Lindsay, 44 years old, last night became the 89th person to take the oath of office as Mayor of New York.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP) There has been no significant reaction in Hanoi to the halt of United States air raids on North Vietnam, a Yale assistant professor said today by telephone from the capital.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 31 Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Emslie Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Jeanne Emslie, to Gerard Anthony Sheridan, son of Mrs. William Sheridan of Mineola and the late Mr. Sheridan.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 31 The bell is coming off the voting machines in Connecticut. It will be the first practical result of the proclamation of Connecticut's new Constitution by Gov. John N. Dempsey.
SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., Dec. 31 Miss Larraine Zax and James R. Levitt are planning to be married in Los Angeles in April.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 31 (AP) Payoffs of up to "many thousands of dollars" to Oklahoma legislators are not uncommon, a grand jury said yesterday, but instead appear to be considered a "normal business expense."
The British pound closed practically steady yesterday in sluggish pre-holiday trading on foreign exchange markets here. Sterling was quoted at $2.8030, down a point from Thursday's close of $2.8031.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 (UPI) A subsidiary of the American Express Company is liable to the Procter Gamble Company for more than a half million dollars, the State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.
EL PASO, Dec. 31 (AP) Billy Stevens, a sophomore quarterback, led a second-half rally that carried Texas Western to 13-12 Sun Bowl football victory over Texas Christian today.

IT may be that the manufacturers of furniture are tak- ing the cue from the clothes industry with plans that will make English decor the most talked about and heavily promoted home furnishings look this year.
MIAMI, Dec. 31 (UPI) A schooner returning from a cruise in the Bahamas struck a reef today and foundered in the predawn darkness, but all 35 persons aboard were rescued.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 31 (AP) A conference on classroom cheating will be held here Jan. 8, organized and led by high-school students.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 31 The resignation of Galo Plaza Lasso as United Nations mediator for Cyprus was announced today.

The nightly pin-up girl may have her problems solved, at long last. Electrically heated "hot rods" called Carmen, which are a big success in Europe, are now being imported by Macy's to sell at virtually the same price as they do in London.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Dec. 31 (AP) Fire believed caused by an explosion destroyed a supermarket owned by Mayor John Nosser tonight.

December sales of the city's leading department stores were generally higher in 1965 than they were in December a year earlier as a result of strong Christmas business and an unusual surge of post-holiday shopping in the month's final week.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 31 Alfred Rowe, a Newark lawyer, and a past Grand Master of Masons of New Jersey, died Tuesday at Newark Presbyterian Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 32 Madison Avenue, here.
NEWARK, Ohio, Dec. 31 (UPI) Chalmers Lowell Pancoast, an author and former reporter, died on Wednesday in Springfield City Hospital. He was 85 years old.
VAIL, Colo., Dec. 31 (AP) Bill Kidd of the University of Colorado won the men's giant slalom and Sandra Shellworth of Boise, Idaho, took the women's event today in the Alpine holiday classic.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 31 President Johnson spent most of the last day of 1965 working at his desk.
Favorable dividend action by directors of 691 corporations last month sent the number of dividend increases for 1965 to a record.

After having chased and caught a cab driver who had allegedly left the scene of an accident in Harlem Thursday night, Earl Brown, the city's Commission on Human Rights, charged yesterday that the police seemed to have taken the case "rather lightly."
CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., Dec. 31 Three teen-agers died in a fire about 12:15 this morning that followed by a day a fire in the Christmas tree wiring in the same house.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 31 A tall, elderly Jor- danian guide asked his Israeli visitor, "How is the King David Hotel these days?"

COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Soviet Union, last year's world amateur hockey champion, used an aggressive defense last night to shut out Czechoslovakia, 3-0, in a tournament at the Broadmoor Arena.
TOKYO, Dec. 31 Kosaku Yamada, a leading Japanese composer and conductor for over half a century, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home in Tokyo. He was 79 years old.
Manhattan birdwatchers went to sea yesterday during the annual Christmas Season bird census.
Norman K. Winston, builder and a close friend of both Robert F. Wagner and Robert Moses, has been appointed to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority by the outgoing Mayor.
MANILA, Dec. 31 President Ferdinand E. Marcos is expected to ask the Philippine Congress to authorize the dispatch of a contingent of Philippine troops to South Vietnam.

Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 9.5 per cent in production for the week ended Dec. 25, compared with the level in the corresponding 1964 week. Output fell 40 per cent from the preceding week.

MANY dedicated persons studied drinking last night. Their pirimary researches, however zealous, were generally informal. Today they will cheerfully air bonded conclusions at learned conferences and sub-summit meetings called eggnog parties.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (UPI) Marion H. Van Berg won the money-winning title for 1965 among thoroughbred owners today despite Louis Wolfson's strong bid to wrest the title from the Nebraska cattleman.

RENO, Dec. 31 (AP) Robert Worth Bingham, a former merchant banker in Britain and member of a Louisville, Ky. newspaper family, died at a hospital here last night. He was 68 years old and lived in Genoa, Nev.
BONN, Dec. 31 A former Nazi police officer shot himself to death at his home near Bielefeld today a few minutes before he was to have been arrested on charges of mass murder during World War II.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec.31 The Armed Forces Minister, Commodore Francisco Javier Riveras Caminero, issued a communique today warning Dominicans to expect a wave of disorders Sunday and Monday.

NORFOLK ISLAND, South Pacific, Dec. 29 A visitor to this green and tranquil South Pacific island is likely to find that the clerk who waits on him in the Burns Philp general store is a great-great-grandson of Fletcher Christian, who led the mutiny on the Bounty.

IF the sum of the qualities of the elegant new Ground Floor Restaurant in the C.B.S. Building were equal to some of its parts, it would surely be counted among the grandest, most gratifying dining establishments in the city. In a physical sense, a more stylish restaurant than this one at 51 West 52d Street hasn't opened in New York in years.

A quiet debate is going on behind the scenes in the New York State Bankers Association over whether or not to ask the Legislature for an increase in the commissions that trustees are allowed to charge.
MADRID, Dec. 31 A new United States library and cultural center will be opened in Madrid in mid-January.
GREENSBORO, N.C. (UPI) Jack Martin hit for 24 points to lead Duke's Blue Devils to a 95-73 victory over Notre Dame after a sluggish start tonight.
NEW DELHI, Dec.31 W. Averell Harriman, President Johnson's Ambassador at Large, will arrive here Sunday for talks with Indian leaders on the new United States peace initiative in Vietnam.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 31 The Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith announced changes in the Cabinet tonight.
SCOTIA, N.Y., Dec. 31 (AP) A husky German hunting dog hauled his young master to safety today as two other boys drowned in an icy lake here.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Dec. 31 (AP) The Glasgow Celtic soccer team defied the Russians today and said it planned to fly by charter plane deep into the heart of the Soviet Union.
Public and private preparations to cope with a threatened strike of the city's transit systems intensified last night as the negotiations entered the final stages.

VERONA, N.J., Dec. 31 Ernest T. Parker, a former safety engineer with the Standard Oil Company of California, died early today at Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 39 Birdseye Glen.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 31 (AP) President Johnson has received a recommendation that the Air Force Academy schedule football games only with schools maintaining similar academic and athletic standards.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 31 Rowing into a 15mile-an-hour wind, the Oyster Bay Rowing Club defeated the New York Athletic Club by a half length today for the first time in four years to capture the Carter Cup for four-oared shells with coxswain.
Frank D. O'Connor was sworn in yesterday as President of the City Council and promised nonpartisan cooperation with John V. Lindsay as Mayor.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 31 An urgent 30-day field test of a new antimalaria drug began Wednesday among several hundred United States soldiers fighting in the malarial South Vietnamese highland.

LONDON, Dec. 31 Future control of the Diners' Club of Britain appeared today to be taking the form of a transAtlantic partnership between the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York and the Westminster Bank of London.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Mrs. James J. Wadsworth, wife of the Federal Communications Commissioner and former United States representative at the United Nations, died today at the age of 59.

The nation's private shipyard industry witnessed in 1965 a substantial expansion of naval ship construction work and a sizable contraction of shipbuilding for private account. Edwin M. Hood, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, said here yesterday.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) Lucky Debonair, the 1965 winner of the Kentucky Derby and Santa Anita Derby, returns to the race track tomorrow as the top horse in the $25,000 added Malibu Stakes.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 31 (UPI) The Green Bay Packers appeared to be near full strength today as they went through their final drill for the National Football League championship game Sunday against the Cleveland Browns.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 31 (UPI) Robert A. Humphrey, 21-yearold son of Vice President Humphrey, and Donna Erickson, 21, announced their engagement tonight at a party in the Regency Room of the Sheraton Ritz Hotel.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 31 Fog above Ljubljana airport blocked the attempt of Ambassador Harriman to meet President Tito today for talks on Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 President Johnson is making no new offers to North Vietnam in his "peace offensive" but is attempting to give added urgency and sincerity to the call for "unconditional negotiations" that he has been making since April 7.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UPI) Florida's gambling Gators and power-running Missouri will clash tomorrow in the 32d Sugar Bowl football game. Missouri, the runner-up to Nebraska in the Big Eight Conference, is a slight favorite
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia An American expert who toured the sprawling enterprise, commented: "In my country Iskra would be ruined in seven days."

Mayor John V. Lindsay, faced with a major transit crisis in his first hours as chief executive, moved into City Hall early today to direct emergency operations in an apparently certain subway and bus strike.
Steel shares sank yesterday in a spiritless year-end trading session on the London Stock Exchange.
The Jacob Ruppert Brewery, the last or the many of breweries that once operated in Manhattan and a landmark in the Yorkville area for 98 years, was closed yesterday.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, Jan. 1 Vice President Humphrey arrived here this morning on the third leg of his Far Eastern trip.
BONN, Dec. 31 President Heinrich Lubke of West Germany called on the United Nations today to take action on ending the division of Germany.

The president of St. John's University said yesterday that the issues threatening a strike by the faculty on Monday at the nation's largest Roman Catholic institution were "irreconcilable" and that the strike seemed inevitable.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 31 A broadcast by the socalled Free Cambodian Radio, monitored here today, said that forces commanded by Son Ngoc Thanhhae, a fugitive Cambodian leader, were attacking military posts in three frontier provinces.

BEMUS POINT, N.Y., Dec. 31 Miss Jeanette Ruth Powell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erby Powell, was married this afternoon to Hunter Watts Corbin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stockton Corbin of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J.

Ely A. Landau, president of the Landau-Unger Company, will receive a special citation from the Independent Film Importers and Distributors of America at the organization's annual awards dinner on Jan. 21 at the Americana Hotel.
The City Planning Commission rejected sharply yesterday a demand by Robert Moses that it withdraw its proposed substitution of a Cross Brooklyn Expressway for routes that Mr. Moses wants.

The forthcoming retirement of James Farmer as national director of the Congress of Racial Equality has put into sharp focus the unforeseen repercussions of the civil rights victories for all the organizations involved in the movement.
Built into Presbyterian law is the notion that when it comes to running the church the wisdom of laymen is at least as reliable as that of ordained clergymen.

How much does an economist make? It might be a surprise. The National Science Foundation has just issued a report on some 12,000 American economists, delving into their salaries, age, sex, academic background and the like. The report was released in connection with the annual meeting here of the American Economic Association and five related organizations.
Two Huntington builders plan to relocate a number of existing trees and plant new ones in an effort to maintain the tree-shaded character of a Dix Hills tract that is being developed into home sites.

A new high-speed electronic information retrieval system that can verify a customer's check-cashing credit status in one-tenth of a second has been introdlced by Telecredit, Inc., a Los Angeles-based checkapproval concern.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 Intermittent light rain dampened the costumes but not the spirits of the Philadelphia Mummers as they staged their 66th annual parade up Broad Street today in their traditional salute to the New Year.

Sandy Koufax, the athlete of the year and the major leaguer most in demand next month, will be the guest of honor at the sixth annual Levittown-Island Trees Youth Council sports night to be held before 1,100 youngsters and parents at Island Trees High School, Levittown. L.I.
WE hadn't seen Dr. Flabbergast for quite some time. So a few days ago we dropped into his studio, to pay him our annual visit.

The special mediation panel in the transit strike met separately with both sides yesterday but adjourned their work at 6:30 P.M. without any report of progress. Further talks were scheduled for 10 A.M. today.
The Phillips Petroleum Company has announced that it has acquired an interest of 1.3 million acres of oil prospecting licenses in the Niger River Delta of Nigeria.

"A BEWILDERMENT of birds" is what John Williams, who assembled and wrote the "Field Guide to the Birds of Central and East Africa," wished us when he inscribed the flyleaf of our copy over lunch the day we arrived in Nairobi. I thought it charming hyperbole, but I was quite wrong. If anything, it was an understatement.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Jan. 1 The engagement of Miss Martha Girdler Beattie to Donald Bruce Nicholson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Nicholson of Wilmington, Del., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Beattie Jr.

Powerboat racing's biggest drawing cards the unlimited hydroplanes appear to be in a bit of hot water on two coasts.
TOKYO, Jan. 1 (AP) President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam urged the Vietcong in a New Year's message today to continue the fight against the United States.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 Gov. and Mrs. Rockefeller today welcomed several hundred Albany residents to the Executive Mansion for the traditional New Year's reception. Outside, eight pickets carried placards urging support of the drive to liberalize the state's divorce law.

HOLLYWOOD. MARTIN RITT is a tough-minded, unconventional man from whom Holly- wood has learned to expect tough-minded, unconventional pictures. NEW HAVEN, Jan. 1 A major redevelopment project for the downtown section of this city is in the final stages of planning, Mayor Richard C. Lee has announced.

Eggs, milk, coal, wool, shoes, rubber and fertilizer don't have much in common at first thought. However, along with a host of other commodities, they make up the Government's wholesale price index.

St. John's University and a substantial part of the faculty last week seemed to move toward head-on collision a professors' strike. The action, set for tomorrow, was called by the United Federation of College Teachers, an affiliate of the AFL-CIO, in protest against the firing of 31 faculty members, including three priests, and against what the disenchanted faculty members called a regime of extreme paternalism and abridgment of academic freedom.

MONTREAL, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press) G.R. McGregor, president of Air Canada, said in his year-end message this week that the airline achieved record traffic and revenues in 1965 and he believed it would record another profit its 12th in 15 years.
PARIS, Jan. 1 Vincent Auriol, President of France from 1947 to 1954, died today in a hospital at the age of 81.

The University of California, Los Angeles, posted a 14-12 victory yesterday over Michigan State, the No. 1 team in the country, at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif. The Spartans scored with 31 seconds remaining but a try for a two-point conversion failed.

The New Yo rk Pro Musica's big 12th-century hit, "The Play of Daniel," has become an annual tradition at St. George's Episcopal Church in Stuyvesant Square. TENAFLY, N.J., Jan. 1 Mrs. W. Kuenlen has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Amy Georgine Kuenlen, to Charles Letson Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Smith of Wyckoff.

LAST summer there appeared in these pages a series of three articles discussing the problems artists have in finding galleries to exhibit their work. In all of them, the artist's position was described as pitiable, but a postscript now seems necessary on an unexpected subject: the silly pigheadedness of some artists who don't recognize a break when they see one.

Strong ordinances prohibiting junk automobiles in yards, driveways and streets as a means of fighting neighborhood blight in the nation's cities are urged by an official of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 1 (UPI) Genevieve Blatt, Secretary of Internal Affairs and the first woman to hold a Pennsylvania state elective office, announced today she was available for the Democratic nomination for governor.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 1 Dr. and Mrs. Saul Freedman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Marian Freedman, to Paul Tigar Cohen of Fort Lee, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Cohen of Schenectady.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 Trinity Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Thomas Gwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Gwin of Jamaica Plain, to Eliot Noble Vestner Jr. He is the son of Lieutenant Colonel Vestner, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Vestner of Freedom, N.H.

NEW DELHI capital of the modern India that sprang almost parthenogenetically from the British Raj, is the scene of this novel by an author who has already shown that, despite Kipling's over-quoted lines, East and West can and do meet.
The director-counsel of the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., said yesterday that the task of civil rights lawyers in the South would become "increasingly difficult in 1966."
The Kosciuszko Foundation will mark its 40th anniversary at its 32d annual ball on Jan. 22 at the Waldorf-Astoria.
ALTHOUGH the collecting of coins of European countries by date-andmint series is currently in the spotlight, modern English coins have been popularly collected that way for some time.
STAMPS commemorating the New Year have been issued by Japan, the Ryukyu Islands and the Soviet Union, a custom that started some years ago.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) Terry's Secret got off to a good start, held back, then came on strong around the turn to win the $30,200 Malibu Stakes today at Santa Anita Park.

A manuscript that may be the original draft of Sir Thomas Malory's "Morte d'Arthur," printed in the 15th century, has been discovered by John Steinbeck, the author, at Alnwick castle in Northumberland, England.
ROVANIEMI, Finland, Jan. 1 (AP) The growth of dynamos and construction machinery is transforming Lapland.

The Soviet Union is preparing to double its radio broadcasting potential on its Central Asian frontier with China, reinforcing Moscow's Capacity to reach across the border into China's western-most province, Sinkiang, with its version of developments at home and abroad.
Despite Michael J. Quill's biannual threats of a transit strike, until yesterday his Transport Workers Union had never actually struck here since its founding in 1934.
The over-the-counter market continued to move lower last week in moderate trading.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 The Government's monetary and fiscal policy in 1966 "will be appropriate to encourage price stability," Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor said today.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Free of Christchurch, N.Z., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Isabel Free, to Timothy George Gates, who is with Firestone International in Christchurch. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Gates of Manchester, Mass.

Miss Ellen Jane Silverman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Silverman of Belle Harbor, Queens, was married last evening to Richard Nassberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Nassberg of New York. Rabbi Joseph I. Weiss performed the ceremony at the Plaza.
Jack Kemp, the Buffalo Bills' quarterback who was acquired for the $100 waiver price in 1962, was voted the American Football League's player of the year yesterday by United Press International.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 1 From out of the West comes Bob Farrington, the so-called cheese champion, with a string of second-rate horses. Prince of the platers, this Ohio farmer is the harness driver whom they say dodged the Big Apple because he knew the big boys would get him.
MOSCOW, Jan. 1 A Soviet Sunday newspaper called today for public distribution of underground ballads composed, written and performed by guitarplaying Moscow youths.
EAST LONDON, South Africa, Jan. 1 (UPI) A broken rubber injector belt in the gearbox deprived Jack Brabham of Australia of victory today in the 12th South African Grand Prix auto race.
New Yorkers seeking information on the effects of the transit strike may telephone 999-1234 to hear a recorded summary of the latest information, or 244-9400 to have specific questions answered.
Anything a modern conventional merchant ship can do, a modern nuclear-powered merchant vessel can do better, an expert on commercial ship operations said yesterday.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 1 A leading electronics engineer has devised an antenna system that he believes could detect the television emissions of a civilization like our own out to a distance of 200 light-years.
BALTLIMORE (AP) The Maryland Racing Commission approved recently a 1966 racing schedule that included split meeting for Bowie and Pimlico.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 1 Mr. and Mrs. W. Mack Abbott have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann Abbott, to Eric Barton Meyers. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Earnest S. Meyers of Searsdale.
BOSTON, Jan. 1 The final steps were completed here this week in setting up a communications system between the medical profession and manufacturers of medical instrumentation.

THE Indians are said to have eaten 24 kinds of flowers raw and to have broiled or fried at least a score of others. Today's list of edible flowers rivals theirs, although some of our more delectable delicacies hide under the guise of vegetables or herbs.

SAMMY'S party broke up at 4 A.M. and when the cast and crew showed up at the studio a few hours later, they yawned and stretched. Sammy's secretary kept on her dark glasses and whispered into the phone: "Jay, Jay, Jay, please don't scream, it's too early in the morning..." and Sammy's driver sighed and mumbled that he needed sleep. Perhaps the only member of the entourage who wasn't drowsy or worn out was Sammy.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 1 (UPI) Butler shot 55 per cent from the field and led all the way tonight to defeat Yale, 75-67, for its fifth straight victory.
BANGUI, Central African Republic, Jan. 1 Col. Jean Bedel Bokassa, chief of staff of the Central African Republic's army, seized power and ousted President David Dacko early today.
HARTFORD, Jan. 1 Dr. Frederick Landis Gwynn, chairman of the English department of Trinity College, died of a heart attack yesterday in Rutland, Vt., while on a skiing weekend. His age was 49.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Jan. 1 Mr. and Mrs. William Sorey Hazelton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Ellen Hazelton, to Winston Nichols Block Jr., son of Mrs. Block of Lousiville, Ky., and the late Dr. Bloch.
MALCOLM FRAGER and Vladimir Ashkenazy are giving a two-piano recital on Jan. 14 at Carnegie Hall, but do them a favor: Don't call them a "team."
Airline pilots, once coming in a steady flow from the military, are now in short supply. The shortage, in fact, is becoming critical among many of the nation's airlines.
New Yorkers who hadn't ridden bicycles since they were wheel-high to a crosstown bus were busy trying to rent them yesterday.

THE burning of draft cards, the organized campaigns to encour age draft dodging and other recent demonstrations against military conscription have been directed primarily against the Government's policies in Vietnam rather than the draft itself. To recognise that, however, is not to ignore the almost universal dissatisfaction with the Universal Military Training and Service Act. Not surprisingly, as some of our youth go to war and others do not, serious moral issues have been raised.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1 St. John's Episcopal Church was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Edith Lynn White, daughter of Mrs. Harwood White of Lloyd Harbor here and John Chester White Jr. of New York, to Charles Hornisher. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles John Hornisher of Tuscon, Ariz.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 The American Red Cross spent $108,081,320 on its services in the year ended June 30, one of the busiest years in the organization's postwar history, according to the annual report published today.
Traffic in the city is light this morning, as might be expected. Many New Yorkers are still resting after their New Year's Eve celebrations, but we expect traffic to get heavier as the day goes on.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan, 1 Motorists traveling the big boulevards that fan out from downtown Buenos Aires passed the time this holiday season counting the cars wrapped around curbside trees and traffic-light stanchions.

An unusual $8-million construction project in which university needs will be blended with an attempt to attract industry to the St. Joseph Valley will be started next spring by the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind.
TOKYO, Dec. 31 (Reuters) The Japanese government has decided to open a vigorous campaign to stop the spread of venereal disease, especially among the young.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 1 The engagement of Miss Nancy Harris Hornaday to William Alexander McGibbon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund L. McGibbon of Barrington Hills, Ill., has been announced by her stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Judson S. Corbin.
Joe Lapchick thinks it's "intriguing," but it will have to be "sold."
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1, (AP) Fifth-seeded Zan Guerry of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., defeated Steve Faulk of New Orleans, 6-0, 6-4, in the final of the Sugar Bowl Junior tennis tourney yesterday.

PEKING, Jan. 1 (Reuters) The State Department's action leasing passport restrictions on travel to Communist China and four other countries is "nauseating hypocrisy," Jenmin Jih Pao, the Communist party newspaper, said today.

NEW HOPE, Pa., Jan. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Lefferts Hutton of New Hope and New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Ranson Hutton, to Specialist Frederick R. Sayen Sayen 2d of the Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Sayen 3d of Princeton, N.J.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 1 Miss Carol Park Armstrong and Roy Conrad Haberkern 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haberkern Jr. of Garden City, L.I., plan to marry in June.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1 (UPI) Joe Caldwell sank a basket with three seconds left to give the St. Louis Hawks a 100-98 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.

THE world's greatest bridge team is breaking up. The Blue Team of Italy, which since 1956 has won eight world team titles, will fight its last battles in the 1966 world championship at St. Vincent, Italy.

TORONTO, Jan. 1(AP) Brit Selby and George Armstrong each scored twice tonight to lead Toronto to a 6-3 victory over the Boston Bruins, extending the Maple Leafs' unbeaten string to 10 games and moving them into third place in the National Hockey League.

Harold Johnson, the 37-yearold former world light-heavyweight champion from Manayunk, Pa., will make his first start in Madison Square Garden in eight years when he meets Johnny Persol in the 10-round feature bout Friday night.

MIDDLEVILLE, Mich., Jan. 1 (AP) Margaretha Andren fits right into the image of tall blondes from Sweden who upset strong men no end on this side of the Atlantic. But she does not exact her dominance with charm alone, but more so with skill in athletics.

THE big question in New York City politics a few months ago was whether John Lindsay could repeat Fiorello La Guardia's electoral miracle of 1933, and now that the answer is in, people are asking whether the new Mayor will take over as commandingly as did his celebrated predecessor 32 years ago.
TOKYO, Jan. 1 (AP) Cambodia accused Thailand today of "armed aggression" against a border post yesterday and on Thursday, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Stuart C. Henry have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Washburn Henry, to Samuel Henry Clarke, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Giesler Clarke of Northampton and Ashfield.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 The Johnson Administration and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation were at a stand-off tonight after a hurriedly called and apparently fruitless conference on the company's plan for a selective price increase.
HOLDEN, Mass., Jan. 1 Miss Maxine M. Forkey and W. Gillette Bird Jr., son of Mrs. Raymond Blanchet of Summit, N.J., and the late W. Gillette Bird of New York, plan to be married in the spring.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Jan. 1 A group of Hebrew University scholars is building an experimental literary bridge between Arabs and Jews by translating the writings of each into the language of the other.
NEWARK, Jan. 1 Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced plans today for a new state agency to help New Jersey's cities solve the problems of modern society.

FOR a low, medium or even a high hedge, nothing is more practical, and handsome, than Canadian hemlock. This fast-growing evergreen adapts to any type of soil. Its own clippings tend to acidify the ground where its roots penetrate. Drought or flood seem to make no difference in its growth.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 1 Dr. Mrs. Louis H. Nahum have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Teresa Nahum, to Dr. Emanuel Rice, His parents are Mrs. Samuel Rice of New York and the late Mr. Rice.

THE New Year is a time for a particular form of stock-taking in television. Not only are there the normal reflections on the preceding 12 months but the shape of next season must be determined in the immediate weeks ahead. With the completion of the holiday recess, the selling of new shows for next September gets into full swing.
MONTREAL, Jan. 1 (AP) Henri Richard scored two goals and assisted on one tonight as the Montreal Canadiens routed the New York Rangers, 5-1, in a National Hockey League game.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP) Gordon Milne's goal with two minutes to play gave Liverpool's leading team a 2-1 victory over Manchester United today in the English Soccer League.

A $6.5-million urban renewal project now getting under way in Newport, R.I., has been designed to rejuvenate a part of the city's downtown section without doing esthetic injury to an adjoining area that contains many historic buildings.
OTTAWA, Jan. 1 A beautifully white Christmas across Canada raised anew the old question about winter here. Is it a bogy or a boon?
BRUSSELS, Jan. 1 When the big hand of the clock moved Europe into 1966 this morning, it propelled the Common Market into its third and last transitional stage.
DETROIT, Dec. 30 Ten years ago, the Ford Motor Company opened a major advertising campaign to promote the safety features of its new automobiles.

PARIS, Jan. 1 "The situation of the political parties [in 1966]," wrote a Figaro pundit this week, "will be what it has been since the death of Louis XVI...regroupments, favored by dissidence, and new scissions provoked by the regroupments."

SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 1 The engagement of Miss Joan Norma Hayes to Christopher Royer Donoho Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Donoho of Newark, Del., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Hayes, parents of the bride-to-be.
The last train to move on New York's subway system yesterday was an IRT Seventh Avenue express.
Five years ago, the use of metal studs on tires to help a car grip the road would have been classed as a gimmick from an Ian Fleming novel.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 1 (UPI) Thousands of residents of the south Phoenix area, ravaged by floods when water was deliberately released from six overflowing reservoirs, returned to their homes early today.
More and more cereal cargoes are now being carried by ships that are at least twice as large as the 10,000-ton dry-cargo tramp vessel, which was standard a decade ago.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 1 School-teachers, expert swimmers and nature lovers from the metropolitan area are already applying to the Chief Federal Ranger of Fire Island for jobs next summer at the nation's newest seashore playground.

THE Concord Hotel, Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., will be the scene this week of the largest annual nursery industry convention in the country when more than 1,800 exhibitors, nurse rymen, growers and retailers attend the Garden Living Industries of the Eastern United States Convention and Trade Exposition tomorrow through Thursday. Theme of this year's convention is "Your Opportunity...A More Beautiful America." Speakers will discuss the theme from the standpoint of merchandising and landscaping.
Despite a continuing building boom that produced 10 more major office buildings in 1965, there is a shortage of new office space in Manhattan that will last until 1967, a new survey shows.
CAIRO, Jan. 1 Egyptian archeologists have discovered the tombs of two court officials from the Fifth Dynasty, which promise to shed more light on daily life 4,500 years ago.
DENVER, Jan. 1 (AP) Sixteen men and 12 women were named by Coach Bob Beattie today to the United States 1966 national Alpine teams.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 The South is short-changing itself and its poor in the national campaign against poverty.
The construction of 1,500 widely diversified housing units on a 500-acre tract of hills on the island of St. Croix has been given final approval by the Virgin Islands Planning Board.

The third and final performance of the Hanukkah Festival for Israel will be staged by the Israel Bond Organization tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden. A special feature will be an address by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay after being sworn in as Mayor.

NEWPORT, N.Y., Jan. 1- Dr. and Mrs. Timothy J. Howard have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Nora Parker Howard, to Edward James Snyder. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Snyder. A spring wedding is planned.

HARTFORD, Jan. 1 Mr. and Mrs. John Peter McDonnell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Taylor McDonnell, to Orval Warren Jones Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Pittsford, N.Y.

BOUDA, Algeria This country's newest tour ist attraction is one that few other nations have a "miraculous spring." It is situated here at Bouda, a tiny Sahara oasis 550 miles due south of the Mediterranean Sea and at the edge of the Erg Chech, a vast ocean of sand that stretches across western Algeria into Mali and Morocco.

OF the six light-hearted disks that could brighten up the New Year festivities, Woody Allen, Vol- ume 2 leads the rest by alphabetical precedence and the superiority of his material especially the latter (Colpix 488). Mr. Allen has created a timid, long-suffering character trying to survive in a world of disasters. His childhood was one long obstacle race; his maturity is no better.

THE British team that created "Darling" and thereby won The New York Film Critics' awards for the best picture, actress and director of 1965 last week, will now try to do the same for Thomas Hardy and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

BETWEEN Dec. 1, 1942, and Nov. 15, 1945, the U.S. Army Air Corps lifted over three-quarters of a million tons of cargo, much of it inflammable highoctane gasoline and explosive ammunition, and thousands of soldiers between the Assam Valley where India, Burma and Tibet nudge together at the foot of the Himalayas and China's mile-high Yunnan Province.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 Starting today, all cigarette packages that come off the factory production lines must carry the warning that smoking is or rather "may be" hazardous to health. There is no reason, however, to believe that the warning will have any effect on the smoking habits of the nation.

Edmund Quincy Moses, a patent lawyer here for 60 years and senior partner of Moses, McGlew Toren at 28 West 44th St., died on Friday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived on Illington Road in Ossining, N.Y.

The engagement of Miss Joan Helen Coulborn and James Harris Stevens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Stevens of Philadelphia, has been announced here. The future bride is the daughter of Dr. Rushton Coulborn of Kyoto, Japan, formerly of Atlanta, and the late Mrs. Helen McIntosh Coulborn.
MIAMI, Jan. 1 Ogden Mills Phipps's Time Tested defeated six strong rivals today to win the second division of the New Year's Handicap at Tropical Park.
SARASOTA, Fla. Tourists who know this Gulf Coast City, and who are returning here this winter, will find that many changes have occurred in town and on the offshore keys.

NEWARK, Jan. 1 An Oriental party in the Terrace Room of Symphony Hall on Wednesday will follow the opening-night performance there by the Metropolitan Opera National Company of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly." The company is giving eight performances of operas through Saturday.

A comparison of season records for the Green Bay Packers and Cleveland Browns, opponents in today's National Football League championship game. Last Sunday's Western Division playoff game involving the Packers and Baltimore Colts is not included.

YONKERS, Jan. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Eugene E. Hult of Crestwood have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Margaret Sara Hult, to Kenneth W. Watson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel W. Watson of Mamaroneck.

SOL HUROK is going shopping again. Next month the veteran impresario takes off for Europe where he will involve himself in all the accustomed intricacies of international trade as he seeks an assortment of talent with which to please his varied clientele here and across the Hudson.

JEROME, Ariz. This state is dotted with abandoned cowtowns and mining camps, only a handful of which have survived on Arizona maps. As ghost towns, they rarely attract visitors, and then only a few diligent collectors of antiques and those hardy sightseers who enjoy poking around in the sagging remnants of a once-colorful era.

HAMDEN, Conn., Jan. 1 Dr. Clyde H. Hill, professor emeritus and former chairman of the Yale University graduate department of education, died yesterday in his home at 105 Mill Rock Road after a long illness. His age was 80.
The city's schools, businesses, government agencies and private citizens made plans yesterday to cope with the transit strike should it continue into the start of the business week tomorrow.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 Stubby Joe LaBruzzo's slicing runs and a rock-ribbed middle-of-the-line defense anchored on Bill Bass carried Louisiana State to a 14-7 upset of Arkansas today in the 30th annual Cotton Bowl football game. The loss was Arkansas' first after 22 straight victories.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 1 Prof. Yigael Yadin, Israel's leading archeologist, announced tonight the acquisition of a fragment of a Dead Sea scroll containing portions of the Psalms.
THINGS that are pretty sure of happening in the automobile sports field in 1966:
The head of a union representing 6,000 Welfare Department case workers yesterday demanded a meeting with Mayor Lindsay to discuss what he said was the city's failure to implement its labor contract.

IN mid-1964 Mihajlo Mihajlov, a 30-year old Yugoslav teacher of Russian origin, visited the Soviet Union as an exchange scholar. From this innocuous event, as many Western readers are now aware, came another one of those political-literary tempests to which the Communist world is prone.
Fred R. Sullivan, president of Walter Kidde Co., Inc., has just made his company's 15th acquisition since he assumed his present post on Jan. 7, 1964.
The American Power Boat Association, the governing body for powerboat racing in the United States, has named the dates and sites for two of its major 1966 championship regattas.
