COOPER CLIFF, Ont., Jan. 1 (UPI) Free-world nickel consumption rose last year by 60 million pounds to a record of 730 million pounds, according to the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.
BONN, Jan. 1 A popular program of political satire has become the first victim of political censorship in West German television.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 1 (AP) Maj. Gen. George Gelston, who directed peace-keeping efforts during long months of ramial disquiet in Cambridge, Md., in 1963 and 1964, was named today as the state's Adjutant General.

The Shields Class of 30-foot fiberglass keel sloops took an important stride forward last week with the establishment of a 13-boat fleet at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L.I., With additions to existing fleets at other clubs expected before next season begins, the class will be strong on Long Island Sound.
ROME, Jan. 1 Pope Paul VI made public today New Year's appeals to the chiefs of state of the Soviet Union and Communist China to intervene for peace in Vietnam.

The development of a drug that appears to offer the first safe and effective treatment of a cruel disease that afflicts hundreds of millions of persons throughout the world has been reported by CIBA, Ltd., of Basle, Switzerland.

Pinpoint navigation that led to the rescue of an airplane pilot who had ditched in the South Atlantic was recognized last week by the American Merchant Marine Institute and the Marine Section of the National Safety Council.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 1 A Princeton University lecture fund has been established in honor of Dr. Americo Castro, professor emeritus of Spanish, by one of his former students.

Mrs. Irene S. Powers and W. Hayward Powers, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Whitney Powers, to Donald Eugene Harwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. A.R. Harwood of Chatfield, Minn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 Few subjects have produced so many yaws among the public and the politicians and such heated squabbling in recent months among the scientific community as the question of whether to build civil defense shelters to protect Americans against nuclear attack.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 1 (AP) Duke's top-ranked Blue Devils rallied tonight after trailing much of the first half and routed Wake Forest, 92-76, in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

The new Soviet Five-Year Plan for 1966-70 to be unveiled soon will probably show important cutbacks in Soviet 1970 production goals from targets announced earlier, American specialists on the Soviet economy suggested last week.
A condominium development of 224 apartments in "town house"-style structures is nearing completion on a strip of oceanfront sandwiched between two surf clubs at Lido Beach, L.I.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan, 1 (UPI) President and Mrs. Johnson attended a New Year's mass tonight at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Stonewall, Tex., a few miles from the LBJ Ranch.

IN most of the games from the recently completed United States Chess Championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel, middlegame tactics, rather than opening novelties or end-game maneuverings, were the compulsive, deciding factors.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 1 Development of the Tennessee River for modern barge navigation has brought vast changes in the two decades that the channel has been in use.
Until Friday, the final day of last year, it appeared that the business and financial world would be content to let 1965, the economy's greatest year expire rather docilely. But that was not to be.

PARIS. ALAIN RESNAIS is com- ing back. It's not that France's far-out director of "Last Year at Marienbad" was away, but since his last film, the mystical "Muriel," confounded critics and The Cahiers du Cinema crowd three years ago, both Resnais and "Muriel" seemingly disappeared. There is no underestimating the influence of foreign cuisine on American taste during the last decade or so. It is probably not coincidence that the three recipes that held the greatest appeal for our readers in 1965 were for a French lamb stew called navarin d'agneau, Russian pastries made with a cream cheese dough and a Spanish paella. One or another version of paella has been among the most requested recipes for several years.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 3 The European Economic and Atomic Energy Communities started the new year without 1966 budgets but also without any noticeable limp.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The United States has decided to renew its aid program to Algeria after having allowed it, in effect, to lapse during the last six months.
Walter Nirenberg has been elected president of M. Nirenberg Sons, Inc., men's shirt producer, succeeding his father, Arthur Nirenberg, who is retiring.

MIAMI., Jan. 3 President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado of Cuba opened a conference of Asian, African and Latin-American Communist and pro-Communist parties tonight with a strong endorsement of armed struggle as the only means to end the undevelopment of nations.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) Each team in the Gator Bowl football game Friday will collect about $161,000, bowl officials said today. The sum is a record because the stadium was enlarged to 60,000 seats after last year's game.

The Municipal Broadcasting System has been kept busy transmitting strike information and interviews to 24 commercial radio and six commercial television stations in addition to running the city-owned stations WNYC, WNYC-FM and WNYC TV.

The New York Legislature convenes tomorrow amid many uncertainties, heightened by the fact that it is a house divided. Last year, for the first time in three decades, both chambers were controlled by the Democrats; this year the Senate is Republican and the Assembly Democratic.
Henry James Forman, an author, editor and book reviewer, died yesterday at French Hospital. He was 886 years old and lived at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
KENOSHA, Wis., Jan. 3 (UPI) The American Motors Corporation resumed today production in its assembly division here after calling back 3,200 workers laid off last month for a three-week shutdown.
Price changes, both up and down, were announced yesterday for a variety of items, taking in tea, orange juice and technical fiber.

MOSCOW, Jan. 3 (Reuters) The Soviet Union expelled today the West German Fmbassy's First Secretary, three months after he was accused of spreading anti-Soviet propaganda and collecting information for the Roman Catholic organization Opus Dei.

A 26-year-old former Playboy bunny and dancer in the Copacabana nightclub chorus line was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon to five years in prison for attempting to bribe a juror in a mutimillion-dollar narcotics case.
The start of construction on the first of five high-speed automated cargo ships for American President Lines was announced yesterday by the Ingails Shipbuilding division of Litton Industries.

GROSSE POINTE, Mich., Jan. 3 Miss Suzanne Chapin, daughter of John C. Chapin of Washington and Mrs. Deacon Chapin of Grosse Pointe, was married today to Charles Christopher Trowbridge Wilkins. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross Wilkins Jr., of Grosse Pointe.
H. Wendell Chapman was named yesterday as president of American Steel Foundries, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Amsted Industries, Inc.
LONDON, Jan. 3 An increase in Zambia's copper prices was announced here today following similar price moves in the Congo (Leopoldville) and in Chile.
Uncertainty permeated trading in the stock market in its first session of 1966.
The arts and show business were generally listless yesterday.
ANYTHING, well, almost anything, that anyone could want to know about the art, craft and cult of Dance is to be found in the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (UPI) A report that Japanese fisherman landed in the New World in 3000 B.C. or before is "just as moonstruck as the claim that Japan did not bomb Pearl Harbor," State Supreme Court Justice Michael A. Musmanno said today.
Production of steel in the United States set a record in 1965, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Amid the flare-up over price increases for structural steels, a pointed reminder was offered yesterday that there are two sides to the coin.

PARIS, Jan. 3 Lieut. Col Lamizana Sangoule, army chief in Upper Volta, declared tonight that the army was "assuming its responsibilities" following street demonstrations against President Maurice Yameogo, the French news agency reported.
The subway and bus strike dealt a harsh blow to the city's economy yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey said today that the Selective Service System might begin drafting college students in its search for manpower.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 3 The Iraqi Defense Minister said in an interview published today that, although his country wants good relations with neighboring Iran, "our patience has a limit."
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner was driving his wife and two sons in a white jeep yesterday morning down the main thoroughfare under a brilliant, tropical sun in Acapulco, Mexico.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Vice President Humphrey said today that he had found no indication on his Asian tour that the enemy might be willing to negotiate a peaceful settlement of the war in Vietnam.
The highest corporate profit for any 12-month period in the history of United States business was announced yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Appointments of new partners and senior excecutives were announced yesterday by several Wall Street investment companies.
The Community Council of Greater New York will receive $247,715 in state and Federal antipoverty funds to help the elderly poor, the council announced yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 Shells from United States artillery fell among American paratroopers operating west of Saigon this morning, killing or wounding a number of them.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 3 Come Quill or high water, the wheels rolled at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. A crowd of 24,167 persons, apparently undisturbed by the New York transit strike, turned out for the opening of the harness-racing season. It was the earliest start for horse racing, either harness or thoroughbred, in the history of New York State.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 Former Lieut. Gov. Francis X. Bellotti joined today the Democratic rush to stake claim to the nomination for Massachusetts Attorney General. He was immediately scored for "callous irresponsibility" by another aspirant.
NEWARK, Jan. 3 The Sheriff's Office raided a hobby shop in the exclusive Forest Hill section tonight and confiscated several thousand allegedly obscene slides, negatives and pictures.
TRENTON, Jan. 3, AP The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled today that a real estate broker could sue another broker for malicious interference in the sale of a piece of property.

The Community Blood Council of Greater New York has asked all hospitals in the area to permit it to coordinate all appeals for blood during the transit strike emergency. The council will operate its central inventory service on a 24-hour basis to expedite full use of blood on hand.
CONCORD. N.H., Jan. 3 (UPI) The Boston Maine Railroad announced today that it will discontinue all remaining passenger service between Boston and points in New Hampshire on Feb. 7.
BUFFALO, Jan. 3 (AP) Joel Collier loomed today as a favorite to succeed Lou Saban as coach of the Bills.
Plans for expansion of capital facilities were announced by several large concerns yesterday. The advances were heavy in the paper and pulp field.

The citywide transit strike put a crimp in the operations of New York's fashion industry yesterday. However, on the first business day since the strike began, the initial effect was more irksome than a deterrent, as widespread absenteeism worried employers.

Roy Wilkins reported yesterday a decline in membership and funds for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the 57-year old pioneer civil rights organization in the United States.

CAIRO, Jan. 3 The United States signed a new $55-million aid agreement with the United Arab Republic today. It was the first major accord since relations between Cairo and Washington became strained last winter.
Several of the most powerful labor leaders in the state came out yesterday in support of the strike by the Transport Workers Union here.

VLADIMIR DUDINTSEV, a controversial figure in the contemporary onestep-forward, two-steps back, Russian literary scene, "does not resemble the portrait in the Serbo-Croatian edition of his novel." Our authority? Today's new book.

Mrs. Charles P. Noyes of New York and Amory Bradford of Aspen, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carola Bradford to Sydney Longstreth Wright Lea Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lea of Chestnut Hill in Philadelphia.
Drivers are urged not to bring cars into the congested parts of the city unless absolutely necessary. Those who do drive are urged to carry as many passengers as possible.

BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Jan. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Norman J. Fredericks have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcia Ann Fredericks, to Edward J. McGratty 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McGratty Jr. of Birmingham, formerly of New York. A summer wedding is planned.
LISBON, Jan. 3 Portugal will keep facilities in Mozambique open to oil and other traffic for Rhodesia despite increasing international pressures, high Government sources disclosed today.

ROME, Jan 3 The giant Fiat industrial complex, ending a record breaking year in production and sales, looked forward today to 1966 with "a better outlook" and "extra confidence that automotive sales in Italy and abroad will expand."
Directors of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, meeting yesterday in Chicago, approved an increase in the company's quarterly dividend to 30 cents a common share from 25 cents in preceding quarters.
Millions of New Yorkers and suburbanites got up early yesterday, stared in their mirrors and searched for something "essential." Many of them shrugged and went back to bed.
From a helicopter above Manhattan yesterday morning, Mayor Lindsay radioed:
LONDON, Jan. 3 (Reuters) Britain's fashion invasion of American wholesale markets was only $66,000 short of its million-dollar target.
Public schools in New York City will reopen today after oneday extensions of the Christmas holidays, but most parochial high schools and many colleges will remain closed.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 The Democratic and Republican state chairmen are exploring a bipartisan approach on legislative reapportionment.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) Directors of the British Diners' Club and a London brokerage firm have asked the Stock Exchange Council to investigate share deals during a recent takeover battle for the company.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 3 The Government announced today changes in Zambia's tariff structure that will have the effect of raising duties slightly on British products while reducing them on other foreign goods.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Officials of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare were accused by the American Civil Liberties Union today of dissembling, in saying they were bound by law to require a disclaimer of Communist affiliation from certain applicants under the Medicare program.

AN American pick-up basketball team, formed in much the same manner as any school-yard five in New York City, is sweeping the opposition in and around London these days. But unlike many school-yard teams, this one has good reason to be undefeated in 15 games.
DUBLIN, Jan. 3 Trawlers from the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland clashed at sea today.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 3 (UPI) The traditional LatinAmerican siesta become illegal in Chile today.

THE contretemps over the city's underground has pro- duced an unusual personality clash on the television screen. The viewer could not wish for two more disparate leading players than Mayor Lindsay as the handsome young man making his bow in the big time and the veteran Michael J. Quill dancing unionism's most spectacular labor jig.
The National Guard provided cots for hundreds of persons who were stranded in the transit strike last night.

Traders and executives of bond houses decided they were essential and reported for work in Wall Street yesterday, but many messengers and back-office workers stayed home. The result: little trading and few price changes:

While the compilers of statistics were compiling their statistics yesterday on the economic impact of the transit strike, one advertiser was bemoaning a statistic of its own a strike-out. And it was the first time at bat, too.

At 9:35 yesterday morning, a slim young man in dark slacks and a black sweater stepped in front of the orchestra seated on the stage of Carnegie Hall, lifted his baton and gave the beat that set the orchestra to playing Brahms's Symphony No. 1. He was Candidate No. 1 of about 35 in the 1966 Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition for Conductors.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 3 Palmer D. Farrington, former presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, went on trial in County Court here today on a charge of taking an unlawful fee of $11,000.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 3 Robert C. Henry was elected Mayor here tonight, becoming the first Negro to serve in the top municipal post in an Ohio city. Springfield has a population of 85,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 What is the mature adult response to a ringing telephone? This question is raised by the case of a man named Cardoza who, according to the press, went berserk in his home the other day and wrecked his new Christmas phonograph, smashed a fourrecord set of "Tristan and Isolde" and was visited by the police after using foul language over the telephone to a 15-yearold child named Carol.
The $10-million hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, air-conditioned throughout its 12 stories, opened in the Bronx yesterday.

The Police Department has designated the following areas in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn as places where persons who have arranged car pools may pick up and discharge their passengers. Parking will not be permitted in these areas.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 3 Last August, before the National Football League season began, Vince Lombardi regarded his Green Bay Packers as a team in transition. Coach Lombardi was slowly replacing age with youth, especially on his offensive unit, and he believed the Packers.
Ten thousand of the Transport Workers Union's 36,000 members picketed 59 key subway and bus locations throughout the city yesterday.

The Public Service Commission asked 72 electric power companies throughout the state yesterday what they had done to prevent a power failure like the one that crippled most of the Northeast last Nov. 9.

The Transit Authority is seriously concerned about making a martyr of Michael J. Quill if he is imprisoned for civil contempt for defying an antistrike injunction. City Corporation Council J. Lee Rankin said last night.
Most people who work on Wall Street made it to their desks despite the transit strike yesterday, thanks to an adroit combination of shoe leather, bicycles, car pools, rented cars and chartered buses.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 George Christopher today challenged Ronald Reagan, the actor, to face him in a debate on the issues of their campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor.

Sears, Roebuck Co. has leased 6,500 square feet of space in the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center in Garden City, L.I., for one of the chain's new telephone-order centers. The fiveyear lease for 5,000 square feet of mall-level space and 1,500 square feet of basement space was negotiated by Feist Feist, the shopping center's managing agents.
HAWTHORNE, N.Y., Jan. 3 Lift the folksy label on Aunt Millie's spaghetti sauces and what do you find?
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 3 (AP) A $100,000 suit filled against the Internal Revenue Service by George Lincoln Rockwell, head of the American Nazi party, was dismissed today in Federal District Court.

The Marquesa de Cuevas, a granddaughter of John D. Rockefeller Sr., who a year ago bought three Pyne-Davison landmark mansions at Park Avenue and 68th Street to save them from demolition, is giving one to the Center for InterAmerican Relations, a new organization.
TORONTO, Jan. 3 Mitchell Sharp, Canada's new Finance Minister, declared today that access to the United States capital market was of "vital importance" to finance Canada's large trade deficit.
The London Stock market opened the new year on a quiet note yesterday. Trading was slow and prices edged off after a promising start.
Michael J. Quill and eight other leaders of the striking transit workers were ordered last night to end the city's, subway and bus walkout by 11 A.M. today or go to jail.
HOUSTON, Jan. 3 (AP) Joe Namath, the New York Jets' rookie quarterback, and 13 other American Football League players were named today to the All-Star squad by Coach Sid Gilman.
Two large steel companies joined the Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday in its defiance of the Johnson Administration over prices.

IRA BRALL, who died in Florida on Sunday while vacationing, was a prominent figure in New York bridge for more than 30 years. In the thirties he was not only a leading player but also the proprietor of a successful club. In his later years when business was more important to him than bridge he continued to play enthusiastically and won a major championship, the Eastern Mixed Teams, in 1955.
A Deputy Buildings Commissioner and two assistant commissioners, all under 30 years old, were sworn in yesterday to assist the city's new 31-year-old Buildings Commissioner, Charles G. Moerdler.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Jan. 3 Dr Ernest Hatch Wilkins, president emeritus of Oberlin College, a leading American authority on Italian literature and culture, died yesterday in Newton Centre, Mass., where he had lived since his retirement in 1946. He was 85 years old.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 3 Edward Heath, leader of the Conservative Opposition in the British Parliament, proposed today a joint Commonwealth effort to help India handle "massive American food supplies."

Dr. Geneva Penn Holder of 457 West 148th Street, a physician long active in health work in Harlem and on the public health program of the Board of Education, died yesterday at Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia. -Presbyterian Medical Center. Her age was 50.
The J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation and the Schroder Trust Company announced here yesterday the election of John F. Kuemmerle as a vice president.

SEATTLE, Jan. 3 (UPI) A T-38 jet trainer piloted by the commander of the Air Force Flight Test Center at Edwards Air Force Base vanished while coming in for an instrument landing at Boeing Field here during rainy weather today. It was feared he had perished in Puget Sound.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 3 The ambulance was waiting at an open gate in Lambeau Field when the game ended. Attendants tenderly lifted a Green Bay Packer fan, female division, onto a stretcher and carted her off to the hospital to see whether she had broken her ankle or sprained it badly.

Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida a confidant of Presidents Johnson and Kennedy, announced in Miami yesterday that he would retire on doctors' orders when his present term expires in January, 1969.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 3 Fairfield University, held scoreless for the first 5 minutes 3 seconds tonight, went on to defeat Fairleigh Dickinson, 82-65. The Stags did not make their first field goal until 10:52 remained in the first half.

NORTHFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 3 Dr. and Mrs. William E. Mishler of Old Acres have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Therese Mishler, to Lieut. (jg.) James Thomas Griffin, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Griffin of Keswick, Va., and Chicago. A spring wedding is planned.
HAVANA, Jan. 3 (Reuters) --The agenda of the nine-day conference on combatting imperialism, colonialism and neo-colonialism, which opened here today, had a decided anti-United States tone.
TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Jan. 3. The leaders of India and Pakistan arrived here today for an unusual effort to resolve their countries' 18-year-old dispute over Kashmir under Soviet auspices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Despite the political bitterness in Premier Fidel Castro's announcement yesterday that the Chinese Communists had cut their purchases of Cuban sugar, there is a strong likelihood that the Cuban economy will, in fact, profit from the move.
Long Island University swept past St. Michael's, 85-68, last night at the Blackbirds' court in Brooklyn. It was L.I.U.'s ninth victory in 10 games.

A new four-year labor agreement for the 2,000 watchmen and guards on piers and at terminals in the Port of New York has been announced by the New York Shipping Association and the Port Watchmen's Union, Local 1456.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Marguerite Higgins, the columnist and war correspondent who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1951 for her front-line reports from Korea, died today in Walter Reed Army Hospital. She was 45 years old.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) Kerby Farrell, the manager of the Cleveland Indians in 1957 and a first baseman for the Chicago White Sox in 1945, was named a Sox coach today by Manager Eddie Stanky.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) The International Tin Council announced today that the necessary number of tin producing and consuming countries had signed the third international tin agreement before the Dec. 31 deadline.

IBROKE a long-standing rule the other day and picked up a hitchhiker while driving through the White Mountains in New Hampshire near Pinkham's Notch. It was hard to pass him by because he was so distinctively dressed.

With the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads believed nearing final approval, a dissident Pennsylvania stockholder has petitioned the Interestate Commerce Commission to reopen the case.
The 22-foot Camel cigarette smoker blew his last four-foot smoke ring yesterday from the Times Square billboard that has been a landmark for 24 years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The Treasury bill rate rose sharply at today's auction to a peak for the present period of rising interest rates, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Like most of the other 20,600 apartment houses in the Bronx. 2249 Morris Avenue was calmer than usual yesterday morning.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange seemed to have followed Mayor Lindsay's advice concerning the transit dispute and stayed off the street, or in this case the trading block.
Intricate planning paid off yesterday as the city's police force, hospitals and fire department rode out the first working day of the transit strike with no serious breakdown of their operations.

Mrs. M. Reed Foster of Fairfield, Cornn., and Frank Brisbin Foster Jr. of Kimberton, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Carolyn Reed Foster, to Robert Michael McNaught. His parents are Brig. Robert Stephen McNaught, retired, of the British Army, and Mrs. McNaught of Pendell Farm House, Bletchingley, Surrey, England.

GENEVA, Jan. 3 The further tightening of Switzerland's fiscal screws that marked the arrival of the new year may damage an important but unofficial export trade by taking much of the profit out of the cigarette-smugglers' profession.
Courts in Manhattan suffered a dearth of defendants, jurors, stenographers and clerks yesterday because of the transit strike.

The first trading day in the new year for commodities futures brought sharp increases in many prices, although some exchanges here shortened their session because of the transit strike and the New York Cotton Exchange and Wool Associates did not open at all.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 3 (UPI) The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen announced today that it would seek a 25 per cent basic wage increase from 190 railroads, effective Feb. 2.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 3 (UPI) Coach Norm Van Brocklin of the Minnesota Vikings, who quit during a slump last fall but rejoined the National Football League club the next day, agreed today to a new five-year contract at an increase in salary.

Adolph Zukor, retired chairman and still a director of Paramount Pictures Corporation, who celebrates his 93d birthday on Friday, forged a motionpicture empire almost 50 years ago that today is going through the very kind of corporate struggle on which he himself used to thrive. The chances are that he will outlive this battle too.

New Yorkers, who responded so magnificently to the disruption caused by the blackout, demonstrated again yesterday their equanimity in moments of crisis. With subway and bus service cut off by Michael J. Quill's "war" against the city, the people did not panic. They did their duty as citizens by cooperating with Mayor Lindsay in curtailing nonessential travel and observing the other emergency rules he laid down.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 3 Machinery to tap a wealth of citizen talent in Nassau County will be set up in the next two weeks, County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said today.
ROME, Jan. 3 The authoritative Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano said today that Pope Paul VI had exhorted President Johnson to explore every conceivable avenue toward peace in Vietnam.
Just two "bench marks" in the United States Department of Agriculture's annual survey tell the story.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said last night that he would serve as campaign chairman for Theodore R. Kupferman, a Republican City Councilman seeking to succeed Mayor Lindsay as Representative from the 17th Congressional District.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 3 (AP) A petition signed by 25,380 Norwegians was sent today to President Johnson and Gov. John J. McKeithen of Louisiana asking that the case of Edgar Labat be reopened.

Heavy blue fiber glass curtains screen the transit deliberations from prying eyes at the Americana hotel. Security men stand guard outside the room where negotiators sit about green felt-covered tables.
ONE of the nicest exhibitions of chinoiserie to open in Manhattan in many a moon is the new Shun Lee Dy- nasty restaurant at 900 Second Avenue (49th Street).

Picketing of St. John's University, deferred yesterday when classes were suspended because of the subway strike, is scheduled to begin today at 7 A.M., an hour before resumption of classes at the world's largest Roman Catholic university.
NEWTON, Ga., Jan. 3 (AP) Agents of the George Bureau of Investigation and sheriff's officers are investigating the burning of a Negro church near here.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 3 President Hector Garcia-Godoy told the nation tonight that a number of military officers would be sent out of the country to diplomatic posts and on training missions "in the next few hours."

An exhibition of 40 impressionist paintings, lent by collectors here, will be given at the M. Knoedler and Company gallery, 14 East 57th Street for the benefit of the St. Luke's Hospital Center Building Fund.
Mayor Lindsay moved around New York City on foot yesterday morning, but later in the day he switched to the cityowned limousine assigned to him.
The promotion of two highranking passenger traffic executives was announced yesterday by the Matson Navigation Company and American Export Isbrandtsen Lines.
WESTBURY. L.I., Jan. 3 "Why'ja park here? You're out in the wilderness!" screamed a short, heavy woman wearing a short, heavy mink to her shorter, skinnier husband.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Manufacturers' inventories rose by $437-million in November, a larger increase than the average monthly rise for the first 10 months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 3 President Hector Garcia-Godoy told the nation tonight that a number of military officers would be sent out of the country to diplomatic posts and on training missions "in the next few hours."

Fifteen witnesses headed by Governor Rockefeller and the new Queens County District Attorney, Nat H. Hentel, gave strong support yesterday to the principle that the state should indemnify victims of criminal violence.

Mayor Lindsay implied before a cheering and laughing audience of more than 10,000 persons in Madison Square Garden that New York might be having its transit problems but he was pleased to report that the "subway in Haifa [Israel] was still running."

A harrowing travel crush ended the first workday of the transit strike here last night. The city had earlier managed to get through the day as only half the usual number of motor vehicles entered Manhattan.
NEWTON, Ga., Jan. 3 (AP) Agents of the George Bureau of Investigation and sheriff's officers are investigating the burning of a Negro church near here.
TRENTON, Jan. 3 New Jersey moved today to reduce wa- ter pollution in the populous and highly industrialized Raritan River Basin.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The Government moved on four fronts today in its running battle against a price increase for structural steel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (UPI) A suit asking for an impartial test of Krebiozen and the end of the Government's ban in interstate shipments of the alleged cancer drug was filed today on behalf of a retired physician and 10 of his patients.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 3 Prof. Dow V. Baxter of the University of Michigan, an internationally known forest pathologist, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, in Tucson, Ariz. His age was 67.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 3 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach today urged Federal attorneys in the South to take immediate steps to bring about "fair representation" of Negroes on Federal juries and in staff jobs.
The British pound held steady in very quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.8030, unchanged from the Friday level.
The Enjay Chemical Company said yesterday it had acquired the remaining 50 per cent interest in the National Plastic Products Company from J.P. Stevens Co.

Farrell Lines has been authorized by the Maritime Administrator and the Maritime Administration's Maritime Subsidy Board to provide subsidized freight service between Great Lakes ports and ports in West, South and East Africa.

Eight National Basketball Association all-stars will be on display tonight at Madison Square Garden when a regular season double-header matches the Baltimore Bullets against the San Francisco Warriors and, in the second game, the Knickerbockers against the Philadelphia 76ers.
MANORVILLE, L.I., Jan. 3 The body of an attractive blonde, one of her stockings tied tightly around her neck, was found here shortly after noon today in a wooded area off Primrose Path.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission asked today for a court injunction to prevent the merger of two large Chicago dairy companies, Dean Foods Company and Bowman Dairy Company.

After the morning rush ended yesterday there were cabs aplenty around town, but while the rush lasted the public pleaded, screamed, fought and then jampacked cabs, sometimes paying too much for the rides.
The Chesapeake Ohio Railway, in a "flash" annual report, announced yesterday a consolidated-system net income of $65-million for 1965, up from $50-million in 1964.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Jan. 3 The Bryn Mawr College Alumnae clubs of Westchester County and of Fairfield County, Conn., are sponsoring a series of lectures by Bryn Mawr professors. They will be at the Pforzheimer Memorial Building here Jan. 13, 20 and 27, 10:30 A.M, to noon. Coffee will be served at 10 A.M.
OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 3 the inmates of Sing Sing Prison went on strike today, demanding liberalization of state parole regulations. Their was no violence or widespread disorder.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) Roy K. Davenport, a manpower specialist, became today the highest-ranking Negro civilian in the Defense Department.

A 13-year-old Boy Scout who was beaten by a po- liceman in Asheville, N.C., because he helped direct traffic during a roller skating tournament has grown up to become the leader of one of the nation's most influential civil rights organizations.

The Atlantic Refining Company announced yesterday that it had formed five major operating departments and named executives to head these departments following merger consummation with the Richfield Oil Corporation, which became effective Jan. 2. Stockholders of both companies approved the merger on Dec. 30.
"Neighbors," a one-act play by Arkady Leokum about race relations, will be televised from 9 to 10 P.M. Monday by station WNDT (Channel 13).

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that a Federally financed educational television station broadcasting color programs would be established in Boston.

The immediate transit crisis in New York, over how to settle the strike, will be followed by another, demanding even more statesmanship, on how to pay for the wage contract without skyrocketing the fare.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 3 (UPI) Lou Saban was named head football coach at the University of Maryland today, less than 24 hours after he had resigned as coach of the Buffalo Bills, champions of the American Foobtall League.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 3 (AP) The Kennecott Copper Corporation's El Teniente mine, one of the world's largest copper installations, was partially paralyzed today when 3,000 of its 6,500 workers refused to accept a strike postponement.
Max Levy, a lawyer and community leader of Staten Island, died Sunday night in his home, 131 Heberton Avenue, Port Richmond. His age was 79.

Pedestrians of the city unite. You have nothing to lose but your corns. It was, however, a gratifyingly large audience who had hotfooted it (but literally) to the East 74th Street Theater last night where Dance Theater Workshop presented the last of their Ethnic Series, with the Mariano Parra Ballet Espanol.
DETROIT, Jan. 3 (AP) The automobile industry took a deep breath today after a record-smashing 1965 and plunged ahead into the new year.
Two newspaper delivery boys for whom the holiday season was a financial success have turned over part of their profits to the Neediest Cases fund.
MIAMI, Jan. 3 (AP) Ditto trailed Lot To Learn until the final 70 yards, then forged to the front to win the featured seventh race by half a length at the Tropical Park race track today.

The Atlantic Refining Company announced yesterday that it had formed five major operating departments and named executives to head these departments following merger consummation with the Richfield Oil Corporation, which became effective Jan. 2. Stockholders of both companies approved the merger on Dec. 30.

The Detroit Pistons' playercoach, Dave DeBusschere, and a Piston guard, Eddie Miles, were named yesterday to round out the West team for the National Basketball Association's 16th annual all-star game next Tuesday at Cincinnati.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson joined her husband today in keeping a joint new year's resolution a regimen of exercise and diet aimed at keeping their weight down.
Dr. Albert T. Martin, associate professor of speech at Teachers College, Columbia University, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Chicago. He was 38 years old.
The Institute of Culture of the Americas will benefit from an exhibition of 40 paintings by Zoltan Perlmutter and Sandu Lieberman at the Lys Gallery, 1008 Lexington Avenue, from Jan. 14 through 29.
PHILHARMONIC HALL braced itself last night. There was no necessity. The transit strike did not keep much of the audience away from the Philadelphia Orchestra. Relatively few seats were vacant.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) Standards of water quality, which a Federal official described as "pioneering," were proposed today at a Federal conference on Lake Michigan pollution.

PREOCCUPATION with the very young has sent milli- ners back to the christening cap. and Sally Victor is no exception. But the milliner who sparked the revival of the Panama hat fashion two years ago has gone several steps beyond the cradle.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 110.5 on Monday from 110.3 on Thursday. Friday was a holiday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) G.I. life insurance dividends will be paid on the anniversary date of the policy, the Veterans Administration announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The possibility that the President may deliver his State of the Union Message Monday on color television is under discussion, the White House said tonight.
Fanny Farmer, whose engagement to another candy company was broken off last June, has a new, and more affluent suitor.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (Reuters) Cambodia has told Britain and the Soviet Union that she will fight any violation of her frontiers and possibly ask for help from friendly countries, wellinformed sources said here today.
An Army recruiting sergeant was arrested yesterday and was charged with having accepted a bribe to enroll a civilian in the State National Guard so that he could evade the draft.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 Governor Rockefeller called on New Yorkers today to join the American Legion's demonstration of support for United States actions in Vietnam.

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Jan. 4 James F. Boyle, a pioneer in the development of life-saving and survival kits for aeronautical use, died today in a nursing home in Madison Township. He was 73 years old and lived at 201 Kingfisher Drive here.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 4 A Negro college student active in the civil rights movement was shot to death here late last night, and a white service station attendant was charged today with first-degree murder in the slaying.

Jerry West of the Los Angeles Lakers scored 166 points in five games last week to retain his precarious lead over Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia, 76ers in the National Basketball Association scoring race.
The Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation postponed yesterday a $3-a-ton increase in the price of its structural steel products.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 4 A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that the Chinese had called in all their ambassadors in Asia, Africa and Europe for "urgent consultations." The Chinese charge d'affaires in New Delhi has also gone to Peking, he said.
A golden eagle has been reported seen at the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge. It is the first such report in the city's history.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Sargent Shriver has received two more resignations from his antipoverty staff, but not the one he is reputed to be looking for.

The chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Labor said last night that the state committee would hold public hearings to determine if strikes similar to New York's transit tie-up could be avoided in the future.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan.4 (UPI) Ernie Terrell said today that Cassius Clay had promised to give him and not Brian London the next shot at Clay's world heavyweight title.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 4 (Reuters) The 15th Pugwash Conference condemned the war in Vietnam today as a threat to world peace and said the situation in Rhodesia was unjust and oppressive.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) ?With a large increase in appropriations from the Federal Government, the nation's public elementary and secondary schools will spend $25.8-billion this year, a record.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 It's an odd time of year to be graduating from school, but then it's an odd time of life even to be thinking about school, the 100 women who received their Developing New Horizons certificates from George Washington University agreed after their commencement ceremonies this morning at Lismer Auditorium.
The Xerox Corporation introduced yesterday a new desk-top combination office-copier and duplicating machine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) Marriner S. Eccles, a prominent economic adviser to the Roosevelt Administration and a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, condemned President Johnson's handling of the Vietnam situation today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System televised a documentary entitled "The Volga" last night in spite of indications that it ran the risk of reprisals by the Soviet Union, which called the program an "insult [to] the dignity of Soviet people."

FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 4 (AP) A former SS (Elite Guard) medical assistant, Gerhard Neubert, was ordered jailed today by the court trying him on charges of having aided and abetted murders at the Nazi concentration camp at Auschwitz, Poland, during World War II.
PARIS, Jan. 4 Henry Torres, a prominent French trial lawyer who fled to the United States in World War II, died today in his Paris apartment. He was 74 years old.

It was pencils, books and dirty looks again yesterday for the city's elementary and junior high school students, but large numbers of high school and college students were still unable to attend classes.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 4 (UPI) About 100 hymn-singing, hand-clapping Negroes marched through a chilling rain tonight to protest alleged discrimination in voter registration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The Department of Labor announced today that the department, in cooperation with the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, would start an immediate study of the feasibility of setting up an upgrading program for ship engineers.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (UPI) Bobby Hull of Chicago picked up 4 points last week to maintain his lead among National Hockey League scorers. The Black Hawk star has 49 points on 29 goals and 20 assists, according to the offical statistics issued today.
SEATTLE, Jan. 4 (AP) Wreckage from a jet plane flown by an Air Force general was found in Puget Sound today near where the aircraft vanished yesterday a few miles from its destination here.
The Magnavox Company, a major television set producer, is going into the furniture business in a big way.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) John Bartlow Martin, diplomat and author, will write the authorized biography of Adlai E. Stevenson, the late Ambassador's son announced today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System television network announced yesterday that it would schedule a second night of feature films next fall, on Fridays from 9 to 11 P.M. Movies are now presented at a similar hour on Thursdays.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 Ronald Reagan, erstwhile television and movie actor, formally announced his candidacy for the Republican gubernatorial nomination today in an elaborately staged television appearance, press conference and public reception.

Three men indicted on charges of burning their draft cards in a demonstration last Nov. 6 at Union Square pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court. A fourth defendant, who was not represented by a lawyer, had his case put over until Jan. 11.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 4 (AP) The Arizona Supreme Court issued today a preemptory writ of prohibition against a contempt of court action brought in Supreme Court against. The Phoenix Gazette and The Arizona Republic.

THE time has come for the operators in the American Football League to hold up a mirror and take a searching, realis tic look into it. They are not going to like what they see. For the last few seasons they have been trying to give the impression that they are rapidly approaching parity with the solidly established National Football League. Recent developments indicate that they are bogged down at midfield.

The New York Rangers decided yesterday it was time to try another goalie and sent Ed Giacomin to their Baltimore farm team in exchange for Cesare Maniago. Giacomin has been the Blues' No. 1 goalie so far this season.
Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., engineering, construction and management consultant concern, announced here yesterday the election of William D. Bruce as a director.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 President Johnson was said today to have expressed the hope for a speedy settlement of the New York Transit strike, but there were no signs that the Federal Government was planning to intervene in the dispute.
The stock market advanced on a broad front yesterday despite much concern over both domestic and foreign developments.

HAVANA, Jan. 4 (Reuters) North Vietnam today called on the Tricontinental Solidarity Conference of Anti-Imperialist Forces, which opened its meeting there yesterday, to condemn the United States as a "war criminal."

Dr. Nicholas S. Gesoalde, executive secretary of the Pharmaceutical Society of the State of New York, said yesterday that the rise in prices of quinine "was about the same all over the United States."
Drivers are urged not to bring cars into the congested parts of the city unless absolutely necessary. Those who do drive are urged to carry as many passengers as possible.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 4 (UPI) Collie Leroy Wilkins, the 22-year-old Ku Klux Klansman tried three times last year on charges relating to a civil rights murder, began serving a one-year Federal prison term today in another case.

Mrs. Victoria McPherson Ray of 1281 President Street, Brooklyn, wife of the Rev. Dr. Sandy F. Ray, pastor of the Corner Stone Baptist Church in Brooklyn, died Monday at St. John's Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn.
The people came back to Manhattan yesterday. Gone was the holiday mood of Monday, when hundreds of thousands took Mayor Lindsay's advice and stayed home to lessen the transit crisis.
A rush for hotel rooms began yesterday afternoon after suburbanites changed their minds about braving hardship and expense to get back to their homes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Walter W. Heller, conceding unusual uncertainties in the outlook for this year, predicted today a gross national product for 1966 of $723-billion, up $50 billion from 1965.

Garrett Mattingly, who died Dec. 18, 1962, was a historian who made other historians proud of their craft. His writings, while of almost unequaled scholarship, were also vivid and humane. His aim was "faithfully reconstructing the past and presenting it in a rich ...
MARIETTA, Ga., Jan. 4 (UPI) Lester Maddox Jr., 21year-old son of Georgia's segregationist candidate for Governor, was sentenced today to five years in jail but was placed on five years' probation.
The automobile industry broke all its sales records last year.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 4 BenJack Cage, a Texas financier who fled here to escape a prison sentence for embezzlement, has been arrested by the Brazilian police investigating diamond smuggling.
Reports of progress in tender offers made by the Eltra Corporation and Indian Head Mills, Inc., were announced yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 4 Rutgers, the eighth oldest college in the United States, began its bicentennial celebration today with the signing of a proclamation by Gov. Richard J. Hughes marking 1966 as the Rutgers Bicentennial Year.
Thomas Edgar Stephens, British-born painter known for his portraits of world personalities, died in his home yesterday after a long illness. He was 80 years old.
The striking Transport Workers Union originally asked for an over-all money package that the Transit Authirity estimated would cost $680 million over a two-year period.
THE Soviet Union's apprehensions over the docu- mentary entitled "The Volga" were well founded. The Columbia Broadcasting System's film on the communities and citizens along the ...
BOSTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) Fire killed about 12,000 persons in the United States in 1965, an increase of 100 over the previous year's toll, the National Fire Protection Association said today.

The Lindsay administration is prepared to finance an increase of up to $7-million in the $25million package originally offered by the Transit Authority to the Transport Workers Union, it was learned yesterday from a source close to the new Mayor.

The general manager of the New York Cloak Joint Board said yesterday that "substantial losses" in both wages and business will be incurred as a result of employe absenteeism in New York's garment industry because of the transit strike.
The Congress of Racial Equality, which has gone through severe organizational and financial problems in recent months, is facing new ones now.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (UPI) Between 200 and 300 members of the London Transport Board's supervisory staff called a wildcat strike Tuesday in a dispute over wages and hours.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 4 To stiffen its resistance against the oil embargo applied against it, Rhodesia tonight halved gasoline supplies to its commercial users who buy in bulk.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits have invited all top county and municipal leaders in New York to a Federal seminar in Washington in February or March.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Jan. 4 (UPI) Authorities disclosed today that two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were fired on while staked out to observe cross-burnings that occurred in at least nine Mississippi counties last night.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 4 The soft white ducks that have helped shape the image of Long Island, and the filth that they contribute, are one of the principal problems of Suffolk County, according to the County Executive's annual message, which is scheduled for delivery tomorrow.
Troubles mounted yesterday for New York's taxicabs almost the sole remaining public transportation in the city.

An agreement between Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and the City Center has been amended to permit the employment of musicians through regular channels for independent attractions booked into the civic house. Heretofore, musicians on the City Center's roster were used.

ALGIERS, Jan. 4?President Houari Boumediene today signed a decree fixing Algeria's 1966 budget at $640-million. The figure covers only administrative expenses and is about $30-million more than last year's total.

The authorization to American commanders in Vietnam to launch attacks into northeastern Cambodia in "self-defense" has now brought notice to the United Nations from Prince Sihanouk that if this happens he will seek foreign military assistance presumably from Communist China for reprisal raids.
Some Liberal party leaders, longtime supporters of Robert F. Wagner, are displaying keen unhappiness with the former Mayor.
RED CLIFF, Wis., Jan. 4 (AP) The Red Cliff Indians have invited back the two Peace Corps workers they cast off this remote reservation in a dispute over antipoverty programs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The Office of Economic Opportunity has approved grants totaling $557,500 for legal services to the poor in Newark and other parts of Essex County.

ROME, Jan. 4 Justice Minister Oronzo Reale said today he would press for the abolition of the law that punishes killings in "crimes of honor" with jail sentences of three to seven years. Abolition of the law would open the way to more severe penalties.
Martin A. Sherre, head of the M.A. Sherre Diamond Company, 105 Canal Street, diamond importers and cutters, died on Monday in his West 55th Street home. His age was 78.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 The Federal Government has again moved into the controversial question of school segregation complaints in Chicago, this time with a conciliatory approach designed to forestall political repercussions.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 4 (UPI) Patrick J. Nugent, the Marquette University graduate whose engagement to Luci Baines Johnson was announced Christmas Eve, is receiving an Air National Guard transfer from Milwaukee to Washington, D.C.
GENEVA, Jan. 4 Helicopters were pressed into service today to enable vacationists to leave for home after an avalanche had cut the railroad to the Alpine resort of Zermatt.

Meadow Brook National Bank, which has $868-million in assets and is controlled by the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, a large sales finance company, said yesterday that it would pay 5 per cent on 1-year, $2,500 minimum savings certificates.
TOPEKA, Jan. 4 (AP) Dr. William C. Menninger, president of the Menninger Foundation, underwent exploratory chest surgery today in Methodist Hospital in Rochester, Minn.
MANILA, Jan. 4 Foreign Secretary Narciso Ramos said today that he favored the dispatch of Philippine combat troops to South Vietnam.

Joe Namath, considered such a good prospect that the New York Jets paid him $400,000 in salary and bonus and traded their top quarterback, lived up to expectations so well that he is the United Press International's American Football League rookie of the year.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 4 Lieut. Gen. Robert H. Nimmo, chief United Nations cease-fire observer in Kashmir, died in his sleep last night at his winter residence in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. He was 72 years old. An examining physician said he died of a heart attack.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 Joseph Zaretzki, the Democratic floor leader in the State Senate, would be treated better by a Republican reapportionment plan than by the proposal of an advisory council appointed by the Democratic leaders.
The city's supply of blood for transfusions dwindled yesterday to its lowest level in 20 years after the transit strike had upset donation programs.

ATLANTA, Jan. 4 (AP) Georgia college students have begun a movement called "Affirmation Vietnam," to demonstrate, they say, that "the majority of Americans are solidly behind the United States commitment in South Vietnam."

"Billy Budd" had been classed as one of Benjamin Britten's two "underground" operas (the other is "Gloriana'") because of the infrequency with which it has been performed. First produced at Covent Garden in London in 1951, it was received well enough, but never attained the popularity of such other Britten operas as "Peter Grimes," "The Rape of Lucretia," "Albert Herring" and "The Turn of the Screw."
ROME, Jan. 4 Rome's experimental, traffic-free pedestrian "island" died today, mourned apparently only by a few sentimentalists of the quiet life and by its founder, who promised to try again.
Kramer Bros., Inc., manufacturers of children's hosiery and stretchwear, announced yesterday the election of Arnold Kramer Sr. as chairman and chief executive officer, a new post.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 4 (UPI) Pat McBride and Carl Gentile, seniors from the National Collegiate Athletic Association champion St. Louis University team, were named today to the 1965 all-America soccer squad selected by the National Soccer Coaches Association of America.
The election of Herbert W. Meierdirks as controller has been announced by the North American Car Corporation.

Jim Taylor, the star of the Green Bay Packers' victory over the Cleveland Browns Sunday, now owns four cars and a stiff right knee that makes it difficult to get in and out of any of them. Car No. 4 was presented to the fullback by Sport Magazine at Cavanagh's Restaurant yesterday because Taylor was selected as the outstanding player of the National Football League championship game.
A Grand Ball on Jan. 14 at the New York Hilton will raise funds for the eighth Commonwealth Games, to be held in Jamaica from Aug. 4 to 13.

Joseph Patrick Sullivan, confidential attendant to Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine, died yesterday after a long illness at Misericordia Hospital in the Bronx. He was 63 years old and lived at 1001 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 4 The discovery that a prospective juror in a murder trial was a close friend of the victim resulted in a mistrial yesterday.
GENEVA, Jan. 4 The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that it had offered to send medical teams into both North and South Vietnam to aid the civilian sick and injured.
ONE transit tie-up at a time, please.
Eugene M. Becker, Mayor Lindsay's Acting Budget Director, said yesterday that the new administration must solve the problem of meeting steadily rising welfare costs.
Fred Hale appointed a senior vice president of Cunningham Walsh, Inc., San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 With Administration approval or without it, a determined effort will be made in Congress to change the direction of domestic farm programs toward expanded production of major food crops.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Norvin H. Rieser Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rieser's daughter, Miss Susan Beecher Smith, to Lieut. Stephen J.T. Masse, U.S.C.G. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Masse of Flushing, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) About 400 letters received by the White House in November and December on the subject of Vietnam demonstrations were referred to the Internal Security Division of the Justice Department to be answered, officials said today.
Two vessels under construction that were sunk by hurricane Betsy last September brought a bid of $150,000 yesterday. That figure was the highest of four to the Avondale ...

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Jan. 4 Alfred R. Marcks, who retired two years ago as senior vice president and a trustee of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, died yesterday in his home at 62 Kennedy Avenue. His age was 62.
RUMSON, N.J., Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Edward McNeil have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Edna McNeil, to David W. Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Fox of Stratford, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The Veterans Administration today reached into its own ranks for the first time to find a Chief Medical Director. He is Dr. H. Martin Engle.

PERTH, Austrailia, Jan. 4, (AP) Arthur Ashe, Cliff Richey and Marty Riessen were among United States winners over Australian opponents today in the opening round of the West Australian tennis championships.
Some of the more than 3.5 million people who are employed in the city and who have been unable to get to work because of the transit strike are eligible for unexpected help unemployment benefits.

Alabama's Crimson Tide, overwhelming victor over Nebraska in the Orange Bowl, was named yesterday the national collegiate football champion for the second straight year in The Associated Press final poll of the season.
Labor support continued to grow yesterday for the striking transit workers and their nine jailed leaders.

NORMAN NORELL, the Seventh Avenue designer who disappointed many of his fans last summer with a fall and winter collection that smacked of Chanel in the nineteen-twenties, was back in the sixties again Monday night this time with what may be properly called a new look with Yves Saint Laurent-Pierre Cardin-Mme. Gres overtones.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 4 Brazil's Minister of War, Gen. Artur Costa e Silva, has stated his willingness to succeed President Humberto Castelo Branco when Congress elects the next President by Oct. 3.

A.L. van Ameringen, chairman of the board of International Flavors Fragrances, Inc., and a leader in welfare work to promote mental health, died of a heart attack Monday in Memorial Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 510 Park Avenue.
Business losses from the transit strike are exceeding $100million a day, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York reported last night.

WITH hair tousled, sweat streaming down his face, and his features contorted in some kind of saintlike agony, the Spanish dancer Antonio resumed his never-ending love affair with his audience at the New York City Center last night. He and his company, Ballets de Madrid, were opening a two-week season, presented by S. Hurok.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The Johnson Administration is favorably considering a request from Israel for a renewal of surplus-food assistance.
The election of Richard Frankfort as president and chief executive officer was announced here yesterday by Donmoor, Inc., a manufacturer of boy's knitwear and coordinates.

PRACTICAL jokers sometimes indulge themselves by stacking a bridge hand for unwary friends. To give each player a complete suit may secure a newspaper mention and does so about once a year but is a little too obvious. Equally hackneyed for this purpose are the Duke of Cumberland's hand and the Mississippi Heart hand.
The British pound inched ahead yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.
It was almost business as usual yesterday on Wall Street as more and more brokerage firm employes found that it was possible to make an endrun around the struck transit lines.
A graceful letter K whose lines depict modern superhighways has been adopted as the new corporate symbol of the Kinney Service Corporation.
A computerized attack on one of the retail industry's chief problems, inventory control, was announced yesterday by the National Cash Register Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 President Johnson has decided to send to Congress soon after it reconvenes Monday a request for a supplemental appropriation of between $12-billion ... lion and $13-billion to finance the increased costs of the war in Vietnam.

Mayor Lindsay issued yesterday his first executive order, reaffirming all executive orders in existence on Dec. 31, 1965, the last day of the Wagner administration. His order substituted the names of persons he had appointed to commissionerships for those who had served under former Mayor Wagner.

LONDON, Jan. 4 British steelmakers, who have had their own confrontation with a Government intent on nationalization, were watching the steel price dispute in the United States with great interest and only faintly disguised sympathy for the American companies.
The Ohio Power Company sold the first new bond issue of 1966 yesterday as Wall Street investment banking and bond market activity continued to be hampered by the New York City transit strike.

The Johnson Administration's case against the structural steel price increase announced by Bethlehem Steel and seconded by Inland Steel is drawing very little support from economists. from economists. Economists queried about the latest test of the Administration's guideposts for maintaining stability said that Washington may still win its battle but could well lose the war.

Arnold G. Fraiman, the new Commissioner of Investigation, initiated his plan yesterday to infuse young blood into his department by asking for the resignations of 10 of the 26 staff attorneys employed by his predecessor, Leon A. Fischel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The House Committe on Un-American Activities resumed its hearings on the Ku Klux Klan today with members saying that the investigation had already thinned Klan ranks in the South.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 (AP) Heavy rains added to the flood woes along the upper California coast today, and mountainous snows and galeforce winds pounded the Northwest.
Mayor Lindsay capped a hectic day at City Hall by having dinner there with his family last night.

IF human beings were as well off as some forms of wild life, they could cope with such crises as transit strikes and dreary winters by hibernating. Thus they could skip all sorts of problems until spring's balmy weather arrived.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Under the surface here there is a growing mood of gloomy fatalism about Vietnam. The unjustified optimism of the peace offensive is gradually giving way to unjustified pessimism.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 Controller Arthur Levitt hurled angry counter-charges at Senator Jacob K. Javits today in their growing dispute over who is doing most to bring more Federal money into New York State.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 4 Democrats in the Pennsylvania Legislature staged a bitter demonstration today against the administration of Gov. William W. Scranton and his presumed national political ambitions.

Recently, the U.S. Government has started a large-scale deceptive peace campaign coupled with the trick of "temporary suspension of air attacks" on North Vietnam as a sign of "goodwill." U.S. President Johnson has repeatedly stated that the United States is determined to "exhaust every prospect for peace," and will "search relentlessly for peace."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 4 Communist diplomats today criticized what they called the "Madison Avenue" publicity surrounding the United States effort to promote negotiations to end the war in Vietnam.

The debate among the 15 members of the President's Maritime Advisory Committee over a vital ship policy question whether the American merchant ship of the future may or may not be built in a foreign yard grew more intense yesterday.
A retired West Virginia real estate man with memories of New York City has sent aid from Florida for the city's Neediest.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 4 The chief civilian spokesman of the Dominican rebel forces said today that his group would no longer "cooperate whatsoever" with the provisional Government as a result of President Hector Garcia-Godoy's address to the nation last night.
Brother Azades Gabriel, dean of De La Salle College in Washington for the last 35 years, died there of a heart attack yesterday. He was 81 years old.

OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, Jan. 4 (AP) The army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Col. Sangoule Lamizana, seized control of Upper Volta today in the fourth military take-over among the central African countries in the last two months.
George Raft, who has portrayed many movie gangsters, appeared briefly yesterday before a Federal rackets grand jury here.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 4 The engagement of Miss Anne Tyson Woodruff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Woodruff, to Eric W. Jorgensen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter D. Jorgensen of Englewood, Colo., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Freishtat have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roslyn Freishtat, to Richard Glenn Sandler, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Herbert Sandler of New York.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 4 An Israeli mystery man serving a 10-year prison sentence has been on a hunger strike here for three days after demanding remission of his sentence for good behavior.

DUBLIN, Jan. 4 In the little farmsteads around Kilgarvan, County Kerry, Michael J. Quill is spoken of with pride as the boy from the farm on the hills of Gortloughera who became the boss of the biggest transport union in the United States.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 Governor Rockefeller set forth a blueprint today for strengthening law enforcement in the state, including the establishment of minimum pay levels for local policemen.
Dr. Zoltan Klar, editor of Az Ember, a Hungarian-language weekly, died yesterday at Madison Avenue Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 100 West 80th Street.
Several large companies in the metals industry or allied to it announced plans yesterday for major industrial expansion.
NEWARK, Jan. 4 The Newark Teachers Union, which struck the school system last month, proposed last night a $17.5-million program for the city's schools in 1966-67.
THE HAGUE The Government and the insurance industry of the Netherlands plan to offer new savings plans in 1966.
The Irving Trust Company announced here yesterday the election as senior vice presidents of Robert A. Kerr, William W. Pevear and G. Robert Truex Jr.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) The White House has five new puppies, offspring of the Presidential beagle 'Him.'
Picketing members of the Transport Workers Union said yesterday that the hospitalization of Michael J. Quill would strengthen their position at the bargaining table.
BONN, Jan. 4 German businessmen are investing their money abroad at about the same pace that foreigners have made direct investment in West Germany during the postwar years.
LYONS, France, Jan. 4 (Reuters) Five butane gas storage tanks exploded near here today, touching off a refinery blaze that killed between 6 and 10 persons. More than 1,000 firemen fought the flames.

The New York Knickerbockers staged one of their patented final-period rallies last night in Madison Square Garden, but once again their efforts were fruitless and resulted in another defeat. This time the loss was to the Philadelphia 76ers, 129-127, and 7,220 fans were left virtually limp from the excitement at the finish.
MONTREAL, Jan. 4 Stein berg's, Ltd., one of North America's largest supermarket chains, today announced its plans to extend operations overseas with a 40-per-cent-owned new company in France.

Stories out of Washington indicate that the Johnson Administration is having problems trying to draw up the new Federal budget. There are hints that the cost of the war in Vietnam will force a slowdown in the war on poverty and may even require tax increases to limit the size of the deficit and to prevent inflation.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 The 189th session of the Legislature will convene at noon tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 A Senate subcommittee staff has begun investigating what it calls "a fantastic rise" in quinine prices.
Two policemen rescued a mother and five children at the scene of a tenement house fire last night while, unknown to the officers, Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick looked on.
OLEG CASSINI is a funloving scion of the Rus- sian aristocracy-in-exile whose personal struggle for survival has been reluctantly waged in the American industry that calls itself the rag business.
New York was choked by traffic and railroad jams yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 4 (AP) France failed today to comply with the agreed 10 per cent cut in customs duties on industrial goods traded among the six Common Market members, according to officials of the trade bloc.
Soybeans retreated yesterday in commodity futures trading in the face of some militant profit taking, following a sharp advance on Monday.

The producers of a teen-age rock 'n' roll show served a complaint on eight leaders of the Transport Workers Union last night, asking for $25-million in damages because the transit strike allegedly closed their show.

Copper shares, especially Zambian issues, were in demand yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. Copper stocks, standouts in an otherwise quiet day, moved up on the heels of the run-up, to records, of cash copper on the London metals market.

United States District Judge Charles Metzner approved yesterday a plan that would allow the First National City Bank to complete its planned acquisition of the former Hilton Hotel's Carte Blanche credit-card system. Pending the outcome of a Government antitrust suit against the acquisition. Carte Blanche must be kept separate as an "independent going concern."
Mrs. Agathi Vernicos, widow of Basil Vernicos and a former resident of the Carlyle Hotel, died on Sunday in London. She was an octogenarian.
A New York City Police Department helicopter was flown into New Jersey last night to rescue three workmen trapped in a swamp at Rutherford.
The first vice president of the Hotel Association of New York City, Harold P. Bock, was elected chairman of the board at the trade group's recent annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 North Vietnam acknowledged for the first time today the suspension of air raids on its territory, called the suspension temporary and denounced it as a trick.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 Testimony in the Krebiozen fraud and conspiracy trial of Dr. Andrew C. Ivy and three other defendants ended this afternoon.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 4 The engagement of Miss Linda Rae Leonard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Leonard, to Stephens M. Fowler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Fowler of Locust Valley, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

The "second line" of the leadership of the Transport Workers Union took over bargaining responsibilities yesterday and immediately assumed the same unyielding posture as their arrested chief, Michael J. Quill.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The United States drew $100-million worth of Canadian dollars from the International Monetary Fund today.
LONDON, Jan. 4 Britain's gold and convertible currency reserves rose by the equivalent of $16.8-million last month to $3,004,400,000, the Treasury reported today.
Citing the inconvenience of the transit crisis, the city's Buildings Commissioner said yesterday that a hearing on rent-impairing building violations has been rescheduled from today to Jan. 26.

AS EVERY self-respecting baseball buff knows, Har vey (The Kitten) Haddix, the new pitching coach of the New York Mets, was the first major leaguer to pitch 12 perfect innings in one game which he lost in the 13th. Few people know, however, that Haddix is also the last major league player to shoot at buffalo.

An experimental children's park will be set up temporarily on a $1-million half-acre bought for right-of-way for the proposed Mid-Manhattan Expressway, Parks Commissoner Thomas P.F. Hoving said yesterday.
The transit strike had little effect on yesterday's activities on the American Stock Exchang as most issues advanced in stepped-up trading.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., the nation's largest food chain, showed a small decline in sales and earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended Nov. 27, according to the results reported yesterday by John D. Ehrgott, chairman.
The deficit-ridden Transit Authority said yesterday it has been losing about $76,834 more a day since the strike began last Saturday than it has been losing in normal periods of full operation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 4 (UPI) The Rutgers Chapter of the nationwide Universities Committee on the Problems of War and Peace has wired President Johnson urging him to continue to halt the bombing of North Vietnam long enough for peace talks to begin.
Douglas MacMahon, who took over negotiations when Michael J. Quill was taken to jail yesterday, has been a long-time associate of Mr. Quill and sometime opponent.

Senator Jacob K. Javits praised Republican Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman yesterday as the man best qualified to succeed Mayor Lindsay as Congressional Representative from Manhattan's 17th (Silk Stocking) District.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 4 (AP) J. Millard Tawes of Maryland will become the nation's first Governor to sign up for Medicare this week because of a routine survey by Social Eecurity officials.
EIGHT furniture styles vie for attention in Blooming- dale's refurbished model rooms, which open today on the store's fifth floor.

In October, 1954, dud bombs bearing Egyptian markings were placed in the United States Information Service office and the British consular library in Cairo. Dud bombs also were thrown into theaters in Egypt.

PARIS One consequence of China's insistence on further warfare in Vietnam and persistent menace to India is the revival of Russian diplomatic interest in Southeast and South Asia. This revival is dramatically confirmed in the Tashkent meeting of the Indian, Pakistani and Soviet chiefs of government, and the simultaneous dispatch to Hanoi of Aleksandr Shelepin.

WHEN he was a youngster living on the lower East Side, Abraham N. Geller heard a frequent reminder from his mother: "Be a lawyer, be a lawyer and you'll be respected." The prodding proved effective. He not only studied law and achieved success in the field, but he moved ...

BOSTON, Jan. 4 State Representative Michael S. Dukakis of suburban Brookline became today the third avowed Democratic candidate for nomination as Attorney General of Massachusetts. At least three others are planning to enter the contest.
ALL major citrus producing areas of the country are reporting bumper crops, especially in orange harvests.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 4 The Rev. Charles W. Nelson, formerly rector of St. Augustine's Episcopal Church here for many years, died Sunday at his home in Trenton. He was 89 years old. He retired in 1951 after serving at St. Monica's Episcopal Church, Trenton.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (UPI) Frank Wall, a 62-year-old London baker, was declared today the winner of $770,000 on a soccer pool.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 5 Japanese steel interests are waiting to see whether the steel price dispute in the United States will bring any substantial increase in their exports to America.

The Mellon National Bank and Trust Company of Pittsburgh. Pennsylvania's largest bank and 13th largest in the nation, announced yesterday record 1965 net operating earnings of $34,983,176, or $5.25 per share, up 8.9 per cent from the $32,085,040, or $4.82 per share reported in 1964.

Mrs. Michael J. Quill, the wife of the leader of the Transport Workers Union, has long been known among the union's top officials as one of the bestinformed persons on the union and a tough opponent in an argument.
