OTTAWA, Jan. 4 Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson pledged to Liberal members of the Canadian Parliament today that he would press for broad progressive legislation despite the party's minority pasition in the new House of Commons.
TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Jan. 4 President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan and Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India met here today and promptly reached their old impasse on Kashmir.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 4 (AP) Sixth-ranked Providence, on an off-night, beat Brown, 66-48, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) The Office of Economic Opportunity and the Social Security Administration have joined forces to warn about 600,000 elderly persons that unless they sign up by March 1 they may lose part of their Medicare benefits.

A NEW prize-winning plan will be tried by the Wat kins Glenn, N.Y., racing corporation at its Formula One Grand Prix of the United States Oct. 2. Cameron Argetsinger, the managing director of the Watkins Glen course, announced the details here yesterday.

Unbeaten Kentucky vaulted into second place yesterday in the United Press International major college basketball ratings. Duke was ranked No. 1 for the fourth consecutive week, but the holiday tournament results completely juggled the rest of the top 10.
The New School for Social Research announced yesterday an experimental graduate program that will eliminate course credits, routine tests and grades.
While many retailers were busy pulling ads on Monday because their potential customers were strikebound, a bank was busy placing ads because its employes were strikebound.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4 A spring wedding is planned by Miss Bettie Jane Hungerford of New York and F. Alan Ruggles of Boston and West Harwich, Mass.

A two-day weekend forum designed to explore how brokers, operators and lawyers team up in successful real estate transactions will be held by the Practicing Law Institute, 20 Vesey Street, on Jan. 21 and 22. The program will be held at the Statler Hilton Hotel from 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Twentyfive operators, brokers, architects, insurance men and lawyers will discuss their roles in real estate.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 4 Six youths and two girls who were arrested in Darien last November on charges of possession of narcotics appeared here today at a brief hearing in First Circuit Court.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Jan. 4 The engagement of Miss Lynn Sharon Mandel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton E. Mandel, to Ronald Paul Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cohen of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 4 Alber von Bonin, a structural and design engineer who worked on hydroelectric power projects and steam electric stations throughout the country, died yesterday at his home, 87 Yantacaw Avenue, of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.
OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 4 A strike by convicts in Sing Sing Prison here continued today as a protest against what the prisoners consider to be unfair state parole regulations. It began yesterday.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 4 Some of the optimism evinced by the track's management over an opening-night crowd of 24,167 faded somewhat tonight as only 14,293 hardy souls showed up at Roosevelt Raceway.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation has received two Army contracts totaling $25million for production of ammunition.
DETROIT, Jan. 4 The American Motors Corporation, maker of the Rambler car, borrowed about $50-million in short-term funds during its fiscal year ended last Sept. 30, it was learned today.

A strike called by the United Federation of College Teachers yesterday at St. John's University, the largest Roman Catholic school in the world, failed to disrupt classes at the main Jamaica campus, according to university officials.

The Democratic majority in the City Council outlined yesterday a plan under which the city could get $502.8-million more in state and Federal aid and thus possibly avoid new taxes to balance the next budget.
Steve Bowman, a star fullback for Alabama's national champions, signed yesterday with the New York Giants of the National Football League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 A United States campaign to discourage shipping by non-Communist nations to North Vietnam has resulted in a sharp reduction of such shipping in the last year, the State Department said today.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hill Pierce Jr. of New Haven and Madison have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margot Pierce, to Elmer Harry Close. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kempf Close of Dublin, N.H. A winter wedding is planned.
TRENTON, Jan. 4 (AP) New Jersey made substantial progress in efforts to curb air and water pollution in the Hackensack River and meadows area in 1965, the State Health Department reported today.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Jan. 4 The sloping four-mile shoreline of this once thriving Hudson River community opposite Manhattan is a relentless reminder today of shifting economic tides and man's maltreatment of nature.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 For the last 10 days 1,000 residents of the Soviet atomic research center of Dubna have been trying to learn English by radio in their sleep, provided, of course, they go to bed in time.

"The Necessary Revolution in American Education," by Francis Keppel, United States Commissioner of Education, will be published on April 27 by Harper Row. Mr. Keppel sees the "revolution" moving toward equality of education and the achievement of quality education for all youth in the country.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 4 A bill containing stiff regulations on coal strip mining operations was introduced tonight at the opening session of the 1966 Kentucky General Assembly.

Michael J. Quill was put in jail yesterday for disobeying a court order to end the transit strike. Two hours later he collapsed with "a possible heart attack" and was taken to Bellevue Hospital's emergency ward.

Mr. and Mrs. David B. Weinman of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzan Weinman, to Fred Ehrman, son of Samuel Ehrman of New York and the late Mrs. Ehrman. The wedding is planned for Jan. 30.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Stevens Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Brooke Stevens, to David Richmond Outerbridge. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Outerbridge of Princeton and Oyster Bay, L.I.

THE HAGUE, Jan. 4 The Dutch police recovered from an Amsterdam canal today the body of an American nutrition expert, Prof. Richard Follis of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He disappeared Dec. 7 while visiting Amsterdam on his way to Teheran.

A recent real estate transaction in North Bergen, N.J., signals the loss of another industry for New York City. The Mackman Realty Corporation of North Bergen has contracted to build a 55,200 square-foot manufacturing building to be leased to the Joshua Meier Company. The company is now in the giant Starrett-Lehigh industrial building at 601 West 26th Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 5 South Korean marines and South Vietnamese paratroopers, fighting to protect the rice harvest in coastal Phuyen Province, encountered savage Vietcong opposition yesterday.
MIAMI, Jan. 4 (AP) Sun Native, closing with a rush over a muddy track, won the featured seventh race at Tropical Park today.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 4 Maryland's controversial Ober Law requiring state employes to swear loyalty to the United States has been challenged in the Federal Court here.

BAOTRI, South Vietnam, Jan. 4 A leathery old farmer with a wispy beard and his tiny careworn wife squatted on their heels as a young American lieutenant spoke to them through an interpreter this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The White House said today that the Government wanted to do what it could to assist in the New York transit strike if city Officials Would give it guidance.

The quest for substitute transportation inspired by the transit strike has again brought to light the ingenuity of New Yorkers. But they need to carry their thinking one step further--to the personal financial hazards created by the emergency.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5-- The world premiere of a symphony by John B. Kennedy, young New York composer, was performed tonight at the War Memorial Opera House by the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Jan. 5--Richard C. Dillon, Governor of New Mexico from 1927 to 1931, died last night in a hospital here at the age of 88.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan 5 (UPI) --Adrian Smith's 35 points led the Cincinnati Royals to a 117103 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight in a National Basketball Association game at the University of Dayton Fieldhouse.
The large, ornate building at 425 Lafayette Street that opened 112 years ago as the Astor Library will become the first permanent home of the New York Shakespeare Festival.
By sheer coincidence the publication date of Branch Rickey's monumental and loving documentary book on baseball, "The American Diamond," reached the stalls shortly before his death last month.

The Police Department has designated the following areas in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn as places where persons who have arranged car pools may pick up and discharge their passengers. Parking will not be permitted in these areas. In addition, municipal off-street parking lots have been designated as staging areas in the Bronx, Queens, and Brooklyn.

Drivers are urged not to bring cars into the congested parts of the city unless absolutely necessary. Those who do drive are urged to carry as many passengers as possible and to stagger their arrivals and departures from Manhattan as follows:
A maritime union leader warned yesterday that the shortage of skilled merchant seamen was increasing, and charged that the Government was not moving fast enough to meet it.
ATLANTA, Jan. 5 (AP)-- A Federal judge ordered the Northern District Dental Society of Georgia today to provide Dr. Roy C. Bell, a Negro, with an application for membership.
The 1966 edition of the booklet "They Represent You," a political guide, has just been published by the League of Women Voters of the City of New York.

OTTAWA, Jan, 5--Canada must have more production at a faster rate to keep up with the United States and increased output from Canada requires more efficient use of manpower and above all better education.
HONG KONG, Jan. 5--Communist China indicated uneasiness today about the impact on world opinion of United States diplomatic moves to bring peace to Vietnam.

ALBANY, Jan. 5--Democratic legislators lashed out at Governor Rockefeller minutes after convening today, denouncing him for not saying anything about the transit strike in his annual message and for not taking a direct role in the negotiations.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 (UPI)--Two Washington Parish deputy sheriffs and a Bogalusa, La., police detective pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges of beating Negroes during a racial disturbance last Oct 20.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 5-- Appointment of a three-man committee to investigate charges of discrimination against Washington Rock Council, Boy Scouts of America, was announced today by the Plainfield human Relations Commission.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which signed a new television contract with the National Football League last week, has set a new top price to sponsors of $70,000 a minute. This is $10,000 more than last pear's price for rgular season games.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5 --J. Raymond Carringer, a retired vice president of Esso Standard Oil Company, died here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 79 years old and lived at 55 High Street, Summit, N.J.

A driver of one of the nine private buses chartered by The York Times for the use of its employes during the transit strike reported that he had been beaten by three men at the end of his run to the Bronx early yesterday morning.

St. John's University has notified 25 faculty members who have not returned to their classes since a strike was called Tuesday that they will be dealt with "properly and appropriately" unless they report for their next scheduled classes.

AMONG those with fingers tightly crossed yesterday that the transit strike would end soon was Diana Henley, the director of dog training for the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
MONTREAL, Jan. 5 (AP)-- Two goals by Bobby Hull, the National Hockey League's scoring leader, paced the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 5-- County Executive H. Lee Dennison proposed today a study of the possibility of levying a 2 per cent county sales tax.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--A Federal grand jury today indicted Robert G. Baker, former secretary to the Senate Democrats, on nine counts charging him with receiving $137,000 under false pretenses and evading taxes on most of the money.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP)--Robert Ruark, American author and journalist, left an estate in Britain valued at 23,908 (about $66,950), his will published in London disclosed today.

Many St. John's University students complained yesterday that only two weeks before final examinations new teachers appeared in their classrooms to take over courses that had been taught by dismissed, striking of absent faculty members.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 5--Mayor Ralph S. Locher, who nearly lost office last fall after a widespread revolt of Negro voters, today announced the appointment of a Negro to his cabinet.

FIRST came the snow. Then came skis and much later snow-making machines. Now along comes Joel N. Myers, a meteorological consultant from State College, Pa., who gazes at his crystal ball and advises ski operators when to make snow.

Douglas L. MacMahon, who succeeded the jailed and hospitalized Michael J. Quill as chief union negotiator in the transit strike, made a brave show of trying to out-Quill Quill in his initial news conference.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 5 (AP) --The Netherlands Bridge Association announced today that the world bridge championship for pairs would take place in Amsterdam May 7 to 16.
LONDON, Jan. 5--European opinion has reacted favorably on the whole to President Johnson's peace offensive on Vietnam, but those skeptical about United States policy remain largely unconvinced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5-- Today's indictment of Robert G. Baker on charges of receiving money under false pretenses and evading income taxes is the latest act in a continuing drama that began three and a half years ago.

The program-and-policy statement issued by the Democratic majority in the City Council and its new president, Frank D. O'Connor, is designed to convince the public that Mayor Lindsay, at the other end of the corridor in City Hall, will not be alone in the effort to improve New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The Ku Klux Klan still controls Bogalusa, La., despite a Federal Court injunction, exposure of its membership and massive anti-Klan efforts by the Justice Department and civil rights groups, a Congressional committee was told today.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Jan. 5 --A unique partnership of government, private enterprise and the trade union movement has been formed to keep a bankrupt shipbuilding company afloat and revive a proud but ailing industry.
The American Institute for Imported Steel asserted yesterday that proposed amendments to the Anti-Dumping Act of 1921 would "cripple import trade."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5-- Democrats may be the party of the "little man," as they like to proclaim, but it is the Republicans who are getting the small contributions.
Mayor Lindsay has chosen Mitchell Sviridoff, now head of New Haven's showcase antipoverty agency, to organize and eventually direct the city's proposed Human Resources Administration.

Hitchhiking has become a favorite method of transportation for many New Yorkers emboldened by aching arches. Women who might have been insulted if a driver had offered them a lift before the transit crisis are skipping recklessly through traffic to pounce on nearempty cars.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The value of the nation's total output of goods and services--the gross national product--rose to more than $675-billion in 1965, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) --The Government is claiming a total of $5,576,742,20 from two tax-exempt foundations that were the subject of a Congressional investigation, it was learned today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 5 (UPI)--More than 200 Negroes, including Leroy Norton, the youth who rode with Mrs. Viola Liuzzo the night she was murdered, marched through downtown Birmingham tonight to protest alleged voter registration discrimination.

New York City has scored its first major preservation success under its 18-month old landmarks law with the dramatic announcement of Joseph Papp's plans to purchase the old Astor Library on Lafayette Street as the Shakespeare Festival's new home.

Sales of Series E and H savings bonds slumped 2.7 per cent during 1965 compared with 1964, the Treasury Department said yesterday. Total sales for the year were $4,486,000,000, compared with $4,609,000,000 in 1964.
The Johns-Manville Corporation announced yesterday the election of George H. Martens Jr. as vice president for marketing and a senior officer of the company, a leading maker of asbestos products.

Prices in town houses in Greenwich Village and on both the East and West Side are increasing according to Beatrice M. Kaye, vice president of L.B. Kaye Associates, Ltd., brokers specializing in town-house transactions.
ANNAPOLIS, Jan. 5 (AP)-- Georgetown handed Navy an 88-75 defeat in basketball at the Academy court today.
Two of the executives Robert G. Baker is alleged to have received money from under false pretenses head two of the biggest savings and loan holding companies in the nation.

In light of Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes's advice for unsnarling traffic and their own exposure to what a transit strike can do to Wall Street's narrow throughfares, the governors of the New York and the American Stock exchanges voted yesterday to halt trading an hour and a half early today.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange advanced sharply yesterday in very heavy trading under the leadership of the steels.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan 5-- Bob Farrington offered substance to his press clippings at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The sturdy harness horse driver, who led the nation last year with 310 victories, came through with three winners.

ANDERMATT, Switzerland, Jan. 5 (Reuters)--New avalaches in the central Swiss Alps cut off hundreds of tourists and villagers today in the popular winter sports resort of Realp, about six miles from here.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 5--Georges Theunis, twice Premier of Belgium between the two World Wars and wartime ambassador to the United States, died last night at the age of 92.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5-- The Treasury announced today it would borrow $1.5 billion this month through the sale of 10-month certificates priced to yield 4.85 per cent.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 (AP)--Collapsing roofs, power blackouts and blocked highways and railroads beset storm-swept Northern California today.

HINDELANG, Germany, Jan. 5 (AP)--Bill Kidd, a sophomore at the University of Colorado, won the men's special slalom today of the Silbertannen races on Mount Iseler, the season's first major Alpine competition.

Provisional President Garcia-Godoy of the Dominican Republic is trying hard not to offend either the rightwing militarists or the constitutionalists, and he is satisfying neither. His problem arose from the vicious attack on ex-rebel officers in Santiago on Dec. 19 by regular officers and troops from the San Isidro airbase.
WASHINGTON,Jan.5--A 10year program of scientific exploration should follow the first landing of astronauts on the moon, 65 scientists urged in a report released today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP)--Joseph P. Kennedy, father of the late President, suffered a fleeting heart block today just after he got out of the pool at his winter home.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5--Mrs. Forence Grunefeld Heller, president of the National Jewish Welfare Board, died here today in her home. She was 68 years old.

"I feel I have done nothing wrong," Mr. Jones said after his indictment in the Baker case.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 5 (UPI) --Rick Barry scored 37 points tonight to lead the San Francisco Warriors to a 118-117 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP)--Al Odom of Galveston, Tex., the defending champion, took a three-stroke lead today in the first round of the national left-handed golf tournament with a three-under-par 69.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 5--Thomas W. Gleason, head of the International Longshoreman's Association, is in Saigon to do some business on the waterfront--but he said today he wasn't interested in organizing South Vietnamese longshoremen.

ROSELLE, N.J., Jan. 5 (AP) --A quick-thinking 10-yearold boy saved his parents and younger brothers and sisters from possible death today when he calmly led them from their burning home.

NASHVILLE, Jan. 5 (UPI) --Although 89 per cent of the school districts in the Southern and Border region are desegregated, only 16 per cent of the area's Negro students are enrolled in schools with whites, the Southern Education Reporting Services reported today.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 5-- Oregon's Republican Secretary of State started the political ball rolling today when he announced that he would become a candidate for Governor.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 5--The columned lobby of the old Kanawha Hotel in downtown Charleston has been the scene of periodic bedlam the last 24 hours while boys have been hopefully prowling about outside.
TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Jan. 5 --Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, the host at the Indian-Pakistani conference here, met for two and a half hours tonight with Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) --The Department of Labor reported tonight that a special training program for 1,000 youths who were not accepted for enlistment in the armed services had enabled 80 per cent of them to find jobs, go back to school or qualify for military service.

The American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday for the second consecutive day in very active trading. The market rose from the start on news that the White House had found acceptable a price rise and other price revisions for structural steel by United States Steel.
MIAMI, Jan. 5 (UPI)--Gentilly Stables' Moss Vale, the winner of last year's $100,000added Hawthorne Gold Cup, scored a nose victory today in the $22,900 Orange Bowl Handicap at Tropical Park.
THIS is a wildly funny avant-garde novel with a message. The message is: "If everybody refused to sing commercials there would be no singing commercials."
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (UPI)--The Chicago Federation of Labor and Industrial Union Council, A.F.L.-C.I.O, has adopted a resolution supporting New York's transit strikers.

NEWTON, N.J., Jan. 5--John Wiederkehr of Tinkeyville Road, Andover Township, died last night at All Souls Hospital in Morristown. He was 75 years old and had retired in 1960 as vice president of Actina, Inc., an export-import firm in New York.
The executive board of the New York City Central Labor Council will meet in emergency session today to discuss the transit strike and the jailing of nine union leaders.

The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, Chicago's number one bank and eighth largest in the nation, reported yesterday that its earnings, assets, and deposits broke all records in 1965.
United States District Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo yesterday announced his retirement after 30 years on the Federal bench in Brooklyn. He is 76 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5-- The first major art ex- hibition of 1966, the Henri Matisse retrospective at the University of California, Los Angeles, is an event unlikely to be exceeded in artistic quality, power or pleasure for many years.
John J. McCloy, the diplomat, banker and adviser to presidents, was elected yesterday as chairman of E.R. Squibb Sons, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) --The Army will award 1,000 Reserve Officers Training Corps scholarships for the coming college year.
The Court of Appeals has ruled that the police do not have the authority to permit parking on private streets.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. --In the week after their brief Christmas truce, the Vietcong initiated a record number of 1,133 attack, acts of terrorism, incidents of sabotage and propaganda efforts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The five-day steel war ended abruptly today with a compromise between the Government and the steel industry.

The Aurora Corporation of Illinois, which is controlled by the Bell Intercontinental Corporation, has announced the election of Charles S. Leonard as chairman. Mr. Leonard, formerly president, succeeds Earl L. Combest, who was named vice chairman. J. Davidge Warfield was elected president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) --The Public Health Service has urged the public today not to use small plastic, waterfilled novelties made in Hong Kong that are used for cooling drinks.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 5--A third of Rhodesia's early tobacco crop has been written off by agricultural experts here as lost in the country's monthold drought.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The White House today finally produced an alibi for its hands-off attitude toward the New York transportation workers' strike that has paralyzed the economy of an interstate area, violated the laws of a state and flouted court orders.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 5--The United States today invited Secretary General Thant or any member of the United Nations to promote a peaceful settlement of the Vietnamese war.
BONN, Jan. 5--President Johnson, President de Gaulle, Pope Paul VI and other world leaders joined West Germans today in congratulating former Chancelor Konrad Adenauer on his 90th birthday.
CHICAGO--William Hansen, proprietor of Bill's Food Mart in Lake Bluff, Ill., said, "It's the only way I know for working families to get a real vacation."
HOUSTON, Jan. 5 (AP)--A Houston developer has taken an option to buy 207 acres near Houston's domed stadium for $6-million.

Francesca Roberto, a soprano from Connecticut who has sung the title role in Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" with the Metropolitan Opera National Company this season, made her debut with the parent company last night in the same role. Visually, Miss Roberto was pleasing, but vocally she was weak.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 5 --David E. Bell, administrator of the United States' Agency for International Development, said today that he expected no difficulty in winning Congressional approval for a vastly expanded program of economic aid to South Vietnam.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5 --Frederick Clarke Baggs, national senior doubles tennis champion with Dr. William Rosenbaum in 1927, 1929, 1931, 1934 and 1938, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach. His age was 83.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

A third Reform Democrat joined Council President Frank D. O'Connor's personal staff yesterday. He is William R. Ginsberg, first vice chairman of the Committee for Democratic Voters, who was named assistant to Mr. O'Connor.
The trend in the tramp shipping industry toward larger and faster vessels continued last year, an authoritative British study of the world's tramp fleet has found.
The City Council opened its new term yesterday by increasing and reorganizing its staff.

PARIS, Jan. 5 (Reuters)-- France approved today a further 10 per cent tariff cut among the six members of the European Economic Community to be effective from Jan. 1, Information Minister Alain Peyrefitte said.
The British pound rose in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.8035, up 4 points from Tuesday.

New York University, a twotime loser in the recent Holiday Festival, will attempt to revive its fortunes when it faces a strong West Virginia squad on the Madison Square Garden basketball court tonight.

FOR the John M. Clarkes of Stowe, Vt., "home for the holidays" means four children returning from schools in Canada and Boston--and a constant stream of young guests parading through the house. Their home is a rambling split-level on a 75-acre hillside farm above the village. The view across the valley is of the snow-capped peak of Mount Mansfield.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) --Two new officials were sworn in today at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
There are two major reasons to hope that the Soviet mission to Hanoi may advance the cause of negotiations on Vietnam, despite Moscow's sensitivity to Peking's charges of a "sellout."
Soybeans soared yesterday, to reach seasonal highs in some cases. Prices rose from 2 5/8 to 4 7/8 cents a bushel from the previous day bolstered by speculative buying.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 5-- Many American consumers, despite some dark clouds foreseen by experts, are optimistic enough about the economy in 1966 to consider buying a second car, according to a consumer poll taken by the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research.
THERE are many deceptive maneuvers which are routine for expert players.

TENAFLY, N.J., Jan. 5--Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence C. Kolb have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Currie Kolb, to Lieut, Robert G. Leadbitter, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley N. Leadbitter of Andover, Mass.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5--William E. Reddig, design director for the Kelvinator Company, has constructed a "Rogue's Galley" to which even the owner's girl friends may be summoned by pushbutton.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 5-- The state decided today not to prosecute four youths and two girls who were arrested in a raid on an apartment last November on charges of possession of marijuana.
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 5 (AP)--Arthur Ashe of Richmond and four other Americans advanced to the third round today in the men's singles of the West Australian tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The Geneva agreements of 1954, which both Washington and Hanoi maintain could provide the basis for peace in Vietnam, were originally designed to end French colonial rule over Indochina, and establish an independent, unified Vietnam.

The formation of a new mutual fund--to invest in United States stocks, to be sold in Europe and the Middle East and headed by Luther H. Hodges, former Secretary of Commerce -was announced at a press luncheon here yesterday.
CAIRO, Jan. 5--United States envoys have told neutralist leaders that Washington is ready to extend indefinitely the pause in the bombings of North Vietnam if Hanoi
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 5--Cornell remained undefeated in Ivy League hockey play tonight with a hard earned, 4-2, victory over Yale.
An airport bus driver who found a shaving kit on a seat in his bus turned it over to the police yesterday when he discovered that it contained $48,800 in cash and $2,500 in traveler's checks.

The City Planning Commission announced yesterday its approval of a mapping change that would add a three-acre plot to a nine-acre park on the south side of West 235th Street, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. The change must now be approved by the Board of Estimate.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 5-- Macon County Sheriff Harvey Sadler said today he had found a witness to the fatal shooting of a student civil rights leader this week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) --The light-plane crash that killed Dr. W. Randolph Lovelace 2d, United States director of space medicine, has spurred the Federal Aviation Agency toward a requirement that air taxi operators file flight plans.

The Curtis Publishing Company has notified its stockholders that on Jan. 31 it will take before Henry Shulman, a courtappointed referee, an application for dismissal of various actions brought by three stockholders.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 5-- A Monmouth County judge disclosed the names of 10 juvenile gang offenders today "because citizens should know against whom to protect themselves."
American Airlines applied yesterday to the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to connect its 44-city domestic system with Tokyo by way of Hawaii.

Sol Katz, president of the Strick Trailer division of the Fruehauf Corporation, disclosed yesterday that he was leading a group of Strick executives, who were negotiating to acquire the division from Fruehauf.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 5--City officials revealed today that what appeared to be the last big obstacle to development by New Rochelle of Fort Slocum had been eliminated.
Peter Lawford, the actor, and his wife, the former Patricia Kennedy, have agreed to a separation, their lawyer announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5-- In a telephone interview in 1963, Clifford A. Jones said that Mr. Baker had helped him and an associate, Jacob Kozloff, in their unsuccessful attempt to get franchises to conduct gambling in Caribbean hotels controlled by Pan American World Airways.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The Pentagon, has added 75 round-trip cargo flights to the Air National Guard schedule for January in order to relieve heavy military transport demands of the war in Vietnam.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5--A greater prize money total and faster play were predicted today for the 1966 golf tour. The first, event of the coast-to-coast schedule is the $70,000 Los Angeles Open that formally, starts the trek here tomorrow.

LISBON, Jan. 5--Lisbon's political police have arrested 17 Africans they believe are trying to set up a new revolutionary movement on the Portuguese islands of Sao Tome and Principe, off equatorial West Africa.
The men who repair and maintain the Transit Authority's buses are paid $3.46 an hour, while auto mechanics in the city's police, fire, public works and other departments get $4.80.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 5 (AP)--Brand Royal overhauled a 30-1 shot, Twins Orbit, in the stretch to win the first division of the Los Feliz Stakes today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 5--The Soviet authorities pressed on today with their ambitious farm relief program by announcing plans for easier bank credits and lower electric power rates.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 5, (AP)--Walter Charles Roberts, a playwright, died Monday at his home in nearby Windsor after suffering a stroke. He was 70 years old.

THE weather may have been chilly in the far northwest part of Washington recently, but it was mighty hot at a hearing when arguments started between commercial salmon and steelhead fishermen and sports fishermen over an extension of the winter commercial fishing season.
The New York Telephone Company sold yesterday $100million of bonds--the key sale of the new issue market for January--to an underwriting syndicate managed by Morgan Stanley Co.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board suspended today reduced rates for bulk Westbound shipments of parcel post that the Flying Tiger Line had proposed to introduce Jan. 20.

MILAN, Italy, Jan. 5--The death of Odoardo Dino Alfieri, Mussolini's former press and propaganda minister who was Ambassador to Berlin at the collapse of Fascism, was disclosed here today. He was 79 years old.
TORONTO. Jan. 5 (Canadian Press)--The board of governors of the Toronto Stock Exchange decided yesterday to delist shares of Seven Arts, Ltd., effective at the opening of trading Jan. 17.

PENNINGTON, N.J.,-- Jan. 5 --Dr. Jack Miscall, a consulting chemist who was former president of the rubber division of the American Chemical Society, died yesterday at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. His age was 64.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The State Department said today that the United States would make no dollar loan to the United Arab Republic to help pay for the purchase of $55million in surplus American foods.
BONN, Jan. 5--The West German Cabinet approved today a draft federal budget of $17.3-billion for 1966.
UNION CITY, N.J., Jan. 5-- Six persons were killed and seven injured today in a predawn fire that demolished adjoining three-story rooming houses here.

MALVERNE, L.I., Jan. 5-- Mr. and Mrs. William Van Rosenbergh have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Ann Van Rosenbergh, to Lieut. John Robert Myrdal, U.S.M.C. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Myrdal of Greenwich, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--Courtesy pays off, it appears-- especially when an iron business hand fits inside the velvet glove. One of the capital's most successful commercial ventures, run entirely by women for men, combines some features of a Geisha house, a data-processing center, and Grand Central Station (when the subways are not on strike).

OLD LYME, Conn., Jan. 5-- Mrs. James Madison Macdonald has announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Miss Sheila Macdonald Watson, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl Hedrick Watson of Glen Head, L.I. to Cameron Clark.
Government bonds and copper issues showed firmness yesterday in mixed trading on the London Stock Exchange.

LONDON, Jan. 5----The British Foreign Secretary, Michael Stewart, and the Defense Secretary, Denis Healey, will fly to Washington Jan. 27 for talks on Britain's review of her global defense commitments, the Foreign Office announced today.
NEWARK, Jan. 5 (AP)-- Arthur Sherod, convicted of causing the death of his wife and seven children through reckless driving, was sentenced today to three years in State Prison.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--Two young men, who until three weeks ago were the captain and chief engineer of the flagship of Cuba's merchant fleet, explained today why they and nine other Cuban officers have jumped ship over the last four months.
The crew of the freighter American Rover quelled a fire yesterday morning in the No. 5 hold as the vessel, more than 100 miles out in the Atlantic, steamed toward Newfoundland.
ALTOONA, Pa., Jan. 5 (AP) --Roy Thompson, mayor of Altoona from 1960 to 1964, died at Altoona Hospital early today. He was 75 years old.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 5-- Miss Nancy Ellen Golin and Jack Wiadro plan to be married this summer. Miss Golin's sister, Miss Jane Rosemarie Golin, and Joel Andrew Strom plan to be married the following summer.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 5 (Reuters)--The North Vietnam press agency reported today that 30,000 people had demonstrated in Cantho Province of South Vietnam in protest against the use of "toxic chemicals" by United States forces. Cantho is in the Mekong delta, 80 miles south of Saigon.
The International Shoe Company had its largest earnings since 1950 and the highest sales in its history in the fiscal year ended last Nov. 30, M.R. Chambers, president, disclosed yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 5 (AP)--Rear Adm. Ralston Smith Holmes, former Director of Naval Intelligence and commandant of the Naval Academy, died yesterday at Huntington Memorial Hospital. He was 83 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Martin Grabiner of the Bronx have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Ronnie Grabiner, to Lieut. Michael David Shankman, U.S.A.F. His parents are the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Jacob K. Shankman of New Rochelle, N.Y.

The Democratic county committeemen in Manhattan's 17th Congressional District last night selected Orin Lehman, grandnephew of the late Senator Herbert H. Lehman, as their candidate for the seat vacated by Mayor Lindsay.

ALBANY, Jan. 5--A mixture of pomp and levity flavored today's convening of the 189th session of the Legislature, but ancient opening-day ritual was severely restricted to meet the inflexible demands of television.
Intervention by President Johnson in the transit strike was urged yesterday by midtown merchants who said they despaired of local efforts to resolve the dispute.
Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery urged the city yesterday to put 30 fire hazards on the list of housing violations for which tenants could legally withhold rent until the violations were removed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The Administration is expected to throw its support this year behind efforts to increase the minimum wage, possibly to $1.50 an hour, Congressional sources say.

ROME, Jan, 5 (AP)--The Vatican published today a decree listing five conditions for Roman Catholics to receive a plenary indulgence during the church's special jubilee that runs from Jan. 1 to May 29.

MIAMI, Jan. 5 (AP)--Cassius Clay, the heavyweight champion, shrugged off the prospect that he might be reexamined for military service and said today he was thinking of only one kind of fighting-- inside the ropes.
Mayor Lindsay's administration set up a voluntary system yesterday for staggering arrival and departure hours of motorists driving into and out of Manhattan.

THE POCKET WATCH," which deals with a Jewish family in a Boston suburb in 1953, was presented last night at the Off Broadway Actors Playhouse as a "new play." The adjective is a technicality. There is no scene, no line, no phrase that is not threadbare.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) --The head of the United States medical aid program in South Vietnam said today that the war was causing more casualties to civilians than to the military because of the nature of the fighting.
The striking Transport Workers Union originally asked for an over-all money package that the Transit Authority estimated would cost $680-million over a two-year period.
"The Devils," the John Whiting drama based on Aldous Huxley's "The Devils of Loudon," will close on Saturday at the Broadway Theater after 75 performances.
Aldo T. (Buff) Donelli has been retained as head football coach at Columbia for the 1966 season.
The Bankers Trust Company reported yesterday that its net operating earnings rose 15.3 per cent last year to $39,895,000, or $4.39 a share, compared with $34,596,000, or $3.81 a share, in 1964.

WILTON, Conn., Jan. 6 Comdr. David Loughlin, U.S.N., and Mrs. Loughlin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Culberson Loughlin, to Nicholas Arthur Rawlings, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Rawlings.
The new turmoil in the Dominican Republic is the latest in a long series of political-military upheavals that have taken thousands of lives in recent years.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 6 Fairfield County Coroner Isadore L. Kotler ruled today that speed and drinking were factors in the death of an 18-yearold Greenwich youth. He was killed last Nov. 25 when the auto in which he was riding went out of control and crashed into a tree and stone wall on Riversville Road in Greenwich.
SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 6 The prosecution began arresting National Railway officials today in connection with charges of embezzlement of at least $100,000 in freight charges in the last year.
Caught between a precipitous drop in sales and high fixed rentals, some midtown shopkeepers face financial disaster or indebtedness unless the transit strike ends quickly.
It was that kind of driving day yesterday the kind of day to make a motorist want to throw his car keys into the East River and then push the car in after them.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 6 Premier Levi Eshkol put together today a broadly based coalition of secular and religious parties. He will present it to the Knesset (Parliament) Monday unless the agreement reached among party leaders is disavowed over the weekend by party councils.

LISBON, Jan. 6 The directors of the Anglo-Portuguese Company, operating the 180mile pipeline from the Mozambique coast to Rhodesia, have decided to keep the line open but to send nothing through it for the time being.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 The Soviet Union has made public a report by a commission of scientists charging that claims of farm successes of Trofim D. Lysenko, the discredited Soviet biologist, were frauds based on falsification of statistics.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 As the 1966 golf tour began today, two professionals shared the lead at 67. Dave Ragan and Steve Oppermann smashed par by four strokes in the first round of the $70,000 Los Angeles open tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--J. Edgar Hoover said today that the Communist party had played an "ever-increasing role in generating opposition to the United States position in Vietnam."
The American Stock Exchange has reported the following changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controling stockholders of listed companies.

THIS corner has watched more than one area or town go through convulsions, usually political and commercial, as it tried to save some of its undeveloped lands and marshes from exploitation and retain them for community open space and recreational uses.

FRESNO, Calif., Jan. 6 (UPI) A local Roman Catholic Bishop denounced a national Catholic leader today for having visited Delano, Calif., last month to support striking central California farm workers.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. (UPI) The Rutgers University Chapter of the American Association of University Professors today urged college teachers throughout the country to refuse jobs at St. John's University until dismissed faculty members at the strikebound school have been reinstated.
EVEN as truckloads of boats were being unloaded at the Coliseum yesterday, rumors rippled around town that the National Boat Show had been postponed.
The United States Gypsum Company, the largest domestic producer of building materials, announced yesterday the election of Edward Rembert as executive vice president.

SEATTLE, Wash., Jan. 6 (UPI) A Federal study recommended today the establishment of a North Cascade National Park, taking in 698,000 acres of some of the most inaccessible and most scenic wilderness left in the United States.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Foreign ministers of the six Common Market nations will meet in Luxembourg on Jan. 17 and 18 in an attempt to solve the crisis that has paralyzed the trade bloc for seven months, it was announced here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) President Johnson is faced with the possibility that he may have to tell a United States airline that it cannot fly passengers across the country when three foreign airlines are already doing so.
Harold Johnson, once the world light-heavyweight champion and now the toughest drummer in Pennsylvania, will meet Johnny Persol tonight in a scheduled 10-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden.

SEWANEE, Tenn., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ramsey Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Starr Elizabeth Ramsey Jr., to Lloyd Spurlock Belcher, son of Mrs. James A. Belcher of Knoxville and the late Mr. Belcher.

Joel Ellis Fisher, former president of the American Alpine Club, died of a heart attack yesterday while en route by car to a meeting of the board of directors of the Melville Shoe Corporation. He was 74 years old and lived at 1020 Fifth Avenue and Mill Neck, L.I.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 7 (AP) The Vietcong have rejected current American peace moves as "cunning and extremely repugnant," the North Vietnamese Press agency reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 United States exports are expected to grow faster and imports slower this year than last, the Commerce Department reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 Marcel Tabuteau, oboist with the Philadelphia Orchestra for nearly 40 years before he retired in 1954, died Tuesday night in Nice, France. He was 78 years old.

The engagement of Miss Donna Karyl Gordon to William Kenneth Peirez has been announced by Mrs. Karyl Halpern of Palm Beach, Fla., and Herbert Gordon of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Mr. Peirez is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Peirez of Woodside, Queens, and Great Neck, L.I.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6 Miss Caroline Elise Kerr and Ralph Decker Bennett Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Bennett of Ellicott City, Md., plan to marry here Feb. 27.
LONDON, Jan. 6 Two British psychiatrists have challenged the commonly held view that King George III, whose repressive policies led the American Colonies to rebel, was insane.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 A senior Communist trouble-shooter, Aleksandr N. Shelepin, left today by plane for Hanoi, heading a delegation of high-ranking Soviet experts on armaments, including strategic missiles.
Milady's choice of hat, dress or other fashion item has always been a mystery to most men but the inanimate computer has now been taught to follow the tortuous path of feminine logic.
The United States Trust Company of New York announced yesterday the election of Henry G. Hopper as executive vice president and a member of the management committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) Retail sales dropped 27 per cent in the week after Christmas, but were still 7 per cent higher than sales in the week last year.

RICHMOND, Jan. 6 (UPI) Union and management negotiators reachead a contract agreement here early today only hours before a transit strike would have paralyzed bus operations in Virginia's two largest cities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 A proposal that the Federal Government underwrite two-thirds of the operating deficit of the New York City Transit System and all other ailing commuter services across the nation will be submitted to Congress soon.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Jan. 6 FP 736 is slowly taking shape at the sprawling, muddy John Brown shipyard 10 miles down the River Clyde from Glasgow.
COTONOU, Dahomey, Jan. 4 Outwardly there is nothing to suggest any change in the shuffling pace of life in this humid little seaport capital.
Two New Jersey college youths charged with the fatal beating of another youth were held for grand jury action after a hearing in Staten Island Criminal Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 A team of Cornell University anthropologists reported today that the Peace Corps had its shortcomings but its successes had been "truly impressive."
The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company agreed yesterday to buy the assets of Filler Products, Inc., and the stock of related companies.

On the 12th day of Christmas, the Renaissance Quartet gave to me (and to the large audience that managed to get to the Hunter College Playhouse last night) a beautiful program of prebaroque music played to a tee.
The National Council on the Arts has named three of the five program directors who will administer its projects in five areas of the arts.
Samuel Weiss has become a member of the New York stock Exchange and has formed Samuel Weiss Co., Inc. with offices at 39 Broadway, it was announced yesterday.

Since the city's transit strike began, about one-third of the 175 men ordered to report daily for induction into the Armed Services have apparently decided they were not essential and have stayed home.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 6 (AP) The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway said today it would file a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission opposing a proposed purchase by the Santa Fe Railway of certain lines of the Rock Island Railroad.
Sparkling gains in earnings set the general tone of comments by several executives of a diversified group of companies who estimated results for 1965 in talks before financial analysts yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (UPI) Third-period goals by Parker MacDonald, Bruce MacGregor and Ron Murphy gave the Detroit Red Wings their eighth victory of the season over the Boston Bruins by a 5-3 score tonight.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 6 A lawyer testified today that he had paid $15,000 to a high Democratic official and was later successful in selling a parcel of land to Nassau County. The testimony was given in the trial of former Presiding Supervisor Palmer D. Farrington, who is charged with taking an unlawful fee of $11,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 President Johnson, in a move to keep the chief weapon in his antipoverty drive flexible and independent, has decided that the community action program will remain part of the Office of Economic Opportunity.
John W. Wolcott resigned yesterday as president of Ametek, Inc., and was replaced by Dr. John H. Lux, 47 years old. Mr. Wolcott held the presidency for less than a year and also served as a director.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 6 Mike Silliman scored 21 points today in leading Army to a 64-52 victory over Lehigh. The victory was the seventh against four losses for the cadets.

The London Stock Exchange registered small gains yesterday and closed generally below the day's top prices. Late profit taking and a slackening of demand were said to be the chief factors behind the day's performance.
ATHENS, Jan. 6 The traditional "blessing of the waters" for Epiphany in Piraeus, the port of Athens, was turned into a political demonstration today.
TORONTO, Jan. 6 Canada announced today that her foreign exchange reserves at the end of 1965 showed a slight decline from the level at the beginning of the year.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 6 South Africa is setting up racially integrated stations on the way toward full apartheid.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) James Lawrence Fly, former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, died of cancer today. He was 67 years old.

St. Francis of Brooklyn rolled to its record single-game scoring total last night as the Terriers routed Siena, 118-74, on the victors' home court. The previous record was 102, scored against Bridgeport earlier this season.
ROME, Jan. 6 Pope Paul VI called upon the faithful today to renew their prayers for peace.
SACRAMENTO, Calif. Jan. 6 (AP) Gov. Edmund G. Brown accused Ronald Reagan today of making false statements and invited him to the capitol for a briefing on state government.

FLAT ROCK, N. C., Jan. 6 (UPI. Carl Sandburg, Lincoln biographer, celebrated his 88th birthday today by reading a new book about himself, eating a rare steak and worrying more about the New York transit strike than the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) The National Council of Churches reported today that membership in United States religious bodies had reached a new high of 123,307,000, an increase of 2 per cent over the previous year.
Stone Webster, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of Peter J. Murphy Jr. as vice president of the Stone Webster Securities Corporation.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (UPI) Inga Voronina, four times world speed-skating champion, was killed by her "jealous and possessive" husband after a family argument, it was reported today. The husband, Sergei Voronin, was arrested yesterday in connection with the stabbing, but no details were disclosed.
The stock market gave a strong performance in an abbreviated session yesterday. Trading was heavy even though the closing bell rung 90 minutes early because of the transit strike.
Yield seems to carry more weight in the bond market than investment-quality rating, if this week's new issues of utility bonds are an accurate gauge.
Eagle Clothes, Inc., the apparel manufacturer and retailer, announced yesterday the election of A. Michael Victory as a director.
Two maritime unions representing seamen and licensed engineers have set up a joint program to upgrade seagoing personnel and alleviate the growing shortage of trained engineroom officers.

The Board of Education told the city's high school students yesterday that if they were unable to reach their regular schools they might attend the schools closest to their homes until the transit strike ends.
SEBRING, Fla., Jan. 6 Phyliss (Tish) Preuss of Pompano Beach, Fla., took a onestroke lead in the 10th annual Harden Hall memorial invitation golf tournament today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 6 Hungarian workers are grumbling about having to pay more for their Government's version of Communism, reports from Budapest indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Local draft boards rather than schools determine whether young men are satisfactory students and eligible for deferment, Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey emphasized in his latest policy statement.
